original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully awakened Buddha.

original: Aṅguttaranikāye
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāye
translated: In the Numerical Discourses

original: Ekakanipāta-ṭīkā
analyzed: ekaka nipāta ṭīkā
translated: Commentary on the Group of Ones

original: Ganthārambhakathā
analyzed: gantha ārambha kathā
translated: Introduction

original: Anantañāṇaṃ karuṇāniketaṃ,
analyzed: ananta ñāṇam karuṇā niketam
translated: Infinite knowledge, the abode of compassion,

original: Namāmi nāthaṃ jitapañcamāraṃ;
analyzed: namāmi nātham jita pañca māram
translated: I pay homage to the protector who has conquered the five Māras;

original: Dhammaṃ visuddhaṃ bhavanāsahetuṃ,
analyzed: dhammam visuddham bhavanāsa hetum
translated: The pure Dhamma, the cause for overcoming existence,

original: Saṅghañca seṭṭhaṃ hatasabbapāpaṃ.
analyzed: saṅghañca seṭṭham hata sabba pāpam
translated: And the supreme Saṅgha, who have destroyed all evil.

original: Kassapaṃ taṃ mahātheraṃ, saṅghassa pariṇāyakaṃ;🔽Dīpasmiṃ tambapaṇṇimhi, sāsanodayakārakaṃ.
analyzed: kassapam tam mahā theram saṅghassa pariṇāyakam  dīpasmim tamba paṇṇimhi sa āsana udaya kārakam
translated: That great elder Kassapa, the leader of the Saṅgha,🔽Who caused the rise of the Dispensation on the island of Sri Lanka.

original: Paṭipattiparādhīnaṃ, sadāraññanivāsinaṃ;
analyzed: paṭipatti para adhīnam sa dārañña nivāsinam
translated: Devoted to practice, always dwelling in the forest,

original: Pākaṭaṃ gagane canda-maṇḍalaṃ viya sāsane.
analyzed: gagane canda maṇḍalam sa āsane
translated: Clearly visible in the Dispensation, like the orb of the moon in the sky.

original: Saṅghassa pitaraṃ vande, vinaye suvisāradaṃ;
analyzed: saṅghassa pitaram vande vinaye su visāra dam
translated: I pay homage to the father of the Saṅgha, well-versed in the Vinaya,

original: Yaṃ nissāya vasantohaṃ, vuḍḍhippattosmi sāsane.
analyzed: yam nissāya vasantaḥ aham vuḍḍhippatto asmi sāsane
translated: Relying on whom, while dwelling here, I have attained growth in the Dispensation.

original: Anutheraṃ mahāpaññaṃ, sumedhaṃ sutivissutaṃ;
analyzed: anutheram mahā paññam sumedham suti vissutam
translated: The elder Mahā-Tissa, of great wisdom, well-known as Sumedha,

original: Avikhaṇḍitasīlādi-parisuddhaguṇodayaṃ.
analyzed: a vikhaṇḍita sīla ādi parisuddha guṇa udayam
translated: The rising of pure qualities, such as unshakable virtue.

original: Bahussutaṃ satimantaṃ, dantaṃ santaṃ samāhitaṃ;
analyzed: bahussutam satimantam dantam santam samāhitam
translated: Learned, mindful, restrained, peaceful, concentrated,

original: Namāmi sirasā dhīraṃ, garuṃ me gaṇavācakaṃ.
analyzed: namāmi sirasā dhīram garum me gaṇa vācakam
translated: I pay homage with my head to the wise one, whom I revere as the teacher of the Saṅgha.

original: Āgatāgamatakkesu, saddasatthanayaññusu;
analyzed: āgata āgama takkesu sadda sattha naya ñusu
translated: In the discussion of the Āgatāgama, in the discussion of the Saddasattha,

original: Yassantevāsibhikkhūsu, sāsanaṃ suppatiṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: yassa antevāsi bhikkhūsu sāsanam su patiṭṭhitam
translated: In the discussion of the Yassantevāsi, the Dispensation was well-established.

original: Yo sīhaḷindo dhitimā yasassī,
analyzed: yaḥ sīhaḷindaḥ dhitimā yasassī
translated: The wise and famous King of Siṅghala,

original: Uḷārapañño nipuṇo kalāsu;
analyzed: uḷāra paññaḥ nipuṇaḥ kalāsu
translated: Of great wisdom, skilled in the arts,

original: Jāto visuddhe ravisomavaṃse,
analyzed: jātaḥ visuddhe ravi soma vaṃse
translated: Born in the pure family of the Sun and Moon,

original: Mahabbalo abbhutavuttitejo.
analyzed: mahā balaḥ abbhuta vutti tejaḥ
translated: Of great strength, of wonderful conduct, of fiery energy.

original: Jitvārivaggaṃ atiduppasayhaṃ,
analyzed: jitvā ari vaggam ati duppasayham
translated: Having conquered the army of his enemies, so hard to conquer,

original: Anaññasādhāraṇavikkamena;
analyzed: anañña sādhāraṇa vikkamena
translated: By his unique and incomparable valour;

original: Pattābhiseko jinadhammasevī,
translated: Having received his consecration, devoted to the Dhamma of the Victorious One,

original: Abhippasanno ratanattayamhi.🔽Ciraṃ vibhinne jinasāsanasmiṃ,
analyzed: abhippasannaḥ ratanattayamhi  ciram vibhinne jina sāsanasmin
translated: Delighting in the Three Jewels.🔽For a long time the Dispensation of the Victorious One had been divided,

original: Paccatthike suṭṭhu viniggahetvā;
analyzed: paccatthike suṭṭhu viniggahetvā
translated: Having thoroughly defeated the opponents,

original: Sudhaṃva sāmaggirasaṃ pasatthaṃ,
analyzed: su dhaṃva sāma aggirasam pasattham
translated: He, like nectar, praised the sweet words of unity,

original: Pāyesi bhikkhū parisuddhasīle.
analyzed: pāyesi bhikkhū parisuddha sīle
translated: And refreshed the monks of pure virtue.

original: Katvā vihāre vipule ca ramme,
analyzed: katvā vihāre vipule ca ramme
translated: Having built many large and beautiful monasteries,

original: Tatrappitenekasahassasaṅkhe;
analyzed: tatrappitena eka sahassa saṅkhe
translated: There, with one thousand monks,

original: Bhikkhū asese catupaccayehi,
analyzed: bhikkhū asese catu paccayehi
translated: He satisfied the monks with the four requisites,

original: Santappayanto suciraṃ akhaṇḍaṃ.
analyzed: santappayantaḥ su ciram akhaṇḍam
translated: And for a long time without interruption.

original: Saddhammavuddhiṃ abhikaṅkhamāno,
analyzed: saddhamma vuddhim abhikaṅkhamānaḥ
translated: Desiring the growth of the true Dhamma,

original: Sayampi bhikkhū anusāsayitvā;🔽Niyojayaṃ ganthavipassanāsu,
analyzed: sayam pi bhikkhū anusāsayitvā  niyojayam gantha vipassanāsu
translated: Having instructed the monks himself,🔽Engaging them in texts and insight,

original: Akāsi vuddhiṃ jinasāsanassa.
analyzed: akāsi vuddhim jina sāsanassa
translated: He caused the growth of the Dispensation of the Victorious One.

original: Tenāhamaccantamanuggahīto,🔽Anaññasādhāraṇasaṅgahena;🔽Yasmā parakkantabhujavhayena,
analyzed: tena aham accantam anuggahītaḥ  anañña sādhāraṇa saṅgahena  yasmai
translated: So I am greatly favoured,🔽By the bond of affection not shared by another,🔽Since I am summoned in the midst of the community of monks

original: Ajjhesito bhikkhugaṇassa majjhe.
analyzed: ajjhesitaḥ bhikkhu gaṇassa majjhe
translated: By the power of the arm of the one who has gone beyond.

original: Tasmā anuttānapadānamatthaṃ,
analyzed: tasmai
translated: Therefore, the meaning of the unexcelled words,

original: Seṭṭhāya aṅguttaravaṇṇanāya;
analyzed: seṭṭhāya aṅguttara vaṇṇanāya
translated: For the sake of the best commentary on the Anguttara,

original: Sandassayissaṃ sakalaṃ suboddhuṃ,
analyzed: sandassayissam sakalam su boddhum
translated: I will explain the whole for easy understanding,

original: Nissāya pubbācariyappabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: nissāya pubba ācariya ppabhāvam
translated: Relying on the brilliance of the ancient teachers.

original: Ganthārambhakathāvaṇṇanā🔽1. Saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayaṃ namassitukāmo tassa visiṭṭhaguṇayogasandassanatthaṃ🔽“karuṇāsītalahadaya”ntiādimāha. Visiṭṭhaguṇayogena hi vandanārahabhāvo, vandanārahe
analyzed: gantha ārambha kathā vaṇṇanā  saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe ratanattayam namassitu kāmo tassa visiṭṭha guṇa yoga sandassana attham  āha visiṭṭha guṇa yogena hi vandanāraha bhāvaḥ vandanārahe
translated: Explanation of the Introduction to the Text

original: ca katā vandanā yathādhippetamatthaṃ sādheti. Ettha ca saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayappaṇāmakaraṇappayojanaṃ
analyzed: ca katā vandanā yathā adhippetam attham sādha iti ettha ca saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe
translated: Desiring to pay homage to the Three Jewels at the beginning of the explanation, he says Karuṇāsītalahadaya and so on in order to show their special qualities. For it is by possessing special qualities that they become worthy of homage, and homage paid to those worthy of homage accomplishes the intended purpose. Here, the teachers elaborate in many ways on the purpose of paying homage to the Three Jewels at the beginning of the explanation,

original: tattha tattha bahudhā papañcenti ācariyā, mayaṃ pana idhādhippetameva payojanaṃ dassayissāma,
analyzed: tattha tattha bahudhā papañcenti ācariyāḥ mayam pana idha adhippetam eva payojanam dassayissāma
translated: but we will show only the intended purpose here.

original: tasmā saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayappaṇāmakaraṇaṃ yathāpaṭiññātasaṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena
analyzed: tasmā saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe yathā paṭiññāta saṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena
translated: Therefore, when the teacher begins the composition, he makes the salutation to the Three Jewels in order that the composition of the commentary may be accomplished without hindrance and in accordance with the promise.

original: parisamāpanatthanti veditabbaṃ. Idameva hi payojanaṃ ācariyena idhādhippetaṃ. Tathā hi vakkhati –
analyzed: parisamāpana atthanti veditabbam idam eva hi payojanam ācariyena idha adhippetam tathā hi vakkhati
translated: This should be understood as the purpose that the teacher intends here. For he says:

original: “Iti me pasannamatino, ratanattayavandanāmayaṃ puññaṃ;
analyzed: iti me pasanna matinaḥ puññam
translated: “This merit born of saluting the Three Jewels,🔽May it be the cause of the completion of the commentary,

original: Yaṃ suvihatantarāyo, hutvā tassānubhāvenā”ti.
analyzed: yam su vihata antarāyaḥ hutvā tassa anubhāvena ati
translated: Which, having been interrupted, may be resumed.”

original: Ratanattayappaṇāmakaraṇena cettha yathāpaṭiññātasaṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpanaṃ ratanattayapūjāya paññāpāṭavato, tāya paññāpāṭavañca rāgādimalavidhamanato. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: ratanattaya ppaṇāma karaṇena ca ittha yathā paṭiññāta saṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpanam ratanattaya pūjāya paññā pāṭavato tāya paññā pāṭavam ca rāga ādi mala vidhamanataḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: Here, the completion of the commentary in accordance with the promise without hindrance through the salutation to the Three Jewels is due to the sharpness of wisdom born of the worship of the Three Jewels, and that sharpness of wisdom is due to the removal of the stains of greed, etc. For this is said:

original: “Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako tathāgataṃ anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ samaye
analyzed: yasmin mahānāma samaye ariya sāvakaḥ tathāgatam anussarati na iva assa tasmin samaye
translated: “Mahānāma, when a noble disciple recollects the Tathāgata, on that occasion🔽his mind is free from greed,

original: rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: rāga pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na dosa pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na moha pariyuṭṭhitam
translated: free from hatred, free from delusion,

original: cittaṃ hoti, ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hotī”tiādi.
analyzed: cittam hoti uju gatam eva assa tasmin samaye cittam hoti itiādi
translated: his mind is straight on that occasion.”

original: Tasmā ratanattayapūjanena vikkhālitamalāya paññāya pāṭavasiddhi.🔽Atha vā ratanattayapūjanassa paññāpadaṭṭhānasamādhihetuttā paññāpāṭavaṃ. Vuttañhi tassa samādhihetuttaṃ –🔽“Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ,🔽labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati,
analyzed: tasmai vikkhālita malāya paññāya pāṭava siddhi  atha vā ratanattaya pūjanassa paññā padaṭṭhāna samādhi hetu ttā paññā pāṭavam vuttam hi tassa samādhi hetu ttam  ujugatacittaḥ kho pana mahā nāma ariya sāvakaḥ labhati attha vedam labhati dhamma vedam  labhati dhamma upasaṃhitam pāmojjam pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati
translated: So the keenness of understanding is due to the purification of understanding by the paying of homage to the Three Gems.

original: passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyatī”ti.
analyzed: passaddha kāyaḥ sukham vediyati sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati iti
translated: Or alternatively, the keenness of understanding is due to the cause for concentration, which is a footing for understanding, being provided by the paying of homage to the Three Gems. For the cause for concentration is stated in the passage beginning thus: “When a noble disciple is thus concentrated in mind, Mahānāma, he achieves the analytical knowledges” , and ending up with: “He achieves the happiness conditioned by which the mind becomes concentrated” .

original: Samādhissa ca paññāya padaṭṭhānabhāvo vuttoyeva – “samāhito yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī”ti.
analyzed: samādhissa ca paññāya padaṭṭhāna bhāvo vuttaḥ yā iva samāhitaḥ yathābhūtam pajānāti iti
translated: And the footing for understanding of concentration has already been stated in the passage beginning thus: “When he is concentrated, Mahānāma, a noble disciple understands” , and ending up with: “He understands in accordance with actuality” .

original: Tato evaṃ paṭubhūtāya paññāya paṭiññāmahattakataṃ khedamabhibhuyya anantarāyena saṃvaṇṇanaṃ samāpayissati.
analyzed: tatas evam paṭu bhūtāya paññāya paṭiññā mahatta katam khedam abhibhuyya anantarāyena saṃvaṇṇanam samāpayissati
translated: So when understanding has become keen in this way, he will overcome the fatigue that is a hindrance to the completion of the exposition without delay.

original: Atha vā ratanattayapūjāya āyuvaṇṇasukhabalavaḍḍhanato anantarāyena parisamāpanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ratanattayappaṇāmena hi āyuvaṇṇasukhabalāni vaḍḍhanti. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: atha vā ratana taya pūjāya āyu vaṇṇa sukha bala vaḍḍhanataḥ anantarāyena parisamāpanam veditabbam ratana taya ppaṇāmena hi āyu vaṇṇa sukha balāni vaḍḍhanti vuttam ha etam
translated: Or else it should be understood that the completion of the undertaking without hindrance is due to the increase of life, beauty, happiness and strength that comes from worshipping the Three Jewels. For life, beauty, happiness and strength increase through paying homage to the Three Jewels. For this is said:🔽“For one who is of habit to pay homage,

original: “Abhivādanasīlissa, niccaṃ vuḍḍhāpacāyino;
analyzed: abhivādana sīlissa niccam vuḍḍha apacāyinaḥ
translated: Who always respects the elders,🔽Four things increase:

original: Cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti, āyu vaṇṇo sukhaṃ bala”nti. –
analyzed: cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti āyu vaṇṇo sukham
translated: Life, beauty, happiness and strength.”

original: Tato āyuvaṇṇasukhabalavuddhiyā hoteva kāriyaniṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: tatas āyu vaṇṇa sukha bala vuddhiyā hotā iva kāriya niṭṭhānam
translated: And then the completion of the undertaking is due to the increase of life, beauty, happiness and strength.

original: Atha vā ratanattayagāravassa paṭibhānāparihānāvahattā. Aparihānāvahañhi tīsupi ratanesu gāravaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: atha vā ratana ttaya gāravassa paṭibhāna a parihāna āvaha tā a parihāna āvahan hi tīsu pi ratanesu gāravam vuttam ha etam
translated: Or else it is due to the non-abandonment of the inspiration that has arisen through the honouring of the Three Jewels. For the honouring of the Three Jewels is the cause for the non-abandonment of inspiration. For this is said:

original: “Sattime, bhikkhave, aparihānīyā dhammā. Katame satta? Satthugāravatā, dhammagāravatā, saṅghagāravatā, sikkhāgāravatā, samādhigāravatā, sovacassatā, kalyāṇamittatā”ti.
analyzed: sattime bhikkhave a parihānīyāḥ dhammāḥ katame satta satthu gāravatā dhamma gāravatā saṅgha gāravatā sikkhā gāravatā samādhi gāravatā sovacassa tā kalyāṇa mitta tā ati
translated: “Monks, there are these seven things that lead to non-decline. What seven? Respect for the Teacher, respect for the Dhamma, respect for the Saṅgha, respect for the training, respect for concentration, being easy to admonish, and having good friends.”

original: Hoteva ca tato paṭibhānāparihānena yathāpaṭiññātaparisamāpanaṃ.
analyzed: hotā iva ca tatas paṭibhāna a parihānena yathā paṭiññāta parisamāpanam
translated: And then the completion of the undertaking according to the vow is due to the non-abandonment of inspiration.

original: Atha vā pasādavatthūsu pūjāya puññātisayabhāvato. Vuttañhi tassā puññātisayattaṃ –
analyzed: atha vā pasāda vatthūsu pūjāya puñña atisaya bhāvataḥ vuttam hi tassā puñña atisaya ttam
translated: Or alternatively, it is the best of merits because of the excellence of the merit in the act of worshipping in the bases for confidence. For the excellence of its merit is stated thus:🔽“When one who is worthy of worship is worshipped,

original: “Pūjārahe pūjayato, buddhe yadi va sāvake;
analyzed: pūjā rahe pūjayataḥ buddhe yadi sāvake
translated: Whether a Buddha or his disciple,🔽Who has gone beyond all worldly things,

original: Papañcasamatikkante, tiṇṇasokapariddave.
analyzed: papañca sama tikkante tiṇṇa soka pariddave
translated: And crossed over doubt and ignorance,🔽When one who is such is worshipped,

original: Te tādise pūjayato, nibbute akutobhaye;
analyzed: te tādise pūjayataḥ nibbute akutobhaye
translated: Who is extinguished, free from all fear,🔽No one can measure the merit,

original: Na sakkā puññaṃ saṅkhātuṃ, imettamapi kenacī”ti. ;
analyzed: na sakkā puññam saṅkhātum kenaci iti
translated: Even with a portion of it.”

original: Puññātisayo ca yathādhippetaparisamāpanūpāyo. Yathāha –
analyzed: puñña atisayaḥ ca yathā adhippeta parisamāpana upāyaḥ yathā āha
translated: And the excellence of merit is the means to the fulfilment of the wish as desired. As it is said:🔽“This is the treasure of gods and men,

original: “Esa devamanussānaṃ, sabbakāmadado nidhi;
analyzed: esa deva manussānam sabba kāma dadaḥ nidhi
translated: The fulfiller of all wishes;🔽Whatever they aspire to,

original: Yaṃ yadevābhipatthenti, sabbametena labbhatī”ti. ;
analyzed: yam yat eva abhipatthenti sabbam etena labbhati iti
translated: All that they obtain thereby.”

original: Upāyesu ca paṭipannassa hoteva kāriyaniṭṭhānaṃ. Ratanattayapūjā hi niratisayapuññakkhettasambuddhiyā
analyzed: upāyesu ca paṭipannassa hotā iva kāriya niṭṭhānam ratanattaya pūjā hi niratisaya puñña khetta sambuddhiyā
translated: And when one is engaged in the means, the accomplishment of the task is certain. For the worship of the Three Jewels is the supreme field of merit for the production of the unsurpassed knowledge.

original: aparimeyyappabhāvo puññātisayoti bahuvidhantarāyepi lokasannivāse antarāyanibandhanasakalasaṃkilesaviddhaṃsanāya
analyzed: aparimeyya pabhāvo puññātisayo ti bahuvidha antarāye pi loka sannivāse antarāya nibandhana sakala saṃkilesa viddhaṃsanāya
translated: The excellence of merit has immeasurable radiance. It is the destruction of all defilements, which are the cause of obstacles, in the world of obstacles.

original: pahoti, bhayādiupaddavañca nivāreti. Tasmā vuttaṃ – “saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayappaṇāmakaraṇaṃ🔽yathāpaṭiññātasaṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpanattha”nti.
analyzed: bhaya ādi upaddavam ca nivāreti tasmai vuttam saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe  yathā paṭiññāta saṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpana atthanti
translated: and he wards off the dangers of fear, etc., as well. That is why it is said: “The paying homage to the Triple Gem at the beginning of the commendation is for the purpose of warding off obstacles to the completion of the commendation as undertaken.”

original: Evañca sappayojanaṃ ratanattayavandanaṃ kattukāmo paṭhamaṃ tāva bhagavato vandanaṃ
analyzed: evam ca sa ppayojanam rata nattaya vandanam kattu kāmo paṭhamam tāva bhagavataḥ vandanam
translated: And wishing to pay homage to the Triple Gem in this way with due purpose, he first pays homage to the Blessed One,

original: kātuṃ tammūlakattā sesaratanānaṃ “karuṇāsītalahadayaṃ…pe… gativimutta”nti āha. Tattha
analyzed: kātum gati vimuttanti āha tattha
translated: saying, “Whose heart is cool with the moisture of compassion … freed from all states of woe,” for the other two Gems have their ground in him.

original: yassā desanāya saṃvaṇṇanaṃ kattukāmo, sā na vinayadesanā viya karuṇāpadhānā, nāpi🔽abhidhammadesanā viya paññāpadhānā, atha kho karuṇāpaññāpadhānāti tadubhayappadhānameva
analyzed: yassā desanāya saṃvaṇṇanam kattu kāmaḥ sā na vinaya desanā karuṇā apadhānā na api  abhidhamma desanā viya paññā apadhānā atha kho karuṇā paññā apadhānā ti tad ubhaya ppadhānam eva
translated: The teaching of the Dhamma that he wishes to commend is not a teaching of the Vinaya, which is based on compassion,🔽nor a teaching of the Abhidhamma, which is based on wisdom,🔽but a teaching of the Suttas, which is based on both compassion and wisdom.

original: tāva sammāsambuddhassa thomanaṃ kātuṃ “karuṇāsītalahadayaṃ, paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti
analyzed: tāva sammāsambuddhassa thomanam kātum karuṇā sīta lahadayam paññāpajjota vihata moha tamanti
translated: So he first pays homage to the Fully Enlightened One, who is the ground of both, saying, “Whose heart is cool with the moisture of compassion, whose darkness is dispelled by the light of wisdom.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha kiratīti karuṇā, paradukkhaṃ vikkhipati apanetīti attho. Atha vā kiṇātīti
analyzed: vuttam tattha kirati iti karuṇā para dukkham vikkhipati apaneti iti attho atha vā kiṇāti iti
translated: Herein, the Blessed One is called “compassionate” because he is the one who “compresses” , that is, dispels, the suffering of others. Or alternatively, he is “compassionate” because he is the one who “compresses” , that is, gathers together, the whole of this world’s multitude of beings with his compassion, treating them as his own children.

original: karuṇā, paradukkhe sati kāruṇikaṃ hiṃsati vibādhatīti attho. Paradukkhe sati sādhūnaṃ
analyzed: karuṇā para dukkhe sati kāruṇikam hiṃsati vibādhati iti attho para dukkhe sati sādhūnam
translated: Compassion is the wish to remove the suffering of others. The meaning is that it harms, it disturbs, those who are cruel to others. When there is suffering in others, it is good for the good.

original: kampanaṃ hadayakhedaṃ karotīti vā karuṇā. Atha vā kamiti sukhaṃ, taṃ rundhatīti karuṇā.
analyzed: kampanam hadaya khedam karoti iti vā karuṇā atha vā kam iti sukham tam rundhati iti karuṇā
translated: Compassion is the state of being compassionate, the meaning being that it hurts, it harms, another’s pain. Or alternatively, it is the state of shaking, of distressing, the hearts of the good when they see another’s pain, and so it is compassion . Or kam means pleasure, and it is the state of preventing that, thus it is compassion .

original: Esā hi paradukkhāpanayanakāmatālakkhaṇā attasukhanirapekkhatāya kāruṇikānaṃ sukhaṃ🔽rundhati vibandhatīti attho. Karuṇāya sītalaṃ karuṇāsītalaṃ, karuṇāsītalaṃ hadayaṃ
analyzed: esā hi para dukkha apanayana kāma tā lakkhaṇā atta sukha nirapekkha tāya kāruṇikānam sukham  rundhati vibandhati iti karuṇāya sītalam karuṇā sītalam karuṇā sītalam hadayam
translated: For this has the characteristic of wishing to remove another’s pain. It prevents, it obstructs, the pleasure of the compassionate, since they are disinterested in their own pleasure. That is the meaning.

original: assāti karuṇāsītalahadayo, taṃ karuṇāsītalahadayaṃ.🔽Tattha kiñcāpi paresaṃ hitopasaṃhārasukhādiaparihānicchanasabhāvatāya, byāpādāratīnaṃ
analyzed: tam karuṇā sīta lahadayam  kiñca api paresam hita upasaṃhāra sukha ādi a parihāni chana sabhāva tāya byāpāda aratīnam
translated: The heart of one who has compassion is cool with compassion, thus it is a heart cool with compassion.🔽That is the heart cool with compassion.

original: ujuvipaccanīkatāya ca sattasantānagatasantāpavicchedanākārappavattiyā mettāmuditānampi
analyzed: uju vipaccanīka tāya ca satta santāna gata santāpa vicchedana ākāra ppavattiyā
translated: Herein, although loving-kindness and gladness are also causes of coolness in the mind since they have the nature of wishing for the acquisition of welfare and pleasure, etc., in others, and since they are the direct opposites of ill will and worry,

original: cittasītalabhāvakāraṇatā upalabbhati, tathāpi dukkhāpanayanākārappavattiyā parūpatāpāsahanarasā
analyzed: citta sītala bhāva kāraṇa tā upalabbhati tathā api dukkha apanayana ākāra ppavattiyā parūpa tāpa āsahana rasā
translated: nevertheless they are not found in the aspect of removing pain, and so they are not the state of being cool with compassion.🔽The meaning of the words is this. The state of being cool with compassion is the state of being cool with compassion. He has a heart cool with compassion, thus he is one whose heart is cool with compassion.

original: avihiṃsabhūtā karuṇā visesena bhagavato cittassa cittappassaddhi viya sītibhāvanimittanti🔽vuttaṃ – “karuṇāsītalahadaya”nti. Karuṇāmukhena vā mettāmuditānampi hadayasītalabhāvakāraṇatā
analyzed: avihiṃsa bhūtā karuṇā visesena bhagavato cittassa citta ppassaddhi viya sīti bhāva nimittanti  vuttam karuṇā mukhena vā hadaya sītala bhāva kāraṇa tā
translated: Compassion, which is the state of non-violence, is the cause of the Blessed One’s mental tranquillity, like the cause of the cooling of the mind.

original: vuttāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Atha vā asādhāraṇañāṇavisesanibandhanabhūtā sātisayaṃ niravasesañca
analyzed: vuttā iti daṭṭhabbam atha vā asādhāraṇa ñāṇa visesa nibandhana bhūtā sa atisayam niravasesam ca
translated: Therefore it is said: “Whose heart is cool with compassion.” Or it should be understood that the words “Whose heart is cool with compassion” are said in order to show that loving-kindness and gladness also cause the heart to be cool through compassion.

original: sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ viya savisayabyāpitāya mahākaruṇābhāvaṃ upagatā karuṇāva bhagavato🔽atisayena hadayasītalabhāvahetūti āha – “karuṇāsītalahadaya”nti. Atha vā satipi mettāmuditānaṃ🔽sātisaye hadayasītibhāvanibandhanatte sakalabuddhaguṇavisesakāraṇatāya tāsampi kāraṇanti
analyzed: sabbaññu taññāṇam viya sa visaya byāpitāya mahā karuṇā bhāvam upagatā karuṇā ava bhagavataḥ  āha atha vā  sa atisaye sakala buddha guṇa visesa kāraṇatāya tāsam pi
translated: Or, just as the knowledge of omniscience, which is the cause of the Blessed One’s unique knowledge, is the cause of the Blessed One’s heart being cool, because it is the cause of the Blessed One’s great compassion, which pervades all objects without exception,🔽so too compassion is the cause of the Blessed One’s heart being cool. Therefore it is said: “Whose heart is cool with compassion.” Or, although loving-kindness and gladness are the cause of the Blessed One’s heart being cool, compassion is said to be the cause of the Blessed One’s heart being cool because it is the cause of all the Blessed One’s unique qualities of a Buddha.

original: karuṇāva bhagavato “hadayasītalabhāvakāraṇa”nti vuttā. Karuṇānidānā hi sabbepi buddhaguṇā.
analyzed: karuṇā ava bhagavataḥ hadaya sītala bhāva kāraṇan ti vuttā karuṇā nidānāḥ hi sabbe pi buddha guṇāḥ
translated: For all the qualities of a Buddha have compassion as their source.

original: Karuṇānubhāvanibbāpiyamānasaṃsāradukkhasantāpassa hi bhagavato paradukkhāpanayanakāmatāya
analyzed: karuṇā anubhāva nibbāpiyamāna saṃsāra dukkha santāpassa hi bhagavato para dukkha apanayana kāma tāya
translated: For the Blessed One’s mind, which is cooled of the fever of the suffering of the round of rebirths by the influence of compassion, is desirous of removing the suffering of others.

original: anekānipi asaṅkhyeyyāni kappānaṃ akilantarūpasseva niravasesabuddhakaradhammasambharaṇaniratassa🔽samadhigatadhammādhipateyyassa ca sannihitesupi sattasaṅkhārasamupanītahadayūpatāpanimittesu🔽na īsakampi cittasītibhāvassa aññathattamahosīti. Etasmiñca atthavikappe tīsupi avatthāsu
analyzed: anekāni api asaṅkhyeyyāni kappānam a kilanta rūpassa iva niravasesa buddha kara dhamma sambharaṇa niratassa  samadhigata dhamma ādhipateyyassa ca sannihitesu pi satta saṅkhāra samupanīta hadaya upatāpa nimittesu  na īsakam pi citta sīti bhāvassa aññathattam ahosi iti etasmin ca attha vikappe tīsu pi avatthāsu
translated: And for him, who, without being wearied, for many an incalculable age and more, has been gathering the requisites for Buddhahood,🔽and who has the overlordship of the Dhamma that has been attained, there is not the slightest alteration in his mind, which is not heated by the fires of the suffering of others that come within the range of his heart.

original: bhagavato karuṇā saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Pajānātīti paññā, yathāsabhāvaṃ pakārehi paṭivijjhatīti attho. Paññāva ñeyyāvaraṇappahānato
analyzed: bhagavato karuṇā saṅgahitā iti daṭṭhabbam  pajānāti iti paññā yathā sabhāvam pakārehi paṭivijjhati iti attho paññā va ñeyya āvaraṇa pahānato
translated: And in this interpretation, it should be understood that in all three instances compassion is the cause of the Blessed One’s knowledge.🔽“He knows” : paññā = paññāyati, it is discerned, by means of the specific characteristics of its function, etc.

original: pakārehi dhammasabhāvāvajotanaṭṭhena pajjototi paññāpajjoto. Savāsanappahānato visesena
analyzed: pakārehi dhamma sabhāva avajotana ṭṭhena pajjoto ti paññāpajjoto sa vāsanā pahānataḥ visesena
translated: Paññā is a light because it illuminates the specific nature of states by means of the specific characteristics.🔽It is destroyed by the light of wisdom, which is why it is called “destroyed by the light of wisdom.”

original: hataṃ samugghātitaṃ vihataṃ. Paññāpajjotena vihataṃ paññāpajjotavihataṃ, muyhanti
analyzed: hatam samugghātitam vihatam paññāpajjotena vihatam paññāpajjota vihatam muyhanti
translated: It is confused by the light of wisdom, which is why it is called “confused by the light of wisdom.”

original: tena, sayaṃ vā muyhati, mohanamattameva vā tanti moho, avijjā. Sveva visayasabhāvappaṭicchādanato🔽andhakārasarikkhatāya tamo viyāti mohatamo, paññāpajjotavihato mohatamo etassāti
analyzed: tena sayam vā muyhati mohana mattam eva vā mohaḥ avijjā svā iva visaya sabhā vappaṭicchādanato  tamaḥ viyāti moha tamo paññāpajja uta vihataḥ moha tamo etassa ati
translated: It is darkness because it is like darkness in that it conceals the real nature of its object.🔽He has dispelled the darkness of delusion with the light of wisdom: the darkness of delusion is like this because it is dispelled by the light of wisdom.

original: paññāpajjotavihatamohatamo, taṃ paññāpajjotavihatamohatamaṃ. Sabbesampi hi khīṇāsavānaṃ🔽satipi paññāpajjotena avijjandhakārassa vihatabhāve saddhādhimuttehi viya diṭṭhippattānaṃ
analyzed: tam paññāpajjota vihata mohatamam sabbesam pi hi khīṇāsavānam  sati pi paññāpajjotena avijja andhakārassa vihata bhāve saddhā adhimuttehi viya diṭṭhi ppattānam
translated: For although the darkness of ignorance is dispelled by the light of wisdom in all those who are cankers destroyed,🔽nevertheless, just as the light of the sun and moon is surpassed by the light of the jewel of the gods, so the darkness of ignorance dispelled by the light of wisdom in the disciples and the paccekabuddhas who have attained to the right view by the faith of acquiescence,

original: sāvakehi paccekasambuddhehi ca savāsanappahānena sammāsambuddhānaṃ kilesappahānassa
analyzed: sāvakehi paccekasambuddhehi ca sa vāsana ppahānena sammāsambuddhānam kilesa ppahānassa
translated: is surpassed by the darkness of ignorance dispelled by the light of wisdom in the Buddhas, who have destroyed the defilements together with their residues.

original: viseso vijjatīti sātisayena avijjāpahānena bhagavantaṃ thomento āha – “paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti.
analyzed: visesaḥ vijjati iti sa atisayena avijjā apahānena bhagavantam thomentaḥ āha
translated: Therefore, in praising the Blessed One for the destruction of his ignorance beyond that of others, he said: “He has dispelled the darkness of delusion with the light of wisdom.”

original: Atha vā antarena paropadesaṃ attano santāne accantaṃ avijjandhakāravigamassa nibbattitattā,
analyzed: atha vā antarena para upadesam attano santāne accantam avijja andhakāra vigamassa
translated: Or alternatively, he has arisen by himself in his own continuity without the intervention of another’s advice, with the destruction of the darkness of ignorance,

original: tattha ca sabbaññutāya balesu ca vasībhāvassa samadhigatattā, parasantatiyañca dhammadesanātisayānubhāvena
analyzed: tattha ca sabbaññu tāya balesu ca vasībhāvassa samadhigata ttā para santatiyam ca dhamma desanā atisaya anubhāvena
translated: And because of his omniscience, and because of his mastery of the powers, and because of the surpassing influence of his teaching of the Dhamma in the mental continuum of another,

original: sammadeva tassa pavattitattā bhagavāva visesato mohatamavigamena thometabboti āha
analyzed: sammat eva tassa pavatti tattā bhagavā ava visesataḥ moha tama vigamena thometabbaḥ iti āha
translated: the Blessed One is to be praised above all others for the removal of the darkness of delusion.

original: – “paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti. Imasmiñca atthavikappe “paññāpajjoto”ti padena
analyzed: imasmin ca attha vikappe paññāpajjota uti padena
translated: In this interpretation, the phrase “the darkness of delusion dispelled by the light of wisdom”

original: bhagavato paṭivedhapaññā viya desanāpaññāpi sāmaññaniddesena, ekasesanayena vā saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Atha vā bhagavato ñāṇassa ñeyyapariyantikattā sakalañeyyadhammasabhāvāvabodhanasamatthena🔽anāvaraṇañāṇasaṅkhātena paññāpajjotena sabbañeyyadhammasabhāvacchādakassa mohandhakārassa
analyzed: bhagavato paṭivedha paññā viya desanā paññā api sāmañña niddesena ekasesa nayena vā saṅgahitā ti daṭṭhabbam  atha vā bhagavataḥ ñāṇassa ñeyya pariyantika ttā sakala ñeyya dhamma sabhāva avabodhana samatthena  anāvaraṇa ñāṇa saṅkhātena paññāpajjotena sabba ñeyya dhamma sabhā avacchādakassa moha ndhakārassa
translated: should be understood to include the Blessed One’s wisdom of teaching as well as his wisdom of penetration, either by way of a general statement or by way of a partial statement.🔽Or else, because the Blessed One’s knowledge is bounded by the knowable, the darkness of delusion that covers the true nature of all knowable things is dispelled by the light of wisdom called unobstructed knowledge, which is capable of penetrating the true nature of all knowable things.

original: vidhamitattā anaññasādhāraṇo bhagavato mohatamavināsoti katvā vuttaṃ – “paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti.
analyzed: vidhamita ttā anañña sādhāraṇaḥ bhagavataḥ moha tama vināsaḥ ti katvā vuttam paññāpajja uta vihata moha tamanti
translated: Thus the removal of the darkness of delusion is unique to the Blessed One and is not shared by others.

original: Ettha ca mohatamavidhamanante adhigatattā anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ kāraṇopacārena sasantānamohatamavidhamanaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca moha tama vidhamana nte adhigata ttā anāvaraṇa ñāṇam kāraṇa upacārena sa santāna moha tama vidhamanam
translated: And here the knowledge of non-obstruction should be regarded as the dispelling of the darkness of delusion in one’s own continuity by way of a figurative use of the cause for the effect.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Abhinīhārasampattiyā savāsanappahānameva hi kilesānaṃ ñeyyāvaraṇappahānanti,
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam abhinīhāra sampattiyā sa vāsanā pahānam eva hi kilesānam ñeyya āvaraṇa ppahānam ti
translated: For the abandoning of defilements together with their traces is the abandoning of the hindrance of the knowable.

original: parasantāne pana mohatamavidhamanassa kāraṇabhāvato anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ “mohatamavidhamana”nti vuccatīti.🔽Kiṃ pana kāraṇaṃ avijjāsamugghātoyeveko pahānasampattivasena bhagavato thomanānimittaṃ
analyzed: para santāne pana mohatama vidhamanassa kāraṇa bhāvato anāvaraṇa ñāṇam mohatama vidhamananti vuccati iti  kim pana kāraṇam pahāna sampatti vasena bhagavataḥ thomanā nimittam
translated: But the knowledge of non-obstruction is called the dispelling of the darkness of delusion in the continuity of another because it is the cause for the dispelling of the darkness of delusion in another’s continuity.

original: gayhati, na pana sātisayaniravasesakilesappahānanti? Tappahānavacaneneva tadekaṭṭhatāya
analyzed: gayhati na pana sa atisaya niravasesa kilesa pahānan ti tad pahāna vacanena iva tad ekaṭṭhatāya
translated: But why does the Blessed One take up the destruction of the darkness of delusion as the sign of his thundering only in the sense of the perfection of abandoning, and not in the sense of the complete and utter abandoning of defilements?🔽Because by the statement of the abandoning of that , the destruction of the entire mass of defilements is stated, since that is the one thing .

original: sakalasaṃkilesagaṇasamugghātassa vuttattā. Na hi so tādiso kileso atthi, yo niravasesaavijjāpahānena na pahīyatīti.
analyzed: sakala saṃkilesa gaṇa samugghātassa vutta ttā na hi so tādisaḥ kileso atthi yaḥ niravasesa avijjā pahānena na pahīyati iti
translated: For there is no such defilement that is not destroyed by the complete and utter abandoning of ignorance.

original: Atha vā vijjā viya sakalakusaladhammasamuppattiyā, niravasesākusaladhammanibbattiyā
analyzed: atha vā vijjā viya sakala kusala dhamma samuppattiyā niravasesa akusala dhamma nibbattiyā
translated: Or else, just as knowledge is the cause for the arising of all wholesome states and for the production of all unwholesome states,

original: saṃsārappavattiyā ca avijjā padhānakāraṇanti tabbighātavacanena sakalasaṃkilesagaṇasamugghāto
analyzed: saṃsāra ppavattiyā ca avijjā padhāna kāraṇan ti tad bighāta vacanena sakala saṃkilesa gaṇa samugghātaḥ
translated: And ignorance is the principal cause of the occurrence of the round of rebirths. So by the words “the darkness of delusion dispelled by the light of wisdom” the entire mass of defilements is also included.

original: vutto eva hotīti vuttaṃ – “paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti.
analyzed: vuttaḥ eva hoti iti vuttam
translated: That is why it is said that the words “the darkness of delusion dispelled by the light of wisdom” are said.🔽“Gods and men” are “gods-and-men” . The world is “gods-and-men” and the world of beings .

original: Narā ca amarā ca narāmarā, saha narāmarehīti sanarāmaro, sanarāmaro ca so loko cāti🔽sanarāmaraloko, tassa garūti sanarāmaralokagaru, taṃ sanarāmaralokagaruṃ. Etena devamanussānaṃ
analyzed: narā ca amarā ca nara amarā saha nara amara ihi iti sa nara amaraḥ sa nara amaraḥ ca saḥ lokaḥ ca ati  sa nara amara lokaḥ tassa garu uti sa nara amara loka garu tam sa nara amara loka garum etena deva manussānam
translated: He is “honoured in the world of gods-and-men” .

original: viya tadavasiṭṭhasattānampi yathārahaṃ guṇavisesāvahatāya bhagavato upakārataṃ dasseti.
analyzed: viya tad avasiṭṭha sattānam pi yathāraham guṇa visesa āvahatāya bhagavataḥ upakāra tam dasseti
translated: By this he shows that the Blessed One is a benefactor to all beings, not only to gods and men, but also to the rest, in accordance with their ability, by the special qualities he has aroused in them.

original: Na cettha padhānappadhānabhāvo codetabbo. Añño hi saddakkamo, añño atthakkamo. Īdisesu
analyzed: na ca ittha padhāna ppadhāna bhāvaḥ codetabbaḥ aññaḥ hi sadda kkamaḥ aññaḥ attha kkamaḥ īdisesu
translated: And here the fact that the word “world” is in the locative case should not be disputed. For there is one sequence of terms according to the order of the words and another according to the order of the meaning.

original: hi samāsapadesu padhānampi appadhānaṃ viya niddisīyati yathā “sarājikāya parisāyā”ti.
analyzed: hi samāsa padesu padhānam pi appadhānam viya niddisīyati yathā sa rājikāya parisāya ati
translated: For in such compounds as this the principal term is exhibited as if it were subordinate, as in the phrase “the whole city of Rājagaha” .

original: Kāmañcettha sattasaṅkhārabhājanavasena tividho loko, garubhāvassa pana adhippetattā
analyzed: kāmam ca ittha satta saṅkhāra bhājana vasena tividhaḥ lokaḥ garu bhāvassa pana adhippeta ttā
translated: Herein, although the world is threefold as consisting of beings, aggregates, and elements, and as consisting of the physical basis, the sense-bases, and the world of natural law, still it is the world of beings that is intended here.

original: garukaraṇasamatthasseva yujjanato sattalokassa vasena attho gahetabbo. So hi lokīyanti
analyzed: garu karaṇa samatthassa iva satta lokassa vasena atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ saḥ hi lokīyanti
translated: for it is only a person who is capable of doing what is weighty who is to be taken as the meaning of the word “world” in the sense of the living world.🔽For that is called “world” in the sense of “it is gone ,”

original: ettha puññapāpāni tabbipāko cāti “loko”ti vuccati. Amaraggahaṇena cettha upapattidevā adhippetā.
analyzed: ettha puñña pāpāni tad vipāko ca ati loko ti vuccati amara ggahaṇena ca ittha upapatti devāḥ adhippetā
translated: and here it is gone in the sense of merit and demerit and their result. And by the word “gods” here the gods of the happy destiny are intended.🔽Or alternatively, the word “world” has the meaning of “collection” in the sense of “it is gone together ,” that is to say, it is gone together with the aggregates, elements, and sense bases.

original: Atha vā samūhattho lokasaddo samudāyavasena lokīyati paññāpīyatīti. Saha narehīti
analyzed: atha vā samūha atthaḥ loka saddo samudāya vasena lokīyati paññāpīyati iti saha narehi iti
translated: With men,🔽with gods,🔽with the world of men and gods,

original: sanarā, sanarā ca te amarā cāti sanarāmarā, tesaṃ lokoti sanarāmaralokoti purimanayeneva
analyzed: sa narā sa narā ca te amarā ca ati sa nara amarā tesam loka uti sa nara amara loka uti purima nayena iva
translated: with the world of gods and men.

original: yojetabbaṃ. Amarasaddena cettha visuddhidevāpi saṅgayhanti. Tepi hi maraṇābhāvato
analyzed: yojetabbam amara saddena ca ittha visuddhi devā api saṅgayhanti te pi hi maraṇa abhāvato
translated: And here the word “gods” includes the gods of purification too, for they are also immortal in the ultimate sense because they are devoid of death.

original: paramatthato amarā. Narāmarānaṃyeva ca gahaṇaṃ ukkaṭṭhaniddesavasena yathā “satthā
analyzed: paramatthataḥ amarāḥ ca gahaṇam ukkaṭṭha niddesa vasena yathā satthā
translated: And the inclusion of only men and gods is by way of what is outstanding, as in the passage, “The Master, friends, is a god, a Brahmā” .

original: devamanussāna”nti. Tathā hi sabbānatthapariharaṇapubbaṅgamāya niravasesahitasukhavidhānatapparāya
analyzed: deva manussānam ti tathā hi sabba anattha pariharaṇa pubbaṅgamāya niravasesa hita sukha vidhāna tapparāya
translated: For it is said that the Master is a god, a Brahmā, in the sense that he has gone to the further shore of all disadvantage and has gone to the further shore of all suffering by providing the incomparable help of happiness.

original: niratisayāya payogasampattiyā sadevamanussāya pajāya accantūpakāritāya aparimitanirupamappabhāvaguṇavisesasamaṅgitāya
analyzed: niratisayāya payoga sampattiyā sa deva manussāya pajāya accantu upakāri tāya aparimita nirupama ppabhāva guṇa visesa samaṅgi tāya
translated: He is the most excellent of all beings because of the excellence of his practice, which is unsurpassed, and because of his extreme helpfulness to the world of men and gods, and because of his possession of the special qualities of immeasurable and incomparable glory.

original: ca sabbasattuttamo bhagavā aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ uttamagāravaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: ca sabba sattuttamaḥ bhagavā aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānam sattānam uttama gārava ṭhānam
translated: The Blessed One is the most excellent of all beings in immeasurable world systems and the object of the highest reverence for immeasurable beings.

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “sanarāmaralokagaru”nti.
analyzed: tena vuttam sa nara amara loka garun ti
translated: Therefore it is said that he is “honored by gods and men.”

original: Sobhanaṃ gataṃ gamanaṃ etassāti sugato. Bhagavato hi veneyyajanūpasaṅkamanaṃ ekantena
analyzed: sobhanam gatam gamanam etassa ati sugataḥ bhagavataḥ hi veneyya janūpasaṅkamanam ekantena
translated: He is called “well-gone” because he has gone well. The Blessed One’s approach to those who are to be trained is entirely

original: tesaṃ hitasukhanipphādanato sobhanaṃ, tathā lakkhaṇānubyañjanappaṭimaṇḍitarūpakāyatāya
analyzed: tesam hita sukha nipphādanato sobhanam tathā lakkhaṇa anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍita rūpa kāya tāya
translated: beautiful because it produces their welfare and happiness. Likewise, his bodily approach is beautiful because it is adorned with the major and minor characteristics of a great man.

original: dutavilambitakhalitānukaḍḍhananippīḷanukkuṭikakuṭilākuṭilatādi- dosarahitamavahasitarājahaṃsavasabhavāraṇamigarājagamanaṃ
analyzed: duta vilambita khalita anukaḍḍhana nippīḍa nukkuṭika kuṭila akuṭila tā ādi dosa rahitam avahasita rājahaṃsa vasabha vāraṇa miga rāja gamanam
translated: His bodily approach is free from the faults of being too slow, too fast, unsteady, dragging, oppressive, stooping, crooked, or twisted, etc., and is like the approach of a royal swan, a bull, or a lion.

original: kāyagamanaṃ ñāṇagamanañca vipulanimmalakaruṇāsativīriyādiguṇavisesasahitamabhinīhārato
analyzed: kāya gamanam ñāṇa gamanam ca vipula nimmala karuṇā sati vīriya ādi guṇa visesa sahitam abhinīhārato
translated: His bodily approach and his approach of knowledge, accompanied by the special qualities of vast, stainless, compassionate, mindful, energetic, etc., are undertaken by him.

original: yāva mahābodhi anavajjatāya sobhanamevāti. Atha vā sayambhuñāṇena sakalampi lokaṃ
analyzed: yāva mahā bodhi anavajja tāya sobhanam eva ati atha vā sayambhu ñāṇena lokam
translated: and the Great Enlightenment Tree is lovely because of its blamelessness.

original: pariññābhisamayavasena parijānanto ñāṇena sammā gato avagatoti sugato, tathā lokasamudayaṃ🔽pahānābhisamayavasena pajahanto anuppattidhammataṃ āpādento sammā gato atītoti sugato,🔽lokanirodhaṃ nibbānaṃ sacchikiriyābhisamayavasena sammā gato adhigatoti sugato, lokanirodhagāminipaṭipadaṃ
analyzed: pariññā abhisamaya vasena parijānantaḥ ñāṇena sammā gataḥ avagataḥ iti sugataḥ tathā loka samudayam  pahāna abhisamaya vasena pajahantaḥ anuppatti dhamma tam āpādentaḥ sammā gataḥ atītaḥ iti sugato  loka nirodham nibbānam sacchikiriyā abhisamaya vasena sammā gataḥ adhigataḥ iti sugataḥ loka nirodha gāmini paṭipadam
translated: Or else, he is “well-gone” in the sense that he has “gone” by means of his self-begotten knowledge, that is, he has “gone” and “reached” the whole world by fully understanding it by means of the penetration of understanding ;🔽and he is “well-gone” in the sense that he has “gone” and “transcended” by abandoning the world’s origin by means of the penetration of abandoning , and so he has “gone” and “reached” the state of non-arising ;🔽and he is “well-gone” in the sense that he has “gone” and “attained” the world’s cessation, Nibbāna, by means of the penetration of realization ;

original: bhāvanābhisamayavasena sammā gato paṭipannoti sugato. “Sotāpattimaggena ye kilesā
analyzed: bhāvanā abhisamaya vasena sammā gataḥ paṭipanno ti sugataḥ sa utāpatti maggena ye kilesāḥ
translated: and he is “well-gone” in the sense that he has “gone” and “entered upon” the way leading to the cessation of the world by means of the penetration of development .

original: pahīnā, te kilese na puneti na pacceti na paccāgacchatīti sugato”tiādinā nayena ayamattho
analyzed: pahīnā te kilese na puneti na pacceti na paccāgacchati iti sugataḥ iti ādinā nayena ayam attho
translated: Or else, this meaning should be illustrated in this way: he is “well-gone” in the sense that he does not again and again return to, does not revert to, does not come back to, those defilements that have been abandoned by the path of stream-entry.

original: vibhāvetabbo. Atha vā sundaraṃ ṭhānaṃ sammāsambodhiṃ, nibbānameva vā gato adhigatoti
analyzed: vibhāvetabbaḥ atha vā sundaram ṭhānam sammāsambodhim nibbānam eva vā gataḥ adhigataḥ ti
translated: Or else, he is “well-gone” in the sense that he has “gone” and “reached” the place that is beautiful, that is, the supreme enlightenment, or Nibbāna.

original: sugato, yasmā vā bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ veneyyānaṃ yathārahaṃ kālayuttameva
analyzed: sugataḥ yasmai vā bhūtam tat śam attha saṃhitam veneyyānam yathāraham kāla yuttam eva
translated: He is Sugata because He speaks rightly, since He speaks Dhamma to disciples in a way suitable to their needs, at the appropriate time, and in accordance with what is factual, true, and beneficial.

original: ca dhammaṃ bhāsati, tasmā sammā gadatīti sugato, da-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā. Iti sobhanagamanatādīhi
analyzed: ca dhammam bhāsati tasmai sammā gadati iti sugataḥ dakārassa takāram katvā iti sobhana gamana tā ādīhi
translated: The syllable da- of the word sugata is changed to ta-. Thus He is Sugata because of His good going, good practice, good path, good conduct, good proclamation, and good speech.

original: sugato, taṃ sugataṃ.🔽Puññapāpakammehi upapajjanavasena gantabbato gatiyo, upapattibhavavisesā. Tā pana
analyzed: sugataḥ tam sugatam  puñña pāpa kammehi upapajjana vasena gantabbataḥ gatiyaḥ upapatti bhava visesā tāḥ pana
translated: He is Sugata because of these good goings, etc.

original: nirayādivasena pañcavidhā. Tāhi sakalassapi bhavagāmikammassa ariyamaggādhigamena🔽avipākārahabhāvakaraṇena nivattitattā bhagavā pañcahipi gatīhi suṭṭhu mutto visaṃyuttoti
analyzed: niraya ādi vasena pañcavidhā tāhi sakalassa api bhava gāmi kammassa ariya magga adhigamena  a vipāka araha bhāva karaṇena bhagavā pañcahi api gatīhi suṭṭhu muttaḥ visaṃyuttaḥ ti
translated: The destinies are the different kinds of rebirth that one goes to by means of profitable and unprofitable kamma. They are of five kinds as hell, etc.,🔽and by the Blessed One’s attainment of the noble path and his making unprofitable kamma incapable of result, he has turned away from all kamma that leads to existence.🔽So he is “released from the five destinations” , that is, well released, well detached from them.

original: āha – “gativimutta”nti. Etena bhagavato katthacipi gatiyā apariyāpannataṃ dasseti,
analyzed: āha gati vimuttam ti etena bhagavataḥ katthacipi gatiyāḥ a pariyāpanna tam dasseti
translated: This shows that the Blessed One is not included in any destination at all,🔽and that is why he is called “the deva above the devas” .

original: yato bhagavā “devātidevo”ti vuccati. Tenevāha –
analyzed: yatas bhagavā devātidevaḥ iti vuccati tena iva āha
translated: Hence it is said:🔽“By which I might be reborn a deva,

original: “Yena devūpapatyassa, gandhabbo vā vihaṅgamo;
analyzed: yena deva upapatyassa gandhabbaḥ vā vihaṅgamaḥ
translated: Or a gandhabbaja in the sky,

original: Yakkhattaṃ yena gaccheyyaṃ, manussattañca abbaje;
analyzed: yakkhattam yena gaccheyyam manussattam ca abbaje
translated: Or a yakkha, or a man,

original: Te mayhaṃ āsavā khīṇā, viddhastā vinaḷīkatā”ti. ;🔽Taṃtaṃgatisaṃvattanikānañhi kammakilesānaṃ aggamaggena bodhimūleyeva suppahīnattā
analyzed: te mayham āsavā khīṇāḥ vid hastāḥ vinaḷīka tā ati  taṃ taṃ gati saṃvattanikānaṃ hi kamma kilesānam aggamaggena bodhi mūleya iva su ppahīna ttā
translated: for me, the cankers are destroyed, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so that they are no longer subject to future arising.🔽For the Blessed One, at the foot of the Bodhi Tree, by the path of penetrating the noble truths, had well destroyed the kamma-formations and defilements that lead to the various destinies,

original: natthi bhagavato gatipariyāpannatāti accantameva bhagavā sabbabhavayonigativiññāṇaṭṭhitisattāvāsasattanikāyehi
analyzed: natthi bhagavataḥ gati pariyāpanna tā ti accantam eva bhagavā sabba bhava yoni gati viññāṇa ṭṭhiti sattāvāsa satta nikāyehi
translated: and so he is utterly liberated from all the realms of existence, wombs, destinies, consciousness, stations of consciousness, abodes of beings, and groups of beings.

original: suparimutto, taṃ gativimuttaṃ. Vandeti namāmi, thomemīti vā attho.
analyzed: su parimuttaḥ tam gati vimuttam vandeti namāmi thomemi iti vā attho
translated: He is liberated from the destinies. The meaning is: I praise, I revere, I worship him.

original: Atha vā gativimuttanti anupādisesanibbānadhātuppattiyā bhagavantaṃ thometi. Ettha
analyzed: atha vā gati vimuttam ti anupādisesa nibbāna dhātu pattiyā bhagavantam thometi ettha
translated: Or else, by saying “liberated from the destinies,” he praises the Blessed One for his attainment of the destruction of the taints, the state of peace.

original: hi dvīhi ākārehi bhagavato thomanā veditabbā attahitasampattito parahitappaṭipattito
analyzed: hi dvīhi ākārehi bhagavataḥ thomanā veditabbā atta hita sampattitaḥ para hita paṭipattitaḥ
translated: Herein, the praise of the Blessed One should be understood in two ways: in terms of the perfection of his own welfare and in terms of his undertaking for the welfare of others.

original: ca. Tesu attahitasampatti anāvaraṇañāṇādhigamato savāsanānaṃ sabbesaṃ kilesānaṃ accantappahānato
analyzed: ca tesu atta hita sampatti anāvaraṇa ñāṇa adhigamataḥ sa vāsanānam sabbesam kilesānam accanta ppahānato
translated: Among them, the perfection of his own welfare should be understood in terms of the attainment of unobstructed knowledge, the utter destruction of all defilements together with their traces, and the attainment of the destruction of the taints that is without residue of attachment.

original: anupādisesanibbānappattito ca veditabbā, parahitappaṭipatti lābhasakkārādinirapekkhacittassa
analyzed: an upādisesa nibbāna ppattitaḥ ca veditabbā para hita ppaṭipatti lābha sakkāra ādi nirapekkha cittassa
translated: His undertaking for the welfare of others should be understood in terms of his mind’s freedom from concern for gain, honour, and fame,

original: sabbadukkhaniyyānikadhammadesanato viruddhesupi niccaṃ hitajjhāsayato ñāṇaparipākakālāgamanato
analyzed: sabba dukkha niyyānika dhamma desanataḥ viruddhesu pi niccam hita jjhāsayataḥ ñāṇa paripāka kāla āgamanataḥ
translated: And because he is the one who teaches the Dhamma that leads out of all suffering, and because he is the one who is always well disposed even towards his enemies, and because he is the one who has reached the time of the ripening of his knowledge.

original: ca. Sā panettha āsayato payogato ca duvidhā, parahitappaṭipatti tividhā ca, attahitasampatti
analyzed: ca sā pana ittha āsayataḥ payogataḥ ca duvidhā para hita paṭipatti tividhā ca atta hita sampatti
translated: And this is twofold as disposition and as practice, and threefold as the practice of benefiting others and as the manifestation of the fulfilment of one’s own welfare.

original: pakāsitā hoti. Kathaṃ? “Karuṇāsītalahadaya”nti etena āsayato parahitappaṭipatti,
analyzed: pakāsitā hoti katham etena āsayato para hita paṭipatti
translated: How so? By the words “Whose heart is cool with compassion” he shows the practice of benefiting others as disposition;

original: sammāgadanatthena sugatasaddena payogato parahitappaṭipatti, “paññāpajjotavihatamohatamaṃ
analyzed: sammā gadana tthena sugata saddena payogataḥ para hita ppaṭipatti
translated: by the word “Sugata” in the sense of “one who goes rightly” he shows the practice of benefiting others as practice;

original: gativimutta”nti etehi catusaccasampaṭivedhanatthena ca sugatasaddena tividhāpi attahitasampatti,
analyzed: gati vimuttan ti etehi catu sacca sampaṭivedhana atthena ca sugata saddena tividhā api atta hita sampatti
translated: by the word “Sugata” in the sense of “one who has known the four truths” he shows the fulfilment of one’s own welfare as threefold;

original: avasiṭṭhena “paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti etena cāpi attahitasampatti parahitappaṭipatti pakāsitā hotīti.
analyzed: avasiṭṭhena etena ca api atta hita sampatti para hita paṭipatti pakāsitā hoti iti
translated: and by the remaining words “Whose darkness is dispelled by the light of wisdom” he shows the fulfilment of one’s own welfare and the practice of benefiting others.🔽Or alternatively, the Blessed One’s greatness should be understood in three ways, that is, as cause, fruit, and service.

original: Atha vā tīhi ākārehi bhagavato thomanā veditabbā hetuto, phalato, upakārato ca. Tattha
analyzed: atha vā tīhi ākārehi bhagavataḥ thomanā veditabbā hetutaḥ phalataḥ upakārato ca tattha
translated: Herein,

original: hetu mahākaruṇā, sā paṭhamapadena dassitā. Phalaṃ catubbidhaṃ ñāṇasampadā, pahānasampadā,🔽ānubhāvasampadā, rūpakāyasampadā cāti. Tāsu ñāṇappahānasampadā dutiyapadena saccappaṭivedhanatthena
analyzed: hetu mahākaruṇā sā paṭhama padena dassitā phalam catubbidham ñāṇa sampadā pahāna sampadā  ānubhāva sampadā rūpa kāya sampadā ca ati tāsu ñāṇa ppahāna sampadā dutiya padena sacca ppaṭivedhana tthena
translated: The cause is the Great Compassion, which is shown by the first word. The fruit is fourfold: the perfection of knowledge, the perfection of abandonment,🔽the perfection of influence, and the perfection of the form-body. Of these, the perfection of knowledge and the perfection of abandonment are shown by the word “well-farer” in the sense of penetrating the truths,

original: ca sugatasaddena pakāsitā honti, ānubhāvasampadā tatiyapadena, rūpakāyasampadā yathāvuttakāyagamanasobhanatthena🔽sugatasaddena lakkhaṇānubyañjanapāripūriyā vinā tadabhāvato. Upakāro anantaraṃ abāhiraṃ
analyzed: ca sugata saddena pakāsitāḥ honti ānubhāva sampadā tatiya padena rūpa kāya sampadā yathā vutta kāya gamana sobhana tthena  sugata saddena lakkhaṇa anubyañjana pāripūriyā vinā tad abhāvataḥ upakāraḥ anantaram abāhiram
translated: the perfection of influence is shown by the second word, and the perfection of the form-body is shown by the word “well-farer” in the sense of the beauty of the going of the body,

original: karitvā tividhayānamukhena vimuttidhammadesanā. So sammāgadanatthena sugatasaddena
analyzed: karitvā tividha yāna mukhena vimutti dhamma desanā saḥ sammā gadana tthena sugata saddena
translated: because without the fulfilment of the major and minor characteristics there is no such going. The benefit is the teaching of the Dhamma of deliverance by way of the three vehicles, which is not external to the cause and fruit. That is shown by the word “well-farer” in the sense of right guidance,

original: pakāsito hotīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pakāsitaḥ hoti iti veditabbam
translated: it should be understood.

original: Tattha “karuṇāsītalahadaya”nti etena sammāsambodhiyā mūlaṃ dasseti. Mahākaruṇāsañcoditamānaso
analyzed: tattha etena sammāsambodhiyā mūlam dasseti mahā karuṇā sañcodita mānasaḥ
translated: Herein, by “heart-cooled with compassion” he shows the root of the supreme enlightenment. For the Blessed One, whose mind was urged on by great compassion,

original: hi bhagavā saṃsārapaṅkato sattānaṃ samuddharaṇatthaṃ katābhinīhāro anupubbena pāramiyo
analyzed: hi bhagavā saṃsāra paṅkataḥ sattānam samuddharaṇa attham kata abhinīhāraḥ anupubbena pāramiyaḥ
translated: having made his aspiration for the purpose of rescuing beings from the mire of saṃsāra, gradually fulfilled the pāramīs,

original: pūretvā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ adhigatoti karuṇā sammāsambodhiyā mūlaṃ. “Paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti
analyzed: pūretvā anuttaram sammāsambodhim adhigataḥ iti karuṇā sammāsambodhiyāḥ mūlam
translated: and having fulfilled it, he has attained supreme enlightenment. So compassion is the root of supreme enlightenment.🔽By the words “the darkness of delusion dispelled by the light of understanding”

original: etena sammāsambodhiṃ dasseti. Anāvaraṇañāṇapadaṭṭhānañhi maggañāṇaṃ, maggañāṇapadaṭṭhānañca
analyzed: etena sammāsambodhim dasseti anāvaraṇa ñāṇa padaṭṭhānam hi magga ñāṇam magga ñāṇa padaṭṭhānam ca
translated: he shows supreme enlightenment. For path knowledge has unobstructed knowledge as its proximate cause, and unobstructed knowledge has path knowledge as its proximate cause.🔽This is called “supreme enlightenment.”

original: anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ “sammāsambodhī”ti vuccatīti. Sammāgamanatthena sugatasaddena sammāsambodhiyā
analyzed: anāvaraṇa ñāṇam sammāsambodhī iti vuccati iti sammāgamana atthena sugata saddena sammāsambodhiyā
translated: By the word “well-farer” he shows the practice for supreme enlightenment,

original: paṭipattiṃ dasseti līnuddhaccapatiṭṭhānāyūhanakāmasukhallikattakilamathānuyogasassatucchedābhinivesādiantadvayarahitāya🔽karuṇāpaññāpariggahitāya majjhimāya paṭipattiyā pakāsanato sugatasaddassa. Itarehi
analyzed: paṭipattim dasseti  karuṇā paññā pariggahitāya majjhimāya paṭipattiyā pakāsanato sugata saddassa itarehi
translated: which is the middle practice free from the two extremes of indulgence in sensual pleasure and self-mortification, and so on, and free from the two assumptions of eternalism and annihilationism,🔽because it is the proclamation of that middle practice which is embraced by compassion and understanding.🔽By the other two words he shows the practice for supreme enlightenment as the practice of striving and the practice of striving in the right way.

original: sammāsambodhiyā padhānappadhānabhedaṃ payojanaṃ dasseti. Saṃsāramahoghato sattasantāraṇañhettha
analyzed: sammāsambodhiyā padhāna ppadhāna bhedam payojanam dasseti saṃsāra mahoghato satta santāraṇam ha ittha
translated: For the practice of striving here is the deliverance of beings from the great flood of the round of rebirths,

original: padhānaṃ payojanaṃ, tadaññamappadhānaṃ. Tesu padhānena parahitappaṭipattiṃ dasseti,
analyzed: padhānam payojanam tad aññam appadhānam tesu padhānena para hita paṭipattim dasseti
translated: and the practice of striving in the right way is the other practice. Of these, by the practice of striving he shows the practice for the benefit of others,

original: itarena attahitasampattiṃ. Tadubhayena attahitāya paṭipannādīsu catūsu puggalesu
analyzed: itarena atta hita sampattim tad ubhayena atta hitāya paṭipanna ādīsu catūsu puggalesu
translated: and by the other, his own welfare. And by both he shows the four kinds of persons who have set out for their own welfare,

original: bhagavato catutthapuggalabhāvaṃ dasseti. Tena ca anuttaradakkhiṇeyyabhāvaṃ uttamavandaneyyabhāvaṃ
analyzed: bhagavato catuttha puggala bhāvam dasseti tena ca anuttara dakkhiṇeyya bhāvam uttama vandaneyya bhāvam
translated: and he shows that the Blessed One is the fourth kind of person. And thereby he shows that he is worthy of the highest offering, worthy of the highest welcome,

original: attano ca vandanakiriyāya khettaṅgatabhāvaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: attano ca vandana kiriyāya khettaṅgata bhāvam dasseti
translated: and that he is a field of merit not shared by others.

original: Ettha ca karuṇāgahaṇena lokiyesu mahaggatabhāvappattāsādhāraṇaguṇadīpanato bhagavato
analyzed: ettha ca karuṇā gahaṇena lokiyesu mahaggata bhāva ppatta asādhāraṇa guṇa dīpanataḥ bhagavataḥ
translated: And here the Blessed One’s possession of compassion shows his excellence in all mundane special qualities, since it is a quality not shared by others and is the cause for his attaining the exalted state of being a great man.

original: sabbalokiyaguṇasampatti dassitā hoti, paññāgahaṇena sabbaññutaññāṇapadaṭṭhānamaggañāṇadīpanato
analyzed: sabba lokiya guṇa sampatti dassitā hoti paññā gahaṇena sabbaññuta ññāṇa padaṭṭhāna magga ñāṇa dīpanato
translated: And his possession of understanding shows his excellence in all supramundane special qualities, since it is the cause for his knowledge of the path that has the knowledge of omniscience as its fruit.

original: sabbalokuttaraguṇasampatti. Tadubhayaggahaṇasiddho hi attho “sanarāmaralokagaru”ntiādinā
analyzed: tad ubhaya ggahaṇa siddhaḥ hi atthaḥ sa nara amara loka garunti ādinā
translated: The meaning established by the mention of both is elaborated in the passage beginning, “Honoured of men and gods” .

original: papañcīyatīti. Karuṇāgahaṇena ca upagamanaṃ nirupakkilesaṃ dasseti, paññāgahaṇena
analyzed: papañcīyati iti karuṇā gahaṇena ca upagamanam nirupakkilesam dasseti paññā gahaṇena
translated: And by the mention of compassion he shows that his approach is free from defilements, and by the mention of understanding he shows that his departure is free from defilements.

original: apagamanaṃ. Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena lokasamaññānurūpaṃ bhagavato pavattiṃ dasseti lokavohāravisayattā
analyzed: apagamanam tathā karuṇā gahaṇena loka samaññā anurūpam bhagavato pavattim dasseti loka vohāra visaya ttā
translated: And by the mention of compassion he shows that the Blessed One’s conduct accords with the world’s opinion, since the world’s opinion is the province of mundane talk,

original: karuṇāya, paññāgahaṇena samaññāya anatidhāvanaṃ. Sabhāvānavabodhena hi dhammānaṃ
analyzed: karuṇāya paññā gahaṇena samaññāya an atidhāvanam sabhāva an avabodhena hi dhammānam
translated: and by the word “compassion” he shows the perfection of his virtue, and by the word “wisdom” he shows the perfection of his understanding. For it is through not understanding the true nature of things that one transgresses the conventions of the world and clings to the notion of a being, etc.

original: samaññaṃ atidhāvitvā sattādiparāmasanaṃ hotīti. Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena mahākaruṇāsamāpattivihāraṃ
analyzed: samaññam atidhāvitvā sattā ādi parāmasanam hoti iti tathā karuṇā gahaṇena mahākaruṇā samāpatti vihāram
translated: By the word “compassion” he shows the abiding in the attainment of great compassion,

original: dasseti, paññāgahaṇena tīsu kālesu appaṭihatañāṇaṃ catusaccañāṇaṃ, catupaṭisambhidāñāṇaṃ,
analyzed: dasseti paññā gahaṇena tīsu kālesu appaṭihata ñāṇam catu sacca ñāṇam catu paṭisambhidā ñāṇam
translated: and by the word “wisdom” he shows the knowledge that is unobstructed in the three times, the knowledge of the Four Noble Truths, the knowledge of the four discriminations,

original: catuvesārajjañāṇaṃ. Karuṇāgahaṇena mahākaruṇāsamāpattiñāṇassa gahitattā sesāsādhāraṇañāṇāni,
analyzed: catu vesārajja ñāṇam karuṇā gahaṇena mahākaruṇā samāpatti ñāṇassa gahita ttā sesa a sādhāraṇa ñāṇāni
translated: and the knowledge of the four confidences. By the word “compassion” he shows the knowledge of the attainment of great compassion, and by the word “wisdom” he shows the knowledge that is not shared by disciples and others,

original: cha abhiññā, aṭṭhasu parisāsu akampanañāṇāni, dasa balāni, cuddasa buddhañāṇāni,
analyzed: cha abhiññāḥ aṭṭhasu parisāsu akampana ñāṇāni dasa balāni cuddasa buddha ñāṇāni
translated: the six kinds of direct knowledge, the knowledge that is unshaken in the eight assemblies, the ten powers, the fourteen knowledges of a Buddha,

original: soḷasa ñāṇacariyā, aṭṭhārasa buddhadhammā, catucattālīsa ñāṇavatthūni, sattasattati
analyzed: soḷasa ñāṇa cariyāḥ aṭṭhārasa buddha dhammā catucattālīsa ñāṇa vatthūni satta sattati
translated: the sixteen kinds of knowledge and conduct, the eighteen qualities of a Buddha, the forty-four bases of knowledge, the seventy-seven bases of knowledge,

original: ñāṇavatthūnīti evamādīnaṃ anekesaṃ paññāpabhedānaṃ vasena ñāṇacāraṃ dasseti. Tathā
analyzed: ñāṇa vatthūni iti evamādīnam anekesam paññā apabhedānam vasena ñāṇa cāram dasseti tathā
translated: and so on—he shows the conduct of knowledge by way of these and other numerous kinds of knowledge.

original: karuṇāgahaṇena caraṇasampattiṃ, paññāgahaṇena vijjāsampattiṃ. Karuṇāgahaṇena attādhipatitā,
analyzed: karuṇā gahaṇena caraṇa sampattim paññā gahaṇena vijjā sampattim karuṇā gahaṇena attā adhipati tā
translated: By the word “compassion” he shows the perfection of his conduct, and by the word “wisdom” he shows the perfection of his insight. By the word “compassion” he shows the supremacy of his virtue,🔽and by the word “wisdom” he shows the supremacy of his understanding.

original: paññāgahaṇena dhammādhipatitā. Karuṇāgahaṇena lokanāthabhāvo, paññāgahaṇena attanāthabhāvo.
analyzed: paññā gahaṇena dhamma adhipati tā karuṇā gahaṇena loka nātha bhāvo paññā gahaṇena atta nātha bhāvo
translated: and by the word “wisdom” the lordship of the Dhamma. By the word “compassion” he shows his being a protector of the world, and by the word “wisdom” his being a protector of himself.

original: Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena pubbakāribhāvo, paññāgahaṇena kataññutā. Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena🔽aparantapatā, paññāgahaṇena anattantapatā. Karuṇāgahaṇena vā buddhakaradhammasiddhi,
analyzed: tathā karuṇā gahaṇena pubba kāri bhāvaḥ paññā gahaṇena kataññu tā tathā karuṇā gahaṇena  aparantapa tā paññā gahaṇena anattantapa tā karuṇā gahaṇena vā buddha kara dhamma siddhi
translated: And by the word “compassion” he shows his being a doer of what should be done, and by the word “wisdom” his being grateful. And by the word “compassion” he shows🔽that he is not a shirker of the future life, and by the word “wisdom” that he is not a shirker of the present life. Or by the word “compassion” he shows the accomplishment of the state of a Buddha-to-be,

original: paññāgahaṇena buddhabhāvasiddhi. Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena paresaṃ tāraṇaṃ, paññāgahaṇena🔽sayaṃtaraṇaṃ. Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena sabbasattesu anuggahacittatā, paññāgahaṇena sabbadhammesu
analyzed: paññā gahaṇena buddha bhāva siddhi tathā karuṇā gahaṇena paresam tāraṇam paññā gahaṇena  sayaṃtaraṇam tathā karuṇā gahaṇena sabba sattesu anuggaha citta tā paññā gahaṇena sabba dhammesu
translated: and by the word “wisdom” the accomplishment of the state of a Buddha. And by the word “compassion” he shows that he delivers others,🔽and by the word “wisdom” that he delivers himself. And by the word “compassion” he shows that he has a mind to help all beings,

original: virattacittatā dassitā hoti.🔽Sabbesañca buddhaguṇānaṃ karuṇā ādi tannidānabhāvato, paññā pariyosānaṃ tato uttarikaraṇīyābhāvato.
analyzed: viratta citta tā dassitā hoti  sabbesam ca buddha guṇānam karuṇā ādi tad nidāna bhāvato paññā pariyosānam tatas uttari karaṇīya abhāvato
translated: and by the word “wisdom” that he has a mind to abandon all ideas.🔽And all the special qualities of a Buddha are shown by the words “compassion” and “wisdom” because compassion is the beginning of the special qualities of a Buddha since it is their cause, and wisdom is their end since there is nothing further beyond it.

original: Iti ādipariyosānadassanena sabbe buddhaguṇā dassitā honti. Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena sīlakkhandhapubbaṅgamo
analyzed: iti ādi pariyosāna dassanena sabbe buddha guṇāḥ dassitāḥ honti tathā karuṇā gahaṇena sīla kkhandha pubbaṅgamaḥ
translated: So all the special qualities of a Buddha are shown by the words “beginning” and “end.” And by the word “compassion” he shows that he has virtue as his forerunner,

original: samādhikkhandho dassito hoti. Karuṇānidānañhi sīlaṃ tato pāṇātipātādiviratippavattito,🔽sā ca jhānattayasampayoginīti. Paññāvacanena paññākkhandho. Sīlañca sabbesaṃ buddhaguṇānaṃ
analyzed: samādhi khandho dassitaḥ hoti karuṇā nidānam hi sīlam tatas pāṇātipāta ādi virati ppavattito  sā ca jhāna ttaya sampayoginī iti paññā vacanena paññā kkhandho sīlam ca sabbesam buddha guṇānaṃ
translated: The concentration aggregate is shown. For virtue is the source of compassion, since it occurs in the form of abstention from killing living beings, etc.,🔽and that is associated with the three jhānas. By the word “wisdom” the wisdom aggregate is shown. And virtue is the beginning, concentration the middle, and wisdom the end of all the Buddha-qualities.

original: ādi, samādhi majjhe, paññā pariyosānanti evampi ādimajjhapariyosānakalyāṇā sabbe
analyzed: ādi samādhi majjhe paññā pariyosānanti evam pi ādi majjha pariyosāna kalyāṇā sabbe
translated: Thus it is also shown that all the Buddha-qualities are good in the beginning, middle, and end. For they are shown by implication.

original: buddhaguṇā dassitā honti nayato dassitattā. Eso eva hi niravasesato buddhaguṇānaṃ🔽dassanupāyo, yadidaṃ nayaggahaṇaṃ, aññathā ko nāma samattho bhagavato guṇe anupadaṃ
analyzed: buddha guṇāḥ dassitāḥ honti nayataḥ dassita ttā esaḥ eva hi niravasesataḥ buddha guṇānaṃ  dassan upāyaḥ yat idam naya ggahaṇam aññathā kaḥ nāma samatthaḥ bhagavataḥ guṇe anupadam
translated: For this is the only way to show the Buddha-qualities without omission, namely, by the mention of the three aggregates,

original: niravasesato dassetuṃ? Tenevāha –
analyzed: niravasesataḥ dassetum tena iva āha
translated: since no one else is able to show the Blessed One’s qualities without omission and in their full detail. That is why it is said:

original: “Buddhopi buddhassa bhaṇeyya vaṇṇaṃ,🔽Kappampi ce aññamabhāsamāno;
analyzed: buddhaḥ api buddhassa bhaṇeyya vaṇṇam  kappam pi ce aññam a bhāsamāno
translated: “Even if he were to praise the Enlightened One’s beauty

original: Khīyetha kappo ciradīghamantare,
analyzed: khīyetha cira dīgham antare
translated: For an eon or more than an eon,

original: Vaṇṇo na khīyetha tathāgatassā”ti. ;
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ na khīyetha tathāgatassa ati
translated: The eon would end but the description of the Tathāgata’s beauty would not. ”

original: Teneva ca āyasmatā sāriputtattherenapi buddhaguṇaparicchedanaṃ pati anuyuttena “no hetaṃ, bhante”ti paṭikkhipitvā “apica me, bhante, dhammanvayo vidito”ti vuttaṃ.🔽2. Evaṃ saṅkhepena sakalasabbaññuguṇehi bhagavantaṃ abhitthavitvā idāni saddhammaṃ
analyzed: tena iva ca āyasmatā sāriputta therena api buddha guṇa paricchedanam anuyuttena no ha etam bhante iti paṭikkhipitvā apica me bhante dhamma anvayaḥ viditaḥ iti vuttam  evam saṅkhepena sakala sabbaññu guṇehi bhagavantam abhitthavitvā idāni saddhammam
translated: And so it was that the venerable elder Sāriputta, who was intent on defining the special qualities of the Enlightened One, replied: “No, indeed, venerable sir,” and then said: “But, venerable sir, the trend of the Dhamma is known to me” .🔽Having thus briefly extolled the Blessed One with the special qualities of an Enlightened One in their entirety, he now said “The Buddha too” in order to extol the True Idea.

original: thometuṃ “buddhopī”tiādimāha. Tattha buddhoti kattuniddeso. Buddhabhāvanti kammaniddeso.🔽Bhāvetvā sacchikatvāti ca pubbakālakiriyāniddeso. Yanti aniyamato kammaniddeso. Upagatoti
analyzed: thometum buddhaḥ api iti ādim āha tattha buddhaḥ iti kattu niddesaḥ buddha bhāvanti kamma niddeso  bhāvetvā sacchikatvā iti ca pubba kāla kiriyā niddesaḥ yanti aniyamataḥ kamma niddesaḥ upagataḥ ti
translated: Herein, the Buddha is the nominative case of the verb, and the state of being a Buddha is the verbal noun.🔽Having developed and realized is the past participial adjective. The word y means “in a certain way” and is the verbal noun.🔽Approached is the past participial adjective. The word vande is the verb. The word ta is the demonstrative.

original: aparakālakiriyāniddeso. Vandeti kiriyāniddeso. Tanti niyamanaṃ. Dhammanti vandanakiriyāya
analyzed: apara kāla kiriyā niddeso vandeti kiriyā niddeso vandana kiriyāya
translated: The word Dhamma is the verbal noun of the verb vandati .

original: kammaniddeso. Gatamalaṃ anuttaranti ca tabbisesanaṃ.
translated: The words gatamalaṃ anuttarā are the description of that .

original: Tattha buddhasaddassa tāva “bujjhitā saccānīti buddho, bodhetā pajāyāti buddho”tiādinā
analyzed: tattha buddha saddassa tāva bujjhitā saccāni iti buddhaḥ pajāyāti buddha uti ādinā
translated: Herein, as regards the word Buddha, it is said: “He is a Buddha because he has awakened to the truths, he is a Buddha because he has caused the world to awaken” .

original: niddesanayena attho veditabbo. Atha vā savāsanāya aññāṇaniddāya accantavigamato,
analyzed: niddesa nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ atha vā sa vāsanāya aññāṇa niddāya accanta vigamato
translated: The meaning should be understood according to the method of exposition.🔽Or else, he is “awakened” because of the complete disappearance of the sleep of ignorance together with its residues,

original: buddhiyā vā vikasitabhāvato buddhavāti buddho jāgaraṇavikasanatthavasena. Atha vā
analyzed: buddhiyā vā vikasita bhāvataḥ buddhavāti buddhaḥ jāgaraṇa vikasana attha vasena atha vā
translated: or because of the blossoming of his knowledge. Or else,

original: kassacipi ñeyyadhammassa anavabuddhassa abhāvena ñeyyavisesassa kammabhāvena aggahaṇato🔽kammavacanicchāya abhāvena avagamanatthavaseneva kattuniddeso labbhatīti buddhavāti
analyzed: kassaci pi ñeyya dhammassa anavabuddhassa abhāvena ñeyya visesassa kamma bhāvena aggahaṇato  kamma vacanicchāya abhāvena avagamana attha vasena iva kattu niddesaḥ labbhati iti
translated: he is “awakened” because of the absence of any object of knowledge that is not known, and because of the absence of any object of knowledge that is not fully apprehended by the function of knowledge.🔽The nominative case is used because of the meaning of understanding, not because of the meaning of action.

original: buddho yathā “dikkhito na dadātī”ti. Atthato pana pāramitāparibhāvito sayambhuñāṇena🔽saha vāsanāya vihataviddhaṃsitaniravasesakileso mahākaruṇāsabbaññutaññāṇādiaparimeyyaguṇagaṇādhāro
analyzed: buddhaḥ yathā dikkhitaḥ na dadāti iti atthataḥ pana pāramitā paribhāvito sayambhu ñāṇena  saha vāsanāya vihata viddhaṃsita niravasesa kilesaḥ mahā karuṇā sabbaññuta ññāṇa ādi aparimeyya guṇa gaṇa ādhāraḥ
translated: But in the sense of the meaning of action, the nominative case is used in such expressions as “the awakened one” and “the one who has awakened,” just as in the expressions “the one who gives a gift” and “the one who awakens.”🔽In the ultimate sense, however, the Buddha is the continuum of aggregates that is the repository of immeasurable qualities such as great compassion, the knowledge of omniscience, etc.,

original: khandhasantāno buddho. Yathāha –
analyzed: khandha santānaḥ buddhaḥ yathā āha
translated: which is purified of all defilements together with their residues by means of self-awakened knowledge perfected by the perfections.

original: “Buddhoti yo so bhagavā sayambhū anācariyako pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu sāmaṃ saccāni abhisambujjhi, tattha ca sabbaññutaṃ patto balesu ca vasībhāva”nti.
analyzed: buddhaḥ ti yaḥ saḥ bhagavā sayambhu an ācariyako pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu sāmam saccāni abhisambujjhi tattha ca sabbaññu tam pattaḥ balesu ca vasībhāvanti
translated: “Buddha’: he who is the Blessed One, the Self-becoming One, the One without a Teacher, who by himself directly experiences the True Ideas not yet experienced by anyone else, and who has reached omniscience and mastery over all things that can be.”

original: Api-saddo sambhāvane. Tena “evaṃ guṇavisesayutto sopi nāma bhagavā”ti vakkhamānaguṇadhamme🔽sambhāvanaṃ dīpeti. Buddhabhāvanti sammāsambodhiṃ. Bhāvetvāti uppādetvā vaḍḍhetvā
analyzed: api saddaḥ sambhāvane tena evam guṇa visesa yuttaḥ saḥ api nāma bhagavā ti vakkhamāna guṇa dhamme  sambhāvanam dīpeti buddha bhāvanti sammāsambodhim bhāvetvā ati uppādetvā vaḍḍhetvā
translated: The word “also” is for emphasis. By it he shows the emphasis on the qualities of the Blessed One that are about to be stated, namely, “He who is thus endowed with special qualities, that Blessed One also.”🔽“The Buddha-state”: the supreme enlightenment. “Having developed”: having aroused and increased.🔽“Having directly experienced”: having made it evident. “Has attained”: has reached; the meaning is, has acquired. This is the connection with the words “the Buddha-state.”

original: ca. Sacchikatvāti paccakkhaṃ katvā. Upagatoti patto, adhigatoti attho. Etassa buddhabhāvanti🔽etena sambandho. Gatamalanti vigatamalaṃ, niddosanti attho. Vandeti paṇamāmi, thomemi🔽vā. Anuttaranti uttararahitaṃ, lokuttaranti attho. Dhammanti yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjamāne
analyzed: ca sacchikatvā iti paccakkham katvā upagataḥ iti pattaḥ adhigataḥ iti attho etassa buddha bhāvanti  etena sambandhaḥ gata malanti vigata malam niddosanti attho vandeti paṇamāmi thomemi  vā anuttaran ti uttara rahitam lokuttaran ti atthaḥ dhamman ti yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjamāne
translated: “The dust-free”: the dust-free, the dust-free; the meaning is, the passion-free. “I praise”: I honour, I extol.

original: apāyato ca saṃsārato ca apatamāne katvā dhāretīti dhammo. Ayañhettha saṅkhepattho
analyzed: apāyataḥ ca saṃsārataḥ ca a patamāne katvā dhāreti iti dhammaḥ ayan ha ittha saṅkhepa attho
