original: cassa paramāya anukampāya samannāgamaṃ, pacchimena paramāya upekkhāya samannāgamaṃ
analyzed: cassa paramāya anukampāya samannāgamam pacchimena paramāya upekkhāya samannāgamam
translated: and by the latter the performance of the function of understanding. By the former he shows the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest compassion,

original: dīpeti. Bhagavā hi sabbasatte paramāya anukampāya anukampati, na ca tattha sinehadosānupatito
analyzed: dīpeti bhagavā hi sabba satte paramāya anukampāya anukampati na ca tattha sineha dosa anupatito
translated: and by the latter his endowment with the highest equanimity. For the Blessed One has compassion on all beings with the highest compassion, and he is not subject to the taint of affection there.

original: paramupekkhakabhāvato. Upekkhako ca na parahitasukhakaraṇe appossukko mahākāruṇikabhāvato.
analyzed: param upekkhaka bhāvataḥ upekkhakaḥ ca na para hita sukha karaṇe appa ussukkaḥ mahā kāruṇika bhāvato
translated: and because of his equanimity towards others, he is not negligent in bringing about the welfare and happiness of others, because of his great compassion.

original: Tassa mahākāruṇikatāya lokanāthatā, upekkhakatāya attanāthatā.
analyzed: tassa mahā kāruṇika tāya loka nātha tā upekkhaka tāya atta nātha tā
translated: Because of his great compassion he is the protector of the world, and because of his equanimity he is the protector of himself.

original: Tathā hesa bodhisattabhūto mahākaruṇāya sañcoditamānaso sakalalokahitāya ussukkamāpanno🔽mahābhinīhārato paṭṭhāya tadatthanipphādanatthaṃ puññañāṇasambhāre sampādento aparimitaṃ
analyzed: tathā ha isa bodhisatta bhūtaḥ mahā karuṇāya sañcodita mānasaḥ sakala loka hitāya ussukkam āpannaḥ  mahā abhinīhārataḥ paṭṭhāya tad attha nipphādana attham puññañāṇa sambhāre sampādento aparimitam
translated: For, as a Bodhisatta, he, being urged on by great compassion, was intent on the welfare of the whole world,🔽and, from the time of his great resolution, for the sake of fulfilling that purpose, he underwent immeasurable suffering for an immeasurable time,

original: kālaṃ anappakaṃ dukkhamanubhosi, upekkhakatāya sammā patitehi dukkhehi na vikampitatā.
analyzed: kālam anappakam dukkham anubhosi upekkhaka tāya sammā patitehi dukkhehi na vikampita tā
translated: accumulating the requisites of merit and knowledge, and because of his equanimity he was not shaken by the suffering that befell him.

original: Mahākāruṇikatāya saṃsārābhimukhatā, upekkhakatāya tato nibbindanā. Tathā upekkhakatāya
analyzed: mahā kāruṇika tāya saṃsāra abhimukha tā upekkhaka tāya tatas nibbindanā tathā upekkhaka tāya
translated: Because of his great compassion he is intent on the round of rebirths, and because of his equanimity he is not wearied by it. Because of his equanimity

original: nibbānābhimukhatā, mahākāruṇikatāya tadadhigamo. Tathā mahākāruṇikatāya paresaṃ ahiṃsāpanaṃ,
analyzed: nibbāna abhimukha tā mahā kāruṇika tāya tad adhigamaḥ tathā mahā kāruṇika tāya paresam ahiṃsāpanam
translated: he is intent on Nibbāna, and because of his great compassion he has not yet attained it. Because of his great compassion he is not harmed by others,

original: upekkhakatāya sayaṃ parehi abhāyanaṃ. Mahākāruṇikatāya paraṃ rakkhato attano rakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: upekkhaka tāya sayam parehi abhāyanam mahā kāruṇika tāya param rakkhataḥ attanaḥ rakkhaṇam
translated: and because of his equanimity he does not harm others. Because of his great compassion he protects others, and because of his equanimity he protects himself.

original: upekkhakatāya attānaṃ rakkhato paresaṃ rakkhaṇaṃ. Tenassa attahitāya paṭipannādīsu
analyzed: upekkhaka tāya attānam rakkhataḥ paresam rakkhaṇam tenassa atta hitāya paṭipanna ādīsu
translated: and by his equanimity, the protection of others. Thus, in the case of the four kinds of persons,

original: catutthapuggalabhāvo siddho hoti. Tathā mahākāruṇikatāya saccādhiṭṭhānassa ca cāgādhiṭṭhānassa
analyzed: catuttha puggala bhāvo siddho hoti tathā mahā kāruṇika tāya sacca adhiṭṭhānassa ca cāga adhiṭṭhānassa
translated: the fourth type is established for him. Likewise, by his great compassion, the fulfillment of the foundation of truth and the foundation of relinquishment ;

original: ca pāripūrī, upekkhakatāya upasamādhiṭṭhānassa ca paññādhiṭṭhānassa ca pāripūrī.
analyzed: ca pāripūrī upekkhaka tāya upasamā dhiṭṭhānassa ca paññā adhiṭṭhānassa ca pāripūrī
translated: and by his equanimity, the fulfillment of the foundation of peace and the foundation of wisdom .

original: Evaṃ purisuddhāsayappayogassa mahākāruṇikatāya lokahitatthameva rajjasampadādibhavasampattiyā
analyzed: evam purisa uddha āsaya ppayogassa mahā kāruṇika tāya loka hita attham eva rajja sampad ādi bhava sampattiyā
translated: Thus, for one whose heart and efforts are pure, by his great compassion, the undertaking of the perfection of sovereignty, etc., and of the perfection of existence is for the welfare of the world alone;

original: upagamanaṃ, upekkhakatāya tiṇāyapi amaññamānassa tato apagamanaṃ. Iti suvisuddhaupagamāpagamassa
analyzed: upagamanam upekkhaka tāya a maññamānassa tatas apagamanam iti su visuddha aupagama apagamassa
translated: and by his equanimity, the renunciation of them is like straw. Thus, for one who has well purified his undertaking and renunciation,

original: mahākāruṇikatāya lokahitatthameva dānavasena sampattīnaṃ pariccajanā, upekkhakatāya
analyzed: mahā kāruṇika tāya loka hita attham eva dāna vasena sampattīnam pariccajanāḥ upekkhaka tāya
translated: by his great compassion, the relinquishment of the attainments by way of generosity is for the welfare of the world alone;

original: cassa phalassa attano apaccāsīsanā. Evaṃ samudāgamanato paṭṭhāya acchariyabbhutaguṇasamannāgatassa
analyzed: cassa phalassa attano a paccāsīsanā evam samudāgamanataḥ paṭṭhāya acchariya bbhuta guṇa samannāgatassa
translated: and by his equanimity, the non-appropriation of their fruit. Thus, for one who is endowed with the qualities of wonder and marvel from the time of his arising,

original: mahākāruṇikatāya paresaṃ hitasukhatthaṃ atidukkarakāritā, upekkhakatāya kāyampi analaṅkāritā.
analyzed: mahā kāruṇika tāya paresam hita sukha attham ati dukkara kāri tā upekkhaka tāya kāyampi an alaṅkāri tā
translated: And because of his great compassion he did what was extremely difficult to do for the sake of the welfare and happiness of others, and because of his equanimity he did not even adorn his body.

original: Tathā mahākāruṇikatāya carimattabhāve jiṇṇāturamatadassanena sañjātasaṃvego, upekkhakatāya
analyzed: tathā mahā kāruṇika tāya carimatta bhāve jiṇṇa ātura mata dassanena sañjāta saṃvegaḥ upekkhaka tāya
translated: Similarly, because of his great compassion he went forth into homelessness with great renunciation, being moved by the sight of the aged, the sick, and the dead in his last existence as a bodhisatta, and because of his equanimity

original: uḷāresu devabhogasadisesu bhogesu nirapekkho mahābhinikkhamanaṃ nikkhami. Tathā mahākāruṇikatāya
analyzed: uḷāresu deva bhoga sadisesu bhogesu nirapekkhaḥ mahā abhinikkhamanam nikkhami tathā mahā kāruṇika tāya
translated: he was indifferent to the enjoyments he was enjoying, which were like those of the highest gods. And because of his great compassion

original: “kicchaṃ vatāyaṃ loko āpanno”tiādinā karuṇāmukheneva vipassanārambho, upekkhakatāya
analyzed: kiccham vata ayam lokaḥ āpannaḥ ti ādinā karuṇā mukhena iva vipassanā ārambhaḥ upekkhaka tāya
translated: he began his insight meditation with the meditation on compassion, beginning with the words, “Alas, this world has fallen on misfortune,” and because of his equanimity

original: buddhabhūtassa satta sattāhāni vivekasukheneva vītināmanaṃ. Mahākāruṇikatāya dhammagambhīrataṃ
analyzed: buddha bhūtassa satta satta ahāni viveka sukhena iva vītināmanam mahā kāruṇika tāya dhamma gambhīra tam
translated: he spent the first seven days after his enlightenment experiencing the bliss of seclusion. And because of his great compassion

original: paccavekkhitvā dhammadesanāya appossukkanaṃ āpajjitvāpi mahābrahmuno ajjhesanāpadesena
analyzed: paccavekkhitvā dhamma desanāya appossukkanam āpajjitvā api mahābrahmunaḥ ajjhesana apadesena
translated: he did not at first consent to teach the Dhamma, reflecting on the profundity of the Dhamma, but he made himself available to others by accepting the request of the Great Brahma,

original: okāsakaraṇaṃ, upekkhakatāya pañcavaggiyādiveneyyānaṃ ananurūpasamudācārepi anaññathābhāvo.
analyzed: okāsa karaṇam upekkhaka tāya pañcavaggiya ādi veneyyānam ananurūpa samudācāre pi anaññathābhāvaḥ
translated: and because of his equanimity he remained unchanged even when the group-of-five disciples behaved improperly towards him.

original: Mahākāruṇikatāya katthaci paṭighātābhāvenassa sabbattha amittasaññābhāvo, upekkhakatāya🔽katthacipi anurodhābhāvena sabbattha sinehasanthavābhāvo. Mahākāruṇikatāya paresaṃ
analyzed: mahā kāruṇika tāya katthaci paṭighāta abhāvena assa sabbattha amitta saññā bhāvaḥ upekkhaka tāya  katthacipi anurodha abhāvena sabbattha sineha santhava abhāvaḥ mahā kāruṇika tāya paresam
translated: And because of his great compassion he has no hostile thoughts anywhere, and because of his equanimity🔽he has no affection for anyone anywhere. Because of his great compassion he inspires confidence in others, and because of his equanimity he is not shaken by the signs of confidence. Because of his great compassion he has no teacher’s pride, and because of his equanimity he has no pride in his retinue.

original: pasādanā, upekkhakatāya pasannākārehi na vikampanā. Mahākāruṇikatāya dhammānurāgābhāvena🔽tattha ācariyamuṭṭhiabhāvo, upekkhakatāya sāvakānurāgābhāvena parivāraparikammatābhāvo.🔽Mahākāruṇikatāya dhammaṃ desetuṃ parehi saṃsaggamupagacchatopi upekkhakatāya na tattha🔽abhirati. Mahākāruṇikatāya gāmādīnaṃ āsannaṭṭhāne vasatopi upekkhakatāya araññaṭṭhāne
analyzed: pasādanā upekkhaka tāya pasanna ākārehi na vikampanā mahā kāruṇika tāya dhamma anurāga abhāvena  tattha ācariya muṭṭhi abhāvaḥ upekkhaka tāya sāvaka anurāga abhāvena parivāra parikamma tā bhāvaḥ  mahā kāruṇika tāya dhammam desetum parehi saṃsaggam upagacchataḥ api upekkhaka tāya na tattha  mahā kāruṇika tāya gāma ādīnam āsanna ṭhāne vasataḥ api upekkhaka tāya arañña ṭṭhāne
translated: And because of his great compassion he does not delight in that, though he goes to meet people in order to teach them the Dhamma. Because of his great compassion he lives in the vicinity of villages, etc., and because of his equanimity he lives in the forest.

original: eva viharaṇaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ – “purimenassa paramāya anukampāya samannāgamaṃ dīpetī”ti.
analyzed: eva viharaṇam tena vuttam purima inassa paramāya anukampāya samannāgamam dīpeti iti
translated: Hence it was said above: “He illustrates the first by the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest compassion” .

original: Tanti tatrāti padaṃ. “Desakālaparidīpana”nti ye desakālā idha viharaṇakiriyāvisesanabhāvena
analyzed: padam ye desa kālāḥ viharaṇa kiriyā visesana bhāvena
translated: “Tanti tatrā” : the word “tatrā” . “He illustrates the second by the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest equanimity” . “He illustrates the second by the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest equanimity” .🔽“He illustrates the second by the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest equanimity” . “He illustrates the second by the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest equanimity” .🔽“He illustrates the second by the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest equanimity” . “He illustrates the second by the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest equanimity” .🔽“He illustrates the second by the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest equanimity” . “He illustrates the second by the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest equanimity” .🔽“He illustrates the second by the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest equanimity” . “He illustrates the second by the Blessed One’s endowment with the highest equanimity” .

original: vuttā, tesaṃ paridīpananti dassento “yaṃ samayaṃ…pe… dīpetī”ti āha. Taṃ-saddo hi
analyzed: vuttā tesam paridīpananti dassentaḥ yam dīpeti iti āha tad saddaḥ hi
translated: and he said “at the time when … he illuminates” in order to show the meaning of that. For the word “that”

original: vuttassa atthassa paṭiniddeso, tasmā idha kālassa desassa vā paṭiniddeso bhavitumarahati,
analyzed: vuttassa atthassa paṭiniddeso tasmai idha kālassa desassa vā paṭiniddesaḥ bhavitum arahati
translated: is a demonstrative of the meaning of what has been said, and so here it can only be a demonstrative of time or place,

original: na aññassa. Ayaṃ tāva tatra-saddassa paṭiniddesabhāve atthavibhāvanā. Yasmā pana
analyzed: na aññassa ayam tāva tatra saddassa paṭiniddesa bhāve attha vibhāvanā yasmā pana
translated: not of anything else. This, firstly, is the elucidation of the meaning of the word “that” as a demonstrative. But since

original: īdisesu ṭhānesu tatra-saddo dhammadesanāvisiṭṭhaṃ desakālañca vibhāveti, tasmā vuttaṃ🔽– “bhāsitabbayutte vā desakāle dīpetī”ti. Tena tatrāti yatra bhagavā dhammadesanatthaṃ
analyzed: īdisesu ṭhānesu tatra saddaḥ dhamma desanā visiṭṭham desa kālañca vibhāveti tasmā vuttam  bhāsitabba yutte vā desa kāle dīpeti iti tena tatra ati yatra bhagavā dhamma desana attham
translated: in such passages as this the word “that” indicates the place and time distinguished by the teaching of the Dhamma, it is said🔽that it “illuminates the place and time suitable for the utterance.”

original: bhikkhū ālapati bhāsati, tādise dese, kāle vāti attho. Na hītiādinā tamevatthaṃ samattheti.
analyzed: bhikkhū ālapati bhāsati tādise dese kāle vā ati atthaḥ na hi iti ādinā tam eva attham samattheti
translated: The meaning is: in the place where the Blessed One addresses the bhikkhus and speaks for the purpose of teaching the Dhamma, and at the time when he does so. The words “not otherwise” confirm that meaning.

original: Nanu ca yattha ṭhito bhagavā “akālo kho tāvā”tiādinā bāhiyassa dhammadesanaṃ paṭikkhipi,
analyzed: nanu ca yattha ṭhitaḥ bhagavā akālaḥ kho tāva āti ādinā bāhiyassa dhamma desanam paṭikkhipi
translated: But was it not in the very place where the Blessed One, standing, refused to teach the Dhamma to Bahiya saying, “The time is not yet, Bahiya,”

original: tattheva antaravīthiyaṃ ṭhito tassa dhammaṃ desesīti? Saccametaṃ, adesetabbakāle
analyzed: tattha iva antara vīthiyam ṭhitaḥ tassa dhammam desesi iti saccam etam a desetabba kāle
translated: that he taught the Dhamma to him while standing in the middle of the road? That is so, but the place was not suitable for teaching the Dhamma,🔽and the time was not suitable.

original: adesanāya idaṃ udāharaṇaṃ. Tenevāha – “akālo kho tāvā”ti.🔽Yaṃ pana tattha vuttaṃ – “antaragharaṃ paviṭṭhamhā”ti, tampi tassa akālabhāvasseva
analyzed: idam udāharaṇam tena iva āha  yam pana tattha vuttam antara gharam paviṭṭhamha ati tam pi tassa akāla bhāvassa iva
translated: This is an example of non-exposition. Hence it is said: “Now is not the time for that” .🔽But what is said there, “We have entered among the houses,” is said for the purpose of showing that it is not the time by a roundabout way.

original: pariyāyena dassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Tassa hi tadā addhānaparissamena rūpakāye akammaññatā
analyzed: pariyāyena dassana attham vuttam tassa hi tadā rūpa kāye akammañña tā
translated: For at that time his material body was unwieldy owing to the fatigue of the journey,

original: ahosi, balavapītivegena nāmakāye. Tadubhayassa vūpasamaṃ āgamento papañcaparihāratthaṃ
analyzed: ahosi balava pīti vegena nāmakāye tad ubhayassa vūpasamam āgamento papañca parihāra attham
translated: and his mental body was overwhelmed by the force of the inspiration. When he had gone and the fatigue of the journey had subsided,

original: bhagavā “akālo kho”ti pariyāyena paṭikkhipi. Adesetabbadese adesanāya pana udāharaṇaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā akālaḥ kho ti pariyāyena a desetabba dese a desanāya pana udāharaṇam
translated: the Blessed One refused by a roundabout way, saying: “Now is not the time,” for the purpose of avoiding trouble.🔽But the example of non-exposition in the case of a place where exposition should be given is such passages as:

original: “atha kho bhagavā maggā okkamma aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle nisīdi, vihārapacchāyāyaṃ🔽paññatte āsane nisīdī”ti ca evamādikaṃ idha ādisaddena saṅgahitaṃ. “Atha kho so,
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā maggā okkamma aññatarasmim rukkha mūle nisīdi vihāra pacchāyāyam  paññatte āsane nisīdi iti ca evamādikam idha ādi saddena saṅgahitam atha kho so
translated: “Then the Blessed One, having gone down from the road, sat down on a seat made ready at the foot of a tree in the shadow of the dwelling house,🔽on a seat made ready” .🔽And such passages as: “Then, bhikkhus, that fool, having here misconducted himself in body, speech, and mind,🔽having destroyed good and made evil happen,

original: bhikkhave, bālo idha pubbe nesādo idha pāpāni kammāni karitvā”tiādīsu padapūraṇamatte
analyzed: bhikkhave bālo idha pubbe nesādaḥ idha pāpāni kammāni karitvā ati ādīsu pada pūraṇa matte
translated: at the breaking up of the body after death, is reborn in a state of misery, in a bad destination, in the nether world, in hell” , are included here by the word “etc.”

original: kho-saddo, “dukkhaṃ kho agāravo viharati appatisso”tiādīsu avadhāraṇe, “kittāvatā
analyzed: kho saddaḥ dukkham kho agāravaḥ viharati appatissaḥ ti ādīsu avadhāraṇe kittāvatā
translated: The word kho is used in the sense of definition in such passages as “He lives without respect and without deference, suffering the painful feeling” .

original: nu kho, āvuso, satthu pavivittassa viharato sāvakā vivekaṃ nānusikkhantī”tiādīsu🔽ādikālatthe, vākyārambheti attho. Tattha padapūraṇena vacanālaṅkāramattaṃ kataṃ hoti,
analyzed: nu kho āvuso satthu pavivittassa viharato sāvakāḥ vivekam na anusikkhanti itiādīsu  ādi kāla tthe vākya ārambha iti tattha pada pūraṇena vacana alaṅkāra mattam katam hoti
translated: It is used in the sense of the beginning of time in such passages as “In what way, friends, do the disciples of the Teacher who lives secluded not train in seclusion?” .🔽Here it has the meaning of the beginning of a sentence. Herein, it is made a mere figure of speech by the filling out of the sentence.

original: ādikālatthena vākyassa upaññāsamattaṃ. Avadhāraṇatthena pana niyamadassanaṃ, tasmā
analyzed: ādi kāla atthena vākyassa avadhāraṇa atthena pana niyama dassanam tasmā
translated: But by the sense of the beginning of time it is merely the introduction of the sentence. But by the sense of definition it is the showing of a restriction. Therefore

original: āmantesi evāti āmantane niyamo dassito hoti.
analyzed: āmantesi eva ati āmantane niyamaḥ dassito hoti
translated: he addresses them, thus the restriction in the addressing is shown.

original: Bhagavāti lokagarudīpananti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu pubbepi bhagavāsaddassa attho vuttoti?
analyzed: bhagavā iti loka garu dīpananti kasmā vuttam nanu pubbe pi bhagavā saddassa atthaḥ vutto ti
translated: Why is it said “the Blessed One, the supreme man in the world” ? Has not the meaning of the word “Blessed One” already been stated?

original: Yadipi vutto, taṃ panassa yathāvutte ṭhāne viharaṇakiriyāya kattu visesadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: yadi api vuttaḥ tam panassa yathā vutte ṭhāne viharaṇa kiriyāya kattu visesa dassana attham
translated: Although it has been stated, it was done there in order to show the particular doer of the action of living in the way stated in the passage,

original: kataṃ, na āmantanakiriyāya, idha pana āmantanakiriyāya, tasmā tadatthaṃ puna “bhagavā”ti
analyzed: katam naḥ āmantana kiriyāya idha pana āmantana kiriyāya tasmai puna bhagavā ati
translated: not in order to show the particular doer of the action of addressing. But here it is in order to show the particular doer of the action of addressing. Therefore the meaning of it is stated again as “the Blessed One, the supreme man in the world” .

original: pāḷiyaṃ vuttanti tassatthaṃ dassetuṃ “bhagavāti lokagarudīpana”nti āha. Tena lokagarubhāvato🔽tadanurūpaṃ paṭipattiṃ patthento attano santikaṃ upagatānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ ajjhāsayānurūpaṃ🔽dhammaṃ desetuṃ te āmantesīti dasseti. Kathāsavanayuttapuggalavacananti vakkhamānāya🔽cittapariyādānadesanāya savanayoggapuggalavacanaṃ. analyzed: bhagavā āmantesi iti vutta ttā bhagavato paccassosuṃ idha bhagavato ti sāmi vacanam
translated: Since it is said previously that “the Blessed One addressed them thus,” here the word bhagavato is in the genitive case

original: āmantanameva sambandhiantaraṃ apekkhatīti iminā adhippāyena “bhagavato āmantanaṃ
analyzed: āmantanam eva sambandhi antaram apekkhati iti iminā adhippāyena bhagavataḥ āmantanam
translated: because it is dependent on the vocative. With the intention that “the Blessed One’s address”

original: paṭiassosu”nti vuttaṃ. “Bhagavato”ti pana idaṃ paṭissavasambandhena sampadānavacanaṃ
analyzed: paṭiassosunti vuttam bhagavato ti pana idam paṭissava sambandhena sampadāna vacanam
translated: is dependent on the vocative, it is said: “they listened to the Blessed One’s address.” But the word bhagavato is in the genitive case🔽because it is dependent on the verb paṭissavanti in the sense of giving,

original: yathā “devadattāya paṭissuṇotī”ti. Yaṃ nidānaṃ bhāsitanti sambandho. Imassa suttassa
analyzed: yathā devadattāya paṭissuṇoti iti yam nidānam bhāsitam ti sambandhaḥ imassa suttassa
translated: just as in the expression “he listens to Devadatta” . The construction is: “they listened to the Blessed One’s address, which was spoken as the occasion arose.”

original: sukhāvagāhaṇatthanti kamalakuvalayujjalavimalasādurasasalilāya pokkharaṇiyā sukhāvataraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: kamala kuvalaya ujjala vimala sādu rasa salilāya pokkharaṇiyā sukha avataraṇa ttham
translated: “For the sake of easy access”: for the sake of easy access to the lotus-pond, whose water is pleasant to bathe in, and which is pure, clear, and sweet-tasting, like a lotus and a jasmine flower.

original: nimmalasilātalaracanāvilāsasobhitaratanasopānaṃ vippakiṇṇamuttātalasadisavālukācuṇṇapaṇḍarabhūmibhāgaṃ
analyzed: nimmala silā tala racanā vilāsa sobhita ratana sopānam vippakiṇṇa muttā tala sadisa vālukā cuṇṇa paṇḍara bhūmi bhāgam
translated: Like a ford, it is adorned with the beauty of the playful designs of spotless marble slabs, with jeweled stairways, and with the ground, white as a mass of pearls, strewn with sand.

original: titthaṃ viya suvibhattabhittivicitravedikāparikkhittassa nakkhattapathaṃ phusitukāmatāya
analyzed: tittham viya su vibhatta bhitti vicitra vedikā parikkhittassa nakkhattapatham phusitu kāma tāya
translated: Like a stairway, it is for the sake of easy ascent to the best of palaces, which is as if it were eager to touch the path of the stars,

original: viya paṭivijambhitasamussayassa pāsādavarassa sukhārohanatthaṃ dantamayasaṇhamuduphalakañcanalatāvinaddhamaṇigaṇappabhāsamudayujjalasobhaṃ🔽sopānaṃ viya suvaṇṇavalayanūpurādisaṅghaṭṭanasaddasammissitassa kathitahasitamadhurassaragehajanavijambhitavicaritassa
analyzed: viya paṭivijambhita samussayassa pāsāda varassa sukha ārohana attham danta maya saṇha mudu phala kañcana latā vinaddha maṇi gaṇa ppabhā samudaya ujjala sobham  sopānam viya suvaṇṇa valaya nūpura ādi saṅghaṭṭana sadda sammissitassa kathita hasita madhurassara geha jana vijambhita vicaritassa
translated: with its upper chambers wide open, and its jeweled stairways shining with the splendor of the rising radiance of the many gems, which are bound with golden vines, soft and smooth as ivory.🔽Like a great house, it is for the sake of easy entry, which is resplendent with abundant wealth,🔽with its upper chambers wide open, and its sounds of the tinkling of golden bracelets and anklets mixed with the sounds of laughter and conversation, sweet as the humming of bees, of the women of the house, who are moving about,

original: uḷāraissariyavibhavasobhitassa mahāgharassa sukhappavesanatthaṃ suvaṇṇarajatamaṇimuttāpavāḷādijutivissaravijjotitasuppatiṭṭhitavisāladvārabāhaṃ
analyzed: uḷāra aissariya vibhava sobhitassa mahā gharassa sukha ppavesana attham suvaṇṇa rajata maṇi muttā pavāḷa ādi juti vissara vijjotita suppatiṭṭhita visāla dvāra bāham
translated: with its wide doors and doorposts well set up, shining with the light of the rays of the jewels, pearls, sapphires, and so on.

original: mahādvāraṃ viya ca atthabyañjanasampannassa buddhānaṃ desanāñāṇagambhīrabhāvasaṃsūcakassa
analyzed: mahādvāram viya ca attha byañjana sampannassa buddhānam desanā ñāṇa gambhīra bhāva saṃsūcakassa
translated: And it is like a great door, indicating the profundity of the Buddhas’ knowledge of the True Idea and of the True Idea and the True Idea’s expression that is possessed of the eight good qualities.

original: imassa suttassa sukhāvagāhatthaṃ.🔽Etthāha – “kimatthaṃ pana dhammavinayasaṅgahe kayiramāne nidānavacanaṃ, nanu bhagavatā
analyzed: imassa suttassa sukha avagāha attham  ettha āha kimattham pana dhamma vinaya saṅgahe nidāna vacanam nanu bhagavatā
translated: It is for the sake of easy understanding of this sutta.🔽Here it may be asked: But what is the point of stating the introduction when the True Idea and Discipline are being collected? Should not only the words spoken by the Blessed One be collected?

original: bhāsitavacanasseva saṅgaho kātabbo”ti? Vuccate, desanāya ṭhitiasammosasaddheyyabhāvasampādanatthaṃ.
analyzed: bhāsita vacanassa iva saṅgahaḥ kātabbaḥ iti vuccate desanāya ṭhiti asammosa saddheyya bhāva sampādana attham
translated: It may be replied: for the purpose of ensuring the teaching’s long preservation, its non-corruption, and its credibility.

original: Kāladesadesakanimittaparisāpadesehi upanibandhitvā ṭhapitā hi desanā ciraṭṭhitikā
analyzed: kāla desa desaka nimitta parisā apadesehi upanibandhitvā ṭhapitā hi desanā cira ṭṭhitikā
translated: For a teaching that is set up by being tied to a place, a time, a person, a reason, an assembly, and a speaker, is preserved long,

original: hoti asammosadhammā saddheyyā ca. Desakālakattuhetunimittehi upanibaddho viya vohāravinicchayo.
analyzed: hoti asammosa dhammā saddheyyā ca desa kāla kattu hetu nimittehi upanibaddhaḥ viya vohāra vinicchayaḥ
translated: is not corrupted, and is credible, just as a legal verdict is when it is tied to a place, a time, an action, a reason, and a cause.

original: Teneva ca āyasmatā mahākassapena “cittapariyādānasuttaṃ, āvuso ānanda, kattha bhāsita”ntiādinā
analyzed: tena iva ca āyasmatā mahākassapena citta pariyādāna suttam āvuso ānanda kattha bhāsita nti ādinā
translated: That is why, when the venerable Maha Kassapa asked the venerable Ananda the questions beginning with ‘Friend Ananda, where was the Cittasamyutta spoken? ’

original: desādipucchāsu katāsu tāsaṃ vissajjanaṃ karontena dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena “evaṃ me suta”ntiādinā
analyzed: desa ādi pucchāsu katāsu tāsam vissajjanam karontena dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena evam me sutanti ādinā
translated: and the venerable Ananda, as the venerable Maha Kassapa’s questioner, replied to them with ‘Thus I have heard’ and so on.

original: imassa suttassa nidānaṃ bhāsitaṃ. Apica satthusampattippakāsanatthaṃ nidānavacanaṃ.🔽Tathāgatassa hi bhagavato pubbacaraṇānumānāgamatakkābhāvato sammāsambuddhabhāvasiddhi.
analyzed: imassa suttassa nidānam bhāsitam apica satthu sampatti pakāsana ttham nidāna vacanam  tathāgatassa hi bhagavataḥ pubba caraṇa anumāna āgama takka abhāvato sammāsambuddha bhāva siddhi
translated: Moreover, the words of the Introduction are spoken for the purpose of showing the excellence of the Teacher.🔽For the Blessed One, the Tathāgata, is established as a Perfectly Enlightened Buddha because he has no need of a guide in his previous lives, in the scriptures, or in reasoning.

original: Na hi sammāsambussa pubbacaraṇādīhi attho atthi sabbattha appaṭihatañāṇacāratāya
analyzed: na hi sammāsambussa pubba caraṇa ādīhi atthaḥ atthi sabbattha a paṭihata ñāṇa cāra tāya
translated: For a Perfectly Enlightened Buddha has no need of a guide in his previous lives, etc., because his knowledge extends everywhere without obstruction,

original: ekappamāṇattā ca ñeyyadhammesu. Tathā ācariyamuṭṭhidhammamacchariyasāsanasāvakānānurāgābhāvato
analyzed: eka ppamāṇa ttā ca ñeyya dhammesu tathā
translated: and because he is the one and only measure in regard to things to be known. Likewise, he is established as one whose cankers are destroyed because he has no need of a teacher, of a guide, of the scriptures, of envy, of the Dispensation, or of disciples.

original: khīṇāsavabhāvasiddhi. Na hi sabbaso khīṇāsavassa te sambhavantīti suvisuddhassa parānuggahappavatti.🔽Evaṃ desakasaṃkilesabhūtānaṃ diṭṭhisīlasampadādūsakānaṃ avijjātaṇhānaṃ accantābhāvasaṃsūcakehi
analyzed: na hi sabbasas khīṇāsavassa te sambhavanti iti su visuddhassa para anuggaha ppavatti  evam desaka saṃkilesa bhūtānam diṭṭhi sīla sampadā dūsakānam avijjā taṇhānam accanta abhāva saṃsūcakehi
translated: For these do not occur in one whose cankers are completely destroyed. Thus his purity is very evident, and he is one who acts for the welfare of others.

original: ñāṇappahānasampadābhibyañjanakehi ca sambuddhavisuddhabhāvehi purimavesārajjadvayasiddhi,
analyzed: ñāṇa ppahāna sampadā abhibyañjanakehi ca sambuddha visuddha bhāvehi
translated: In this way, the first two kinds of fearlessness are established by the two kinds of purity of a Perfectly Enlightened Buddha, which respectively show the utter absence of the defilements and the subsidiary defilements, which are the soil of the corruption of the country, and the possession of the perfection of knowledge and relinquishment.

original: tato ca antarāyikaniyyānikadhammesu sammohābhāvasiddhito pacchimavesārajjadvayasiddhīti
analyzed: tatas ca antarāyika niyyānika dhammesu sammoha abhāva siddhito pacchima vesārajja dvaya siddhi iti
translated: And then, since there is no confusion about the factors that are hindrances and the factors that are emancipations, the last two kinds of perfect confidence are established.

original: bhagavato catuvesārajjasamannāgamo attahitaparahitappaṭipatti ca nidānavacanena pakāsitā🔽hoti. Tattha tattha sampattaparisāya ajjhāsayānurūpaṃ ṭhānuppattikappaṭibhānena dhammadesanādīpanato,
analyzed: bhagavato catu vesārajja samannāgamaḥ atta hita para hita paṭipatti ca nidāna vacanena pakāsitā  hoti tattha tattha sampatta parisāya ajjhāsayā anurūpam ṭhāna uppattika paṭibhānena dhamma desanā dīpanato
translated: Thus the Blessed One’s endowment with the four kinds of perfect confidence and his practice for the benefit of himself and others are revealed by the words of the introduction.🔽For the introduction shows how the Blessed One teaches the Dhamma by answering questions that arise in the course of discussion in accordance with the dispositions of the assembly present on that occasion.

original: idha pana rūpagarukānaṃ puggalānaṃ ajjhāsayānurūpaṃ ṭhānuppattikappaṭibhānena dhammadesanādīpanatoti🔽yojetabbaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ – “satthusampattippakāsanatthaṃ nidānavacana”nti.
analyzed: idha pana rūpa garukānam puggalānam ajjhāsayā anurūpam ṭhāna uppattika paṭibhānena dhamma desanā dīpanato ti  yojetabbam tena vuttam satthu sampatti pakāsana tham nidāna vacanan ti
translated: But here it should be understood that the introduction shows how the Blessed One teaches the Dhamma by answering questions that arise in the course of discussion in accordance with the dispositions of those who are fond of form.🔽Hence it is said: “The words of the introduction are spoken for the purpose of showing the excellence of the Master.”

original: Tathā sāsanasampattippakāsanatthaṃ nidānavacanaṃ. Ñāṇakaruṇāpariggahitasabbakiriyassa
analyzed: tathā sāsana sampatti pakāsana ttham nidāna vacanam ñāṇa karuṇā pariggahita sabba kiriyassa
translated: Likewise, the words of the introduction are spoken for the purpose of showing the excellence of the Dispensation.

original: hi bhagavato natthi niratthakā paṭipatti, attahitatthā vā. Tasmā paresaṃ eva atthāya
analyzed: hi bhagavataḥ natthi niratthakā paṭipatti atta hita tthā vā tasmā paresam eva atthāya
translated: For the Blessed One, whose every act is imbued with knowledge and compassion, has no practice that is purposeless or directed only to his own benefit. Therefore his practice is only for the benefit of others.

original: pavattasabbakiriyassa sammāsambuddhassa sakalampi kāyavacīmanokammaṃ yathāpavattaṃ🔽vuccamānaṃ diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaparamatthehi yathārahaṃ sattānaṃ anusāsanaṭṭhena
analyzed: pavatta sabba kiriyassa sammāsambuddhassa sakalam pi kāya vacī manaḥ kammam yathāpavattam  vuccamānam diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika paramatthehi yathāraham sattānam anusāsana ṭṭhena
translated: The entire physical, verbal, and mental activity of the Perfectly Enlightened One, as it occurs,

original: sāsanaṃ, na kapparacanā. Tayidaṃ satthucaritaṃ kāladesadesakaparisāpadesehi saddhiṃ
analyzed: sāsanam na kappa racanā tayā idam satthu caritam kāla desa desaka parisā apadesehi saddhim
translated: is called the Dispensation in the sense of being the teaching of beings in accordance with their needs, with reference to the highest good of this life and the life to come. It is not a mere composition. This conduct of the Teacher, together with the time, place, company, and discourse,

original: tattha tattha nidānavacanehi yathārahaṃ pakāsīyati. “Idha pana rūpagarukānaṃ puggalāna”ntiādi
analyzed: tattha tattha nidāna vacanehi yathāraham pakāsīyati idha pana rūpa garukānam puggalān antiādi
translated: is revealed here and there in the Nidānas in accordance with the circumstances. “Herein, with regard to those who esteem form” —

original: sabbaṃ purimasadisameva. Tena vuttaṃ – “sāsanasampattippakāsanatthaṃ nidānavacana”nti.
analyzed: sabbam purima sadisam eva tena vuttam sāsana sampatti pakāsana tham nidāna vacanan ti
translated: all this is as in the previous sutta. Therefore it is said: “The Nidāna is stated for the purpose of showing the excellence of the Dispensation.”

original: Apica satthuno pamāṇabhāvappakāsanena vacanena sāsanassa pamāṇabhāvadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: apica satthuno pamāṇa bhāva ppakāsanena vacanena sāsanassa pamāṇa bhāva dassana attham
translated: Moreover, the Nidāna is stated for the purpose of showing the excellence of the Dispensation by means of a statement that shows the excellence of the Teacher.

original: nidānavacanaṃ, tañca desakappamāṇabhāvadassanaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayānusārena “bhagavā”ti
analyzed: nidāna vacanam tat ca desa kappamāṇa bhāva dassanam heṭṭhā vutta naya anusārena bhagavā ti
translated: And the showing of the excellence of the time and the place is done by the words “the Blessed One”🔽in accordance with the method stated above.

original: ca iminā padena vibhāvitanti veditabbaṃ. Bhagavāti hi tathāgatassa rāgadosamohādisabbakilesamaladuccaritadosappahānadīpanena
analyzed: ca iminā padena vibhāvitan ti veditabbam bhagavā ati hi tathāgatassa rāga dosa moha ādi sabba kilesa mala duccarita dosa ppahāna dīpanena
translated: and this is what is shown by the word “Blessed.” For the meaning of “Blessed” is shown in every way by the word “accomplished,” which shows the abandonment of all the defilements such as lust, hate, and delusion, and of the evil-doing of the three doors ,

original: vacanena anaññasādhāraṇasuparisuddhañāṇakaruṇādiguṇavisesayogaparidīpanena tato eva
analyzed: vacanena anañña sādhāraṇa su parisuddha ñāṇa karuṇā ādi guṇa visesa yoga paridīpanena tatas eva
translated: and by the word “fully awakened,” which shows the possession of the special qualities of knowledge and compassion, etc., that are not shared by others,🔽and by the word “fortunate,” which shows that he is the most excellent of all beings. This is the mere beginning of the explanation of the purpose of the words of the introduction.

original: sabbasattuttamabhāvadīpanena ayamattho sabbathā pakāsito hotīti. Idamettha nidānavacanappayojanassa🔽mukhamattanidassanaṃ.🔽Nikkhittassāti desitassa. Desanā hi desetabbassa sīlādiatthassa veneyyasantānesu
analyzed: sabba sattuttama bhāva dīpanena ayam attho sabbathā pakāsitaḥ hoti iti idam ettha nidāna vacana ppayojanassa  mukha matta nidassanam  nikkhittassa ati desitassa desanā hi desetabbassa sīla ādi atthassa veneyya santānesu
translated: “The meaning of the words of the introduction is to be discerned”: the meaning of the words of the introduction should be discerned.🔽“The meaning of the words of the introduction is to be discerned”: the meaning of the words of the introduction should be discerned.🔽“The meaning of the words of the introduction is to be discerned”: the meaning of the words of the introduction should be discerned.🔽“The meaning of the words of the introduction is to be discerned”: the meaning of the words of the introduction should be discerned.

analyzed: desanāya samuṭṭhāne dassite suttassa sammadeva nidāna parijānanena vaṇṇanāya su viññeyya ttā
translated: “The meaning of the words of the introduction is to be discerned”: the meaning of the words of the introduction should be discerned.🔽“The meaning of

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha yathā anekasataanekasahassabhedānipi suttantāni saṃkilesabhāgiyādipaṭṭhānanayavasena
analyzed: vuttam tattha yathā aneka sata aneka sahassa bhedāni pi suttantāni saṃkilesa bhāgiya ādi paṭṭhāna naya vasena
translated: This has been said. Herein, just as the sutta-texts, though classed in many hundreds of thousands, do not exceed the sixteen kinds of promulgation beginning with the promulgation of corruption ,

original: soḷasavidhataṃ nātivattanti, evaṃ attajjhāsayādisuttanikkhepavasena catubbidhabhāvanti🔽āha – “cattāro hi suttanikkhepā”ti. Ettha ca yathā attajjhāsayassa aṭṭhuppattiyā
analyzed: na ativattanti evam  āha cattāro hi sutta nikkhepā ti ettha ca yathā aṭṭhuppattiyā
translated: so too the four kinds of meditation do not exceed the four kinds of sutta-preface beginning with the preface concerned with what is familiar to oneself.🔽So he said: “For there are four kinds of sutta-preface” .

original: ca parajjhāsayapucchāhi saddhiṃ saṃsaggabhedo sambhavati “attajjhāsayo ca parajjhāsayo
analyzed: ca parajjhāsaya pucchāhi saddhim saṃsagga bhedo sambhavati ca parajjhāsayo
