original: ca, attajjhāsayo ca pucchāvasiko ca, aṭṭhuppattiko ca parajjhāsayo ca, aṭṭhuppattiko🔽ca pucchāvasiko cā”ti ajjhāsayapucchānusandhisabbhāvato, evaṃ yadipi aṭṭhuppattiyā
analyzed: ca attajjhāsayo ca pucchāvasiko ca aṭṭhuppattiko ca parajjhāsayo ca aṭṭhuppattiko  ca pucchāvasiko ca ati ajjhāsaya puccha anusandhi sabbhāvato evam yadi api aṭṭhuppattiyā
translated: the preface concerned with what is familiar to oneself and the preface concerned with a question, the preface concerned with an existing fact and the preface concerned with what is familiar to another, the preface concerned with an existing fact and the preface concerned with a question” ,

original: attajjhāsayenapi saṃsaggabhedo sambhavati, attajjhāsayādīhi pana purato ṭhitehi aṭṭhuppattiyā
analyzed: saṃsagga bhedaḥ sambhavati atta jhāsaya ādīhi pana puratas ṭhitehi aṭṭhuppattiyā
translated: so too, although the distinction of association is possible with the origin-of-what-is-familiar-to-oneself and with the other three kinds of preface, namely, the preface concerned with what is familiar to oneself, the preface concerned with a question, and the preface concerned with an existing fact, since the four are combined in the following way: “The origin-of-what-is-familiar-to-oneself and the preface concerned with what is familiar to oneself,🔽the origin-of-what-is-familiar-to-oneself and the preface concerned with a question, the origin-of-what-is-familiar-to-oneself and the preface concerned with an existing fact, the origin-of-what-is-familiar-to-oneself and the preface concerned with what is familiar to another” ,

original: saṃsaggo natthīti na idha niravaseso vitthāranayo sambhavatīti “cattāro suttanikkhepā”ti
analyzed: saṃsaggo natthi iti na idha niravasesaḥ vitthāra nayo sambhavati iti cattāro sutta nikkhepā ti
translated: The method of exposition in detail is not possible here in full, since there is no connection. So it is said: “There are four kinds of suttas that are introductions.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tadantogadhattā vā sesanikkhepānaṃ mūlanikkhepavasena cattārova dassitā.
analyzed: vuttam vā sesa nikkhepānam mūla nikkhepa vasena cattāro eva dassitā
translated: Or alternatively, the other introductions are shown as four only, since they are included in the root introduction.

original: Yathādassanañhettha ayaṃ saṃsaggabhedo gahetabboti.🔽Tatrāyaṃ vacanattho – nikkhipīyatīti nikkhepo, suttaṃ eva nikkhepo suttanikkhepo.
analyzed: yathādassanam ha ittha ayam saṃsagga bhedaḥ gahetabbo ti  tatra ayam vacana atthaḥ nikkhipīyati iti nikkhepaḥ suttam eva nikkhepaḥ sutta nikkhepaḥ
translated: For the classification of connection should be understood here according to the way it is seen.🔽Herein, the meaning of the words is this: it is an introduction because it is introduced , thus it is an introduction . A sutta is an introduction, thus it is a sutta-introduction .

original: Atha vā nikkhipanaṃ nikkhepo, suttassa nikkhepo suttanikkhepo, suttadesanāti attho.
analyzed: atha vā nikkhipanam nikkhepaḥ suttassa nikkhepaḥ sutta nikkhepaḥ sutta desanā ati attho
translated: Or alternatively, it is an introduction of a sutta, thus it is a sutta-introduction ; the meaning is that it is a teaching of a sutta.

original: Attano ajjhāsayo attajjhāsayo, so assa atthi kāraṇabhūtoti attajjhāsayo. Attano ajjhāsayo
analyzed: attanaḥ ajjhāsayo attajjhāsayo so assa atthi kāraṇa bhūto ti attajjhāsayo attanaḥ ajjhāsayo
translated: One’s own inclination is one’s own inclination . It has that as its reason, thus it is one with one’s own inclination .

original: etassāti vā attajjhāsayo. Parajjhāsayepi eseva nayo. Pucchāya vaso pucchāvaso, so
analyzed: etassa ati vā esā iva nayo pucchāya vaso pucchāvaso so
translated: Or alternatively, it is one’s own inclination that is one with one’s own inclination . The same method applies in the case of another’s inclination . It has the power of the question, thus it is one that has the power of the question .

original: etassa atthīti pucchāvasiko. Suttadesanāvatthubhūtassa atthassa uppatti atthuppatti,
analyzed: etassa atthi iti pucchāvasiko sutta desanā vatthu bhūtassa atthassa uppatti atthuppatti
translated: The occurrence of the meaning that is the basis for the teaching of the sutta is the occurrence of the meaning .

original: atthuppattiyeva aṭṭhuppatti ttha-kārassa ṭṭha-kāraṃ katvā. Sā etassa atthīti aṭṭhuppattiko.
analyzed: atthuppattiyā iva aṭṭhuppatti tthakārassa ṭṭhakāram katvā sā etassa atthi iti aṭṭhuppattikaḥ
translated: The arising of the meaning is the arising of the ground for the question, which is the ground for the question when the letter ṭṭha is taken as the letter ṭha. He has that, thus he is one who has the arising of the ground for the question.

original: Atha vā nikkhipīyati suttaṃ etenāti suttanikkhepo, attajjhāsayādi eva. Etasmiṃ atthavikappe
analyzed: atha vā nikkhipīyati suttam etena ati sutta nikkhepaḥ eva etasmin attha vikappe
translated: Or alternatively, the meaning is: the Thread is laid down by this, thus it is a Thread-laying; the personal inclination, etc., are that.

original: attano ajjhāsayo attajjhāsayo. Paresaṃ ajjhāsayo parajjhāsayo. Pucchīyatīti pucchā,
analyzed: attanaḥ ajjhāsayo attajjhāsayo paresam ajjhāsayo parajjhāsayo pucchīyati iti pucchā
translated: In this interpretation of the meaning, his own inclination is personal inclination. Another’s inclination is other’s inclination. It is asked, thus it is a question.

original: pucchitabbo attho. Pucchāvasena pavattaṃ dhammappaṭiggāhakānaṃ vacanaṃ pucchāvasikaṃ,
analyzed: pucchitabbaḥ atthaḥ pucchā vasena pavattam dhamma ppaṭiggāhakānam vacanam pucchāvasikam
translated: The meaning is what is asked. The speech of the questioners that occurs by way of the question is what is based on the question.

original: tadeva nikkhepasaddāpekkhāya pulliṅgavasena vuttaṃ – “pucchāvasiko”ti. Tathā aṭṭhuppatti
analyzed: tat eva nikkhepa sadda apekkhāya pulliṅga vasena vuttam pucchāvasikaḥ ti tathā aṭṭhuppatti
translated: That same is said in the feminine as “what is based on the question” in the sense of the word “laying” looking for a noun in the feminine. Likewise the arising of the ground for the question

original: eva aṭṭhuppattikoti evamettha attho veditabbo.🔽Apicettha paresaṃ indriyaparipākādikāraṇanirapekkhattā attajjhāsayassa visuṃ suttanikkhepabhāvo
analyzed: eva aṭṭhuppattikaḥ ti evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbo  api ca ittha paresam indriya paripāka ādi kāraṇa nirapekkha ttā visum sutta nikkhepa bhāvo
translated: is the one who has the arising of the ground for the question. This is how the meaning should be understood here.🔽And here the personal inclination is a Thread-laying by itself because it is independent of any cause such as the ripening of faculties in others.

original: yutto kevalaṃ attano ajjhāsayeneva dhammatantiṭṭhapanatthaṃ pavattitadesanattā. Parajjhāsayapucchāvasikānaṃ
analyzed: yuttaḥ kevalam attanaḥ ajjhāsayena iva dhamma tanti ṭṭhapana attham pavatti ta desana ttā para jjhāsaya pucchāvasikānam
translated: It is fitting that it should be so because it occurs only for the purpose of establishing the True Idea according to one’s own inclination. As for the other’s inclination and what is based on the question,

original: pana paresaṃ ajjhāsayapucchānaṃ desanāpavattihetubhūtānaṃ uppattiyaṃ pavattitānaṃ🔽kathamaṭṭhuppattiyā anavarodho, pucchāvasikaaṭṭhuppattikānaṃ vā parajjhāsayānurodhena
analyzed: pana paresam ajjhāsaya pucchānam desanā pavatti hetu bhūtānam uppattiyam  katham aṭṭhuppattiyāḥ anavarodhaḥ pucchāvasika aṭṭhuppattikānam vā parajjhāsayā anurodhena
translated: But in the case of the arising of those that are the cause for the occurrence of the teaching to those who ask about the thoughts of others,🔽how is there no obstruction to the arising of the Thread? Or, in the case of those that have the arising of the Thread due to the question, in accordance with the thoughts of others,🔽🔽

original: pavattitānaṃ kathaṃ parajjhāsaye anavarodhoti? Na codetabbametaṃ. Paresañhi abhinīhāraparipucchādivinimuttasseva🔽suttadesanākāraṇuppādassa aṭṭhuppattibhāvena gahitattā parajjhāsayapucchāvasikānaṃ🔽visuṃ gahaṇaṃ. Tathā hi brahmajāladhammadāyādasuttādīnaṃ vaṇṇāvaṇṇaāmisuppādādidesanānimittaṃ🔽“aṭṭhuppattī”ti vuccati. Paresaṃ pucchaṃ vinā ajjhāsayaṃ eva nimittaṃ katvā desito
analyzed: katham anavarodhaḥ iti na codetabbam etam paresam hi abhinīhāra paripuccha ādi vinimuttassa iva  sutta desanā kāraṇa uppādassa aṭṭhuppatti bhāvena gahita ttā  visum gahaṇam tathā hi brahmajāla dhamma dāyāda sutta ādīnam vaṇṇa avaṇṇa āmisa uppāda ādi desanā nimittam  aṭṭhuppattī iti vuccati paresam puccham vinā ajjhāsayam eva nimittam katvā desito
translated: But how is there no contradiction in the arising of the Thread, which is the cause of the teaching’s occurrence, in the questioning of others’ intentions? Or how is there no contradiction in the occurrence of the Thread, which arises owing to the questioning of others, in accordance with others’ intentions? It should not be objected that this is so. For the occurrence of the Thread is taken as the cause of the teaching’s occurrence only in the case of one who has no need of urging or questioning, etc.,

original: parajjhāsayo, pucchāvasena desito pucchāvasikoti pākaṭoyamatthoti. Attano ajjhāsayeneva
analyzed: para ajjhāsayo pucchā vasena desito pucchāvasikaḥ ti pākaṭaḥ yam attho ti attanaḥ ajjhāsayena iva
translated: and so it is taken separately from the questioning of others’ intentions and the questioning of others. For thus the teaching of the Brahmajala, the Dhamma- dayada, and other Threads, which have as their reason for teaching the arising of the Thread, the arising of the Thread, is called ‘ the arising of the Thread’ owing to the arising of the Thread. The teaching given by the Blessed One without any question from others, but with the intention of others as the reason, is ‘ according to others’ intentions ‘ . The teaching given by the Blessed One in response to a question is ‘ according to the questioning of others ‘ . This is the meaning that is evident here. The teaching given by the Blessed One according to his own intention is ‘ according to his own intention ‘ .

original: kathesīti dhammatantiṭṭhapanatthaṃ kathesi. Vimuttiparipācanīyā dhammā saddhindriyādayo.
analyzed: kathesi iti dhamma tanti ṭṭhapana attham kathesi vimutti paripācanīyāḥ dhammā saddhi indriya ādayaḥ
translated: He spoke for the purpose of establishing the Dhamma. The ideas that ripen in liberation are the faith faculty, etc.

original: Ajjhāsayanti adhimuttiṃ. Khantinti diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiṃ. Mananti paññatticittaṃ.
analyzed: ajjhāsayanti adhimuttim khantin ti diṭṭhi nijjhāna khantim mananti paññatti cittam
translated: Inclination: resolution. Acceptance: acceptance of views and of knowledge. Mind: the mind of the rule.

original: Abhinīhāranti paṇidhānaṃ. Bujjhanabhāvanti bujjhanasabhāvaṃ, paṭivijjhanākāraṃ vā.
analyzed: abhinīhāranti paṇidhānam bujjhana bhāvanti bujjhana sabhāvam paṭivijjhana ākāram vā
translated: Aim: aspiration. The state of awakening: the state of awakening, or the mode of penetrating.

original: Rūpagarukānanti pañcasu ārammaṇesu rūpārammaṇagarukā rūpagarukā. Cittena rūpaninnā
analyzed: pañcasu ārammaṇesu rūpa ārammaṇa garukā rūpa garukā cittena rūpa ninnā
translated: Who are fond of form: who are fond of form among the five objects, who are fond of the object form, who are drawn by the mind to form,

original: rūpapoṇā rūpapabbhārā rūpadassanappasutā rūpena ākaḍḍhitahadayā, tesaṃ rūpagarukānaṃ.
analyzed: rūpa poṇāḥ rūpa pabbhārāḥ rūpa dassana ppasutāḥ rūpena ākaḍḍhita hadayā tesam rūpa garukānam
translated: who are inclined to form, who are attached to form, who are intent on seeing form, who have their hearts drawn out by form. For those who are fond of form.

original: Paṭisedhatthoti paṭikkhepattho. Kassa pana paṭikkhepatthoti? Kiriyāpadhānañhi vākyaṃ,🔽tasmā “na samanupassāmī”ti samanupassanākiriyāpaṭisedhattho. Tenāha – “imassa pana
analyzed: paṭisedha tthaḥ ti paṭikkhepa tthaḥ kassa pana paṭikkhepa tthaḥ ti kiriyā padhānam hi vākyam  tasmā na samanupassāmi iti samanupassanā kiriyā paṭisedha atthaḥ tena āha imassa pana
translated: For the purpose of rejecting: for the purpose of denial. But whose denial? For the sentence is the principal verb.

original: padassā”tiādi. Yo paro na hoti, so attāti lokasamaññāmattasiddhaṃ sattasantānaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: padassa atiādi yaḥ paraḥ na hoti saḥ attā iti loka samaññā matta siddham satta santānam sandhāya
translated: Therefore the meaning is the denial of the act of seeing in “I do not see.” Hence he said: “The meaning of this word” , etc. The “self” that is not another is the continuity of being established by mere social usage.

original: – “aha”nti satthā vadati, na bāhirakaparikappitaṃ ahaṃkāravisayaṃ ahaṃkārassa bodhimūleyeva
analyzed: aham ti satthā vadati na bāhiraka parikappitam ahaṃkāra visayam ahaṃkārassa
translated: “I” is what the Teacher says, not the object of the conceit “I am,” which is imagined by outsiders.

original: samucchinnattā. Lokasamaññānatikkamantā eva hi buddhānaṃ lokiye visaye desanāpavatti.
analyzed: samucchinna ttā loka samaññā an atikkamantā eva hi buddhānam lokiye visaye desanā pavatti
translated: “I” : the Teacher speaks thus, not the externalist’s invented sphere of conceit, since conceit was uprooted at the root of the tree of enlightenment. For the teaching of the Buddhas occurs only in the world’s range of ideas, not transcending the world’s conventions.

original: Bhikkhaveti ālapane kāraṇaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva. Aññanti apekkhāsiddhattā aññatthassa
analyzed: bhikkhave ti ālapane kāraṇam heṭṭhā vuttam eva aññan ti apekkhā siddha ttā aññatthassa
translated: “Bhikkhus” : the reason for the address has been given above. “Another” : since the meaning of “another” is established by implication,

original: “idāni vattabbaitthirūpato añña”nti āha. Ekampi rūpanti ekaṃ vaṇṇāyatanaṃ. Samaṃ🔽visamaṃ sammā yāthāvato anu anu passatīti samanupassanā, ñāṇaṃ. Saṃkilissanavasena🔽anu anu passatīti samanupassanā, diṭṭhi. No niccatoti ettha iti-saddo ādiattho, evamādikoti
analyzed: idāni vattabba aitthi rūpataḥ aññanti āha ekam pi rūpanti ekam vaṇṇa āyatanam samam  visamam sammā yāthāvataḥ anu anu passati iti samanupassanā ñāṇam saṃkilissana vasena  anu anu passati iti samanupassanā diṭṭhi no niccatas ti ettha iti saddaḥ ādi attho evam ādiko ti
translated: he says, “other than the woman’s form that should be spoken of now.” “A single form” : a single base consisting of visible form.

original: attho. Tena “dukkhato samanupassatī”ti evamādīni saṅgaṇhāti. Olokentopīti devamanussavimānakapparukkhamaṇikanakādigatāni
analyzed: atthaḥ tena dukkhataḥ samanupassati iti evamādīni saṅgaṇhāti olokentaḥ api iti deva manussa vimāna kappa rukkha maṇi kanaka ādi gatāni
translated: “Contemplating” : seeing, observing, is “contemplation” , which is knowledge. “Contemplating” in the sense of defilement is “contemplation” , which is view. “Not as self” : here the word “as” has the meaning of “in such a way as,” thus the meaning is “in such a way as beginning with.” Therefore it includes such passages as “He contemplates as suffering” . “Looking on” : the visible forms of gods, men, mansions, celestial wishing trees, gems, gold, etc.

original: rūpāni anavasesaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇena olokentopi. Sāmaññavacanopi yaṃ-saddo “ekarūpampī”ti
analyzed: rūpāni anavasesam sabbaññuta ññāṇena olokentaḥ api sāmañña vacanaḥ api yaṃ saddaḥ eka rūpam pi iti
translated: The word ‘yaṃ’ in the expression ‘ekarūpampi yaṃ’ is a demonstrative pronoun.🔽The word ‘rūpa’ is used because the object of the word ‘yaṃ’ is form.

original: rūpassa adhigatattā rūpavisayo icchitoti “yaṃ rūpa”nti vuttaṃ. Tathā purisasaddo
analyzed: rūpassa adhigata ttā rūpa visayaḥ icchito ti yam rūpan ti vuttam tathā purisa saddaḥ
translated: Similarly, the word ‘purisa’ is used because the object of the word ‘yaṃ’ is a person.

original: pariyādiyitabbacittapuggalavisayoti rūpagarukassāti visesitaṃ. Gahaṇaṃ “khepana”nti
analyzed: rūpa garukassa ati visesitam gahaṇam khepananti
translated: The word ‘rūpagarukassa’ is used to specify the object of the word ‘yaṃ’ as a person who is a connoisseur of form.🔽The word ‘khepana’ is intended to mean ‘grasping’, and the word ‘pariyādāna’ is intended to mean ‘preventing arising’.

original: ca adhippetaṃ, pariyādānañca uppattinivāraṇanti āha – “catubhūmakakusalacitta”nti.
analyzed: ca adhippetam pariyādānam ca uppatti nivāraṇan ti āha catu bhūmaka kusala cittam ti
translated: Therefore the author of the commentary says: ‘Having grasped a form with a wholesome consciousness belonging to the four planes.’

original: Tañhi rūpaṃ tādisassa parittakusalassapi uppattiṃ nivāreti, kimaṅgaṃ pana mahaggatānuttaracittassāti🔽lokuttarakusalacittassapi uppattiyā nivāraṇaṃ hotuṃ samatthaṃ, lokiyakusaluppattiyā
analyzed: tat hi rūpam tādisassa paritta kusalassa api uppattim nivāreti kim aṅgam pana mahaggata anuttara cittassa ati  lokuttara kusala cittassa api uppattiyāḥ nivāraṇam hotum samattham lokiya kusala uppattiyā
translated: For that form prevents the arising of even a limited wholesome consciousness of that kind, how much more so of a sublime or supramundane consciousness?

original: nivārakatte vattabbameva natthīti “catubhūmakakusalacittaṃ pariyādiyitvā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nivāraka tte vattabbam eva natthi iti catu bhūmaka kusala cittam pariyādiyitvā iti vuttam
translated: Therefore it is said: ‘Having grasped a form with a wholesome consciousness belonging to the four planes.’

original: Na hi kāmaguṇassādappasutassa purisassa dānādivasena savipphārikā kusaluppatti sambhavati.
analyzed: na hi purisassa dāna ādi vasena sa vipphārikā kusala uppatti sambhavati
translated: For a person who is addicted to the enjoyment of the sense pleasures, the arising of wholesome consciousness accompanied by the jhānas is impossible through giving, etc.

original: Gaṇhitvā khepetvāti attānaṃ assādetvā pavattamānassa akusalacittassa paccayo hontaṃ
analyzed: gaṇhitvā khepetvā ati attānam assādetvā pavattamānassa akusala cittassa paccayaḥ hontam
translated: It stands by holding and by driving away: it stands by being a condition for the unprofitable consciousness that occurs delighting in itself,

original: pavattinivāraṇena muṭṭhigataṃ viya gahetvā anuppādanirodhena khepetvā viya tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: pavatti nivāraṇena muṭṭhi gatam viya gahetvā anuppāda nirodhena khepetvā viya tiṭṭhati
translated: by preventing its occurrence, as if by holding it fast, and by driving it away as if by banishing it, by preventing its arising and cessation.

original: Tāva mahati lokasannivāse tassa pariyādiyaṭṭhānaṃ avicchedato labbhatīti āha – “tiṭṭhatī”ti
analyzed: tāva mahati loka sannivāse tassa pariyādiya ṭṭhānam avicchedataḥ labbhati iti āha tiṭṭhati iti
translated: It is possible to say that it stands in the great world of beings without interruption, without leaving a gap, as if it were covering it, which is why he said “it stands.”

original: yathā “pabbatā tiṭṭhanti, najjo sandantī”ti. Tenāha – “idha ubhayampi vaṭṭatī”tiādi.🔽Yathayidanti sandhivasena ākārassa rassattaṃ yakārāgamo cāti āha – “yathā ida”nti.🔽Itthiyā rūpanti itthisarīragataṃ tappaṭibaddhañca rūpāyatanaṃ. Paramatthassa niruḷho,
analyzed: yathā pabbatā tiṭṭhanti najjaḥ sandanti iti tena āha idha ubhayam pi vaṭṭati itiādi  sandhi vasena ākārassa yakāra āgamaḥ ca ati āha yathā  itthiyāḥ itthi sarīra gatam tad paṭibaddham ca rūpa āyatanam paramatthassa niruḷhaḥ
translated: “It stands” is like “mountains stand” and “rivers flow.” That is why he said “both are allowable here.”

original: paṭhamaṃ sādhāraṇato saddasatthalakkhaṇāni vibhāvetabbāni, pacchā asādhāraṇatoti🔽tāni pāḷivasena vibhāvetuṃ – “ruppatīti kho…pe… veditabba”nti āha. Tattha ruppatīti
analyzed: paṭhamam sādhāraṇato sadda sattha lakkhaṇāni vibhāvetabbāni pacchā asādhāraṇato ti 🔽tāni pāḷi vasena vibhāvetum ruppati iti khope veditabbanti āha tattha ruppati iti
translated: As to the way: the way is the mode of the state of being. The letter ya is added to the word yathā in the sense of mode, as in the words yathābhūtaṃ, yathāvasaṃ, yathāpaccayaṃ, yathāvisesaṃ, yathāsamācāraṃ, yathāsamāhitaṃ, yathāsamāpannaṃ, yathāsamuppannaṃ, yathāpaṭiladdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdhaṃ, yathāpaṭividdha

original: sītādivirodhipaccayehi vikāraṃ āpādīyati, āpajjatīti vā attho. Vikāruppatti ca virodhipaccayasannipāte
analyzed: sītā ādi virodhi paccayehi vikāram āpādīyati āpajjati iti vā atthaḥ vikāra uppatti ca virodhi paccaya sannipāte
translated: It is “distorted” by the conditions of the opposite kind, such as cold, etc., or it “goes to distortion,” is the meaning. And the occurrence of distortion is more obvious when there is a concurrence of conditions of the opposite kind.

original: visadisuppatti vibhūtatarā, kuto panāyaṃ visesoti ce? “Sītenā”tiādivacanato. Evañca
analyzed: visadisuppatti vibhūtatarā kutas pana ayam visesaḥ iti ce sītena ati ādi vacanataḥ evam ca
translated: But how is this distinction to be known? From the words “by cold” , etc.

original: katvā vedanādīsu anavasesarūpasamaññā sāmaññalakkhaṇanti sabbarūpadhammasādhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: katvā vedanā ādīsu anavasesa rūpa samaññā sāmañña lakkhaṇan ti sabba rūpa dhamma sādhāraṇam
translated: And in this way the general characteristic of “deformability” is common to all material dhammas, such as feeling, etc.,🔽and is therefore the general characteristic of materiality.

original: rūppanaṃ. Idāni atthuddhāranayena rūpasaddaṃ saṃvaṇṇento “ayaṃ panā”tiādimāha. Rūpakkhandhe
analyzed: rūppanam idāni attha uddhāra nayena rūpa saddam saṃvaṇṇentaḥ ayam pana ati ādim āha rūpa kkhandhe
translated: Now, in the method of the word-commentary, he says “This word ‘rūpa’ occurs” , etc.

original: vattatīti “oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā”tiādivacanato. Rūpūpapattiyāti ettha rūpabhavo
analyzed: vattati iti oḷārikam vā sukhumam vā ati ādi vacanataḥ rūpa upapattiyā ti ettha rūpa bhavaḥ
translated: It occurs in the aggregate of materiality, according to the words “gross or subtle” , etc.🔽In the arising of materiality: here the word “materiality” is a bahuvrīhi compound meaning “the arising of materiality” by elision of the middle term.

original: rūpaṃ uttarapadalopena. Rūpabhavūpapattiyāti ayañhettha attho. Kasiṇanimitteti pathavīkasiṇādisaññite
analyzed: rūpam uttara pada lopena rūpa bhava upapattiyā iti ayam ha ittha attho kasiṇa nimitta iti pathavī kasiṇa ādi saññite
translated: In the sign of the kasiṇa: in the counterpart sign of the earth kasiṇa, etc.

original: paṭibhāganimitte. Rūppati attano phalassa sabhāvaṃ karotīti rūpaṃ, sabhāvahetūti
analyzed: paṭibhāga nimitte attanaḥ phalassa sabhāvam karoti iti rūpam sabhāva hetu uti
translated: It is “material” because it “distorts” , that is, it makes its own fruit its own individual essence .

original: āha – “sarūpā…pe… ettha paccaye”ti. Karacaraṇādiavayavasaṅghātabhāvena rūpīyati nirūpīyatīti
analyzed: āha sarūpa ape ettha paccaya iti kara caraṇa ādi avayava saṅghāta bhāvena rūpīyati nirūpīyati iti
translated: He said: “Material, etc., here in the conditions.” It is material because it is made to be, is made to appear, in the form of a collection of parts such as hands and feet, etc.

original: rūpaṃ, rūpakāyoti āha – “ākāso…pe… ettha sarīre”ti.🔽Rūpayati vaṇṇavikāraṃ āpajjamānaṃ hadayaṅgatabhāvaṃ pakāsetīti rūpaṃ, vaṇṇāyatanaṃ.
analyzed: rūpam rūpa kāyaḥ iti āha ākāsa upe ettha sarīrā iti  rūpayati vaṇṇa vikāram āpajjamānam hadayaṅgata bhāvam pakāseti iti rūpam vaṇṇa āyatanam
translated: He said: “Space, etc., here in the body.”🔽It is material because it makes manifest the state of being in the heart when the change of colour is taking place. It is the visible-data base.

original: Ārohapariṇāhādibhedarūpagataṃ saṇṭhānasampattiṃ nissāya pasādaṃ āpajjamāno rūpappamāṇoti
analyzed: āroha pariṇāha ādi bheda rūpa gatam saṇṭhāna sampattim nissāya pasādam āpajjamānaḥ rūpa ppamāṇaḥ ti
translated: The material form is called “the size of the material form” because the clarity that arises in dependence on the perfection of the shape in the material form, which is classed as height, width, etc., is called “the size of the material form.”🔽He said: “Here in the shape.” In the case of “agreeable visible objects,” etc., the word “visible” has the meaning of “individual essence.”

original: vuttoti āha – “ettha saṇṭhāne”ti. Piyarūpantiādīsu sabhāvattho rūpasaddo. Ādisaddena🔽rūpajjhānādīnaṃ saṅgaho. “Rūpī rūpāni passatī”ti ettha ajjhattaṃ kesādīsu parikammasaññāvasena
analyzed: vuttaḥ iti āha ettha saṇṭhāne iti piya rūpam ti ādīsu sabhāvatthaḥ rūpa saddaḥ ādi saddena  rūpa jhāna ādīnam saṅgahaḥ rūpī rūpāni passati iti ettha ajjhattam kesa ādīsu parikamma saññā vasena
translated: By the word “etc.”🔽the jhāna of the fine-material sphere, etc., are included.

original: paṭiladdharūpajjhānaṃ rūpaṃ, taṃ assa atthīti rūpīti vutto. Itthiyā catusamuṭṭhāne
analyzed: paṭiladdha rūpa jhānam rūpam tam assa atthi iti rūpī iti vuttaḥ itthiyā catu samuṭṭhāne
translated: In the case of “One possessing material form sees material forms,” the jhāna of the fine-material sphere that has been obtained by the perception of reviewing in the head hairs, etc., that are internal is the material form. He is called “possessing material form” because that exists in him. In the case of “The fourfold materiality of a woman,”

original: vaṇṇeti itthisarīrapariyāpannameva rūpaṃ gahitaṃ, tappaṭibaddhavatthālaṅkārādirūpampi
analyzed: vaṇṇa iti itthi sarīra pariyāpannam eva rūpam gahitam tad paṭibaddha vattha alaṅkāra ādi rūpam pi
translated: only the material form included in the woman’s body is taken, and also the material form of the clothes, ornaments, etc., that are bound up with it.

original: pana purisacittassa pariyādāyakaṃ hotīti dassetuṃ – “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Gandhavaṇṇaggahaṇena🔽vilepanaṃ vuttaṃ. Kāmaṃ “asukāya itthiyā pasādhana”nti sallakkhitassa akāyappaṭibaddhassapi
analyzed: pana purisa cittassa pariyādāyakam hoti iti dassetum api ca atiādi vuttam gandha vaṇṇa ggahaṇena  vilepanam vuttam kāmam asukāya itthiyā pasādhananti sallakkhitassa a kāya ppaṭibaddhassa api
translated: But in order to show that it is a condition for the arising of a man’s consciousness, “And further” is said. By the words “scent and colour”🔽ointment is included. Although the colour of something not belonging to the body,

original: vaṇṇo paṭibaddhacittassa purisassa cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭheyya, taṃ pana na ekantikanti
analyzed: vaṇṇo paṭibaddha cittassa purisassa cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭheyya tam pana na ekantikam ti
translated: such as a woman’s adornment, may be a condition for the arising of a man’s consciousness, it is not a fixed condition.

original: ekantikaṃ dassento “kāyappaṭibaddho”tiāha. Upakappatīti cittassa pariyādānāya upakappati.🔽Purimassevāti pubbe vuttaatthasseva daḷhīkaraṇatthaṃ vuttaṃ yathā “dvikkhattuṃ bandhaṃ🔽subandha”nti. Nigamanavasena vā etaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Opammavasena vuttanti “yaṃ
analyzed: ekantikam dassento kāya paṭibaddhaḥ ti āha upakappati iti cittassa pariyādānāya upakappati  purimassa eva āti pubbe vutta atthassa iva daḷhīkaraṇa attham vuttam yathā dvi khattum bandham  su bandhanti nigamana vasena vā etam vuttanti daṭṭhabbam opamma vasena vuttanti yaṃ
translated: Therefore, in order to show a fixed condition, “belonging to the body” is said. “Is a condition” means it is a condition for the arising of a man’s consciousness.🔽“The same as the former” is said in order to strengthen the meaning of the former statement, just as “twice bound” is said to be “well bound.” Or it should be seen as said by way of conclusion. “Said by way of simile” means that the entire former statement, “that which thus remains in the man’s consciousness,”

original: evaṃ purisassa cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī”ti sakalamevidaṃ purimavacanaṃ upamāvasena
analyzed: evam purisassa cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti sakalam eva idam purima vacanam upamā vasena
translated: is said by way of simile.

original: vuttaṃ, tattha pana upamābhūtaṃ atthaṃ dassetuṃ – “yathayidaṃ…pe… itthirūpa”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam tattha pana upamā bhūtam attham dassetum itthi rūpam ti vuttam
translated: But in order to show the meaning of the simile, it is said: “Just as this … the form of a woman.”

original: Pariyādāne ānubhāvo sambhavo pariyādānānubhāvo, tassa dassanavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pariyādāne ānubhāvaḥ sambhavaḥ pariyādāna anubhāvaḥ tassa dassana vasena vuttam
translated: The “power of exhaustion” is the occurrence of the exhaustion of the defilements.

original: Idaṃ pana “itthirūpa”ntiādivacanaṃ pariyādānānubhāve sādhetabbe dīpetabbe vatthu
analyzed: idam pana itthi rūpa nti ādi vacanam pariyādāna anubhāve sādhetabbe dīpetabbe vatthu
translated: The “basis” is the subject matter that should be illustrated and established in the “power of exhaustion.”

original: kāraṇaṃ. Nāgo nāma so rājā, dīghadāṭhikattā pana “mahādāṭhikanāgarājā”ti vutto. Asaṃvaraniyāmenāti
analyzed: kāraṇam nāgaḥ nāma saḥ rājā dīgha dāṭhika ttā pana mahā dāṭhika nāga rājā ati vuttaḥ a saṃvara niyāmena ati
translated: The “king” is the king named Nāga, but he is called “the king of the Nāgas with big tusks” because of his big tusks.🔽The “mode of non-restraint” is the mode of non-restraint by means of the eye-door.

original: cakkhudvārikena asaṃvaranīhārena. Nimittaṃ gahetvāti rāguppattihetubhūtaṃ rūpaṃ subhanimittaṃ
analyzed: cakkhudvārikena asaṃvara nīhārena nimittam gahetvā ati rāga uppatti hetu bhūtam rūpam subha nimittam
translated: “Having taken a sign” means having taken the form that is the cause for the arising of lust, the sign of the beautiful.

original: gahetvā. Visikādassanaṃ gantvāti sivathikadassanaṃ gantvā. Tattha hi ādīnavānupassanā
analyzed: gahetvā visikā dassanam gantvā ati sivathika dassanam gantvā tattha hi ādīnava anupassanā
translated: “Having gone to see a corpse” means having gone to see a charnel ground, for the contemplation of danger arises there.🔽Not believing that death can come to one like her because of greed for the basis, he says,

original: ijjhati. Vatthulobhena kuto tādisāya maraṇanti asaddahanto “mukhaṃ tumhākaṃ dhūmavaṇṇa”nti
analyzed: ijjhati vatthu lobhena kuto asat dahantaḥ mukham tumhākam dhūma vaṇṇanti
translated: “Your faces are smoke-colored,”

original: te daharasāmaṇere uppaṇḍento vadati.
analyzed: te dahara sāmaṇere uppaṇḍentaḥ vadati
translated: mocking those young bhikkhus.

original: Ratanattaye suppasannattā kākavaṇṇatissādīhi visesanatthañca so tissamahārājā saddhāsaddena
analyzed: ratanattaye suppasanna ttā kākavaṇṇa tissa ādīhi visesa nattham ca saḥ tissa mahā rājā saddhā saddena
translated: and because of his great confidence in the Three Jewels, and in order to distinguish him from Tissa the quail-livered king, he is called Tissa the Great, distinguished by his faith.

original: visesetvā vuccati. Daharassa cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatīti adhikāravasena vuttaṃ.🔽Niṭṭhituddesakiccoti gāme asappāyarūpadassanaṃ imassa anatthāya siyāti ācariyena🔽nivāritagāmappaveso pacchā niṭṭhituddesakicco hutvā ṭhito. Tena vuttaṃ – “atthakāmānaṃ
analyzed: visesetvā vuccati daharassa cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti adhikāra vasena vuttam  niṭṭhita uddesa kiccaḥ ti gāme asappāya rūpa dassanam imassa anatthāya siyā ti ācariyena  nivārita gāma ppaveso pacchā niṭṭhita uddesa kicco hutvā ṭhitaḥ tena vuttam attha kāmānam
translated: “It held his mind captive” is said by way of the function of the mind.

original: vacanaṃ aggahetvā”ti. Nivatthavatthaṃ sañjānitvāti attanā diṭṭhadivase nivatthavatthaṃ
analyzed: vacanam aggahetvā iti nivattha vattham sañjānitvā iti attanā diṭṭha divase nivattha vattham
translated: “Having finished his duties as a teacher” means that the teacher had previously prevented him from entering the village, thinking that it would be harmful for him to see improper sights in the village. Later, having finished his duties as a teacher, he remained there. Therefore it is said: “without accepting the advice of those who wished him well.”

original: tassā matadivase sivathikadassanatthaṃ gatena laddhaṃ sañjānitvā. Evampīti evaṃ maraṇasampāpanavasenapi.🔽Ayaṃ tāvettha aṭṭhakathāya anuttānatthadīpanā.🔽Nettinayavaṇṇanā🔽Idāni pakaraṇanayena pāḷiyā atthavaṇṇanaṃ karissāma. Sā pana atthasaṃvaṇṇanā yasmā
analyzed: tassāḥ mata divase sivathika dassana attham gatena laddham sañjānitvā evam pi iti evam maraṇa sampāpana vasena api 🔽ayam tāva ettha aṭṭhakathāya anuttāna attha dīpanā 🔽na itti naya vaṇṇanā 🔽idāni pakaraṇa nayena pāḷiyā attha vaṇṇanam karissāma sā pana attha saṃvaṇṇanā yasmā
translated: “Recognizing the clothes she was wearing” means that he recognized the clothes she was wearing on the day he saw her, which were obtained by someone who had gone to see her corpse in the charnel ground on the day she died. “In this way” means in this way, by bringing about her death.

original: desanāya samuṭṭhānappayojanabhājanesu piṇḍatthesu ca niddhāritesu sukarā hoti suviññeyyā🔽ca, tasmā suttadesanāya samuṭṭhānādīni paṭhamaṃ niddhārayissāma. Tattha samuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: desanāya samuṭṭhāna payojana bhājanesu piṇḍatthesu ca niddhāritesu sukarā hoti su viññeyyā  ca tasmai sutta desanāya samuṭṭhāna ādīni paṭhamam niddhārayissāma tattha samuṭṭhānam
translated: When the meaning of the word “aggregates” has been elucidated in this way, the teaching of the suttas becomes easy to understand and easy to penetrate.

original: nāma desanānidānaṃ, taṃ sādhāraṇamasādhāraṇanti duvidhaṃ. Tattha sādhāraṇampi ajjhattikabāhirabhedato
analyzed: nāma desanā nidānam tam sādhāraṇam asādhāraṇam ti duvidham tattha sādhāraṇam pi ajjhattika bāhira bhedato
translated: Therefore we shall first elucidate the origin, etc., of the teaching of the suttas. Herein, the origin of the teaching is the reason for the teaching. It is twofold, common and uncommon.🔽Herein, the common origin is twofold, internal and external.

original: duvidhaṃ. Tattha sādhāraṇaṃ ajjhattikasamuṭṭhānaṃ nāma lokanāthassa mahākaruṇā. Tāya
analyzed: duvidham tattha sādhāraṇam ajjhattika samuṭṭhānam nāma lokanāthassa mahā karuṇā tāya
translated: Herein, the common internal origin is the Great Compassion of the Lord of the World.

original: hi samussāhitassa bhagavato veneyyānaṃ dhammadesanāya cittaṃ udapādi, yaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: hi samussāhitassa bhagavataḥ veneyyānam dhamma desanāya cittam udapādi yam sandhāya
translated: For the Blessed One’s mind was aroused to teach the Dhamma to his disciples by that Great Compassion,

original: vuttaṃ – “sattesu ca kāruññataṃ paṭicca buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokesī”tiādi. Ettha
analyzed: vuttam sattesu ca kāruñña tam paṭicca buddha cakkhunā lokam volokesi itiādi ettha
translated: which is why it was said: “And he surveyed the world with his Buddha-eye out of compassion for beings” .

original: ca hetāvatthāyapi mahākaruṇāya saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo yāvadeva saṃsāramahoghato saddhammadesanāhatthadānehi
analyzed: ca mahākaruṇāya saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ yāvat eva saṃsāra mahoghato saddhamma desanā hattha dānehi
translated: And here the Great Compassion should be regarded as the reason for the teaching as far as the giving of the gift of the true Dhamma from the great ocean of the round of rebirths.

original: sattasantāraṇatthaṃ taduppattito. Yathā ca mahākaruṇā, evaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ dasabalañāṇādayo🔽ca desanāya abbhantarasamuṭṭhānabhāvena vattabbā. Sabbañhi ñeyyadhammaṃ tesaṃ desetabbākāraṃ
analyzed: satta santāraṇa attham tad uppattitaḥ yathā ca mahākaruṇā evam sabbaññuta ññāṇam dasa bala ñāṇa ādayaḥ  ca desanāya abbhantara samuṭṭhāna bhāvena vattabbā sabbam hi ñeyya dhammam tesam desetabba ākāram
translated: And as with great compassion, so too should all-knowledge, knowledge of the ten powers, etc.,🔽be described as the internal condition for the teaching. For the Blessed One, knowing all knowable dhammas, the way in which they should be taught,

original: sattānañca āsayānusayādiṃ yāthāvato jānanto bhagavā ṭhānāṭṭhānādīsu kosallena veneyyajjhāsayānurūpaṃ
analyzed: āsayā anusaya ādim yāthāvataḥ jānantaḥ bhagavā ṭhāna aṭṭhāna ādīsu kosallena
translated: and the dispositions, latent tendencies, etc., of beings, taught the Dhamma with skill in means, in accordance with the dispositions of those to be trained,

original: vicittanayadesanaṃ pavattesīti. Bāhiraṃ pana sādhāraṇaṃ samuṭṭhānaṃ dasasahassamahābrahmaparivārassa🔽sahampatibrahmuno ajjhesanaṃ. Tadajjhesanuttarakālañhi dhammagambhīratāpaccavekkhaṇājanitaṃ
analyzed: vicitta naya desanam pavattesi iti bāhiram pana sādhāraṇam samuṭṭhānam dasa sahassa mahābrahma parivārassa  sahampati brahmunaḥ ajjhesanam tad ajjhesana uttara kālam hi dhamma gambhīra tā paccavekkhaṇā janitam
translated: by means of the various methods. The external condition, however, which is common to all, is the request of the chief of the Tavatimsa devas, Sahampati, who was accompanied by ten thousand great brahma kings.

original: appossukkataṃ paṭippassambhetvā dhammassāmī dhammadesanāya ussāhajāto ahosi. Asādhāraṇampi
analyzed: appossukkatam paṭippassambhetvā dhammassāmī dhamma desanāya ussāha jātaḥ ahosi a sādhāraṇam pi
translated: For when the Blessed One, after reflecting on the profundity of the Dhamma, had stilled his inclination to inaction, he became eager to teach the Dhamma, having generated the energy to do so. The uncommon condition

original: abbhantarabāhirabhedato duvidhameva. Tattha abbhantaraṃ yāya mahākaruṇāya yena ca
analyzed: abbhantara bāhira bhedataḥ duvidham eva abbhantaram yāya mahākaruṇāya yena ca
translated: is twofold, as internal and external. Herein, the internal condition is the great compassion by which the Blessed One,

original: desanāñāṇena idaṃ suttaṃ pavattitaṃ, tadubhayaṃ veditabbaṃ. Bāhiraṃ pana rūpagarukānaṃ
analyzed: desanā ñāṇena idam suttam pavattitam tat ubhayam veditabbam bāhiram pana rūpa garukānam
translated: and the knowledge of teaching. Both these should be understood. But the external

original: puggalānaṃ ajjhāsayo. Svāyamattho aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vutto eva.
analyzed: puggalānam ajjhāsayo svāyamatthaḥ aṭṭhakathāyam vuttaḥ eva
translated: The knowledge of teaching is the knowledge of the method of teaching. Both these kinds of knowledge should be understood as the internal. But the external is the inclination of those who value form. This meaning is stated in the commentary.

original: Payojanampi sādhāraṇāsādhāraṇato duvidhaṃ. Tattha sādhāraṇaṃ yāva anupādāparinibbānaṃ
analyzed: payojanam pi sādhāraṇa asādhāraṇataḥ duvidham tattha sādhāraṇam yāva anupādā parinibbānam
translated: The purpose is twofold, general and specific. Herein, the general purpose is the attainment of the state of perfect peace through non-clinging,

original: vimuttirasattā bhagavato desanāya. Tenevāha – “etadatthā kathā, etadatthā mantanā”tiādi.
analyzed: vimuttiḥ asattā bhagavataḥ desanāya tena iva āha etad atthā kathā etad atthā mantanā atiādi
translated: which is the end of the Blessed One’s teaching. Hence it is said: “This is the purpose of the talk, this is the purpose of the discussion” , and so on.

original: Asādhāraṇaṃ pana tesaṃ rūpagarukānaṃ puggalānaṃ rūpe chandarāgassa jahāpanaṃ, ubhayampetaṃ🔽bāhirameva. Sace pana veneyyasantānagatampi desanābalasiddhisaṅkhātaṃ payojanaṃ adhippāyasamijjhanabhāvato
analyzed: asādhāraṇam pana tesam rūpa garukānam puggalānam rūpe chanda rāgassa jahāpanam ubhayampetam  bāhiram eva sace pana veneyya santāna gatam pi desanā bala siddhi saṅkhātam payojanam adhippāya samijjhana bhāvato
translated: But the specific purpose is the abandoning of desire and lust for form in those who value form. Both these purposes are external.

original: yathādhippetatthasiddhiyā mahākāruṇikassa bhagavatopi payojanamevāti gaṇheyya, iminā
analyzed: mahā kāruṇikassa bhagavataḥ api payojanam eva ati gaṇheyya iminā
translated: But if the purpose is taken as the success of the teaching power that is inherent in the disciple’s mental continuity, then, since the success of the purpose is the fulfilment of the desired meaning, the purpose belongs to the Blessed One, the Greatly Compassionate One,

original: pariyāyenassa abbhantaratāpi siyā.
analyzed: pariyāyena assa abbhantara tā api siyā
translated: and in this sense it is internal.

original: Apica tesaṃ rūpagarukānaṃ puggalānaṃ rūpasmiṃ vijjamānassa ādīnavassa yāthāvato anavabodho🔽imissā desanāya samuṭṭhānaṃ, tadavabodho payojanaṃ. So hi imāya desanāya bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: apica tesam rūpa garukānam puggalānam rūpasmim vijjamānassa ādīnavassa yāthāvataḥ anavabodhaḥ  imissā desanāya samuṭṭhānam tad avabodho payojanam saḥ hi imāya desanāya bhagavantam
translated: Furthermore, the source of this teaching is the failure of those who are devoted to form to understand as it actually is the danger that exists in form.

original: payojeti tannipphādanaparāyaṃ desanāti katvā. Yañhi desanāya sādhetabbaṃ phalaṃ,
analyzed: payojā iti tad nipphādana parāyam desanā ati katvā yat hi desanāya sādhetabbam phalam
translated: The purpose is the understanding of that. For he urges the Blessed One to teach with the thought, “This is the purpose for which you should teach, namely, the production of that understanding.”

original: taṃ ākaṅkhitabbattā desakaṃ desanāya payojetīti payojananti vuccati. Tathā tesaṃ🔽puggalānaṃ tadaññesañca veneyyānaṃ rūpamukhena pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu ādīnavadassanañcettha
analyzed: tam ākaṅkhitabba ttā desakam desanāya payojeti iti payojanam ti vuccati tathā tesam  puggalānam tad aññesam ca veneyyānam rūpa mukhena pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu ādīnava dassanam ca ittha
translated: For what is to be accomplished by the teaching is called its purpose because it is desired.🔽And the purpose here is the seeing of the danger in the five aggregates as objects of clinging by way of form, etc.,

original: payojanaṃ. Tathā saṃsāracakkanivattisaddhammacakkappavattisassatādimicchāvādanirākaraṇaṃ
analyzed: payojanam tathā

translated: But from here on the sixteen modes of teaching should be shown. Herein, the words “material form” are a designation for all material and immaterial states associated with material form, and for those states bound up with material form, as object, by way of craving. The truth of suffering. The craving that originates that is the truth of origin. The non- occurrence of both is the truth of cessation. The way that understands cessation is the truth of the path. Herein, the origin is the gratification, the truth of suffering is the danger, and the cessation and the path are the escape.

original: sādhetabbaṃ payojanaṃ, taṃ phalanti vuttovāyamattho. Tadatthaṃ hidaṃ suttaṃ bhagavatā

translated: The exhaustion of the unwholesome and wholesome consciousnesses that have material form as their object is the fruit. For the purpose that is to be accomplished by the teaching is the fruit. This is the meaning of the word. For this sutta was spoken by the Blessed One🔽for the purpose of showing the four truths.

original: desitanti. Yathā taṃ kusalacittaṃ na pariyādiyati, evaṃ paṭisaṅkhānabhāvanābalapariggahitā

original: indriyesu guttadvāratā upāyo. Purisassa kusalacittapariyādānenassa rūpassa aññarūpāsādhāraṇatādassanāpadesena

original: dhammānaṃ abhāvanāya padaṭṭhānaṃ, sā sabbassapi saṃkilesapakkhassa parivuddhiyā padaṭṭhānaṃ.

translated: When a woman’s form is looked at unwisely, it is a footing for the faculties’ being unguarded. That is a footing for the non-development of profitable ideas. That is a footing for the increase of the whole side of corruption.

original: Byatirekato pana itthirūpaṃ yoniso olokiyamānaṃ satipaṭṭhānabhāvanāya padaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: byatirekato pana itthi rūpam yonisas olokiyamānam sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanāya padaṭṭhānam
translated: But when a woman’s form is looked at wisely, it is a footing for the development of the foundations of mindfulness.

original: sā bojjhaṅgānaṃ bhāvanāpāripūriyā padaṭṭhānaṃ, sā vijjāvimuttīnaṃ pāripūriyā padaṭṭhānaṃ,🔽kusalassa cittassa pariyādānaṃ sammohābhinivesassa padaṭṭhānaṃ, so saṅkhārānaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: sā bojjhaṅgānam bhāvanā pāripūriyā padaṭṭhānam sā vijjā vimuttīnam pāripūriyā padaṭṭhānam  kusalassa cittassa pariyādānam sammoha abhinivesassa padaṭṭhānam so saṅkhārānam padaṭṭhānam
translated: That is a footing for the fulfilment of the development of the enlightenment factors. That is a footing for the fulfilment of the true knowledge and the deliverance.🔽The exhaustion of profitable cognizance is a footing for the misidentification of what is not the self. That is a footing for determinations.

original: saṅkhārā viññāṇassāti sabbaṃ āvattati bhavacakkaṃ. Byatirekato pana kusalassa cittassa
analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ viññāṇassa ati sabbam āvattati bhava cakkam byatirekato pana kusalassa cittassa
translated: Determinations are a footing for consciousness. So the whole round of becoming revolves. But when a woman’s form is looked at wisely, it is a footing for the development of the foundations of mindfulness.

original: apariyādānaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya pāripūriyā padaṭṭhānanti ayaṃ

translated: The footing for the arising and fulfilment of profitable ideas is the un-exhaustedness of these or those profitable ideas. This, in the first place, is the method in general.

original: tāva avisesato nayo. Visesato pana sīlassa apariyādānaṃ avippaṭisārassa padaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: tāva avisesataḥ nayaḥ visesataḥ pana sīlassa apariyādānam avippaṭisārassa padaṭṭhānam
translated: But in particular, the un-exhaustedness of virtue is the footing for non-remorse,

translated: In the case of ideas stated in the texts, the footing is the ideas that are the footing for them, and the footing for those ideas that are the footing for them, and so on as far as possible.

original: padaṭṭhānabhūtadhammaniddhāraṇalakkhaṇo hi padaṭṭhāno hāro. Vuttañcetaṃ –
analyzed: padaṭṭhāna bhūta dhamma niddhāraṇa lakkhaṇaḥ hi padaṭṭhānaḥ hāraḥ vuttam ca itam
translated: For the characteristic of this Mode of Conveying is the selection of ideas that are a footing. And this is said:

original: “Dhammaṃ deseti jino, tassa ca dhammassa yaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ;
analyzed: dhammam deseti jino tassa ca dhammassa yam padaṭṭhānam
translated: “The Victor teaches the idea, And the footing for that idea,

translated: Thus as far as all ideas, This Mode is the Footing” .

analyzed: padaṭṭhānam ti āsanna kāraṇam idha pana padaṭṭhāna vicāraṇā padaṭṭhāna uti ādi yutti hāre vutta nayena iva veditabbam

analyzed: ajjhattika āyatana bhāvena eka lakkhaṇa ttā evam khandha dhātā ādi vasena api eka lakkhaṇa tā  vattabbā ayam lakkhaṇaḥ hāraḥ lakkhīyanti etena ettha vā eka lakkhaṇa dhammā a vuttā api
translated: So too, it can be said that they are of one characteristic as aggregates, bases, and elements, and so on.🔽This is the Mode of Conveying Characteristics. translated: which is divided into three kinds as “question-connection, intention-connection, and connection by similarity.” Herein, the intention

translated: and the contact is hard to discern. So too, a man with a woman’s form, and the seeing contact there is more weighty🔽than the other kinds and is the root of the rest. That is why, when asked

analyzed: idam eva suttam paṭhamam desesi nibbāna adhigamāya paṭipattiyāḥ ādi resā paṭipatti iti  yam pana ekissā desanāya desana antarena saṃsandanam ayam pi desanā sandhi sā idha

original: abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati, tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya
analyzed: abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati tassa tam abhinandataḥ abhivadataḥ ajjhosāya

He is not released from birth, ageing, and death; from sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair; he is not released from suffering, I say.

translated: The mode of Conveying a Conversion is that of the five categories, the twelve bases, the eighteen elements, etc., and it is this: Conversion by the five categories is as follows: the eye is a category of form, the ear, nose, tongue, and body are categories of form, mind is a category of consciousness, and the rest are categories of mental data. Conversion by the eighteen elements is as follows: the eye is an element of form, the ear, nose, tongue, and body are elements of form, mind is the element consciousness, and the rest are elements of mental data. Conversion by the four truths is as follows: the eye is the truth of suffering, the ear, nose, tongue, and body are the truth of suffering, mind is the truth of suffering, and the rest are the truth of origination. Conversion by the four noble traditions is as follows: the eye is the noble tradition of good manners and good customs, the ear, nose, tongue, and body are the noble tradition of good manners and good customs, mind is the noble tradition of good manners and good customs, and the rest are the noble tradition of right view. Conversion by the four foundations is as follows: the eye is the foundation of truth, the ear, nose, tongue, and body are the foundation of truth, mind is the foundation of truth, and the rest are the foundation of relinquishment. Conversion by the four renunciations is as follows: the eye is the renunciation of the form category, the ear, nose, tongue, and body are the renunciation of the form category, mind is the renunciation of the consciousness category, and the rest are the renunciation of the mental-data category. Conversion by the four fruits is as follows: the eye is the fruit of stream-entry, the ear, nose, tongue, and body are the fruit of stream-entry, mind is the fruit of stream-entry, and the rest are the fruit of the path. Conversion by the four paths is as follows: the eye is the path of stream-entry, the ear, nose, tongue, and body are the path of stream-entry, mind is the path of stream-entry, and the rest are the path of the fruition of stream-entry. original: “Yo ca paṭiccuppādo, indriyakhandhā ca dhātuāyatanā;🔽Etehi otarati yo, otaraṇo nāma so hāro”ti. ;🔽Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave…pe… samanupassāmīti ārambho. Evaṃ purisassa cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatīti
analyzed: yaḥ ca paṭiccuppādaḥ indriya khandhā ca dhātu āyatanā 🔽etehi otarati yaḥ otaraṇaḥ nāma saḥ 🔽na aham bhikkha vepe samanupassāmi iti ārambhaḥ evam purisassa cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: The mode of Conveying a Conversion is that of conversion by way of the categories of aggregates, bases, and elements, etc., as follows. Conversion by way of the aggregates is that of the four aggregates of form, feeling, perception, and determinations, and the five aggregates with the addition of consciousness. Herein, the aggregate of form is the footing for the sign. Conversion by way of the footing for the sign is that of the four kinds of materiality, namely, primary, secondary, bodily- form, and bodily-form-as- characteristic. Herein, the primary is the four great entities and the secondary is the five objects of sense-desire. Conversion by way of the four great entities is that of the four great elementals, earth, water, fire, and air. Conversion by way of the four great elementals is that of the four modes of materiality’s presence, namely, cohesion, distension, caloricity, and oscillation. Conversion by way of the four modes of materiality’s presence is that of the four modes of origination, namely, origination by the seed, by kamma, by temperature, and by nutriment. Conversion by way of the four modes of origination is that of the four modes of materiality’s occurrence, namely, occurrence as the primary elements, as the secondary elements, as bodily-form, and as bodily-form-as- characteristic. Conversion by way of the four modes of materiality’s occurrence is that of the four modes of materiality’s dissolution, namely, dissolution through the exhaustion of the kamma that produced it, through temperature, through the exhaustion of the nutriment that maintains it, and through the exhaustion of both. Conversion by way of the four modes of materiality’s dissolution is that of the four modes of materiality’s non-existence, namely, non-existence of the materiality of the past, of the future, of the external, and of the internal. Conversion by way of the four modes of materiality’s non-existence is that of the four modes of materiality’s non-perception, namely, non-perception of the past, of the future, of the external, and of the internal. Conversion by way of the four modes of materiality’s non-perception is that of the four modes of materiality’s non-attention, namely, non-attention to the past, to the future, to the external, and to the internal. translated: And the strand that leads to the wholesome,

original: Bhūtaṃ tathaṃ avitathaṃ,
analyzed: bhūtam tatham a vitatham
translated: The strand that is real, true, and not otherwise,

original: Tipukkhalaṃ taṃ nayaṃ āhū”ti. ;🔽Vuttanayena gahitesu taṇhāvijjātappakkhiyadhammesu visesato taṇhādiṭṭhīnaṃ vasena🔽asubhe “subha”nti, dukkhe “sukha”nti ca vipallāsā, avijjādiṭṭhīnaṃ vasena anicce
analyzed: tipukkhalam tam nayam āhūti  vutta nayena gahitesu taṇhā vijjāta pakkhiya dhammesu visesataḥ taṇhā diṭṭhīnam vasena  asubhe subhanti dukkhe sukhanti ca vipallāsāḥ avijjā diṭṭhīnam vasena anicce
translated: This method is called the triple strand.”

original: “nicca”nti, anattani “attā”ti vipallāsā veditabbā. Tesaṃ paṭipakkhato kusalacittaggahaṇena
analyzed: niccanti an attani attā ti vipallāsā veditabbā tesam paṭipakkhataḥ kusala citta ggahaṇena
translated: When the states on the side of greed and delusion have been apprehended in the way already described, the perversions should be understood as follows: the perversions of perceiving beauty in the foul and of perceiving pleasure in pain belong to the side of greed; the perversions of perceiving permanence in the impermanent and of perceiving self in the non-self belong to the side of delusion.

original: siddhehi sativīriyasamādhipaññindriyehi cattāri satipaṭṭhānāni siddhāniyeva honti.
analyzed: siddhehi sati vīriya samādhi paññindriyehi cattāri sati paṭṭhānāni honti
translated: When the wholesome consciousnesses have been apprehended by apprehending the states on the side of greed and delusion, the faculties of mindfulness, concentration, and understanding are established by the establishment of the four right kinds of striving.

original: Tattha catūhi indriyehi cattāro puggalā niddisitabbā. Kathaṃ? Duvidho hi taṇhācarito
analyzed: tattha catūhi indriyehi cattāraḥ puggalāḥ niddisitabbā katham duvidhaḥ hi taṇhā caritaḥ
translated: Herein, four kinds of persons should be demonstrated by means of the four faculties. How? For the person of greedy temperament

original: mudindriyo tikkhindriyoti, tathā diṭṭhicarito. Tesu paṭhamo asubhe “subha”nti vipariyesaggāhī
analyzed: tikkhindriyo ti tathā diṭṭhi carito tesu paṭhamaḥ asubhe vipariyesa gāhī
translated: The first of these, who misapprehends what is foul as fair,

original: satibalena yathābhūtaṃ kāyasabhāvaṃ sallakkhento bhāvanābalena taṃ vipallāsaṃ samugghātetvā
analyzed: sati balena yathābhūtam kāya sabhāvam sallakkhentaḥ bhāvanā balena tam vipallāsam samugghātetvā
translated: contemplates the real state of the body’s nature with the strength of mindfulness, and by the strength of development he eradicates that perversion,

original: sammattaniyāmaṃ okkamati. Dutiyo asukhe “sukha”nti vipariyesaggāhī “uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ
analyzed: sammatta niyāmam okkamati dutiyaḥ asukhe sukhanti vipariyesa gāhī uppannam kāma vitakkam
translated: and he enters upon the certainty of rightness. The second, who misapprehends what is painful as pleasant,

original: nādhivāsetī”tiādinā vuttena vīriyasaṃvarabhūtena vīriyabalena paṭipakkhaṃ vinodento
analyzed: na adhivāseti iti ādinā vuttena vīriya saṃvara bhūtena vīriya balena paṭipakkham vinodento
translated: dispels the opposite by the strength of energy, which is the strength of restraint by energy described in the way beginning, “When a thought of sensual desire has arisen he does not tolerate it” ,

original: bhāvanābalena taṃ vipallāsaṃ vidhametvā sammattaniyāmaṃ okkamati. Tatiyo anicce “nicca”nti
analyzed: bhāvanā balena tam vipallāsam vidhametvā sammatta niyāmam okkamati tatiyaḥ anicce niccanti
translated: and by the strength of development he eradicates that perversion and enters upon the certainty of rightness. The third, who misapprehends what is impermanent as permanent,

original: vipallāsaggāhī samathabalena samāhitacitto saṅkhārānaṃ khaṇikabhāvaṃ sallakkhento
analyzed: vipallāsa ggāhī samatha balena samāhita citto saṅkhārānam khaṇika bhāvam sallakkhento
translated: contemplates the momentary nature of formations with his mind concentrated by the strength of serenity,

original: bhāvanābalena taṃ vipallāsaṃ samugghātetvā sammattaniyāmaṃ okkamati. Catuttho santatisamūhakiccārammaṇaghanavañcitatāya
analyzed: bhāvanā balena tam vipallāsam samugghātetvā sammatta niyāmam okkamati catutthaḥ santati samūha kicca ārammaṇa ghana vañcita tāya
translated: and by the strength of development he eradicates that perversion and enters upon the certainty of rightness. The fourth, who misapprehends what is not self as self, does so because of the compactness due to continuity, to accumulation, to function, and to object.

original: phassādidhammapuñjamatte anattani “attā”ti micchābhinivesī catukoṭikasuññatāmanasikārena
analyzed: phassa ādi dhamma puñja matte anattani attā ati micchā abhinivesī catu koṭika suñña tā manasikārena
translated: and in the mere aggregates of feeling, etc., which are not self, he conceives a self. He should do this by giving attention to the voidness of the four quarters.

original: taṃ micchābhinivesaṃ viddhaṃsento sāmaññaphalaṃ sacchikaroti. Subhasaññādīhi catūhipi
analyzed: tam micchā abhinivesam sāmañña phalam sacchikaroti subha saññā ādīhi
translated: He who misapprehends the mere aggregates of form, feeling, perception, mental formations and consciousness, which are devoid of self, as a self, realizes the fruit of recluseship by destroying that misapprehension with the attention given to the four-cornered voidness.

original: vā vipallāsehi samudayasaccaṃ, tesamadhiṭṭhānārammaṇabhūtā pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhasaccantiādinā
analyzed: vā vipallāsehi samudaya saccam tesam adhiṭṭhāna ārammaṇa bhūtā pañca upādāna kkhandhāḥ dukkha sacca nti ādinā
translated: Or else, the four perversions are the truth of origination, and the five aggregates of clinging, which are the basis and object of those perversions, are the truth of suffering.

original: saccayojanā veditabbā. Phalaṃ panettha cattāri sāmaññaphalāni, catūhi cettha vipallāsehi
analyzed: sacca yojanā veditabbā phalam pana ittha cattāri sāmañña phalāni catūhi ca ittha vipallāsehi
translated: The method of yoking the truths should be understood in this way. The fruit here is the four fruits of recluseship.

original: caturāsavoghayogaganthaagatitaṇhupādānasallaviññāṇaṭṭhitiapariññādivasena akusalapakkho
analyzed: catur āsava ogha yoga gantha agati taṇhu pādāna salla viññāṇa ṭṭhiti apariññā ādi vasena akusala pakkhaḥ
translated: The unprofitable side should be understood here by way of the four perversions, the four taints, the four yokes, the four bonds, the four kinds of craving, the four kinds of clinging, the four kinds of wrongness, the four stations of consciousness, the four kinds of non-knowledge, etc.;

original: netabbo, tathā catūhi satipaṭṭhānehi catubbidhajjhānavihārādhiṭṭhānasukhabhāgiyadhammaappamaññāsammappadhānaiddhipādādivasena🔽vodānapakkho netabboti ayaṃ sīhavikkīḷitassa nayassa bhūmi. Yo hi subhasaññādīhi
analyzed: netabbaḥ tathā catūhi sati paṭṭhānehi catubbidha jjhāna vihāra adhiṭṭhāna sukha bhāgiya dhamma appamaññā sammappadhāna eddhipāda ādi vasena 🔽vodāna pakkhaḥ netabbaḥ ti ayam sīhavikkīḷitassa nayassa bhūmi yaḥ hi subha saññā ādīhi
translated: and the purified side should be understood by way of the four foundations of mindfulness, the four kinds of abiding in divine abidings, the four kinds of happiness, the four kinds of sharing the Dhamma, the four immeasurable states, the four right efforts, the four bases of success, etc. This is the plane of the method of the lion’s play.

original: vipallāsehi sakalassa saṃkilesapakkhassa saddhindriyādīhi ca vodānapakkhassa catusaccayojanāvasena
analyzed: vipallāsehi sakalassa saṃkilesa pakkhassa saddhi indriya ādīhi ca vodāna pakkhassa catu sacca yojanā vasena
translated: and by the four Truths in the way beginning “The four kinds of misapprehension are the footing for the whole category of defilement, and the faith faculty, etc., are the footing for the whole category of purification” .

original: nayanalakkhaṇo saṃvaṇṇanāviseso, ayaṃ sīhavikkīḷito nāma. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: nayana lakkhaṇaḥ saṃvaṇṇanā visesaḥ ayam sīhavikkīḷitaḥ nāma vuttam ha etam
translated: The special mode of exposition that has the characteristic of leading is called the “lion’s play.” For this is said:

original: “Yo neti vipallāsehi,🔽Kilese indriyehi saddhamme;
analyzed: yaḥ na iti vipallāsehi  kilese indriyehi saddhamme
translated: “He who leads by the misapprehensions,🔽By the defilements, and by the faculties, by the True Idea,

original: Etaṃ nayaṃ nayavidū,
analyzed: etam nayam naya vidū
translated: That mode of leading the one who knows the modes,

original: Sīhavikkīḷitaṃ āhū”ti. ;
analyzed: sīhavikkīḷitam āhūti
translated: They call the lion’s play.”

original: Asantāsanajavaparakkamādivisesayogena sīho bhagavā, tassa vikkīḷitaṃ desanā vacīkammabhūto
analyzed: asanta āsana java parakkama ādi visesa yogena sīhaḥ bhagavā tassa vikkīḷitam desanā vacī kamma bhūto
translated: The Blessed One is a lion because he possesses such special qualities as fearlessness, swiftness, and courage. His teaching, which is an act of speech, is his play.

original: vihāroti katvā vipallāsatappaṭipakkhaparidīpanato sīhassa vikkīḷitaṃ etthāti sīhavikkīḷito,
analyzed: vihāraḥ ti katvā vipallāsa tad paṭipakkha paridīpanataḥ sīhassa vikkīḷitam ettha ati sīha vikkīḷitaḥ
translated: And because it is a mode of exposition that shows the opposite of the four kinds of misapprehension, it is the “lion’s play” in the sense that it is the lion’s play.

original: nayo. Balavisesayogadīpanato vā sīhavikkīḷitasadisattā nayo sīhavikkīḷito. Balaviseso
analyzed: nayaḥ bala visesa yoga dīpanataḥ vā sīha vikkīḷita sadisa ttā nayaḥ sīha vikkīḷitaḥ bala visesaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, it is the “lion’s play” because it is like the lion’s play in that it shows the possession of a special kind of strength.

original: cettha saddhādibalaṃ, dasabalāni eva vā.
analyzed: ca ittha saddhā ādi balam eva vā
translated: The special strength here is the strength of faith, etc., or the ten powers.

original: Imesaṃ pana tiṇṇaṃ atthanayānaṃ siddhiyā vohāranayadvayaṃ siddhameva hoti. Tathā hi atthanayattayadisābhāvena kusalādidhammānaṃ ālocanaṃ disālocanaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: imesam pana tiṇṇam attha nayānam siddhiyā vohāra naya dvayam siddham eva hoti tathā hi attha naya ttaya disa abhāvena kusala ādi dhammānam ālocanam disa ālocanam vuttam ha etam
translated: But when these three methods of exposition are established, the two methods of expression are established too. For the “survey of the directions” is the survey of profitable, etc., states by way of the three directions of meaning. For this is said:

original: “Veyyākaraṇesu hi ye,
analyzed: veyyākaraṇesu hi ye
translated: “In the grammarians’ works

original: Kusalākusalā tahiṃ tahiṃ vuttā;
analyzed: kusala akusalā tahim tahim vuttā
translated: The profitable and unprofitable are stated here and there;

original: Manasā olokayate,
analyzed: manasā olokayate
translated: The mind surveys them:

original: Taṃ khu disālocanaṃ āhū”ti. ;
analyzed: tam khu disā locanam
translated: This is called the survey of the directions.”

original: Tathā ālocitānaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ atthanayattayayojane samānayanato aṅkuso viya aṅkuso. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: tathā ālocitānam tesam dhammānam attha naya ttaya yojane samānayanataḥ aṅkusaḥ viya aṅkusaḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: And the “goad” is so called because it goes after the states that have been surveyed and goads them into the three directions of meaning. For this is said:🔽“Having surveyed with the survey of the directions,

original: “Oloketvā disalocanena, ukkhipiya yaṃ samāneti;
analyzed: oloketvā disa locanena ukkhipiya yam samāneti
translated: He goes after and goads whatever there is;🔽All the profitable and unprofitable:

original: Sabbe kusalākusale, ayaṃ nayo aṅkuso nāmā”ti. ;
analyzed: sabbe kusala akusale ayam nayaḥ aṅkusaḥ nāma ati
translated: This method is called the goad.”

original: Tasmā manasāva atthanayānaṃ disābhūtadhammānaṃ locanaṃ disālocanaṃ, tesaṃ samānayanaṃ aṅkusoti pañcapi nayāni yuttāni honti.
analyzed: tasmā manasā ava atthanayānam disābhūta dhammānam locanam disālocanam tesam samānayanam aṅkusaḥ ti pañca api nayāni yuttāni honti
translated: So the five methods are included in the survey of the directions, which is the survey of the states that are the directions of meaning by means of the mind, and in the goad, which is the going after and goading of them.

original: Ettāvatā ca –🔽“Paṭhamo nandiyāvaṭṭo, dutiyo ca tipukkhalo;
analyzed: ettāvatā ca  paṭhamaḥ nandiyāvaṭṭaḥ dutiyaḥ ca tipukkhalo
translated: And at this point🔽The first is called the “whirlpool,”🔽The second, “the three spikes,”🔽The third, “the lion’s play,”

original: Sīhavikkīḷito nāma, tatiyo nayalañjako.
analyzed: sīhavikkīḷitaḥ nāma tatiyaḥ naya lañjakaḥ
translated: And the fourth, “the method’s mark.”

original: Disālocanamāhaṃsu, catutthaṃ nayamuttamaṃ;
analyzed: catuttham nayam uttamam
translated: They say the scanning of the directions Is the fourth, the best of guides.

original: Pañcamo aṅkuso nāma, sabbe pañca nayā gatā”ti. –
analyzed: pañcamaḥ aṅkusaḥ nāma sabbe pañca nayāḥ gatā ati
translated: The fifth is called the goad: All five are guides indeed.🔽The five guides mentioned in this verse should be understood as shown here.

original: Evaṃ vuttapañcanayāpi ettha dassitāti veditabbā. Nayati saṃkilesaṃ vodānañca vibhāgato
analyzed: evam vutta pañcanayā api ettha dassitā ati veditabbā nayati saṃkilesam vodānam ca vibhāgato
translated: It guides by distinguishing defilement and purification,

original: ñāpetīti nayo, lañjeti pakāseti suttatthanti lañjako, nayo ca so lañjako cāti nayalañjako.
analyzed: ñāpeti iti nayaḥ lañjeti pakāseti sutta tthanti lañjakaḥ nayo ca so lañjako ca ati naya lañjako
translated: it causes to be known, thus it is a guide ; it marks, it reveals, the meaning of the suttas, thus it is a mark ; it is a guide and a mark, thus it is a guide-mark.

original: Idañca suttaṃ soḷasavidhe suttantapaṭṭhāne saṃkilesabhāgiyaṃ byatirekamukhena nibbedhāsekkhabhāgiyanti
analyzed: idam ca suttam soḷasavidhe suttanta paṭṭhāne saṃkilesa bhāgiyam byatireka mukhena nibbedha asekkha bhāgiyan ti
translated: And this sutta should be regarded as belonging to the section of suttas dealing with defilement and to the section dealing with penetration and the disciple in higher training by way of distinction.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Aṭṭhavīsatividhe pana suttantapaṭṭhāne lokiyalokuttaraṃ sattadhammādhiṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam aṭṭhavīsatividhe pana suttanta paṭṭhāne lokiya lokuttaram satta dhamma adhiṭṭhānam
translated: But in the twenty-eightfold section of suttas it should be understood as belonging to the mundane and supramundane, to the section dealing with the seven ideas,

original: ñāṇaññeyyaṃ dassanabhāvanaṃ sakavacanaṃ vissajjanīyaṃ kusalākusalaṃ anuññātaṃ paṭikkhittañcāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ñāṇa ñeyyam dassana bhāvanam saka vacanam vissajjanīyam kusala akusalam anuññātam paṭikkhittam ca ati veditabbam
translated: to knowledge and what should be known, to seeing and to development, to one’s own words, to the answer, to the profitable and unprofitable, and to what is allowed and forbidden.

original: Tattha soḷasavidhasuttantaṃ paṭṭhānaṃ nāma “saṃkilesabhāgiyaṃ suttaṃ, vāsanābhāgiyaṃ
analyzed: tattha soḷasavidha suttantam paṭṭhānam nāma saṃkilesa bhāgiyam suttam vāsanā bhāgiyam
translated: Herein, the sixteenfold section of suttas is called the section of suttas dealing with defilement, the section of suttas dealing with purification,

original: suttaṃ, nibbedhabhāgiyaṃ suttaṃ, asekkhabhāgiyaṃ suttaṃ, saṃkilesabhāgiyañca vāsanābhāgiyañca🔽suttaṃ, saṃkilesabhāgiyañca nibbedhabhāgiyañca suttaṃ, saṃkilesabhāgiyañca asekkhabhāgiyañca🔽suttaṃ, vāsanābhāgiyañca nibbedhabhāgiyañca suttaṃ, vāsanābhāgiyañca asekkhabhāgiyañca🔽suttaṃ, nibbedhabhāgiyañca asekkhabhāgiyañca suttaṃ, saṃkilesabhāgiyañca vāsanābhāgiyañca
analyzed: suttam nibbedha bhāgiyam suttam asekkha bhāgiyam suttam saṃkilesa bhāgiyañca vāsanā bhāgiyañca  suttam saṃkilesa bhāgiyañca nibbedha bhāgiyañca suttam saṃkilesa bhāgiyañca asekkha bhāgiyañca  suttam vāsanā bhāgiyañca nibbedha bhāgiyañca suttam vāsanā bhāgiyañca asekkha bhāgiyañca  suttam nibbedha bhāgiyañca asekkha bhāgiyañca suttam saṃkilesa bhāgiyañca vāsanā bhāgiyañca
translated: the suttas of penetration, the suttas of the one beyond training, the suttas of corruption and the suttas of the underlying tendency to conceit,🔽the suttas of corruption and the suttas of penetration, the suttas of corruption and the suttas of the one beyond training,🔽the suttas of the underlying tendency to conceit and the suttas of penetration, the suttas of the underlying tendency to conceit and the suttas of the one beyond training,🔽the suttas of penetration and the suttas of the one beyond training, the suttas of corruption and the suttas of the underlying tendency to conceit,

original: nibbedhabhāgiyañca suttaṃ, saṃkilesabhāgiyañca vāsanābhāgiyañca asekkhabhāgiyañca🔽suttaṃ, saṃkilesabhāgiyañca nibbedhabhāgiyañca asekkhabhāgiyañca suttaṃ, vāsanābhāgiyañca🔽nibbedhabhāgiyañca asekkhabhāgiyañca suttaṃ, saṃkilesabhāgiyañca vāsanābhāgiyañca
analyzed: nibbedha bhāgiyañca suttam saṃkilesa bhāgiyañca vāsanā bhāgiyañca asekkha bhāgiyañca 🔽suttam saṃkilesa bhāgiyañca nibbedha bhāgiyañca asekkha bhāgiyañca suttam vāsanā bhāgiyañca 🔽nibbedha bhāgiyañca asekkha bhāgiyañca suttam saṃkilesa bhāgiyañca vāsanā bhāgiyañca
translated: a discourse that is a penetration-of-the-Dhamma discourse, a discourse that is a disciple-of-the-Buddha discourse, a discourse that is a corruption-of-the-Dhamma discourse, a discourse that is a corruption-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a penetration-of-the-Dhamma discourse, a discourse that is a corruption-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a disciple-of-the-Buddha discourse, a discourse that is a penetration-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a disciple-of-the-Buddha discourse, a discourse that is a corruption-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a corruption-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a penetration-of-the-Dhamma discourse, a discourse that is a corruption-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a corruption-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a disciple-of-the-Buddha discourse, a discourse that is a corruption-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a penetration-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a disciple-of-the-Buddha discourse, a discourse that is a corruption-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a corruption-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a penetration-of-the-Dhamma discourse and a disciple-of-the-Buddha discourse.

original: nibbedhabhāgiyañca asekkhabhāgiyañca suttaṃ, neva saṃkilesabhāgiyaṃ na vāsanābhāgiyaṃ
analyzed: nibbedha bhāgiyañca asekkha bhāgiyañca suttam na iva saṃkilesa bhāgiyam na vāsanā bhāgiyam
translated: and the kind not concerned with corruption and the kind not concerned with the preservation of what has come to be,

original: na nibbedhabhāgiyaṃ na asekkhabhāgiyaṃ sutta”nti evaṃ vuttasoḷasasāsanapaṭṭhānāni.
analyzed: na nibbedha bhāgiyam na asekkha bhāgiyam suttan ti evam vutta soḷasa sāsana paṭṭhānāni
translated: and the kind not concerned with penetration and the kind not concerned with the adept.

original: Tattha saṃkilissanti etenāti saṃkileso, saṃkilesabhāge saṃkilesakoṭṭhāse pavattaṃ🔽saṃkilesabhāgiyaṃ. Vāsanā puññabhāvanā, vāsanābhāge pavattaṃ vāsanābhāgiyaṃ, vāsanaṃ
analyzed: tattha saṃkilissanti etena ati saṃkilesaḥ saṃkilesa bhāge saṃkilesa koṭṭhāse pavattam  saṃkilesa bhāgiyam vāsanā puñña bhāvanā vāsanā bhāge pavattam vāsanābhāgiyam vāsanam
translated: Herein, it is corruption because there is corruption by it, thus corruption is defilement. It is concerned with corruption because it occurs in the section on corruption, or it is concerned with corruption because it makes one go to corruption.🔽The preservation of what has come to be is the preservation of what has been acquired. It is concerned with the preservation of what has come to be because it occurs in the section on the preservation of what has come to be, or it is concerned with the preservation of what has come to be because it makes one go to the preservation of what has come to be.

original: bhajāpetīti vā vāsanābhāgiyaṃ. Nibbijjhanaṃ lobhakkhandhādīnaṃ padālanaṃ nibbedho,
analyzed: bhajāpeti iti vā vāsanā bhāgiyam nibbijjhanam lobha kkhandha ādīnam padālanam nibbedhaḥ
translated: Penetration is the crushing of the aggregates of greed, etc.;

original: nibbedhabhāge pavattaṃ, nibbedhaṃ bhajāpetīti vā nibbedhabhāgiyaṃ. Pariniṭṭhitasikkhā

Tattha ye brāhmaṇāti ye🔽bāhitapāpā parisuddhā brāhmaṇā. Vedagūti vedānaṃ pāraṃ gatā, vedehi pāraṃ gatāti🔽vā vedagū. Idha pana sabbe saṅkhatadhamme vidite pākaṭe katvā katāti vedagū. Tenevāha
analyzed: evam bodhisattaḥ imāya gāthāya sūriyam namassitvā dutiya gāthāya atīte parinibbute  buddhe ca iva buddha guṇe ca namassati ye brāhmaṇa ati ādinā tattha ye brāhmaṇa ati ye  bāhita pāpā parisuddhāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ vedagūti vedānam pāram gatāḥ vedehi pāram gatā ati  vā vedagū idha pana sabbe saṅkhata dhamme vidite pākaṭe katvā katā ati vedagū tena iva āha
translated: So the Bodhisatta, having paid homage to the sun with this stanza, in the second stanza pays homage to the Buddhas of the past who have attained final Nibbana and to the special qualities of the Buddhas, with the words “The Brahmins who have gone to the end of knowledge.” Herein, the Brahmins who have gone to the end of knowledge are those who have expelled evil and are purified. They have gone to the end of the Vedas, or they are those who have gone to the end of the Vedas. But here they are those who have made all formed things evident and known, and so they have gone to the end of knowledge. Hence it is said:🔽🔽

original: – “sabbadhamme”ti. Sabbe khandhāyatanadhātudhamme salakkhaṇasāmaññalakkhaṇavasena🔽attano ñāṇassa vidite pākaṭe katvā tiṇṇaṃ mārānaṃ matthakaṃ madditvā sammāsambodhiṃ🔽pattā, saṃsāraṃ vā atikkantāti attho. Te me namoti te mama imaṃ namakkāraṃ paṭicchantu.🔽Te ca maṃ pālayantūti evaṃ mayā namassitā ca te bhagavanto maṃ pālayantu rakkhantu.
analyzed: sabba dhamma iti sabbe khandha āyatana dhātu dhamme sa lakkhaṇa sāmañña lakkhaṇa vasena 🔽attanaḥ ñāṇassa vidite pākaṭe katvā tiṇṇam mārānam matthakam madditvā sammāsambodhim 🔽pattā saṃsāram vā atikkantā ati te me namaḥ ti te mama imam namakkāram paṭicchantu 🔽te ca mama pālayantu uti evam mayā namassitā ca te bhagavantaḥ mama pālayantu rakkhantu
translated: So the Bodhisatta, having paid homage to the sun with this stanza, in the second stanza pays homage to the Buddhas of the past who have attained final Nibbana, and to the special qualities of the Buddhas, with the words “Those Brahmas who are free from evil, purified, and knowers of the Vedas.” Herein, those Brahmas who are free from evil are those who have expelled evil and are quite purified. Purified, and knowers of the Vedas : they have gone to the other side of the Vedas, or they are gone to the other side by means of the Vedas. But here they are knowers of the Vedas because they have made all formed things clear to themselves by knowing them. Hence he said “all things.” They have made all things, that is, all aggregates, bases, and elements, clear to themselves by knowing them according to their specific characteristics and their general characteristics. They have crushed the heads of the three defilements, and they have attained supreme enlightenment, or they have gone beyond the round of rebirths, is the meaning. May they accept this homage from me: may those Blessed Ones accept this homage from me. And may they guard me: may those Blessed Ones, having been thus paid homage by me, guard me.

original: Ekekārammaṇagarukānañhi pañcannaṃ puggalānaṃ tattha āgatattā taṃ jātakaṃ “pañcagarukajātaka”nti
