original: na icchi. Anatikkamantoti saṃsandento. Dve hatthaṃ pattānīti dve uppalāni hatthaṃ
analyzed: na icchi an atikkamanto ti saṃsandentaḥ dve hattham pattāni iti dve uppalāni hattham
translated: “Without going beyond” means: while connecting them. “Two lotuses reached his hand” means: two lotuses reached his hand.

original: gatāni. Pahaṭṭhākāraṃ dassetvāti aparāhi itthīhi ekekaṃ laddhaṃ, mayā dve laddhānīti
analyzed: gatāni pahaṭṭha ākāram dassetvā ati aparāhi itthīhi ekekam laddham mayā dve laddhāni iti
translated: He showed his satisfaction. He showed his satisfaction by saying, “I have received two, while each of the other women has received only one.”

original: santuṭṭhākāraṃ dassetvā. Parodīti tassā pubbasāmikassa mukhagandhaṃ saritvā. Tassa
analyzed: santuṭṭha ākāram dassetvā parodi iti tassāḥ pubba sāmikassa mukha gandham saritvā tassa
translated: He remembered the smell of his former wife’s mouth. For a fragrance like that of a blue lotus emanated from her mouth.

original: hi mukhato uppalagandho vāyati. Hāretvāti tasmā ṭhānā apanetvā, “harāpetvā”ti vā pāṭho, ayamevattho.
analyzed: hi mukhataḥ uppala gandhaḥ vāyati hāretvā iti tasmā ṭhānā apanetvā harāpetvā iti vā pāṭhaḥ ayam eva atthaḥ
translated: He removed it: he took it away from that place. The reading “had it removed” has the same meaning.

original: Sādhu sādhūti bhāsatoti dhammakathāya anumodanavasena “sādhu sādhū”ti bhāsato. Uppalaṃva
analyzed: sādhu sādhu iti bhāsato ti dhamma kathāya anumodana vasena sādhu sādhu iti bhāsato uppalam va
translated: He spoke in praise: he spoke in praise with the words “Good! Good!” in appreciation of the Dhamma talk.🔽Like a blue lotus in water: like a blue lotus, the fragrance of which arises from its mouth.

original: yathodaketi yathā uppalaṃ uppalagandho mukhato nibbattoti. Vaṭṭameva kathitanti yathārutavasena
analyzed: yathā udaka iti yathā uppalam uppala gandhaḥ mukhataḥ nibbattaḥ ti vaṭṭam eva kathitam ti yathā ruta vasena
translated: He spoke only of the round: he spoke only of the round of rebirths.

original: vuttaṃ. Yadipi evaṃ vuttaṃ, tathāpi yathārutamatthe avatvā vivaṭṭaṃ nīharitvā kathetabbaṃ
analyzed: vuttam yadi api evam vuttam tathā api yathārutam atthe avatvā vivaṭṭam nīharitvā kathetabbam
translated: Although he spoke in this way, nevertheless he should have spoken by removing the round of rebirths and referring to the supramundane state,

original: vimuttirasattā bhagavato desanāya.
analyzed: vimuttiḥ asattā bhagavataḥ desanāya
translated: for the Blessed One’s teaching is characterized by the supramundane state.

original: Rūpādivaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: rūpa ādi vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the “Form” chapter is ended.🔽The Commentary on the Anguttara Nikāya,

original: Iti manorathapūraṇiyā aṅguttaranikāya-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: iti manorathapūraṇiyā aṅguttara nikāya aṭṭhakathāya
translated: called Manorathapūraṇī,

original: Paṭhamavaggavaṇṇanāya anuttānatthadīpanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama vagga vaṇṇanāya anuttānatthadīpanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the first chapter, which shows the meaning of the unexcelledness, is ended.

original: 2. Nīvaraṇappahānavaggavaṇṇanā🔽11. Dutiyassāti dutiyavaggassa. Ekadhammampīti ettha “ekasabhāvampī”ti iminā sabhāvatthoyaṃ
analyzed: nīvaraṇa ppahāna vagga vaṇṇanā  dutiyassa ati dutiya vaggassa eka dhammam pi iti ettha eka sabhāvam pi iti iminā sabhāva atthaḥ yaṃ
translated: The chapter on the abandoning of the hindrances

original: dhammasaddo “kusalā dhammā”tiādīsu viyāti dassitaṃ hoti. Yadaggena ca sabhāvattho,🔽tadaggena nissattattho siddho evāti “nissattaṭṭhena dhammo veditabbo”ti vuttaṃ. Subhanimittanti
analyzed: dhamma saddaḥ kusalāḥ dhammā ti ādīsu viyā ati dassitam hoti yad aggena ca sabhāvattho  tad aggena nissatta attho siddhaḥ evā ati nissatta ṭṭhena dhammo veditabbaḥ iti vuttam subha nimittam
translated: Of the second: of the second chapter. Of a single idea: here the word idea is shown to have the meaning of “state” by the phrase “of a single state.” And since it has the meaning of “state,”

original: dhammapariyāyena vuttaṃ. Tañhi atthato kāmacchando vā siyā. So hi attano gahaṇākārena🔽subhanti, tenākārena pavattanakassa aññassa kāmacchandassa nimittattā “subhanimitta”nti🔽ca vuccati. Tassa ārammaṇaṃ vā subhanimittaṃ. Iṭṭhañhi iṭṭhākārena vā gayhamānaṃ
analyzed: dhamma pariyāyena vuttam tat hi atthataḥ kāmacchandaḥ vā siyā saḥ hi attanaḥ gahaṇa ākārena  subham ti tena ākārena pavattanakassa aññassa kāmacchandassa nimitta ttā subha nimittanti  ca vuccati tassa ārammaṇam vā subha nimittam iṭṭham hi iṭṭha ākārena vā gayhamānam
translated: the meaning of “non-existence of being” is established by implication, which is why it is said “the idea should be understood in the sense of non-existence of being.” The sign of the beautiful: this is said by way of the text of the True Idea. For that is either lust for sensual desires in meaning,

original: rūpādiārammaṇaṃ “subhanimitta”nti vuccati. Ārammaṇameva cettha nimittaṃ. Tathā hi
analyzed: rūpa ādi ārammaṇam subha nimittanti vuccati ārammaṇam eva ca ittha nimittam tathā hi
translated: for that is called “the sign of the beautiful” because it is the sign for another lust for sensual desires that occurs in the mode of apprehending itself as “beautiful.” Or the sign of the beautiful is its object. For a desirable object is called “the sign of the beautiful” when it is apprehended in the mode of the desirable. But here the sign is the object itself. For

original: vakkhati – “subhanimittanti rāgaṭṭhāniyaṃ ārammaṇa”nti. Samuccayattho vā-saddo anekatthattā
analyzed: vakkhati subha nimittan ti rāgaṭṭhāniyam ārammaṇam ti samuccaya tthaḥ vā saddaḥ anekatthattā
translated: The word “and” has the meaning of “together with.”🔽“For the sake of increase” means for the sake of repeated existence.

original: nipātānaṃ. Bhiyyobhāvāyāti punappunaṃ bhāvāya. Vepullāyāti vipulabhāvāya, vaḍḍhiyāti
analyzed: nipātānam bhiyyobhāvāya ati punappunam bhāvāya vepullāya ati vipula bhāvāya vaḍḍhiyāti
translated: “For the sake of abundance” means for the sake of extensive existence. The meaning is: for the sake of growth.🔽“Not born” : not arisen. The remaining terms are synonyms for that.

original: attho. Ajāto nijjāto. Sesapadāni tasseva vevacanāni. Kāmesūti pañcasu kāmaguṇesu.
analyzed: atthaḥ a jātaḥ nijjātaḥ sesa padāni tassa iva vevacanāni kāmesu iti pañcasu kāma guṇesu
translated: “In the sense objects” : in the five strands of sense pleasure.🔽“Lust for sense desires” : desire called “sense desire,” not desire to do, not desire for the Dhamma.

original: Kāmacchandoti kāmasaṅkhāto chando, na kattukamyatāchando na dhammacchando. Kāmanavasena
analyzed: kāma chando ti kāma saṅkhāto chandaḥ na kattu kamyatā chandaḥ na dhamma chando kāmana vasena
translated: “Lust” is sense desire by way of sense desire and by way of lusting.🔽“Delight” is sense desire by way of sense desire and by way of delighting.

original: rajjanavasena ca kāmo eva rāgo kāmarāgo. Kāmanavasena nandanavasena ca kāmo eva nandīti🔽kāmanandī. Kāmanavasena taṇhāyanavasena ca kāmataṇhā. Ādisaddena “kāmasneho kāmapariḷāho
analyzed: rajjana vasena ca kāmaḥ eva rāgaḥ kāma rāgaḥ kāmana vasena nandana vasena ca kāmaḥ eva nandī iti  kāma nandī kāmana vasena taṇhāyana vasena ca kāma taṇhā ādi saddena kāma sneho kāma pariḷāho
translated: “Craving” is sense desire by way of sense desire and by way of craving.🔽The word “etc.” should be regarded as including the terms “attachment to sense desires,” “fever of sense desires,”

original: kāmamucchā kāmajjhosāna”nti etesaṃ padānaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Tattha vuttanayeneva
analyzed: kāmamucchā kāmajjhosānanti etesam padānam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo tattha vutta nayena iva
translated: “conceit of sense desires,” and “clinging to sense desires.” Herein, “attachment to sense desires” should be regarded as sense desire by way of the state of being attached,

original: kāmatthaṃ viditvā sinehanaṭṭhena kāmasneho, pariḷāhanaṭṭhena kāmapariḷāho, mucchanaṭṭhena
analyzed: kāmattham viditvā sinehana ṭṭhena kāma snehaḥ pariḷāhana ṭṭhena kāma pariḷāhaḥ mucchana ṭṭhena
translated: “fever of sense desires” by way of the state of being feverish, “conceit of sense desires” by way of the state of being conceited, and “clinging to sense desires” by way of the state of being clung to.

original: kāmamucchā, gilitvā pariniṭṭhāpanaṭṭhena kāmajjhosānaṃ veditabbaṃ. Kāmacchando eva
analyzed: kāma mucchāḥ gilitvā pariniṭṭhāpana ṭṭhena kāma ajjhosānam veditabbam kāmacchandaḥ eva
translated: And it should be understood that sensual desire is the pursuit of sensual desires in the sense of bringing to fulfilment what has been begun.

original: kusalappavattito cittassa nīvaraṇaṭṭhena kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ, soti kāmacchando.
analyzed: kusala ppavattitaḥ cittassa nīvaraṇa aṭṭhena kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam saḥ ti kāmacchandaḥ
translated: Sensual desire itself is the hindrance of sensual desire in the sense of hindering the mind from becoming composed in the sense of skill.

original: Asamudācāravasenāti asamudācārabhāvena. Ananubhūtārammaṇavasenāti “idaṃ nāmeta”nti🔽vatthuvasena utvā tasmiṃ attabhāve ananubhūtassa ārammaṇassa vasena. Rūpasaddādibhedaṃ
analyzed: asamudācāra vasena ati asamudācāra bhāvena ananubhūta ārammaṇa vasena ati idam nāma etat ti  vatthu vasena utvā tasmin atta bhāve ananubhūtassa ārammaṇassa vasena rūpa sadda ādi bhedam
translated: In the sense of non-occurrence: by means of non-occurrence. In the sense of an unused object: in the sense of an object not experienced thus, “This is this.”

original: pana ārammaṇaṃ ekasmimpi attabhāve ananubhūtaṃ nāma nattheva, kimaṅgaṃ pana anādimati saṃsāre.
analyzed: pana ārammaṇam ekasmim pi atta bhāve ananubhūtam nāma nattha iva kimaṅgam pana anādimati saṃsāre
translated: For there is nothing that is an object such as visible forms, sounds, etc., that has not been experienced in a single existence, let alone in the beginningless round of rebirths.

original: Yaṃ vuttaṃ – “asamudācāravasena cā”tiādi, taṃ atisaṃkhittanti vitthārato dassetuṃ
analyzed: yam vuttam asamudācāra vasena ca atiādi tam atisaṃkhittan ti vitthārataḥ dassetuṃ
translated: But what was said above, namely, “In the sense of non-occurrence, etc.,” is too concise. So in order to expound it in detail he said:

original: – “tatthā”tiādimāha. Tattha bhavaggahaṇena mahaggatabhavo gahito. So hi oḷārikakilesasamudācārarahito.
analyzed: tattha ati ādim āha tattha bhava ggahaṇena mahaggata bhavaḥ gahito saḥ hi oḷārika kilesa samudācāra rahitaḥ
translated: Herein, by the word “existence” the existence of the higher realms is included. For that is free from the occurrence of gross defilements.

original: Tajjanīyakammakatādikāle pārivāsikakāle ca caritabbāni dveasīti khuddakavattāni nāma.
analyzed: tajjanīya kammaka tā ādi kāle pārivāsika kāle ca caritabbāni dveasīti khuddakavattāni nāma
translated: The two hundred and eighty minor rules of conduct are those that should be observed by one who has been given the penalty of demotion, etc., and by one on probation.

original: Na hi tāni sabbāsu avatthāsu caritabbāni, tasmā tāni na mahāvattesu antogadhānīti
analyzed: na hi tāni sabbāsu avatthāsu caritabbāni tasmā tāni na mahā vattesu antogadhāni iti
translated: For they are not to be practised in all circumstances. That is why they are not included in the great observances.

original: “cuddasa mahāvattānī”ti vuttaṃ. Tathā āgantukavattaāvāsikagamika-anumodanabhattagga-
analyzed: cuddasa mahāvattāni iti vuttam tathā
translated: “The fourteen great observances” are stated. So too, the observance for visitors, for residents, for the chief seat, for the reciter of the code,

original: piṇḍacārikaāraññakasenāsanajantāgharavaccakuṭiupajjhāya- saddhivihārikaācariya-antevāsikavattānīti
analyzed: piṇḍa cārika āraññaka senāsana jantā ghara vacca kuṭi upajjhāya saddhivihārika ācariya antevāsika vattāni iti
translated: for alms-wanderers, for forest-dwellers, for those who use a resting-stick, for those who live in a group, for pupils, for students, for preceptors, for teachers, and for co-resident pupils.

original: etāni cuddasa mahāvattāni nāmāti vuttaṃ. Itarāni pana “pārivāsikānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ vattaṃ
analyzed: etāni cuddasa mahāvattāni nāma ati vuttam itarāni pana pārivāsikānam bhikkhūnam vattam
translated: These are called the fourteen great observances. The others, beginning with “I will lay down the observance for probationary monks,”

original: paññāpessāmī”ti ārabhitvā “na upasampādetabbaṃ, na chamāyaṃ caṅkamante caṅkame caṅkamitabba”nti
analyzed: paññāpessāmi iti ārabhitvā na upasampādetabbam na chamāyam caṅkamante caṅkame caṅkamitabbanti
translated: and ending with “One on probation should not walk in the outer passage above the ground when the monks are walking in the inner passage,”

original: vuttāni pakatatte caritabbavattāni chasaṭṭhi, tato paraṃ “na, bhikkhave, pārivāsikena
analyzed: vuttāni pakatatte caritabba vattāni cha saṭṭhi tatas param na bhikkhave pārivāsikena
translated: are the sixty-six ordinary observances to be practised. After that, “A probationary monk should not, bhikkhus,

original: bhikkhunā pārivāsikavuḍḍhatarena bhikkhunā saddhiṃ, mūlāyapaṭikassanārahena, mānattārahena,
analyzed: bhikkhunā pārivāsika vuḍḍhatarena bhikkhunā saddhim mūlāya paṭikassana arahena mānatta arahena
translated: conclude the observance-day ceremony together with a regular monk who is senior to him, nor one deserving to be sent back to the beginning, nor one deserving the trial period,

original: mānattacārikena, abbhānārahena bhikkhunā saddiṃ ekacchanne āvāse vatthabba”ntiādīni
analyzed: mānatta cārikena abbhāna arahena bhikkhunā saddim ekacchanne āvāse vatthabba nti ādīni
translated: “He should not live in the same room in a monastery with a fully ordained monk who is undertaking the trial period as a probationer and who deserves rehabilitation.”🔽Because they are not different from the duties that should be carried out by a regular monk, they are not counted separately. But they are included in the group of five, which is made up by adding the duties of a probationer, etc.,

original: pakatatte caritabbehi anaññattā visuṃ visuṃ agaṇetvā pārivāsikavuḍḍhatarādīsu puggalantaresu🔽caritabbattā tesaṃ vasena sampiṇḍetvā ekekaṃ katvā gaṇitāni pañcāti ekasattativattāni.🔽Ukkhepanīyakammakatavattesu vattapaññāpanavasena vuttaṃ – “na pakatattassa bhikkhuno🔽abhivādanaṃ paccuṭṭhānaṃ…pe… piṭṭhiparikammaṃ sāditabba”nti idaṃ abhivādanādīnaṃ
analyzed: pakatatte caritabbehi an aññattā visum visum a gaṇetvā pārivāsika vuḍḍhatara ādīsu puggalantaresu  tesam vasena sampiṇḍetvā ekekam katvā gaṇitāni pañca ati ekasattati vattāni  ukkhepanīya kamma kata vattesu vatta paññāpana vasena vuttam na pakatattassa bhikkhuno  abhivādanam paccuṭṭhānam pe piṭṭhi parikammam sāditabbanti idam abhivādana ādīnam
translated: because they should be carried out by a regular monk.🔽The duties for one who has been given the trial period of six days are stated in the rule for the determining of the trial period of six days: “He should not consent to regular monks bowing down to him, rising up for him, raising their joined palms to him, doing acts of respect toward him, offering him a seat, offering him a bed, offering him water for washing his feet and a foot stool, offering him a foot scraper, receiving his bowl and robe, and massaging his back when he is bathing.”

original: assādiyanaṃ ekaṃ, “na pakatatto bhikkhu sīlavipattiyā anuddhaṃsetabbo”tiādīni ca🔽dasāti evaṃ dvāsīti honti. Etesveva pana kānici tajjanīyakammakatādivattāni kānici
analyzed: assādiyanam ekam na pakatattaḥ bhikkhu sīla vipattiyā an uddhaṃsetabbā iti ādīni ca  dasāti evam dvāsīti honti etesu eva pana kānici tajjanīya kammaka tā ādi vattāni kānici
translated: The duties for one who has been given the trial period of six days are stated in the rule for the determining of the trial period of six days: “He should not consent to regular monks bowing down to him, rising up for him, raising their joined palms to him, doing acts of respect toward him, offering him a seat, offering him a bed, offering him water for washing his feet and a foot stool, offering him a foot scraper, receiving his bowl and robe, and massaging his back when he is bathing.”

original: pārivāsikādivattānīti aggahitaggahaṇena dvāvīsativattanti veditabbaṃ. “Cuddasa mahāvattānī”ti
analyzed: pārivāsika ādi vattāni iti aggahita ggahaṇena dvāvīsati vattan ti veditabbam cuddasa mahā vattāni iti
translated: The duties for one who has been given the trial period of six days are stated in the rule for the determining of the trial period of six days: “He should not consent to regular monks bowing down to him, rising up for him, raising their joined palms to him, doing acts of respect toward him, offering him a seat, offering him a bed, offering him water for washing his feet and a foot stool, offering him a foot scraper, receiving his bowl and robe, and massaging his back when he is bathing.”🔽The duties for one who has been given the trial period of six days are stated in the rule for the determining of the trial period of six days: “He should not consent to regular monks bowing down to him, rising up for him, raising their joined palms to him, doing acts of respect toward him, offering him a seat, offering him a bed, offering him water for washing his feet and a foot stool, offering him a foot scraper, receiving his bowl and robe,

original: vatvāpi “āgantukagamikavattāni cā”ti imesaṃ visuṃ gahaṇaṃ imāni abhiṇhaṃ sambhavantīti
analyzed: vatvā api āgantuka gamika vattāni ca ati imesam visum gahaṇam imāni sambhavanti iti
translated: and also “the duties for the incoming and outgoing bhikkhu” are mentioned separately, because these are frequently met with.

original: katvā. Kileso okāsaṃ na labhati sabbadā vattappaṭipattiyaṃyeva byāvaṭacittatāya.🔽Ayonisomanasikāranti aniccādīsu “nicca”ntiādinā pavattaṃ anupāyamanasikāraṃ. Sativossagganti🔽satiyā vissajjanaṃ, sativirahanti attho. Evampīti vakkhamānāpekkhāya avuttasampiṇḍanattho pi-saddo.
analyzed: katvā kilesaḥ okāsam na labhati sabbadā vatta paṭipattiyaṃ yā iva byāvaṭa citta tāya  a yoniso manasikāram ti anicca ādīsu nicca anti ādinā pavattam anupāya manasikāram sati vossaggam ti  satiyāḥ vissajjanam sati virahanti attho evam pi iti vakkhamāna apekkhāya avutta sampiṇḍana tthaḥ pi saddaḥ
translated: The defilements do not get an opportunity, because his mind is always occupied with the practice of the duties.🔽Improper attention: attention given to impermanence, etc., as permanent, etc., i.e., attention given by an improper method. Neglect of mindfulness:🔽the letting go of mindfulness, the meaning is, the absence of mindfulness. The word pi, “also,” is used in the sense of an addition to what has gone before, looking to what follows.

original: Anusandhivasenāti pucchānusandhiādianusandhivasena. Pubbāparavasenāti pubbāparaganthasallakkhaṇavasena.🔽Gaṇhantassāti ācariyamukhato gaṇhantassa. Sajjhāyantassāti ācariyamukhato uggahitaganthaṃ
analyzed: anusandhi vasena ati puccha anusandhi ādi anusandhi vasena pubba apara vasena ati pubba apara gantha sallakkhaṇa vasena  gaṇhantassa ati ācariya mukhataḥ gaṇhantassa sajjhāyantassa ati ācariya mukhataḥ uggahita gantham
translated: By way of sequence: by way of the sequence of the questions, etc. By way of what is before and after: by way of the discernment of the text as what is before and after.

original: sajjhāyantassa. Vācentassāti pāḷiṃ tadatthañca uggaṇhāpanavasena paresaṃ vācentassa.
analyzed: sajjhāyantassa vācentassa ati pāḷim tad attham ca uggaṇhāpana vasena paresam vācentassa
translated: To one who is learning: to one who is learning from the teacher’s mouth. To one who is rehearsing: to one who is rehearsing the text that he has learned from the teacher’s mouth. To one who is reciting: to one who is reciting to others in order to get them to learn the text and its meaning.

original: Desentassāti desanāvasena paresaṃ dhammaṃ desentassa. Pakāsentassāti attano attano🔽saṃsayaṭṭhāne pucchantānaṃ yāthāvato atthaṃ pakāsentassa. Kileso okāsaṃ na labhati🔽rattindivaṃ ganthakammesuyeva byāvaṭacittatāya. Evampīti vuttasampiṇḍanattho pi-saddo. Evaṃ sesesupi.🔽Dhutaṅgadharo hotīti vuttamevatthaṃ pakāseti “terasa dhutaṅgaguṇe samādāya vattatī”ti.
analyzed: desentassa ati desanā vasena paresam dhammam desentassa pakāsentassa ati attanaḥ attanaḥ  saṃsaya ṭṭhāne pucchantānam yāthāvataḥ attham pakāsentassa kilesaḥ okāsam na labhati  rattindivam gantha kammesu yā iva byāvaṭa citta tāya evam pi iti vutta sampiṇḍana atthaḥ pi saddaḥ evam sesesu pi  dhutaṅga dharaḥ hoti iti vuttam eva attham pakāseti terasa dhutaṅga guṇe samādāya vattati iti
translated: ‘To one who teaches’: to one who teaches the Dhamma to others by way of instruction. ‘To one who explains’: to one who explains the meaning as it really is to those who ask about the points on which they are doubtful. ‘Defilement finds no opportunity’: because his mind is occupied all day and night with the work of learning, defilement finds no opportunity. The word ‘also’ is meant to include the rest. ‘He is one who bears the ascetic practices’: he shows the meaning of the words ‘he is one who bears the ascetic practices’ by saying ‘he goes about undertaking the thirteen ascetic practices.’🔽

original: Bāhullāyāti cīvarādipaccayabāhullāya. Yathā cīvarādayo paccayā bahulaṃ uppajjanti,🔽tathā āvattassa pavattassāti attho. Parihīnajjhānassāti jhānantarāyakarena visabhāgarūpadassanādinā🔽kenaci nimittena parihīnajjhānassa. Vissaṭṭhajjhānassāti asamāpajjanavasena pariccattajjhānassa.
analyzed: bāhullāya ati cīvara ādi paccaya bāhullāya yathā cīvara ādayaḥ paccayāḥ bahulam uppajjanti 🔽tathā āvattassa pavattassa ati attho parihīna jjhānassa ati jhā anantarāya karena visa bhāga rūpa dassana ādinā 🔽kenaci nimittena parihīna jjhānassa vissaṭṭha jhānassa ati a samāpajjana vasena pariccatta jhānassa
translated: ‘To one who teaches’: to one who teaches the Dhamma to others by way of instruction. ‘To one who explains’: to one who explains the meaning correctly to those who ask about the points on which he is in doubt. ‘Defilement finds no opportunity’: because his mind is occupied all day and night with the work of study, defilement finds no opportunity. The word ‘also’ is for the purpose of including what is stated in the following passage: ‘And how, bhikkhus, is a bhikkhu devoted to wakefulness? Here a bhikkhu is a forest-dweller … or a refuse-rag wearer … or a triple-robe wearer, and he does not give up the ascetic practice of the triple robe. He does not store away the various kinds of requisites.’ ‘To one who is not greedy for requisites’: to one who is not greedy for the abundance of requisites such as robes, etc. The meaning is that he does not turn to the abundance of requisites such as robes, etc., in the way that they occur, i.e. in the way that they are obtained. ‘To one who has lost his jhana’: to one who has lost his jhana by some sign that is a condition for the jhana, such as a visible form, etc., that is of a different nature from the object of jhana. ‘To one who has abandoned his jhana’: to one who has given up his jhana by not attaining it.

original: Bhassādīsūti ādi-saddena gaṇasaṅgaṇikaniddānavakammādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Sattasu vā anupassanāsūti
analyzed: bhassa ādīsu iti ādi saddena gaṇa saṅgaṇika niddānava kamma ādim saṅgaṇhāti sattasu vā anupassanāsu iti
translated: “In the seven contemplations” :

original: ettha satta anupassanā nāma aniccānupassanā dukkhānupassanā anattānupassanā nibbidānupassanā
analyzed: ettha satta anupassanā nāma anicca anupassanā dukkha anupassanā anatta anupassanā nibbida anupassanā
translated: Herein, the seven contemplations are contemplation of impermanence, contemplation of pain, contemplation of not-self, contemplation of dispassion,

original: virāgānupassanā nirodhānupassanā paṭinissaggānupassanā khayānupassanā vayānupassanā
analyzed: virāga anupassanā nirodha anupassanā paṭinissagga anupassanā khaya anupassanā vayā anupassanā
translated: contemplation of fading away of lust, contemplation of cessation, contemplation of relinquishment, contemplation of destruction, contemplation of fall,

original: vipariṇāmānupassanā animittānupassanā appaṇihitānupassanā suññatānupassanā adhipaññādhammavipassanā
analyzed: vipariṇāma anupassanā animitta anupassanā appaṇihita anupassanā suññatā anupassanā adhi paññā dhamma vipassanā
translated: contemplation of change, contemplation of the signless, contemplation of the desireless, contemplation of the void, contemplation of higher wisdom,

original: yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ ādīnavānupassanā paṭisaṅkhānupassanā vivaṭṭānupassanāti imāsu
analyzed: yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassanam ādīnava anupassanā paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā vivaṭṭa anupassanā ati imāsu
translated: contemplation of right view, contemplation of danger, contemplation of reflexion, contemplation of turning away.

original: aṭṭhārasasu mahāvipassanāsu ādito vuttā aniccānupassanādi-paṭinissaggānupassanāpariyantā
analyzed: aṭṭhārasasu mahāvipassanāsu āditas vuttā anicca anupassanā ādi paṭinissagga anupassanā pariyantā
translated: In these eighteen great kinds of insight, the first seven are the contemplation of impermanence, etc., and the last is the contemplation of turning away.

original: satta. Ettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ visuddhimaggasaṃvaṇṇanāto gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: satta ettha yam vattabbam tat visuddhi magga saṃvaṇṇanātaḥ gahetabbam
translated: What should be said about them is given in the Visuddhimagga commentary.🔽“By non-development” :

original: Anāsevanatāyāti purimattabhāve jhānena vikkhambhitakilesassa kāmacchandādiāsevanāya
analyzed: anāsevana tāya ati purima tad bhāve jhānena vikkhambhita kilesassa kāmacchanda ādi āsevanāya
translated: By the non-development of the defilements suppressed by the jhāna in the previous existence.

original: abhāvato. Ananubhūtapubbanti tasmiṃ attabhāve ananubhūtapubbaṃ. Jātoti etasseva vevacanaṃ
analyzed: abhāvataḥ ananubhūta pubbanti tasmin atta bhāve ananubhūta pubbam jātaḥ iti etassa iva vevacanam
translated: Because of non-existence. Not experienced before in this existence. Born is a synonym for arisen.

original: sañjātotiādi. Nanu ca khaṇikattā sabbadhammānaṃ uppannassa kāmacchandassa taṅkhaṇaṃyeva
analyzed: sañjātaḥ iti ādi nanu ca khaṇika ttā sabba dhammānam uppannassa kāmacchandassa
translated: Arisen, etc. But since all things are momentary, lust that has arisen

original: avassaṃ nirodhasambhavato niruddhe ca tasmiṃ puna aññasseva uppajjanato ca kathaṃ
analyzed: avassam nirodha sambhavataḥ niruddhe ca tasmin puna aññassa iva uppajjanato ca katham
translated: ceases in that moment itself. And since it has ceased, it is another that arises again. So how can there be

original: tassa punappunabhāvo rāsibhāvo cāti āha – “tattha sakiṃ uppanno kāmacchando”tiādi.
analyzed: tassa punappunabhāvaḥ rāsi bhāvaḥ ca ati āha tattha uppanno kāmacchandaḥ itiādi
translated: its repeated existence and its existence as a mass? He says: “Herein, lust that has arisen once,” etc.

original: Aṭṭhānametanti akāraṇametaṃ. Yena kāraṇena uppanno kāmacchando na nirujjhati, niruddho
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etat ti akāraṇam etam yena kāraṇena uppannaḥ kāmacchandaḥ na nirujjhati niruddhaḥ
translated: This is not a reason. The meaning is: there is no reason by which lust that has arisen does not cease, and

original: ca sveva puna uppajjissati, tādisaṃ kāraṇaṃ natthīti attho.🔽Rāgaṭṭhāniyanti rāgajanakaṃ. Aniccādīsu niccādivasena viparītamanasikāro, idha ayonisomanasikāroti
analyzed: ca su eva puna uppajjissati tādisam kāraṇam na atthi iti attho  rāga janakam anicca ādīsu nicca ādi vasena viparīta manasikāraḥ
translated: having ceased, it will arise again.🔽Causing passion: producing passion. Wrong reflection here is reflection on impermanence, etc., as permanent, etc.

original: āha – “anicce nicca”ntiādi. Ayonisomanasikāroti anupāyamanasikāro, kusaladhammappavattiyā
analyzed: āha anicce nicca ntiādi ayoniso manasikāro ti anupāya manasikāro kusala dhamma ppavattiyā
translated: He says: “On the impermanent as permanent,” etc. Wrong reflection is reflection by an improper means. For the arising of wholesome states

original: akāraṇabhūto manasikāroti attho. Uppathamanasikāroti kusaladhammappavattiyā amaggabhūto
analyzed: akāraṇa bhūtaḥ manasikāraḥ ti atthaḥ uppatha manasikāro ti kusala dhamma ppavattiyā amagga bhūto
translated: The meaning is: attention that is not a cause. The expression “attention to what is unsuitable” is attention that is not a way to the arising of profitable states.

original: manasikāro. Saccavippaṭikūlenāti saccābhisamayassa anunulomavasena. Āvajjanātiādinā🔽āvajjanāya paccayabhūtā tato purimuppannā manodvārikā akusalajavanappavatti phalavohārena
analyzed: manasikāraḥ sacca vippaṭikūlena ati sacca abhisamayassa āvajjana ati ādinā  āvajjanāya paccaya bhūtā tatas purima uppannā manodvārikā akusala javana ppavatti phala vohārena
translated: “Attention to what is contrary to truth” is attention that is not in conformity with the penetration of the truths.🔽The unprofitable javanas that occur in the cognitive series beginning with adverting are called “adverting” and so on because they are the conditions for the adverting, etc., that immediately precede them.

original: tathā vuttā. Tassa hi vasena sā akusalappavattiyā upanissayo hoti. Āvajjanāti bhavaṅgacittaṃ
analyzed: tathā vuttā tassa hi vasena sā akusala ppavattiyāḥ upanissayaḥ hoti bhavaṅga cittam
translated: For they are the decisive support for the occurrence of that unprofitable javana.🔽Adverting is the life-continuum consciousness.

original: āvajjayatīti āvajjanā. Anu anu āvajjetīti anvāvajjanā. Bhavaṅgārammaṇato aññaṃ ābhujatīti🔽ābhogo. Samannāharatīti samannāhāro. Tadevārammaṇaṃ attānaṃ anubandhitvā uppajjamāno
analyzed: āvajjayati iti āvajjanā anu anu āvajjeti iti anvāvajjanā bhavaṅga ārammaṇataḥ aññam ābhujati iti  ābhogaḥ samannāharati iti samannāhāraḥ tat eva ārammaṇam attānam anubandhitvā uppajjamānaḥ
translated: It adverts , thus it is adverting . It adverts again and again, thus it is repeated adverting . It emerges from the life-continuum, thus it is emergence .

original: manasi karoti ṭhapetīti manasikāro. Ayaṃ vuccati ayonisomanasikāroti ayaṃ anupāyauppathamanasikāralakkhaṇo
analyzed: manasi karoti ṭhapeti iti manasikāraḥ ayam vuccati a yoniso manasikāro ti ayam anupāya oppatha manasikāra lakkhaṇo
translated: It is the act of emerging, thus it is the act of emergence . It is the act of directing , thus it is direction . It is the act of giving attention , thus it is attention .

original: ayonisomanasikāro nāma vuccati.
analyzed: a yoni somanasikāraḥ nāma vuccati
translated: This is called “inattention” : this unprofitable attention, which is characterized by being a way that is not a way, is called “inattention.”

original: 12. Dutiye bhattabyāpatti viyāti bhattassa pūtibhāvena vippakārappatti viya, cittassa
analyzed: dutiye bhatta byāpatti viya ati bhattassa pūti bhāvena vippakāra ppatti viya cittassa
translated: Like the corruption of the food: like the corruption of the food by the rotting of it, so too by the corruption of the mind;

original: byāpajjananti cittassa vikārabhāvāpādanaṃ. Tenevāha – “pakativijahanabhāvo”ti. Byāpajjati
analyzed: byāpajjananti cittassa vikāra bhāva āpādanam tena iva āha pakati vijahana bhāvaḥ ti byāpajjati
translated: Corruption of the mind is the bringing about of a change in the mind. Hence it is said: “The state of abandoning its normal mode” .

original: tena cittaṃ pūtikummāsādayo viya purimapakatiṃ jahatīti byāpādo. Paṭighoyeva uparūpari🔽uppajjamānassa paṭighassa nimittabhāvato paṭighanimittaṃ, paṭighassa ca kāraṇabhūtaṃ
analyzed: tena cittam pūti kummāsa ādayaḥ purima pakatim jahati iti  uppajjamānassa paṭighassa nimitta bhāvataḥ paṭigha nimittam paṭighassa ca kāraṇa bhūtam
translated: The mind is corrupted by it, like a rotten cucumber, etc., because it abandons its normal mode, thus it is corruption .

original: ārammaṇaṃ paṭighanimittanti āha – “paṭighassapi paṭighārammaṇassapi etaṃ adhivacana”nti.
analyzed: ārammaṇam paṭigha nimittan ti āha paṭighassa api paṭigha ārammaṇassa api etam adhivacanam ti
translated: The sign of resistance: because it is the cause of the arising of resistance again and again, it is the sign of resistance . And the object that is the cause of resistance is the sign of resistance .

original: Aṭṭhakathāyanti mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ.🔽13. Tatiye thinatā thinaṃ, sappipiṇḍo viya avipphārikatāya cittassa ghanabhāvo baddhatāti
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāyanti mahā aṭṭhakathāyam  tatiye thina tā thinam sappi piṇḍaḥ viya a vipphārika tāya cittassa ghana bhāvaḥ baddha tā ti
translated: The commentary: in the Great Commentary .🔽In the third, sluggishness is sluggishness. The state of being compact of the mind, which is unserviceability because it does not spread out, is sluggishness. The meaning is, it is bound up .

original: attho. Medhatīti middhaṃ, akammaññabhāvena hiṃsatīti attho. “Yā tasmiṃ samaye cittassa
analyzed: atthaḥ medhati iti middham akammañña bhāvena hiṃsati iti atthaḥ yā tasmin samaye cittassa
translated: Drowsiness is sleep. The meaning is, it torments by making the mind unserviceable.

original: akalyatā”tiādinā thinassa, “yā tasmiṃ samaye kāyassa akalyatā”tiādinā ca middhassa
analyzed: a kalya tā ati ādinā thinassa yā tasmin samaye kāyassa a kalya tā ati ādinā ca middhassa
translated: “Sluggishness” is stated because sluggishness is described in the Abhidhamma as follows: “At that time there is sluggishness of the body” .

original: abhidhamme niddiṭṭhattā vuttaṃ – “cittassa akammaññatā thinaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ khandhānaṃ
analyzed: abhidhamme niddiṭṭha ttā vuttam cittassa akammañña tā thinam tiṇṇam khandhānam
translated: “Dullness” is stated because dullness is described in the Abhidhamma as follows: “At that time there is dullness of the three mental aggregates” .

original: akammaññatā middha”nti. Satipi aññamaññāvippayoge cittakāyalahutādīnaṃ viya cittacetasikānaṃ🔽yathākkamaṃ taṃtaṃviseso siyā, yā tesaṃ akalyatādīnaṃ visesapaccayatā, ayametesaṃ
analyzed: akammañña tā sati pi aññamaññā vippayoge citta kāya lahu tā ādīnam viya citta cetasikānam  yathākkamam taṃ taṃ visesaḥ siyā yā tesam akalya tā ādīnam visesa paccaya tā ayam etesam
translated: Even though they are mutually exclusive, there is a difference between them, just as there is a difference between lightness of the mind and lightness of the body.🔽The specific conditionality of sluggishness, etc., should be regarded as their individual characteristics.

original: sabhāvoti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kapimiddhassāti vuttamevatthaṃ vibhāveti “pacalāyikabhāvassā”ti.
analyzed: sabhāvaḥ ti daṭṭhabbam kapi middhassa ti vuttam eva attham vibhāveti pacalāyika bhāvassa ati
translated: The meaning stated by the words “sluggishness and drowsiness” is analyzed in the words “the state of being restless.”

original: Akkhidalānaṃ pacalabhāvaṃ karotīti pacalāyiko, pacalāyikassa bhāvo pacalāyikabhāvo,
analyzed: akkhi dalānam pacala bhāvam karoti iti pacalāyikaḥ pacalāyikassa bhāvaḥ pacalāyika bhāvaḥ
translated: Restlessness is that which makes the eyelids restless; the state of being restless is the state of restlessness.🔽The meaning is: the condition of being restless. “The two” means sluggishness and drowsiness.

original: pacalāyikattanti vuttaṃ hoti. Ubhinnanti thinamiddhānaṃ. “Vitthāro veditabbo”ti iminā
analyzed: vuttam hoti ubhinnam ti thinamiddhānam vitthāraḥ veditabbo ti iminā
translated: The connection should be understood with the words “the details should be understood.”

original: sambandho veditabbo. Cittassa akalyatāti cittassa gilānabhāvo. Gilāno hi akalyakoti
analyzed: sambandhaḥ veditabbo cittassa akalya tā ati cittassa gilāna bhāvaḥ gilānaḥ hi akalyakaḥ ti
translated: “Sluggishness of the mind” is the sickliness of the mind. For one who is sick is sluggish.

original: vuccati. Vinayepi vuttaṃ – “nāhaṃ, bhante, akalyako”ti. Kālaṃ khamatīti hi kalyaṃ,🔽arogatā, tassaṃ niyutto kalyako, na kalyako akalyako. Akammaññatāti cittagelaññasaṅkhātova
analyzed: vuccati vinaye pi vuttam na aham bhante akalyakaḥ iti kālam khamati iti hi kalyam  aroga tā tassam niyuttaḥ kalyakaḥ na kalyakaḥ a kalyakaḥ a kammañña tā ati citta gelañña saṅkhātaḥ uva
translated: and in the Vinaya: “I am not, venerable sir, out of sorts” . “Kalyāṇa” is health,🔽and “out of sorts” is opposed to that; “not out of sorts” is “not out of sorts” . “Unfitness” is the state of being unfit, which is a state of the mind’s being sluggish.

original: akammaññatākāro. Olīyanāti olīyanākāro. Iriyāpathūpatthambhitañhi cittaṃ iriyāpathaṃ
analyzed: akammañña tā ākāraḥ olīyanā ati olīyana ākāraḥ iriyāpatha upatthambhitam hi cittam iriyāpatham
translated: “Slackness” is the state of slackness. For when the mind is slack, it is unable to support the postures,

original: sandhāretuṃ asakkontaṃ rukkhe vagguli viya khīle laggitaphāṇitavārako viya ca olīyati
analyzed: sandhāretum a sakkontam rukkhe vagguli viya khīle laggita phāṇita vārakaḥ viya ca olīyati
translated: and then it is as if it were hanging down, like a creeper on a tree, or like a rope of fibres on a post.

original: lambati, tassa taṃ ākāraṃ sandhāya – “olīyanā”ti vuttaṃ. Dutiyapadaṃ upasaggena vaḍḍhitaṃ.
analyzed: lambati tassa tam ākāram sandhāya olīyanā ti vuttam dutiya padam upasaggena vaḍḍhitam
translated: The word “slackness” is said with reference to that state. The second word is extended by the prefix “pari” .

original: Kāyassāti vedanādikkhandhattayasaṅkhātassa nāmakāyassa. Akalyatā akammaññatāti heṭṭhā
analyzed: kāyassa ati vedanā ādi khandha ttaya saṅkhātassa nāmakāyassa a kalya tā akammañña tā ati heṭṭhā
translated: “In the body” : in the “body of name” consisting of the three aggregates beginning with feeling. “Out of sorts” and “unfitness” are in the way already stated.

original: vuttanayameva. Megho viya ākāsaṃ onayhatīti onāho. Onayhatīti ca chādeti avattharati
analyzed: vutta nayam eva meghaḥ viya ākāsam onayhati iti onāhaḥ onayhati iti ca chādeti avattharati
translated: “Overspreading” : it overspreads like a cloud the sky. “Overspreads” is the same as “covers” . The meaning is that it covers over or envelops.

original: vāti attho. Sabbatobhāgena onāhoti pariyonāho. Aratiādīnaṃ attho vibhaṅge vuttanayeneva
analyzed: vā ti attho sabbatobhāgena onāhaḥ ti pariyonāhaḥ arati ādīnam attho vibhaṅge vutta nayena iva
translated: “All round overspreading” is complete overspreading. The meaning of disinclination, etc., is given in the Vibhaṅga in the way beginning:🔽“What is disinclination?

original: veditabboti tattha vuttapāḷiyā dassetuṃ – “vuttaṃ heta”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ iti tattha vutta pāḷiyā dassetum vuttam hetat tiādim āha
translated: “Should be known” : in order to show this by means of the text quoted above, he says: “For this is said” .

original: Tattha pantesūti dūresu, vivittesu vā. Adhikusalesūti samathavipassanādhammesu. Aratīti🔽ratippaṭikkhepo. Aratitāti aramanākāro. Anabhiratīti anabhiratabhāvo. Anabhiramanāti
analyzed: tattha pantesu iti dūresu vivittesu vā adhi kusalesu iti samatha vipassanā dhammesu arati iti  rati paṭikkhepaḥ a rati tā ati a ramanā ākāraḥ an abhirati iti an abhirata bhāvaḥ an abhiramanā ati
translated: Herein, in the wilderness means in the remote or secluded places. In the higher states of heart means in the states of concentration and insight. Discontent means🔽the opposite of contentment. Discontentedness means the state of being discontented. Lack of delight means🔽the state of not delighting. Displeasure means the state of displeasure. Aversion means the state of aversion.

original: anabhiramanākāro. Ukkaṇṭhitāti ukkaṇṭhanākāro. Paritassitāti ukkaṇṭhanavaseneva paritassanā,
analyzed: an abhiramana ākāraḥ ukkaṇṭhitā ati ukkaṇṭhana ākāraḥ paritassitā ati ukkaṇṭhana vasena iva paritassanā
translated: Agitation means the state of agitation. Worry means the state of worry.

original: ukkaṇṭhitasseva tattha tattha taṇhāyanāti vuttaṃ hoti. Paritassitāti vā kampanā.🔽Tandīti jātiālasiyaṃ, pakatiālasiyanti attho. Tathā hi kusalakaraṇe kāyassa avipphārikatā
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhitassa iva tattha tattha taṇhāyanā ti vuttam hoti paritassitā ati vā kampanā  tandī iti jāti ālasiyam pakati ālasiyam ti attho tathā hi kusala karaṇe kāyassa a vipphārika tā
translated: It is said that one who is agitated worries about this and that out of craving for it. Or worry means trembling.🔽Dullness means natural sluggishness. For sluggishness in the sense of unserviceability of the body in the doing of profitable things is

original: līnatā jātiālasiyaṃ tandī nāma, na rogautujādīhi kāyagelaññaṃ. Tandiyanāti tandiyanākāro.
analyzed: līna tā jāti ālasiyam tandī nāma na ro gautuja ādīhi kāya gelaññam tandiyanā ati tandiyana ākāraḥ
translated: natural sluggishness, called dullness, not sluggishness of the body due to disease, etc. Dullness of mind means the state of being dull.

original: Tandimanatāti tandiyā abhibhūtacittatā. Alasassa bhāvo ālasyaṃ, ālasyāyanākāro ālasyāyanā.
analyzed: tandiyā abhibhūta citta tā alasassa bhāvaḥ ālasyam ālasya ayana ākāraḥ
translated: Dullness of cognizance means the state of being overcome by dullness. Laziness means the state of being lazy. The state of being lazy is laziness.

original: Ālasyāyitassa bhāvo ālasyāyitattaṃ. Iti sabbehipi imehi padehi kilesavasena kāyālasiyaṃ
analyzed: ālasyāyitassa bhāvaḥ ālasyāyitattam iti sabbehi pi imehi padehi kilesa vasena kāya ālasiyam
translated: The state of one who is lazy is laziness. So all these terms refer to bodily sluggishness by way of defilements.

original: kathitaṃ. Thinamiddhakāraṇānañhi rāgādikilesānaṃ vasena nāmakāyassa ālasiyaṃ, tadeva
analyzed: kathitam thinam iddha kāraṇānam hi rāga ādi kilesānam vasena nāmakāyassa ālasiyam tat eva
translated: For the sluggishness of the name-group is due to the defilements of lust, etc., which are the cause of stiffness and torpor,🔽and that of the form-group is due to them in the same way.

original: rūpakāyassāpīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Jambhanāti phandanā. Punappunaṃ jambhanā vijambhanā.
analyzed: rūpa kāyassa api iti daṭṭhabbam jambhanā ati phandanā punappunam jambhanā vijambhanā
translated: Shaking is trembling. Trembling again and again is quivering.

original: Ānamanāti purato namanā. Vinamanāti pacchato namanā. Sannamanāti samantato namanā.
analyzed: ānamanā ati puratas namanā vinamanā ati pacchatas namanā sannamanā ati samantataḥ namanā
translated: Bending is bending forward. Bowing is bending backward. Stretching is bending in all directions.

original: Paṇamanāti yathā tantato uṭṭhitapesakāro kismiñcideva gahetvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ ussāpeti,🔽evaṃ kāyassa uddhaṃ ṭhapanā. Byādhiyakanti uppannabyādhitā. Iti sabbehipi imehi padehi🔽thinamiddhakāraṇānaṃ rāgādikilesānaṃ vasena kāyabaddhanameva kathitaṃ. Bhuttāvissāti
analyzed: yathā tantataḥ uṭṭhita pesakāraḥ kismiñcid eva gahetvā ujum kāyam ussāpeti  evam kāyassa uddham ṭhapanāḥ uppanna byādhitāḥ iti sabbehi pi imehi padehi  rāga ādi kilesānam vasena kathitam
translated: Pulling is straightening the body as a weaver straightens warp threads by pulling them up one by one.🔽All these terms refer to bodily stiffness due to the defilements of lust, etc., which are the cause of stiffness and torpor.

original: bhuttavato. Bhattamucchāti bhattagelaññaṃ. Balavabhattena hi mucchāpatto viya hoti.
analyzed: bhuttavataḥ bhattam ucchāti bhatta gelaññam balava bhattena hi mucchā pattaḥ viya hoti
translated: The state of one who has eaten is the state of one who has eaten food. The state of one who has drunk is the state of one who has drunk a beverage. For one who has drunk a beverage is as if overcome by faintness.

original: Bhattakilamathoti bhattena kilantabhāvo. Bhattapariḷāhoti bhattadaratho. Tasmiñhi🔽samaye pariḷāhuppattiyā upahatindriyo hoti, kāyo jīratīti. Kāyaduṭṭhullanti bhattaṃ🔽nissāya kāyassa akammaññataṃ. Akalyatātiādi heṭṭhā vuttanayameva. Līnanti avipphārikatāya🔽paṭikuṭitaṃ. Itare dve ākārabhāvaniddesā. Thinanti sappipiṇḍo viya avipphārikatāya
analyzed: bhatta kilamatho ti bhattena kilanta bhāvaḥ bhatta pariḷāho ti tasmin hi  samaye pariḷāha uppattiyā upahata indriyaḥ hoti kāyaḥ jīrati iti kāya duṭṭhullanti bhattam  nissāya kāyassa akammañña tam a kalya tā atiādi heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva līnanti a vipphārika tāya  paṭikuṭitam itare dve ākāra bhāva niddesā sappi piṇḍaḥ viya a vipphārika tāya
translated: “Fatigue from eating” is the state of being tired by eating. “Swelling from eating” is the state of being bloated by eating. For at that time his faculties are impaired by the arising of swelling, and his body is worn out. “Rigidity of the body” is unserviceability of the body due to eating. “Unfitness” and so on are as already explained . “Dullness” is the state of being contracted through lack of diffusion. The other two are descriptions of the development of the mode . “Drowsiness” is the state of being contracted through lack of diffusion, like a ball of oil-cakes.

original: ghanabhāvena ṭhitaṃ. Thiyanāti ākāraniddeso. Thiyibhāvo thiyitattaṃ, avipphāravaseneva🔽baddhatāti attho. Imehi pana sabbehipi padehi thinamiddhakāraṇānaṃ rāgādikilesānaṃ🔽vasena cittassa gilānākāro kathitoti veditabbo. Purimā cattāro dhammāti arati, tandī,🔽vijambhitā, bhattasammadoti ete cattāro dhammā. Yadā thinamiddhaṃ uppannaṃ hoti,
analyzed: ghana bhāvena ṭhitam ākāra niddeso thiyi bhāvaḥ thiyi tattam a vipphāra vasena iva 🔽baddha tā ti atthaḥ imehi pana sabbehi pi padehi thina middha kāraṇānam rāga ādi kilesānam 🔽vasena cittassa gilāna ākāraḥ kathito ti veditabbo purimā cattāro dhammā ati arati tandī 🔽vijambhitā bhatta sammado ti ete cattāro dhammā yadā thinamiddham uppannam hoti
translated: “Fatigue from eating” is the state of being tired by eating. “Satiety from eating” is the state of being oppressed by eating. For at that time the faculties are impaired by the arising of satiety, and the body becomes old. “Unfitness of the body” is the unserviceability of the body due to eating. “Unfitness of the mind” and so on are as already explained. “Dullness” is the state of being contracted due to lack of diffusion. The other two terms are descriptions of the mode of activity. “Drowsiness” is the state of being stuck together like a lump of dough due to lack of diffusion. “Dullness” is a description of the mode of activity. “The state of being dull” is the state of being contracted, the meaning being “the state of being bound up” due to lack of diffusion. But it should be understood that all these terms refer to the sick state of the mind due to the defilements such as lust that are the causes of dullness and drowsiness. “The first four things” are disliking, sluggishness, yawning, and drowsiness. When dullness and drowsiness arise,

original: tadā aratiādīnampi sambhavato “upanissayakoṭiyā pana hotī”ti vuttaṃ, upanissayakoṭiyā
analyzed: tadā arati ādīnam pi sambhavataḥ upanissaya koṭiyā pana hoti iti vuttam upanissaya koṭiyā
translated: Since discontent, etc., are also possible, it is said: “but it is as decisive-support condition.”

original: paccayo hotīti attho.
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti iti attho
translated: The meaning is: it is a condition as decisive-support.

original: 14. Catutthe uddatassa bhāvo uddhaccaṃ. Yassa dhammassa vasena uddhataṃ hoti cittaṃ,
analyzed: catutthe uddatassa bhāvaḥ uddhaccam yassa dhammassa vasena uddhatam hoti cittam
translated: In the fourth, agitation is the state of being agitated. Or the state of that idea by means of which consciousness is agitated,

original: taṃsampayuttā vā dhammā, so dhammo uddaccaṃ. Kucchitaṃ kataṃ kukataṃ, duccaritaṃ
analyzed: tad sampayuttāḥ vā dhammā saḥ dhammaḥ uddaccam kucchitam katam kukatam duccaritam
translated: or the ideas associated with that idea, is agitation. Badly done is done badly, badly conducted,

original: sucaritañca. Akatampi hi kukatameva. Evañhi vattāro honti “yaṃ mayā na kataṃ, taṃ🔽kukata”nti. Evaṃ katākataṃ duccaritaṃ sucaritañca kukataṃ, taṃ ārabbha vippaṭisāravasena🔽pavattaṃ pana cittaṃ idha kukatanti veditabbaṃ. Tassa bhāvo kukkuccaṃ. Cittassa uddhatākāroti
analyzed: su caritam ca a katam pi hi ku katam eva evam hi vattāraḥ honti yam mayā na katam tam  evam kata akatam duccaritam su caritam ca kukatam tam ārabbha vippaṭisāra vasena  pavattam pana cittam idha kukatanti veditabbam tassa bhāvo kukkuccam cittassa uddhata ākāro ti
translated: and also well done is badly done. For even what is not done is badly done. For people say: “What I have not done is badly done by me.”🔽So what is done and what is not done are badly done, badly conducted. But the consciousness that occurs with remorse as its source🔽should be understood as “badly done” here. The state of that is worry. The state of agitation of consciousness

original: cittassa avūpasamākārova vutto. Avūpasamalakkhaṇañhi uddhaccaṃ. Yathāpavattassa katākatākāravisiṭṭhassa
analyzed: cittassa a vūpasama ākāraḥ uva vuttaḥ a vūpasama lakkhaṇam hi uddhaccam yathā pavattassa kata a kata ākāra visiṭṭhassa
translated: is said to be the state of non-quieting of consciousness. For agitation has the characteristic of non-quieting. It is the state of what is done and what is not done, distinguished by the way in which it occurs,

original: duccaritasucaritassa anusocanavasena virūpaṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ vippaṭisāro. Kukkuccassapi🔽katākatānusocanavasena cittavikkhepabhāvato avūpasamākāro sambhavatīti āha – “cetaso🔽avūpasamoti uddhaccakukkuccassevataṃ nāma”nti. Sveva ca cetaso avūpasamoti uddhaccakukkuccameva
analyzed: duccarita su caritassa anusocana vasena virūpam paṭisaraṇam vippaṭisāraḥ kukkuccassa pi  kata akata anusocana vasena citta vikkhepa bhāvataḥ a vūpasama ākāraḥ sambhavati iti āha cetasaḥ  avūpasamaḥ uti su eva ca cetasaḥ uddhacca kukkuccam eva
translated: Disappointment is a repulsive resort in the sense of sorrow over evil and good done. And since anxiety is a state of mental distraction in the sense of sorrow over what has been done and what has not been done, it has the mode of non- pacification. Thus it is said: “Non-pacification of mind is agitation and anxiety.”

original: niddiṭṭhaṃ. Tañca attanova attanā sahajātaṃ na hotīti āha – “ayaṃ pana upanissayakoṭiyā
analyzed: niddiṭṭham tat ca attanā iva attanā sahajātam na hoti iti āha ayam pana upanissaya koṭiyā
translated: And this non-pacification of mind is shown to be agitation and anxiety. And that is not conascent with itself. Thus it is said: “This is a condition by way of decisive support.”

original: paccayo hotī”ti. Upanissayapaccayatā ca purimuppannavasena veditabbā.
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti iti upanissaya paccaya tā ca purima uppanna vasena veditabbā
translated: And the state of being a decisive support condition should be understood as prior.

original: 15. Pañcame vigatā cikicchā assāti vicikicchā. Sabhāvaṃ vicinanto tāya kicchatīti vā vicikicchā.
analyzed: pañcame vigatā cikicchā assa ati vicikicchā sabhāvam vicinantaḥ tāya kicchati iti vā vicikicchā
translated: In the fifth, there is no desire to investigate, thus there is non-investigation . Or, one investigates the individual essence by means of that, thus it is non-investigation .

original: 16. Chaṭṭhe hetuṃ vā paccayaṃ vā na labhatīti ettha hetuggahaṇena janakaṃ kāraṇamāha,
analyzed: chaṭṭhe hetum vā paccayam vā na labhati iti ettha hetu ggahaṇena janakam kāraṇam āha
translated: In the sixth, there is no obtaining of a cause or condition. Herein, by the word “cause” a productive cause is meant,

original: paccayaggahaṇena anupālanakaṃ kāraṇaṃ. Hetunti vā upādānakāraṇaṃ. Paccayanti sahakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: paccaya ggahaṇena anupālanakam kāraṇam hetunti vā upādāna kāraṇam paccayanti saha kāraṇam
translated: and by the word “condition” a sustaining cause is meant. Or, “cause” is a cause that is a support, and “condition” is a co-operating cause.

original: vuttaṃ. Tanti kilesaṃ. Vivaṭṭetvā arahattaṃ gaṇhātīti vivaṭṭābhimukhaṃ cittaṃ pesetvā
analyzed: vuttam tanti kilesam vivaṭṭetvā arahattam gaṇhāti iti vivaṭṭa abhimukham cittam pesetvā
translated: “Tanti kilesaṃ” means: defilement. “Having turned it over, he should reach Arahantship” means: having directed the mind towards turning it over,

original: vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhento arahattaphalaṃ gaṇhāti. Bhikkhāya caranti etthāti bhikkhācāro,
analyzed: vipassanam vaḍḍhentaḥ arahatta phalam gaṇhāti bhikkhāya caranti ettha ati bhikkhācāro
translated: increasing insight, he should reach the fruit of Arahantship. “In the alms-resort” means: in the alms-resort village,

original: gocaragāmassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ, tasmiṃ bhikkhācāre. Vayaṃ āgammāti dārabharaṇānurūpaṃ
analyzed: gocara gāmassa itam adhivacanam tasmin bhikkhā ācāre vayam āgamma ati dāra bharaṇa anurūpam
translated: this is the designation for the village where one goes for alms. “Having come to the alms-resort” means: having come to the alms-resort in accordance with the amount of provisions.

original: vayaṃ āgamma. Āyūhantoti upacinanto. Aṅgārapakkanti vītaccikaṅgāresu pakkaṃ. Kiṃ
analyzed: vayam āgamma āyūhantaḥ iti upacinantaḥ aṅgāra pakkam ti vītaccikaṅgāresu pakkam kim
translated: “Gathering” means: accumulating. “Cooked in a charcoal pit” means: cooked in a charcoal pit without embers. “What is it?”

original: nāmetanti bhikkhū garahanto āha. Jīvamānapetakasattoti jīvamāno hutvā “teneva attabhāvena🔽petabhāvaṃ pattasatto bhavissatī”ti parikappavasena vuttaṃ. Kuṭanti pānīyaghaṭaṃ.🔽Yāva dāruṇanti ativiya dāruṇaṃ. Vipāko kīdiso bhavissatīti tayā katakammassa āyatiṃ
analyzed: nāma etat ti bhikkhū garahantaḥ āha jīvamāna petaka satto ti jīvamānaḥ hutvā tena iva atta bhāvena  peta bhāvam pattasatto bhavissati iti parikappa vasena vuttam kuṭanti pānīya ghaṭam  yāva ativiya dāruṇam vipākaḥ kīdisaḥ bhavissati iti tayā kata kammassa āyatim
translated: means: while reproaching the monks he said this. “A living ghost” means: “having become a living being,🔽he will become a ghost with that very body” is said by way of supposition. “A water-pot” means: a water-jar.🔽“How terrible!” means: very terrible. “What will the result be like?” means: what will the result be like that you will experience in the future

original: anubhavitabbavipāko kīdiso bhavissati.
analyzed: anubhavitabba vipāko kīdisaḥ bhavissati
translated: as a consequence of the deed you have done?

original: Visaṅkharitvāti chedanabhedanādīhi vināsetvā. Dīpakamigapakkhinoti attano nisinnabhāvassa
analyzed: visaṅkharitvā iti chedana bhedana ādīhi vināsetvā dīpaka miga pakkhino ti attanaḥ nisinna bhāvassa
translated: Without making them up again: without mending them by sewing, etc. The deer-bird: the bird that is so called because it shows itself by its own sitting.

original: dīpanato evaṃladdhanāmā migapakkhino, yena araññaṃ netvā nesādo tesaṃ saddena āgatāgate🔽migapakkhino vadhitvā gaṇhāti. Theranti cūḷapiṇḍapātikatissattheraṃ. Iddhiyā abhisaṅkharitvāti
analyzed: dīpanataḥ evaṃladdha nāmā miga pakkhinaḥ yena araññam netvā nesādaḥ tesam saddena āgata āgate  miga pakkhinaḥ vadhitvā gaṇhāti theram ti cūḷa piṇḍapātika tissa theram iddhiyā abhisaṅkharitvā ati
translated: The hunter took it to the forest. Whenever the deer-bird called,🔽the hunter killed the deer that came in response to its call and took them. The elder: the elder Tissa, the lesser alms-food eater.

original: adhiṭṭhānādivasena iddhiṃ abhisaṅkharitvā. Upayogatthe cetaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ. Aggipapaṭikanti🔽accikaraṇaṃ, vipphuliṅganti attho. Passantassevāti anādare sāmivacanaṃ. Tassa therassāti
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna ādi vasena iddhim abhisaṅkharitvā upayoga tthe ca itam karaṇa vacanam  accikaraṇam vipphuliṅganti attho passantassa iva ati anādare sāmi vacanam tassa therassa ati
translated: Having made it by supernormal power: having made it by supernormal power in the way of resolve, etc. The gerund is in the sense of instrument. The fire-wheel:🔽the making of fire, the meaning is, the sparks. As he was looking on: the instrumental case is in the sense of disrespect. Of that elder:

original: tassa milakkhatissattherassa. Tassāti tassā aggipapaṭikāya. Paṭibalassāti uggahaṇasajjhāyādīsu
analyzed: tassa milakkha tissa therassa tassa ati tassā aggipa paṭikāya paṭibalassa ati uggahaṇa sajjhāya ādīsu
translated: of that elder Tissa the foreigner. Of it: of that fire-wheel. Able: able in learning, rehearsal, etc.

original: paṭibalassa. Dukkhaṃ upanisā kāraṇametissāti dukkhūpanisā, dukkhanibandhanā dukkhahetukā
analyzed: paṭibalassa dukkham upanisā kāraṇam etissa ati dukkhūpanisā dukkha nibandhanā dukkha hetukā
translated: With pain as its source: with pain as its cause, with pain as its origin, with pain as its requisite.

original: saddhāti vuttaṃ hoti. Vattamukhena kammaṭṭhānassa kathitattā “vattasīse ṭhatvā”ti
analyzed: saddhā iti vuttam hoti vatta mukhena kammaṭṭhānassa kathita ttā vatta sīse ṭhatvā iti
translated: “Faith” is what is meant. Since the meditation subject is given by way of the in-breath and out-breath, he should “stand at the head of the practice”

original: vuttaṃ. Palālavaraṇakanti palālapuñjaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam palāla varaṇakam ti palāla puñjam
translated: “Faith” is what is meant. “At the head of the practice” is said because the meditation subject is taught by way of the practice. “A heap of straw” is a bundle of straw.

original: Ārambhathāti samathavipassanādīsu vīriyaṃ karotha. Nikkamathāti kosajjato nikkhamatha,
analyzed: ārambhatha ati samatha vipassana ādīsu vīriyam karotha nikkamatha ati kosajjataḥ nikkhamatha
translated: “Make an effort” means make energy arise in the kinds of concentration and insight, etc.; “make an effort” means come out from idleness,

original: kāmānaṃ vā panūdanāya nikkhamatha, ubhayenapi vīriyameva vuttaṃ. Vīriyañhi ārambhanakavasena🔽ārambho, kosajjato nikkhamanavasena “nikkamo”ti vuccati. Yuñjatha buddhasāsaneti
analyzed: kāmānam vā panūdanāya nikkhamatha ubhayena api vīriyam eva vuttam vīriyam hi ārambhanaka vasena  ārambhaḥ kosajjataḥ nikkhamana vasena nikkamo ti vuccati yuñjatha buddha sāsanā iti
translated: or make an effort to remove sense desires. By both expressions energy is meant. For energy is called “making an effort”

original: buddhassa bhagavato pariyattipaṭipattipaṭivedhasaṅkhāte tividhasāsane yuñjatha yogaṃ
analyzed: buddhassa bhagavataḥ pariyatti paṭipatti paṭivedha saṅkhāte tividha sāsane yuñjatha yogam
translated: because it is the beginning of work, and it is called “coming out” because it comes out from idleness. “Apply yourselves to the Dispensation of the Buddha” means apply yourselves to the Dispensation of the Exalted One, which is threefold as learning, practice, and realization.

original: karotha. Evamanuyuñjantā maccuno senaṃ dhunātha viddhaṃsetha. Tattha maccuno senanti –
analyzed: karotha evam anuyuñjantā maccunaḥ senam dhunātha viddhaṃsetha tattha maccunaḥ senam iti
translated: By so doing, you will shake off and destroy the army of Death. Herein, the army of Death is

original: “Kāmā te paṭhamā senā, dutiyā arati vuccati;
analyzed: kāmā te paṭhamā senā dutiyā arati vuccati
translated: “Sense desires are the first army, the second is called discontent;

original: Tatiyā khuppipāsā te, catutthī taṇhā pavuccati.
analyzed: tatiyā khuppipāsā te catutthī taṇhā pavuccati
translated: The third is hunger and thirst, the fourth is called craving.

original: “Pañcamaṃ thinamiddhaṃ te, chaṭṭhā bhīrū pavuccati;
analyzed: pañcamam thinamiddham te chaṭṭhā bhīrū pavuccati
translated: “The fifth is sloth and torpor, the sixth is called fear;

original: Sattamī vicikicchā te, makkho thambho te aṭṭhamo.🔽“Lābho siloko sakkāro,
analyzed: sattamī vicikicchā te makkhaḥ thambhaḥ te aṭṭhamaḥ  lābhaḥ silokaḥ sakkāro
translated: Is conceit and arrogance.🔽Gain, fame, and honour,🔽And the wrong kind of respect,

original: Micchāladdho ca yo yaso;🔽Yo cattānaṃ samukkaṃse,
analyzed: micchā laddhaḥ ca yaḥ yaso  yaḥ cattānam samukkaṃse
translated: And one who exalts oneself

original: Pare ca avajānāti.
analyzed: pare ca avajānāti
translated: And disparages others,🔽This is your army, Namuci,

original: “Esā namuci te senā, kaṇhassābhippahārinī;
analyzed: esā namuci te senā kaṇhassa abhippahārinī
translated: Which carries off the dark one,🔽The non-hero does not conquer it,

original: Na naṃ asūro jināti, jetvā ca labhate sukha”nti. –
analyzed: na nam asūraḥ jināti jetvā ca labhate sukhanti
translated: Having conquered, one obtains happiness.

original: Evamāgataṃ kāmādibhedaṃ maccuno senaṃ. Ettha ca yasmā āditova agāriyabhūte satte🔽vatthukāmesu kilesakāmā mosayanti, te abhibhuyya anagāriyabhāvaṃ upagatānaṃ pantesu
analyzed: evam āgatam kāma ādi bhedam maccuno ca yasmai āditas va agāriya bhūte satte  vatthu kāmesu kilesa kāmāḥ mosayanti te abhibhuyya anagāriya bhāvam upagatānam pantesu
translated: Thus, the army of Death, which has come in this way, is divided into sensual desires, etc. And here, since from the very beginning sensual desires as defilements delude beings who are householders,

original: senāsanesu aññataraññataresu vā adhikusalesu dhammesu arati uppajjati. Vuttañhetaṃ
analyzed: senāsanesu aññatara aññataresu vā adhikusalesu dhammesu arati uppajjati vuttam ha etam
translated: and having overcome them, they go forth from the home life. Then, in regard to the dwellings in the forest, or in regard to the other unskillful states, discontent arises. This is said:

original: – “pabbajitena kho, āvuso, abhirati dukkarā”ti. Tato te parappaṭibaddhajīvikattā

analyzed: arañña vana patthesu pantesu senāsanesu viharatam utrāsa saññitā bhīru jāyati tesam  ussaṅkita parisaṅkitānam dīgharattam viveka rasa manaḥ sādayamānānam viharatam na siyā

translated: and so the first part of the verse should be understood as “sensual desires, etc.”🔽“A hut of reeds”: a hut made of reeds and thatched with grass.

original: Vihassatīti uggahaṇasajjhāyanamanasikārādīhi viharissati. Jātisaṃsāranti punappunaṃ
analyzed: vihassati iti uggahaṇa sajjhāyana manasikāra ādīhi viharissati jāti saṃsāranti punappunam
translated: “Will live”: he will live by way of learning, rehearsing, giving attention, etc.🔽“The round of rebirths”: the round of rebirths called “the round of births and deaths.”

original: jātisaṅkhātasaṃsāravaṭṭaṃ. Dukkhassantaṃ karissatīti dukkhassa antasaṅkhātaṃ nibbānaṃ
analyzed: jāti saṅkhāta saṃsāra vaṭṭam dukkhassa antam karissati iti dukkhassa anta saṅkhātam nibbānam
translated: “Will make an end of suffering”: he will realize Nibbāna, which is called “the end of suffering.”

original: sacchikarissati. Palālapuñjāhanti palālapuñjaṃ ahanti padacchedo. Tatiyaṃ ṭhānanti
analyzed: sacchikarissati palāla puñja āhanti palāla puñjam ahanti padacchedaḥ tatiyam ṭhānan ti
translated: “The bundle of sticks”: the analysis of the words is “a bundle of sticks he will strike.”

original: anāgāmiphalaṃ sandhāya vadati.🔽Tivassabhikkhukāleti upasampadato tīṇi vassāni assāti tivasso, tivasso ca so bhikkhu
analyzed: anāgāmi phalam sandhāya vadati  ti vassa bhikkhu kāle ti upasampadataḥ tīṇi vassāni assa ati ti vassaḥ ti vassaḥ ca so bhikkhu
translated: The third stage: he says this referring to the fruit of non-return.

original: cāti tivassabhikkhu, tassa, tena vā upalakkhito kālo tivassabhikkhukālo, tasmiṃ.
analyzed: tassa tena vā upalakkhitaḥ kālaḥ ti vassa bhikkhu kālo tasmin
translated: “A bhikkhu of three years’ standing”: one who has three years is a “three-year bhikkhu” ; the time that is characterized by him is the “time of a bhikkhu of three years’ standing”; in that.🔽When he is called a “three-year bhikkhu,” then—this is what is meant.

original: Yadā so tivasso bhikkhu nāma hoti, tadāti vuttaṃ hoti. Kammaṃ karotīti bhāvanākammaṃ
analyzed: yadā so ti vassaḥ bhikkhu nāma hoti tadā ati vuttam hoti kammam karoti iti bhāvanā kammaṃ
translated: “Will do the work”: he will do the work of development.

original: karoti. Ganthakammanti ganthavisayaṃ uggahaṇādikammaṃ. Piṇḍāpacitiṃ katvāti antovasse
analyzed: karoti gantha kamman ti gantha visayam uggahaṇa ādi kammam piṇḍa apacitim katvā ati antovasse
translated: He did. The work of binding: the work of learning the subject of the bonds.

original: temāsaṃ dinnapiṇḍassa kilesakkhayakaraṇena apacitiṃ pūjaṃ katvā. Piṇḍāpacitiṃ karonto🔽hi bhikkhu yehi attano yo piṇḍapāto dinno, tesaṃ tassa mahapphalabhāvaṃ icchanto
analyzed: temāsam dinna piṇḍassa kilesa khaya karaṇena apacitim pūjam katvā piṇḍāpacitim karontaḥ  hi bhikkhu yehi attanaḥ yaḥ piṇḍapātaḥ dinno tesam tassa mahapphala bhāvaṃ icchanto
translated: Having made an end of his dependence on alms: having made an end of his dependence on alms by destroying the defilements during the three months of the rains.

original: attano santānameva kilesakkhayakaraṇena visodhetvā arahattaṃ gaṇhāti.
analyzed: attano santānam eva kilesa khaya karaṇena visodhetvā arahattam gaṇhāti
translated: For when a bhikkhu makes an end of his dependence on alms, he attains Arahantship by purifying his own continuity by destroying the defilements, desiring thereby to make the alms given to him by others fruitful.

original: Mahābhūtīti ettha pūjāvacano mahantasaddo, bhūtīti ca nāmekadesena tissabhūtittheraṃ
analyzed: mahābhūtī iti ettha pūjā vacanaḥ mahanta saddaḥ bhūtī iti ca nāma eka desena
translated: The Greatly Prosperous: the word “greatly” is an expression of respect. And “prosperous” is addressed to the Elder Tissa, who was so called by the first part of his name.

original: ālapati. Bhavati hi nāmekadesenapi vohāro yathā “devadatto datto”ti. Mahābhūtīti
analyzed: ālapati bhavati hi nāma eka desena api vohāraḥ yathā devadattaḥ mahābhūtī iti

original: vā piyasamudāhāro, so mahati bhūti vibhūti puññañāṇādisampadā assāti mahābhūti. Channaṃ
analyzed: vā piya samudāhāraḥ saḥ mahati bhūti vibhūti puññañāṇa ādi sampadā assa ati mahābhūti channam

original: sepaṇṇigacchamūlanti sākhāpalāsādīhi channaṃ ghanacchāyaṃ sepaṇṇigacchamūlaṃ. Asubhakammaṭṭhānaṃ

original: vā pādakaṃ katvā. Asubhavisayaṃ upacārajjhānādikammamevettha upari pavattetabbabhāvanākammassa
analyzed: vā pādakam katvā asubha visayam upacāra jjhāna ādi kammam eva itthā upari pavattetabba bhāvanā kammassa

analyzed: kāraṇa bhāvato ṭhānan ti kammaṭṭhānam
translated: The place is the meditation subject since it is the place for the work of development.

analyzed: bhante divāṭṭhāne pāda dhovana kāle bhante iti tatas paṭṭhāya yāva aruṇā apare pucchanti  āvuso ti danta kaṭṭham gahetvā mukha dhovana ttham gamana kāle bhante ti tadā api aññe

analyzed: pucchanti iti mukham dhovitvā āgamana kāle bhante ti tatra api aññe pucchissanti iti
translated: “Venerable Sir.” “When I had washed my face and returned, Venerable Sir.” There, too, others would ask me.

original: Senāsanaṃ pavisitvā nisinnakāle, bhanteti. Tatrāpi aññe pucchanti, āvusoti. Evaṃ
analyzed: senāsanam pavisitvā nisinna kāle bhante ti tatra api aññe pucchanti āvuso ti evam
translated: “When I entered the dwelling and sat down, Venerable Sir.” There, too, others asked me, “Friend.”

original: sabbesu rattidivasabhāgesu yācamāno okāsaṃ na labhi, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ – “evaṃ🔽okāse asati maraṇassa kathaṃ okāsaṃ labhissathā”ti. Bhante, nanu mukhaṃ dhovitvā
analyzed: sabbesu ratti divasa bhāgesu yācamānaḥ okāsam na labhi tam sandhāya itam vuttam evam  okāse asati maraṇassa katham okāsam labhissatha ati bhante nanu mukham dhovitvā
translated: He said this referring to the fact that he did not get an opportunity to ask for it at any time of day or night.

original: senāsanaṃ pavisitvā tayo cattāro pallaṅke uṇhāpetvā yonisomanasikārakammaṃ karontānaṃ
analyzed: senāsanam pavisitvā tayo cattāraḥ pallaṅke uṇhāpetvā yonisomanasikāra kammam karontānam
translated: The meaning of his statement is this: “Venerable Sir, when one washes one’s face, enters one’s dwelling, warms one’s bed three or four times, and then sits down to attend to the higher thought, will one not get an opportunity to do so?”🔽The color of a gem: the color of an indanīla gem.

original: okāsalābhena bhavitabbaṃ siyāti adhippāyena vadati. Maṇivaṇṇeti indanīlamaṇivaṇṇe.
analyzed: okāsa lābhena bhavitabbam siyā ti adhippāyena vadati maṇi vaṇṇa iti inda nīla maṇi vaṇṇe
translated: As if grinding: as if exercising.

original: Ghaṭentassevāti vāyāmantasseva. Visuddhipavāraṇanti “parisuddho aha”nti evaṃ pavattaṃ
analyzed: ghaṭentassa iva ati vāyāma antassa iva visuddhi pavāraṇam ti parisuddhaḥ aham ti evam pavattam
translated: Invitation to purity: the invitation to purity that occurs thus: “I am pure.”🔽This is the invitation of the arahats.

original: visuddhipavāraṇaṃ. Arahantānameva hesā pavāraṇā. Kāḷakaṃ vāti mahantaṃ kāḷakaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: visuddhi pavāraṇam arahantānam eva hesā pavāraṇā kāḷakam vāti mahantam kāḷakam sandhāya
translated: The black: he speaks of the great black. The speck: he speaks of the small.

original: vadati, tilako vāti khuddakaṃ sandhāya. Ubhayenapi sīlassa parisuddhabhāvameva vibhāveti.
analyzed: vadati tilakaḥ vāti khuddakam sandhāya ubhayena api sīlassa parisuddha bhāvam eva vibhāveti
translated: By both he shows the purity of virtue.

original: Padhānakammikāti padhānakamme niyuttā. Laddhamagganti laddhūpāyaṃ, paṭhamameva laddhūpadesanti
analyzed: padhāna kammikā ati padhāna kamme niyuttā laddha magganti laddha upāyam paṭhamam eva laddha upadesanti
translated: Those who are devoted to the practice: those who are occupied with the practice.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Apattānīti chaḍḍitāni. Alābūneva sāradeti saradakāle vātātapahatāni
analyzed: vuttam hoti apattāni iti chaḍḍitāni alābūn eva sārada iti sarada kāle vāta ātapa hatāni
translated: “They are not bones” means they are discarded. “Like gourds in autumn” means in the autumn season, when they are beaten by the wind and sun,

original: tattha tattha vippakiṇṇaalābūni viya. Kāpotakānīti kapotakavaṇṇāni. Tāni disvāna
analyzed: tattha tattha vippakiṇṇa alābūni viya kāpotakāni iti kapotaka vaṇṇāni tāni disvāna
translated: they are scattered here and there like broken pieces of gourds. “Like pigeons” means they are the color of pigeons. Having seen them,

original: kā ratīti tāni evarūpāni aṭṭhīni disvā tumhākaṃ kā nāma rati, nanu appamattakāpi🔽rati kātuṃ na vaṭṭatiyevāti attho. Dutiyakathaṃ akathitapubboti attano vuḍḍhatarena
analyzed: kā ratī iti tāni evarūpāni aṭṭhīni disvā tumhākam kā nāma rati nanu appamattakā api  rati kātum na vaṭṭatiyā iva ati attho dutiya katham a kathita pubbaḥ ti attanaḥ vuḍḍhatarena
translated: “What delight?” means having seen such bones, what delight is there for you? The meaning is, it is not proper to take any delight at all.

original: saddhiṃ vuttavacanassa paccanīkaṃ dutiyakathaṃ akathitapubbo.
analyzed: saddhim vutta vacanassa paccanīkam dutiya katham a kathita pubbaḥ
translated: “The second talk was never told before” means the second talk, which is the opposite of the words spoken by one who is older than himself.

original: Tadaṅgena, tadaṅgassa pahānaṃ tadaṅgappahānaṃ. Yañhi rattibhāge samujjalitena dīpena
analyzed: tad aṅgena tad aṅgassa pahānam tad aṅga ppahānam yat hi ratti bhāge samujjalitena dīpena
translated: The abandoning of a part by a part is the abandoning of a part by a part. For just as darkness is abandoned by a lamp that is lit at night,

original: andhakārassa viya tena tena vipassanāya avayavabhūtena ñāṇaṅgena paṭipakkhavaseneva
analyzed: andhakārassa viya tena tena vipassanāya avayava bhūtena ñāṇa aṅgena paṭipakkha vasena iva
translated: so too, by a part of insight, which is a part of the knowledge that is opposed to the things that are to be abandoned,
