analyzed: tassa tassa pahātabba dhammassa pahānam idam tad aṅga ppahānam nāma yathā kāmacchanda ādayaḥ
translated: the abandoning of those things that are to be abandoned is called the abandoning of a part by a part. For example, sensual desire,

original: na cittaṃ pariyuṭṭhāya tiṭṭhanti, evaṃ pariyuṭṭhānassa nisedhanaṃ appavattikaraṇaṃ
analyzed: na cittam pariyuṭṭhāya tiṭṭhanti evam pariyuṭṭhānassa nisedhanam appavatti karaṇam
translated: They do not stand surrounding the mind. So this is the prevention of their surrounding, the non- occurrence of it,

original: vikkhambhanaṃ vikkhambhanappahānaṃ. Yañhi sasevāle udake pakkhittena ghaṭena sevālassa🔽viya tena tena lokiyasamādhinā nīvaraṇādīnaṃ paccanīkadhammānaṃ vikkhambhanamidaṃ🔽vikkhambhanappahānaṃ nāma. Sammā upacchijjanti etena kilesāti samucchedo, pahīyanti
analyzed: vikkhambhanam vikkhambhana ppahānam yat hi sa sevāle udake pakkhittena ghaṭena sevālassa  viya tena tena lokiya samādhinā nīvaraṇa ādīnam paccanīka dhammānam vikkhambhanam idam  vikkhambhana ppahānam nāma sammā upacchijjanti etena pahīyanti
translated: the suppression, the abandoning, the casting out, of the surrounding. For just as when a pot of water is heated on a stove, the water prevents the pot from being broken by the fire’s heat, so too, when the hindrances are present, the defilements prevent the noble state from being reached.🔽This is the suppression-abandoning. For just as when a pot of water is heated on a stove, the water prevents the pot from being broken by the fire’s heat, so too, when the hindrances are present, the defilements prevent the noble state from being reached.

original: etena kilesāti pahānaṃ, samucchedasaṅkhātaṃ pahānaṃ niravasesappahānanti samucchedappahānaṃ.🔽Yañhi asanivicakkābhihatassa rukkhassa viya ariyamaggañāṇena saṃyojanādīnaṃ dhammānaṃ🔽yathā na puna vattanti, evaṃ pahānamidaṃ samucchedappahānaṃ nāma. Paṭippassambhati
analyzed: etena kilesā ati pahānam samuccheda saṅkhātam pahānam niravasesa pahānam nti samuccheda ppahānam  yat hi asani vicakka abhihatassa rukkhassa viya ariya magga ñāṇena saṃyojana ādīnam dhammānam  yathā na puna vattanti evam pahānam idam samuccheda pahānam nāma
translated: This is the suppression-abandoning. For just as when a pot of water is heated on a stove, the water prevents the pot from being broken by the fire’s heat, so too, when the hindrances are present, the defilements prevent the noble state from being reached.🔽This is the suppression-abandoning. For just as when a pot of water is heated on a stove, the water prevents the pot from being broken by the fire’s heat, so too, when the hindrances are present, the defilements prevent the noble state from being reached.🔽This is the suppression-abandoning. For just as when a pot of water is heated on a stove, the water prevents the pot from being broken by the fire’s heat, so too, when the hindrances are present, the defilements prevent the noble state from being reached.🔽This is the suppression-abandoning. For just as when a pot of water is heated on a stove, the water prevents the pot from being broken by the fire’s heat, so too, when the hindrances are present, the defilements prevent the noble state from being reached.🔽This is the suppression-abandoning. For just as when a pot of water is heated on a stove, the water prevents the pot from being broken by the fire’s heat, so too, when the hindrances are present, the defilements prevent the noble state from being reached.

original: vūpasammati kilesadaratho etāyāti paṭippassaddhi, phalaṃ, sāyeva pahānanti paṭippassaddhippahānaṃ.
analyzed: etāya ati paṭippassaddhi phalam sāya iva pahānanti paṭippassaddhi ppahānam
translated: This is the suppression-abandoning. For just as when a pot of water is heated on a stove, the water prevents the pot from being broken by the fire’s heat, so too, when the hindrances are present, the defilements prevent the noble state from being reached.🔽This is the suppression-abandoning. For

original: Sabbe kilesā sabbasaṅkhatā vā nissaranti apagacchanti etenāti nissaraṇaṃ, nibbānaṃ,
analyzed: sabbe kilesā sabba saṅkhatāḥ vā nissaranti apagacchanti etena ati nissaraṇam nibbānam
translated: All defilements and all formed things depart from it, go out of it, thus it is an escape ; Nibbāna is what is meant.🔽That itself is the abandoning, thus it is the escape-abandoning.

original: tadeva pahānanti nissaraṇappahānaṃ. Paṭippassambhayamānanti paṭippassambhaṃ kilesavūpasamaṃ
analyzed: tat eva pahānam ti nissaraṇa ppahānam paṭippassambhayamānam ti paṭippassambham kilesa vūpasamam
translated: Who are making it subside: who are making the subsiding of defilements, the subsiding,🔽take place.

original: kurumānaṃ. Lokiyalokuttarehīti tadaṅgavikkhambhanappahānānaṃ lokiyattā, itaresaṃ
analyzed: kurumānam lokiya lokuttarehi iti tad aṅga vikkhambhana ppahānānam lokiya ttā itaresam
translated: By means of the mundane and supramundane: this is said because the abandoning consisting in disappearance and the abandoning consisting in substitution of opposites are mundane,

original: lokuttarattā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam
translated: and the rest are supramundane.

original: Nimīyati phalaṃ etena uppajjanaṭṭhāne pakkhipamānaṃ viya hotīti nimittaṃ, kāraṇassetaṃ
analyzed: nimīyati phalam etena uppajjana ṭṭhāne pakkhipamānam viya hoti iti nimittam kāraṇassa etam
translated: It is a sign in the sense of a cause since the fruit is as if closed up by it as it is deposited in the place of its reappearance, thus it is a sign ; this is a designation for a cause.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Asubhassa nimittaṃ, asubhameva vā nimittanti asubhanimittaṃ. Asubhanissitampi
analyzed: adhivacanam asubhassa nimittam asubham eva vā nimittanti asubha nimittam asubha nissitam pi
translated: The sign of foulness, or foulness itself is the sign, thus it is the sign of foulness.

original: hi jhānaṃ nissite nissayavohārena asubhanti voharīyati yathā “mañcā ukkuṭṭhiṃ karontī”ti.
analyzed: hi jhānam nissite nissaya vohārena asubhanti voharīyati yathā mañcāḥ ukkuṭṭhim karonti iti
translated: For although the jhāna is dependent on foulness, still it is called “foulness” in the way beginning “The bed is lice-ridden” by using the name of the thing causing the dependence in place of the name of the dependence itself.🔽That is why it is said, “The first jhāna, which has arisen making the sign of foulness its object” .

original: Tenevāha – “dasasu asubhesu uppannaṃ sārammaṇaṃ paṭhamajjhāna”nti. Anicce aniccantiādinā
analyzed: tena iva āha dasasu asubhesu uppannam sa ārammaṇam paṭhama jhānam ti anicce anicca nti ādinā
translated: In what follows, the words “in what way” should be taken as having no place, as in the passage beginning, “The first jhāna, in what way, how, may it be said to exist? ” .

original: nayena vuttassāti iminā catubbidhaṃ yonisomanasikāraṃ dasseti. Heṭṭhā cettha idha
analyzed: nayena vuttassa iti iminā catubbidham yonisoma nasikāram dasseti heṭṭhā ca itthā idha
translated: By “in the way stated” he shows the fourfold attention.

original: ca catubbidhassa ayonisomanasikārassa yonisomanasikārassa ca gahaṇaṃ niravasesadassanatthaṃ🔽katanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tesu pana asubhe “asubha”nti manasikāro idhādhippeto, tadanukūlattā
analyzed: ca catubbidhassa a yonisoma nasikārassa yonisoma nasikārassa ca gahaṇam niravasesa dassana attham  katam ti daṭṭhabbam tesu pana asubhe asubham ti manasikāraḥ idha adhippetaḥ tad anukūla ttā
translated: By “method” he shows the four kinds of proper attention. And here the inclusion of the four kinds of improper attention and the four kinds of proper attention should be understood as stated in the Paṭisambhidā.

original: vā itaresampi gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Ekādasasu asubhesu paṭikūlākārassa uggaṇhanaṃ, yathā vā tattha uggahanimittaṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: vā itaresam pi gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam  ekādasasu asubhesu paṭikūla ākārassa uggaṇhanam yathā vā tattha uggaha nimittam uppajjati
translated: Of these, attention given to what is foul as “foul” is intended here, or else the inclusion of the other three should be understood as appropriate to that.🔽The learning of the repulsive aspect in the eleven kinds of foulness is the learning sign.🔽The practice in the way stated is the learning sign of foulness.

original: tathā paṭipatti asubhanimittassa uggaho. Upacārappanāvahāya asubhabhāvanāya anuyuñjanaṃ🔽asubhabhāvanānuyogo. Bhojane mattaññuno thinamiddhābhibhavābhāvā otāraṃ alabhamāno
analyzed: tathā paṭipatti asubha nimittassa uggahaḥ upacāra ppanā vahāya asubha bhāvanāya anuyuñjanam  asubha bhāvanā anuyogaḥ bhojane mattaññunaḥ thinam iddha abhibhava abhāvāḥ otāram a labhamānaḥ
translated: The pursuit of foulness meditation by means of access and absorption is the pursuit of foulness meditation.🔽They say that when one is moderate in eating, greed for sensual desires is abandoned because sloth and torpor are absent and there is no opportunity for them.

original: kāmacchando pahīyatīti vadanti. Bhojananissitaṃ pana āhāre paṭikūlasaññaṃ, tabbipariṇāmassa
analyzed: kāmacchandaḥ pahīyati iti vadanti bhojana nissitam pana āhāre paṭikūla saññam tad vipariṇāmassa
translated: But the perception of foulness in relation to food is the perception of repulsiveness in relation to what is desirable.

original: tadādhārassa tassa ca udariyabhūtassa asubhatādassanaṃ, kāyassa ca āhāraṭṭhitikatādassanaṃ
analyzed: tad ādhārassa tassa ca udariya bhūtassa asubha tā dassanam kāyassa ca āhāra ṭṭhitika tā dassanam
translated: The contemplation of the foul in the stomach and in the body as the support for the stomach is the contemplation of the body as “subject to being kept going by nutriment.”

original: yo uppādeti, so visesato bhojane pamāṇaññū nāma, tassa ca kāmacchando pahīyateva.🔽Dasavidhañhi asubhanimittanti pākaṭavasena vuttaṃ. Kāyagatāsatiṃ pana gahetvā ekādasavidhampi
analyzed: yaḥ uppādeti so visesataḥ bhojane pamāṇaññū nāma tassa ca kāmacchandaḥ pahīyateva  dasavidham hi asubha nimittam ti pākaṭa vasena vuttam kāya gata asatim pana gahetvā ekādasavidham pi
translated: The person who arouses it is called “moderate in eating” in the special sense of the word. And his sensual desire is abandoned.

original: asubhanimittaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: asubha nimittam veditabbam
translated: “The sign of foulness in eleven ways”: this is said with reference to the obvious kinds. But when the kinds of foulness are taken as the meditation subject, the sign of foulness should be understood as elevenfold in all.

original: Abhutvā udakaṃ piveti pānīyassa okāsadānatthaṃ cattāro pañca ālope abhutvā pānīyaṃ
analyzed: a bhutvā udakam piva iti pānīyassa okāsa dāna attham cattāraḥ pañca ālope a bhutvā pānīyam
translated: “Having eaten, he drinks water”: the meaning is that he should drink water after leaving aside four or five mouthfuls in order to make room for the water.

original: piveyyāti attho. Tena vuttaṃ – “catunnaṃ pañcannaṃ ālopānaṃ okāse satī”ti. Abhidhammaṭīkākārena🔽panettha “cattāro pañca ālope, bhutvāna udakaṃ pive”ti pāṭhaṃ parikappetvā aññathā
analyzed: piveyya ati attho tena vuttam catunnam pañcannam ālopānam okāse sati iti abhidhamma ṭīkākārena  pana ittha cattāro pañca ālope bhutvāna udakam piva iti pāṭham parikappetvā aññathā
translated: That is why it is said: “When there are four or five mouthfuls left.”

original: attho vaṇṇito, so aṭṭhakathāya na sameti. Asubhakammikatissatthero dantaṭṭhidassāvī.
analyzed: atthaḥ vaṇṇito saḥ aṭṭhakathāya na sameti asubha kammika tissa theraḥ dantaṭṭhi dassāvī
translated: But the author of the Paramatthamañjūsā, taking the reading “having eaten four or five mouthfuls, he drinks water,” explains the meaning in a different way, but that does not agree with the commentary. The Elder Tissa, who was a maker of foul things, was the one who showed the tooth stick.

original: 17. Sattame mijjati hitapharaṇavasena siniyhatīti mitto, hitesī puggalo, tasmiṃ mitte🔽bhavā, mittassa vā esāti mettā, hitesitā. Tattha “mettā”ti vutte appanāpi upacāropi
analyzed: sattame mijjati hita pharaṇa vasena siniyhati iti mittaḥ hita īsī puggalo tasmin mitte  bhavā mittassa vā esā ati mettā hita isitā tattha mettā ati vutte appanā api upacāraḥ api
translated: a person who is helpful.🔽The state of that is friendliness .🔽Herein, when “friendliness” is said, both absorption and access are allowable, since the word is a common one.

original: vaṭṭati sādhāraṇavacanabhāvatoti āha – “mettāti ettāvatā pubbabhāgopi vaṭṭatī”ti.
analyzed: vaṭṭati sādhāraṇa vacana bhāvato ti āha mettā iti ettāvatā pubba bhāgaḥ api vaṭṭati iti
translated: The word “also” includes absorption.

original: Api-saddo appanaṃ sampiṇḍeti. Appanaṃ appattāya mettāya suṭṭhu muccanassa abhāvato
analyzed: api saddaḥ appanam sampiṇḍeti appanam appattāya mettāya suṭṭhu muccanassa abhāvato
translated: Because there is no proper fulfilment of the wish in friendliness that has not reached absorption,

original: cetovimuttīti “appanāva adhippetā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: cetaḥ vimutti iti appanā eva adhippetā iti vuttam
translated: it is said that “only absorption is intended here by ‘deliverance of mind.’”

original: Sattesu mettāyanassa hitūpasaṃhārassa uppādanaṃ pavattanaṃ mettānimittassa uggaho.
analyzed: sattesu mettāyanassa hitu upasaṃhārassa uppādanam pavattanam mettā nimittassa uggaho
translated: The arousing and occurrence of the sending of the wish for beings’ welfare is the apprehending of the sign of friendliness.

original: Paṭhamuppanno mettāmanasikāro parato uppajjanakassa kāraṇabhāvato mettāmanasikārova
analyzed: paṭhama uppannaḥ mettā manasikāro paratas uppajjanakassa kāraṇa bhāvataḥ mettā manasikāraḥ uva
translated: The first attention given to friendliness is the sign of friendliness since it is the cause of what arises later.

original: mettānimittaṃ. Kammaṃyeva sakaṃ etesanti kammassakā, sattā, tabbhāvo kammassakatā,
analyzed: mettā nimittam kammaṃyā iva sakam etesanti kammassakā sattā tad bhāvaḥ kammassaka tā
translated: Beings are “self-made” in the sense that kamma is their own, thus they are “self-makers” .🔽The state of that is self-making.

original: kammadāyādatā. Dosamettāsu yāthāvato ādīnavānisaṃsānaṃ paṭisaṅkhānavīmaṃsā idha paṭisaṅkhānaṃ.
analyzed: kamma dāyāda tā dosa mettāsu yāthāvataḥ ādīnava a nisaṃsānam paṭisaṅkhāna vīmaṃsāḥ idha paṭisaṅkhānam
translated: and the kamma-resultant eye-consciousness.🔽The reflection here is the reflection on the drawbacks and advantages of hate and loving-kindness respectively.🔽The good friend here is one who dwells in loving-kindness.

original: Mettāvihārīkalyāṇamittavantatā idha kalyāṇamittatā. Odissakaanodissakadisāpharaṇānanti🔽attaatipiyamajjhattaverivasena odissakatā, sīmāsambhede kate anodissakatā, ekādidisāpharaṇavasena
analyzed: kalyāṇa mitta tā  atta ati piya majjhatta veri vasena odissaka tā sīmā sambhede kate anodissaka tā eka ādi disā pharaṇa vasena
translated: The pervasion of directions with and without an objective is as follows.🔽The objective is the direction consisting of oneself, a loved one, a neutral person, and a hostile person. The non-objective is the direction when the boundaries are not defined. The pervasion of the directions is the pervasion of the four directions beginning with the east.

original: disāpharaṇatā mettāya uggahaṇe veditabbā. Vihāraracchagāmādivasena vā odissakadisāpharaṇaṃ.
analyzed: disāpharaṇa tā mettāya uggahaṇe veditabbā vihāra raccha gāma ādi vasena vā odissaka disāpharaṇam
translated: Or alternatively, the objective is the pervasion of the directions by way of the monastery, the village, etc.,🔽and the non-objective is the pervasion of the directions by way of the east, etc., without any objective such as the monastery, etc.

original: Vihārādiuddesarahitaṃ puratthimādidisāvasena anodissakadisāpharaṇaṃ. Evaṃ vā dvidhā
analyzed: vihāra ādi uddesa rahitam puratthima ādi disā vasena evam vā dvidhā
translated: Thus the pervasion of the directions with and without an objective is twofold.

original: uggahaṇaṃ sandhāya – “odissakaanodissakadisāpharaṇa”nti vuttaṃ. Uggaho ca yāva upacārā
analyzed: uggahaṇam sandhāya odissaka anodissaka disā pharaṇam ti vuttam uggahaḥ ca yāvaḥ upacārā
translated: The learning sign should be seen as far as the access of absorption. The counterpart sign is the development of the learning sign.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Uggahitāya āsevanā bhāvanā. Tattha sabbe sattā, pāṇā, bhūtā, puggalā,
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ uggahitāya āsevanā bhāvanā tattha sabbe sattā pāṇā bhūtā puggalā
translated: Herein, all beings, all breathing things, all creatures, all persons,

original: attabhāvapariyāpannāti etesaṃ vasena pañcavidhā. Ekekasmiṃ averā hontu, abyāpajjhā,🔽anīghā, sukhī attānaṃ pariharantūti catudhā pavattito vīsatividhā anodhisopharaṇā
analyzed: etesam vasena pañcavidhāḥ ekekasmin averāḥ hontu a byāpajjhāḥ  anīghā sukhī attānam pariharantu uti catudhā pavattitaḥ vīsatividhā
translated: and the fivefold one according to them.

original: mettā. Sabbā itthiyo, purisā, ariyā, anariyā, devā, manussā, vinipātikāti sattādhikaraṇavasena🔽pavattā sattavidhā aṭṭhavīsatividhā vā, dasahi disāhi disādhikaraṇavasena pavattā
analyzed: sabbā itthiyaḥ purisāḥ ariyāḥ anariyāḥ devāḥ manussāḥ vinipātikāḥ ti satta adhikaraṇa vasena  pavattā sattavidhā aṭṭhavīsatividhā vā dasahi disāhi disa adhikaraṇa vasena pavattā
translated: The twentyfold one is the extension of loving-kindness without measure that occurs in four ways thus: “May all women be free from enmity, affliction and anxiety, and so live happily. May all men … all Noble Ones … all not Noble Ones … all deities … all human beings … all those in states of loss be free from enmity, affliction and anxiety, and so live happily.”

original: dasavidhā ca, ekekāya vā disāya sattādiitthādiaverādibhedena asītādhikacatusatappabhedā
analyzed: dasavidhā ca eka ekāya vā disāya
translated: The sevenfold one is the extension of loving-kindness with measure that occurs according to the seven bases of kindness thus: “All women … all men … all Noble Ones … all not Noble Ones … all deities … all human beings … all those in states of loss.” Or it is the twenty-eightfold one that occurs according to the seven bases of kindness and according to the fourfold division of women and so on.🔽The tenfold one is the extension of loving-kindness without measure that occurs according to the ten directions.🔽And the extension of loving-kindness with measure should be understood as occurring in each direction in the way just stated, making two hundred and eighty in all, since there are twenty-eight kinds of women and so on in each direction.🔽“When he develops loving-kindness”: when he develops the jhāna of loving-kindness.

original: ca odhisopharaṇā veditabbā. Mettaṃ bhāventassāti mettājhānaṃ bhāventassa. Tvaṃ etassa
analyzed: ca odhi sopharaṇā veditabbā mettam bhāventassa ati mettā jhānam bhāventassa tvam etassa
translated: “You are angry with him”: this is the way to reflect.🔽“As if he were a discarded piece of wood”: as if he were a piece of wood that is thrown away.🔽“By reviewing”: by means of the investigation.

original: kuddhotiādi paccavekkhaṇāvidhidassanaṃ. Appaṭicchitapaheṇakaṃ viyāti asampaṭicchitapaṇṇākāraṃ🔽viya. Paṭisaṅkhāneti vīmaṃsāyaṃ. Vattaniaṭaviyaṃ attaguttattherasadise.
analyzed: kuddha uti ādi paccavekkhaṇā vidhi dassanam appaṭicchita paheṇakam viyāti a sampaṭicchita paṇṇa ākāram 🔽paṭisaṅkhānā iti vīmaṃsāyam
translated: “As in the case of the Elder Anāthapiṇḍika”:

original: 18. Aṭṭhame kusaladhammasampaṭipattiyā paṭṭhapanasabhāvatāya tappaṭipakkhānaṃ visosanasabhāvatāya
analyzed: aṭṭhame kusala dhamma sampaṭipattiyā paṭṭhapana sabhāva tāya tad paṭipakkhānam visosana sabhāva tāya
translated: 18. The eighth is the nature of establishing the practice of profitable ideas, and the nature of purifying from their opposites.

original: ca ārambhadhātuādito pavattavīriyanti āha – “paṭhamārambhavīriya”nti. Yasmā paṭhamārambhamattassa🔽kosajjavidhamanaṃ thāmagamanañca natthi, tasmā vuttaṃ – “kosajjato nikkhantattā tato
analyzed: ca ārambha dhātu āditaḥ pavatta vīriyanti āha paṭhama ārambha vīriyanti yasmā paṭhama ārambha mattassa  kosajja vidhamanam thāma gamanam ca na atthi tasmā vuttam kosajjataḥ nikkhanta ttā tatas
translated: 18. The energy that occurs first in the sense of being the instigation of the undertaking of the practice of profitable states and in the sense of the clearing away of their opposites is called “first-kind energy” .🔽Since there is no shaking off of indolence and no arousing of energy in one who has merely begun,

original: balavatara”nti. Yasmā pana aparāparuppattiyā laddhāsevanaṃ uparūpari visesaṃ āvahantaṃ🔽ativiya thāmagatameva hoti, tasmā vuttaṃ – “paraṃ paraṃ ṭhānaṃ akkamanato tatopi
analyzed: yasmā pana apara apara uppattiyā laddha āsevanam upari upari visesam āvahantam  ativiya thāma gatam eva hoti tasmā vuttam param param ṭhānam akkamanataḥ tatas pi
translated: it is said: “It is stronger than that because it has come out from indolence” .🔽But since that which has been practised by the repeated performance of the next higher stage brings about a further distinction and is very much further advanced,

original: balavatara”nti. Panūdanāyāti nīharaṇāya. Yathā mahato palighassa ugghāṭakajanassa
analyzed: balavataranti nīharaṇāya yathā mahataḥ palighassa ugghāṭaka janassa
translated: it is said: “It is stronger than that because it goes further and further” .🔽“For the purpose of banishing” : for the purpose of removing.

original: mahanto ussāho icchitabbo, evamidhāpīti “nikkamo cetaso palighugghāṭanāyā”ti vuttaṃ.

original: Mahāparakkamo eva parena kataṃ bandhanaṃ chindeyya, evamidhāpīti vuttaṃ – “parakkamo
analyzed: mahā parakkamaḥ eva parena katam bandhanam chindeyya evam idha api iti vuttam parakkamaḥ

original: cetaso bandhanacchedanāyā”ti.🔽Āraddhaṃ saṃsādhitaṃ paripūritaṃ vīriyaṃ etassāti āraddhavīriyo, nipphannavīriyo,

translated: For over-fain development of consciousness is slackness-rooted, and over- strenuous is agitation-rooted.

original: sambhavati. Imesu suttesūti imesu pana paṭhamadutiyasuttesu yathākkamaṃ vaṭṭavivaṭṭameva kathitaṃ.

analyzed: vohāraḥ mahantam aggahetvā appamattakassa iva gahaṇe payojanam dassetum kasmā pana atiādi
translated: In order to show the purpose of taking the small instead of the great, he asks “But why?”

original: āraddhaṃ. Tena “vivaṭṭūpanissayakusalaṃ nāma yoniso uppāditaṃ appaka”nti na cintetabbaṃ,
analyzed: āraddham tena vivaṭṭu upanissaya kusalam nāma yonisas uppāditam appakanti na cintetabbam
translated: and so on. Therefore it should not be thought that “skill in the condition for the turning about is small, being produced by right reflection” .

original: anukkamena laddhapaccayaṃ hutvā vaḍḍhamānaṃ khuddakanadī viya pakkhandamahoghā samuddaṃ,
analyzed: anukkamena laddha paccayam hutvā vaḍḍhamānam khuddaka nadī viya pakkhanda mahā oghā samuddam
translated: For it is like a small river that, having obtained conditions in due course, increases and, becoming a great flood, enters the ocean.

original: anukkamena nibbānamahāsamuddameva purisaṃ pāpetīti dīpeti. Paccekabodhiṃ buddhabhūminti
analyzed: anukkamena nibbāna mahā samuddam eva purisam pāpeti iti dīpeti paccekabodhim buddha bhūmin ti
translated: So too, this skill in the condition for the turning about, having obtained conditions in due course, increases and eventually leads the man to the great ocean of Nibbāna.🔽The expression “individual enlightenment, the plane of the Buddhas” is a locative of advantage .

original: ca paccatte upayogavacanaṃ. Vaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ kathitanti yathākkamena vuttaṃ.🔽43. Tatiye dosena paduṭṭhacittanti sampayuttadhammānaṃ, yasmiṃ santāne uppajjati,
analyzed: ca paccatte upayoga vacanam vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam kathitam iti yathākkamena vuttam  tatiye dosena paduṭṭha cittam ti sampayutta dhammānam yasmin santāne uppajjati
translated: “The turning about of the round” is what is stated in due course.🔽In the third case, “with a mind corrupted by hate” : a mind corrupted by hate that is mixed with hate, like poison mixed with food, in the continuity of the one in whom it arises.

original: tassa ca dūsanena visasaṃsaṭṭhapūtimuttasadisena dosena padūsitacittaṃ. Attano cittenāti
analyzed: tassa ca dūsanena visa saṃsaṭṭha pūti mutta sadisena dosena padūsita cittam attano cittena ati
translated: “With his own mind” :

original: attano cetopariyañāṇena sabbaññutaññāṇena vā sahitena cittena. Paricchinditvāti ñāṇena
analyzed: attano cetaḥ pariya ñāṇena sabbaññuta ññāṇena vā sahitena cittena paricchinditvā ati ñāṇena
translated: Having discerned: having discerned with knowledge.

original: paricchinditvā. Iṭṭhākārena etīti ayo, sukhaṃ. Sabbaso apeto ayo etassa, etasmāti
analyzed: paricchinditvā iṭṭha ākārena eti iti ayaḥ sukham sabbasas apetaḥ ayaḥ etassa etasmā ati
translated: It comes with a desirable form, thus it is a heaven ; it is free from all that is not a heaven , thus it is a heaven ;

original: vā apāyo, kāyikassa cetasikassa ca dukkhassa gati pavattiṭṭhānanti duggati, kāraṇāvasena🔽vividhaṃ vikārena ca nipātiyanti etthāti vinipāto, appakopi natthi ayo sukhaṃ etthāti
analyzed: vā apāyaḥ kāyikassa cetasikassa ca dukkhassa gati pavatti ṭṭhānan ti duggati kāraṇā vasena  vividham vikārena ca nipātiyanti ettha ati vinipātaḥ appakaḥ api na atthi ayaḥ sukham ettha ati
translated: or it is not a heaven for him, thus it is a heaven ;

original: nirayoti evamettha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: nirayaḥ ti evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: it is a downfall because various kinds of beings fall into it through their change , thus it is a downfall ; there is no heaven at all here, thus it is a hell . This is how the meaning should be understood here.

original: 44. Catutthe saddhāpasādena pasannanti saddhāsaṅkhātena pasādena pasannaṃ, na indriyānaṃ🔽avippasannatāya. Sukhassa gatinti sukhassa pavattiṭṭhānaṃ. Sukhamevettha gacchanti,
analyzed: catutthe saddhā pasādena pasannanti saddhā saṅkhātena pasādena pasannam naḥ indriyānam  a vippasanna tāya sukhassa gatinti sukhassa pavatti ṭṭhānam sukham eva ittha gacchanti
translated: In the fourth , he is serene with serenity of faith: he is serene with serenity consisting in faith, not with unclarity of the faculties.🔽A way to happiness: a place of occurrence for happiness. Or it is a good way because they go only in happiness, not in suffering.

original: na dukkhanti vā sugati. Manāpiyarūpāditāya saha aggehīti saggaṃ, lokaṃ.
analyzed: na vā sugati manāpiya rūpa āditāya saha aggehi iti saggam lokam
translated: A heaven: a world that is a high place because of being a desirable form, and so on.

original: 45. Pañcame pariḷāhavūpasamakaro rahado etthāti rahado, udakapuṇṇo rahado udakarahado.
analyzed: pañcame pariḷāha vūpasama karaḥ rahadaḥ ettha ati rahadaḥ udaka puṇṇaḥ rahadaḥ udaka rahadaḥ
translated: The fifth simile is that of the lake. The word rahado is derived from the verb pariḷāha karo, “to cause to be heated.” A lake is a body of water, a rahado.

original: Udakaṃ dahati dhāretīti udakadaho. Āviloti kalalabahulatāya ākulo. Tenāha – “avippasanno”ti.
analyzed: udakam dahati dhārā iti iti udaka dahaḥ āvilaḥ iti kalala bahula tāya ākulaḥ tena āha a vippasannaḥ iti
translated: The word udakadaho is derived from the verb dahati, “to burn,” and udaka, “water.”🔽The word āvila is derived from the verb ākulo, “to be agitated.”

original: Luḷitoti vātena āloḷito. Tenāha – “aparisaṇṭhito”ti. Vātābhighātena vīcitaraṅgamalasamākulatāya🔽hi parito na saṇṭhito vā aparisaṇṭhito. Vātābhighātena udakassa ca appabhāvena kalalībhūto
analyzed: luḷitā iti vātena tena āha a parisaṇṭhitā iti vāta abhighātena vīci taraṅga mala samākula tāya  hi paritas na saṇṭhitaḥ vā a parisaṇṭhitaḥ vāta abhighātena udakassa ca appabhāvena kalalībhūtaḥ
translated: The word luḷita is derived from the verb loḷito, “to be tossed about.”🔽The word kaddamo is derived from the verb kaddamo, “to become muddy.”🔽The word sippiyo is derived from the verb sippa karo, “to drink.”

original: kaddamabhāvappattoti āha – “kaddamībhūto”ti. Sippiyo muttasippiādayo. Sambukā saṅkhasalākavisesā.
analyzed: kaddama bhāva ppatto ti āha kaddamībhūtaḥ ti sippiyaḥ mutta sippi ādayaḥ sambukā saṅkha salāka visesā
translated: The word sambuko is derived from the verb sambujjhati, “to be agitated.”

original: Carantampi tiṭṭhantampīti yathālābhavacanametaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tameva hi yathālābhavacanataṃ🔽dassetuṃ – “etthā”tiādi āraddhaṃ.🔽Pariyonaddhenāti paṭicchāditena. Tayidaṃ kāraṇena āvilabhāvassa dassanaṃ. Diṭṭhadhamme
analyzed: carantam pi tiṭṭhantam pi iti yathā lābha vacanam etam daṭṭhabbam tam eva hi yathā lābha vacanatam 🔽dassetum ettha atiādi āraddham 🔽pariyonaddhena ati paṭicchāditena tayā idam kāraṇena āvila bhāvassa dassanam diṭṭhadhamme
translated: The word carantam pi tiṭṭhantam pi is a locative of manner.

original: imasmiṃ attabhāve bhavo diṭṭhadhammiko, so pana lokiyopi hoti lokuttaropīti āha –
analyzed: imasmin atta bhāve bhavaḥ diṭṭhadhammiko so pana lokiyaḥ api hoti lokuttaraḥ api iti āha
translated: In this existence, the becoming is in the present life. But that is mundane and supramundane. Therefore it is said:

original: “lokiyalokuttaramissako”ti. Pecca samparetabbato samparāyo, paraloko. Tenāha – “so
analyzed: lokiya lokuttara missakaḥ ti pecca samparetabbato samparāyaḥ para loko tena āha so
translated: “It is a mixture of mundane and supramundane.” The next world is the world beyond, the world to come, because it is to be reached after death. Therefore it is said:

original: hi parattha atthoti parattho”ti. Iti dvidhāpi sakasantatipariyāpanno eva gahitoti🔽itarampi saṅgahetvā dassetuṃ – “apicā”tiādimāha. Ayanti kusalakammapathasaṅkhāto
analyzed: hi parattha attho ti parattho ti iti dvidhā api saka santati pariyāpannaḥ eva gahitaḥ iti  itaram pi saṅgahetvā dassetum api ca ati ādim āha ayanti kusala kamma patha saṅkhāto
translated: “It is the world beyond because it is a world that is beyond.” Thus, in both cases, only what is included in one’s own continuity is taken.🔽In order to show that the other is also included, he says: “Moreover, etc.” The “this” is the tenfold good action path.

original: dasavidho dhammo. Satthantarakappāvasāneti idaṃ tassa āsannabhāvaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dasavidhaḥ dhammaḥ satthantara kappa avasāne ti idam tassa āsanna bhāvam sandhāya vuttam
translated: “The end of the aeon” is said with reference to its nearness.🔽It should be understood as the end of any intermediate aeon.

original: Yassa kassaci antarakappassāvasāneti veditabbaṃ. Ariyānaṃ yuttanti ariyānaṃ ariyabhāvāya
analyzed: yassa kassaci antara kappassa avasāne iti veditabbam ariyānam yuttanti ariyānam ariya bhāvāya
translated: “Suitable for the noble ones” is suitable for the noble ones’ noble state.

original: yuttaṃ, tato eva ariyabhāvaṃ kātuṃ samatthaṃ. Ñāṇameva ñeyyassa paccakkhakaraṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: yuttam tatas eva ariya bhāvam kātum samattham ñāṇam eva ñeyyassa paccakkha karaṇa ṭṭhena
translated: Therefore, it is able to make the noble state. Knowledge itself is seeing in the sense of making the known manifest.

original: dassananti āha – “ñāṇameva hī”tiādi. Kiṃ pana tanti āha – “dibbacakkhū”tiādi.
analyzed: dassananti āha ñāṇam eva hi itiādi kim pana tat ti āha dibba cakkhu itiādi
translated: Therefore it is said: “Knowledge itself, etc.” But what is it? He says: “The divine eye, etc.”

original: 46. Chaṭṭhe acchoti tanuko. Tanubhāvameva hi sandhāya “abahalo”ti vuttaṃ. Yasmā pasanno
analyzed: chaṭṭhe accho ti tanuko tanu bhāvam eva hi sandhāya abahalo ti vuttam yasmā pasanno
translated: In the sixth, accho means slender. For it is only slenderness that is referred to by the word abahalo . Since one who is pleased is slender and not stout, it is said: “It is also proper to say ‘pleased’ ” . Vippasanno means well pleased. But that is called “rightly pleased” , thus it is said: “Well pleased” . Anāvilo means unclouded.

original: nāma accho na bahalo, tasmā “pasannotipi vaṭṭatī”ti vuttaṃ. Vippasannoti visesena🔽pasanno. So pana sammā pasanno nāma hotīti āha – “suṭṭhu pasanno”ti. Anāviloti akaluso.
analyzed: nāma acchaḥ na bahalaḥ tasmā pasannaḥ ti pi vaṭṭati iti vuttam vippasannaḥ ti visesena  pasanno so pana sammā pasannaḥ nāma hoti iti āha suṭṭhu pasannaḥ iti anāvilaḥ ti akaluso
translated: Hence it is said: “Pure” , etc. Saṅkha means a small kind of grass called tilabījakā .🔽Sevāla means a kind of grass called kaṇṇikasevāla . Paṇaka means a kind of water plant called udakamala . The clouding of the mind is due to the hindrances,🔽thus it is said: “By one free from the five hindrances” .🔽In the seventh, rukkhajāti . Here the word jāti is used in the sense of “kind” , as in the expression “kosajātaka” .🔽Thus it is said: “This is a designation for trees” . For some tree is foremost in colour, as in the case of the🔽 Translation: Accho means slender. For only slenderness is referred to by the word abahalo . But that is called “rightly pleased” , thus it is said: “Well pleased” . Anāvilo means unclouded.

original: Tenāha – “parisuddho”tiādi. Saṅkhanti khuddakasevālaṃ, yaṃ “tilabījaka”nti vuccati.
analyzed: tena āha parisuddha utiādi yam tila bījakanti vuccati
translated: Hence it is said: “Pure” , etc. Saṅkha means a small kind of grass called tilabījakā .

original: Sevālanti kaṇṇikasevālaṃ. Paṇakanti udakamalaṃ. Cittassa āvilabhāvo nīvaraṇahetukoti
analyzed: sevālanti kaṇṇika sevālam paṇakanti udaka malam cittassa āvila bhāvaḥ nīvaraṇa hetukaḥ ti

analyzed: āha anāvilena ati pañca nīvaraṇa vimuttena iti
translated: thus it is said: “By one free from the five hindrances” .🔽In the seventh, rukkhajāti . Here the word jāti is used in the sense of “kind” , as in the expression “kosajātaka” .

original: 47. Sattame rukkhajātānīti ettha jātasaddena padavaḍḍhanameva kataṃ yathā “kosajāta”nti🔽āha – “rukkhānamevetaṃ adhivacana”nti. Koci hi rukkho vaṇṇena aggo hoti yathā taṃ
analyzed: sattame rukkha jātāni iti ettha jāta saddena pada vaḍḍhanam eva katam yathā kosa jātam ti 🔽āha rukkhānam eva etam adhivacanam ti koci hi rukkhaḥ vaṇṇena aggaḥ hoti yathā tam
translated: Thus it is said: “This is a designation for trees” . For some tree is foremost in colour, as in the case of the

original: rattacandanādi. Koci gandhena yathā taṃ gosītacandanaṃ. Koci rasena khadirādi. Koci🔽thaddhatāya campakādi. Maggaphalāvahatāya vipassanāvasena bhāvitampi gahitaṃ. “Tattha🔽tattheva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇātī”ti vacanato “abhiññāpādakacatutthajjhānacittameva,🔽āvuso”ti phussamittatthero vadati.
analyzed: ratta candana ādi gandhena yathā tam gosīta candanam rasena khadira ādi koci  thaddhatāya campaka ādi magga phala avahatāya vipassanā vasena bhāvitam pi gahitam tattha  tattha iva sakkhibhabbatam pāpuṇāti iti vacanataḥ abhiññā pādaka catuttha jjhāna cittam eva  āvuso ti phussamitta theraḥ vadati
translated: “By scent” means by the scent of red sandalwood, etc., “By taste” means by the taste of khadira, etc., “By hardness” means by the hardness of campaka, etc., “By the way it is carried” means by the way it is carried on the path of insight. “It reaches the state of being able to be experienced there and then” . “Friend, it is the consciousness of the fourth jhāna, which is the basis for direct knowledge,” says the elder Phussamitta.

original: 48. Aṭṭhame cittassa parivattanaṃ uppādanirodhā evāti āha – “evaṃ lahuṃ uppajjitvā🔽lahuṃ nirujjhanaka”nti. Adhimattapamāṇattheti atikkantapamāṇatthe, pamāṇātītatāyanti🔽attho. Tenāha – “ativiya na sukarā”ti. Cakkhuviññāṇampi adhippetamevāti sabbassapi🔽cittassa samānakhaṇattā vuttaṃ. Cittassa ativiya lahuparivattibhāvaṃ theravādena

original: dīpetuṃ – “imasmiṃ panatthe”tiādi vuttaṃ. Cittasaṅkhārāti sasampayuttaṃ cittaṃ vadati.
analyzed: dīpetum imasmin pana attha itiādi vuttam citta saṅkhārā ati sa sampayuttam cittam vadati
translated: In order to illustrate this, the following is said: “In this case, what is meant is this.” “Mental formations” refers to consciousness together with its concomitants.

original: Vāhasatānaṃ kho, mahārāja, vīhīnanti potthakesu likhanti, “vāhasataṃ kho, mahārāja,🔽vīhīna”nti pana pāṭhena bhavitabbaṃ. Milindapañhepi hi katthaci ayameva pāṭho dissati.
analyzed: vāha satānam kho mahā rāja potthakesu likhanti vāha satam kho mahā rāja  pana pāṭhena bhavitabbam milinda pañhe pi hi katthaci ayam eva pāṭhaḥ dissati
translated: “A hundred cartloads of paddy,” they write in the books. But it should read: “A hundred cartloads of paddy, great king,🔽for it is this reading that is found in the Milindapañha in some places.

original: “Vāhasatāna”nti vā paccatte sāmivacanaṃ byattayena vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Aḍḍhacūḷanti🔽thokena ūnaṃ upaḍḍhaṃ. Kassa pana upaḍḍhanti? Adhikārato vāhassāti viññāyati. “Aḍḍhacuddasa”nti
analyzed: vāhasatānanti vā paccatte sāmi vacanam byattayena vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam aḍḍhacūḷanti  thokena ūnam upaḍḍham kassa pana upaḍḍhanti adhikārataḥ vāhassa ati viññāyati aḍḍha cuddasanti
translated: Or else, “vāhassatāna” should be taken as a genitive tatpuruṣa compound meaning “of a hundred cartloads.” “Aḍḍhacuḷa” means “half less than a full measure.”

original: keci. “Aḍḍhacatuttha”nti apare. Sādhikaṃ diyaḍḍhasataṃ vāhāti daḷhaṃ katvā vadanti,🔽vīmaṃsitabbaṃ. Catunāḷiko tumbo. Pucchāya abhāvenāti “sakkā pana, bhante, upamaṃ
analyzed: apare sa adhikam diyaḍḍha satam daḷham katvā vadanti  vīmaṃsitabbam catu nāḷikaḥ tumbaḥ pucchāya abhāvena ati sakkā pana bhante upamaṃ
translated: But whose measure? It is understood to be the measure of a hundred cartloads. Some read “aḍḍhacatuttha” . Others read “aḍḍhacuḷa.” They insistently declare that it means “more than one hundred and fifty cartloads,”

original: kātu”nti evaṃ pavattāya pucchāya abhāvena na katā upamā. Dhammadesanāpariyosāneti
analyzed: evam pavattāya pucchāya abhāvena na katā upamā dhamma desanā pariyosānā iti
translated: but this should be investigated. “A four-gallon pot” . “Because there is no question” : the simile is not given because there is no question such as “Can a simile be given, venerable sir?” “At the conclusion of the teaching of the Dhamma” :

original: sannipatitaparisāya yathāraddhadhammadesanāya pariyosāne.
analyzed: sannipatita parisāya yathā āraddha dhamma desanāya pariyosāne
translated: At the end of the teaching of the Dhamma in accordance with the inclination of the assembly that had assembled.

original: 49. Navame pabhassaranti pariyodātaṃ sabhāvaparisuddhaṭṭhena. Tenāha – “paṇḍaraṃ🔽parisuddha”nti. Pabhassaratādayo nāma vaṇṇadhātuyaṃ labbhanakavisesāti āha – “kiṃ🔽pana cittassa vaṇṇo nāma atthī”ti? Itaro arūpatāya “natthī”ti paṭikkhipitvā pariyāyakathā
analyzed: navame pabhassaranti pariyodātam sabhāva parisuddha ṭṭhena tena āha paṇḍaram  parisuddhanti pabhassara ta ādayaḥ nāma vaṇṇa dhātuyam labbhanaka visesā ti āha kim  pana cittassa vaṇṇo nāma atthi iti itaraḥ arūpa tāya natthi iti paṭikkhipitvā pariyāya kathā
translated: In the ninth simile, “shining” means pure in the sense of being pure by nature. Therefore it is said: “white,

original: ayaṃ tādisassa cittassa parisuddhabhāvanādīpanāyāti dassento “nīlādīna”ntiādimāha.🔽Tathā hi “so evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte”ti vuttaṃ. Tenevāha – “idampi
analyzed: ayam tādisassa cittassa parisuddha bhāvanā dīpanāya ati dassentaḥ nīla ādīn anti ādim āha  tathā hi saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodātā iti vuttam tena iva āha idam pi
translated: pure.” The qualities of shining, etc., are special qualities that can be found in the color element. Therefore it is said: “But is there such a thing as the color of consciousness?” The other, because of its being immaterial, denies that there is. But this is a discussion in terms of a figure of speech. The explanation of the purity of such consciousness is to be understood as the illumination of the development of purity. Therefore it is said: “blue, etc.”

original: nirupakkilesatāya parisuddhanti pabhassara”nti. Kiṃ pana bhavaṅgacittaṃ nirupakkilesanti?
analyzed: nirupakkilesa tāya parisuddhanti pabhassaranti kim pana bhavaṅga cittam
translated: For thus it is said: “When his concentrated mind is purified, cleansed, and bright, etc.” Therefore it is said: “This is shining because of the absence of defilement.” But is the life-continuum consciousness free from defilement?

original: Āma sabhāvato nirupakkilesaṃ, āgantukaupakkilesavasena pana siyā upakkiliṭṭhaṃ. Tenāha
analyzed: sa bhāvataḥ nirupakkilesam āgantuka aupakkilesa vasena pana siyāḥ tena āha
translated: Yes, it is free from defilement in its own nature, but it may be defiled by the defilement of the adventitious nature. Therefore it is said:

original: – “tañca kho”tiādi. Tattha attano tesañca bhikkhūnaṃ paccakkhabhāvato pubbe “ida”nti
analyzed: tat ca kho ti ādi tattha attanaḥ tesam ca bhikkhūnam paccakkha bhāvato pubbe idam ti
translated: “And that” , etc. Herein, he said “this” before because of his own and the bhikkhus’ direct knowledge,

original: vatvā idāni paccāmasanavasena “ta”nti āha. Ca-saddo atthūpanayane. Kho-saddo vacanālaṅkāre,
analyzed: vatvā idāni pacca āmasana vasena tanti āha ca saddaḥ attha upanayane kho saddaḥ vacana alaṅkāre
translated: but now he says “that” by way of recollection. The word “and” is for the purpose of summing up. The word “kho” is an ornament of speech,

original: avadhāraṇe vā. Vakkhamānassa atthassa nicchitabhāvato bhavaṅgacittena sahāvaṭṭhānābhāvato🔽upakkilesānaṃ āgantukatāti āha – “asahajātehī”tiādi. Rāgādayo upecca cittasantānaṃ
analyzed: avadhāraṇe vā vakkhamānassa atthassa nicchita bhāvataḥ bhavaṅga cittena saha avaṭṭhāna abhāvataḥ  āgantuka tā iti āha rāga ādayaḥ citta santānam
translated: or it is an indeclinable word. Because the meaning stated is ascertained, and because it does not occur together with the life-continuum consciousness,🔽it is an adventitious defilement. Therefore he said “from those that are not conascent with it” , etc. Because greed, etc., defile, obstruct, and torment the mental continuum,

original: kilissanti vibādhenti upatāpenti cāti āha – “upakkilesehīti rāgādīhī”ti. Bhavaṅgacittassa🔽nippariyāyato upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭhatā nāma natthi asaṃsaṭṭhabhāvato, ekasantatipariyāpannatāya
analyzed: kilissanti vibādhenti upatāpenti ca ati āha upakkilesehi iti rāga ādīhi iti bhavaṅga cittassa  nippariyāyataḥ upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭha tā nāma natthi a saṃsaṭṭha bhāvataḥ eka santati pariyāpanna tāya
translated: he said “from the defilements” , i.e., from greed, etc. Because the life-continuum consciousness is not really defiled by defilements,🔽because it does not occur together with them, it is said that it is “called defiled” because it is included in the same continuum,

original: pana siyā upakkiliṭṭhatāpariyāyoti āha – “upakkiliṭṭhaṃ nāmāti vuccatī”ti. Idāni
analyzed: pana siyā upakkiliṭṭha tā pariyāyaḥ ti āha upakkiliṭṭham nāma ati vuccati iti idāni
translated: even though it is not really defiled.

original: tamatthaṃ upamāya vibhāvetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādimāha. Tena bhinnasantānagatāyapi nāma
analyzed: tam attham upamāya vibhāvetum yathā hi iti ādim āha tena nāma
translated: In order to illustrate this matter by means of a simile, he says “Just as” , etc. By that he shows that the name “continuity” is used even in the case of a different continuity.

original: iriyāya loke gārayhatā dissati, pageva ekasantānagatāya iriyāyāti imaṃ visesaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: iriyāya loke gārayha tā dissati pagā iva eka santāna gatāya iriyāya ati imam visesam dasseti
translated: In order to illustrate this meaning by means of a simile, he said, “Just as … ” . By this he shows that even in the case of a posture that belongs to a different continuity, blame is seen in the world, all the more so in the case of a posture that belongs to the same continuity.

original: Tenāha – “javanakkhaṇe…pe… upakkiliṭṭhaṃ nāma hotī”ti.
analyzed: tena āha java nakkhaṇepe upakkiliṭṭham nāma hoti iti
translated: Therefore he said, “At the moment of impulsion … it is called defiled” .

original: 50. Dasame bhavaṅgacittameva cittanti “pabhassaramidaṃ, bhikkhave, citta”nti vuttaṃ
analyzed: dasame bhavaṅga cittam eva cittanti pabhassaram idam bhikkhave cittanti vuttam
translated: In the tenth case, the consciousness called “mind” is the life-continuum consciousness itself. “This mind, bhikkhus, is luminous” is said

original: bhavaṅgacittameva. Yadaggena bhavaṅgacittaṃ tādisapaccayasamavāye upakkiliṭṭhaṃ nāma
analyzed: bhavaṅga cittam eva yat aggena bhavaṅga cittam tādisa paccaya samavāye upakkiliṭṭham nāma
translated: with reference to the life-continuum consciousness itself. That which is called defiled by the condition of the life-continuum consciousness itself when there is the concurrence of such conditions,

original: vuccati, tadaggena tabbidhurapaccayasamavāye upakkilesato vimuttanti vuccati. Tenāha
analyzed: vuccati tad aggena tad bidhura paccaya samavāye upakkilesataḥ vimuttan ti vuccati tena āha
translated: is called freed from defilement by the condition of that very thing when there is the concurrence of conditions of that kind. Therefore he said,

original: – “upakkilesehi vippamuttaṃ nāma hotī”ti. Sesamettha navamasutte vuttanayānusārena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: upakkilesehi vippamuttam nāma hoti iti sesam ettha navama sutte vutta naya anusārena veditabbam
translated: “It is called freed from defilements” . The rest should be understood here in the way already stated in the ninth sutta .

original: Paṇihitaacchavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṇihita accha vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Paṇihitaacchavagga is ended.

original: 6. Accharāsaṅghātavaggavaṇṇanā
translated: The Accharāsaṅghātavagga

original: 51. Chaṭṭhassa paṭhame assutavāti ettha “sādhu paññāṇavā naro”tiādīsu atthitāmattassa
analyzed: chaṭṭhassa paṭhame assutavā ti ettha sādhu paññāṇavā naraḥ ti ādīsu atthi tā mattassa
translated: The negative particle is used in the sense of existence in such passages as “It is good for a man to have understanding” ,

original: bodhako vā-saddo. “Sīlavā hoti kalyāṇadhammo”tiādīsu pasaṃsāvisiṭṭhāya atthitāya.
analyzed: bodhakaḥ vā saddaḥ sīlavā hoti kalyāṇa dhammo ti ādīsu pasaṃsā visiṭṭhāya atthitāya
translated: and in the sense of existence qualified by blame in such passages as “He is virtuous, of good character” .

original: “Paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato”tiādīsu atisayatthavisiṭṭhāya🔽atthitāya, tasmā yassa pasatthaṃ atisayena vā sutaṃ atthi, so sutavā, saṃkilesaviddhaṃsanasamatthaṃ
analyzed: paññavā hoti udaya ttha gāminiyā paññāya samannāgataḥ ti ādīsu atisaya ttha visiṭṭhāya  atthitāya tasmai yassa pasattham atisayena vā sutam atthi so sutavā saṃkilesa viddhaṃsana samattham
translated: It is used in the sense of existence qualified by excess in such passages as “He is wise, he is endowed with wisdom that is penetrating and unearths the hidden meaning” .

original: pariyattidhammassavanaṃ, taṃ sutvā tathattāya paṭipatti ca “sutavā”ti iminā padena🔽pakāsitā. Sotabbayuttaṃ sutvā kattabbanipphattivasena suṇīti vā sutavā, tappaṭikkhepena
analyzed: pariyatti dhamma ssavanam tam sutvā tathattāya paṭipatti ca iminā padena  pakāsitā sotabba yuttam sutvā kattabba nipphatti vasena vā sutavā tad paṭikkhepena
translated: Therefore one who has what is approved or what is excessive is “learned” . The word “learned” signifies one who has heard the scriptures that are able to destroy defilement and who has practice in accordance with their meaning.

original: na sutavāti assutavā.
analyzed: na sutavā ati a sutavā
translated: Or alternatively, it signifies one who is able to hear what should be heard and who has the fruit of what should be done in hearing. One who is the opposite of that is “unlearned” .

original: Ayañhi akāro “ahetukā dhammā, abhikkhuko āvāso”tiādīsu taṃsamāyoganivattiyaṃ diṭṭho.
analyzed: ayam hi akāraḥ ahetukāḥ dhammāḥ abhikkhukaḥ āvāsaḥ ti ādīsu tad samāyoga nivattiyam diṭṭho
translated: For this negative particle is seen to be used in the sense of the cessation of the connection with what is stated in such passages as “There are uncaused dhammas” and “A monastery without bhikkhus” .

original: “Appaccayā dhammā”ti taṃsambandhibhāvanivattiyaṃ. Paccayuppannañhi paccayasambandhīti
analyzed: appaccayāḥ dhammā ti tad sambandhi bhāva nivattiyam paccaya uppannam hi paccaya sambandhi iti
translated: “Non-dependent states” in the sense of the non-occurrence of the state of being dependent on that. For what is dependent is dependent on conditions.

original: apaccayuppannattā ataṃsambandhitā ettha jotitā. “Anidassanā dhammā”ti taṃsabhāvanivattiyaṃ.
analyzed: a paccaya uppanna ttā a taṃsambandhi tā ettha joti tā anidassanāḥ dhammā ati
translated: So the non-occurrence of the state of being dependent on that is what is intended here. “Non-manifest states” in the sense of the non-occurrence of that state.

original: Nidassanañhi ettha daṭṭhabbatā. Atha vā passatīti nidassanaṃ, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Taggahetabbatānivattiyaṃ,
analyzed: nidassanam hi ettha daṭṭhabba tā atha vā passati iti nidassanam cakkhu viññāṇam
translated: For what is manifest is visible. Or alternatively, “manifest” is what is seen, that is, eye-consciousness. In the sense of the non-occurrence of the state of being apprehensible by that.

original: tathā “anāsavā dhammā”ti. “Appaṭighā dhammā anārammaṇā dhammā”ti taṃkiccanivattiyaṃ.
analyzed: tathā anāsavāḥ dhammā ati appaṭighāḥ dhammāḥ anārammaṇāḥ dhammā ti taṃkiccanivattiyam
translated: So too with “uncontaminated states.” “Non-opposed states, non-objective states” in the sense of the non-occurrence of the state of being an object of that.

original: “Arūpino dhammā acetasikādhammā”ti taṃsabhāvanivattiyaṃ. Tadaññatā hi idha pakāsitā.
analyzed: arūpino dhammā acetasikā adhammā ti taṃsa bhāva nivattiyam tad añña tā hi idha pakāsitā
translated: “Non-material states, non-mental-data states” in the sense of the non-occurrence of that state. For what is different from that is what is intended here.

original: “Amanusso”ti tabbhāvamattanivattiyaṃ. Manussattamattaṃ natthi, aññaṃ taṃsadisanti.
analyzed: amanussaḥ ti tad bhāva matta nivattiyam manussatta mattam natthi aññam tad sadisanti
translated: “Non-human” in the sense of the non-occurrence of the mere state of being a human being. For there is no mere human being, but only one or other of the kinds of human being.

original: Sadisatā hi ettha sūcitā. “Assamaṇo samaṇapaṭiñño abrahmacārī brahmacāripaṭiñño”ti
analyzed: sadisa tā hi ettha sūcitā a samaṇaḥ samaṇa paṭiññaḥ a brahmacārī brahmacāri paṭiññaḥ ti
translated: For what is similar is what is intended here. “Non-ascetic, one who pretends to be an ascetic, non- celibate, one who pretends to be celibate” in the sense of the non-occurrence of the state of being an object of that.

original: ca taṃsambhāvanīyaguṇanivattiyaṃ. Garahā hi idha ñāyati. “Kacci bhoto anāmayaṃ anudarā
analyzed: ca garahā hi idha ñāyati kacci bhotaḥ anāmayam
translated: and in the cessation of the qualities worthy of esteem. For here blame is known as “I hope you are well, I hope you are happy,

original: kaññā”ti ca tadanappabhāvanivattiyaṃ. “Anuppannā dhammā”ti taṃsadisabhāvanivattiyaṃ.
analyzed: kaññā ati ca tad anappabhāva nivattiyam anuppannāḥ dhammā ti tad sadisa bhāva nivattiyam
translated: and in the cessation of the qualities that are worthy of esteem. For here the censure is known thus: “I trust that your young wife is well and healthy and not over- exacting?” and in the cessation of the non-manifestation of that. “Unarisen states” : in the cessation of the manifestation of that.

original: Atītānañhi uppannapubbattā uppādidhammānañca paccayekadesasiddhiyā āraddhuppādabhāvato🔽kālavinimuttassa ca vijjamānattā uppannānukūlatā, pageva paccuppannānanti tabbidhuratā🔽hettha viññāyati. “Asekkhā dhammā”ti tadapariyosānanivattiyaṃ. Tanniṭṭhānañhettha🔽pakāsitanti evaṃ anekesaṃ atthānaṃ jotako. Idha pana “arūpino dhammā, acetasikā dhammā”tiādīsu
analyzed: atītānam hi uppanna pubbattā uppādi dhammānam ca paccaya eka desa siddhiyā āraddha uppāda bhāvato  kāla vinimuttassa ca vijjamāna ttā uppanna anukūla tā pagā iva paccuppannānam ti tad bidhura tā  ha ittha viññāyati asekkhāḥ dhammā ti tad apariyosāna nivattiyam tad niṭṭhānam ha ittha  pakāsitam ti evam anekesam atthānam jotakaḥ idha pana arūpinaḥ dhammāḥ acetasikāḥ dhammā ti ādīsu
translated: For past states are called “arisen” because they have arisen already, and future states are called “states that have arisen” because they are established as a class of conditions by having arisen already.🔽And because what is free from temporal determination exists, it is suitable to speak of it as “arisen,” all the more so of present states. Thus the suitability of speaking of it is known here. “States that are not subject to cankers” : in the cessation of the non-completion of that. For the completion of that is revealed here.

original: viya taṃsabhāvanivattiyaṃ daṭṭhabbo, aññattheti attho. Etenassa sutādiñāṇavirahaṃ
analyzed: viya taṃsa bhāva nivattiyam daṭṭhabbo aññattha iti attho etena assa suta ādi ñāṇa viraham

original: Nayidamīdisaṃ paṭivedhaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Yathā pana sāvakā aññesaṃ nissayena saccāni🔽paṭivijjhanti paratoghosena vinā tesaṃ dassanamaggassa anuppajjanato. Yathā ca sammāsambuddhā
