Or else, in accordance with the rule means in accordance with the arising of the eight grounds for deliverance .

original: Samayayuttanti tasseva vevacanaṃ, aṭṭhuppattianurūpaṃ vā. Samayayuttanti vā ariyasamayasaṃyuttaṃ.
analyzed: samaya yuttam ti tassa iva vevacanam aṭṭhuppatti anurūpam vā samaya yuttam ti vā ariya samaya saṃyuttam
translated: Or else, in accordance with the rule means in conformity with the noble rule.

original: Desakālānurūpameva hi buddhā bhagavanto dhammaṃ desenti, desentā ca ariyasammataṃ
analyzed: desa kāla anurūpam eva hi buddhāḥ bhagavantaḥ dhammam desenti desentā ca ariya sammatam
translated: For the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, teach the Dhamma in accordance with the time and place, and when they teach, they teach in conformity with the noble rule.

original: paṭiccasamuppādanayaṃ dīpentāva desenti. Atha vā samayayuttanti hetūdāharaṇasahitaṃ.🔽Kālena sāpadesañhi bhagavā dhammaṃ deseti, kālaṃ viditvā parisaṃ uyyojeti, na yāva
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppāda nayam dīpenta ava desenti atha vā samaya yuttanti hetu udāharaṇa sahitam  kālena sa apadesam hi bhagavā dhammam deseti kālam viditvā parisam uyyojeti na yāva
translated: Or else, “in season” means together with cause and example.

original: samandhakārā dhammaṃ deseti.
analyzed: samandhakārā dhammaṃ deseti
translated: For the Blessed One teaches the Dhamma in season and with reference to the right occasion. He dismisses the assembly when he knows the time. He does not teach the Dhamma until nightfall.

original: Utuṃ gaṇhāpeti, na pana malaṃ pakkhāletīti adhippāyo. Na hi bhagavato kāye rajojallaṃ🔽upalimpatīti. Tato tatoti attano attano divāṭṭhānādito. Okāsaṃ labhamānāti purebhattapacchābhattapurimayāmesu🔽okāsaṃ alabhitvā idāni majjhimayāme okāsaṃ labhamānā, bhagavatā vā katokāsatāya okāsaṃ
analyzed: utum gaṇhāpeti na pana malam pakkhāleti iti adhippāyaḥ na hi bhagavato kāye rajaḥ jallam  upalimpati iti tatas tatas iti attanaḥ attanaḥ divāṭṭhānāt itas okāsam purebhatta pacchābhatta purima yāmesu  okāsam a labhitvā idāni majjhima yāme okāsam labhamānāḥ bhagavatā vā kata ukāsa tāya okāsam
translated: The intention is that he does not wash away the dust. For dust and dirt do not soil the Blessed One’s body.🔽“From here and there” means from their respective day-quarters.

original: labhamānā. Pacchābhattassa tīsu bhāgesu paṭhamabhāge sīhaseyyakappanaṃ ekantikaṃ
analyzed: labhamānā pacchābhattassa tīsu bhāgesu paṭhama bhāge sīhaseyya kappanam ekantikam
translated: “Finding an opportunity” means that, not finding an opportunity in the morning, at midday, or in the first watch of the night, they now find an opportunity in the middle watch of the night, or they find an opportunity because the Blessed One has made an opportunity.🔽The Blessed One’s permission to lie down on his right side in the last watch of the night is not absolute.

original: na hotīti āha – “purebhattato paṭṭhāya nisajjāpīḷitassa sarīrassā”ti. Teneva hi tattha
analyzed: na hoti iti āha purebhattataḥ paṭṭhāya nisajja āpīḷitassa sarīrassa ati tena iva hi tattha
translated: Therefore it is said: “For one who is oppressed by sitting since the morning.”

original: “sace ākaṅkhatī”ti tadā sīhaseyyakappanassa anibaddhatā vibhāvitā. Kilāsubhāvo parissamo.🔽Sīhaseyyaṃ kappeti sarīrassa kilāsubhāvamocanatthanti yojetabbaṃ. Buddhacakkhunā
analyzed: sace ākaṅkhati iti tadā sīhaseyya kappanassa anibaddha tā vibhāvitā kilāsu bhāvaḥ parissamaḥ  sīhaseyyam kappeti sarīrassa kilāsu bhāva mocana atthan ti yojetabbam buddha cakkhunā
translated: “If he wishes”: this shows that the rule about the lion-posture is not fixed. The state of being worn out is a kind of exhaustion.🔽The sentence “he makes the lion-posture in order to remove the state of being worn out of the body” should be construed thus.

original: lokaṃ voloketīti idaṃ pacchimayāme bhagavato bahulaṃ āciṇṇavasena vuttaṃ. Appekadā
analyzed: lokam voloketi iti idam pacchima yāme bhagavataḥ bahulam vuttam appa ekadā
translated: “He surveys the world with the Buddha-eye”: this is said with reference to the Blessed One’s usual practice in the last watch of the night. But on some occasions

original: avasiṭṭhabalañāṇehi sabbaññutaññāṇeneva ca bhagavā tamatthaṃ sādhetīti.🔽Imasmiṃyeva kicceti pacchimayāmakicce. Balavatā paccanutāpena saṃvaḍḍhamānena karajakāye
analyzed: avasiṭṭha bala ñāṇehi sabbaññuta ññāṇena iva ca bhagavā tam attham sādheti iti  imasmiṃyeva kiccā iti pacchima yāma kicce balavatā paccanutāpena saṃvaḍḍhamānena karaja kāye
translated: the Blessed One establishes that matter by means of the knowledge of omniscience, which is the remainder of the strength of knowledge.🔽“In this very task”: in the task of the last watch of the night.🔽The great fever arises in the physical body, which is being increased by the strong, increasing heat.

original: mahāpariḷāho uppajjatīti āha – “nāmakāye santatte karajakāyo santatto”ti. Nidhānagatanti
analyzed: mahā pariḷāhaḥ uppajjati iti āha nāmakāye santatte karaja kāyaḥ santattaḥ iti nidhāna gatam ti
translated: “When the mental body is heated, the physical body is heated” is said with reference to the blood that has been stored up.

original: sannicitalohitaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Uṇhaṃ lohitaṃ mukhato uggañchīti lohitaṃ uṇhaṃ
analyzed: sannicita lohitam sandhāya vuttam uṇham lohitam mukhataḥ uggañchi iti lohitam uṇham
translated: The hot blood boiled up from his mouth: the blood boiled up from his mouth,🔽having been heated. “The place”: the bhikkhu’s confession.

original: hutvā mukhato uggañchi. Ṭhānanti bhikkhupaṭiññaṃ. Taṃ pāpaṃ vaḍḍhamānanti bhikkhupaṭiññāya
analyzed: hutvā mukhataḥ uggañchi ṭhānanti bhikkhu paṭiññam tat pāpam vaḍḍhamānanti bhikkhu paṭiññāya
translated: “That evil increased”: the evil increased because of the bhikkhu’s confession.

original: avijahitattā tathā pavaḍḍhamānapāpaṃ. Antimavatthuajjhāpannānampi upāyena pavattiyamāno
analyzed: a vijahita ttā tathā pavaḍḍhamāna pāpam antima vatthu ajjhāpannānam pi upāyena
translated: Even for those who have undertaken the last basis, the proper attention that is being practiced by means of a means

original: yonisomanasikāro sātthako hotiyevāti dassento “jātasaṃvegā”tiādimāha. Aho sallekhitanti
analyzed: yoniso manasikāro sātthakaḥ dassentaḥ jātasaṃvega ati ādim āha aho sallekhitanti
translated: is indeed meaningful. Showing this, he said “Jātasaṃvegā” , etc. Aho sallekhitanti

original: aho ativiya sallekhena itaṃ pavattaṃ. Kāsāvapajjototi bhikkhūnaṃ bahubhāvato ito
analyzed: aho ativiya sallekhena itam pavattam bhikkhūnam bahu bhāvataḥ itas
translated: aho ativiya sallekhena itaṃ pavattaṃ. Kāsāvapajjototi bhikkhūnaṃ bahubhāvato ito

original: cito ca vicarantānaṃ tesaṃ kāsāvajutiyā pajjotito. Isivātaparivātoti sīlakkhandhādīnaṃ
analyzed: citaḥ ca vicarantānam tesam kāsāva jutiyā pajjotitaḥ isivāta parivātaḥ ti sīlakkhandha ādīnam
translated: cito ca vicarantānaṃ tesaṃ kāsāvajutiyā pajjotito. Isivātaparivātoti sīlakkhandhādīnaṃ

original: nibbānassa ca esanato isīnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ guṇagandhena ceva guṇagandhavāsitena sarīragandhena
analyzed: nibbānassa ca esanataḥ isīnam bhikkhūnam guṇa gandhena ca iva guṇa gandha vāsitena sarīra gandhena
translated: nibbānassa ca esanato isīnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ guṇagandhena ceva guṇagandhavāsitena sarīragandhena

original: ca parito samantato vāyito.
analyzed: ca paritas samantataḥ
translated: ca parito samantato vāyito.

original: Dhammasaṃvego uppajji anāvajjanena pubbe tassa atthassa asaṃviditattā. Dhammasaṃvegoti
analyzed: dhamma saṃvegaḥ uppajji an āvajjanena pubbe tassa atthassa a saṃvidita ttā dhamma saṃvegaḥ ti
translated: Dhammasaṃvego uppajji anāvajjanena pubbe tassa atthassa asaṃviditattā. Dhammasaṃvegoti

original: ca tādise atthe dhammatāvasena uppajjanakaṃ sahottappañāṇaṃ. Assāsaṭṭhānanti cittassāsakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: ca tādise atthe dhamma tā vasena uppajjanakam sahottappa ñāṇam assāsa ṭṭhānam ti citta ssāsa kāraṇam
translated: ca tādise atthe dhammatāvasena uppajjanakaṃ sahottappañāṇaṃ. Assāsaṭṭhānanti cittassāsakāraṇaṃ

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ. Sabbesaṃ kiccānaṃ pubbabhāgo sabbapubbabhāgo. “Sabbe sattā averā hontū”tiādinā
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam sabbesam kiccānam pubba bhāgaḥ sabba pubbabhāgaḥ sabbe sattāḥ averāḥ hontu iti ādinā
translated: The preliminary work for all tasks is the “preliminary work for all tasks.”🔽For the preliminary work of the mind is the arousing, the adverting, the directing of the mind to the thought “May all beings be free from enmity, etc.,”

original: hi cittassa paṭṭhānaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ hitapharaṇaṃ. Itaraṃ ito thokaṃ mahantanti katvā
analyzed: hi cittassa paṭṭhānam upaṭṭhānam hita pharaṇam itaram itas thokam mahantanti katvā
translated: The other is called the “Great Discourse on the Fading Away of Lust” because it is slightly greater than this one.

original: idaṃ “cūḷaccharāsaṅghātasutta”nti vuttaṃ. Accharāsaṅghāto vuccati aṅguliphoṭanakkhaṇo
analyzed: idam cūḷaccharā saṅghāta suttam ti vuttam accharā saṅghāto vuccati aṅguli phoṭana kkhaṇo
translated: The moment of snapping the fingers is called the “moment of an akkhaṇa.”

original: akkhinimisakālo, yo ekassa akkharassa uccāraṇakkhaṇo. Tenāha – “dve aṅguliyo paharitvā🔽saddakaraṇamatta”nti. Sabbasattānaṃ hitapharaṇacittanti sabbesampi sattānaṃ sammadeva
analyzed: akkhi nimisa kālaḥ yaḥ ekassa akkharassa uccāraṇa kkhaṇo tena āha dve aṅguliyaḥ paharitvā  sadda karaṇa mattanti sabba sattānam hita pharaṇa cittanti sabbesam pi sattānam sammat eva
translated: The moment of uttering an akkhaṇa is the moment of an akkhaṇa.

original: hitesitavasena pavattacittaṃ. Āvajjento āsevatīti hitesitavasena āvajjento. Āvajjanena🔽ābhujantopi āsevati nāma ñāṇavippayuttena. Jānantoti tathā ñāṇamattaṃ uppādentopi.
analyzed: hita īsita vasena pavatta cittam āvajjentaḥ āsevati iti hita īsita vasena āvajjentaḥ āvajjanena  ābhujantaḥ api āsevati nāma ñāṇa vippayuttena jānantaḥ ti tathā ñāṇa mattam uppādentaḥ api
translated: He directs his mind to the thought of wishing welfare: he directs his mind to the thought of wishing welfare in the way described.🔽He adverts: he adverts by means of the adverting that is associated with the knowledge of what is the path and what is not the path.🔽He knows: he produces mere knowledge.

original: Passantoti tathā ñāṇacakkhunā paccakkhato viya vipassantopi. Paccavekkhantoti tamatthaṃ
analyzed: passantoti tathā ñāṇa cakkhunā paccakkhataḥ viya vipassantaḥ api paccavekkhantaḥ ti tam attham
translated: He sees: he also sees by means of insight knowledge as if facing outwards.🔽He reviews: he reviews that meaning.

original: pati pati avekkhantopi. Saddhāya adhimuccantotiādi pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ vasena vuttaṃ.🔽Abhiññeyyantiādi catusaccavasena vuttaṃ. Sabbameva cetaṃ vitthārato, sāmaññena āsevanadassanamevāti🔽idhādhippetameva āsevanatthaṃ dassetuṃ – “idha panā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pati pati avekkhantaḥ api saddhāya adhimuccantaḥ itiādi pañcannam indriyānam vasena vuttam  abhiññeyya ntiādi catu sacca vasena vuttam sabbam eva ca itam vitthārato sāmaññena āsevana dassanam eva ati  idha adhippetam eva āsevana attham dassetum idha pana atiādi vuttam
translated: and he resolves upon them with faith, and so on.🔽The words “to be directly known” and so on are said with reference to the four truths.

original: Arittajjhānoti avirahitajjhāno. Atucchajjhānoti jhānena atuccho. Cāgo vā vevacananti🔽āha – “apariccattajjhāno”ti. Viharatīti padassa vibhaṅge āgatanayena atthaṃ dassento
analyzed: aritta jhāno ti avirahita jhāno atuccha jhāno ati jhānena atucchaḥ cāgaḥ vā  āha a pariccatta jhāno ti viharati iti padassa vibhaṅge āgata nayena attham dassento
translated: And all this is given in detail in the Vibhaṅga in the way beginning, “‘The establishment of mindfulness by means of in-breaths and out-breaths is fourfold: when mindfulness of in-breaths and out-breaths as long or short is being developed, when mindfulness of in-breaths and out-breaths as in front is being developed, when mindfulness of in-breaths and out-breaths as void is being developed, when mindfulness of in-breaths and out-breaths as a concept is being developed’—thus it is fourfold.🔽But here only the development of mindfulness as a concept is intended” .

original: “viharatīti iriyatī”tiādimāha. Ayaṃ panettha saddattho – viharatīti ettha vi-saddo🔽vicchedatthajotano. Haratīti neti, pavattetīti attho, vicchinditvā harati viharatīti
analyzed: viharati iti iriyati itiādim āha ayam pana ittha sadda atthaḥ viharati iti ettha visaddaḥ  viccheda attha jotanaḥ harati iti na iti pavatteti iti atthaḥ vicchinditvā harati viharati iti
translated: And in order to show the meaning of development here, he said, “Here, however, ‘development’ is this” .🔽The words “he is one who obtains at will, without trouble or difficulty, the bliss of renunciation” are said with reference to the development of the first jhāna.🔽The words “he is one who obtains at will, without trouble or difficulty, the bliss of seclusion” are said with reference to the development of the second jhāna.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. So hi ekaṃ iriyāpathabādhanaṃ aññena iriyāpathena vicchinditvā aparipatantaṃ
analyzed: vuttam hoti so hi ekam iriyāpatha bādhanam aññena iriyāpathena vicchinditvā a paripatantam
translated: The words “he is one who obtains at will, without trouble or difficulty, the bliss of voidness” are said with reference to the development of the third jhāna.🔽The words “he is one who obtains at will, without trouble or difficulty, the bliss of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception” are said with reference to the development of the fourth jhāna.🔽The words “he is one who obtains at will, without trouble or difficulty, the signless concentration of mind” are said with reference to the development of the signless concentration of mind.

original: attabhāvaṃ harati pavatteti, tasmā “viharatī”ti vuccati. Iriyatīti ṭhānanisajjādikiriyaṃ
analyzed: atta bhāvam harati pavattā iti tasmai viharati iti vuccati iriyati iti ṭhāna nisajja ādi kiriyam
translated: He carries on, he makes occur, his own being, thus he is said to “live” . He moves : he occurs by doing the action of standing, sitting, etc.,

original: karonto pavattati. Pavattatīti ṭhānādisamaṅgī hutvā pavattati. Pāletīti ekaṃ iriyāpathabādhanaṃ🔽iriyāpathantarehi rakkhanto pāleti. Yapeti yāpetīti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Ekañhi iriyāpathabādhanaṃ
analyzed: karontaḥ pavattati pavattati iti ṭhāna ādi samaṅgī hutvā pavattati pāleti iti ekam iriyāpatha bādhanam  iriyāpatha antarehi rakkhanto pāleti yapeti yāpeti iti tassa iva vevacanam ekam hi iriyāpatha bādhanam
translated: He occurs : he occurs possessed of standing, etc. He guards : he guards by protecting with other postures the one that is painful

original: aññena iriyāpathena vicchinditvā aparipatantaṃ attabhāvaṃ pālento yapeti yāpetīti
analyzed: aññena iriyāpathena vicchinditvā a paripatantam atta bhāvam pālentaḥ yapeti yāpeti iti
translated: because of the occurrence of another. He maintains : he maintains by keeping going his own being, which does not fall down, by dividing the painful one🔽with another posture. He nourishes : this is a synonym for “he maintains.” For he is said to “maintain” and “nourish” his own being, which does not fall down, by protecting it from falling down with another posture when one posture becomes painful.

original: vuccati. Caratīti ṭhānanisajjādīsu aññatarasamaṅgī hutvā pavattati. Iminā padenāti
analyzed: vuccati carati iti ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu aññatara samaṅgī hutvā pavattati iminā padena ati
translated: He goes : he occurs possessed of one or other of the postures of standing, sitting, etc.🔽By this word “lives” :

original: “viharatī”ti iminā padena.🔽Iriyāpathavihāroti ettha iriyanaṃ pavattanaṃ iriyā, kāyappayogo kāyikakiriyā. Tassā
analyzed: viharati iti iminā padena  iriyāpatha vihāraḥ ti ettha iriyanam pavattanam iriyā kāya payogo kāyika kiriyā tassā
translated: by this word “lives” .

original: pavattanūpāyabhāvato iriyāya patho iriyāpatho, ṭhānanisajjādi. Na hi ṭhānanisajjādīhi
analyzed: pavatta nūpāya bhāvataḥ iriyāya pathaḥ iriyāpathaḥ ṭhāna nisajja ādi na hi ṭhāna nisajja ādīhi
translated: Posture-living : here the going is the occurrence, the posture is the bodily effort, the bodily action. Because it is a means to the occurrence of that, the path of the posture is the posture-path, which is standing, sitting, etc. For it is not by means of lying down that one can stand, sit, or walk.

original: avatthāhi vinā kiñci kāyikakiriyaṃ pavattetuṃ sakkā. Ṭhānasamaṅgī vā hi kāyena kiñci
analyzed: avatthāhi vinā kiñci kāyika kiriyam pavattetum sakkā ṭhāna samaṅgī vā hi kāyena kiñci
translated: No bodily action can be performed without a posture. For one might perform some bodily action while standing or while possessing any one of the other postures beginning with walking.

original: kareyya, gamanādīsu aññatarasamaṅgī vā. Viharaṇaṃ, viharati etenāti vā vihāro, iriyāpathova🔽vihāro iriyāpathavihāro, so ca atthato ṭhānanisajjādiākārappavatto catusantatirūpappabandho
analyzed: kareyya gamana ādīsu aññatara samaṅgī vā viharaṇam viharati etena ati vā vihāraḥ iriyāpatha uva  vihāro iriyāpatha vihāro so ca atthataḥ ṭhāna nisajja ādi ākāra ppavatto catu santati rūpa ppabandho
translated: Or the posture is that by means of which one abides , thus it is abiding ; the posture is the abiding.🔽That is, in the ultimate sense, the posture is a continuum of material instances occurring in the form of the postures of standing, sitting, etc.

original: eva. Ovādānusāsanīnaṃ ekānekavārādivisiṭṭhoyeva bhedo, na pana paramatthato tesaṃ🔽nānākaraṇanti dassetuṃ – “paramatthato panā”tiādimāha. Tattha ese eke ekaṭṭhetiādīsu
analyzed: eva ovāda anusāsanīnam bhedaḥ na pana paramatthato tesam  nānākaraṇanti dassetum paramatthataḥ pana iti ādim āha tattha ese eke ekaṭṭha iti ādīsu
translated: The difference in the admonishments and instructions is due to their being given in one or many ways, etc., but not in the ultimate sense.

original: eso eko ekatthotiādinā attho veditabbo.
analyzed: esaḥ ekaḥ ekatthaḥ iti ādinā attho veditabbo
translated: In order to show this, he says, “But in the ultimate sense, etc.” Herein, the meaning should be understood in the way beginning, “This one is one, of one . . . ”

original: Raṭṭhassa, raṭṭhato vā laddho piṇḍo raṭṭhapiṇḍo. Tenāha – “ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāyā”tiādi.
analyzed: raṭṭhassa raṭṭhataḥ vā laddhaḥ piṇḍaḥ raṭṭha piṇḍaḥ tena āha ñāti parivaṭṭam pahāya atiādi
translated: The alms food obtained in a village or from a village is the alms food of a village. Hence it is said, “having abandoned the alms food of relatives” .

original: Tattha “amhākamete”ti viññāyantīti ñātī, pitāmahapituputtādivasena parivaṭṭanaṭṭhena
analyzed: tattha amhākam ete iti viññāyanti iti ñātī pitāmaha pitu putta ādi vasena parivaṭṭana ṭṭhena
translated: Herein, relatives are those who are known as “ours” . They are so called because of the act of revolving around , in the sense of revolving around as father, grandfather, uncle, etc.

original: parivaṭṭo, ñātiyeva parivaṭṭo ñātiparivaṭṭo. Theyyaparibhogo nāma anarahassa paribhogo.
analyzed: parivaṭṭaḥ ñātiyā iva parivaṭṭaḥ ñātiparivaṭṭaḥ theyyaparibhogo nāma anarahassa paribhogo
translated: A relative’s means a relative’s turn. A turn by relatives is a relative’s turn. A use by theft is a use of what belongs to another by theft.

original: Bhagavatā hi attano sāsane sīlavato paccayā anuññātā, na dussīlassa. Dāyakānampi
analyzed: bhagavatā hi attanaḥ sāsane sīlavataḥ paccayāḥ anuññātāḥ na dussīlassa dāyakānam pi
translated: For the requisites have been allowed by the Blessed One for one who is virtuous in his own field of training, not for one who is not virtuous. And

original: sīlavato eva pariccāgo, na dussīlassa attano kārānaṃ mahapphalabhāvassa paccāsīsanato.
analyzed: sīlavataḥ eva pariccāgaḥ na dussīlassa attanaḥ kārānam mahat phala bhāvassa paccāsīsanato
translated: the giving of donors is for one who is virtuous, not for one who is not virtuous, because it is a repayment of the great fruitfulness of their own action.

original: Iti satthārā ananuññātattā dāyakehi ca apariccattattā saṅghamajjhepi nisīditvā paribhuñjantassa
analyzed: iti satthārā an anuññāta ttā dāyakehi ca a pariccatta ttā saṅgha majjhe api nisīditvā paribhuñjantassa
translated: So it is because it is not allowed by the Teacher and it is not given by donors that the use by one who is not virtuous of what he has taken a turn about in the midst of the Sangha,

original: dussīlassa paribhogo theyyāya paribhogo theyyaparibhogo. Iṇavasena paribhogo iṇaparibhogo
analyzed: dussīlassa paribhogo theyyāya paribhogaḥ theyya paribhogaḥ iṇa vasena paribhogaḥ iṇa paribhogaḥ
translated: is a use by theft. A use by debt is a use by borrowing.

original: paṭiggāhakato dakkhiṇāvisuddhiyā abhāvato iṇaṃ gahetvā paribhogo viyāti attho.🔽Dātabbaṭṭhena dāyaṃ, taṃ ādiyantīti dāyādā, puttānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ, tesaṃ bhāvo
analyzed: paṭiggāhakataḥ dakkhiṇā visuddhiyāḥ abhāvataḥ iṇam gahetvā paribhogaḥ viyā ti attho  dātabba ṭṭhena dāyam tam ādiyanti iti dāyādāḥ puttānam etam adhivacanam tesam bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is a use as though it were borrowed on loan because there is no purification of offering on the part of the receiver.🔽A gift is what is to be given. Those who take that are heirs. This is a term for sons. Their state

original: dāyajjaṃ, dāyajjavasena paribhogo dāyajjaparibhogo, puttabhāvena paribhogoti vuttaṃ
analyzed: dāyajjam dāyajja vasena paribhogaḥ dāyajja paribhogo putta bhāvena paribhogo ti vuttam
translated: is inheritance. A use by inheritance is a use as inheritance. It is said that it is a use as a son.

original: hoti. Sekkhā hi bhikkhū bhagavato orasaputtā, te pitu santakānaṃ dāyādā hutvā te
analyzed: hoti sekkhā hi bhikkhū bhagavataḥ orasa puttā te pitu santakānam dāyādāḥ hutvā te
translated: For the bhikkhus who are the Blessed One’s disciples are his sons by the Dhamma, and they enjoy the requisites as the heirs of his father’s estate.

original: paccaye paribhuñjanti. Kiṃ pana te bhagavato paccaye paribhuñjanti, udāhu gihīnanti?🔽Gihīhi dinnāpi bhagavatā anuññātattā bhagavato santakā ananuññātesu sabbena sabbaṃ
analyzed: paccaye paribhuñjanti kim pana te bhagavato paccaye paribhuñjanti udāhu  gihīhi dinnā api bhagavatā anuññāta ttā bhagavataḥ santakā an anuññātesu sabbena sabbam
translated: But are the requisites enjoyed by them the Blessed One’s or are they householders’?

original: paribhogābhāvato, anuññātesuyeva ca paribhogasambhavato. Dhammadāyādasuttañcettha sādhakaṃ.🔽Vītarāgā eva taṇhāya dāsabyaṃ atītattā sāmino hutvā paribhuñjantīti āha – “khīṇāsavassa🔽paribhogo sāmiparibhogo nāmā”ti. Avītarāgānañhi taṇhāparavasatāya paccayaparibhoge
analyzed: paribhoga abhāvataḥ ca paribhoga sambhavataḥ dhammadāyādasuttam ca ittha sādhakam  vīta rāgāḥ eva taṇhāya dāsabyam sāminaḥ hutvā paribhuñjanti iti āha khīṇāsavassa  paribhogo sāmi paribhogaḥ nāma ati a vīta rāgānam hi taṇhā paravasa tāya paccaya paribhoge
translated: Though given by householders, they are the Blessed One’s because he has allowed them. For there is no enjoyment of what is not allowed, and there is enjoyment of what is allowed. The sutta on the inheritance of the Dhamma is the proof here.🔽He said that they enjoy them as owners because they are free from lust, since they have passed beyond being slaves to craving.

original: sāmibhāvo natthi, tadabhāvena vītarāgānaṃ tattha sāmibhāvo yathāruciparibhogasambhavato.
analyzed: sāmibhāvaḥ natthi tad abhāvena vīta rāgānam tattha sāmibhāvaḥ yathā ruci paribhoga sambhavato
translated: For those who are not free from lust have no ownership in the enjoyment of requisites because they are subject to craving. And it is because they have that that those who are free from lust have ownership in the enjoyment of requisites, since they can enjoy them as they choose.

original: Tathā hi te paṭikūlampi appaṭikūlākārena, appaṭikūlampi paṭikūlākārena, tadubhayampi
analyzed: tathā hi te paṭikūlam api appaṭikūla ākārena appaṭikūlam api paṭikūla ākārena tat ubhayam pi
translated: For they can enjoy what is repulsive as if it were unrepulsive, and what is unrepulsive as if it were repulsive, and both as neither.

original: vajjetvā ajjhupekkhanākārena paccaye paribhuñjanti, dāyakānañca manorathaṃ pūrenti.🔽Yo panāyaṃ sīlavato paccavekkhitaparibhogo, so iṇaparibhogassa paccanīkattā āṇaṇyaparibhogo🔽nāma hoti. Yathā hi iṇāyiko attano ruciyā icchitaṃ desaṃ gantuṃ na labhati, evaṃ
analyzed: vajjetvā ajjhupekkhanā ākārena paccaye paribhuñjanti dāyakānam ca manoratham pūrenti  yaḥ pana ayam sīlavataḥ paccavekkhita paribhogo saḥ iṇa paribhogassa paccanīka ttā āṇaṇya paribhogaḥ  nāma hoti yathā hi iṇāyikaḥ attanaḥ ruciyā icchitam desam gantum na labhati evam
translated: They use them by way of equanimity after reflection, and they fulfill the givers’ wishes.🔽But the use of one who is virtuous after reflection is called the use of one free from debt because it is the opposite of the use of one in debt.🔽For just as one in debt is not free to go where he would like, so one bound by the debt of requisites is not free to leave the world.

original: iṇaparibhogayutto lokato nissarituṃ na labhatīti tappaṭipakkhattā sīlavato paccavekkhitaparibhogo
analyzed: iṇa paribhoga yuttaḥ lokataḥ nissaritum na labhati iti tad paṭipakkha ttā sīlavataḥ paccavekkhita paribhogaḥ
translated: The use of one who is virtuous after reflection is the opposite of that,

original: “āṇaṇyaparibhogo”ti vuccati, tasmā nippariyāyato catuparibhogavinimutto visuṃyevāyaṃ
analyzed: vuccati tasmā catu paribhoga vinimuttaḥ
translated: and so it is called the use of one free from debt. Therefore, in the ultimate sense, this use is quite distinct from the four kinds of use,

original: paribhogoti veditabbo. So idha visuṃ na vutto, dāyajjaparibhogeyeva vā saṅgahaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: paribhogaḥ iti veditabbaḥ saḥ idha visum na vuttaḥ vā saṅgaham gacchati
translated: and it should be understood as a separate use. But it is not mentioned separately here, or else it is included in the use as an inheritance.🔽For the virtuous one is called a “learner” because he possesses this training.

original: Sīlavāpi hi imāya sikkhāya samannāgatattā “sekho”tveva vuccati. Imesu paribhogesu
analyzed: sīlavā api hi imāya sikkhāya samannāgata ttā sekho tvā eva vuccati imesu paribhogesu
translated: Of these four kinds of use,

original: sāmiparibhogo dāyajjaparibhogo ca ariyānaṃ puthujjanānañca vaṭṭati, iṇaparibhogo
analyzed: sāmi paribhogaḥ dāyajja paribhogo ca ariyānam puthujjanānam ca vaṭṭati iṇa paribhogo
translated: the use as master and the use as an inheritance are proper for noble disciples and ordinary people alike, but the use of one in debt is not.

original: na vaṭṭati. Theyyaparibhoge kathāyeva natthi. Kathaṃ panettha sāmiparibhogo dāyajjaparibhogo🔽ca puthujjanānaṃ sambhavati? Upacāravasena. Yo hi puthujjanassapi sallekhappaṭipattiyaṃ🔽ṭhitassa paccayagedhaṃ pahāya tattha anupalittena cittena paribhogo, so sāmiparibhogo🔽viya hoti. Sīlavato pana paccavekkhitaparibhogo dāyajjaparibhogo viya hoti dāyakānaṃ
analyzed: na vaṭṭati theyya paribhoge kathāya iva natthi katham pana ittha sāmi paribhogaḥ dāyajja paribhogo  ca puthujjanānam sambhavati upacāra vasena yaḥ hi puthujjanaḥ api sallekha ppaṭipattiyam  ṭhitassa paccaya gedham pahāya tattha an upalittena cittena paribhogo so sāmi paribhogo  viya hoti sīlavataḥ pana paccavekkhita paribhogaḥ dāyajja paribhogaḥ viya hoti dāyakānam
translated: There is no question of using what is stolen. But how can there be use of what is one’s own and use of an inheritance in the case of ordinary men? It is in the sense of a figure of speech. For the use of one who is established in the practice of restraint, abandoning greed for the object, and using it with a mind that does not cling, is like use of what is one’s own. But the use of one who is virtuous and reviews the object is like use of an inheritance.

original: manorathassa avirādhanato. Kalyāṇaputhujjanassa paribhoge vattabbameva natthi tassa🔽sekkhasaṅgahato. Sekkhasuttaṃ hetassa atthassa sādhakaṃ.
analyzed: manorathassa avirādhanato kalyāṇa puthujjanassa paribhoge vattabbam eva na atthi tassa  sekkha saṅgahataḥ sekkha suttam ha itassa atthassa sādhakam
translated: There is no question of using what is stolen. But how can there be use as owner and use as an inheritance for ordinary men? It is by way of a figure. For the use of one who is established in the practice of reflection, even though he be an ordinary man, without craving for the object, is like use as owner. But the use of one who is virtuous, and reflects on the object, is like use as an inheritance, because it does not frustrate the hopes of the givers. As for the use of a good ordinary man, there is nothing to be said about it, because he is included among the trainees. The sutta on the trainee is the proof of this meaning.

original: Imassa bhikkhunoti accharāsaṅghātamattampi kālaṃ mettacittaṃ āsevantassa bhikkhuno.
analyzed: imassa bhikkhuno ti accharā saṅghāta mattam pi kālam metta cittam āsevantassa bhikkhuno
translated: Of this bhikkhu: of a bhikkhu who cultivates loving-kindness for the time of a mere finger- snap.

original: Amogho raṭṭhapiṇḍaparibhogoti “ayaṃ pabbajito samaṇo bhikkhūti āmisaṃ dentānaṃ tāya
analyzed: amoghaḥ raṭṭha piṇḍa paribhogo ti ayam pabbajitaḥ samaṇaḥ bhikkhu iti āmisam dentānam tāya
translated: Not in vain is the use of the country’s alms: “This one who has gone forth, this recluse, is a bhikkhu,” and they give him material things.

original: mettāsevanāya attano santāne dosamalassa vā tadekaṭṭhānañca pāpadhammānaṃ pabbājanato
analyzed: mettā sevanāya attano santāne dosa malassa vā tad eka ṭṭhānam ca pāpa dhammānam pabbājanato
translated: Because of the cultivation of loving-kindness, the stain of hate and the other evil things that are in the same category as that are expelled from his own mental continuity,

original: vūpasamanato saṃsāre ca bhayassa sammāva ikkhaṇato ajjhāsayassa avisaṃvādanenassa🔽amogho raṭṭhapiṇḍaparibhogo. Mahaṭṭhiyanti mahatthikaṃ mahāpayojanaṃ. Mahapphalanti
analyzed: vūpasamanataḥ saṃsāre ca bhayassa ajjhāsayassa  amoghaḥ raṭṭha piṇḍa paribhogaḥ mahaṭṭhiyanti mahatthikam mahā payojanam mahapphalanti
translated: and because of the complete removal of fear in the round of rebirths, and because of the non-deception of his own intention,

original: vipulapphalaṃ. Mahānisaṃsanti mahānissandapphalaṃ. Mahājutikanti mahānubhāvaṃ. Mahāvipphāranti🔽mahāvitthāraṃ. Ettha ca paṭhamaṃ kāraṇaṃ mettāsevanāya tassa bhikkhuno sāmiādibhāvena
analyzed: vipula phalam mahā nisaṃsanti mahā nissanda phalam mahā jutikanti mahā anubhāvam mahā vipphāranti  mahā vitthāram ettha ca paṭhamam kāraṇam mettā sevanāya tassa bhikkhuno sāmi ādi bhāvena
translated: the use of the country’s alms food is not fruitless. It is of great fruit: it has great fruit. It has great profit: it has great consequential fruit. It has great splendour: it has great efficacy. It has great radiance: it has great extension.

original: raṭṭhapiṇḍaparibhogārahatā, dutiyaṃ parehi dinnassa dānassa mahaṭṭhiyabhāvakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: raṭṭha piṇḍa paribhoga araha tā dutiyam parehi dinnassa dānassa mahaṭṭhiya bhāva karaṇam
translated: And here the first reason is the reason why the use of the country’s alms food is worthy of that bhikkhu because of his being a master, etc., of loving-kindness. The second is the making of the gift given by others fruitful in a high degree.

original: Ko pana vādoti mettāya āsevanamattampi evaṃmahānubhāvaṃ, ko pana vādo bahulīkāre,
analyzed: kaḥ pana mettāya evaṃmahā anubhāvam kaḥ pana vādaḥ bahulīkāre
translated: What to say then of the development? What to say then of the development of loving-kindness, which is so powerful,

original: ettha vattabbameva natthī”ti attho.
analyzed: ettha vattabbam eva na atthi iti atthaḥ
translated: there is nothing to say” is the meaning.

original: 54. Catutthe uppādeti vaḍḍhetīti ettha bhāvanāsaddassa uppādanavaḍḍhanatthatā pubbe vuttā eva.
analyzed: catutthe uppādeti vaḍḍheti iti ettha bhāvanā saddassa uppādana vaḍḍhana tā pubbe vuttā eva
translated: In the fourth, he generates and develops. Herein, the meaning of the word “development” as generating and developing has already been given above.🔽In the fifth, in these two: in the fourth and fifth.

original: 55. Pañcame imesu dvīsūti catutthapañcamesu. “Tatiye vuttanayeneva veditabba”nti
analyzed: pañcame imesu dvīsu iti catuttha pañcamesu tatiye vutta nayena iva veditabbanti
translated: After saying, “It should be understood in the way stated in the third,”

original: vatvā tathā veditabbataṃ dassetuṃ – “yo hi āsevatī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tena āsevanābhāvanāmanasikārānaṃ
analyzed: vatvā tathā veditabba tam dassetum yaḥ hi āsevati itiādi vuttam tena
translated: he said, “For he who cultivates” in order to show how it should be understood. By that he shows that there is no difference in the meaning of the words “cultivation,” “development,” and “attention.”

original: atthavisesābhāvamāha. Yadi evaṃ suttantassa desanā kathanti āha – “sammāsambuddho🔽panā”tiādi. Yāya dhammadhātuyāti sabbaññutaññāṇamāha. Tena hi dhammānaṃ ākārabhedaṃ
analyzed: attha visesa abhāvam āha yadi evam suttantassa desanā katham ti āha sammāsambuddhaḥ  pana atiādi yāya dhammadhātuyā iti sabbaññuta ññāṇam āha tena hi dhammānam ākāra bhedam
translated: If that is so, then how is the teaching of the sutta to be interpreted? He said, “The Fully Enlightened One,” etc.🔽By the element of Dhamma: he refers to the knowledge of omniscience. For by that the Exalted One, having known the diversity of the modes of dhammas, shows them after dividing them in that way, even a single dhamma.

original: ñatvā tadanurūpaṃ ekampi dhammaṃ tathā vibhajitvā bhagavā dasseti. Tīhi koṭṭhāsehīti
analyzed: ñatvā tad anurūpam ekam pi dhammam tathā vibhajitvā bhagavā dasseti tīhi koṭṭhāsehi iti
translated: By the three sections: by the sections on cultivation, development, and attention.

original: āsevanābhāvanāmanasikārabhāgehi. Mettā hi sabbavatthuno mettāyanavasena ānītā sevanā
analyzed: āsevanā bhāvanā manasikāra bhāgehi mettā hi sabba vatthunaḥ mettāyana vasena ānītā sevanā
translated: For loving-kindness, which is brought in by the word “loving-kindness” in the phrase “one should cultivate loving-kindness,” is the cultivation.

original: āsevanā, tassā vaḍḍhanā bhāvanā, avissajjetvā manasi ṭhapanaṃ manasikāro.
analyzed: āsevanā tassāḥ vaḍḍhanā bhāvanā a vissajjetvā manasi ṭhapanam manasikāraḥ
translated: Its increase is the development. The fixing of the mind without letting it go is attention.

original: 56. Chaṭṭhe aniyamitavacanaṃ “ime nāmā”ti niyametvā avuttattā. Niyamitavacanaṃ “akusalā”ti
analyzed: chaṭṭhe a niyamita vacanam ime nāma ati niyametvā a vutta ttā niyamita vacanam akusalā ti
translated: In the sixth, the expression is not restricted, since it is not stated by restricting it to “these” . The expression is restricted in the seventh, since it is stated by restricting it to “unprofitable” .

original: sarūpeneva vuttattā. Asesato pariyādinnā honti appakassapi akusalabhāgassa aggahitassa
analyzed: sarūpena iva vutta ttā asesataḥ pariyādinnāḥ honti appakassa api akusala bhāgassa aggahitassa
translated: They are completely exhausted, since there is no unprofitable part left out, not even a little.

original: abhāvato. Akusalaṃ bhajantīti akusalabhāgiyā. Akusalapakkhe bhavāti akusalapakkhikā.🔽Tenāha – “akusalāyevā”tiādi. Paṭhamataraṃ gacchatīti paṭhamataraṃ pavattati, paṭhamo🔽padhāno hutvā vattatīti attho. Ekuppādādivasena hi ekajjhaṃ pavattamānesu catūsu🔽arūpakkhandhesu ayameva paṭhamaṃ uppajjatīti idaṃ natthi, lokuttaramaggesu viya pana
analyzed: abhāvataḥ akusalam bhajanti iti akusala bhāgiyāḥ akusala pakkhe bhavāti akusala pakkhikā  tena āha akusalāya iva atiādi paṭhamataram gacchati iti paṭhamataram pavattati  padhānaḥ hutvā vattati iti atthaḥ ekuppāda ādi vasena hi ekajjham pavattamānesu catūsu  arūpa khandhesu ayam eva paṭhamam uppajjati iti idam natthi lokuttara maggesu viya pana
translated: They belong with the unprofitable, thus they are belonging-with-the- unprofitable. They exist in the unprofitable side, thus they are on the unprofitable side.

original: paññindriyassa, lokiyadhammesu manindriyassa puretarassa bhāvo sātisayoti “sabbete
analyzed: paññindriyassa lokiya dhammesu manindriyassa puretarassa bhāvo sa atisayaḥ ti sabbe ete
translated: Hence he said, “They are only unprofitable” , etc. It goes first, thus it occurs first; it goes as the chief, is the meaning. For when the four immaterial aggregates occur together by arising together, etc., there is no question of this being the first to arise, as there is in the case of the supramundane paths. But the state of the mind faculty as the most prominent is more than that, since it is said, “All states are preceded by mind” .

original: manopubbaṅgamā”ti vuttaṃ. Tathā hi abhidhammepi “yasmiṃ samaye kāmāvacaraṃ kusalaṃ
analyzed: manaḥ pubbaṅgamā ti vuttam tathā hi abhidhamme pi yasmin samaye kāmāvacaram kusalam
translated: For in the Abhidhamma too it is said: “When profitable consciousness of the sense sphere has arisen …

original: cittaṃ uppannaṃ hotī”ti cittaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ jeṭṭhaṃ katvā desanā pavattā. Suttesupi
analyzed: cittam uppannam hoti iti cittam pubbaṅgamam jeṭṭham katvā desanā pavattā suttesu pi
translated: The teaching is given with the mind as the forerunner and leader.🔽And in the Suttas it is said: “Ideas have mind as their forerunner, Mind is their chief, and they are mind-made” .

original: vuttaṃ – “manopubbaṅgamā dhammā, chadvārādhipati rājā”ti. Tenāha – “ete hī”tiādi.
analyzed: vuttam manaḥ pubbaṅgamāḥ dhammāḥ cha dvāra adhipati rājā ati tena āha ete hi itiādi
translated: That is why he said “These, however, … ” .

original: Tesaṃ mano uppādakoti ca yadaggena mano sampayuttadhammānaṃ jeṭṭhako hutvā pavattati,
analyzed: tesam manaḥ uppādako ti ca yad aggena manaḥ sampayutta dhammānam jeṭṭhakaḥ hutvā pavattati
translated: And the mind is their producer in the sense that it occurs as the senior partner of the ideas associated with it,

original: tadaggena te attānaṃ anuvattāpento te tathā uppādento nāma hotīti katvā vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ🔽pana cittassa jeṭṭhakabhāvameva sandhāya rājagamanaññāyena sahuppattipi paṭhamuppatti
analyzed: tad aggena te attānam anuvattāpento te tathā uppādento nāma hoti iti katvā vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam  pana cittassa jeṭṭhaka bhāvam eva sandhāya rāja gamana ñāyena paṭhama uppatti
translated: and it is called their producer in the sense that it makes them occur by following after itself.🔽But in the Commentary the meaning shown is this: that the co-arising is like the first arising, as in the case of going to the capital city, taking into account only the mind’s senior status.

original: viya katvā vuttāti ayamattho dassito. Anvadevāti eteneva cittassa khaṇavasena paṭhamuppattiyā
analyzed: viya katvā vuttā ati ayam attho dassito etena iva cittassa khaṇa vasena paṭhama uppattiyā
translated: And the meaning of “in its wake” should be regarded as showing that there is no first arising of the mind in the sense of a moment.

original: abhāvo dīpitoti daṭṭhabbo. Tenevāha – “ekatoyevāti attho”ti.
analyzed: abhāvaḥ dīpito ti daṭṭhabbo tena iva āha ekatoyā iva ati attho ti
translated: That is why he said “the meaning is that they are all together” .

original: 57. Sattame catubhūmakāpi kusalā dhammā kathitāti “ye keci kusalā dhammā”ti anavasesapariyādānato vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sattame catu bhūmakā api kusalā dhammā kathitā ati ye keci kusalā dhammā ti anavasesa pariyādānataḥ vuttam
translated: In the seventh case the profitable ideas in the four planes are referred to by the words “whatever profitable ideas there are” because they are stated without remainder.

original: 58. Aṭṭhame idanti liṅgavipallāsena niddeso, nipātapadaṃ vā etaṃ “yadida”ntiādīsu
analyzed: aṭṭhame idam ti liṅga vipallāsena niddesaḥ nipāta padam vā etam yat idam ti ādīsu
translated: “In the eighth” : the demonstrative pronoun “this” is used in the sense of a neuter noun. Or it is a particle.🔽“The meaning is: this is negligence” .

original: viyāti āha – “ayaṃ pamādoti attho”ti. Pamajjanākāroti pamādāpatti. Cittassa vossaggoti
analyzed: viyā ti āha ayam pamādaḥ ti attho ti pamajjana ākāraḥ ti pamāda āpatti cittassa vossaggaḥ
translated: “The way of negligence” : the occurrence of negligence.

original: imesu ettakesu ṭhānesu satiyā aniggaṇhitvā cittassa vossajjanaṃ sativiraho. Vossaggānuppadānanti🔽vossaggassa anu anu padānaṃ punappunaṃ vissajjanaṃ. Asakkaccakiriyatāti etesaṃ dānādīnaṃ
analyzed: imesu ettakesu ṭhānesu satiyāḥ a niggaṇhitvā cittassa vossajjanam sati virahaḥ vossagga anuppadānam ti  vossaggassa anu anu padānam punappunam vissajjanam etesam dāna ādīnam
translated: “The giving up of the mind” : the giving up of the mind without being guarded by mindfulness in these eight places.🔽“The non-performance of giving up” : the non-performance of giving up again and again.

original: kusaladhammānaṃ pavattane puggalassa vā deyyadhammassa vā asakkaccakiriyā. Satatabhāvo
analyzed: kusala dhammānam pavattane puggalassa vā deyya dhammassa vā asakkacca kiriyā satata bhāvaḥ
translated: “The non-performance of the duties” : the non-performance of the duties of the person or the gift in the practice of the wholesome states of giving, etc.🔽“The state of being constant” : the state of being constant.

original: sātaccaṃ, sātaccena kiriyā sātaccakiriyā, sāyeva sātaccakiriyatā, na sātaccakiriyatā🔽asātaccakiriyatā. Anaṭṭhitakiriyatāti aniṭṭhitakiriyatā nirantaraṃ na anuṭṭhitakiriyatā
analyzed: sātaccam sātaccena kiriyā sātacca kiriyā sāyā iva sātacca kiriya tā na sātacca kiriya tā  asātacca kiriya tā an aṭṭhita kiriya tā ati aniṭṭhita kiriya tā nirantaram na anuṭṭhita kiriya tā
translated: “The performance of the state of being constant” : the performance by means of the state of being constant.🔽“The non-performance of the state of being constant” : the non-performance of the state of being constant.🔽“The non-performance of the duties” : the non-performance of the duties.

original: ca. Olīnavuttitāti nirantarakaraṇasaṅkhātassa vipphārassa abhāvena olīnavuttitā.
analyzed: ca olīna vutti tā ti nirantara karaṇa saṅkhātassa vipphārassa abhāvena olīna vutti tā
translated: “The state of being sluggish” : the state of being sluggish by reason of the absence of the spreading out called “continuity.”

analyzed: nikkhitta chanda tā ati kusala kiriyāya vīriya chandassa nikkhitta bhāvaḥ nikkhitta dhura tā ati
translated: ‘His zeal is slack’ means that his zeal for wholesome action is slack. ‘His energy is low’ means that his energy for wholesome action is low.

original: vīriyadhurassa oropanaṃ, osakkitamānasatāti attho. Anadhiṭṭhānanti kusalakaraṇe appatiṭṭhitabhāvo.🔽Ananuyogoti ananuyuñjanaṃ. Kusaladhammesu āsevanādīnaṃ abhāvo anāsevanādayo. Pamādoti
analyzed: vīriya dhurassa oropanam osakkita mānasa tā ti attho anadhiṭṭhānam ti kusala karaṇe appatiṭṭhita bhāvaḥ  ananuyogaḥ iti ananuyuñjanam kusala dhammesu āsevana ādīnam abhāvaḥ anāsevana ādayo pamādaḥ ti
translated: ‘His zeal is cast down’ means that his zeal for profitable action is cast down. ‘His energy is cast down’ means that his energy is lowered, his mind is slack, is the meaning. ‘He is not resolved’ means that he is not established in doing the profitable.

original: sarūpaniddeso. Pamajjanāti ākāraniddeso. Pamajjitattanti bhāvaniddeso. Parihāyantīti🔽iminā pamādassa sāvajjataṃ dasseti. Tayidaṃ lokiyānaṃ vasena, na lokuttarānanti āha

translated: ‘He does not exert himself’ means that he does not apply himself. ‘He does not practice’ is the absence of repetition, etc., in profitable ideas. ‘Negligence’ is stated by its own individual essence. ‘He is negligent’ is stated by its mode. ‘He has been negligent’ is stated by its state. ‘He falls away’

original: – “uppannā…pe… ida”ntiādi.🔽59. Navame na pamajjati etenāti appamādo, pamādassa paṭipakkho satiyā avippavāso.

This is in the sense of the mundane, not in the sense of the supramundane, so he said ‘When he has arisen … and so on.🔽In the ninth case ‘he is not negligent with that’ is ‘conscientiousness’ , which is the opposite of negligence, and it is non-separation from mindfulness.

original: Atthato niccaṃ upaṭṭhitāya satiyā etaṃ nāmaṃ. Pamādo pana satiyā satisampajaññassa
analyzed: atthataḥ niccam upaṭṭhitāya satiyā etam nāmam pamādaḥ pana satiyā sati sampajaññassa
translated: In the sense of ‘mindfulness constantly established’ this is a name for that. But negligence is the opposite of mindfulness, of being mindful and fully aware,

analyzed: vā paṭipakkha bhūtaḥ akusala cittuppādaḥ daṭṭhabbo tena āha pamādassa paṭipakkha vasena

analyzed: vitthārataḥ veditabbā uti
translated: or the unprofitable consciousness that is its opposite should be regarded. Hence it was said above: “It should be understood in detail as the opposite of negligence.”

original: 60. Dasame kucchitaṃ sīdatīti kusīto da-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā, tassa bhāvo kosajjaṃ, ālasiyanti attho.
analyzed: dasame kucchitam sīdati iti kusītaḥ dakārassa takāram katvā tassa bhāvaḥ kosajjam ālasiyanti attho
translated: In the tenth, he is slack, thus he is indolent (kosajja); the syllable ta of the syllable ta is made ta, and its state is indolence (kosajja), the meaning of which is idleness.

analyzed: accharā saṅghāta vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  vīriya ārambha ādi vagga vaṇṇanā  sattamassa paṭhame vīrānam kammanti vīriyam vidhinā vā īrayitabbam pavattetabbam ti  vīriyam tat eva kusala kiriyāya padhāna ṭṭhena ārambhaḥ vīriya ārambhaḥ āraddha vīriya tā
translated: The commentary on the “Blistering” chapter is finished.🔽The chapter on the beginning of energy, etc.

analyzed: paggahita vīriya tā paripuṇṇa vīriya tā ti paccekam vīriya tā saddaḥ yojetabbo  dutiye mahatī icchā etassa ati mahicchaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ mahiccha tā mahā visayaḥ lobho
translated: The first of the seventh: Energy is the work of the energetic (vīra); or it is to be sent forth (īrayita) by means of a method , thus it is energy (vīriya). That itself is the beginning of energy (vīriyārambha) in the sense of exertion for profitable action. The word energy (vīriya) should be construed in each case as follows: the state of one who has begun energy, the state of one who has taken hold of energy, the state of one who has fulfilled energy.

original: mahālobho mahantānaṃ vatthūnaṃ bahūnañca abhigijjhanato. Itarītarātiādinā pabbajitānaṃ
analyzed: mahā lobhaḥ mahantānam vatthūnam bahūnam ca abhigijjhanataḥ itarītarāti ādinā pabbajitānam
translated: In the second, he has great desire, thus he is greedy (mahiccho); its state is greediness (mahicchatā). Greed with a great scope is great greed (mahālobho) because of its great objects and because of its great abundance. The word “other” , etc., is said

original: uppajjanamahicchatā vuttā. Pañcahi kāmaguṇehītiādi gahaṭṭhānaṃ vasena vuttaṃ. Icchāti
analyzed: uppajjana mahiccha tā vuttā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi itiādi gaha ṭṭhānam vasena vuttam icchā ati
translated: The word “great” is said to be used in the sense of “arising” . The words “with the five strands of sense pleasure” are said with reference to householders. The word “desire” is

translated: greed, it is said: “greed, being greedy” .

analyzed: tatiye appicchassa ati ettha appa saddaḥ abhāva atthaḥ appa ābādhaḥ hoti appa ātaṅkaḥ ti ādīsu  viya iti āha anicchassa ati loke pākaṭassa hi akkhi roga kucchi roga ādi bhedassa ābādhassa  abhāvam sandhāya appa ābādho ti vuttam idāni vuttam eva attham pākaṭataram kātum ettha

analyzed: hi itiādi vuttam byañjanam sa avasesam viya parittake pi appa saddassa dissamāna ttā
translated: Therefore it is said: “of one with little desire” . original: Attho pana niravaseso sabbaso paccayicchāya abhāvassa adhippetattā. Tenāha – “na hī”tiādi.
analyzed: atthaḥ pana niravasesaḥ sabbaso paccayicchāya abhāvassa adhippeta ttā tena āha na hi itiādi
translated: But the meaning is quite complete, because the absence of desire for all conditions is intended. Therefore it is said: “for there is no” , etc.

original: Icchāya abhāveneva appiccho nāma hotīti imamatthaṃ pakārantarena dīpetuṃ – “apicā”tiādi

translated: It is by the absence of desire that one is called “little-desired.” To illustrate this meaning in another way, the Exalted One said, “Moreover, a bhikkhu is not desirous of gain, honour, and fame, and he does not yearn for these things.”

original: vuttaṃ. Atricchatā nāma atra atra icchā. Asantaguṇasambhāvanatāya pāpā lāmikā nihīnā🔽icchā pāpicchatā. Yāya paccayuppādanatthaṃ attani vijjamānaguṇe sambhāveti, paccayānaṃ
analyzed: vuttam atricchatā nāma atra atra icchā asanta guṇa sambhāvanatāya pāpā lāmikā nihīnā  icchā pāpa icchā tā yāya paccaya uppādana ttham attani vijjamāna guṇe sambhāveti paccayānam
translated: Here “desire” is the desire for this and that. “Evil desires” are low, vulgar, coarse, ignoble, and unworthy desires.

original: paṭiggahaṇe ca na mattaṃ jānāti, ayaṃ mahicchatā. Asantaguṇasambhāvanatāti attani
analyzed: paṭiggahaṇe ca na mattam jānāti ayam mahiccha tā asanta guṇa sambhāvana tā ati
translated: “Great desires” are the desire to obtain requisites for oneself by praising one’s own good qualities and by not knowing moderation in accepting requisites.

original: avijjamānānaṃ guṇānaṃ vijjamānānaṃ viya paresaṃ pakāsanā. Santaguṇasambhāvanatāti
analyzed: a vijjamānānam guṇānam vijjamānānam viya paresam pakāsanā santa guṇa sambhāvana tā ati
translated: “The praise of non-existent good qualities” is the proclamation to others of qualities that one does not possess.

original: icchācāre ṭhatvā attani vijjamānasīladhutadhammādiguṇavibhāvanā. Tādisassapi paṭiggahaṇe
analyzed: icchā ācāre vijjamāna sīla dhuta dhamma ādi guṇa vibhāvanā tādisassa api paṭiggahaṇe
translated: “The praise of existent good qualities” is the proclamation of one’s own good qualities such as virtue, ascetic practices, etc., that one does possess, while standing on the plane of desire.

original: amattaññutāpi hoti, sāpi abhidhamme āgatāyevāti sambandho. Dussantappayoti duttappayo.
analyzed: amattaññu tā api hoti sā api abhidhamme āgatāya iva ati sambandhaḥ dussantappayo ti duttappayo
translated: Even one who is such does not know moderation in accepting requisites. This is also mentioned in the Abhidhamma.

translated: “Difficult to support” means difficult to maintain. “Great hardship” means great difficulty in regard to the bowl and robes. Having seen this, people think,

analyzed: amaṅgala divasaḥ sumbhaka siniddha patta cīvaraḥ ayyo pubbaṅgamo kātabbo iti cintetvā
translated: “Today is an inauspicious day. Let the venerable one go first.”🔽“Venerable sir, please go outside for a while.”

original: “bhante, thokaṃ bahi hothā”ti āhaṃsu. Ummujjīti manussānaṃ ajānantānaṃyeva pathaviyaṃ
analyzed: bhante thokam bahi hotha ati āhaṃsu ummujjī iti manussānam a jānantānam yeva pathaviyam
translated: He rose up from the earth without the people knowing.

original: nimujjitvā gaṇhantoyeva ummujji. Yadi thero “khīṇāsavabhāvaṃ jānantū”ti iccheyya,
analyzed: nimujjitvā yadi theraḥ khīṇāsava bhāvam jānantu iti iccheyya
translated: If the Elder wished to make them know his state of being an Arahant,

analyzed: na nam manussāḥ bahi hotha ati vadeyyum khīṇa āsavānam pana tathā cittam eva na uppajjeyya  appiccha tā apadhānam puggala adhiṭṭhānam catubbidha aicchā apabhedam dassetvā puna api puggala adhiṭṭhānena
translated: the people would not have said, “Go outside.” But the thought of going outside did not occur to the Arahants.🔽Having shown the four kinds of desire by way of the person in the context of the practice of fewness of wishes, he now shows the four kinds of desire by way of the person in the context of the practice of contentment.

original: catubbidhaṃ icchābhedaṃ dassento “aparopi catubbidho appiccho”tiādimāha. Paccayaappicchoti
analyzed: catubbidham icchā bhedam dassentaḥ aparaḥ api catubbidhaḥ appiccha iti ādim āha paccaya appiccho ti
translated: “Another is of four kinds as to fewness of wishes”:🔽he is free from desire for requisites.🔽He is free from desire for the ascetic practices through esteeming them.

original: paccayesu icchārahito. Dhutaṅgaappicchoti dhutaguṇasambhāvanāya icchārahito. Pariyattiappicchoti
analyzed: paccayesu icchā rahitaḥ dhuta aṅga appiccho ti dhuta guṇa sambhāvanāya icchā rahitaḥ pariyatti appiccho ti
translated: He is free from desire for learning through esteeming it.

original: bahussutasambhāvanāya icchārahito. Adhigamaappicchoti “ariyo”ti sambhāvanāya icchārahito.🔽Dāyakassa vasanti appaṃ vā yaṃ dātukāmo bahuṃ vāti dāyakassa cittassa vasaṃ, ajjhāsayanti
analyzed: bahussuta sambhāvanāyai icchā rahitaḥ adhigama appiccho ti ariyaḥ ti sambhāvanāyai icchā rahitaḥ  dāyakassa vasanti appam vā yam dātu kāmo bahum vā ati dāyakassa cittassa vasam ajjhāsayanti
translated: He is free from desire for the respect of being considered learned. He is free from desire for the respect of being considered a noble one.

original: attho. Deyyadhammassa vasanti deyyadhammassa abahubhāvaṃ. Attano thāmanti attano🔽pamāṇaṃ. Yattakena attā yāpeti, tattakasseva gahaṇaṃ. Yadi hītiādi saṅkhepato vuttassa
analyzed: atthaḥ deyya dhammassa vasanti deyya dhammassa a bahu bhāvam attano attano  pamāṇam yattakena attā tattakassa iva gahaṇam yadi hi itiādi saṅkhepataḥ vuttassa
translated: He is under the control of the giver: he is under the control of the giver’s mind as to whether he gives little or much. He is under the control of the gift: he is under the control of the paucity of the gift. He is under the control of himself: he is under the control of his own measure. He takes only what is enough to maintain himself.

original: atthassa vivaraṇaṃ. Pamāṇenevāti yāpanappamāṇeneva.
analyzed: atthassa vivaraṇam pamāṇena iva ati yāpana pamāṇena iva
translated: If he were to take more than that, etc. is a detailed explanation of what was said in brief in the phrase “he is under the control of himself.” He is under the control of his measure: he is under the control of the measure of what is enough to maintain himself.

original: Ekabhikkhupi nāññāsīti sosānikavatte sammadeva vattitattā ekopi bhikkhu na aññāsi.🔽Abbokiṇṇanti avicchedaṃ. Dutiyo maṃ jāneyyāti dutiyo sahāyabhūtopi yathā maṃ jānituṃ
analyzed: eka bhikkhu api na aññāsi iti sosānika vatte sammat eva vattita ttā ekaḥ api bhikkhu na aññāsi  a vicchedam dutiyaḥ mam jāneyya iti dutiyaḥ sahāya bhūtaḥ api yathā mama jānitum
translated: Not even a single bhikkhu knew: because he was perfectly secluded in his practice of the charnel-ground dweller’s practice, not even a single bhikkhu knew .

original: na sakkuṇeyya, tathā saṭṭhi vassāni nirantaraṃ susāne vasāmi, tasmā ahaṃ aho sosānikuttamo.
analyzed: na tathā vassāni nirantaram susāne vasāmi tasmai aham aho sosānika uttamaḥ
translated: Without interruption: without a break. Let no second know me: let no second person, even a companion, know me in such a way that he could say, “So-and-so lives in the charnel ground.” I live in the charnel ground continuously for sixty years without interruption. Therefore I am the foremost of charnel-ground dwellers.

original: Upakāro hutvāti uggahaparipucchādīhi pariyattidhammavasena upakāro hutvā. Dhammakathāya
analyzed: upakāraḥ hutvā iti uggaha paripuccha ādīhi pariyatti dhamma vasena upakāraḥ hutvā dhammakathāya

translated: By way of fewness of wishes regarding the scriptures.

analyzed: ime tayo kula puttāḥ etesu pi hi anuruddha ttherena bhagavatā atthi pana vaḥ anuruddhā

translated: “So it is, friends, for those who are heedful, ardent, and resolute.”🔽When this was said, the elder bhikkhus replied: “Here, friend, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, we enter upon and abide in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

original: kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ🔽jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmā”tiādinā anupubbavihārasamāpattīsu ārocitāsu itare therā

translated: We have attained this comfortable abiding here and now that the Blessed One has announced.”🔽The other elder bhikkhus did not want to claim the jhanas.

analyzed: na tathā hi te pakkante bhagavati āyasmantam anuruddham etat avocum kinnu  mayam āyasmataḥ anuruddhassa evam ārocimha imāsam ca imāsam ca vihāra samāpattīnam mayam

analyzed: yam naḥ āyasmai anuruddhaḥ bhagavataḥ sammukhā api āsavānam khayam pakāseti iti

original: Ghaṭīkāropi attano ariyabhāve kikissa rañño bhagavatā ārocite na attamano ahosi?
analyzed: ghaṭīkāraḥ api attanaḥ ariya bhāve kikissa raññaḥ bhagavatā ārocite na atta manaḥ ahosi
translated: And was not the venerable Ghatikara displeased when the Blessed One announced his noble qualities in the presence of King Pasenadi?

original: Tenāha – “ghaṭīkārakumbhakāro viyā”ti. Imasmiṃ panattheti “yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave,
analyzed: tena āha ghaṭīkāra kumbhakāraḥ viyāti imasmin pana attha iti yathayidam bhikkhave

original: appicchatā”ti vutte appicchatāsaṅkhāte atthe. Balavaalobhenāti daḷhatarappavattikena alobhena.
analyzed: appicchatā iti vutte appiccha tā saṅkhāte atthe balava alobhena ati daḷhatara ppavattikena alobhena
translated: With strong greed: with greed that occurs in a strong form.

original: 64. Catutthe natthi etassa santuṭṭhīti asantuṭṭhi, tassa bhāvo asantuṭṭhitā. Taṃ pana sarūpato dassento “asantuṭṭhe puggale…pe… lobho”ti āha. Sevantassātiādīni aññamaññavevacanāni.
analyzed: catutthe na atthi etassa santuṭṭhi iti asantuṭṭhi tassa bhāvaḥ asantuṭṭhi tā tam pana sarūpataḥ dassentaḥ asantuṭṭhe puggala īpe lobho ti āha sevantassa atiādīni aññamañña vevacanāni
translated: In the fourth, he has no contentment, thus he is discontented; the state of that is discontentment. But showing it in its individual essence he said: “In a discontented person … greed” . “One who serves” , etc., are synonyms.

original: 65-67. Pañcame tussanaṃ tuṭṭhi, samaṃ, sakena, santena vā tuṭṭhi etassāti santuṭṭhi,
analyzed: pañcame tussanam tuṭṭhi samam sakena santena vā tuṭṭhi etassa ati santuṭṭhi
translated: In the fifth, satisfaction is contentment; he is content with what is proper, with what is his own, with what is enough, thus he is content;

original: tassa bhāvo santuṭṭhitā. Yassa santosassa atthitāya bhikkhu “santuṭṭho”ti vuccati,🔽taṃ dassento “itarītarapaccayasantosena samannāgatassā”ti āha – cīvarādike yattha
analyzed: tassa bhāvaḥ santuṭṭhi tā yassa santosassa atthi tāya bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ ti vuccati  tam dassento itarītara paccaya santosena samannāgatassa iti āha cīvara ādike yattha
translated: the state of that is contentment. He is called “content” because he has the kind of satisfaction that is called “contentment” .

original: katthaci kappiye paccaye santussanena samaṅgībhūtassāti attho. Atha vā itaraṃ vuccati
analyzed: katthaci kappiye paccaye santussanena samaṅgībhūtassa ati atthaḥ atha vā itaram vuccati
translated: Showing that he said: “Endowed with satisfaction with any kind of requisite” . The meaning is: he is endowed with satisfaction with any kind of requisite, such as robes, etc., that is allowable. Or alternatively, what is other is called “another” .

original: hīnaṃ paṇītato aññattā, tathā paṇītampi itaraṃ hīnato aññattā. Apekkhāsiddhā hi itaratā.
analyzed: hīnam paṇītataḥ aññattā tathā paṇītam pi itaram hīnataḥ aññattā apekkhā siddhā hi itaratā
translated: Inferior to superior, and vice versa, because the otherness of the inferior and the superior is established by comparison.

original: Iti yena dhammena hīnena vā paṇītena vā cīvarādipaccayena santussati, so tathā pavatto
analyzed: iti yena dhammena hīnena vā paṇītena vā cīvara ādi paccayena santussati saḥ tathā pavatto
translated: So when a bhikkhu is satisfied with any kind of requisite, whether inferior or superior,

original: alobho itarītarapaccayasantoso, tena samannāgatassa. Yathālābhaṃ attano lābhānurūpaṃ🔽santoso yathālābhasantoso. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Labbhatīti vā lābho, yo yo
analyzed: alobho itarītara paccaya santoso tena samannāgatassa yathālābham attanaḥ lābha anurūpam  santosaḥ yathā lābha santosaḥ sesa pada dvaye pi esā iva nayaḥ labbhati iti vā lābhaḥ yaḥ yaḥ
translated: that is non-greed. He who possesses that is “content with any kind of requisite.”🔽Satisfaction with what is obtained is satisfaction with what one has got according to one’s chance. The same method of explanation applies to the other two terms.🔽Or alternatively, what is obtained is what is got; what is got according to one’s chance is what is obtained; satisfaction with that is satisfaction with what is obtained.

original: lābho yathālābho, tena santoso yathālābhasantoso. Balanti kāyabalaṃ. Sāruppanti bhikkhuno anucchavikatā.🔽Yathāladdhato aññassa apatthanā nāma siyā appicchatāpi pavattiākāroti tato vinivecitameva
analyzed: lābhaḥ yathālābhaḥ tena santosaḥ yathālābha santosaḥ balanti kāya balam sāruppanti bhikkhuno anucchavika tā  yathā laddhataḥ aññassa apatthanā nāma siyā appiccha tā api tatas vinivecitam eva
translated: Strength is bodily strength. Suitability is what is suitable for a bhikkhu.🔽Not aspiring for more is non-greed. The words “he does not hope for more” show the nature of satisfaction.

original: santosassa sarūpaṃ dassento “labhantopi na gaṇhātī”ti āha. Taṃ parivattetvā pakatidubbalādīnaṃ
analyzed: santosassa sarūpam dassentaḥ labhantaḥ api na gaṇhāti iti āha tam parivattetvā pakati dubbala ādīnam
translated: He does not take what is not given is said in order to show the nature of non-greed. That is, he does not take what is not given to him by the owners, whether in the way of requisites or anything else, by theft or by cheating or by force. He does not take what is not given to him by the owners, whether in the way of requisites or anything else, by theft or by cheating or by force.

original: garucīvaraṃ aphāsubhāvāvahaṃ sarīrakhedāvahañca hotīti payojanavasena na atricchatādivasena
analyzed: garu cīvaram a phāsu bhāva āvaham sarīra kheda āvaham ca hoti iti payojana vasena na

analyzed: tam parivattetvā lahuka cīvara paribhogaḥ santosa virodhi na hoti iti āha  lahukena yāpentaḥ api

analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti iti mahaggha cīvaram bahūni vā cīvarāni labhitvā tāni vissajjetvā  tad aññassa gahaṇam yathā sāruppa naye ṭhita ttā na santosa virodhi iti āha
translated: and he is not discontented because he is not opposed to using a valuable robe or many robes, since he gives them away and uses what he gets in exchange.🔽That is why he is “content with any old alms food,” etc.,🔽and he is not discontented because he is not opposed to using a valuable bowl or many bowls, since he gives them away and uses what he gets in exchange.🔽That is why he is “content with any old bowl,” etc.,

analyzed: dhārentaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ va hoti iti evam sesa paccayesu pi yathā sāruppa niddese api sadda ggahaṇe

translated: and he is not discontented because he is not opposed to using a valuable resting place or many resting places, since he gives them away and uses what he gets in exchange.🔽That is why he is “content with any old resting place.”🔽The meaning of the word “any” should be understood in this way in each case.

original: harītakaṃ. Buddhādīhi vaṇṇitanti appicchatāsantuṭṭhīsu bhikkhū niyojetuṃ “pūtimuttabhesajjaṃ

analyzed: catubbidhānam bojjhaṅgānam bhūmi vibhāga dassanam
translated: There is the showing of the analysis of the plane of the four kinds of enlightenment factors, etc.🔽In the sixth, among those bhikkhus: among those bhikkhus.

analyzed: kathāya atiracchāna kathā bhāvam āhu tathā hi sā pubbe bahu ñātikam ahosi bahu pakkham

analyzed: aṭṭhama ādīsu heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva ati yā esa mama sāsana iti ādinā heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva sesam ettha uttānattham eva
translated: In the eighth and the rest, as in the previous case, means as in the previous case stated in the way beginning, “In my Dispensation there is no such thing as a person who is a monk merely by being called so by others” . The rest here is evident in meaning.

analyzed: kalyāṇamittā ādi vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā

analyzed: bhavam bāhiram vutta paṭipakkha nayena ati avināsāya ati evamādinā atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ  catukkoṭikā iti anuyogaḥ akusalānam ananuyogaḥ kusalānam anuyogaḥ kusalānam ananuyogaḥ

original: 130. Suttantanaye yathācodanā saṃkilesadhammānaṃ vipariyesanaṃ, taṃtaṃdhammakoṭṭhāsānañca

original: Adhigantabbato adhigamo, maggaphalāni. Nibbānaṃ pana antaradhānābhāvato idha na gayhati.🔽Paṭipajjanaṃ paṭipatti, sikkhattayasamāyogo. Paṭipajjitabbato vā paṭipatti. Pariyāpuṇitabbato🔽pariyatti, piṭakattayaṃ. Maggaggahaṇena gahitāpi tatiyavijjāchaṭṭhābhiññā vijjābhiññāsāmaññato
analyzed: adhigantabbataḥ adhigamaḥ magga phalāni nibbānam pana antaradhāna abhāvataḥ idha na gayhati  paṭipajjanam paṭipatti sikkhattaya samāyogaḥ paṭipajjitabbataḥ vā paṭipatti pariyāpuṇitabbataḥ  pariya tti magga ggahaṇena gahitā api tatiya vijjā chaṭṭha abhiññā vijjā abhiññā sāmaññato
translated: Attainment is the path and fruition. But Nibbāna is not mentioned here because it is not something to be attained.🔽Practice is the undertaking of the three trainings. original: “tisso vijjā cha abhiññā”ti punapi gahitā. Tato paraṃ cha abhiññāti vassasahassato

translated: Although the three knowledges and the six kinds of direct knowledge are included by the mention of the path, they are mentioned again as “the three knowledges and the six kinds of direct knowledge” because they are the same as the knowledge of omniscience and the knowledge of supernormal power, etc.🔽The intention is that after a thousand years only the six kinds of direct knowledge can be produced, not the analytical knowledges.

original: paraṃ cha abhiññā nibbattetuṃ sakkonti, na paṭisambhidāti adhippāyo. Tatoti abhiññākālato
analyzed: param cha abhiññāḥ nibbattetum sakkonti na paṭisambhidā ati adhippāyo tatas ti abhiññā kālato
translated: After that: after the direct knowledges.

original: pacchā. Tāti abhiññāyo. Pubbabhāge jhānasinehābhāvena kevalāya vipassanāya ṭhatvā

analyzed: vattabbaḥ samatha vipassanam yuga naddham bhāveti iti vacanato pacchimakassa āti sabba pacchimassa  kiñca api ariyaḥ a parihāna dhammo sotāpannassa pana uddham jīvita pariyādānā adhigata dhammo

translated: They do not accuse: they do not accuse one another of faults even though they know of them. They do not complain: they do not complain about one another. They are not irate: they do not become angry. They are not contemptuous: they do not despise one another. They do not sneer: they do not sneer at one another. They do not show the door: they do not dismiss one another by saying, “Get out of my sight.” They do not fall into offenses: they do not commit offenses. They do not conceal offenses: they do not conceal offenses they have committed. They do not quarrel: they do not argue. They do not dispute: they do not take sides against one another. They do not become angry: they do not become irritated. They do not become incensed: they do not become inflamed with anger. They do not bear ill will: they do not have an underlying tendency of annoyance. They do not incite one another: they do not incite one another to offenses. They do not revile: they do not revile one another with the word “stick,” etc., as described in the Peṭaka. They do not harass: they do not harass one another by body and speech. They do not give the order: they do not give the order to evict one another from monasteries. They do not give the harangue: they do not give the harangue to one another. They do not give the information: they do not give the information about one another. They do not give the hint: they do not give the hint to one another. They do not give the sign: they do not give the sign to one another. They do not give the order to evict: they do not give the order to evict one another from monasteries. They do not accuse: they do not accuse one another of faults even though they know of them. They do not complain: they do not complain about one another. They

original: bāhullavasena vuttaṃ. Antimavatthuanajjhāpannesu katipayamattesupi bhikkhūsu dharantesu,
analyzed: bāhulla vasena vuttam antima vatthu anajjhāpannesu katipaya mattesu pi bhikkhūsu dharantesu
translated: and it is said in the plural because of the abundance.

original: ekasmiṃ vā dharante paṭipatti anantarahitā eva nāma hoti. Tenevāha – “pacchimakassa…pe… antarahitā hotī”ti.🔽Antevāsike gahetunti antevāsike saṅgahetuṃ. Atthavasenāti aṭṭhakathāvasena. Matthakato
analyzed: ekasmin vā dharante paṭipatti anantarahitā eva nāma hoti tena iva āha pacchima kassape antarahitā hoti iti  antevāsike gahetum ti antevāsike saṅgahetum attha vasena ati aṭṭhakathā vasena matthakato
translated: When there are two or three bhikkhus left, or even when there is only one, the practice is not interrupted. original: paṭṭhāyāti uparito paṭṭhāya. Uposathakkhandhakamattanti vinayamātikāpāḷimāha. Āḷavakapañhādīnaṃ

translated: “The practice of the texts among the gods is immeasurable”: he says “among men” because the practice of the texts among the gods is immeasurable, like the questions of Āḷavaka, etc.🔽“Wearing a strip of reddish-brown cloth”: the reddish-brown of the reddish-brown cloth is the color of the tusk of an elephant. original: kese bandhantā allīyāpenti. Bhikkhugottassa abhibhavanato vināsanato gotrabhuno.

original: Tenevāti pariyattiantaradhānamūlakattā eva itaraantaradhānassa. Sakko devarājā chātakabhaye🔽paratīragamanāya bhikkhū ussukkamakāsīti adhippāyo. original: sammutidesanā. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Uppādavayavanto sabhāvadhammā na niccāti
analyzed: sammuti desanā sesa padesu pi esā iva nayo uppāda vayavanto sabhāva dhammā na nicca ati

analyzed: khandha samaññā phassa ādīsu viya paramattha sannissayā tassa āsannatarā

original: puggalasamaññādayo viya na dūreti paramatthasaṅgahā vuttā. Khandhasīsena vā tadupādānasabhāvadhammā🔽eva gahitā. Nanu ca sabhāvadhammā sabbepi sammutimukheneva desanaṃ ārohanti, na samukhenāti

analyzed: puggala adhiṭṭhānā eva katvā dīpetabbā satta santāna visaya ttā aṭṭha purisa puggalā
