analyzed: te purisā samāgata ṭṭhānataḥ magadha raṭṭhe mahātitthagāmam madda raṭṭhe sāgala nagarañca
translated: aiming for Mahātitthagāma in the Magadha country and Sāgalanagara in the Maddaraṭṭha,

original: uddissa apakkamantā aññamaññaṃ vissajjantā nāma hontīti “ito ca etto ca pesesu”nti vuttā.
analyzed: uddissa apakkamantāḥ aññamaññam vissajjantāḥ nāma honti iti itas ca ettas ca pesesunti vuttā
translated: are those who send each other away. Therefore, they are said to be sent from here and there.

original: Pupphadāmanti hatthihatthappamāṇaṃ pupphadāmaṃ. Tānīti tāni ubhohi ganthāpitāni dve
analyzed: puppha dāmanti hatthi hattha ppamāṇam puppha dāmam tāni iti tāni ubhohi ganthāpitāni dve
translated: Pupphadāmanti: a garland of flowers the size of an elephant’s trunk. Tānīti: those two garlands of flowers woven together by both

original: pupphadāmāni. Teti ubho bhaddā ceva pippalikumāro ca. Lokāmisenāti kāmassādena. Asaṃsaṭṭhāti
analyzed: puppha dāmāni te iti ubho bhaddā ca iva pippali kumāro ca loka āmisena ati kāma ssādena asaṃsaṭṭhā ati
translated: of them. Teti: both Bhaddā and Pippali the prince. Lokāmisenāti: by the passion of sensual pleasure. Asaṃsaṭṭhāti

original: na saṃyuttā ghaṭe jalantena viya padīpena ajjhāsaye samujjalantena vimokkhabījena
analyzed: na saṃyuttā ghaṭe jalantena viya padīpena ajjhāsaye samujjalantena vimokkha bījena
translated: He is not associated with them, like a lamp burning in a pot is not associated with the pot, or like a liberation that is burning in his heart is not associated with his heart.

original: samussāhitacittattā. Yantabaddhānīti sassasampādanatthaṃ tattha tattha dvārakavāṭayojanavasena🔽baddhāni nikkhamanatumbāni. Kammantoti kasikammakaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ. Dāsikagāmāti dāsānaṃ
analyzed: samussāhita citta ttā yanta baddhāni iti sassa sampādana ttham tattha tattha dvāra kavāṭa yojana vasena  baddhāni nikkhamana tumbāni kammanto ti kasi kamma karaṇa ṭhānam dāsikagāmā ti dāsānam
translated: Because his mind is uplifted. “Bound to the fields” : bound to the fields by the construction of gates and fences for the purpose of cultivating the crops.🔽“The village of female slaves” : the village where the female slaves live.

original: vasanagāmā. Osāretvāti pakkhipitvā. Ākappakuttavasenāti ākāravasena kiriyāvasena.
analyzed: vasana gāmā osāretvā āti pakkhipitvā ākappa kutta vasena āti ākāra vasena kiriyā vasena
translated: “Having placed” : having put. “By way of the mode of action” : by way of the mode, by way of the action.

original: Ananucchavikanti pabbajitabhāvassa ananurūpaṃ. Tassa matthaketi dvedhāpathassa dvidhābhūtaṭṭhāne.
analyzed: ananucchavikam ti pabbajita bhāvassa ananurūpam tassa matthake iti dvedhāpathassa dvidhā bhūta ṭṭhāne
translated: “Inappropriate” : not suitable for the state of a monk. “On the head of that” : at the place where the fork in the road occurs.

original: Etesaṃ saṅgahaṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭatīti nisīdatīti sambandho. Sā pana tattha satthu nisajjā
analyzed: etesam saṅgaham kātum vaṭṭati iti nisīdati iti sambandhaḥ sā pana tattha satthu nisajjā
translated: The construction is: “It is proper to sit down in order to gather them together.” But the sitting down of the Exalted One there

original: edisīti dassetuṃ – “nisīdanto panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yā buddhānaṃ aparimitakālasambhūtācinteyyāpariññeyyapuññasambhārūpacayanibbattā
analyzed: edisī iti dassetum nisīdantaḥ pana itiādi vuttam tattha yā buddhānam aparimita kāla sambhūta acinteyya apariññeyya puñña sambhāra upacaya nibbattā
translated: was of this kind. In order to show this, it is said: “When he sat down” and so forth. Therein, the sitting down of the Buddhas is produced by the accumulation of the requisites of merit and knowledge, which are immeasurable, inconceivable, and immeasurable, and which have been accumulated for an immeasurable time.

original: rūpappabhāvabuddhaguṇavijjotitā dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇaasītianubyañjanasamujjalitā
analyzed: rūpa ppabhāva buddha guṇa vijjotitā dvattiṃsa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇa asīti anubyañjana samujjalitā
translated: and with the radiance of his body, the radiance of the Buddha’s special qualities, and the radiance of the thirty-two marks of a great man and the eighty minor characteristics,

original: byāmappabhāketumālālaṅkatā sabhāvasiddhitāya akittimā rūpakāyasirī, taṃyeva mahākassapassa
analyzed: sabhāva siddhitāya akittimā rūpa kāya sirī taṃyeva mahākassapassa
translated: and with the radiance of the crest and garland of the sky, and with the radiance of his natural glory, the glory of his physical body, which is not to be compared with anything else,🔽the Blessed One sat down without hiding it, so that the Venerable Kassapa, who had never seen the Buddha before, might increase his confidence.

original: adiṭṭhapubbappasādasaṃvaddhanatthaṃ aniggūhitvā nisinno bhagavā “buddhavesaṃ gahetvā…pe…
analyzed: a diṭṭha pubba ppasāda saṃvaddha nattham a niggūhitvā nisinnaḥ bhagavā buddha vesam gahetvā āpe
translated: “Take the appearance of a Buddha,” etc., and “sit down” were said to him.🔽The radiance extended for eighty leagues, so it is said to have been eighty leagues.

original: nisīdī”ti vutto. Asītihatthappadesaṃ byāpetvā pavattiyā asītihatthāti vuttā. Satasākhoti
analyzed: nisīdi iti vuttaḥ asīti hattha padesam byāpetvā pavattiyā asīti hatthā ati vuttā sata sākhā iti
translated: The tree had a hundred branches, so it is said to have had a hundred branches.

original: bahusākho anekasākho. Suvaṇṇavaṇṇova ahosi nirantaraṃ buddharasmīhi samantato samokiṇṇabhāvato.
analyzed: bahu sākhaḥ aneka sākhaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ uva ahosi nirantaram buddha rasmīhi samantataḥ samokiṇṇa bhāvataḥ
translated: It was golden-colored, completely covered all around with the Buddha’s radiance, without a break.

original: Tīsu ṭhānesūti dūrato nātidūre āsanneti tīsu ṭhānesu. Tīhi ovādehīti “tasmātiha te,
analyzed: tīsu ṭhānesu uti dūratas na atidūre āsannā iti tīsu ṭhānesu tīhi ovādehi iti tasmāt ati ha te
translated: In three places: not too far, not too near, but in three places.

original: kassapa, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ ‘tibbaṃ me hirottappaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ bhavissati theresu
analyzed: kassapa evam sikkhitabbam tibbam me hirottappam paccupaṭṭhitam bhavissati theresu
translated: With three admonitions: “Therefore, Kassapa, you should train yourself thus: ‘I will maintain a high sense of moral shame and moral dread,🔽toward the elders, the leaders, the chief elders, the venerable ones, the well-known ones, and the famous ones in the various districts.’

original: navesu majjhimesū’ti. Evañhi te, kassapa, sikkhitabbaṃ. Tasmātiha te, kassapa, evaṃ
analyzed: navesu majjhimesu iti evam hi te kassapa sikkhitabbam tasmā ati ha te kassapa evam
translated: “Therefore, Kassapa, you should train yourself:

original: sikkhitabbaṃ ‘yaṃ kiñci dhammaṃ suṇissāmi kusalūpasaṃhitaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ aṭṭhiṃ katvā
analyzed: sikkhitabbam yam kiñci dhammam suṇissāmi kusala upasaṃhitam sabbam tam aṭṭhim katvā
translated: ‘Whatever I hear that is connected with skillful qualities, I will reflect on it with a mind well-concentrated,

original: manasi karitvā sabbaṃ cetasā samannāharitvā ohitasoto dhammaṃ suṇissāmī’ti, evañhi
analyzed: manasi karitvā sabbam cetasā samannāharitvā ohita sotaḥ dhammam suṇissāmi iti evam hi
translated: with all my mind, with a mind that is not distracted by other matters.

original: te, kassapa, sikkhitabbaṃ. Tasmātiha te, kassapa, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ ‘sātasahagatā
analyzed: te kassapa sikkhitabbam tasmā ati ha te kassapa evam sikkhitabbam sāta sahagatā
translated: “Therefore, Kassapa, you should train yourself:🔽‘I will not be without the mindfulness directed to the body that is accompanied with joy.’ Thus should you train yourself.”

original: ca me kāyagatāsati na vijahissatī’ti, evañhi te, kassapa, sikkhitabba”nti imehi tīhi
analyzed: ca me kāya gatā asati na vijahissati iti evam hi te kassapa sikkhitabbanti imehi tīhi
translated: With these three admonishments.

original: ovādehi. Ettha hi bhagavā paṭhamaṃ ovādaṃ therassa brāhmaṇajātikattā jātimānappahānatthamabhāsi,🔽dutiyaṃ bāhusaccaṃ nissāya uppajjanakaahaṃkārappahānatthaṃ, tatiyaṃ upadhisampattiṃ
analyzed: ovādehi ettha hi bhagavā paṭhamam ovādam therassa brāhmaṇa jātikattā jātimān appahāna attham abhāsi  dutiyam bāhusaccam nissāya uppajjanaka ahaṃkāra ppahāna attham tatiyam upadhi sampattim
translated: For the Blessed One gave the elder the first admonishment for the purpose of abandoning pride in his brahmin birth,🔽the second for the purpose of abandoning the conceit “I am,” which arises through the abundance of learning,

original: nissāya uppajjanakaattasinehappahānatthaṃ. Mudukā kho tyāyanti mudukā kho te ayaṃ.
analyzed: nissāya uppajjanaka atta sineha ppahāna attham mudukā kho tyāyanti mudukā kho te ayam
translated: and the third for the purpose of abandoning the affection for the excellence of his material possessions.

original: Kasmā pana bhagavā evamāha? Therena saha cīvaraṃ parivattetukāmatāya. Kasmā parivattetukāmo
analyzed: kasmai pana bhagavā evam āha therena saha cīvaram parivattetu kāma tāya kasmai parivattetu kāmaḥ
translated: Why did the Exalted One say this? Because he wanted to exchange robes with the Elder. Why did he want to exchange robes?

original: jātoti? Theraṃ attano ṭhāne ṭhapetukāmatāya. Kiṃ sāriputtamoggallānā natthīti? Atthi,🔽evaṃ panassa ahosi “imena ciraṃ ṭhassanti, kassapo pana vīsativassasatāyuko, so mayi🔽parinibbute sattapaṇṇiguhāyaṃ vasitvā dhammavinayasaṅgahaṃ katvā mama sāsanaṃ pañcavassasahassaparimāṇakālappavattanakaṃ
analyzed: jātaḥ iti theram attano ṭhāne ṭhapetu kāma tāya kim sāriputta moggallānā natthi iti atthi  evam panassa ahosi imena ciram kassapaḥ pana vīsati vassa sata āyukaḥ saḥ mayi  parinibbute sattapaṇṇiguhāyam vasitvā dhamma vinaya saṅgaham katvā mama sāsanam pañca vassa sahassa parimāṇa kāla ppavattanakam
translated: Because he wanted to place the Elder in his own position. “But,” it may be asked, “were there no other disciples of the Buddha?” There were,🔽but the Exalted One thought to himself, “These two will last long. Kassapa, however, will live for two hundred years. After my parinibbāna, he will live in the Sattapaṇṇiguhā and, having compiled the Dhamma and the Vinaya,

original: karissatīti attano ṭhāne ṭhapesi. Evaṃ bhikkhū kassapassa sussūsitabbaṃ maññissantī”ti. Tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: karissati iti attanaḥ ṭhāne ṭhapesi evam bhikkhū kassapassa sussūsitabbam maññissanti iti tasmai evam āha
translated: he will make my Dispensation last for a period of five thousand years.” Thus he placed him in his own position, thinking, “In this way the bhikkhus will think that they should listen to Kassapa as to me.” This is why the Exalted One said what he did.

original: Candūpamoti candasadiso hutvā. Kiṃ parimaṇḍalatāya? No, apica kho yathā cando gaganatalaṃ
analyzed: candu upamaḥ ti canda sadisaḥ hutvā kim parimaṇḍala tāya no api ca khaḥ yathā candaḥ gagana talam
translated: “Like the moon” means like the moon. Is it because of its roundness? No, but rather because, just as the moon,

original: pakkhandamāno na kenaci saddhiṃ santhavaṃ vā sinehaṃ vā ālayaṃ vā karoti, na ca na
analyzed: pakkhandamānaḥ na kenacid saddhim santhavam vā sineham vā ālayam vā karoti na ca na
translated: when it has risen into the sky, does not make any contact, affection, or attachment to anything, and yet

original: hoti mahājanassa piyo manāpo, ayampi evaṃ kenaci saddhiṃ santhavādīnaṃ akaraṇena
analyzed: hoti mahājanassa piyaḥ manāpaḥ ayam pi evam kenacid saddhim santhava ādīnam a karaṇena
translated: He is dear and beloved to the multitude. This is the meaning: he, too, by not engaging in gossip with anyone,

original: bahujanassa piyo manāpo candūpamo hutvā khattiyakulādīni cattāri kulāni upasaṅkamatīti🔽attho. Apakasseva kāyaṃ apakassa cittanti teneva santhavādīnaṃ akaraṇena kāyañca
analyzed: bahu janassa piyaḥ manāpaḥ canda upamaḥ hutvā khattiya kula ādīni cattāri kulāni upasaṅkamati iti  attho apakassa iva kāyam apakassa cittam ti tena iva santhava ādīnam a karaṇena kāyam ca
translated: becomes like the moon, dear and beloved to the multitude, and he approaches the four families, the khattiya family, etc.🔽By not engaging in gossip, he removes his body and mind. The meaning is that he takes away, he removes his body and mind.

original: cittañca apakaḍḍhitvā, apanetvāti attho. Niccaṃ navoti niccanavakova, āgantukasadiso🔽hutvāti attho. Āgantuko hi paṭipāṭiyā sampattagehaṃ pavisitvā sace naṃ gharasāmikā🔽disvā “amhākampi puttabhātaro vippavāsaṃ gantvā evaṃ vicariṃsū”ti anukampamānā nisīdāpetvā
analyzed: cittam ca apakaḍḍhitvā apanetvā ti attho niccam navaḥ ti nicca navakaḥ uva āgantuka sadiso  hutvā ti atthaḥ āgantukaḥ hi paṭipāṭiyā sampatta geham pavisitvā sace nam ghara sāmikā  disvā amhākam pi putta bhātaraḥ vippavāsam gantvā evam vicariṃsu iti anukampamānāḥ nisīdāpetvā
translated: He is always new. The meaning is that he is like a newcomer.

original: bhojenti, bhuttamattoyeva “tumhākaṃ bhājanaṃ gaṇhathā”ti uṭṭhāya pakkamati, na tehi
analyzed: bhojenti bhutta matta uyā iva tumhākam bhājanam gaṇhatha ati uṭṭhāya pakkamati na tehi
translated: For a newcomer, when he enters the house in turn, if the householders see him, they take pity on him, thinking, “Our sons and brothers, too, have wandered about like this after going away to live abroad,” and they make him sit down and feed him. As soon as he has eaten, he gets up and leaves, saying, “Take away your dish.” He does not engage in gossip with them or make any plans with them.

original: saddhiṃ santhavaṃ vā karoti, kiccakaraṇīyāni vā saṃvidahati, evamayampi paṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: saddhim santhavam vā karoti kicca karaṇīyāni vā saṃvidahati evam ayam pi paṭipāṭiyā
translated: In the same way, he, too, by not engaging in gossip, removes his body and mind.

original: sampattaṃ gharaṃ pavisitvā yaṃ iriyāpathe pasannā manussā denti, taṃ gahetvā chinnasanthavo
analyzed: sampattam gharam pavisitvā yam iriyāpathe pasannāḥ manussāḥ denti tam gahetvā chinna santhavaḥ
translated: Having gone to the house and taken what the people who are pleased with his deportment give, he goes away with his patched cloak.

original: tesaṃ kiccakaraṇīye abyāvaṭo hutvā nikkhamatīti dīpeti.
analyzed: tesam kicca karaṇīye abyāvaṭaḥ hutvā nikkhamati iti dīpeti
translated: This shows that he is not a bother to them in the performance of their duties.

original: Appagabbhoti nappagabbho, aṭṭhaṭṭhānena kāyapāgabbhiyena, catuṭṭhānena vacīpāgabbhiyena,
analyzed: appagabbho ti nappagabbhaḥ aṭṭha ṭṭhānena kāya pāgabbhiyena catu ṭṭhānena vacī pāgabbhiyena
translated: Not a bother: not a botherer, not a nuisance, not a pest. The meaning is that he is free from the eight kinds of physical nuisance, the four kinds of verbal nuisance,

original: anekaṭṭhānena manopāgabbhiyena ca virahitoti attho. Aṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ kāyapāgabbhiyaṃ
analyzed: aneka ṭṭhānena manaḥ pāgabbhiyena ca virahitaḥ ti atthaḥ aṭṭha ṭhānam kāya pāgabbhiyam
translated: and the many kinds of mental nuisance. The eight kinds of physical nuisance are:

original: nāma saṅghagaṇapuggalabhojanasālajantāgharanahānatitthabhikkhācāramaggesu antaragharapavesane
analyzed: nāma saṅgha gaṇa puggala bhojana sāla jantā ghara nahāna tittha bhikkhā cāra maggesu antara ghara pavesane
translated: to make oneself difficult to support by the Sangha, by a group, or by individuals; to make oneself difficult to lodge by going in among the houses;

original: ca kāyena appatirūpakaraṇaṃ. Catuṭṭhānaṃ vacīpāgabbhiyaṃ nāma saṅghagaṇapuggalaantaragharesu🔽appatirūpavācānicchāraṇaṃ. Anekaṭṭhānaṃ manopāgabbhiyaṃ nāma tesu tesu ṭhānesu kāyavācāhi
analyzed: ca kāyena appatirūpakaraṇam catu ṭṭhānam vacīpāgabbhiyam nāma saṅgha gaṇa puggala antara gharesu  aneka ṭṭhānam manopāgabbhiyam nāma tesu tesu ṭhānesu kāya vācāhi
translated: and to make oneself difficult to lodge by entering the houses. The four kinds of verbal nuisance are:🔽to make oneself difficult to lodge by talking in an unbecoming manner to the Sangha, to a group, or to individuals, or in among the houses;🔽and to make oneself difficult to lodge by talking in an unbecoming manner in the houses. The many kinds of mental nuisance are:

original: ajjhācāraṃ anāpajjitvāpi manasā kāmavitakkādīnaṃ vitakkanaṃ. Sabbesampi imesaṃ pāgabbhiyānaṃ
analyzed: ajjhācāram an āpajjitvā api manasā kāma vitakka ādīnam vitakkanam sabbesam pi imesam pāgabbhiyānam
translated: to give rise to thoughts of sensual desire, etc., in the mind, even though one does not commit any physical or verbal misconduct in these various situations.

original: abhāvena appagabbho hutvā kulāni upasaṅkamatīti attho. Kassapasaṃyuttena ca candūpamappaṭipadāditherassa
analyzed: abhāvena appagabbhaḥ hutvā kulāni upasaṅkamati iti attho kassapasaṃyuttena ca candu upama paṭipada ādi therassa
translated: The meaning is that he went to families without being over-bold through lack of it.

original: dhutavādesu aggabhāvassa bodhitattā vuttaṃ “etadeva kassapasaṃyuttaṃ aṭṭhuppattiṃ katvā”ti.
analyzed: dhuta vādesu agga bhāvassa bodhita ttā vuttam etat eva kassapa saṃyuttam aṭṭhuppattim katvā iti
translated: And because the Elder Candūpama was declared to be foremost among those who preach the ascetic practices, the text says “the Kassapa-samyutta was spoken for the purpose of establishing him in that”.

original: Anuruddhattheravatthu🔽192. Pañcame bhojanapapañcamattanti gocaragāme piṇḍāya caraṇāhāraparibhogasaññitaṃ
analyzed: anuruddhattheravatthu  pañcame gocara gāme piṇḍāya caraṇa āhāra paribhoga saññitam
translated: The story of the Elder Anuruddha🔽In the fifth, the mere elaboration of eating is the mere elaboration of eating called “the enjoyment of nutriment consisting in the life of one who goes for alms in a village in the alms resort” .

original: bhojanapapañcamattaṃ. Dīparukkhānanti lohadantakaṭṭhamayānaṃ mahantānaṃ dīparukkhānaṃ.
analyzed: dīpa rukkhānan ti loha danta kaṭṭha mayānam mahantānam dīpa rukkhānam
translated: The great lamp-trees are made of iron and wood.

original: Lohamayesupi hi tesu dīpādhāresu dīparukkhakāti ruḷhiresā daṭṭhabbā. Olambakadīpamaṇḍaladīpasañcaraṇadīpādikā sesadīpā.
analyzed: loha mayesu pi hi tesu dīpa ādhāresu dīpa rukkhakā ati ruḷhire esā daṭṭhabbā olambaka dīpa maṇḍala dīpa sañcaraṇa dīpa ādikā sesa dīpā
translated: For in those iron lamp-holders the lamps are called “lamp-trees” in the sense of “tree-like lamps” . The rest of the lamps are the surrounding lamps, the ring of lamps, the moving lamps, and so on.🔽By going round them in the proper order and turning them clockwise.

original: Anupariyāyi padakkhiṇakaraṇavasena. Ahaṃ tenāti yena tuyhaṃ attho, ahaṃ tena pavāremi,
analyzed: anupariyāyi padakkhiṇa karaṇa vasena aham tena ati yena tuyham atthaḥ aham tena pavāremi
translated: I will give you that: the meaning is that I will give you what you want, I will invite you to take it,

original: tasmā taṃ āharāpetvā gaṇhāti attho. Suvaṇṇapātiyaṃyevassa bhattaṃ uppajjīti devatānubhāvena
analyzed: tasmā tam āharāpetvā gaṇhāti devatā anubhāvena
translated: so fetch it and take it. His rice appeared in a golden bowl.

original: uppajji, na kiñci pacanakiccaṃ atthi. Satta mahāpurisavitakke vitakkesīti “appicchassāyaṃ🔽dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo mahicchassā”tiādike satta mahāpurisavitakke vitakkesi. Aṭṭhameti
analyzed: uppajji na kiñci pacana kiccam atthi satta mahāpurisa vitakke vitakkesi iti appicchassa ayam  dhammo na ayam dhammo mahicchassa ati ādike satta mahāpurisa vitakke vitakkesi aṭṭhame ti
translated: and there was no need for any cooking. He reflected on the seven ways of reflecting for a great man: “This Dhamma is for one who is contented, not for one who is discontent,” and so on. He reflected on the seven ways of reflecting for a great man.

original: “nippapañcārāmassāyaṃ dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo papañcārāmassā”ti etasmiṃ purisavitakke.🔽Mama saṅkappamaññāyāti “appicchassāyaṃ dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo mahicchassā”tiādinā mahāpurisavitakkavasena
analyzed: nippapañca ārāmassa ayam dhammo na ayam dhammo papañca ārāmassa ati etasmin purisa vitakke  mama saṅkappam aññāya ati appicchassa ayam dhammo na ayam dhammo mahicchassa āti ādinā mahāpurisa vitakka vasena
translated: and there was no need to cook anything. He reflected on the seven great men’s thoughts: “This is the Dhamma for the contented one, not for the discontented; this is the Dhamma for the secluded one, not for the unsecluded; this is the Dhamma for the energetic one, not for the lazy; this is the Dhamma for the one who is concentrated, not for the unconcentrated; this is the Dhamma for the wise one, not for the unwise.” He reflected on these seven great men’s thoughts. On the eighth: “This is the Dhamma for the one who delights in non-proliferation, not for the one who delights in proliferation.”

original: āraddhamattaṃ matthakaṃ pāpetuṃ asamatthabhāvena ṭhitaṃ mama saṅkappaṃ jānitvā. Manomayenāti🔽manomayena viya manasā nimmitasadisena, pariṇāmitenāti attho. Iddhiyāti “ayaṃ kāyo
analyzed: āraddha mattam matthakam pāpetum asamattha bhāvena ṭhitam mama saṅkappam jānitvā manaḥ mayena ati  manaḥ mayena viya manasā nimmita sadisena pariṇāmitena ati attho iddhiyā ati ayam kāyo
translated: Knowing my thought: knowing my thought, which was as follows: “I am unable to bring to a head the thought of a great man, which is only half-developed, by means of the seven great men’s thoughts beginning with ‘This is the Dhamma for the contented one, not for the discontented one.’“🔽By his mind-made body: by his mind-made body, which is like a mind-made body, which is like a body created by the mind; the meaning is, by his transformed body.

original: idaṃ cittaṃ viya hotū”ti evaṃ pavattāya adhiṭṭhāniddhiyā.
analyzed: idam cittam viya hotu uti evam pavattāya adhiṭṭhāna iddhiyā
translated: By his psychic power: by his psychic power consisting in resolve, which is manifested by the thought, “Let this body be like this mind.”

original: Yadā me ahu saṅkappoti yasmiṃ kāle mayhaṃ “kīdiso nu kho aṭṭhamo mahāpurisavitakko”ti
analyzed: yadā me ahu saṅkappo ti yasmin kāle mayham kīdisaḥ nu kho aṭṭhamaḥ mahā purisa vitakko ti
translated: When I had this thought: at the time when I had this thought,

original: parivitakko ahosi, yadā me ahu saṅkappo, tato mama saṅkappamaññāya iddhiyā upasaṅkami,🔽uttari desayīti yojanā. Uttari desayīti “nippapañcārāmassāyaṃ dhammo nippapañcaratino,
analyzed: parivitakkaḥ ahosi yadā me ahu saṅkappo tatas mama saṅkappa maññāya iddhiyā upasaṅkami  uttari desayi iti yojanā uttari desayi iti nippapañca ārāmassa ayam dhammo nippapañca ratino
translated: He had a thought, and when he knew my thought, he came to me by his psychic power.🔽He taught me further: the construction is this. “He taught me further” means that he taught me further while fulfilling the eighth thought of a Great Man, namely,🔽“This Dhamma is for one who delights in non-afflictioṉ, who takes delight in non-afflictioṉ,

original: nāyaṃ dhammo papañcārāmassa papañcaratino”ti imaṃ aṭṭhamaṃ mahāpurisavitakkaṃ pūrento
analyzed: na ayam dhammo papañca ārāmassa papañca ratino ti imam aṭṭhamam mahāpurisa vitakkam pūrento
translated: not for one who delights in afflictioṉ, who takes delight in afflictioṉ.”

original: upari desayi. Taṃ pana desitaṃ dassento āha – “nippapañcarato buddho, nippapañcamadesayī”ti,
analyzed: upari tam pana desitam dassentaḥ āha nippapañca rataḥ buddhaḥ nippapañcam adesayi iti
translated: Showing that teaching, he said: “The Buddha, who delights in non-afflictioṉ, taught me non-afflictioṉ.”

original: papañcā nāma rāgādayo kilesā, tesaṃ vūpasamanatāya tadabhāvato ca lokuttaradhammā
analyzed: papañcā nāma rāga ādayo kilesā tesam vūpasamana tāya tad abhāvato ca lokuttara dhammā
translated: Afflictioṉ is defilements such as lust, etc. The supramundane states are called “non-afflictioṉ” because they are the opposite of that and because they are the state of their subsiding.

original: nippapañcā nāma. Yathā taṃ pāpuṇāti, tathā dhammaṃ desesi, sāmukkaṃsikaṃ catusaccadesanaṃ adesayīti attho.
analyzed: nippapañcā nāma yathā tam pāpuṇāti tathā dhammam desesi sāmukkaṃsikam catu sacca desanam adesayi iti attho
translated: He taught the Dhamma in such a way that I attained it. The meaning is that he taught me the Dhamma in its entirety, the teaching of the Four Noble Truths.🔽I understood that Dhamma: having understood the Dhamma taught by that teacher,

original: Tassāhaṃ dhammamaññāyāti tassa satthu desanādhammaṃ jānitvā. Vihāsinti yathānusiṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: tassa aham tassa satthu desanā dhammam jānitvā vihāsinti yathānusiṭṭham
translated: I lived: I lived in accordance with the teaching.

original: paṭipajjanto vihariṃ. Sāsane ratoti sikkhattayasaṅgahe sāsane abhirato. Tisso vijjā
analyzed: paṭipajjantaḥ viharim sāsane rato ti sikkhattaya saṅgahe sāsane abhirato tissaḥ vijjā
translated: and I lived by practicing it. Delighted in the Dispensation: devoted to the Dispensation consisting in the three trainings.

original: anuppattāti pubbenivāsañāṇaṃ, dibbacakkhuñāṇaṃ, āsavakkhayañāṇanti imā tisso vijjā
analyzed: anuppattā ati pubbenivāsa ñāṇam dibba cakkhu ñāṇam āsava kkhaya ñāṇam ti imā tissaḥ vijjā
translated: I have attained the three knowledges: the knowledge of recollecting past lives, the knowledge of the passing away and arising of beings, and the knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: mayā anuppattā sacchikatā. Tato eva kataṃ buddhassa sāsanaṃ, anusiṭṭhi ovādo anuṭṭhitoti attho.
analyzed: mayā anuppattā sacchikatā tatas eva katam buddhassa sāsanam ovādaḥ anuṭṭhitaḥ ti attho
translated: I have realized these three knowledges. Therefore the Dispensation of the Buddha has been fulfilled by me, the instruction and admonition have been carried out, is the meaning.

original: Bhaddiyattheravatthu
analyzed: bhaddiyattheravatthu
translated: The Story of the Elder Bhaddiya

original: 193. Chaṭṭhe ucca-saddena samānattho uccā-saddoti āha – “uccākulikānanti ucce kule
analyzed: chaṭṭhe ucca saddena samāna atthaḥ uccā saddo ti āha uccākulikānam ti ucce kule
translated: In the sixth story, the word uccā-saddo is synonymous with ucca-saddena. Therefore the commentator says: “Uccā-kulikān means those born in high families.”

original: jātāna”nti. Kāḷī sā devīti kāḷavaṇṇatāya kāḷī sā devī. Kulānukkamena rajjānuppatti
analyzed: kāḷī sā devī iti kāḷa vaṇṇa tāya kāḷī sā devī kula anukkamena rajja anuppatti
translated: Kāḷī sā devī means that queen was called Kāḷī because of her dark complexion.

original: mahākulinassevāti vuttaṃ – “soyeva cā”tiādi.
analyzed: mahā kulinassa iva iti vuttam ca atiādi
translated: The succession of kings in the family is referred to by the words “So yeva ca so.”

original: Lakuṇḍakabhaddiyattheravatthu🔽194. Sattame rittakoti deyyavatthurahito. Guṇe āvajjetvāti bhagavato rūpaguṇe ceva
analyzed: lakuṇḍaka bhaddiyattheravatthu  sattame deyya vatthu rahitaḥ guṇe āvajjetvā ati bhagavataḥ rūpa guṇe ca iva
translated: The Story of the Elder Lakkhaṇabhaddiya🔽In the seventh story, rittako means devoid of an object of giving.

original: ākappasampadādiguṇe ca attano adhippāyaṃ ñatvā ambapakkassa paṭiggahaṇaṃ paribhuñjananti
analyzed: ā kappa sampad ādi guṇe ca attanaḥ adhippāyam ñatvā amba pakkassa paṭiggahaṇam paribhuñjananti
translated: Having considered his qualities: having known the Blessed One’s qualities of physical beauty and his qualities of deportment, etc., and his own intention, he accepted the mango fruit and ate it.

original: evamādike yathāupaṭṭhite guṇe āvajjetvā.
analyzed: evamādike yathā upaṭṭhite guṇe āvajjetvā
translated: and he adverts to the special qualities as they become manifest in him.

original: Piṇḍolabhāradvājattheravatthu🔽195. Aṭṭhame abhītanādabhāvena sīhassa viya nādo sīhanādo, so etesaṃ atthīti sīhanādikā,
analyzed: piṇḍola bhāradvājattheravatthu  aṭṭhame abhīta nāda bhāvena sīhassa viya nādaḥ sīha nādo saḥ etesam atthi iti sīhanādikā
translated: The story of the Elder Piṇḍolabhāradvāja.🔽In the eighth place, the roar of a lion is called a lion’s roar because it is a roar of fearlessness, like the roar of a lion. Those who have that are called lion- roarers.

original: tesaṃ sīhanādikānaṃ. Garahitabbapasaṃsitabbadhamme yāthāvato jānantasseva garahā
analyzed: tesam sīha nādikānam garahitabba pasaṃsitabba dhamme yāthāvataḥ jānantassa iva garahā
translated: The lion-roarers, who are fit to be blamed or praised in accordance with their blame- worthiness or praiseworthiness,

original: pasaṃsā ca yuttarūpāti āha – “buddhā ca nāmā”tiādi. Khīṇā jātītiādīhi paccavekkhaṇañāṇassa
analyzed: pasaṃsā ca yutta rūpā ti āha buddhā ca nāma atiādi khīṇā jātī iti ādīhi paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇassa
translated: are “the Buddhas, etc.,” he said. And by the words “Birth is destroyed” he shows the plane of the knowledge of reviewing,

original: bhūmiṃ dasseti. Tena hi ñāṇena ariyasāvako paccavekkhanto “khīṇā jātī”tiādiṃ pajānāti.
analyzed: bhūmim dasseti tena hi ñāṇena ariya sāvakaḥ paccavekkhantaḥ khīṇā jātī iti ādim pajānāti
translated: for it is by means of that knowledge that a noble disciple understands that “birth is destroyed.”

original: Katamā panassa jāti khīṇā, kathañca pajānātīti? Na tāvassa atītā khīṇā pubbeva khīṇattā,
analyzed: katamā panassa jāti khīṇā kathañca pajānāti iti na tāva assa atītā khīṇā pubbā iva khīṇattā
translated: But what is the birth that is destroyed, and how does he understand? It is not past, because it has already ceased;

original: na anāgatā anāgate vāyāmābhāvato, na paccuppannā vijjamānattā. Yā pana maggassa abhāvitattā
analyzed: na anāgatāḥ anāgate vāyāma abhāvataḥ na paccuppannāḥ vijjamāna ttā yā pana maggassa a bhāvita ttā
translated: nor future, because he has no concern with the future; nor present, because it is actually occurring. But the kind of birth that would occur if the path had not been developed,

original: uppajjeyya ekacatupañcavokārabhavesu ekacatupañcakkhandhappabhedā jāti, sā maggassa
analyzed: uppajjeyya eka catu pañca vokāra bhavesu eka catu pañca khandha ppabhedā jāti sā maggassa
translated: in the one tetra-, five-, or six-constituent becoming, divided into the four tetra-

original: bhāvitattā anuppādadhammataṃ āpajjanena khīṇā. Taṃ so maggabhāvanāya pahīnakilese
analyzed: bhāvita ttā an uppāda dhamma tam āpajjanena khīṇā tam saḥ magga bhāvanāya pahīna kilese
translated: and by the state of their not arising again through the development of the path they are destroyed.

original: paccavekkhitvā “kilesābhāve vijjamānampi kammaṃ āyatiṃ appaṭisandhikaṃ hotī”ti jānanto pajānāti.
analyzed: paccavekkhitvā kilesa abhāve vijjamānam api kammaṃ āyatim appaṭisandhikam hoti iti jānantaḥ pajānāti
translated: He understands this by reviewing the defilements abandoned by the development of the path.

original: Vusitanti vuṭṭhaṃ parivuṭṭhaṃ, kataṃ caritaṃ niṭṭhitanti attho. Brahmacariyanti maggabrahmacariyaṃ.
analyzed: vusitanti vuṭṭham parivuṭṭham katam caritam niṭṭhitanti attho brahmacariyanti magga brahmacariyam
translated: “Led to” : entered, penetrated, done, performed, completed, is the meaning. “The holy life” : the life of the path.

original: Puthujjanakalyāṇakena hi saddhiṃ satta sekkhā maggabrahmacariyaṃ vasanti nāma, khīṇāsavo
analyzed: puthujjana kalyāṇakena hi saddhim satta sekkhāḥ magga brahmacariyam vasanti nāma khīṇa asavaḥ
translated: For the seven disciples in training and the good persons live the holy life together with the path, but the one who has destroyed the taints🔽has lived it.

original: vuṭṭhavāso. Tasmā ariyasāvako attano brahmacariyavāsaṃ paccavekkhanto “vusitaṃ brahmacariya”nti
analyzed: vuṭṭhavāso tasmai ariya sāvako attanaḥ brahmacariya vāsam paccavekkhantaḥ vusitam brahmacariyanti
translated: Therefore, when the noble disciple reviews his own dwelling in the holy life, he understands thus:

original: pajānāti. Kataṃ karaṇīyanti catūsu saccesu catūhi maggehi pariññāpahānasacchikiriyābhāvanābhisamayavasena
analyzed: pajānāti katam karaṇīyanti catūsu saccesu catūhi maggehi pariññā apahāna sacchikiriyā bhāvanā abhisamaya vasena
translated: “The holy life has been lived.” “What had to be done has been done” : the meaning is that the sixteen duties in the four truths by the four paths, namely, the duties of full understanding, abandoning, realizing, and developing,

original: soḷasavidhaṃ kiccaṃ niṭṭhāpitanti attho. Puthujjanakalyāṇakādayo hi taṃ kiccaṃ karonti,
analyzed: soḷasavidham kiccam niṭṭhāpitanti attho puthujjana kalyāṇaka ādayaḥ hi tam kiccam karonti
translated: have been completed. For the good persons and so on are doing those duties,

original: khīṇāsavo katakaraṇīyo. Tasmā ariyasāvako attano karaṇīyaṃ paccavekkhanto “kataṃ🔽karaṇīya”nti pajānāti. Nāparaṃ itthattāyāti idāni puna itthabhāvāya evaṃ soḷasavidhakiccabhāvāya,
analyzed: khīṇa āsavaḥ kata karaṇīyo tasmai ariya sāvako attanaḥ karaṇīyam paccavekkhanto katam  karaṇīyanti pajānāti na aparam itthattāya ati idāni punar ittha bhāvāya evam soḷasavidha kicca bhāvāya
translated: and his taints are destroyed. Thus, when he reflects on what ought to be done by one in training, he understands: “What ought to be done by one in training has been done by me.🔽” “There is no more of this sort of becoming”: he understands that there is no more need for him to develop the path in order to abandon the defilements or in order to reach the sixteen kinds of knowledge of the clearing up of doubts.🔽Or else, “of this sort” refers to the continuity of aggregates of this sort, of this kind, which is now present. He understands that there is no more need for him to develop the path in order to reach another continuity of aggregates in the future.

original: kilesakkhayāya vā maggabhāvanāya kiccaṃ me natthīti pajānāti. Atha vā itthattāyāti
analyzed: kilesa kkhayāya vā magga bhāvanāya kiccam me natthi iti pajānāti atha vā itthattāya ati
translated: Or else, “of this sort” refers to the continuity of aggregates of this sort, of this kind, which is now present. He understands that there is no more need for him to develop the path in order to reach another continuity of aggregates in the future.

original: itthabhāvato imasmā evaṃpakārā idāni vattamānakkhandhasantānā aparaṃ khandhasantānaṃ🔽mayhaṃ natthi, ime pana pañcakkhandhā pariññātā tiṭṭhanti chinnamūlakā rukkhā viya,
analyzed: ittha bhāvataḥ imasmai evaṃpakārāḥ idāni vattamāna kkhandha santānāḥ aparam khandha santānam  mayham natthi ime pana pañca kkhandhā pariññātā tiṭṭhanti chinna mūlakāḥ rukkhāḥ viya
translated: Or else, “of this sort” refers to the continuity of aggregates of this sort, of this kind, which is now present. He understands that there is no more need for him to develop the path in order to reach another continuity of aggregates in the future.

original: te carimakaviññāṇanirodhena anupādāno viya jātavedo nibbāyissantīti pajānāti.🔽Mantāṇiputtapuṇṇattheravatthu
analyzed: te carimaka viññāṇa nirodhena anupādānaḥ viya jātavedaḥ nibbāyissanti iti pajānāti  mantāṇiputta puṇṇatthera vatthu
translated: Or else, “of this sort” refers to the continuity of aggregates of this sort, of this kind, which is now present. He understands that there is no more need for him to develop the path in order to reach another continuity of aggregates in the future.🔽Or else, “of this sort” refers to the continuity of aggregates of this sort, of this kind, which is now present. He understands that there is no more need for him to develop the path in order to reach another continuity of aggregates in the future.

original: 196. Navame aṭṭhārasasupi vijjāṭṭhānesu nipphattiṃ gatattā “sabbasippesu kovido hutvā”ti
analyzed: navame aṭṭhārasa supi vijjāṭṭhānesu nipphattim gata ttā sabba sippesu kovidaḥ hutvā ati
translated: Or else, “of this sort” refers to the continuity of aggregates of this sort, of this kind, which is now present. He understands that there is no more need for him to develop the path in order to reach another continuity of aggregates in the future.🔽Or else, “of this sort” refers to the continuity of aggregates of this sort, of this kind, which is now present. He understands that there is no more need for him to develop the

original: vuttaṃ. Abhidayāabbhaññāvahasseva dhammassa tattha upalabbhanato “mokkhadhammaṃ adisvā”ti
analyzed: vuttam abhidayā abbhaññā vahassa iva dhammassa tattha upalabbhanataḥ mokkha dhammam a disvā ti
translated: It is said. Because the state of deliverance is found there in the case of the state of penetration and the state of the path, it is said: “without seeing the state of deliverance.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tenāha – “idaṃ vedattayaṃ nāmā”tiādi. Tathā hi anena duggatiparimuccanampi
analyzed: vuttam tena āha idam veda ttayam nāma atiādi tathā hi anena duggati parimuccanam pi
translated: “The Dhamma of deliverance” is said because the manifestation of the Dhamma is found there. Therefore he said: “This is called the three kinds of feeling.”

original: dullabhaṃ, abhiññāparivārānaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ samāpattīnaṃ lābhitāya sayaṃ ekadesena upasanto
analyzed: dullabham abhiññā parivārānam aṭṭhannam samāpattīnam lābhi tāya sayam eka desena upasanto
translated: For it is difficult for him to be delivered from the woeful states. Having attained the eight attainments surrounded by the higher knowledges, he himself is partially pacified.

original: paramukkaṃsagataṃ uttamadamathasamathaṃ anaññasādhāraṇaṃ bhagavantaṃ sambhāvento
analyzed: param ukkaṃsa gatam uttama damatha samatham anañña sādhāraṇam bhagavantam sambhāvento
translated: Having attained the highest peace, the highest tranquility, the highest self-control, which is not shared by others, he reveres the Blessed One,

original: “ayaṃ puriso”tiādimāha. Piṭakāni gahetvā āgacchantīti phalabhājanāni gahetvā assāmikāya🔽āgacchanti. Buddhānanti gāravavasena bahuvacananiddeso kato. Paribhuñjīti devatāhi
analyzed: ayam purisaḥ iti ādim āha piṭakāni gahetvā āgacchanti iti phala bhājanāni gahetvā assāmikāya  āgacchanti gārava vasena bahuvacana niddeso kataḥ devatāhi
translated: saying: “This person.” They come with baskets in their hands means they come without a master,

original: pakkhittadibbojaṃ vanamūlaphalāphalaṃ paribhuñji. Patte patiṭṭhāpitasamanantarameva
analyzed: pakkhitta dibbojam vana mūla phala aphalam paribhuñji patte patiṭṭhāpita samanantaram eva
translated: having taken fruit baskets. The plural form “Buddhas” is used out of respect. He enjoyed means he enjoyed the forest fruits and roots offered by the deities.

original: hi devatā tattha dibbojaṃ pakkhipiṃsu. Sammasitvāti paccavekkhitvā, parivattetvāti
analyzed: hi devatā tattha dibbojam pakkhipiṃsu sammasitvā ati paccavekkhitvā parivattetvā ati
translated: For as soon as he placed his bowl there, the deities put divine food into it. Having tasted means having reflected, having turned over.

original: ca vadanti. Arahattaṃ pāpuṇiṃsūti mahādevattherassa anumodanakathāya anupubbikathāsakkhikāya🔽suvisodhitacittasantānā arahattaṃ pāpuṇiṃsu.
analyzed: ca vadanti arahattam pāpuṇiṃsu iti mahādeva ttherassa anumodana kathāya anupubbi kathā sakkhikāya  su visodhita citta santānāḥ arahattam pāpuṇiṃsu
translated: They reached Arahantship by the gradual talk in the Elder Maha-Devata’s thanksgiving address.

original: Dasahi kathāvatthūhīti appicchakathā santuṭṭhikathā pavivekakathā asaṃsaggakathā
analyzed: dasahi kathā vatthūhi iti appiccha kathā santuṭṭhi kathā paviveka kathā asaṃsagga kathā
translated: By the ten talk-topics: by the talk on fewness of wishes, on contentment, on solitude, on non-entanglement,

original: vīriyārambhakathā sīlasampadākathā samādhisampadākathā paññāsampadākathā vimuttisampadākathā
analyzed: vīriya ārambha kathā sīla sampadā kathā samādhi sampadā kathā paññā sampadā kathā vimutti sampadā kathā

original: attho – yathā kokanadasaṅkhātaṃ padumaṃ pāto sūriyuggamanavelāyaṃ phullaṃ vikasitaṃ🔽avītagandhaṃ siyā virocamānaṃ, evaṃ sarīragandhena guṇagandhena ca sugandhaṃ saradakāle
analyzed: yathā kokanada saṅkhātam padumam phullam vikasitam  a vīta gandham siyā virocamānam evam sarīra gandhena guṇa gandhena ca su gandham sarada kāle
translated: blossomed,🔽and has not yet lost its scent, shining,🔽so he saw the Fully Enlightened One, fragrant with the scent of his body and the scent of his virtues,🔽scorching with his own splendour like the sun in the sky in autumn,

original: antalikkhe ādiccamiva attano tejasā tapantaṃ aṅgehi niccharaṇakajutiyā aṅgīrasaṃ🔽sammāsambuddhaṃ passāti.
analyzed: antalikkhe ādiccam iva tejasā tapantam aṅgehi niccharaṇaka jutiyā aṅgīrasam  sammāsambuddham passāti
translated: with the radiance of his limbs shining forth from his limbs.🔽It seems that Cūḷapanthaka went forth in the time of Kassapa Buddha and became wise.

original: Cūḷapanthako kira kassapasammāsambuddhakāle pabbajitvā paññavā hutvā aññatarassa
analyzed: cūḷapanthakaḥ kira kassapa sammāsambuddha kāle pabbajitvā paññavā hutvā aññatarassa
translated: When a certain slow-witted bhikkhu was learning the recitation, he made fun of him.

original: dandhabhikkhuno uddesagahaṇakāle parihāsakeḷiṃ akāsi. So bhikkhu tena parihāsena
analyzed: dandha bhikkhuno uddesa gahaṇa kāle parihāsa keḷim akāsi saḥ bhikkhu tena parihāsena
translated: The bhikkhu, ashamed because of the ridicule,🔽neither learned the recitation nor recited it.

original: lajjito neva uddesaṃ gaṇhi, na sajjhāyamakāsi. Tena kammenāyaṃ pabbajitvāva dandho
analyzed: lajjitaḥ na iva uddesam gaṇhi na sajjhāyam akāsi tena kammena ayam pabbajitvā ava dandhaḥ
translated: As a result of that kamma he was slow-witted even when he went forth as a monk in the dispensation of the Buddha Gotama.

original: jāto, tasmā gahitagahitapadaṃ upariuparipadaṃ gaṇhantassa nassati. Iddhiyā abhisaṅkharitvā
analyzed: jātaḥ tasmai gahita gahita padam upari upari padam gaṇhantassa nassati iddhiyā abhisaṅkharitvā
translated: and so he forgot the words he had already learned and was unable to learn any more.

original: suddhaṃ coḷakhaṇḍaṃ adāsīti tassa pubbahetuṃ disvā tadanurūpe kammaṭṭhāne niyojento
analyzed: suddham coḷa khaṇḍam adāsi iti tassa pubba hetum disvā tad anurūpe kammaṭṭhāne niyojento
translated: He gave him a piece of pure cloth. Seeing that this was the cause of his previous failure, the Elder assigned him a meditation subject in conformity with that cause,

original: suddhaṃ coḷakhaṇḍaṃ adāsi. So kira pubbe rājā hutvā nagaraṃ padakkhiṇaṃ karonto nalāṭato🔽sede muccante parisuddhena sāṭakena nalāṭaṃ puñchi, sāṭako kiliṭṭho ahosi. So “imaṃ
analyzed: suddham coḷa khaṇḍam adāsi so kira pubbe rājā hutvā nagaram padakkhiṇam karontaḥ nalāṭataḥ  sede muccante parisuddhena sāṭakena nalāṭam puñchi sāṭakaḥ kiliṭṭhaḥ ahosi saḥ imaṃ
translated: and gave him a piece of pure cloth. For it seems that in a previous birth this man was a king who was circumambulating a shrine. Sweat ran from his forehead

original: sarīraṃ nissāya evarūpo parisuddhasāṭako pakatiṃ jahitvā kiliṭṭho jāto, aniccā vata
analyzed: sarīram nissāya evarūpaḥ parisuddha sāṭakaḥ pakatim jahitvā kiliṭṭhaḥ jātaḥ aniccāḥ vata
translated: and he wiped it off with a pure cloth. The cloth became soiled. He thought, “This pure cloth has lost its original condition and become soiled because of this body. Impermanent, indeed, are formations! ”

original: saṅkhārā”ti aniccasaññaṃ paṭilabhi. Tena kāraṇenassa rajoharaṇameva paccayo jāto.
analyzed: saṅkhārā ati anicca saññam tena kāraṇena assa rajaḥ haraṇam eva paccayaḥ jāto
translated: He acquired the perception of impermanence. That was the reason why he became a rag-robe wearer.

original: Lomānīti coḷakhaṇḍatantagataaṃsuke vadati. “Kiliṭṭhadhātukānī”ti kiliṭṭhasabhāvāni.
analyzed: lomāni iti coḷa khaṇḍa tanta gata aṃsuke vadati kiliṭṭha dhātukāni iti kiliṭṭha sabhāvāni
translated: “Hair-ends” : he calls the fine hairs on the edge of the cloth “hair-ends.” “Soiled elements” : elements that have become soiled.

original: Evaṃgatikamevāti idaṃ cittampi bhavaṅgavasena pakatiyā paṇḍaraṃ parisuddhaṃ rāgādisampayuttadhammavasena
analyzed: evaṃgatikam evā ti idam cittam pi bhavaṅga vasena pakatiyā paṇḍaram parisuddham rāga ādi sampayutta dhamma vasena
translated: ‘It is bound to go that way’: this shows that the mind, being by nature clear and pure as the life-continuum, is defiled by being associated with states such as greed.

original: saṃkiliṭṭhaṃ jātanti dasseti. Nakkhattaṃ samānetvāti nakkhattaṃ samannāharitvā, āvajjetvāti
analyzed: saṃkiliṭṭham jātanti dasseti nakkhattam samānetvā ati nakkhattam samannāharitvā āvajjetvā iti
translated: ‘Having brought out the constellation’: having brought out the constellation, having advert-ed to it.

original: attho. Biḷārassatthāyāti biḷārassa gocaratthāya. Jalapathakammikenāti samuddakammikena.🔽Cārinti khāditabbatiṇaṃ. Saccakāranti saccabhāvāvahaṃ kāraṃ, “attanā gahite bhaṇḍe🔽aññesaṃ na dātabba”nti vatvā dātabbalañjanti vuttaṃ hoti. Tatiyena paṭihārenāti tatiyena
analyzed: atthaḥ biḷārassa atthāya ati biḷārassa gocara tthāya jala patha kammikena ati samudda kammikena  khāditabba tiṇam sacca kāranti sacca bhāva āvaham kāram attanā gahite bhaṇḍe  aññesam na dātabbanti vatvā dātabba lañjanti vuttam hoti tatiyena paṭihārena ati tatiyena
translated: ‘For the cat’s sake’: for the cat’s prey. ‘By the man who works on the water’: by the man who works on the sea.🔽‘The wanderer’: the one who eats the grass. ‘The true means’: the means that brings about the truth. The meaning is: ‘Having said, “The goods that I have seized are not to be given to others,” he gives them as a present.’

original: sāsanena. Pattikā hutvāti sāmino hutvā.
analyzed: sa āsanena pattikāḥ hutvā ati sāminaḥ hutvā
translated: ‘By the third blow’: by the third order. ‘As owners’: as masters.

original: Appakenapīti thokenapi parittenapi. Medhāvīti paññavā. Pābhatenāti bhaṇḍamūlena.
analyzed: appakena api iti thokena api parittena api medhāvī iti paññavā pābhatena ati bhaṇḍa mūlena
translated: ‘Even with a little’: even with a small amount, even with a little. ‘The wise man’: the man of understanding. ‘With what he has earned’: with the proceeds of his goods.

original: Vicakkhaṇoti vohārakusalo. Samuṭṭhāpeti attānanti mahantaṃ dhanaṃ yasañca uppādetvā
analyzed: vicakkhaṇo ti vohāra kusalo samuṭṭhāpeti attānanti mahantam dhanam yasam ca uppādetvā
translated: ‘The clever man’: the man skilled in business. ‘He makes himself’: having produced great wealth and fame,

original: tattha attānaṃ saṇṭhapeti patiṭṭhāpeti. Yathā kiṃ? Aṇuṃ aggiṃva sandhamaṃ, yathā
analyzed: tattha attānam saṇṭhapeti patiṭṭhāpeti yathā kim aṇum aggim iva sandhamam yathā
translated: Herein, he establishes himself, he sets himself up. How? As a small fire,

original: paṇḍito puriso parittakaṃ aggiṃ anukkamena gomayacuṇṇādīni pakkhipitvā mukhavātena🔽dhamento samuṭṭhāpeti vaḍḍheti, mahantaṃ aggikkhandhaṃ karoti, evameva paṇḍito thokampi
analyzed: paṇḍitaḥ purisaḥ parittakam aggim anukkamena gomaya cuṇṇa ādīni pakkhipitvā mukha vātena  dhamentaḥ samuṭṭhāpeti vaḍḍheti mahantam aggi khandham karoti evam eva paṇḍitaḥ thokam pi
translated: As a wise man gradually increases a small fire by adding cowdung, chaff, etc., and by blowing on it with his mouth,

original: pābhataṃ labhitvā nānāupāyehi payojetvā dhanañca yasañca vaḍḍheti, vaḍḍhetvā puna
analyzed: pābhatam labhitvā nānā upāyehi payojetvā dhanañca yasañca vaḍḍheti vaḍḍhetvā punar
translated: so the wise man, having obtained a little wealth, increases it by various means and makes it grow. Having made it grow, he again

original: tattha attānaṃ patiṭṭhāpeti. Tāya eva vā pana dhanassa mahantatāya attānaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti,
analyzed: tattha attānam patiṭṭhāpeti tāya eva vā pana dhanassa mahanta tāya attānam samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: establishes himself in it. Or else, by reason of the greatness of his wealth, he establishes himself,

original: abhiññātaṃ pākaṭaṃ karotīti attho.
analyzed: abhiññātam pākaṭam karoti iti attho
translated: he makes himself well known and conspicuous.

original: Subhūtittheravatthu🔽201-202. Tatiye raṇāti hi rāgādayo kilesā vuccantīti “saraṇā dhammā”tiādīsu rāgādayo
analyzed: subhūtittheravatthu  tatiye hi rāga ādayaḥ kilesā vuccanti iti saraṇā dhammā ti ādīsu rāga ādayaḥ
translated: The Story of the Elder Subhuti

original: kilesā “raṇā”ti vuccanti. Raṇanti etehīti raṇā. Yehi abhibhūtā sattā nānappakārena
analyzed: kilesāḥ raṇā ti vuccanti raṇanti etehi iti raṇā yehi abhibhūtā sattā nānappakārena
translated: In the third stanza, the word “ran” is used in the sense of the defilements such as lust, etc., as in the passage, “The Dhamma is a refuge from the defilements” . The defilements such as lust, etc., are called “ran”🔽in the sense that they are “ran” because beings are “ran” by them. Those by which beings are overcome and are made to go in various ways to the plane of misery, to the plane of misery in the hells, etc., are called “ran” in the sense that they are “ran” because beings are “ran” by them.

original: kandanti paridevanti, tasmā te rāgādayo “raṇā”ti vuttā. Desitaniyāmato anokkamitvāti🔽desitānokkamanato anupagantvā deseti, satthārā desitaniyāmeneva anodissakaṃ katvā
analyzed: kandanti paridevanti tasmā te rāga ādayaḥ vuttāḥ desita niyāmataḥ an ukkamitvā ati  desita anokkamanataḥ an upagantvā deseti satthārā desita niyāmena iva anodissakam katvā
translated: They lament and weep, and so they are called “distresses” .🔽Without overstepping the norm laid down: without overstepping the norm laid down by the Teacher.

original: dhammaṃ desetīti vuttaṃ hoti. Evanti evaṃ mettājhānato vuṭṭhāya bhikkhāgahaṇe sati.
analyzed: dhammam deseti iti vuttam hoti evanti evam mettā jhānataḥ vuṭṭhāya bhikkhā gahaṇe sati
translated: He teaches the Dhamma without deviating from the norm laid down by the Teacher, without deviating from the straight path.🔽Thus: after emerging from the jhāna of loving-kindness, when it is time to go on alms round.

original: Bhikkhādāyakānaṃ mahapphalaṃ bhavissatīti idaṃ cūḷaccharāsaṅghātasuttena dīpetabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhā dāyakānam mahapphalam bhavissati iti idam cūḷaccharā saṅghāta suttena dīpetabbam
translated: The alms givers will reap great fruit: this should be illustrated by the Cūḷa-Accuta Sutta .

original: Accharāsaṅghātamattampi hi kālaṃ mettacittaṃ āsevantassa bhikkhuno dinnadānaṃ mahapphalaṃ
analyzed: accharā saṅghāta mattam pi hi kālam metta cittam āsevantassa bhikkhuno dinna dānam mahapphalam
translated: For the alms given to a bhikkhu who cultivates loving-kindness even for the time of a mere finger- snap bring great fruit and great profit,

original: hoti mahānisaṃsaṃ, tena ca so amoghaṃ raṭṭhapiṇḍaṃ bhuñjatīti ayamattho tattha āgatoyeva.
analyzed: hoti mahā nisaṃsam tena ca so amogham raṭṭha piṇḍam bhuñjati iti ayam attho tattha āgataḥ yā iva
translated: and he eats the country’s alms food without wasting it. This meaning is found in that sutta.

original: Nimittaṃ gaṇhitvāti ākāraṃ sallakkhetvā.
analyzed: nimittam gaṇhitvā ati ākāram sallakkhetvā
translated: Seizing the sign: observing the appearance.

original: Khadiravaniyarevatattheravatthu
analyzed: khadira vani ya revata tthera vatthu
translated: The story of the Elder Revata of Khadira Grove

original: 203. Pañcame vanasabhāganti sabhāgaṃ vanaṃ, sabhāganti ca sappāyanti attho. Yañhi
analyzed: pañcame vana sabhāganti sabhāgam vanam sabhāganti ca sappāyanti atthaḥ yat hi
translated: The fifth is a forest that is suitable: a suitable forest. And “suitable” means “beneficial.” For

original: pakativiruddhaṃ byādhiviruddhañca na hoti, taṃ “sabhāga”nti vuccati. Udakasabhāgantiādīsupi🔽imināva nayena attho veditabbo. Kalyāṇakammāyūhanakkhaṇoti kalyāṇakammūpacayassa
analyzed: pakati viruddham byādhi viruddham ca na hoti tam sabhāganti vuccati udaka sabhāganti ādīsu pi  iminā ava nayena atthaḥ veditabbo kalyāṇa kamma āyūhana khaṇo ti kalyāṇa kamma upacayassa
translated: and it is not contrary to nature or to the disease, it is called “suitable.” In the case of “suitable water” and so on,🔽the meaning should be understood in the same way. The moment for accumulating good kamma:🔽

original: okāso. Tiṇṇaṃ bhātikānanti upatisso, cundo, upasenoti imesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ jeṭṭhabhātikānaṃ.
analyzed: okāsaḥ tiṇṇam bhātikānam ti upatissaḥ cundaḥ upasenaḥ ti imesam tiṇṇam jeṭṭha bhātikānam
translated: It is not contrary to nature or to the disease, and so it is called “suitable.” The meaning should be understood in the same way in the case of “water-suitable” and so on. The time for accumulating good kamma: the opportunity for accumulating good kamma. The three brothers: Upatissa, Cunda, and Upasena.

original: Tissannañca bhaginīnanti cālā, upacālā, sīsupacālāti imesaṃ tissannaṃ jeṭṭhabhaginīnaṃ.
analyzed: tissannam ca bhaginīnanti cālā upacālā sīsupacālā ati imesam tissannam jeṭṭhabhaginīnam
translated: And the three sisters: Cālā, Upacālā, and Sīsupacālā.

original: Ettha ca sāriputtatthero sayaṃ pabbajitvā cālā, upacālā, sīsupacālāti tisso bhaginiyo,
analyzed: ettha ca sāriputta thero sayam pabbajitvā cālā upacālā sīsupacālā ati tissaḥ bhaginiyo
translated: Here the Elder Sāriputta himself went forth and caused his three elder sisters, Cālā, Upacālā, and Sīsupacālā,

original: cundo upasenoti ime bhātaro pabbājesi, revatakumāro ekova gehe avasissati. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: cundaḥ upasenaḥ ti ime bhātaraḥ pabbājesi revata kumāraḥ ekaḥ iva gehe avasissati tena vuttam
translated: and his two brothers, Cunda and Upasena, to go forth. Only the youth Revata remained in the house. Therefore it is said:

original: – “amhākaṃ…pe… pabbājentī”ti. Mahallakatarāti vuddhatarā. Idañca kumārikāya cirajīvitaṃ
analyzed: pabbājenti iti mahallakatarā ati vuddhatarā idam ca kumārikāya cira jīvitam
translated: “They caused us to go forth.” The elder ones: the more senior ones. And they said this because they desired that the girl should live a long life.

original: abhikaṅkhamānā āhaṃsu. Sā kira tassa ayyikā vīsativassasatikā khaṇḍadantā palitakesā
analyzed: abhikaṅkhamānāḥ āhaṃsu sā kira tassa ayyikā vīsati vassa satikā khaṇḍa dantā palita kesā
translated: It seems that her grandmother was two hundred and fifty years old, with broken teeth and grey hair,

original: valittacā tilakāhatagattā gopānasivaṅkā ahosi. Vidhāvanikanti vidhāvanakīḷikaṃ. Tissannaṃ🔽sampattīnanti anussavavasena manussadevamokkhasampattiyo sandhāya vadati, manussadevabrahmasampattiyo🔽vā. Sīvalissa puññaṃ vīmaṃsissāmāti “sīvalinā katapuññassa vipākadānaṭṭhānamida”nti
analyzed: valittacā tilaka ahata gattā gopānasivaṅkā ahosi vidhāvanikanti vidhāvana kīḷikam tissannam  anussava vasena manussa deva mokkha sampattiyo sandhāya vadati manussa deva brahma sampattiyo  vā sīvalissa puññam vīmaṃsissāma ati sīvalinā kata puññassa vipāka dāna ṭṭhānam idam ti
translated: and he had lines and wrinkles and was bent like a cow’s horn. He played the game of running about. The three kinds of success: he says this referring to the success of human beings, gods and the emancipated, according to the tradition, or the success of human beings, gods and Brahmas. He will examine Sīvali’s merit: “This is the place where the fruit of the merit made by Sīvali is given.”🔽

original: ñatvā evamāha. Sabhāgaṭṭhānanti samaṃ desaṃ.
analyzed: ñatvā evam āha samam desam
translated: and his body was marked with lines like the furrows of a plough. He played the game of running about. The three kinds of success: he says this with reference to the success of human beings, gods, and deliverance, or else with reference to the success of human beings, gods, and Brahmas, according to the tradition. He will test the merit of Sivali: thinking, “This is the place where the fruit of the merit made by Sivali is given,” he said this. A suitable place: a level place.

original: Taṃ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakanti kiñcāpi arahanto gāmante kāyavivekaṃ na labhanti, cittavivekaṃ
analyzed: tam kiñca api arahantaḥ gām ante kāya vivekam na labhanti citta vivekam
translated: That place is delightful: although arahats do not obtain bodily seclusion in a village, they do obtain mental seclusion.

original: pana labhanteva. Tesañhi dibbappaṭibhāgānipi ārammaṇāni cittaṃ cāletuṃ na sakkonti,
analyzed: pana labhantā iva tesam hi dibba paṭibhāgāni pi ārammaṇāni cittam cāletum na sakkonti
translated: For their minds cannot be disturbed even by objects similar to those pertaining to the divine abidings.

original: tasmā gāmo vā hotu araññādīnaṃ vā aññataraṃ, ‘yattha arahanto viharanti, taṃ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṃ’,
analyzed: tasmai gāmaḥ vā hotu arañña ādīnam vā aññataram yattha arahantaḥ viharanti tam bhūmirāmaṇeyyakam
translated: Therefore, whether it be a village or any of the other kinds of places, “that place is delightful where arahats dwell.”

original: so bhūmippadeso ramaṇīyo evāti attho.
analyzed: saḥ bhūmippadesaḥ ramaṇīyaḥ evā ti attho
translated: The meaning is that that place is delightful.

original: Kaṅkhārevatattheravatthu
analyzed: kaṅkhārevatattheravatthu
translated: The Story of the Elder Kaṅkhārevata

original: 204. Chaṭṭhe akappiyo, āvuso, guḷoti ekadivasaṃ thero antarāmagge guḷakaraṇaṃ okkamitvā🔽guḷe piṭṭhampi chārikampi pakkhitte disvāna “akappiyo guḷo, sāmiso na kappati guḷo🔽vikāle paribhuñjitu”nti kukkuccāyanto evamāha. Akappiyā muggāti ekadivasaṃ antarāmagge
analyzed: chaṭṭhe akappiyaḥ āvuso guḷaḥ ti eka divasam theraḥ antara āmagge guḷa karaṇam okkamitvā  guḷe piṭṭham pi chārikam pi pakkhitte disvāna akappiyaḥ guḷaḥ sa āmisaḥ na kappati guḷaḥ  vikāle paribhuñjitum ti kukkuccāyantaḥ evam āha akappiyā muggā ti eka divasam antarāmagge
translated: “‘Sugar is unallowable, friends,’ he said, on one occasion when he saw sugar-making in the course of a journey.🔽Seeing the dregs and the scum thrown away, he said, ‘Sugar is unallowable. Sugar that is a modification of meat is not allowable.

original: vacce muggaṃ jātaṃ disvā “akappiyā muggā, pakkāpi muggā jāyantī”ti kukkuccāyanto
analyzed: vacce muggam jātam disvā akappiyāḥ muggā pakkā api muggāḥ jāyanti iti kukkuccāyantaḥ
translated: Sugar is not allowable to be used out of time.’ On another occasion, seeing mung-beans growing in a field on the way, he said, ‘Mung-beans are unallowable.

original: evamāha. Sesamettha sabbaṃ uttānameva.
analyzed: evam āha sesam ettha sabbam uttānam eva
translated: Even when ripe they grow again.’ The rest is clear.

original: Soṇakoḷivisattheravatthu
analyzed: soṇa koḷi visatthera vatthu
translated: The story of the Elder Soṇa Koḷivisa

original: 205. Sattame hāpetabbameva ahosi accāraddhavīriyattā. Udakena samupabyūḷheti udakena🔽thalaṃ ussāretvā tattha tattha rāsikate. Haritūpalittāyāti gomayaparibhaṇḍakatāya.
analyzed: sattame hāpetabbam eva ahosi accā āraddha vīriyattā udakena samupabyūḍhā iti udakena  thalam ussāretvā tattha tattha rāsikate gomaya paribhaṇḍaka tāya
translated: In the seventh case, it was only necessary to throw it away because of his over-eagerness. ‘Watered’:🔽watered the ground and made heaps here and there. ‘With green grass spread over it’: with cow-dung spread over it.

original: Tividhena udakena posentīti khīrodakaṃ gandhodakaṃ kevalodakanti evaṃ tividhena udakena
analyzed: tividhena udakena posenti iti khīra udakam gandha udakam evam tividhena udakena
translated: ‘They nourished him with water in three ways’: with milk, perfumed water, and ordinary water.

original: posenti paripālenti. Parissāvetvāti parisodhetvā gahite taṇḍuleti yojetabbaṃ. Devo
analyzed: posenti paripālenti parissāvetvā ati parisodhetvā gahite taṇḍule iti yojetabbam devaḥ
translated: They look after, they protect. Having looked after, having protected: having purified, having taken. Rice: this should be construed with “having looked after, having protected.”

original: maññeti devo viya. Vīṇovādenāti “taṃ kiṃ maññasi, soṇa, yadā te vīṇāya tantiyo accāyatā
analyzed: mañña iti devaḥ viya vīṇā vādena ati tam kim maññasi soṇa yadā te vīṇāya tantiyaḥ accāyatā
translated: As if he were a god: like a god. With the lute-simile: “What do you think, Soṇa? When the strings of your lute were too tight, was your lute well tuned and easy to play? ‘No, venerable sir.’

original: honti, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṃ samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vāti? No hetaṃ, bhanteti.
analyzed: honti api nu te vīṇā tasmin samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vāti no hetam bhante iti
translated: When the strings were too loose, was your lute well tuned and easy to play? ‘No, venerable sir.’

original: Evameva kho, soṇa, accāraddhavīriyaṃ uddhaccāya saṃvattati, atisithilavīriyaṃ kosajjāya🔽saṃvattati. Tasmātiha tvaṃ, soṇa, vīriyasamataṃ adhiṭṭhaha, indriyānañca samataṃ
analyzed: evam eva kho soṇa accāraddha vīriyam uddhaccāya saṃvattati ati sithila vīriyam kosajjāya  saṃvattati tasmā ati ha tvam soṇa vīriya samatam adhiṭṭhahe indriyānañca samatam
translated: So too, Soṇa, over-exerted energy leads to restlessness, and over- slack energy leads to sloth and torpor.

original: paṭivijjhā”ti evaṃ vīṇaṃ upamaṃ katvā pavattitena vīṇopamovādena. Vīriyasamathayojanatthāyāti
analyzed: paṭivijjhāti evam vīṇam upamam katvā pavattitena vīṇā upamovādena vīriya samatha yojana tthāya ati
translated: Therefore, Soṇa, you should seek the middle way of energy, and you should seek to understand the equanimity of the faculties.” The simile of the lute is given in this way. With the lute-simile discourse: with the discourse called the “Lute-simile” .

original: vīriyassa samathena yojanatthāya.
analyzed: vīriyassa samathena yojana tthāya
translated: For the purpose of showing the middle way of energy: for the purpose of showing the middle way of energy.

original: Soṇakuṭikaṇṇattheravatthu
analyzed: soṇa kuṭi kaṇṇa tthera vatthu
translated: The story of the Elder Soṇa Kuṭikaṇṇa

original: 206. Aṭṭhame kuṭikaṇṇoti vuccatīti “koṭikaṇṇo”ti vattabbe “kuṭikaṇṇo”ti voharīyati.
analyzed: aṭṭhame kuṭikaṇṇo ti vuccati iti koṭikaṇṇo ti vattabbe kuṭikaṇṇo ti voharīyati
translated: . In the eighth, called Kuṭikaṇṇa: “Koṭikaṇṇa” should be said, but “Kuṭikaṇṇa” is used.

original: Kulaghare bhavā kulagharikā. Sā kira avantiraṭṭhe kulaghare mahāvibhavassa seṭṭhissa
analyzed: kula ghare bhavā kulagharikā sā kira avantiraṭṭhe kula ghare mahā vibhavassa seṭṭhissa
translated: She was the wife of a rich merchant in a town in the Avanti country.

original: bhariyā. Dasabalassa dhammakathaṃ sutvā sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāya cintesīti idaṃ
analyzed: bhariyā dasabalassa dhamma katham sutvā sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāya cintesi iti idam
translated: After hearing the Dhamma from the Ten-Powered One, she was established in the fruit of stream-entry and thought:

original: aṅguttarabhāṇakānaṃ matena vuttaṃ. Suttanipātaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “sapariso bhagavantaṃ🔽upasaṅkamma dhammadesanaṃ assosi, na ca kañci visesaṃ adhigañchi. Kasmā? So hi dhammaṃ🔽suṇanto hemavataṃ anussaritvā ‘āgato nu kho me sahāyako, no’ti disādisaṃ oloketvā🔽taṃ apassanto ‘vañcito me sahāyo, yo evaṃ vicittappaṭibhānaṃ bhagavato desanaṃ na
analyzed: aṅguttara bhāṇakānam matena vuttam suttanipāta ṭṭhakathāyam pana sa parisaḥ bhagavantam  upasaṅkamma dhamma desanam assosi na ca kañci visesam adhigañchi kasmā saḥ hi dhammaṃ  suṇantaḥ hemavatam anussaritvā āgataḥ nu khalu me sahāyakaḥ no ti disādisam oloketvā  tam a passantaḥ vañcitaḥ me sahāyaḥ yaḥ evam vicitta paṭibhānam bhagavataḥ desanam na
translated: This is according to the opinion of the compilers of the Aṅguttara Nikāya. But in the commentary to the Suttanipāta it is said:

original: suṇātī’ti vikkhittacitto ahosī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: suṇāti iti vikkhitta cittaḥ ahosi iti vuttam
translated: “He approached the Blessed One with his retinue and listened to the Dhamma, but he did not attain any distinction. Why was that? For while he was listening to the Dhamma he remembered Hemavata and thought: ‘Has my friend come or not? ’ He looked in all directions, but he did not see him. Then he thought: ‘My friend has deceived me. He has not come to hear the Blessed One’s teaching, which is so well-expounded and so well-revealed. ’ Thus his mind was distracted.”

original: Yasmā paṭisandhijātiabhinikkhamanabodhiparinibbānesveva dvattiṃsa pubbanimittāni
analyzed: yasmā paṭisandhi jāti abhinikkhamana bodhi parinibbānesu eva dvattiṃsa pubba nimittāni
translated: The thirty-two portents appeared only in regard to the conception in the womb, the birth, the Great Renunciation, the enlightenment, and the parinibbāna.

original: hutvāva paṭivigacchanti, na ciraṭṭhitikāni honti, dhammacakkappavattane pana tāni🔽savisesāni hutvā cirataraṃ ṭhatvā nirujjhanti, tasmā vuttaṃ – “tiyojanasahassaṃ himavantaṃ🔽akālapupphitaṃ disvā”tiādi. Aggabalakāyāti sabbapurato gacchantā balakāyā. Kena pupphitabhāvaṃ🔽jānāsīti kena kāraṇena himavantassa pupphitabhāvaṃ jānāsīti, yena kāraṇena imaṃ akālapupphapāṭihāriyaṃ🔽jātaṃ, taṃ jānāsīti vuttaṃ hoti. Tassa pavattitabhāvanti tassa dhammacakkassa bhagavatā
analyzed: hutvā ava paṭivigacchanti na cira ṭṭhitikāni honti dhamma cakka ppavattane pana tāni  sa visesāni hutvā cirataram ṭhatvā nirujjhanti tasmā vuttam ti yojana sahassam himavantam  akāla pupphitam disvā atiādi agga balakāyā ati sabba puratas gacchantā balakāyā kena pupphita bhāvam  jānāsi iti kena kāraṇena himavantassa pupphita bhāvam jānāsi iti yena kāraṇena imaṃ akāla puppha pāṭihāriyam  jātam tam jānāsi iti vuttam hoti tassa pavattita bhāvanti tassa dhammacakkassa bhagavatā
translated: and they do not last long. But in the case of the setting up of the Wheel of the Dhamma they last longer and longer,

original: pavattitabhāvaṃ. Sadde nimittaṃ gaṇhīti sadde ākāraṃ sallakkhesi. Tatoti “ahaṃ ‘etaṃ🔽amatadhammaṃ tampi jānāpessāmī’ti tava santikaṃ āgatosmī”ti yaṃ vuttaṃ, tadanantaranti attho.
analyzed: pavattita bhāvam sadde nimittam gaṇhi iti sadde ākāram sallakkhesi tatas ti aham etam 🔽amata dhammam tam pi jānāpessāmi iti tava santikam āgataḥ asmi iti yat vuttam tad anantaram ti attho
translated: and so it was said: ‘Seeing the Himalayas in full flower for three leagues round’ and so on. ‘The foremost army’: the army that goes in front of all. ‘By what do you know’ means ‘By what reason do you know the Himalayas to be in full flower?’ What is meant is: ‘By what reason has this miracle of untimely flowering taken place? Do you know that?’ ‘The occurrence of that’: the occurrence of that Wheel of the Dhamma by the Blessed One. ‘He took a mental note of the sound’: he observed the mode of the sound. ‘After that’: after the Blessed One had said ‘I have come to you, thinking “I will make him understand the deathless state” ’, after that, is the meaning.

original: Sātāgiro hemavatassa buddhuppādaṃ kathetvā taṃ bhagavato santikaṃ ānetukāmo “ajja
analyzed: sātāgiraḥ hemavatassa buddhuppādam kathetvā tam bhagavato santikam ānetu kāmaḥ ajja
translated: The bird Sātāgira, after telling the story of the Buddha’s appearance in the world, wanted to bring the Blessed One to the place where he was. Therefore he said the stanza beginning with “Today.”

original: pannaraso”tiādigāthamāha. Tattha ajjāti ayaṃ rattindivo pakkhagaṇanato pannaraso,
analyzed: pannaraso ti ādi gātham āha tattha ajjā ti ayam rattindivaḥ pakkha gaṇanato panna rasaḥ
translated: Herein, today means this day and night, the fifteenth day of the half-month, reckoned by the lunar mansions.

original: upavasitabbato uposatho. Tīsu vā uposathesu ajja pannaraso uposatho, na cātuddasiuposatho,
analyzed: upavasitabbataḥ uposathaḥ tīsu vā uposathesu ajja pannarasaḥ uposathaḥ na cātuddasi uposathaḥ
translated: Or else, today is the fifteenth day of the half-month, the Uposatha day, not the fourteenth day of the half-month, nor the day of the full moon.

original: na sāmaggīuposatho. Divi bhavāni dibbāni, dibbāni ettha atthīti dibbāni. Kāni tāni?🔽Rūpāni. Tañhi rattiṃ devānaṃ dasasahassilokadhātuto sannipatitānaṃ sarīravatthābharaṇavimānappabhāhi
analyzed: na sāmaggī uposathaḥ divi bhavāni dibbāni dibbāni ettha atthi iti dibbāni kāni tāni  rūpāni tat hi rattim devānam dasa sahassi lokadhātutaḥ sannipatitānam sarīra vattha ābharaṇa vimāna ppabhāhi
translated: Divine means heavenly. Heavenly things are here. What are they?

original: abbhādiupakkilesavirahitāya candappabhāya ca sakalajambudīpo alaṅkato ahosīti ativiya
analyzed: abbha ādi upakkilesa virahitāya candappabhāya ca sakala jambudīpaḥ alaṅkataḥ ahosi iti
translated: Forms. For on that night, the whole of Jambudīpa was adorned with the bodily radiance of the gods who had assembled from the ten thousand world systems, with the radiance of their garments and ornaments, and with the radiance of their palaces, and with the radiance of the moon, which was free from the obscurations of clouds, mist, and so on. Therefore it was

original: alaṅkato ca parivisuddhidevassa bhagavato sarīrappabhāya. Tenāha – “dibbā ratti upaṭṭhitā”ti.
analyzed: ca parivisuddhidevassa bhagavato sarīra ppabhāya tena āha dibbā ratti upaṭṭhitā ti
translated: adorned exceedingly. And it was adorned with the radiance of the Blessed One, who was a god of the highest purity. Hence it was said: “The heavenly night is come.”

original: Evaṃ rattiguṇavaṇṇanāpadesenapi sahāyassa cittaṃ pasādaṃ janento buddhuppādaṃ kathetvā
analyzed: evam ratti guṇa vaṇṇanā apadesena api sahāyassa cittam pasādam janentaḥ buddhuppādam kathetvā
translated: Thus, by the words “the qualities of the night,” he gladdened his friend’s mind by telling him of the Buddha’s appearance.

original: āha – “anomanāmaṃ satthāraṃ, handa passāma gotama”nti. Tattha anomehi alāmakehi sabbākāraparipūrehi
analyzed: āha anoma nāmam satthāram handa passāma gotaman ti tattha anomehi alāmakehi sabba ākāra paripūrehi
translated: Then he said: “The Teacher named Anomā, let us see Gotama.” Herein, he is called Anomā because his name is Anomā, which is complete with all the qualities of the Noble Ones.

original: guṇehi nāmaṃ assāti anomanāmo. Tathā hissa “bujjhitā saccānīti buddho, bodhetā pajāyāti🔽buddho”tiādinā nayena buddhoti anomehi guṇehi nāmaṃ. “Bhaggarāgoti bhagavā, bhaggadosoti
analyzed: guṇehi nāmam assa ati anoma nāmaḥ tathā hi ssa bujjhitā saccāni iti buddhaḥ bodhetā pajāyāti  buddhaḥ iti ādinā nayena buddhaḥ iti guṇehi nāmam bhagga rāgaḥ iti bhagavā bhagga doso ti
translated: For his name is Anomā in the sense of “he who has awakened to the Truths,” and in the sense of “he who awakens the world.”

original: bhagavā”tiādinā nayena bhagavāti anomehi guṇehi nāmaṃ. Esa nayo “arahaṃ sammāsambuddho🔽vijjācaraṇasampanno”tiādīsu. Diṭṭhadhammikādiatthehi devamanusse anusāsati “imaṃ
analyzed: bhagavān iti ādinā nayena bhagavān ati guṇehi nāmam esa nayaḥ araham sammāsambuddhaḥ  vijjā ācaraṇa sampannaḥ ti ādīsu diṭṭhadhammika ādi atthehi deva manusse anusāsati imaṃ
translated: He is called Bhagavā because his name is Bhagavā, which is complete with the qualities of the Noble Ones.🔽The same method applies in the case of “Arahaṃ Sammāsambuddho,” etc. He teaches gods and men for the sake of the visible qualities of this very life, etc., saying: “Abandon this, undertake that.”

original: pajahatha, imaṃ samādāya vattathā”ti satthā. Taṃ anomanāmaṃ satthāraṃ. Handāti vacasāyatthe
analyzed: pajahatha imam samādāya vattatha ati satthā tam anoma nāmam satthāram handāti vacasāyatthe
translated: The Teacher named Anomā. Let us see Gotama. The word handa is a particle expressing a request.

original: nipāto. Passāmāti tena attānaṃ saha saṅgahetvā paccuppannabahuvacanaṃ. Gotamanti
analyzed: nipātaḥ passāma iti tena attānam saha saṅgahetvā paccuppanna bahuvacanam gotaman ti
translated: Passāma = “We will see.” The plural form is used in the present tense because the speaker refers to himself and others. Gotama = “Gotama.”

original: gotamagottaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – “satthā, na satthā”ti mā vimatiṃ akāsi, ekantabyavasito
analyzed: gotama gottam idam vuttam hoti satthā na satthā ati mā vimatim akāsi ekanta byavasitaḥ
translated: This means: “Do not be in doubt as to whether he is a teacher or not. He is a teacher.

original: hutvāva ehi passāma gotamanti.
analyzed: hutvā avaḥ ehi passāma gotamanti
translated: Having made this decision, come and see Gotama.”

original: Evaṃ vutte hemavato “ayaṃ sātāgiro ‘anomanāmaṃ satthāra’nti bhaṇanto tassa sabbaññutaṃ
analyzed: evam vutte hemavataḥ ayam sātāgiraḥ anoma nāmam satthāram ti bhaṇantaḥ tassa sabbaññu tam
translated: When this was said, Hemavata thought: “This Sātāgira, speaking of the teacher as ‘the one named Anoman,’

original: pakāseti, sabbaññuno ca dullabhā loke, sabbaññupaṭiññehi pūraṇādisadiseheva loko
analyzed: pakāseti sabbaññuno ca dullabhā loke sabbaññu paṭiññehi pūraṇa ādi sadisehi iva lokaḥ
translated: reveals his omniscience. And omniscience is rare in the world. The world is afflicted by those who claim to be omniscient, such as Pūraṇa Kassapa and others.

original: upadduto. So pana yadi sabbaññū, addhā tādilakkhaṇaṃ patto bhavissati, tena evaṃ
analyzed: upaddutaḥ saḥ pana yadi sabbaññū addhā ta ādi lakkhaṇam pattaḥ bhavissati tena evam
translated: But if he is omniscient, he must have attained the characteristics of a Tathāgata. Therefore

original: gahessāmī”ti cintetvā tādilakkhaṇaṃ pucchanto āha – “kacci mano”tiādi. Tattha kaccīti
analyzed: gahessāmi iti cintetvā ta ādi lakkhaṇam pucchantaḥ āha kacci manaḥ tiādi tattha kacci iti
translated: I will test him.” Thinking thus, he asked about the characteristics of a Tathāgata, saying: “Kacci mano” and so on. Here, kacci = “perhaps.”

original: pucchā. Manoti cittaṃ. Supaṇihitoti suṭṭhu ṭhapito acalo asampavedhī. Sabbesu bhūtesu
analyzed: pucchā mano ti cittam su paṇihito ti suṭṭhu ṭhapitaḥ acalaḥ a sampavedhī sabbesu bhūtesu
translated: Mano = mind. Supaṇihito = well-established, unshakable, unperturbed. Sabbesu bhūtesu = in all beings.

original: sabbabhūtesu. Tādinoti tādilakkhaṇaṃ pattasseva sato. Pucchā eva vā ayaṃ “so tava
analyzed: sabba bhūtesu tādino ti tad ādi lakkhaṇam pattassa iva sataḥ pucchā eva vā ayam so tava
translated: to all beings. Tādino: to one who has become such, who has attained the characteristic of suchness. Or this is a question: “To you who are such,

original: satthā sabbabhūtesu tādī, udāhu no”ti. Iṭṭhe aniṭṭhecāti evarūpe ārammaṇe. Saṅkappāti🔽vitakkā. Vasīkatāti vasaṃ gamitā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yaṃ taṃ satthāraṃ vadasi, tassa
analyzed: satthā sabba bhūtesu tādī udāhu no ti iṭṭhe aniṭṭhe ca ati evarūpe ārammaṇe saṅkappāti  vitakkā vasīkatā ati vasam gamitā idam vuttam hoti yam tam satthāram vadasi tassa
translated: To all beings. ‘To him’: to the one who has attained the state of being such. Or this is a question: ‘Is your teacher such to all beings or not? ‘ ‘To what is wished for and what is not wished for’: to such objects. ‘Thoughts’:

original: te satthuno kacci tādilakkhaṇaṃ sampattassa sato sabbabhūtesu mano supaṇihito, udāhu
analyzed: te satthuno kacci ta ādi lakkhaṇam sampattassa sataḥ sabba bhūtesu manaḥ su paṇihitaḥ udāhu
translated: conceptions. ‘Has mastery’: has come under control. This is what is meant: ‘The teacher you speak of, has his mind well-directed to all beings, having attained the state of being such? Or

original: yāva paccayaṃ na labhati, tāva supaṇihito viya khāyati. So vā te satthā kacci sabbabhūtesu
analyzed: yāva paccayam na labhati tāva su paṇihitaḥ viya khāyati saḥ vā te satthā kacci sabba bhūtesu
translated: does it seem well-directed only as long as he does not get the opportunity? Or is your teacher such to all beings,

analyzed: sattesu tādī udāhu no ye ca iṭṭha aniṭṭhesu ārammaṇesu rāga dosa vasena saṅkappāḥ uppajjeyyuṃ
translated: or not? And has he mastery over the thoughts that might arise through lust and hate towards desirable and undesirable objects,

original: tyāssa kacci vasīkatā, udāhu kadāci tesampi vasena vattatīti.
analyzed: kacci vasīkatā udāhu kadāci tesampi vasena vattati iti
translated: or does he sometimes act under their influence? ‘

original: Tīṇi vassānīti soṇassa pabbajitadivasato paṭṭhāya tīṇi vassāni. Tadā kira bhikkhū
analyzed: tīṇi vassāni iti soṇassa pabbajita divasato paṭṭhāya tīṇi vassāni tadā kira bhikkhū
translated: ‘Three years’: from the day of Soṇa’s going forth, three years had passed. It seems that at that time the bhikkhus

original: yebhuyyena majjhimadeseyeva vasiṃsu, tasmā tattha katipayā eva ahesuṃ. Te ca ekasmiṃ
analyzed: yebhuyyena vasiṃsu tasmā tattha katipayāḥ eva ahesum te ca ekasmin
translated: and they lived mostly in the Middle Country, so there were only a few of them there.

original: nigame eko dveti evaṃ visuṃ visuṃ vasiṃsu, therānañca katipaye bhikkhū ānetvā aññesu🔽ānīyamānesu pubbaṃ ānītā kenacideva karaṇīyena pakkamiṃsu, kañci kālaṃ āgametvā puna
analyzed: nigame ekaḥ dve iti evam visum visum vasiṃsu katipaye bhikkhū ānetvā aññesu  ānīyamānesu pubbam ānītā kenacid eva karaṇīyena pakkamiṃsu kañci kālam āgametvā puna
translated: They lived mostly in the Middle Country, so there were only a few of them there. And they lived in different places, one or two in each town. The elder monks brought some of them,🔽and when others were being brought, those already brought left on some pretext. After waiting for some time,

original: tesu ānīyamānesu itare pakkamiṃsu, evaṃ punappunaṃ ānayanena sannipāto cireneva ahosi,
analyzed: tesu ānīyamānesu itare evam punappunam ānayanena sannipātaḥ cirena iva ahosi
translated: when others were being brought, the first ones left again. Thus the gathering took place only after a long time, through the repeated bringing of monks.

original: thero ca tadā ekavihārī ahosi. Tena vuttaṃ – “tīṇi vassāni gaṇaṃ pariyesitvā”ti.🔽Tīṇi vassānīti ca accantasaṃyoge upayogavacanaṃ. Satthu adhippāyaṃ ñatvāti attano
analyzed: thero ca tadā eka vihārī ahosi tena vuttam tīṇi vassāni gaṇam pariyesitvā ati  tīṇi vassāni iti ca accanta saṃyoge upayoga vacanam satthu adhippāyam ñatvā iti attano
translated: And the elder monk was then living in a single dwelling. Hence it was said above: “After three years of seeking a gathering” .

original: āṇāpaneneva “iminā saddhiṃ ekagandhakuṭiyaṃ vasitukāmo bhagavā”ti satthu adhippāyaṃ
analyzed: āṇāpanena iva iminā saddhim eka gandhakuṭiyam vasitu kāmaḥ bhagavā ati satthu adhippāyam
translated: And “three years” is said with reference to the time of service in the case of the ultimate service. “Having understood the Master’s intention”: having understood the Master’s intention, thinking “The Blessed One wants to live in the same fragrant chamber with this one.”

original: jānitvā. Bhagavā kira yena saddhiṃ ekagandhakuṭiyaṃ vasitukāmo, tassa senāsanapaññattiyaṃ
analyzed: jānitvā bhagavā kira yena saddhim eka gandhakuṭiyam vasitu kāmo tassa senāsana paññattiyam
translated: The Blessed One, it seems, wants to live in the same fragrant chamber with the one whose dwelling he has arranged.

original: ānandattheraṃ āṇāpeti.
analyzed: ānandattheram āṇāpa iti
translated: he ordered the Elder Ānanda.

original: Ajjhokāse vītināmetvāti ajjhokāse nisajjāya vītināmetvā. Yasmā bhagavā āyasmato soṇassa

original: hoti. Dānaggaparivahanaketi dānaggadhuravahanake. Māpakoti divase divase parimitaparibbayadānavasena dhaññamāpako.
