analyzed: paṭivacana dānāya thinam iddha vinodana attham nava kkhattum anupariyāyati tena iva āha
translated: he went nine times to give an answer and to dispel his sloth and torpor. Therefore it is said:

original: “evañhissa ahosī”tiādi. Sesamettha suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: evam hissa ahosi itiādi sesam ettha su viññeyyam eva
translated: “This is how it happened to him.” The rest is easy to understand.

original: Uruvelakassapattheravatthu
analyzed: uruvela kassapattheravatthu
translated: The Story of the Elder Uruvelakassapa

original: 224. Dutiye yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ vitthārato vinayapāḷiyaṃ āgatameva.
analyzed: dutiye yat vattabbam tat vitthārataḥ vinaya pāḷiyam āgatam eva
translated: . What should be said about the second story has been said in detail in the Vinaya Piṭaka.

original: Kāḷudāyittheravatthu
analyzed: kāḷu dāyittheravatthu
translated: The Story of the Elder Kaludayi🔽.

original: 225. Tatiye gamanākappanti gamanākāraṃ. Sesamettha uttānameva.
analyzed: tatiye gamana ākappanti gamana ākāram sesam ettha uttānam eva
translated: In the third, the mode of going is the mode of going. The rest here is plain.

original: Bākulattheravatthu
analyzed: bākulattheravatthu
translated: The story of the Elder Bākula

original: 226. Catutthe nirābādhānanti ābādharahitānaṃ. Yathā “dvāvīsati dvattiṃsā”tiādimhi
analyzed: catutthe yathā dvāvīsati dvattiṃsa ati ādimhi
translated: In the fourth, of those free from affliction: of those free from sickness. Just as, when it should be said “twenty-two, thirty-two,”

original: vattabbe “bāvīsati bāttiṃsā”tiādīni vuccanti, evamevaṃ dve kulāni assāti dvikulo,
analyzed: vattabbe bāvīsati bāttiṃsa ati ādīni vuccanti evam evam dve kulāni assa ati dvi kulaḥ
translated: the words “twenty-two, thirty-two” are used, so too, it should be said “two families” ,

original: dvekuloti vā vattabbe bākuloti vuttanti āha – “bākuloti dvīsu kulesu vaḍḍhitattā
analyzed: dvekulo ti vā vattabbe bākulo ti vuttanti āha bākulo ti dvīsu kulesu vaḍḍhita ttā
translated: but the word “Bākula” is used instead. He said “Bākula” because he was brought up in two families.

original: evaṃladdhanāmo”ti. Upayogenāti ānubhāvena. Phāsukakāleti arogakāle. Gadduhanamattampīti🔽goduhanamattampi kālaṃ. Idha pana na sakalo goduhanakkhaṇo adhippeto, atha kho gāviṃ
analyzed: upayogena ati ānubhāvena phāsuka kāla iti aroga kāle iti  go duhana mattam pi kālam idha pana na sakalaḥ go duhana kkhaṇaḥ adhippetaḥ atha kho gāvim
translated: By means of his power: by means of his influence. For his comfort: for his health. Even for the time of a yoke’s length: even for the time of a yoke’s length.🔽But here the whole time of a yoke’s length is not intended, rather the time of a cow’s taking milk from one udder is intended.

original: thane gahetvā ekakhīrabinduduhanakālamattaṃ adhippetaṃ. Ārogyasālanti āturānaṃ arogabhāvakaraṇatthāya katasālaṃ.
analyzed: thane gahetvā eka khīra bindu duhana kāla mattam adhippetam ārogya sālanti aroga bhāva karaṇa tthāya kata sālam
translated: For the sake of health: a drink prepared for the sake of making the sick well.

original: Nimujjanummujjanavasenāti jāṇuppamāṇe udake thokaṃyeva nimujjanummujjanavasena. Chaḍḍetvā
analyzed: nimujjan ummujjana vasena ati jāṇuppamāṇe udake thokaṃyeva nimujjan ummujjana vasena chaḍḍetvā
translated: By means of submerging and emerging: by means of submerging and emerging in water up to the knees. Having discarded

original: palāyīti macchassa mukhasamīpeyeva chaḍḍetvā palāyi. Dārakassa tejenāti dārakassa🔽puññatejena. Māriyamānāva marantīti daṇḍādīhi pothetvā māriyamānāva maranti, na jālena🔽baddhatāmattena amāriyamānā. Nīhaṭamattova matoti nīhaṭakkhaṇeyeva mato. Tenassa🔽māraṇatthaṃ upakkamo na kato, yena upakkamena dārakassa ābādho siyā. Tanti macchaṃ.🔽Sakalamevāti avikalameva paripuṇṇāvayavameva. Na keḷāyatīti na nandati, kismiñci🔽na maññati. Piṭṭhito phālentīti dārakassa puññatejena piṭṭhito phālentī. Bheriṃ carāpetvāti🔽“puttaṃ labhi”nti ugghosanavasena bheriṃ carāpetvā. Pakatiṃ ācikkhīti attano puttabhāvaṃ
analyzed: palāyi iti macchassa mukha samīpeya iva chaḍḍetvā palāyi dārakassa tejena ati dārakassa  puñña tejena māriyamānā ava maranti iti daṇḍa ādīhi pothetvā māriyamānā ava maranti na jālena  baddha tā mattena a māriyamānā nīhaṭa mattaḥ uva mataḥ iti tena assa  māraṇa attham upakkamaḥ na kataḥ yena upakkamena dārakassa ābādhaḥ siyā tanti maccham  sakalam eva ati avikalam eva paripuṇṇa avayavam eva na keḷāyati iti na nandati kismiñcid  na maññati piṭṭhitaḥ phālentī iti dārakassa puñña tejena piṭṭhitaḥ phālentī bherim carāpetvā ati  puttam labhinti ugghosana vasena bherim carāpetvā pakatim ācikkhi iti attanaḥ putta bhāvam
translated: ‘Escaped’: he threw it down near the fish’s mouth and escaped. ‘By the merit of the boy’: by the merit of the boy🔽‘They died as if being killed’: they died as if being killed by being beaten with sticks and so on, not as if not being killed by being caught in a net.🔽‘They died as soon as caught’: they died as soon as they were caught. By that🔽no effort was made to kill them for the purpose of killing, by which effort there might have been a sickness in the boy. ‘That’: the fish.🔽‘The whole’: the complete, the perfect. ‘Does not rejoice’: does not delight, does not think of anything.🔽‘They split from behind’: they split from behind by the merit of the boy. ‘Having had a drum beaten’: having had a drum beaten in the proclamation🔽‘He has got a son’. ‘He told his own story’: he told his own state as a son.

original: kathesi. Kucchiyā dhāritattā amātā kātuṃ na sakkāti jananībhāvato amātā kātuṃ na
analyzed: kathesi kucchiyāḥ a mātā kātum na sakkāti jananī bhāvataḥ a mātā kātum na
translated: He threw it down near the fish’s mouth and ran away. ‘By the power of the boy’s merit’: by the power of the merit of the boy. ‘They die as if they were being killed’: they die as if they were being killed by being beaten with sticks and so on, not as if they were not being killed by being caught in a net. ‘They die as soon as they are caught’: they die as soon as they are caught. ‘He did not make an effort to kill it’: he did not make an effort by which the boy might have become ill. ‘It’: the fish. ‘The whole’: the complete, undamaged. ‘He did not rejoice’: he did not delight, he did not think of anything. ‘They split it open from behind’: they split it open from behind by the power of the boy’s merit. ‘Having had a proclamation made with beaten gongs’: having had a proclamation made with beaten gongs in order to announce ‘He has obtained a son’. ‘He told his true story’: he told his true story of being a son. ‘Because she carried him in her womb, she could not be a stepmother’: because she was his mother, she could not be a stepmother.

original: sakkā. Macchaṃ gaṇhantāpīti macchaṃ vikkiṇitvā gaṇhantāpi. Tathā gaṇhantā ca tappariyāpannaṃ
analyzed: sakkā maccham gaṇhantā api iti maccham vikkiṇitvā gaṇhantā api tathā gaṇhantā ca tat pariyāpannam
translated: It is possible. Those who catch fish: those who catch fish and sell them. And those who catch them catch all that is included in them.

original: sabbaṃ gaṇhanti nāmāti āha – “vakkayakanādīni bahi katvā gaṇhantā nāma natthī”ti.
analyzed: sabbam gaṇhanti nāma ati āha vakkayakana ādīni bahi katvā gaṇhantā nāma natthi iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “There are none who catch them after throwing out the entrails and so on.”

original: Ayampi amātā kātuṃ na sakkāti dinnaputtabhāvato na sakkā.
analyzed: ayam pi a mātā kātum na sakkā ati dinna putta bhāvataḥ na sakkā
translated: This one cannot be made a mother, because he cannot be made a son given to her.

original: Sobhitattheravatthu
analyzed: sobhitattheravatthu
translated: The story of the Elder Sobhita

original: 227. Pañcamaṃ uttānatthameva.
analyzed: pañcamam uttānattham eva
translated: . The fifth is clear in meaning.

original: Upālittheravatthu🔽228. Chaṭṭhe bhārukacchakavatthunti aññataro kira bhārukacchadesavāsī bhikkhu supinante
analyzed: upālittheravatthu  chaṭṭhe bhārukacchaka vatthunti aññataraḥ kira bhārukaccha desa vāsī bhikkhu
translated: The story of the Elder Upāli

original: purāṇadutiyikāya methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevitvā “assamaṇo ahaṃ vibbhamissāmī”ti bhārukacchaṃ
analyzed: purāṇa dutiyikāya methunam dhammam paṭisevitvā a samaṇaḥ aham vibbhamissāmi iti bhārukaccham
translated: . In the sixth, in the case of the man from Bharukaccha: it seems that a certain bhikkhu living in the Bharukaccha country had sexual intercourse in a dream with his former wife. He thought, “I am no recluse. I shall go forth.”

original: gacchanto antarāmagge āyasmantaṃ upāliṃ passitvā etamatthaṃ ārocesi. Āyasmā upāli,
analyzed: gacchantaḥ antara āmagge āyasmantam upālim passitvā etam attham ārocesi āyasmai upāli
translated: As he was going to Bharukaccha, he met the venerable Upāli on the way and told him what he had done. The venerable Upāli

original: evamāha – “anāpatti, āvuso, supinantenā”ti. Yasmā supinante avisayattā evaṃ hoti.
analyzed: evam āha anāpatti āvuso supin antena ati yasmā supin ante a visayattā evam hoti
translated: said: “There is no offence, friend, in a dream.” Because there is no mastery then.

original: Tasmā upālitthero bhagavatā avinicchitapubbampi imaṃ vatthuṃ nayaggāhena evaṃ vinicchini.
analyzed: tasmai upāli ttheraḥ bhagavatā a vinicchita pubbam pi imam vatthum naya ggāhena evam
translated: So the Elder Upāli, without having had the matter settled by the Blessed One, settled it by a principle of construction.

original: Gahapatino dve dārakā honti putto ca bhāgineyyo ca. Atha so gahapati gilāno hutvā
analyzed: gahapatinaḥ dve dārakāḥ honti putto ca bhāgineyyaḥ ca atha saḥ gahapati gilānaḥ hutvā
translated: A certain householder had two children, a son and a nephew. Then the householder fell sick.

original: āyasmantaṃ ajjukaṃ etadavoca – “imaṃ, bhante, okāsaṃ yo imesaṃ dārakānaṃ saddho hoti🔽pasanno, tassa ācikkheyyāsī”ti. Tena ca samayena tassa ca gahapatino bhāgineyyo saddho🔽hoti pasanno. Athāyasmā ajjuko taṃ okāsaṃ tassa dārakassa ācikkhi. So tena sāpateyyena
analyzed: ā ayasmantam ajjukam etat avoca imam bhante okāsam yaḥ imesam dārakānam saddhaḥ hoti  pasannaḥ tassa ācikkheyyāsi iti tena ca samayena tassa ca gahapatino bhāgineyyaḥ saddho  hoti pasannaḥ atha ayasmai ajjuko tam okāsam tassa dārakassa ācikkhi saḥ tena sāpateyyena
translated: He said to the venerable Ajjuka, “Venerable sir, I have this piece of property.🔽If any of these two children has faith and confidence in the Blessed One,🔽tell him about it.” Now at that time the nephew of the householder had faith and confidence.

original: kuṭumbañca saṇṭhapesi, dānañca paṭṭhapesi. Atha tassa gahapatino putto āyasmantaṃ
analyzed: kuṭumbañca saṇṭhapesi dānañca paṭṭhapesi atha tassa gahapatino putto āyasmantam
translated: So the venerable Ajjuka told him about the piece of property. He established a household with that property and he instituted a festival of giving.🔽Then the son of the householder said to the venerable Ānanda,

original: ānandaṃ etadavoca – “ko nu kho, bhante ānanda, pituno dāyajjo putto vā bhāgineyyo
analyzed: ānandam etat avoca kaḥ nu khalu bhante ānanda pitunaḥ dāyajjaḥ puttaḥ vā bhāgineyyaḥ
translated: “Venerable sir, Ānanda, who is the father’s heir, the son or the nephew?”🔽“The son, friend, is the father’s heir.”

original: vā”ti. Putto kho, āvuso, pituno dāyajjoti. Āyasmā, bhante, ayyo ajjuko amhākaṃ sāpateyyaṃ
analyzed: vāti putto kho āvuso pituno āyasmā bhante ayyaḥ ajjukaḥ amhākam sāpateyyam
translated: “Venerable sir, our venerable uncle Ajjuka

original: amhākaṃ methunakassa ācikkhīti. Assamaṇo, āvuso, so ajjukoti. Athāyasmā ajjuko āyasmantaṃ🔽ānandaṃ etadavoca – “dehi me, āvuso ānanda, vinicchaya”nti. Te ubhopi upālittherassa
analyzed: amhākam methunakassa ācikkhi iti assamaṇaḥ āvuso saḥ ajjukaḥ iti atha ayasmai ajjukaḥ āyasmantam  ānandam etat avoca dehi me āvuso ānanda te ubho pi upāli ttherassa
translated: “Tell my wife.” “He’s not a monastic, friend.” The Venerable Ajjuka then said to the Venerable Ānanda,🔽“Give me a ruling, friend Ānanda.” They both went to the elder Upāli.

original: santikaṃ agamaṃsu. Athāyasmā upāli, āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca – “yo nu kho, āvuso
analyzed: santikam agamaṃsu atha ayasmai upāli āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca yaḥ nu khalu āvuso
translated: The Venerable Upāli said to the Venerable Ānanda,

original: ānanda, sāmikena ‘imaṃ okāsaṃ itthannāmassa ācikkhā’ti vutto, tassa ācikkhati, kiṃ
analyzed: ānanda sāmikena imam okāsam itthannāmassa ācikkhāti vuttaḥ tassa ācikkhati kiṃ
translated: “If someone is told by his wife, ‘Tell so-and-so about this opportunity,’ and he tells her,

original: so āpajjatī”ti? Na, bhante, kiñci āpajjati antamaso dukkaṭamatthampīti. Ayaṃ, āvuso,
analyzed: saḥ āpajjati iti na bhante kiñci āpajjati antamasaḥ dukkaṭa mattham pi iti ayam āvuso
translated: what does he commit?” “Nothing, Sir.” “This Venerable Ajjuka

original: āyasmā ajjuko sāmikena “imaṃ okāsaṃ itthannāmassa ācikkhā”ti vutto tassa ācikkhati,
analyzed: āyasman ajjukaḥ sāmikena imam okāsam itthannāmassa ācikkhāti vuttaḥ tassa ācikkhati
translated: was told by his wife, ‘Tell so-and-so about this opportunity,’ and he told her.

original: anāpatti, āvuso, āyasmato ajjukassāti. Bhagavā taṃ sutvā “sukathitaṃ, bhikkhave,
analyzed: anāpatti āvuso āyasmataḥ ajjukassa ati bhagavā tam sutvā su kathitam bhikkhave
translated: There’s no offense for the Venerable Ajjuka.” After hearing this, the Buddha said,

original: upālinā”ti vatvā sādhukāramadāsi, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kumārakassapavatthu pana heṭṭhā āgatameva.
analyzed: upālinā ati vatvā sādhukāram adāsi tam sandhāya itam vuttam kumārakassapa vatthu pana heṭṭhā āgatam eva
translated: “Monks, Upāli has spoken well. He deserves praise.” And he gave his approval. The case of Kumārakassapa was dealt with above.

original: Channaṃ khattiyānanti bhaddiyo sakyarājā anuruddho ānando bhagu kimilo devadattoti imesaṃ channaṃ khattiyānaṃ. Pasādhakoti maṇḍayitā. Pāḷiyanti saṅghabhedakkhandhakapāḷiyanti.
analyzed: channam khattiyānam ti bhaddiyaḥ sakya rājā anuruddhaḥ ānandaḥ kimilaḥ devadatto ti imesam channam khattiyānam maṇḍayitā pāḷiyanti saṅgha bheda khandhaka pāḷiyanti
translated: “The six nobles”: Bhaddiya, the king of the Sakyans, Anuruddha, Ananda, Bhagu, Kimbila, and Devadatta. “The one who was the beautifier”: the one who was the beautifier of the assembly. “The text”: the text of the Khandhaka on a Schism in the Community.

original: Nandakattheravatthu
analyzed: nandakattheravatthu
translated: The Story of the Elder Nandaka

original: 229. Sattame ekasamodhāneti ekasmiṃ samodhāne, ekasmiṃ sannipāteti attho. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: sattame eka samodhāne iti ekasmim samodhāne ekasmim sannipāte iti attho sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: In the seventh story “in one assembly” means in one gathering, in one convocation. The rest is easy to understand.

original: Nandattheravatthu🔽230. Aṭṭhame na taṃ catusampajaññavasena aparicchinditvā oloketīti sātthakasappāyagocaraasammohasampajaññasaṅkhātānaṃ
analyzed: nandattheravatthu  aṭṭhame na tam catu sampajañña vasena a paricchinditvā oloketi iti sa atthaka sa pāya gocara asammoha sampajañña saṅkhātānam
translated: The Story of the Elder Nanda

original: catunnaṃ sampajaññānaṃ vasena aparicchinditvā taṃ disaṃ na oloketi. So hi āyasmā
analyzed: catunnam sampajaññānam vasena a paricchinditvā tam disam na oloketi saḥ hi āyasmā
translated: In the eighth story “he did not look in that direction, having not discerned it by means of the four kinds of clear knowledge” means that he did not look in that direction, having not discerned it by means of the four kinds of clear knowledge called the clear knowledge of the object that is profitable and of the object that is not profitable, the clear knowledge of the object that is far and of the object that is near, and the clear knowledge of non-delusion regarding the object that is the resort of the profitable.🔽For this venerable elder

original: “yamevāhaṃ indriyesu aguttadvārataṃ nissāya sāsane anabhiratiādivippakārappatto,
analyzed: yam eva aham indriyesu a gutta dvāra tam nissāya sāsane anabhirati ādi vippakāra ppatto
translated: “I have come to disaffection with the spiritual life because of my failure to guard the doors of the sense faculties.🔽I will restrain them well.”

original: tameva suṭṭhu niggahessāmī”ti ussāhajāto balavahirottappo, tattha ca katādhikārattā
analyzed: tam eva suṭṭhu niggahessāmi iti ussāha jātaḥ bala vahira uttappaḥ tattha ca kata adhikāra ttā
translated: He was full of zeal and had a strong sense of moral shame and moral dread. And because he had already done his duty in that respect,

original: indriyasaṃvaro ukkaṃsapāramippatto catusampajaññaṃ amuñcitvāva sabbadisaṃ āloketi.
analyzed: indriya saṃvaro ukkaṃsa pārami patto catu sampajaññam a muñcitvā ava sabbadisam āloketi
translated: The restraint of the faculties is the perfection of the head. Without letting go of the four kinds of full awareness, he looks around in all directions.

original: Vuttañcetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: vuttam ca itam bhagavatā
translated: And this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Sace, bhikkhave, nandassa puratthimā disā āloketabbā hoti, sabbaṃ cetaso samannāharitvā🔽nando puratthimaṃ disaṃ āloketi ‘evaṃ me puratthimaṃ disaṃ ālokayato nābhijjhādomanassā
analyzed: sace bhikkhave nandassa puratthimā disā āloketabbā hoti sabbam cetasaḥ samannāharitvā  nando puratthimam disam āloketi evam me puratthimam disam ālokayataḥ na abhijjhā domanassā
translated: “If, bhikkhus, the eastern direction should be the direction for him to look, then, having concentrated his whole being,

original: pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāsavissantī’ti. Itiha tattha sampajāno hoti. Sace, bhikkhave,
analyzed: pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ anvāsavissanti iti iti ha tattha sampajānaḥ hoti sace bhikkhave
translated: Nandaka looks to the eastern direction, thinking, ‘As I look to the eastern direction in this way, no evil unwholesome states such as covetousness and displeasure will invade me.’ Thus he is clearly aware of that. If, bhikkhus,

original: nandassa pacchimā disā, uttarā disā, dakkhiṇā disā, uddhaṃ, adho, anudisā anuviloketabbā
analyzed: nandassa pacchimā disā uttarā disā dakkhiṇā disā uddham adhas anudisā anuviloketabbā
translated: the western direction, the northern direction, the southern direction, above, below, and across are the directions for him to look, then, having concentrated his whole being,

original: hoti, sabbaṃ cetaso samannāharitvā nando anudisaṃ anuviloketi ‘evaṃ me anudisaṃ anuvilokayato…pe… sampajāno hotī”’ti.
analyzed: hoti sabbam cetasaḥ samannāharitvā nandaḥ anudisam anuviloketi evam me anudisam anuvilokayatā upe sampajānaḥ hoti iti
translated: Nandaka looks across, thinking, ‘As I look across in this way, no evil unwholesome states such as covetousness and displeasure will invade me.’ Thus he is clearly aware of that” .

original: Abhisekagehapavesanaāvāhamaṅgalesu vattamānesūti idha tīṇi maṅgalāni vuttāni, vinayaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: abhiseka geha pavesana āvāha maṅgalesu vattamānesu iti idha tīṇi maṅgalāni vuttāni vinaya ṭṭhakathāyam
translated: At the time of the royal consecration, the entering of the house, and the auspicious invitation: here three kinds of auspiciousness are mentioned. In the Vinaya Commentary

original: pana “taṃ divasameva nandakumārassa kesavissajjanaṃ, paṭṭabandho, gharamaṅgalaṃ,🔽chattamaṅgalaṃ, āvāhamaṅgalanti pañca maṅgalāni hontī”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha kulamariyādavasena
analyzed: pana tam divasam eva nanda kumārassa kesa vissajjanam paṭṭabandhaḥ ghara maṅgalam  chatta maṅgalam āvāha maṅgalanti pañca maṅgalāni honti iti vuttam tattha kula mariyāda vasena
translated: But it is said that on that very day there were five auspicious ceremonies for Prince Nanda: the ceremony of shaving his hair, the ceremony of binding on the armour, the ceremony of entering the house,

original: kesoropanaṃ kesavissajjanaṃ. Yuvarājapaṭṭabandhanaṃ paṭṭabandho. Abhinavagharappavesanamaho

original: akaṃsu. Mātucchanti cūḷamātaraṃ. Mātubhaginī hi mātucchāti vuccati. Kalahavivādasuttapariyosāneti
analyzed: cūḷa mātaram mātu bhaginī hi mātucchāti vuccati kalaha vivāda sutta pariyosāne ti
translated: At the end of the Discourse on Quarrels and Disputes:

original: “kutopahūtā kalahā vivādā”tiādinā suttanipāte āgatassa kalahavivādasuttassa pariyosāne.
analyzed: kutopahūtā kalahā vivādā ati ādinā sutta nipāte āgatassa kalahavivāda suttassa pariyosāne
translated: at the end of the Discourse on Quarrels and Disputes in the Sutta Nipāta, which begins thus, “What is the source of quarrels and disputes? ” .

original: Idañca aṅguttarabhāṇakānaṃ kathāmaggānusārena vuttaṃ. Apare pana “tasmiṃyeva suttanipāte
analyzed: idam ca aṅguttara bhāṇakānam kathā magga anusārena vuttam apare pana tasmin yeva suttanipāte
translated: But others say that it is at the end of the Attadaṇḍa Sutta, which is found in the same Sutta Nipāta beginning thus:

original: ‘attadaṇḍābhayaṃ jāta’ntiādinā āgatassa attadaṇḍasuttassa pariyosāne”ti vadanti.
analyzed: attadaṇḍa abhayam jāta nti ādinā āgatassa attadaṇḍa suttassa pariyosānā iti vadanti
translated: ‘Fear of self-punishment arose’ .

original: Nikkhamitvā pabbajitānanti ettha ehibhikkhupabbajjāya ete pabbajitāti vadanti. Teneva
analyzed: nikkhamitvā pabbajitānan ti ettha ehi bhikkhu pabbajjāya ete pabbajitā ti vadanti tena iva
translated: ‘Having gone forth after going forth’: they went forth by the going forth as a bhikkhu. Accordingly,

original: suttanipāte attadaṇḍasuttasaṃvaṇṇanāya vuttaṃ – “desanāpariyosāne pañcasatā sākiyakumārā
analyzed: sutta nipāte attadaṇḍa sutta saṃvaṇṇanāya vuttam desanā pariyosāne pañcasatā sākiya kumārā
translated: it is said in the commentary to the Attadaṇḍa Sutta in the Sutta Nipāta: ‘At the end of the teaching, five hundred young men of the Sākiya clan

original: koḷiyakumārā ca ehibhikkhupabbajjāya pabbajitā. Te gahetvā bhagavā mahāvanaṃ pāvisī”ti.
analyzed: koḷiya kumārā ca ehibhikkhupabbajjāya pabbajitā te gahetvā bhagavā mahā vanam pāvisi iti
translated: and five hundred young men of the Koḷiya clan went forth by the going forth as bhikkhus. Taking them with him, the Blessed One entered the Great Wood’ .

original: Sesamettha suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: sesam ettha su viññeyyam eva
translated: The rest here is quite clear in meaning.

original: Khemātherīvatthu
analyzed: khemātherīvatthu
translated: The Story of the Elder Nun Khemā

original: 236. Dutiye parapariyāpannā hutvāti paresaṃ dāsī hutvā. Suvaṇṇarasapiñjaro ahosīti suvaṇṇarasapiñjaro viya ahosi.
analyzed: dutiye para pariyāpannā hutvā ati paresam dāsī hutvā suvaṇṇa rasa piñjaro ahosi iti suvaṇṇa rasa piñjaraḥ viya ahosi
translated: In the second story, ‘having become the property of others’ means having become the slaves of others. ‘She was like a golden palmyra’: she was like a golden palmyra tree.🔽‘Like a monkey in a snare’: just as a monkey, having made a snare of creepers,

original: Makkaṭakova jālanti yathā nāma makkaṭako suttajālaṃ katvā majjhaṭṭhāne nābhimaṇḍale
analyzed: yathā nāma makkaṭakaḥ sutta jālam katvā majjha ṭṭhāne nābhi maṇḍale
translated: at the middle of it makes a knot for his navel

original: nipanno pariyante patitaṃ paṭaṅgaṃ vā makkhikaṃ vā vegena gantvā vijjhitvā tassa
analyzed: nipannaḥ pariyante patitam paṭaṅgam vā makkhikam vā vegena gantvā vijjhitvā tassa
translated: Just as a snake, when it sees a fly or a bee sitting on a wall or a tree-trunk, etc.,

original: rasaṃ pivitvā punāgantvā tasmiṃyeva ṭhāne nipajjati, evameva ye sattā rāgarattā dosapaduṭṭhā
analyzed: rasam pivitvā punar āgantvā tasmin yeva ṭhāne nipajjati evam eva ye sattāḥ rāga rattāḥ dosa paduṭṭhāḥ
translated: goes quickly, seizes it, and after killing it, swallows it, and then returns to its former place and lies there; so too, those beings who are infatuated with lust, corrupted by hatred,

original: mohamūḷhā sayaṃkataṃ taṇhāsotaṃ anupatanti, te taṃ samatikkamituṃ na sakkonti, evaṃ
analyzed: moha mūḍhā sayaṃkatam taṇhā sotam anupatanti te tam samatikkamitum na sakkonti evam
translated: and confused by delusion follow the stream of craving which they themselves have created, and they are unable to cross it. So it is difficult to cross.

original: duratikkamaṃ. Etampi chetvāna vajanti dhīrāti paṇḍitā etaṃ bandhanaṃ chinditvā anapekkhino
analyzed: duratikkamam etam pi chetvāna vajanti paṇḍitāḥ etam bandhanam chinditvā anapekkhinaḥ
translated: Having cut this (stream) the wise go forth: the wise, the clever, having cut this fetter, without looking back,

original: nirālayā hutvā arahattamaggena sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ pahāya vajanti gacchantīti attho.
analyzed: nirālayāḥ hutvā arahatta maggena sabbam dukkham pahāya vajanti gacchanti iti attho
translated: without attachment, having abandoned all suffering by means of the path of arahatship, go forth, they go, is the meaning.

original: Uppalavaṇṇātherīvatthu
analyzed: uppalavaṇṇā therīvatthu
translated: The Story of the Elder Nun Uppalavaṇṇā

original: 237. Tatiyaṃ uttānatthameva.
analyzed: tatiyam uttānattham eva
translated: The third (story) is clear in its meaning.

original: Paṭācārātherīvatthu
analyzed: paṭa ācāra ātherī vatthu
translated: The Story of the Elder Nun Paṭācārā

original: 238. Catutthe paṭihārasatenapīti dvārasatenapi. Paṭihārasaddo hi dvāre dovārike ca dissati. Kulasabhāganti attano gehasamīpaṃ.
analyzed: catutthe paṭihāra satena api iti dvāra satena api paṭihāra saddo hi dvāre dovārike ca dissati kula sabhā ganti attanaḥ geha samīpam
translated: In the fourth (story), with a hundred shields: with a hundred doors. For the word paṭihāra is found in the sense of door and door-keeper. The family’s dwelling: the vicinity of her own house.

original: Tāṇāyāti tāṇabhāvāya patiṭṭhānatthāya. Bandhavāti putte ca pitaro ca ṭhapetvā avasesā🔽ñātisuhajjā. Antakenādhipannassāti maraṇena abhibhūtassa. Pavattiyañhi puttādayo
analyzed: tāṇāya ati tāṇa bhāvāya patiṭṭhāna tthāya bandhavā ti putte ca pitaro ca ṭhapetvā avasesā  ñāti suhajjāḥ antakena adhipannassa ati maraṇena abhibhūtassa pavattiyam hi putta ādayaḥ
translated: For protection: for the sake of being a refuge, for the sake of being a support. For relatives: for the sake of relatives other than parents and children.

original: annapānādidānena ceva uppannakiccanittharaṇena ca tāṇā hutvāpi maraṇakāle kenaci
analyzed: anna pāna ādi dānena ca iva uppanna kicca nittharaṇena ca tāṇā hutvā api maraṇa kāle kenacid
translated: When overcome by death: when overcome by death. For although parents and children and so on are a refuge and a protection for one who is overcome by death,

original: upāyena maraṇaṃ paṭibāhituṃ asamatthatāya tāṇatthāya leṇatthāya na santi nāma. Teneva
analyzed: upāyena maraṇam paṭibāhitum a samattha tāya tāṇatthāya leṇatthāya na santi nāma tena iva
translated: they are not a refuge and a protection for the sake of protection and the sake of a refuge, since they are unable to ward off death by any means.

original: vuttaṃ – “natthi ñātīsu tāṇatā”ti.
analyzed: vuttam na atthi ñātīsu tāṇa tā ti
translated: Therefore it was said: “There is no protection in relatives” .

original: Etamatthavasanti etaṃ tesaṃ aññamaññassa tāṇaṃ bhavituṃ asamatthabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ kāraṇaṃ🔽jānitvā paṇḍito catupārisuddhisīlena saṃvuto rakkhitagopito hutvā nibbānagamanaṃ
analyzed: etam tesam aññamaññassa tāṇam bhavitum asamattha bhāva saṅkhātam kāraṇam  jānitvā paṇḍito catu pāri suddhi sīlena saṃvutaḥ rakkhita gopitaḥ hutvā nibbāna gamanam
translated: Knowing this reason: knowing this reason called the inability of one to be a refuge and a protection for another,

original: aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ sīghaṃ sodheyyāti attho.
analyzed: aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam sīgham sodheyya ati attho
translated: the wise one should quickly purify the path to Nibbāna, which is the Noble Eightfold Path, by being restrained by the virtue of the fourfold purity and by being guarded and protected. This is the meaning.

original: Dhammadinnātherīvatthu
analyzed: dhammadinnā therī vatthu
translated: The Story of the Elder Nun Dhammadinnā

original: 239. Pañcame parāyattaṭṭhāneti paresaṃ dāsiṭṭhāne. Sujātattherassa adhikārakammaṃ
analyzed: pañcame parāyatta ṭṭhāne iti paresam dāsi ṭṭhāne sujāta therassa adhikāra kammam
translated: In the fifth place, in the position of dependence on others: in the position of being a slave to others. The Elder Sujāta’s act of merit

original: katvāti sā kira attano kese vikkiṇitvā sujātattherassa nāma aggasāvakassa dānaṃ datvā
analyzed: katvā iti sā kira attano kese vikkiṇitvā sujāta therassa nāma aggasāvakassa dānam datvā
translated: She had her hair sold, and with the price she gave a gift to the Elder Sujāta, the chief disciple,

original: patthanaṃ akāsi. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Hatthe pasāriteti tassa hatthāvalambanatthaṃ🔽pubbāciṇṇavasena hatthe pasārite. So kira anāgāmī hutvā gehaṃ āgacchanto yathā aññesu
analyzed: patthanam akāsi tam sandhāya itam vuttam hatthe pasāritā iti tassa hattha avalambana attham  pubba āciṇṇa vasena hatthe pasārite saḥ kira anāgāmī hutvā geham āgacchantaḥ yathā aññesu
translated: and made her wish. This is what is meant by the words, “Having made a wish.” “When he held out his hand” means that he held out his hand for her to hold on to it.

original: divasesu ito cito ca olokento sitaṃ kurumāno hasamāno āgacchati, evaṃ anāgantvā santindriyo
analyzed: divasesu itas citas ca olokentaḥ sitam kurumānaḥ hasamānaḥ āgacchati evam an āgantvā
translated: It seems that he, having become a non-returner, came to the house without doing as he had done on other days, looking here and there,

original: santamānaso hutvā agamāsi. Dhammadinnā sīhapañjaraṃ ugghāṭetvā vīthiṃ olokayamānā
analyzed: santamānasaḥ hutvā agamāsi dhammadinnā sīha pañjaram ugghāṭetvā vīthim olokayamānā
translated: smiling, and laughing. He came with his faculties and mind quiet and calm. Dhammadinnā opened the lion-seat and looked down the street.

original: tassa āgamanākāraṃ disvā “kiṃ nu kho eta”nti cintetvā tassa paccuggamanaṃ kurumānā
analyzed: tassa āgamana ākāram disvā kim nu kho etat ti cintetvā tassa paccuggamanam kurumānā
translated: Seeing the way he was coming, she thought, “What is this?” And as she went out to meet him,

original: sopānasīse ṭhatvā olambanatthaṃ hatthaṃ pasāresi. Upāsako attano hatthaṃ samiñjesi.
analyzed: sopāna sīse ṭhatvā olambana attham hattham pasāresi upāsakaḥ attanaḥ hattham samiñjesi
translated: she stood at the top of the steps and held out her hand for him to hold on to it. The lay disciple drew back his hand.

original: Sā “pātarāsabhojanakāle jānissāmī”ti cintesi. Upāsako pubbe tāya saddhiṃ ekato bhuñjati.
analyzed: sā pāta rāsa bhojana kāle jānissāmi iti cintesi upāsakaḥ pubbe tāya saddhim ekatas bhuñjati
translated: She thought, “I will find out at the time of the breakfast meal.” The lay disciple had previously eaten with her.

original: Taṃ divasaṃ pana taṃ anapaloketvā yogāvacarabhikkhu viya ekakova bhuñji. Tenāha –
analyzed: tam divasam pana tam an apaloketvā yogāvacara bhikkhu viya ekakaḥ iva bhuñji tena āha
translated: But on that day, without looking back, he ate all alone like a meditator bhikkhu. Hence it is said:

original: “bhuñjamānopi imaṃ detha, imaṃ harathāti na byāharī”ti. Tattha imaṃ dethāti imaṃ
analyzed: bhuñjamānaḥ api imam detha imam haratha ati na tattha imam detha iti imam
translated: “While eating, he did not say, ‘Give this, take that.’ ” Herein, give this means

original: khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā detha. Imaṃ harathāti imaṃ khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā🔽apaharatha. Santhavavasenāti kilesasanthavavasena. Cirakālaparibhāvitāya ghaṭadīpajālāya
analyzed: khādanīyam vā bhojanīyam vā detha imam haratha ati imam khādanīyam vā bhojanīyam vā  apaharatha santhava vasena ati kilesa santhava vasena cira kāla paribhāvitāya ghaṭa dīpa jālāya
translated: give this food or drink. Take that means take this food or drink away.

original: viya abbhantare dibbamānāya hetusampattiyā codiyamānā āha – “evaṃ sante…pe… mayhaṃ🔽pabbajjaṃ anujānāthā”ti.🔽Ayaṃ tāva seṭṭhi gharamajjhe ṭhitova dukkhassantaṃ akāsīti sā kira “dhammadinne tuyhaṃ
analyzed: viya abbhantare dibbamānāya hetu sampattiyā codiyamānā āha evam santepe mayham  pabbajjam anujānātha ati  ayam tāva seṭṭhi ghara majjhe ṭhitaḥ uva dukkhassantam akāsi iti sā kira dhamma dinne tuyham
translated: Urged by the excellence of the cause, which was glowing within him like a lamp with a draught-excluding chimney that had been burning for a long time, he said: “If that is so, then grant me the going forth.”

original: doso natthi, ahaṃ pana ajja paṭṭhāya santhavavasena…pe… kulagharaṃ gacchā”ti vutte
analyzed: doso natthi aham pana ajja paṭṭhāya santhava vasenape kula gharam gacchāti vutte
translated: This is how the merchant put an end to suffering while still in the midst of his house. She thought: “There is no fault in you, Dhammadinna. But from today on I shall go to the house of my family by the way of intimacy.”

original: evaṃ cintesi – “pakatipuriso evaṃ vattā nāma natthi, addhā etena lokuttaradhammo
analyzed: evam cintesi pakati purisaḥ evam vattā nāma natthi addhā etena lokuttara dhammo
translated: When he said this, she thought: “No ordinary man speaks like this. Surely he has attained the supramundane Dhamma.

original: nāma paṭividdho”ti. Tenassā ayaṃ saṅkappo ahosi “ayaṃ tāva seṭṭhi gharamajjhe ṭhitova
analyzed: nāma paṭividdhaḥ ti tena assā ayam saṅkappaḥ ahosi ayam tāva seṭṭhi ghara majjhe ṭhitaḥ uva
translated: “I have penetrated the name.” And she thought: “This merchant has put an end to suffering right here in the midst of the house.”

original: dukkhassantaṃ akāsī”ti. Majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “atha kasmā mayā saddhiṃ🔽yathāpakatiyā ālāpasallāpamattampi na karothāti so cintesi – ‘ayaṃ lokuttaradhammo
analyzed: dukkhassantam akāsi iti majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathā ayam pana atha kasmai mayā saddhim  yathā apakatiyā ālāpa sallāpa mattam pi na karotha ati saḥ cintesi ayam lokuttara dhammo
translated: But in the commentary to the Majjhima Nikāya it is said: “Then why do you not talk to me as usual?

original: nāma garu bhāriyo na pakāsetabbo; sace kho panāhaṃ na kathessāmi, ayaṃ hadayaṃ phāletvā
analyzed: nāma garu bhāriyaḥ na pakāsetabbaḥ sace kho pana aham na kathessāmi ayam hadayam phāletvā
translated: ” She thought: “This supramundane Dhamma is weighty and profound; it should not be revealed. But if I do not tell him, his heart will burst and he will die right here.

original: ettheva kālaṃ kareyyā’ti tassā anuggahatthāya kathesi – ‘dhammadinne ahaṃ satthu🔽dhammadesanaṃ sutvā lokuttaradhammaṃ nāma adhigato, taṃ adhigatassa evarūpā lokiyakiriyā
analyzed: ettha iva kālam kareyya ati tassāḥ anuggaha tthāya kathesi dhammadinne aham satthu  dhamma desanam sutvā lokuttara dhammam nāma adhigataḥ tam adhigatassa evarūpā lokiya kiriyā
translated: ” So, in order to help him, she said: “Dhammadinnā, I have heard the Dhamma taught by the Master

original: na vaṭṭatī”’ti vuttaṃ.🔽Pañcakkhandhādivasena pañhe pucchīti “sakkāyo sakkāyoti ayye vuccati, katamo nu kho
analyzed: na vaṭṭati iti vuttam  pañca kkhandha ādi vasena pañhe pucchi iti sakkāyo sakkāyo ti ayye vuccati katamaḥ nu kho
translated: and have attained the supramundane Dhamma. For one who has attained it, such worldly activities are not proper.”🔽She asked the questions about the five aggregates, etc., in the way stated in the Cūḷavedalla Sutta: “Now, what, venerable lady, is called personality?

original: ayye sakkāyo vutto bhagavatā”tiādinā cūḷavedallasutte āgatanayena pucchi. Pucchitaṃ
analyzed: ayye sakkāyaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā ati ādinā cūḷavedalla sutte āgata nayena pucchi pucchitam
translated: What, venerable lady, is said by the Blessed One to be a person?”

original: pucchitaṃ vissajjesīti “pañca kho ime, āvuso visākha, upādānakkhandhā sakkāyo vutto
analyzed: pucchitam vissajjesi iti pañca kho ime āvuso visākha upādāna khandhāḥ sakkāyaḥ vutto
translated: “He answers what is asked” means: “Friend Visākha, the five aggregates as objects of clinging are called the self,🔽

original: bhagavatā”tiādinā tattheva āgatanayena vissajjesi. Sūrabhāvanti tikkhabhāvaṃ. Anadhigataarahattamaggassa
analyzed: bhagavatā ati ādinā tattha eva āgata nayena vissajjesi sūra bhāvam ti tikkha bhāvam anadhigata arahatta maggassa
translated: He answered the question thus: “Friend Visākha, the five aggregates as objects of clinging are called the self by the Blessed One” , and so on, in the way given in the text. “The state of being sharp”: the state of being keen.

original: uggahena vinā tattha pañho na upaṭṭhātīti āha – “uggahavasena arahattamaggepi pucchī”ti.🔽Taṃ nivattentīti “vimuttiyā panāyye kiṃ paṭibhāgo”ti pucchite “vimuttiyā kho, āvuso
analyzed: uggahena vinā tattha pañhaḥ na upaṭṭhāti iti āha uggaha vasena arahatta magge pi pucchi iti  tam nivattenti iti vimuttiyā panāyye kim paṭibhāgaḥ ti pucchite vimuttiyā kho āvuso
translated: Since the question does not arise without the learning of one who has not attained the path of arahatship, he said: “He asked about the path of arahatship by way of learning.”

original: visākha, nibbānaṃ paṭibhāgo”ti vutte “nibbānassa, panāyye, kiṃ paṭibhāgo”ti puna🔽pucchite taṃ nivattentī “accasarāvuso visākhā”tiādimāha. Tattha accasarāti apucchitabbaṃ
analyzed: visākha nibbānam paṭibhāgaḥ ti vutte nibbānassa panāyye kim paṭibhāgaḥ ti puna  pucchite tam nivattentī accasara avuso visākhā iti ādim āha tattha accasara ati a pucchitabbam
translated: “She turned it back”: when asked, “Lady, what is the counterpart of deliverance?” and she answered, “Friend Visākha, the counterpart of deliverance is Nibbāna,” and when he asked again, “Lady, what is the counterpart of Nibbāna?”🔽she turned it back by saying, “Friend Visākha, that question has not been answered … .” Herein, “that question has not been answered” means that he who asks what has not been asked is one who has gone beyond the question.

original: pucchanto pañhaṃ atikkāmitā ahosīti attho. Nāsakkhi pañhānaṃ pariyantaṃ gahetunti
analyzed: pucchantaḥ pañham atikkāmitā ahosi iti attho na asakkhi pañhānam pariyantam gahetunti
translated: “He was not able to grasp the end of the questions” means that he was not able to grasp the end of the questions.

original: pañhānaṃ paricchedappamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ nāsakkhi. Pañhānañhi paricchedaṃ gahetuṃ yuttaṭṭhāne
analyzed: pañhānam pariccheda ppamāṇam gahetum na asakkhi pañhānam hi paricchedam gahetum yutta ṭṭhāne
translated: he was unable to grasp the extent of the questions. For in the place where it was proper to grasp the extent of the questions,

original: aṭṭhatvā tato paraṃ pucchanto nāsakkhi pañhānaṃ pariyantaṃ gahetuṃ. Appaṭibhāgadhammassa🔽ca paṭibhāgaṃ pucchi. Nibbānaṃ nāmetaṃ appaṭibhāgaṃ, na sakkā nīlaṃ vā pītakaṃ vāti
analyzed: a ṭhatvā tatas param pucchantaḥ na asakkhi pañhānam pariyantam gahetum appaṭibhāga dhammassa  ca paṭibhāgam pucchi nibbānam nāma etam appaṭibhāgam na sakkā nīlam vā pītakam vā ati
translated: He was unable to grasp the extent of the questions. For he was unable to grasp the extent of the questions by asking beyond the point at which it was proper to ask. He asked what was not a counterpart of a counterpart.

original: kenaci dhammena saddhiṃ paṭibhāgaṃ katvā dassetuṃ, tañca tvaṃ iminā adhippāyena pucchasīti
analyzed: kenacid dhammena saddhim paṭibhāgam katvā dassetum tat ca tvam iminā adhippāyena pucchasi iti
translated: Nibbana is not a counterpart; it cannot be shown by being made a counterpart of any idea such as blue or yellow. And you ask it with this intention.

original: āvaṭṭo yakkhāvaṭṭo. Evaṃ sesesupi. Atītabuddhānaṃ āciṇṇaṃ olokesīti atītabuddhā kena🔽bhājanena paṭiggaṇhiṃsūti buddhāciṇṇaṃ olokesi. Dvevācike saraṇe patiṭṭhāyāti saṅghassa
analyzed: āvaṭṭaḥ yakkhāvaṭṭaḥ evam sesesu pi atīta buddhānam āciṇṇam olokesi iti atīta buddhā kena  bhājanena paṭiggaṇhiṃsu iti buddha āciṇṇam olokesi dvevācike saraṇe patiṭṭhāya ati saṅghassa
translated: “The yakkha’s snare”: the snare of the yakkha. original: anuppannattā buddhadhammavasena dvevācike saraṇe patiṭṭhahitvā. Cetiyanti pūjanīyavatthuṃ.

translated: “A living hair-relic”: a hair-relic of the living Blessed One.

original: Anāthapiṇḍikaseṭṭhivatthu🔽249. Dutiye teneva guṇenāti teneva dāyakabhāvasaṅkhātena guṇena. So hi sabbakāmasamiddhatāya

analyzed: vigatam accheratāya karuṇā ādi guṇa samaṅgi tāya ca nicca kālam piṇḍam adāsi tena
translated: In the second case, “by that same quality”: by that same quality of being a donor. For he always gave alms to the helpless, because he was endowed with the requisites of generosity, such as being free from stinginess, and because he was endowed with the qualities of compassion, etc.

original: sabbakālaṃ upaṭṭhito anāthānaṃ piṇḍo etassa atthīti anāthapiṇḍikoti saṅkhaṃ gato.
analyzed: sabbakālam upaṭṭhitaḥ anāthānam piṇḍaḥ etassa atthi iti anāthapiṇḍiko ti saṅkham gato
translated: He was known as Anathapindika, “Almsgiver to the Destitute,” because he was always ready to give alms to the destitute.

original: Yojanikavihāre kāretvāti yojane yojane ekamekaṃ vihāraṃ kāretvā. “Evarūpaṃ dānaṃ
analyzed: yojanika vihāre kāretvā ati yojane yojane ekam ekam vihāram kāretvā evarūpam dānam

original: hontī”tiādimāha. Tattha salākāya gāhetabbaṃ bhattaṃ salākabhattaṃ. Ekasmiṃ pakkhe🔽ekadivasaṃ dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ pakkhikabhattaṃ. Dhuragehe ṭhapetvā dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ
analyzed: honti itiādim āha tattha salākāya gāhetabbam bhattam salāka bhattam ekasmim pakkhe  eka divasam dātabbam bhattam pakkhika bhattam dhura gehe ṭhapetvā dātabbam bhattam
translated: Herein, a portion of food to be taken by ticket is a portion of food to be taken by drawing a ticket.🔽A portion of food for one day is a portion of food to be given on one day in one part.🔽A portion of food for a month is a portion of food to be given after placing it in a storehouse.

original: dhurabhattaṃ. Āgantukānaṃ dātabbaṃ bhattaṃ āgantukabhattaṃ. Evaṃ sesesupi. Pañca🔽āsanasatāni gehe niccapaññattāneva hontīti gehe nisīdāpetvā bhuñjantānaṃ pañcannaṃ
analyzed: dhura bhattam āgantukānam dātabbam bhattam āgantuka bhattam evam sesesu pi pañca  āsana satāni gehe nicca paññattāna eva honti iti gehe nisīdāpetvā bhuñjantānam
translated: A portion of food for visitors is a portion of food to be given to visitors.🔽The rest is clear.

original: bhikkhusatānaṃ pañca āsanasatāni niccapaññattāni honti.🔽Cittagahapativatthu
analyzed: bhikkhu satānam pañca āsana satāni nicca paññattāni honti 🔽cittagaha pativatthu
translated: “There were always five hundred seats laid out in his house”: there were always five hundred seats laid out for five hundred bhikkhus who were fed after being seated in the house.

original: 250. Tatiye migā eva migarūpāni. Bhikkhaṃ samādāpetvāti, “bhante, mayhaṃ anuggahaṃ🔽karotha, idha nisīditvā bhikkhaṃ gaṇhathā”ti bhikkhāgahaṇatthaṃ samādāpetvā. Vivaṭṭaṃ

translated: In the third, the deer are the same as the deer-forms. After getting them to accept the alms, he got them to accept the alms for the purpose of his sitting down there and receiving the alms, saying, “Venerable sirs, help me.

original: uddissa upacitaṃ nibbedhabhāgiyakusalaṃ upanissayo. Saḷāyatanavibhattimeva desesīti

translated: or ‘The Tathāgata exists after death,’ or ‘The Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist after death’—🔽these sixty-two views that are reckoned in the Brahmajāla

analyzed: gaṇitāni imā nu kho bhante diṭṭhiyaḥ kismin sati honti kismin asati na honti iti

analyzed: evamādinā pañhe puṭṭhe tam pañham vissajjetum a sakkontena imam kira pañham yāvatatiyam

analyzed: puṭṭhaḥ mahā thero tuṇhī ahosi atha isidatta thero cintesi ayam theraḥ na iva attanā
translated: the elder remained silent. Then the elder Isidatta thought, “This elder neither answers himself

original: byākaroti, na aññaṃ ajjhesati, upāsako ca bhikkhusaṅghaṃ vihesati, ahametaṃ byākaritvā
analyzed: byākaroti na aññam ajjhesati upāsako ca bhikkhu saṅgham vihesati aham etam byākaritvā
translated: nor asks anyone else to answer. The lay follower is harassing the Sangha of bhikkhus. I will answer his question

analyzed: phāsu vihāram katvā dassāmi iti evam cintetvā ca āsanataḥ vuṭṭhāya therassa santikam
translated: and then I will show him how to live comfortably.” Having thought thus, he rose from his seat, went to the elder,

analyzed: gantvā byākarom aham bhante cittassa gahapatino etam pañham ti āha evam vutte
translated: and said, “Venerable sir, I will answer the householder Citta’s question.” When this was said,

analyzed: theraḥ byākarohi tvam āvuso isidatta cittassa gahapatino etam pañhanti isidattam
translated: The Elder said, “Answer the householder Citta’s question, friend Isidatta.”

original: ajjhesi. Tena vuttaṃ – “pañhaṃ vissajjetuṃ asakkontena ajjhiṭṭho”ti.
analyzed: tena vuttam pañham vissajjetum a sakkontena ajjhiṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: He appointed Isidatta. Hence it is said, “He was appointed because he was unable to answer the question.”

original: Pañhaṃ vissajjetvāti “yā imā, gahapati, anekavihitā diṭṭhiyo loke uppajjanti ‘sassato
analyzed: pañham vissajjetvā ti yāḥ imāḥ gahapati aneka vihitāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ loke uppajjanti sassataḥ
translated: Having answered the question: having answered the question in the way beginning, “Householder, these various views that arise in the world—‘The world is eternal’

original: loko’ti vā, ‘asassato loko’ti vā…pe… yāni cimāni dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni brahmajāle🔽gaṇitāni, imā kho, gahapati, diṭṭhiyo sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā sati honti, sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: loko ti vā a sassataḥ loko ti vāpe yāni cimāni dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi gatāni brahmajāle  gaṇitāni imā kho gahapati diṭṭhiyaḥ sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā sati honti sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā
translated: or ‘The world is not eternal,’ … or ‘With the breakup of the body, after death, a Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist’—🔽these views, householder, are dependent on the view of becoming;

original: asati na hontī”tiādinā nayena pañhaṃ vissajjetvā. Gihisahāyakabhāve ñāteti therassa
analyzed: asati na honti itiādinā nayena pañham vissajjetvā gihi sahāyaka bhāve ñātā iti therassa
translated: when there is the view of becoming, these views arise; when there is not the view of becoming, these views do not arise” .

original: gihisahāyakabhāve cittena gahapatinā ñāte. Citto kira, gahapati, tassa pañhaveyyākaraṇe
analyzed: gihi sahāyaka bhāve cittena gahapatinā ñāte citto kira gahapati tassa pañha veyyākaraṇe
translated: When the householder Citta knew that the Elder was a friend of householders: when the householder Citta knew that the Elder was a friend of householders.

analyzed: tuṭṭhaḥ kutas bhante ayyaḥ isidattaḥ āgacchati iti vatvā avantiyā kho aham gahapati
translated: It seems that the householder Citta was satisfied with the Elder’s answer to his question and said, “Venerable sir, where is Master Isidatta coming from?”🔽“From Avantī, householder.”

original: āgacchāmī”ti vutto “atthi, bhante, avantiyā isidatto nāma kulaputto amhākaṃ adiṭṭhasahāyo🔽pabbajito, diṭṭho so āyasmatā”ti pucchi. Thero ca “evaṃ, gahapatī”ti vatvā “kahaṃ
analyzed: āgacchāmi iti vuttaḥ atthi bhante avantiyā isidattaḥ nāma kula putto amhākam a diṭṭha sahāyaḥ  pabbajitaḥ diṭṭho saḥ āyasmatā ati pucchi thero ca evam gahapati iti vatvā kaham
translated: When he said, “I am coming,” the householder asked, “Venerable sir, is there a young man called Isidatta, the son of a good family, who was a friend of ours in Avanti and who went forth into homelessness?🔽Have you seen him?” The elder replied, “Yes, householder.” “Where is he living now, venerable sir?”

original: nu kho, bhante, so āyasmā etarahi viharatī”ti puna puṭṭho tuṇhī ahosi. Atha citto🔽gahapati “ayyo no, bhante, isidatto”ti pucchitvā “evaṃ, gahapatī”ti vutte attano
analyzed: nu kho bhante saḥ āyasmai etarahi viharati iti puna puṭṭho tuṇhī ahosi atha citto  gahapati ayyaḥ naḥ bhante isidatto ti pucchitvā evam gahapati iti vutte attanaḥ
translated: When asked this, the elder remained silent. Then the householder Citta asked, “Venerable sir, is he not called Isidatta?”

original: gihisahāyabhāvaṃ aññāsi.🔽Tejosamāpattipāṭihāriyaṃ dassetvāti ekasmiṃ kira divase citto gahapati “sādhu me,
analyzed: gihi sahāya bhāvam aññāsi  tejo samāpatti pāṭihāriyam dassetvā iti ekasmin kira divase cittaḥ gahapati sādhu me
translated: “Yes, householder.” Then the householder realized that he was his own friend in the world.

original: bhante, ayyo uttarimanussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassetū”ti mahātheraṃ yāci. Thero
analyzed: bhante ayyo uttari manussa dhammā iddhi pāṭihāriyam dassetu uti mahā theram yāci theraḥ
translated: Having shown the miracle of the attainment of heat, it seems, on one occasion the householder Citta asked the elder, “Venerable sir, it would be good if the venerable one would show a miracle of supernormal power that is a superhuman power.”

original: “tena hi tvaṃ, gahapati, āḷinde uttarāsaṅgaṃ paññāpetvā tattha tiṇakalāpaṃ okirā”ti
analyzed: tena hi tvam gahapati āḷinde uttarāsaṅgam paññāpetvā tattha tiṇa kalāpam okirāti
translated: The elder replied, “Well then, householder, spread your upper robe over the terrace and scatter a handful of grass there.”

original: vatvā tena ca tathā kate sayaṃ vihāraṃ pavisitvā ca ghaṭikaṃ datvā tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ
analyzed: vatvā tena ca tathā kate sayam vihāram pavisitvā ca ghaṭikam da tvā tathārūpam iddha abhisaṅkhāram
translated: and when he had done so, the Elder entered the monastery, set the water-clock going, and created a miracle of psychic power such as this:

original: abhisaṅkhāresi, yathā tāḷacchiggaḷena ca aggaḷantarikāya ca acci nikkhamitvā tiṇāni
analyzed: abhisaṅkhāresi yathā tāḷa chiggaḷena ca aggaḷa antarikāya ca acci nikkhamitvā tiṇāni
translated: the flame issued from the keyhole and the chink of the door and set fire to the grass thatch,

original: jhāpeti, uttarāsaṅgaṃ na jhāpeti. Atha citto gahapati uttarāsaṅgaṃ papphoṭetvā saṃviggo🔽lomahaṭṭhajāto ekamantaṃ ṭhito theraṃ bahi nikkhamantaṃ disvā “abhiramatu, bhante,
analyzed: jhāpeti uttarāsaṅgam na jhāpeti atha cittaḥ gahapati uttarāsaṅgam papphoṭetvā saṃviggaḥ  lomahaṭṭha jātaḥ ekamantam ṭhitaḥ theram bahi nikkhamantam disvā abhiramatu bhante
translated: but it did not burn the outer cloak. Then the layman Citta shook out his outer cloak, and being alarmed and his hair standing on end,

original: ayyo macchikāsaṇḍe, ramaṇīyaṃ ambāṭakavanaṃ, ahaṃ ayyassa ussukkaṃ karissāmi cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārāna”nti
analyzed: ayyaḥ macchikāsaṇḍe ramaṇīyam ambāṭaka vanam aham ayyassa ussukkam karissāmi cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārān antima
translated: he stood to one side. When he saw the Elder coming out, he said, “Be pleased, venerable sir, to stay in Macchikāsaṇḍa. The Ambaṭṭha Wood is delightful. I will see to your needs for robes, almsfood, resting place, and medicinal requisites.”

original: āha. Tato thero “na dāni idha vasituṃ sakkā”ti tamhā vihārā pakkāmi. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ
analyzed: āha tatas theraḥ na dāni idha vasitum sakkāti tamhā vihārā tam
translated: Then the Elder thought, “It is not possible to live here now,” and he left the monastery. This is what was meant by the words,

original: vuttaṃ – “tejosamāpatti pāṭihāriyaṃ dassetvā ‘idāni idha vasituṃ na yutta’nti yathāsukhaṃ
analyzed: vuttam tejosamāpatti pāṭihāriyam dassetvā idāni idha vasitum na yuttanti yathāsukham
translated: “Having shown the miracle of psychic power consisting in the attainment of heat, he thought ‘It is not possible to live here now,’ and he left Macchikāṇḍa as he pleased.

original: pakkāmī”ti. Dve aggasāvakātiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ vitthārato vinayapāḷiyaṃ āgatameva.🔽Saddhoti lokiyalokuttarāya saddhāya samannāgato. Sīlenāti agāriyasīlaṃ anagāriyasīlanti
analyzed: pakkāmī iti dve aggasāvaka ati ādīsu yam vattabbam tam vitthārataḥ vinaya pāḷiyam āgatam eva  saddhā iti lokiya lokuttarāya saddhāya samannāgato sīlena ati agāriya sīlam anagāriya sīlanti
translated: As to the two chief disciples, etc., what should be said has been said already in the Vinaya Pitaka.🔽Faithful: endowed with the faith that is mundane and supramundane. In virtue: virtue is of two kinds, that of the house life and that of the homeless life;

original: duvidhaṃ sīlaṃ, tesu idha agāriyaṃ sīlaṃ adhippetaṃ, tena samannāgatoti attho. Yasobhogasamappitoti
analyzed: duvidham sīlam tesu idha agāriyam sīlam adhippetam tena samannāgataḥ ti attho yasaḥ bhoga samappito ti
translated: herein, that of the homeless life is intended; thus he is endowed with that. Renowned for his wealth and fame:

original: yādiso anāthapiṇḍikādīnaṃ pañcaupāsakasataparivārasaṅkhāto agāriyo yaso, tādiseneva
analyzed: yādisaḥ pañca aupāsaka sata parivāra saṅkhātaḥ agāriyaḥ tādisena iva
translated: he is renowned with the kind of fame that is possessed by such laymen as Anathapindika, who had a following of five hundred laymen,

original: yasena, yo ca dhanadhaññādiko ceva sattavidhaariyadhanasaṅkhāto cāti duvidho bhogo,
analyzed: yasena yaḥ ca dhana dhañña ādiko ca iva sattavidha ariya dhana saṅkhāto ca ati duvidhaḥ bhogo
translated: and he is endowed with the two kinds of wealth, that consisting of the seven kinds of noble wealth, namely, faith, virtue, conscience, shame, learning, generosity, and wisdom, and that consisting of the eight worldly items, namely, gold, silver, etc.,

original: tena ca samannāgatoti attho. Yaṃ yaṃ padesanti puratthimādīsu disāsu evarūpo kulaputto
analyzed: tena ca samannāgataḥ ti atthaḥ yam yam padesanti puratthima ādīsu disāsu evarūpaḥ kula putto
translated: and he is endowed with that. Wherever he goes: wherever this clansman goes, to whatever region, whether east, etc.,

original: yaṃ yaṃ padesaṃ bhajati, tattha tattha evarūpena lābhasakkārena pūjitova hotīti attho.
analyzed: yam yam padesam bhajati tattha tattha evarūpena lābha sakkārena pūjitaḥ uva hoti iti attho
translated: there he is honoured with such gain and honour.

original: Hatthakaāḷavakavatthu
analyzed: hatthaka āḷavaka vatthu
translated: The story of Hatthaka of Alavi

original: 251. Catutthe catubbidhena saṅgahavatthunāti dānapiyavacanaatthacariyāsamānattatāsaṅkhātena
analyzed: catutthe catubbidhena saṅgaha vatthunā ati dāna piya vacana attha cariyā samānatta tā saṅkhātena
translated: by the four kinds of grounds for companionship called giving, agreeable speech, taking part in undertakings, and having the same aim.

original: catubbidhena saṅgahavatthunā. “Sve bhattacāṭiyā saddhiṃ āḷavakassa pesetabbo ahosī”ti
analyzed: catubbidhena saṅgaha vatthunā sve bhatta cāṭiyā saddhim āḷavakassa pesetabbo ahosi iti
translated: “Tomorrow the cook is to be sent with Āḷavaka” .

original: vuttamatthaṃ pākaṭaṃ katvā dassetuṃ – “tatrāyaṃ anupubbikathā”tiādimāha. Migavatthāya
analyzed: vutta mattham pākaṭam katvā dassetum tatra ayam anupubbi kathā ti ādim āha miga vatthāya
translated: In order to make the meaning of this statement clear, he said, “Herein, the following is the step-by-step explanation” .

original: araññaṃ gantvāti āḷavako rājā vividhanāṭakūpabhogaṃ chaḍḍetvā corappaṭibāhanatthañca
analyzed: araññam gantvā iti āḷavakaḥ rājā vividha nāṭakūpabhogam chaḍḍetvā cora ppaṭibāhana attham ca

original: paṭirājanisedhanatthañca byāyāmakaraṇatthañca sattame sattame divase migavaṃ gacchanto🔽ekadivasaṃ balakāyena saddhiṃ “yassa passena migo palāyati, tasseva so bhāro”ti katakatikavatto
analyzed: paṭirāja nisedhana ttham ca byāyāma karaṇa ttham ca sattame sattame divase migavam gacchantaḥ  eka divasam balakāyena saddhim yassa passena migo palāyati tassa iva saḥ bhāro ti katakatikavatto
translated: for the purpose of restraining rival kings, and for the purpose of exercising his horses and elephants.🔽Having gone to the forest for hunting, he went to the forest for hunting, having made an agreement with his army thus, “The animal that a deer flees to the side of is his responsibility.”

original: migavatthāya araññaṃ gantvā. Ekaṃ miganti attano ṭhitaṭṭhānena palātaṃ eṇimigaṃ.
analyzed: migavatthāya araññam gantvā ekam miganti attanaḥ ṭhita ṭṭhānena palātam eṇi migam
translated: One deer: a spotted deer that fled to the place where he was standing.

original: Anubandhitvāti tiyojanamaggaṃ ekakova anubandhitvā. Javasampanno hi rājā dhanuṃ gahetvā🔽pattikova tiyojanaṃ taṃ migamanubandhi. Ghātetvāti yasmā eṇimigā tiyojanavegā eva
analyzed: anubandhitvā ti ti yojana maggam ekakaḥ uva anubandhitvā java sampannaḥ hi rājā dhanum gahetvā  pattikā uva ti yojanam tam migam anubandhi ghātetvā ati yasmai eṇi migā ti yojana vegāḥ eva
translated: Having followed it for three leagues all alone: for the king was endowed with speed. Taking his bow, he followed the deer on foot for three leagues.

original: honti, tasmā parikkhiṇajavaṃ taṃ migaṃ udakaṃ pavisitvā ṭhitaṃ ghātetvā. Dvidhā chetvā🔽dhanukoṭiyaṃ lagetvā nivattetvā āgacchantoti anatthikopi maṃsena “nāsakkhi migaṃ

translated: Having killed it: for deer are swift for three leagues. So he killed the deer when it was exhausted and entered the water to drink.🔽Having cut the bowstring in two: for he had to go back, taking the bowstring in his two hands, even though he was not in need of the meat, in order to avoid the accusation, “He was not able to catch the deer.”

original: gahetu”nti apavādamocanatthaṃ dvidhā chinnaṃ dhanukoṭiyaṃ lagetvā āgacchanto. Sandacchāyanti
analyzed: apavāda mocana attham dvidhā chinnam dhanu koṭiyam lagetvā āgacchantaḥ sandacchāyanti
translated: In the shade of a certain tree:

original: ghanacchāyaṃ bahalapattapalāsaṃ.
analyzed: ghana chāyam bahala patta palāsam
translated: in the shade of a certain tree with dense foliage.

original: Rukkhe adhivatthā devatāti āḷavakaṃ yakkhaṃ sandhāya vadati. So hi mahārājūnaṃ santikā
analyzed: rukkhe adhivatthā devatā ti āḷavakam yakkham sandhāya vadati saḥ hi mahā rājūnam santikā
translated: The deity who lived in the tree: he refers to the yakkha Āḷavaka. For the latter, having received a boon from the Great Kings,

original: varaṃ labhitvā majjhanhikasamaye tassa rukkhassa chāyāya phuṭṭhokāsaṃ paviṭṭhe pāṇino
analyzed: varam labhitvā majjhanhika samaye tassa rukkhassa chāyāya phuṭṭha ukāsam paviṭṭhe pāṇino
translated: entered the area covered by the shade of that tree at midday and killed all beings that entered there.

original: khādanto tattha paṭivasati. Āḷavakassa nisīdanapallaṅke nisīdīti yattha abhilakkhitesu
analyzed: khādantaḥ tattha paṭivasati āḷavakassa nisīdana pallaṅke nisīdīti yattha abhilakkhitesu
translated: and he was staying there, eating the food of the gods. ‘Sat on the couch of the lord of the gods’ means on the divine couch of the lord of the gods,

original: maṅgaladivasādīsu āḷavako nisīditvā siriṃ anubhoti, tasmiṃyeva dibbaratanapallaṅke
analyzed: maṅgala divasa ādīsu āḷavakaḥ nisīditvā sirim anubhoti tasmin yeva dibba ratana pallaṅke
translated: on which the lord of the gods sits and enjoys his glory on the auspicious day of the full moon.

original: nisīdi. Attano gamane asampajjamāne “kiṃ nu kho kāraṇa”nti āvajjentāti tadā kira
analyzed: nisīdi gamane a sampajjamāne kim nu kho kāraṇanti tadā kira
translated: ‘Not knowing that he was coming’ means that at that time, it seems,

analyzed: sātāgira hemavatā bhagavantam jetavaneya iva vanditvā yakkha samāgamam gamissāma ati
translated: Sātāgira and Hemavata, after worshipping the Lord in Jeta’s Wood,

original: saparivārā nānāyānehi ākāsena gacchanti, ākāse ca yakkhānaṃ na sabbattha maggo atthi,
analyzed: sa parivārāḥ nānā yānehi ākāsena gacchanti ākāse ca yakkhānam na sabbattha maggo atthi

analyzed: ākāsa ṭṭhāni vimānāni pariharitvā magga ṭṭhānena iva maggaḥ hoti āḷavakassa pana vimānam
translated: for the aerial palaces avoid the road and the road avoids the aerial palaces. But the palace of Āḷavaka

original: bhūmaṭṭhaṃ suguttaṃ pākāraparikkhittaṃ susaṃvihitadvāraṭṭālakagopuraṃ upari kaṃsajālasañchannamañjūsāsadisaṃ
analyzed: bhūmaṭṭham su guttam pākāra parikkhittam su saṃvihita dvāra aṭṭālaka gopuram upari kaṃsa jāla sañchanna mañjūsā sadisam
translated: was on the ground, well guarded, surrounded by a rampart, with well-arranged gates, watch-towers and gateways, and was like a pavilion covered with a roof of gold.

original: tiyojanaṃ ubbedhena, tassa upari maggo hoti, te taṃ padesamāgamma gantumasamatthā
analyzed: ti yojanam ubbedhena tassa upari maggaḥ hoti te tam padesam āgamma gantum asamatthā
translated: It was three leagues high, and there was a road above it. They came to that place and were unable to go on.

original: ahesuṃ. Buddhānañhi nisinnokāsassa uparibhāgena yāva bhavaggā koci gantumasamattho,
analyzed: ahesum buddhānam hi nisinna ukāsassa upari bhāgena yāva koci gantum asamatthaḥ
translated: For no one is able to go up above the place where the Buddhas sit.

analyzed: tasmai attanaḥ gamane a sampajjamāne kim nu khalu kāraṇanti āvajjesum tesam katham
translated: Therefore, when they were unable to go, they thought, “What is the reason for this?”🔽After hearing their discussion, the king thought.

analyzed: sutvā cintesi iti yasmai assaddhassa saddhā kathā dukkathā hoti dussīla ādīnam sīla kathā ādayaḥ  viya tasmā tesam yakkhānam santikā bhagavato pasaṃsam sutvā eva aggimhi pakkhitta loṇa sakkharā
translated: Since the discussion of faith is a bad discussion for one who has no faith, and the discussion of virtue, etc., is a bad discussion for one who is immoral, etc.,

original: viya abbhantare uppannakopena paṭapaṭāyamānahadayo hutvā cintesi. Pabbatakūṭanti kelāsapabbatakūṭaṃ.

translated: the king, after hearing the Exalted One’s praise from the yakkhas, thought, like salt and sugar thrown into a fire, with his heart burning with anger.🔽From here on the battle of Alavaka should be related in detail.

original: Ito paṭṭhāya āḷavakayuddhaṃ vitthāretabbanti so kira manosilātale vāmapādena ṭhatvā
analyzed: itas paṭṭhāya āḷavaka yuddham vitthāretabbanti so kira manosilā tale vāma pādena ṭhatvā

analyzed: passatha dāni tumhākam vā satthā mahā anubhāvaḥ aham vā ati dakkhiṇa pādena saṭṭhi yojana mattam

analyzed: kelāsakūṭa pabbatam akkami tam ayokūṭa ppahataḥ viya niddhanta aya piṇḍaḥ muñci
translated: He climbed the mountain Kelasa-kuta, and it emitted sparks of fire as if struck by lightning.🔽Standing there he cried out, “I am Alavaka!” The cry was heard all over India.

original: So tatra ṭhatvā “ahaṃ āḷavako”ti ugghosesi, sakalajambudīpaṃ saddo phari. Tiyojanasahassavitthatahimavāpi
analyzed: saḥ tatra ṭhatvā aham āḷavakaḥ iti ugghosesi sakala jambudīpam ti yojana sahassa vitthata himavāpi
translated: The Himalayas, three thousand leagues in extent, shook.

original: sampakampi yakkhassānubhāvena. So vātamaṇḍalaṃ samuṭṭhāpesi “eteneva samaṇaṃ palāpessāmī”ti.🔽Te puratthimādibhedā vātā samuṭṭhahitvā aḍḍhayojanayojanadviyojanatiyojanappamāṇāni
analyzed: sampakampi yakkhassa anubhāvena saḥ vātamaṇḍalam samuṭṭhāpesi etena iva samaṇam palāpessāmi iti  te puratthima ādi bhedāḥ samuṭṭhahitvā aḍḍhayojana yojana dviyojana tiyojana ppamāṇāni
translated: The ogre created a whirlwind, thinking, “By this means I will drive the recluse away.”

original: pabbatakūṭāni padāletvā vanagaccharukkhādīni ummūletvā āḷavinagaraṃ pakkhandā jiṇṇahatthisālādīni
analyzed: pabbata kūṭāni padāletvā vana gaccha rukkha ādīni ummūletvā āḷavi nagaram pakkhandā jiṇṇa hatthi sāla ādīni
translated: The winds, divided into east winds, etc., arose, and after demolishing the mountain peaks, half a league, a league, two leagues, and three leagues in extent, and uprooting the trees and creepers, they rushed on to the city of Alavaka, demolishing the old elephant stables, etc.,

original: cuṇṇentā chadaniṭṭhakā ākāse bhamentā. Bhagavā “mā kassaci uparodho hotū”ti adhiṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: ākāse bhamentā bhagavā mā kassaci uparodhaḥ hotu uti adhiṭṭhāsi
translated: and scattering the thatch and timber in the air. The Blessed One resolved that no harm should come to anyone.

original: Te vātā dasabalaṃ patvā cīvarakaṇṇamattampi cāletuṃ nāsakkhiṃsu. Tato mahāvassaṃ
analyzed: te vātāḥ dasabalam patvā cīvara kaṇṇa mattam pi cāletum na asakkhiṃsu tatas mahā vassam
translated: The winds reached the Ten Powered One and were unable to stir even the edge of his robe. Then a great rain

original: samuṭṭhāpesi “udakena ajjhottharitvā samaṇaṃ māressāmī”ti. Tassānubhāvena uparūpari
analyzed: samuṭṭhāpesi udakena ajjhottharitvā samaṇam māressāmi iti tassa anubhāvena upari upari
translated: and he thought, “I’ll drown him.” But because of the power of the Buddha, the water flowed away from him.

original: satapaṭalasahassapaṭalādibhedā valāhakā uṭṭhahitvā pavassiṃsu. Vuṭṭhidhārāvegena🔽pathavī chiddā ahosi. Vanarukkhādīnaṃ upari mahogho āgantvā dasabalassa cīvare ussāvabindumattampi
analyzed: sata paṭala sahassa paṭala ādi bhedāḥ valāhakāḥ uṭṭhahitvā pavassiṃsu vuṭṭhi dhārā vegena  pathavī chiddā ahosi vana rukkha ādīnam upari mahā oghaḥ āgantvā dasabalassa cīvare ussāva bindumattam pi
translated: and he thought, “I will drown him with water.” Through his power, clouds of various kinds, such as those with a hundred layers and those with a thousand layers, arose and rained down.🔽The force of the downpour split the earth. A great flood came over the trees and the forest, but it could not wet even a drop of dew on the ten-powered one’s robe.

original: temetuṃ nāsakkhi. Tato pāsāṇavassaṃ samuṭṭhāpesi. Mahantāni mahantāni pabbatakūṭāni
analyzed: temetum na asakkhi tatas pāsāṇa vassam samuṭṭhāpesi mahantāni mahantāni pabbata kūṭāni
translated: Then he brought down a rain of rocks. Huge rock-peaks,

analyzed: dhūmāyantāni pajjalantāni ākāsena āgantvā dasabalam patvā dibba mālāguḷāni sampajjiṃsu
translated: smoking and blazing, came through the air and became divine garlands when they reached the ten-powered one.

original: Tato paharaṇavassaṃ samuṭṭhāpesi. Ekatodhārā ubhatodhārā asisattikhurappādayo dhūmāyantā
analyzed: tatas paharaṇa vassam samuṭṭhāpesi ekatodhārāḥ ubhatodhārāḥ asi satti khurappa ādayaḥ dhūmāyantā
translated: Then he brought down a rain of weapons. Single-edged swords, double-edged swords, spears, javelins, and so on, smoking and blazing, came through the air

analyzed: pajjalantāḥ ākāsena āgantvā dasabalassa pāda mūle dibba pupphāni ahesuṃ
translated: and became divine flowers at the ten-powered one’s feet.

analyzed: tatas aṅgāra vassam samuṭṭhāpesi kiṃsuka vaṇṇāḥ aṅgārāḥ ākāsena āgantvā dasabalassa pāda mūle
translated: Then he brought down a rain of embers. Embers the color of kimsuka flowers came through the air and became

original: dibbapupphāni hutvā vikiriṃsu. Tato kukkuḷavassaṃ samuṭṭhāpesi. Accuṇho kukkuḷo ākāsenāgantvā
analyzed: dibba pupphāni hutvā vikiriṃsu tatas kukkuḷa vassam samuṭṭhāpesi accuṇhaḥ kukkuḷaḥ ākāsena āgantvā
translated: and fell down as divine flowers. Then he raised a storm of hot embers.🔽The embers, burning and glowing, came through the air
