analyzed: vutta ppakāre iti pañca ātapa tappana ādike vutta ppakāre
translated: The kind already mentioned: the kind already mentioned, namely, the fivefold burning and scorching, etc.

original: 319. Evanti vuttappakārāya cittappasādavhayasuppaṭipattiyā. Tena samaṇadhammakaraṇasukhañca saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: evam ti vutta ppakārāya citta ppasāda vhaya su paṭipattiyā tena samaṇa dhamma karaṇa sukham ca saṅgaṇhāti
translated: Thus: by the practice of the right kind of faith and energy already mentioned. He includes the happiness of doing the ascetic’s duties by this.

original: 320. Navakanipāteti imasmiṃyeva aṅguttaranikāye vakkhamānaṃ navakanipātaṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: navaka nipāta iti imasmin yeva aṅguttara nikāye vakkhamānam navaka nipātam sandhāya āha
translated: In the Nine-factored Collection: he says this referring to the Nine-factored Collection that will be dealt with in this same Numerical Collection.

original: Nava puggalāti sattakkhattuparamakolaṃkolādayo nava puggalā. Sabbatthāti imasmiṃ
analyzed: nava puggalā ti satta kkhattu parama kolaṃkola ādayaḥ nava puggalā sabbattha ati imasmin
translated: Nine persons: the nine persons beginning with the one-seeder and the one- reaper.

original: sutte vuttāvasiṭṭhesu sabbesu suttesu.
analyzed: sutte vutta avasiṭṭhesu sabbesu suttesu
translated: Everywhere: in all the remaining suttas in this sutta collection.

original: Tatiyavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tatiya vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the third section is finished.

original: 16. Ekadhammapāḷi🔽(16) 4. Ekadhammapāḷi-catutthavaggavaṇṇanā
translated: The Collection on One Thing🔽The fourth section🔽In the first of the fourth, the sign of the earth: the sign of the earth is the sign of the earth’s extent.

original: 322. Catutthassa paṭhame saññāṇabhūtāti upalakkhaṇabhūtā. Pañcadasayojanāvaṭṭakkhandhāti🔽pañcadasayojanakkhandhaparikkhepā. Yathā cāti ca-saddena kadambarukkhādīnaṃ kappaṭṭhāyibhāvaṃ
analyzed: catutthassa paṭhame saññāṇa bhūtā ati upalakkhaṇa bhūtā pañcadasa yojana avaṭṭa kkhandhā ati  pañcadasa yojana khandha parikkhepāḥ yathā ca ati ca saddena kadamba rukkha ādīnam kappa ṭṭhāyi bhāvam
translated: The earth’s extent is the earth’s perimeter.🔽And by the word “and” the earth’s height of one hundred leagues, etc., is included.

original: viya yojanasatubbedhādibhāvaṃ samuccinoti, na pana jambuyā jambudīpassa viya tehi
analyzed: viya yojana satubbedha ādi bhāvam samuccinoti na pana jambuyāḥ jambudīpassa viya tehi
translated: But the earth is not the sign of the other continents such as Aparagoyāna, etc., as it is of Jambudipa and of the Rose-Apple Tree.🔽Delightful: delightful in appearance.

original: aparagoyānādīnaṃ saññāṇabhāvaṃ. Rāmaṇeyyakanti ramaṇīyabhāvaṃ. Sesapadesūti vanarāmaṇeyyakādipadesu.
analyzed: apara go yāna ādīnam saññāṇa bhāvam rāmaṇeyyakam ti ramaṇīya bhāvam sesa padesu iti vana rāmaṇeyyaka ādi padesu
translated: In the remaining places: in the places beginning with the delightful forest.

original: Uggataṃ kūlaṃ ussitabhāvo etassāti ukkūlaṃ, vigataṃ apagataṃ kūlaṃ etassāti vikūlanti
analyzed: uggatam kūlam ussita bhāvaḥ etassa ati ukkūlam vigatam apagatam kūlam etassa ati vikūlanti
translated: Ukkūlaṃ means having a raised bank; vikūlaṃ means having a removed bank.

original: āha – “unnataṭṭhānaṃ ninnaṭṭhāna”nti ca. Nandiyāvaṭṭamacchapiṭṭhenevāti kujjakakulisakamacchasaṅghātapiṭṭheneva.
analyzed: āha unnata ṭṭhānam ninna ṭṭhānam iti ca nandiyā vaṭṭa maccha piṭṭhena iva ati kujjaka kulisaka maccha saṅghāta piṭṭhena iva
translated: He says: “A high place and a low place.” Nandiyāvaṭṭamacchapiṭṭhena = with the back of a fish called nandiya or vaṭṭamacca.

original: 323. Dutiyādīsu cattāro apāyā aññatra manussehīti adhippetā, na devā aññatra manussehīti
analyzed: dutiya ādīsu cattāro apāyāḥ aññatra manussehi iti adhippetāḥ na devāḥ aññatra manussehi iti
translated: In the second and following (passages), the four lower worlds are meant except for human beings. Not the gods except for human beings.

original: hīnāya jātiyā adhippetattā. Upādāyupādāyāpi majjhimadeso labbhati, yattha gati bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: hīnāya jātiyāḥ adhippeta ttā upādāya upādāya api majjhima desaḥ labbhati yattha gati bhikkhūnam
translated: Because the low birth is meant. Even by taking up the middle country is obtained, where the going of the monks

original: bhikkhunīnaṃ upāsakānaṃ upāsikānaṃ aññesampi kammavādikiriyavādiviññujātikānaṃ, yo🔽patirūpadesoti vuccati. Tenāha – “sakalopi hī”tiādi.
analyzed: bhikkhunīnam upāsakānam upāsikānam aññesam pi kamma vādi kiriya vādi viññu jātikānam yo  vuccati tena āha sakalaḥ api hi itiādi
translated: and of the nuns, of the male lay followers and of the female lay followers, and of others who are of the nature of those who perform deeds and those who perform rites,🔽is called a suitable country. Therefore he says: “The whole of the low country.”

original: 324. Eḷāti doso. Tenāha – “niddosamukhāti attho”ti.
analyzed: eḷā ati doso tena āha niddosa mukhā ati attho ti
translated: Eḷa = hatred. Therefore he says: “The meaning is: free from hatred.”

original: 326. Tathāgatassa guṇe jānitvā cakkhunāpi dassanaṃ dassanameva, ajānitvā pana dassanaṃ tiracchānagatānampi hotiyevāti āha – “ye tathāgatassa guṇe jānitvā”tiādi.
analyzed: tathāgatassa guṇe jānitvā cakkhunā api dassanam dassanam eva a jānitvā pana dassanam tiracchāna gatānam pi āha ye tathāgatassa guṇe jānitvā atiādi
translated: Knowing the Tathāgata’s special qualities, seeing him with the eye is seeing indeed. But seeing without knowing them is also found among animals.

original: 327. Pakāsetvā kathitanti saccāni pakāsetvā kathitaṃ.
analyzed: pakāsetvā kathitam ti saccāni pakāsetvā kathitam
translated: Having revealed: having told after revealing the Truths.

original: 328. Sutānaṃ dhammānaṃ asammoso dhāraṇanti āha – “dhārentīti na pammussantī”ti.
analyzed: sutānam dhammānam asammosaḥ dhāraṇanti āha dhārenti iti na pammussanti iti
translated: Non-forgetting of the teachings heard is retention.

original: 329. Atthānatthaṃ upaparikkhantīti “ayaṃ imissā pāḷiyā attho, ayaṃ na attho”ti atthānatthaṃ
analyzed: attha anattham upaparikkhanti iti ayam imissā pāḷiyā atthaḥ ayam na atthaḥ iti attha anattham
translated: They investigate the meaning and the non-meaning: they investigate the meaning and the non-meaning of this text thus: “This is the meaning of this text, this is not the meaning.”

original: upaparikkhanti. Anatthaparihārena hi atthaggahaṇaṃ yathā adhammaparivajjanena dhammappaṭipatti.
analyzed: upaparikkhanti anattha parihārena hi attha ggahaṇam yathā adhamma parivajjanena dhamma ppaṭipatti
translated: For the grasping of the meaning is by the avoidance of the non-meaning, as the practice of the profitable is by the avoidance of the unprofitable.

original: 330. Anulomapaṭipadanti nibbānassa anulomikaṃ paṭipadaṃ.
analyzed: anuloma paṭipadam ti nibbānassa anulomikam paṭipadam
translated: The conformity is the conformity to Nibbāna.

original: 331. Saṃvegajanakesu kāraṇesūti saṃvegajanakesu jātiādīsu kāraṇesu. Saṃvejanīyesu ṭhānesu sahottappañāṇaṃ saṃvego.
analyzed: saṃvega janakesu kāraṇesu iti saṃvega janakesu jāti ādīsu kāraṇesu saṃvejanīyesu ṭhānesu sahottappa ñāṇam saṃvegaḥ
translated: In the reasons for arousing spiritual anxiety: in the reasons for arousing spiritual anxiety, namely, birth, ageing, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief and despair. Spiritual anxiety is the knowledge of fear in fearful things.

original: 332. Upāyenāti yena upāyena vaṭṭūpacchedo, tena upāyena. Padhānavīriyaṃ karontīti sammappadhānasaṅkhātaṃ vīriyaṃ karonti uppādenti.
analyzed: upāyena ati yena upāyena vaṭṭūpacchedo tena upāyena padhāna vīriyam karonti iti sammappadhāna saṅkhātam vīriyam karonti uppādenti
translated: By means of the means: by means of the means whereby the cutting off of the round of rebirths is effected. They make effort that is strenuous: they make effort called right endeavour .

original: 333. Vavassajīyanti vissajjīyanti ettha saṅkhārāti vavassaggo, asaṅkhatā dhātūti āha – “vavassaggo vuccati nibbāna”nti.
analyzed: vavassajīyanti vissajjīyanti ettha saṅkhārā ati vavassaggaḥ asaṅkhatā dhātū ti āha vavassaggaḥ vuccati nibbānam ti
translated: They let go: they let go of formations here. The unformed element is what is meant, according to the words, “Letting go is said to be Nibbāna” .

original: 334. Uttamannānanti uttamānaṃ pañcannaṃ bhojanānaṃ. Uttamarasānanti uttamānaṃ rasānaṃ.
analyzed: uttama annānam ti uttamānam pañcannam bhojanānam uttama rasānam ti uttamānam rasānam
translated: The best kinds of: the best kinds of the five kinds of nutriment. The best kinds of taste: the best kinds of taste.

original: Uñchācārenāti uñchācariyāya kassaci apariggahabhūtassa kiñci ayācitvā gahaṇaṃ uñchācāro.🔽Ettha cātiādinā annādīnaṃ aggabhāvo nāma manāpaparamo icchitakkhaṇalābho, na tesaṃ
analyzed: uñchā ācārena ati uñchā cariyāya kassaci a pariggaha bhūtassa kiñci a yācitvā gahaṇam uñchā ācāraḥ  ettha ca ati ādinā anna ādīnam aggabhāvaḥ nāma manāpa paramaḥ icchita kkhaṇa lābho na tesam
translated: By means of the practice of going on all-fours: the practice of going on all-fours is the taking of something without asking permission from anyone who has not made a gift of it.

original: lābhitāmattanti dasseti. Paṭilabhantīti denti paṇītabhāvena. Bhattassa ekapātīti🔽ekapātipūraṃ bhattaṃ. Idaṃ kiṃ nāmāti “idaṃ annaggarasaggaṃ nāma hoti, na hotī”ti
analyzed: lābhi tā mattanti dasseti paṭilabhanti iti denti paṇīta bhāvena bhattassa eka pātī iti 🔽eka pāti pūram bhattam idam kim nāma ati idam anna ggarasaggam nāma hoti na hoti iti
translated: And here, etc.: he shows that the state of being the best of food, etc., is the obtaining of what is desired at the moment, not merely the obtaining of it.

original: pucchati. Uñchena kapālābhatenāti missakabhattena. Yāpenteti yāpanasīsena yāpanahetuṃ🔽bhattaṃ vadati. Upādāya aggarasaṃ nāmāti taṃ taṃ upādāyupādāya annaggarasaggaṃ daṭṭhabbanti
analyzed: pucchati uñchena kapālābhatena ati missakabhattena yāpentā iti yāpana sīsena yāpana hetum  bhattam vadati upādāya agga rasam nāma ati tam tam upādāya upādāya anna agga rasaggam daṭṭhabbanti
translated: ‘He asks for it’: he asks for it. ‘With what is available’: with mixed food. ‘He makes it last’: he makes it last by means of making it last. He speaks of the food as ‘the cause of making it last.’

original: dasseti. Cakkavattiāhārato hi cātumahārājikānaṃ āhāro aggoti evaṃ yāva paranimmitavasavattidevā netabbaṃ.
analyzed: dasseti cakkavatti āhārataḥ hi cātumahārājikānam āhāraḥ aggaḥ ti evam yāva para nimmita vasavatti devāḥ netabbam
translated: ‘The supreme flavour derived from what is taken in’: he shows that the supreme flavour of food should be seen as derived from this or that thing that is taken in. For the food of the gods of the Cātumahārājika heaven is supreme in comparison with the food of the Wheel-turning Monarch, and so on up to the food of the gods of the Highest Gods’ heaven.

original: 335. Attharaso nāma cattāri sāmaññaphalāni “ariyamaggānaṃ phalabhūto raso”ti katvā.🔽Dhammaraso nāma cattāro maggā “sāmaññaphalassa hetubhūto raso”ti katvā vimuttiraso
analyzed: attha rasaḥ nāma cattāri sāmañña phalāni ariya maggānam phala bhūto rasaḥ ti katvā  dhammarasaḥ nāma cattāro maggā sāmañña phalassa hetu bhūto raso ti katvā vimutti rasaḥ
translated: ‘The flavour of meaning’: the four fruits of the monk’s life, taken as ‘the flavour of the fruits of the noble paths.’

original: nāma amataṃ nibbānaṃ “sabbasaṅkhārasamatho”ti katvā.
analyzed: nāma amatam nibbānam sabba saṅkhāra samathaḥ iti katvā
translated: ‘The flavour of the True Idea’: the four paths, taken as ‘the flavour that is the cause of the fruits of the monk’s life.’ ‘The flavour of deliverance’: the deathless state of extinction, taken as ‘the stilling of all process.’

original: Catutthavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: catuttha vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the fourth section is ended.

original: Jambudīpapeyyālo niṭṭhito.
translated: The ‘Rose-Apple Island’ chapter is ended.

original: 17. Pasādakaradhammavaggavaṇṇanā
translated: The Chapter on Things Which Inspire One with Confidence

original: 366. Addhamidanti sandhivasena pāḷiyaṃ rassaṃ katvā vuttaṃ, ma-kāro padasandhikaroti
analyzed: sandhi vasena pāḷiyam rassam katvā vuttam makāraḥ pada sandhi karoti
translated: ‘Half a measure’: this is said in the text in the abbreviated form ‘half a measure’ by the sandhi-contraction of the letters; the letter ‘m’ is a sandhi-connector.

original: āha – “addhā ida”nti. Ekaṃso esāti ekaṃso hetu esa lābhānaṃ. Pāpakaṃ nāmāti appakampi🔽pāpaṃ nāma byattaṃ ekaṃsena na karoti. Tathassāti tathā sammāpaṭipajjamānassa assa.
analyzed: āha addhā idam ti ekaṃsaḥ esa ati ekaṃsaḥ hetu esa lābhānam pāpakam nāma ati appakampi  pāpam nāma byattam ekaṃsena na karoti tathā assa ati tathā sammā paṭipajjamānassa assa
translated: He said, “Certainly this is so.” This is the cause for gain: this is the single cause for gain. Evil: even a little evil is not to be done. Thus: thus for one who conducts himself rightly.🔽The state of being a forest-dweller … the state of being one who possesses only three robes: by undertaking these ascetic practices, the other similar ones are also undertaken.

original: Āraññikattaṃ…pe… tecīvarikattanti imesaṃ dhutadhammānaṃ gahaṇeneva itaresampi taṃsabhāgānaṃ🔽gahitabhāvo daṭṭhabbo. Thāvarappattabhāvoti sāsane thirabhāvappatti therabhāvo. Ākappassa
analyzed: āraññikattam pe tecīvarikattanti imesam dhuta dhammānam gahaṇena iva itaresam pi taṃsa bhāgānam  gahita bhāvaḥ daṭṭhabbo thāvara patta bhāvo ti sāsane thira bhāva ppatti thera bhāvaḥ ākappassa
translated: The state of being one who has attained stability: the state of being an elder, the attainment of stability in the Dispensation.

original: sampattīti “añño me ākappo karaṇīyo”ti evaṃ vuttassa ākappassa sampatti. Kolaputtīti🔽kolaputtiyanti āha – “kulaputtabhāvo”ti. Sampannarūpatāti upadhisampadā. Vacanakiriyāyāti
analyzed: sampattī iti aññaḥ me ākappo karaṇīyaḥ ti evam vuttassa ākappassa sampatti kolaputtī iti  kolaputtiyanti āha kula putta bhāvaḥ ti sampanna rūpa tā ati upadhi sampadā vacana kiriyāya ati
translated: The attainment of the state of being one who has a sense of moral shame: the attainment of the state of being one who has a sense of moral shame. The attainment of the state of being one who has a sense of moral dread: the attainment of the state of being one who has a sense of moral dread. The attainment of the state of being one who has attained view: the attainment of the state of being one who has attained view. The attainment of the state of being one who has attained insight: the attainment of the state of being one who has attained insight. The attainment of the state of being one who has attained peace: the attainment of the state of being one who has attained peace. The attainment of the state of being one who has attained final knowledge: the attainment of the state of being one who has attained final knowledge.

original: vacanappayogassa madhurabhāvo mañjussaratā. Tenassa lābho uppajjatīti idaṃ na lābhuppādanūpāyadassanaparaṃ,
analyzed: vacana ppayogassa madhura bhāvaḥ mañju ssara tā tena assa lābhaḥ uppajjati iti idam na lābha uppādana upāya dassana param
translated: The attainment of the state of being a clansman: the state of being a clansman. The attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with form: the endowment with requisites. The attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with speech and action: the attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with speech and action. The attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with eloquence: the attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with eloquence. The attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with the appearance of a brahmin: the attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with the appearance of a brahmin. The attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with the appearance of a noble: the attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with the appearance of a noble. The attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with the appearance of a recluse: the attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with the appearance of a recluse. The attainment of the state of being one who is endowed with the appearance of a brahmin: the

original: atha kho evaṃ sammāpaṭipajjamānassa anicchantasseva lābho uppajjatīti lābhassa abyabhicārahetudassanaparaṃ
analyzed: atha kho evam sammā paṭipajjamānassa an icchantassa iva lābhaḥ uppajjati iti lābhassa abyabhicāra hetu dassana param
translated: But if one acts rightly in this way, gain will arise even if one is unwilling. The following sutta passage shows the reason for the invariable occurrence of gain:

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yathāha –
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam yathā āha
translated: Then, if one who is practising rightly in this way should not wish for gain, gain will still arise for him. So this sutta should be regarded as showing the reason why gain does not fail one. For it is said:

original: “Ākaṅkheyya ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu lābhī assaṃ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānanti, sīlesvevassa paripūrakārī”ti.
analyzed: ākaṅkheyya ce bhikkhave bhikkhu lābhī assam cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna ppaccaya bhesajja parikkhārā ananti sīlesu eva assa paripūra kārī iti
translated: “If, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu should wish, ‘May I be respected for my virtue,’ he should train in these same five training precepts” .

original: Pasādakaradhammavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pasādakara dhamma vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the “Chapter on the State Conducive to Upleading” is ended.

original: 18. Aparaaccharāsaṅghātavaggavaṇṇanā
translated: The chapter on the state conducive to upleading

original: 382. Idampi suttanti ettha pi-saddo heṭṭhā vuttacūḷaccharāsaṅghātasuttaṃ sampiṇḍeti.🔽Cūḷaccharāsaṅghātasutte appanaṃ appattāya mettāya tāvamahanto vipāko dassito, kimaṅgaṃ
analyzed: idam pi suttam ti ettha pi saddaḥ heṭṭhā vutta cūḷaccharā saṅghāta suttam sampiṇḍeti  cūḷaccharā saṅghāta sutte appanam appattāya mettāya tāva mahantaḥ vipākaḥ dassito kimaṅgam
translated: Herein, the word “also” includes the Shorter Discourse on the Uplifted Mind .

original: pana imissā appanāppattāya mettāyāti dassetuṃ – “appanāppattāya hī”tiādimāha. Vipākakathāyeva
analyzed: pana imissā appanā appattāya mettāya ati dassetum appanā appattāya hi iti ādim āha vipāka kathāya iva
translated: In the Shorter Discourse on the Uplifted Mind the outcome of the development of loving-kindness that has not reached absorption is shown, but what need is there to say anything about the outcome of loving-kindness that has reached absorption? In order to show this, he said “For when it has reached absorption” .🔽There is no talk of outcome at all: the reading is “na kathā atthi vipāko” .

original: natthīti vipāke kathāyeva natthi, ayameva vā pāṭho. Gaṇanānupubbatāti gaṇanānupubbatāya.
analyzed: natthi iti vipāke kathāya iva natthi ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ gaṇanā anupubba tā ati gaṇanā anupubba tāya
translated: In order by number: in order by number.

original: Paṭhamaṃ uppannantipi paṭhamaṃ, paṭhamaṃ samāpajjatīti idaṃ pana na ekantalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhamam uppannanti pi paṭhamam paṭhamam samāpajjati iti idam pana na ekanta lakkhaṇam
translated: “First arisen” is also called “first” . But this is not a characteristic of the jhāna itself.

original: Ciṇṇavasībhāvo hi aṭṭhasamāpattilābhī ādito paṭṭhāya matthakaṃ pāpentopi samāpajjituṃ
analyzed: ciṇṇavasībhāvaḥ hi aṭṭha samāpatti lābhī āditaḥ paṭṭhāya matthakam pāpentaḥ api samāpajjitum
translated: For one who has attained mastery in the attainment of jhāna can enter upon it from the beginning right up to the peak ;

original: sakkoti, matthakato paṭṭhāya ādiṃ pāpentopi, antarantarā okkantopi samāpajjituṃ sakkoti
analyzed: sakkoti matthakato paṭṭhāya ādim pāpentaḥ api antar antarā okkantaḥ api samāpajjitum sakkoti
translated: and he can enter upon it from the peak down to the beginning, and from the beginning up to the peak again by leaping over one or several stages.🔽But it is called “first” in the sense of first-arisen.

original: eva. Pubbuppattiyaṭṭhena pana paṭhamaṃ nāma hoti. Vibhaṅgeti jhānavibhaṅge. Vipassanaṃ
analyzed: eva pubbuppattiya ṭṭhena pana paṭhamam nāma hoti vibhaṅge iti jhāna vibhaṅge vipassanam
translated: In the Vibhaṅga: “‘Jhāna’: the equanimity, the mental factor of equanimity, that is accompanied by the fourth jhāna” .

original: kayiramānaṃ lakkhaṇūpanijjhānakiccaṃ maggena sijjhati taggatasammohaviddhaṃsanato.
analyzed: lakkhaṇa upanijjhāna kiccam maggena sijjhati tad gata sammoha viddhaṃsanato
translated: The function of insight is the act of contemplation of characteristics. It succeeds by means of the path, because it abolishes delusion about the three characteristics.

original: Apica vipassanāya lakkhaṇūpanijjhānaṃ maggena uppannena sijjhati itarathā parivattanato,
analyzed: apica vipassanāya lakkhaṇa upanijjhānam maggena uppannena sijjhati itarathā parivattanato
translated: Besides, the contemplation of characteristics by insight succeeds by means of the path arisen in the penultimately retrieved jhāna, not by means of any other, because of the absence of reviewing.

original: tasmā maggo lakkhaṇūpanijjhānaṃ, na aniccādilakkhaṇānaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇato. Yathā phalaṃ
analyzed: tasmā maggaḥ lakkhaṇa upanijjhānam na anicca ādi lakkhaṇānam ārammaṇa karaṇataḥ yathā phalam
translated: So the path is the contemplation of characteristics, not because it makes the characteristics of impermanence, etc., its object,🔽but rather because it is the contemplation of the characteristics of the path, etc., in the way stated.🔽And just as the fruition of non-return is the contemplation of the characteristic of the unformed element, Nibbāna, by making that its object,

original: nibbānassa asaṅkhatalakkhaṇaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇavasena upanijjhāyati, evaṃ maggopi. Evampissa
analyzed: nibbānassa asaṅkhata lakkhaṇam ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena upanijjhāyati evam maggaḥ api evam pissa
translated: so too is the path.

original: lakkhaṇūpanijjhānataṃ veditabbaṃ. Vattabbameva natthi arittajjhānatāya. Sesaṃ visesaṃ,
analyzed: lakkhaṇa upanijjhāna tam veditabbam vattabbam eva natthi aritta jhāna tāya sesam visesam
translated: It is not necessary to say that it is because of the absence of jhāna. The rest is as already stated.

original: arittajjhānā evāti attho.
analyzed: eva ati attho
translated: The meaning is that they are without jhāna.

original: 386-387. Hitapharaṇanti sattesu hitānurūpaṃ jhānassa pharitvā pavattanaṃ. Cetopaṭipakkhato
analyzed: hita pharaṇam ti sattesu hita anurūpam jhānassa pharitvā pavattanam cetaḥ paṭipakkhato
translated: “Spreading of the mind”: the occurrence of jhāna after spreading it in conformity with the welfare of beings.

original: vimuccati etāyāti cetovimutti, appanāppattā mettā. Tenāha – “idhā”tiādi. Eseva nayoti
analyzed: vimuccati etāya ati cetaḥ vimutti appanā appattā mettā tena āha idha atiādi esā iva
translated: “Liberation of the mind”: the attainment of absorption in loving-kindness.🔽This is the method in each instance.🔽The same method applies to compassion, and so on.

original: iminā karuṇādīnampi appanāppattataṃ atidisati. Vaṭṭaṃ honti kammavaṭṭabhāvato. Vaṭṭapādā
analyzed: iminā karuṇā ādīnam pi appanā appatta tam atidisati vaṭṭam honti kamma vaṭṭa bhāvataḥ vaṭṭa pādāḥ
translated: They are “roots of the round” because they are roots of the round of kamma.

original: hontīti vipākavaṭṭassa kāraṇaṃ honti.
analyzed: honti iti vipāka vaṭṭassa kāraṇam honti
translated: They are “feet of the round” because they are causes for the round of result.

original: 390. Ajjhattaparikammavasenāti attano kesādīsu parikammakaraṇavasena. Aṭṭhārasavidheti🔽aṭṭhārasappabhede. Kāyeti rūpakāye. Rūpakāyo hi idha aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ kesādīnañca
analyzed: ajjhatta parikamma vasena ati attano kesa ādīsu parikamma karaṇa vasena aṭṭhārasavidhā iti  aṭṭhārasa ppabhede kāya iti rūpa kāye rūpa kāyaḥ hi idha aṅga paccaṅgānam kesa ādīnam ca
translated: “By means of the preliminary work on the internal”: by means of the preliminary work on one’s own head hairs, etc.,🔽“Eighteen kinds”: of the eighteen kinds.

original: dhammānaṃ samūhaṭṭhena hatthikāyarathakāyādayo viya kāyoti adhippeto. Samūhavisayatāya
analyzed: dhammānam samūha aṭṭhena hatthi kāya ratha kāya ādayaḥ viya kāyo ti adhippeto samūha visaya tāya
translated: “The body”: the material body. For the material body is intended here in the sense of a collection of the parts of the body, the head hairs, etc., in the way that an army, etc., is .

original: cassa kāyasaddassa samudāyūpādanatāya ca asubhākārassa “kāye”ti ekavacanaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: cassa kāya saddassa samudāya upādana tāya ca asubha ākārassa kāya iti ekavacanam tathā
translated: And because the sound of the body is taken as a whole, the expression “in the body” is in the singular.

original: ārammaṇādivibhāgena anekabhedabhinnampi cittaṃ cittabhāvasāmaññena ekajjhaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: ārammaṇa ādi vibhāgena aneka bheda bhinnam pi cittam citta bhāva sāmaññena ekajjham gahetvā
translated: Likewise, although consciousness is of many kinds, classified according to its objects, etc., it is taken as a unity by the general characteristic of being conscious,🔽and the expression “in consciousness” is in the singular.

original: “citte”ti ekavacanaṃ kataṃ. Kāyānupassīti imassa atthaṃ dassetuṃ – “tameva kāyaṃ
analyzed: citta iti ekavacanam katam kāya anupassī iti imassa attham dassetum tam eva kāyam
translated: To show the meaning of “contemplating the body” he says, “Contemplating that same body with wisdom.”

original: paññāya anupassanto”ti āha. Tameva kāyanti ca avadhāraṇena vedanādianupassanaṃ nivatteti.🔽Tena ca puna kāyaggahaṇassa payojanaṃ sūcitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Kāye”ti hi vatvāpi puna
analyzed: paññāya anupassanto ti āha tam eva kāyanti ca avadhāraṇena vedanā ādi anupassanam nivatteti  tena ca puna kāya ggahaṇassa payojanam sūcitan ti daṭṭhabbam kāya iti hi vatvā api puna
translated: And by the specification “that same body” he excludes contemplation of feeling, etc.🔽And the purpose of mentioning the body again should be understood to be indicated by that.

original: “kāyānupassī”ti dutiyaṃ kāyaggahaṇaṃ asammissato vavatthānaghanavinibbhogādidassanatthaṃ
analyzed: kāya anupassī ti dutiyam kāya ggahaṇam a sammissataḥ vavatthāna ghana vinibbhoga ādi dassana tham
translated: For although he said “in the body,” he mentions the body again with the words “contemplating the body” in order to show that it is distinguished by non-confusion, by the penetration of its individual essence, etc.

original: kataṃ. Tena vedanādayopi ettha sitā, ettha paṭibaddhāti kāyavedanādianupassanappasaṅgepi
analyzed: katam tena vedanā ādayaḥ api ettha sitāḥ ettha paṭibaddhā ati kāya vedanā ādi anupassana ppasaṅge pi
translated: Thus, although the contemplation of feeling, etc., is included in the contemplation of the body since it is white and bound up with the body,

original: āpanne na kāye vedanānupassī cittānupassī dhammānupassī vā. Atha kho kāyānupassīyevāti
analyzed: āpanne na kāye vedanā anupassī citta anupassī dhamma anupassī vā atha kho kāya anupassī iya eva ati
translated: nevertheless he is not “contemplating the body in the body” or “contemplating feeling in the body” or “contemplating mind in the body” or “contemplating dhammas in the body.”🔽But he is “contemplating the body in the body” only.

original: kāyasaṅkhātavatthusmiṃ kāyānupassanākārasseva dassanena asammissato vavatthānaṃ dassitaṃ
analyzed: kāya saṅkhāta vatthusmim kāya anupassanā ākārassa iva dassanena a sammissataḥ vavatthānam dassitam
translated: The delimitation of the body as a particular formation of materiality is shown by the seeing of it as the aspect of contemplation of the body, not confusedly.🔽And so too in the case of the other three.

original: hoti. Tathā na kāye aṅgapaccaṅgavinimuttaekadhammānupassī, nāpi kesalomādivinimuttaitthipurisānupassī.
analyzed: hoti tathā na kāye aṅga paccaṅga vinimutta eka dhamma anupassī na api kesa loma ādi vinimutta aitthi purisa anupassī
translated: And here, although the body is a combination of the primary elements and the materiality derived from the primary elements, he does not contemplate it as a single entity divorced from the primary elements and the materiality derived from the primary elements.🔽And although the body is a combination of limbs and minor parts, he does not contemplate it as a single entity divorced from the limbs and minor parts.🔽And although the body is a combination of head hairs, body hairs, teeth, nails, etc., he does not contemplate it as a single entity divorced from the head hairs, body hairs, teeth, nails, etc.

original: Yopi cettha kesalomādiko bhūtupādāyasamūhasaṅkhāto kāyo, katthapi na bhūtupādāyavinimuttaekadhammānupassī,
analyzed: yaḥ api ca ittha kesa loma ādikaḥ bhūta upādāya samūha saṅkhātaḥ kāyaḥ kattha api na bhūta upādāya vinimutta eka dhamma anupassī
translated: And although the body is a combination of primary elements and derived materiality, he does not contemplate it as a single entity divorced from the primary elements and the derived materiality.

original: atha kho rathasambhārānupassako viya aṅgapaccaṅgasamūhānupassī, nāgarāvayavānupassako🔽viya kesalomādisamūhānupassī, kadalikkhandhapattavaṭṭivinibbhujjako rittamuṭṭhiviniveṭhako
analyzed: atha kho ratha sambhāra anupassakaḥ viya aṅga paccaṅga samūha anupassī nāgara avayava anupassakaḥ  kesa loma ādi samūha anupassī kadali kkhandha patta vaṭṭi vinibbhujjakaḥ ritta muṭṭhi viniveṭhakaḥ
translated: But rather like one who contemplates a chariot’s components, he contemplates the combination of limbs and minor parts.🔽Like one who contemplates the parts of an elephant, he contemplates the combination of head hairs, body hairs, teeth, nails, etc.🔽Like one who, when shown an empty fist, discerns only an empty fist, he contemplates the combination of primary elements and derived materiality.

original: viya ca bhūtupādāyasamūhānupassīyevāti nānappakārato samūhavaseneva kāyasaṅkhātassa🔽vatthuno dassanena ghanavinibbhogo dassito hoti. Na hettha yathāvuttasamūhavinimutto
analyzed: ca bhūta upādāya samūha anupassīya iva ati nānā pakārato samūha vasena iva kāya saṅkhātassa 🔽vatthuno dassanena ghana vinibbhogaḥ dassitaḥ hoti na ha ittha yathāvutta samūha vinimutto
translated: So by seeing the body as a particular combination, the dissection of the compact is shown in various ways.

original: kāyo vā itthī vā puriso vā añño vā koci dhammo dissati, yathāvuttadhammasamūhamatteyeva
analyzed: kāyaḥ vā itthī vā purisaḥ vā aññaḥ vā koci dhammo dissati yathāvutta dhamma samūha mattā iva iva
translated: and the body, or a woman, or a man, or something else, is seen,

original: pana tathā tathā sattā micchābhinivesaṃ karonti.
analyzed: pana tathā tathā sattāḥ micchā abhinivesam karonti
translated: but beings misapprehend it in various ways in the mere aggregate described thus.🔽In the eighteen ways: in the eighteen modes.

original: Aṭṭhārasavidhenāti aṭṭhārasavidhā. Satipaṭṭhānabhāvakassāti satipaṭṭhānabhāvaṃ bhāventassa.
analyzed: aṭṭhārasavidhena ati aṭṭhārasavidhā sati paṭṭhāna bhāvakassa ati sati paṭṭhāna bhāvam bhāventassa
translated: In the development of the foundations of mindfulness: in the development of the meditation that is the foundation of mindfulness.

original: Tīsu bhavesu kilese ātapetīti ātāpo, vīriyassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Yadipi hi kilesānaṃ pahānaṃ
analyzed: tīsu bhavesu kilese ātapeti iti ātāpaḥ vīriyassa etam nāmam yat ipi hi kilesānam pahānam
translated: Heat is the name for energy. For although the abandoning of defilements

original: ātāpananti, taṃ sammādiṭṭhiādīnampi attheva. Ātapasaddo viya pana ātāpasaddopi vīriyeva
analyzed: ātāpanam ti tam sammādiṭṭhi ādīnam pi atthā iva ātapa saddaḥ viya pana ātāpa saddaḥ api vīriyā iva
translated: is also a kind of heating, the word “heat” is used only figuratively for right view, etc.,

original: niruḷho. Atha vā paṭipakkhappahāne sampayuttadhammānaṃ abbhussahanavasena pavattamānassa🔽vīriyassa sātisayaṃ tadātāpananti vīriyameva tathā vuccati, na aññadhammā, tasmā
analyzed: niruḷhaḥ atha vā paṭipakkha ppahāne sampayutta dhammānam abbhussahana vasena pavattamānassa  vīriyassa sa atisayam vīriyam eva tathā vuccati na añña dhammā tasmā
translated: but it is established by usage for energy. Or alternatively, since energy occurs in the sense of bearing up the associated states by abandoning their opposites,🔽it is only energy that is called “heat” in the sense of heating that, not any other state. Therefore

original: ātāpoti vīriyassa nāmaṃ, so assa atthīti ātāpī. Ayañca īkāro pasaṃsāya atisayassa
analyzed: ātāpo ti vīriyassa nāmam saḥ assa atthi iti ātāpī ayam ca īkāro pasaṃsāya atisayassa
translated: “heat” is a name for energy. He has that, thus he is “energetic” . And this “i” is a particle in the sense of a superlative.

original: vā dīpakoti ātāpiggahaṇena sammappadhānasamaṅgitaṃ dasseti. Tenevāha – “ātāpīti…pe…🔽vīriyena vīriyavā”ti. Sampajānoti sampajaññasaṅkhātena ñāṇena samannāgato. Tenāha🔽– “aṭṭhārasavidhena…pe… sammā pajānanto”ti. Ayaṃ panettha vacanattho – sammā samantato🔽sāmañca pajānanto sampajāno, asammissato vavatthāne aññadhammānupassitābhāvena sammā
analyzed: vā dīpako ti ātāpi ggahaṇena sammappadhāna samaṅgi tam dasseti tena iva āha  vīriyena vīriyavāti sampajānoti sampajañña saṅkhātena ñāṇena samannāgataḥ tena āha  sammā pajānanto ti ayam pana ittha vacana attho sammā samantataḥ  sāmañca pajānantaḥ sampajāno a sammissataḥ vavatthāne añña dhamma anupassi tā bhāvena sammā
translated: and “lamp” by “radiance” he shows the possession of right endeavour. Hence he said: “Radiance” is zeal. He is possessed of radiance, thus he is radiant. He is possessed of zeal, thus he is zealous. He is possessed of energy, thus he is energetic.

original: aviparītaṃ sabbākārappajānena samantato uparūparivisesāvahabhāvena pavattiyā sammā pajānantoti attho.🔽Kāyo ca idha lujjanappalujjanaṭṭhena lokoti adhippetoti āha – “tasmiṃyeva kāyasaṅkhāte🔽loke”ti. Pañcakāmaguṇikataṇhanti rūpādīsu pañcasu kāmaguṇesu pavattamānaṃ taṇhaṃ.🔽Yasmā panettha abhijjhāgahaṇena kāmacchando, domanassaggahaṇena byāpādo saṅgahaṃ
analyzed: aviparītam sabba ākāra ppajānena samantataḥ upari upari visesa āvaha bhāvena pavattiyā sammā pajānanto ti attho 🔽kāyo ca idha lujjana ppalujjana aṭṭhena loko iti adhippeto iti āha tasmin yeva kāya saṅkhāte 🔽loka iti rūpa ādīsu pañcasu kāmaguṇesu pavattamānam taṇham 🔽yasmai pana ittha abhijjhā gahaṇena kāmacchandaḥ domanassa gahaṇena byāpādaḥ saṅgaham
translated: “He is fully aware” : he is endowed with the knowledge called “full awareness” . Hence he said: “He is fully aware, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four foundations of mindfulness, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four right endeavours, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four bases of success, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the five spiritual faculties, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the five spiritual powers, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the seven factors of enlightenment, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the Noble Eightfold Path, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four noble truths, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the ten courses of wholesome and unwholesome kamma, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four fruits of asceticism, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four fruits of the contemplative life, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four foundations of mindfulness, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four right endeavours, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four bases of success, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the five spiritual faculties, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the five spiritual powers, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the seven factors of enlightenment, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the Noble Eightfold Path, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four noble truths, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the ten courses of wholesome and unwholesome kamma, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four fruits of asceticism, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four fruits of the contemplative life, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four foundations of mindfulness, thus he is fully aware. He is fully aware of the four right endeavours, thus he is fully aware.

original: gacchati, tasmā nīvaraṇapariyāpannabalavadhammadvayadassanena nīvaraṇappahānaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: gacchati tasmai nīvaraṇa pariyāpanna balava dhamma dvaya dassanena nīvaraṇa ppahānam vuttam
translated: and it goes, therefore it should be understood that the abandoning of the hindrances is stated by the seeing of the two ideas, namely, the hindrances and the strength, which are included in the hindrances.

original: hotīti veditabbaṃ. Visesena cettha abhijjhāvinayena kāyasampattimūlakassa anurodhassa,
analyzed: hoti iti veditabbam visesena ca ittha abhijjhā vinayena kāya sampatti mūlakassa anurodhassa
translated: And here in particular the abandoning of the hindrance of covetousness is stated as the abandoning of compliance rooted in bodily good things,

original: domanassavinayena kāyavipattimūlakassa virodhassa, abhijjhāvinayena ca kāye abhiratiyā,🔽domanassavinayena kāyabhāvanāya anabhiratiyā, abhijjhāvinayena kāye abhūtānaṃ subhasukhabhāvādīnaṃ
analyzed: domanassa vinayena kāya vipatti mūlakassa virodhassa abhijjhā vinayena ca kāye abhiratiyā  domanassa vinayena kāya bhāvanāya anabhiratiyā abhijjhā vinayena kāye abhūtānam subha sukha bhāva ādīnam
translated: and the abandoning of the hindrance of grief is stated as the abandoning of resistance rooted in bodily bad things, and the abandoning of the hindrance of covetousness is stated as the abandoning of delight in the body,🔽and the abandoning of the hindrance of grief is stated as the abandoning of non-delight in the body’s purification, and the abandoning of the hindrance of covetousness is stated as the abandoning of the super imposition on the body of what is not there, namely, beauty, pleasure, permanence, and a self,

original: pakkhepassa, domanassavinayena kāye bhūtānaṃ asubhāsukhabhāvādīnaṃ apanayanassa ca
analyzed: pakkhepassa domanassa vinayena kāye bhūtānaṃ asubha asukha bhāva ādīnam apanayanassa ca
translated: and the abandoning of the hindrance of grief is stated as the abandoning of the removal from the body of what is there, namely, ugliness, pain, impermanence, and not a self.

original: pahānaṃ vuttaṃ. Tena yogāvacarassa yogānubhāvo yogasamatthatā ca dīpitā hoti. Yogānubhāvo
analyzed: pahānam vuttam tena yogāvacarassa yoga anubhāvaḥ yoga samattha tā ca dīpitā hoti yoga anubhāvaḥ
translated: And so the potency of the meditator’s meditation and his capacity for it are also shown.

original: hi esa, yadidaṃ anurodhavirodhavippamutto aratiratisaho abhūtapakkhepabhūtāpanayanavirahito
analyzed: hi esa yat idam anurodha virodha vippamuttaḥ arati rati sahaḥ abhūta pakkhepa bhūta apanayana virahitaḥ
translated: For this is the potency of meditation, namely, that it is free from compliance and resistance, that it is able to endure delight and non-delight, and that it is free from the superimposition of what is not and the removal of what is.

original: ca hoti. Anurodhavirodhavippamutto cesa aratiratisaho abhūtaṃ apakkhipanto bhūtañca🔽anapanento yogasamattho hotīti. Suddharūpasammasanameva kathitanti kevalaṃ kāyānupassanābhāvato vuttaṃ.🔽Sukhādibhedāsu vedanāsūti sukhadukkhaadukkhamasukhasāmisanirāmisabhedāsu vedanāsu.🔽Tattha sukhayatīti sukhā, sampayuttadhamme kāyañca laddhassāde karotīti attho. Suṭṭhu
analyzed: ca hoti anurodha virodha vippamutto ca esa arati rati sahaḥ abhūtam apakkhipantaḥ bhūtam ca  an apanentaḥ yoga samatthaḥ hoti iti suddha rūpa sammasanam eva kathitan ti kevalam kāya anupassanā bhāvataḥ vuttam  sukha ādi bhedāsu vedanāsu iti sukha dukkha adukkha masukha sāmisa nirāmisa bhedāsu vedanāsu  tattha sukhayati iti sukhā sampayutta dhamme kāyañca laddha ssāde karoti iti attho suṭṭhu
translated: He is free from approval and opposition. He is able to endure pleasure and pain. He is able to put aside what is unreal and to maintain what is real. He is fit for the higher iddhi-powers.🔽It is said that he has only the bare purification of his view: this is said because he has only the contemplation of the body.🔽In the kinds of feeling classed as pleasant, etc., : in the kinds of feeling classed as pleasant, painful, neither-painful-nor-pleasant, worldly, and unworldly.🔽Herein, it refreshes , thus it is pleasant ; the meaning is that it makes both associated states and the body possess refreshment. It is pleasant in the sense of refreshing .

original: vā khādati, khanati vā kāyikaṃ cetasikañca ābādhanti sukhā, sukaraṃ okāsadānaṃ etissāti🔽vā sukhā. Dukkhayatīti dukkhā, sampayuttadhamme kāyañca pīḷeti vibādhatīti attho.🔽Duṭṭhu vā khādati, khanati vā kāyikaṃ cetasikañca sātanti dukkhā, dukkaraṃ okāsadānaṃ🔽etissāti vā dukkhā. Dukkhasukhappaṭikkhepena adukkhamasukhāti upekkhā vuttā. Vediyati
analyzed: vā khādati khanati vā kāyikam cetasikam ca ābādhanti sukhā sukaram okāsa dānam etissa ati 🔽vā sukhā dukkhayati iti dukkhā sampayutta dhamme kāyam ca pīḍeti vibādhati iti attho 🔽duṭṭhu vā khādati khanati vā kāyikam cetasikam ca dukkhāḥ dukkaram okāsa dānam 🔽etissa ati vā dukkhā dukkha sukha ppaṭikkhepena adukkha masukhā ati upekkhā vuttā vediyati
translated: He is then one who has overcome approval and resistance, one who has overcome the agreeable and the disagreeable, one who has overcome likes and dislikes. He is then one who can endure the agreeable and the disagreeable. He is then one who can endure the arising of what is unarisen and can abandon the arising of what is arisen. He is then one who can endure the occurrence of what has arisen and the non-occurrence of what has arisen. He is then one who can endure the presence of what is present and the absence of what is present. He is then one who can endure the unarisen and the arisen, the past and the future, the present and the not present. He is then one who can endure the seen and the unseen, the heard and the unheard, the sensed and the unsensed, the cognized and the uncognized. He is then one who can endure the discerned and the undiscerned, the mentally liberated and the not mentally liberated, the well liberated and the not well liberated. He is then one who can endure the known and the unknown, the directly known and the not directly known, the attained and the unattained, the realized and the unrealized, the contacted and the uncontacted, the discerned and the undiscerned. He is then one who can endure the arisen and the unarisen, the present and the not present. He is then one who can endure the past and the future, the seen and the not seen, the heard and the not heard, the sensed and the not sensed, the cognized and the not cognized. He is then one who can endure the discerned and the undiscerned, the mentally liberated and the not mentally liberated, the well liberated and the not well liberated. He is then one who can endure the known and the unknown, the directly known and the not directly known, the attained and the unattained, the realized and the unrealized, the contacted and the uncontacted, the discerned and the undiscerned. He is then one who can endure the arisen and the unarisen, the present and the not present. He is then one who can endure the past and the future, the seen and the not seen, the heard and the not heard, the sensed and the not sensed, the cognized and the not cognized. He is then one who can endure the discerned and the undiscerned, the mentally liberated and the not mentally liberated, the well liberated and the not well liberated. He is then one who can endure the known

original: ārammaṇarasaṃ anubhavatīti vedanā. Vediyamānoti anubhavamāno. Sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyāmīti
analyzed: ārammaṇa rasam anubhavati iti vedanā anubhavamānaḥ sukham vedanam vediyāmi iti
translated: He experiences the taste of the object, thus it is feeling. He feels, thus it is feeling. He experiences pleasant feeling, thus it is pleasant feeling.

original: pajānātīti kāyikaṃ vā cetasikaṃ vā sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyamāno “ahaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ🔽vediyāmī”ti pajānātīti attho. Tattha kāmaṃ uttānaseyyakāpi dārakā thaññapivanādikāle
analyzed: pajānāti iti kāyikam vā cetasikam vā sukham vedanam aham sukham vedanam  vediyāmi iti pajānāti iti kāmam uttānaseyyakā api dārakā thañña pivana ādi kāle
translated: He understands thus: “I experience pleasant feeling” .

original: sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyamānā “sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyāmā”ti pajānanti, na panetaṃ evarūpaṃ🔽pajānanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Evarūpañhi jānanaṃ sattupaladdhiṃ na jahati, attasaññaṃ
analyzed: sukham vedanam sukham vedanam vediyāma iti pajānanti na evarūpam  pajānanam sandhāya vuttam evarūpam hi jānanam satta upaladdhim na jahati atta saññam
translated: Herein, of course, even infants at the breast know when they are experiencing pleasant feeling by drinking milk, etc., and they know that they are experiencing pleasant feeling. But that is not the kind of understanding referred to here.

original: na ugghāṭeti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā satipaṭṭhānabhāvanā vā na hoti. Imassa pana bhikkhuno
analyzed: na ugghāṭeti kammaṭṭhānam vā sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā vā na hoti imassa pana bhikkhuno
translated: For that kind of knowledge does not abandon the assumption of a being, it does not uproot the perception of a self, it is not a meditation subject, it is not the development of the foundations of mindfulness.

original: jānanaṃ sattupaladdhiṃ jahati, attasaññaṃ ugghāṭeti, kammaṭṭhānañceva satipaṭṭhānabhāvanā
analyzed: jānanam satta upaladdhim jahati atta saññam ugghāṭeti kammaṭṭhānam ca iva sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā
translated: But this bhikkhu’s knowledge abandons the assumption of a being, it uproots the perception of a self, it is a meditation subject, it is the development of the foundations of mindfulness.

original: ca hoti. Idañhi “ko vediyati, tassa vedanā, kiṃ kāraṇā vedanā”ti evaṃ sampajānantassa
analyzed: ca hoti idam hi kaḥ tassa vedanā kim kāraṇā vedanā ati evam sampajānantassa
translated: For this is said: “He understands thus: ‘When what exists does what come to be? With the arising of what does what arise? When what does not exist does what not come to be? With the cessation of what does what cease?’

original: vediyanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.🔽Tattha ko vediyatīti? Na koci satto vā puggalo vā vediyati. Kassa vedanāti? Na kassaci
analyzed: vedi yanam sandhāya vuttam  tattha kaḥ vediyati iti na koci sattaḥ vā puggalaḥ vā vediyati kassa vedanā ati na kassaci
translated: and the words “he feels” are said with reference to the feeling.🔽Herein, who feels? No being or person feels. Whose feeling is it? It is not the feeling of any being or person. Why is it called feeling? Because it is the state of being felt.

original: sattassa vā puggalassa vā vedanā. Kiṃ kāraṇā vedanāti? Vatthuārammaṇā ca panassa🔽vedanāti. Tasmā esa evaṃ pajānāti “taṃ taṃ sukhādīnaṃ vatthubhūtaṃ rūpādiṃ ārammaṇaṃ🔽katvā vedanāva vediyati, taṃ pana vedanāpavattiṃ upādāya ‘ahaṃ vediyāmī’ti vohāramattaṃ
analyzed: sattassa vā puggalassa vā vedanā kim kāraṇā vedanā ati vatthu ārammaṇā ca pana assa  tasmai esaḥ evam pajānāti tam tam sukha ādīnam vatthu bhūtam rūpa ādim ārammaṇam  katvā tam pana vedanā pavattim upādāya aham vediyāmi iti vohāra mattam
translated: And what is that? It is the feeling itself.🔽Therefore he understands thus: “It is only feeling that feels, feeling that arises when there is a suitable physical basis and object, such as material form, etc., and that is called ‘I am feeling a pleasant feeling.’ But the expression ‘I feel’ is a mere mode of conventional expression based on the occurrence of the feeling. ”

original: hotī”ti. Evaṃ “sukhādīnaṃ vatthubhūtaṃ rūpādiṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā vedanāva vediyatī”ti
analyzed: hoti iti evam sukha ādīnam vatthu bhūtam rūpa ādim ārammaṇam katvā vedanā ava vediyati iti
translated: Thus, when he discerns that “It is only feeling that feels, feeling that arises when there is a suitable physical basis and object, such as material form, etc.,”

original: sallakkhento esa “sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyāmī”ti pajānātīti veditabbo.🔽Atha vā sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyāmīti pajānātīti sukhavedanākkhaṇe dukkhāya vedanāya
analyzed: sallakkhentaḥ esa sukham vedanam vediyāmi iti pajānāti iti veditabbo  atha vā sukham vedanam vediyāmi iti pajānāti iti sukha vedanā kkhaṇe dukkhāya vedanāya
translated: he should be understood to have realized that “I am feeling a pleasant feeling.”

original: abhāvato sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyamāno “sukhaṃ vedanaṃyeva vediyāmī”ti pajānāti. Tena
analyzed: abhāvataḥ sukham vedanam sukham vedanaṃyā iva vediyāmi iti pajānāti tena
translated: Or alternatively, when he discerns that “I am feeling a pleasant feeling,” he discerns that “I am feeling only a pleasant feeling” because at the moment of a pleasant feeling there is no painful feeling.

original: yā pubbe bhūtapubbā dukkhā vedanā, tassā idāni abhāvato imissā ca sukhāya vedanāya
analyzed: yā pubbe bhūta pubbā dukkhā vedanā tassāḥ idāni abhāvataḥ imissā ca sukhāya vedanāya
translated: And because of the absence now of the painful feeling that was formerly present, and because of the absence of the pleasant feeling that will be here later,

original: ito paraṃ paṭhamaṃ abhāvato “vedanā nāma aniccā addhuvā vipariṇāmadhammā”ti itiha
analyzed: itas param paṭhamam abhāvataḥ vedanā nāma aniccā addhuvā vipariṇāma dhammā ati iti ha
translated: he is aware thus: ‘Feeling is impermanent, unstable, of a nature to change.’

original: tattha sampajāno hoti. Dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vediyāmīti pajānātītiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: tattha sampajānaḥ hoti dukkham vedanam vediyāmi iti pajānāti itiādīsu pi esa eva nayaḥ
translated: So he is fully aware of it in this way. The same method of explanation applies to the case of painful feeling, etc.,

original: Sāmisaṃ vā sukhantiādīsu yasmā kilesehi āmasitabbato āmisā nāma pañca kāmaguṇā. Ārammaṇakaraṇavasena
analyzed: sa āmisam vā sukhanti ādīsu yasmā kilesehi āmasitabbataḥ āmisāḥ nāma pañca kāmaguṇāḥ ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena
translated: In the case of the words with-in-itself pleasant, etc., the five strands of sensual desire are called ‘with-in-itself’ because they can be clung to by defilements,🔽and they are ‘with-in-itself’ in the sense of being clung to by the self.

original: saha āmisehīti sāmisā, tasmā sāmisā sukhā nāma pañcakāmaguṇāmisanissitā chasu dvāresu
analyzed: saha āmisehi iti sāmisā tasmā sāmisā sukhā nāma pañca kāmaguṇa āmisa nissitā chasu dvāresu
translated: Therefore ‘with-in-itself pleasant’ is the pleasant feeling that occurs in the six bases of the sensitive matter and is clung to by the six kinds of craving.

original: uppannā chagehassitā somanassavedanā. Sāmisā dukkhā nāma chagehassitā domanassavedanā.
analyzed: uppannā chagehassitā somanassa vedanā sāmisā dukkhā nāma chagehassitā domanassa vedanā
translated: ‘With-in-itself painful’ is the painful feeling that occurs in the six bases and is clung to by the six kinds of resentment.

original: Sā ca chasu dvāresu “iṭṭhārammaṇaṃ nānubhavissāmi nānubhavāmī”ti vitakkayato uppannā
analyzed: sā ca chasu dvāresu iṭṭha ārammaṇam na anubhavissāmi na anubhavāmi iti vitakkayataḥ uppannā
translated: And that should be understood as the painful feeling that occurs in the six bases and is clung to by the six kinds of resentment in one who thinks, “I shall not experience a desirable object” or “I am not experiencing a desirable object” and so on.

original: kāmaguṇanissitā domanassavedanā veditabbā. Nirāmisā sukhā nāma chanekkhammassitā
analyzed: kāma guṇa nissitā domanassa vedanā veditabbā nirāmisā sukhā nāma cha nekkhamma ssitā
translated: ‘With-out-itself pleasant’ is the pleasant feeling that occurs in the six bases and is clung to by the six kinds of renunciation.

original: somanassavedanā. Sā ca chasu dvāresu iṭṭhārammaṇe āpāthagate aniccādivasena vipassanaṃ
analyzed: somanassa vedanā sā ca chasu dvāresu iṭṭha ārammaṇe āpātha gate anicca ādi vasena vipassanam
translated: and the pleasant feeling. And that should be regarded as the pleasant feeling that arises in one who is able to set about insight and to develop it by way of impermanence, etc.,

original: paṭṭhapetvā ussukkāpetuṃ sakkontassa “ussakkitā me vipassanā”ti somanassajātassa
analyzed: paṭṭhapetvā ussukkāpetum sakkontassa ussakkitā me vipassanā ati somanassa jātassa
translated: when a desirable object comes into focus in the six doors, and who is glad, thinking, “Insight has been set up in me,”

original: uppannā somanassavedanā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: uppannā somanassa vedanā daṭṭhabbā
translated: when the pleasant feeling has arisen.

original: Nirāmisā dukkhā nāma chanekkhammassitā domanassavedanā. Sā pana chasu dvāresu iṭṭhārammaṇe🔽āpāthagate anuttaravimokkhasaṅkhātaariyaphaladhammesu pihaṃ paṭṭhapetvā tadadhigamāya
analyzed: nirāmisā dukkhā nāma domanassa vedanā sā pana chasu dvāresu iṭṭha ārammaṇe  āpātha gate anuttara vimokkha saṅkhāta ariya phala dhammesu piham paṭṭhapetvā tad adhigamāya
translated: The unpleasant feeling called “unworldly” is the displeasure that is not mixed with greed. And that should be regarded as the displeasure that arises in one who is unable to set about insight and to develop it by way of impermanence, etc.,🔽when a desirable object comes into focus in the six doors, and who is unable to set about insight and to develop it by way of impermanence, etc.,

original: aniccādivasena vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā ussukkāpetuṃ asakkontassa “imampi pakkhaṃ imampi
analyzed: anicca ādi vasena vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā ussukkāpetum a sakkontassa imam pi pakkham imam pi
translated: after he has set about longing for the noble fruition attainment called the supreme deliverance,🔽and who grieves, thinking, “I have not been able to reach the plane of the noble ones by setting about insight and developing it for this fortnight,

original: māsaṃ imampi saṃvaccharaṃ vipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā ariyabhūmiṃ pāpuṇituṃ nāsakkhi”nti
analyzed: māsam imam pi saṃvaccharam vipassanam ussukkāpetvā ariya bhūmim pāpuṇitum na asakkhinti
translated: this month, this year,”

original: anusocato uppannā domanassavedanā.
analyzed: anusocataḥ uppannā domanassa vedanā
translated: when the displeasure has arisen.🔽The neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling called “worldly” is the equanimity that is mixed with greed. And that should be regarded as the equanimity that arises in one who is unable to set about insight and to develop it by way of impermanence, etc.,

original: Sāmisā adukkhamasukhā nāma chagehassitā upekkhāvedanā. Sā ca chasu dvāresu iṭṭhārammaṇe
analyzed: sāmisā adukkhamasukhā nāma upekkhā vedanā sā ca chasu dvāresu iṭṭha ārammaṇe
translated: when a desirable object comes into focus in the six doors,

original: āpāthagate guḷapiṇḍake nilīnamakkhikā viya rūpādīni anuvattamānā tattheva laggā laggitā
analyzed: āpātha gate guḷa piṇḍake nilīna makkhikā viya rūpa ādīni anuvattamānā tattha iva laggā laggitā
translated: Like a fly caught in a lump of molasses, it is stuck there, stuck fast,

original: hutvā uppannā kāmaguṇanissitā upekkhāvedanā. Nirāmisā adukkhamasukhā nāma chanekkhammassitā🔽upekkhāvedanā. Sā pana chasu dvāresu iṭṭhādiārammaṇe āpāthagate iṭṭhe arajjantassa,
analyzed: hutvā uppannā kāma guṇa nissitā upekkhā vedanā nirāmisā adukkhamasukhā nāma  upekkhā vedanā sā pana chasu dvāresu iṭṭha ādi ārammaṇe āpātha gate iṭṭhe a rajjantassa
translated: and the feeling of equanimity based on the five strands of sense pleasure arises in him. The feeling of equanimity that is not based on the five strands of sense pleasure is called neither-painful-nor-pleasant.

original: aniṭṭhe adussantassa, asamapekkhanena amuyhantassa uppannā vipassanāñāṇasampayuttā
analyzed: aniṭṭhe a dussantassa a samapekkhanena a muyhantassa uppannā vipassanā ñāṇa sampayuttā
translated: It arises in one who is not lusting after a desirable object, who is not hating an undesirable object, and who is not being ignorant of an object that is neither desirable nor undesirable, when one of the six objects comes into focus in one of the six doors.🔽It is the feeling of equanimity associated with the knowledge of insight.

original: upekkhāvedanā. Evaṃ vuttanti mahāsatipaṭṭhānasutte vuttaṃ. Sāva vedanā veditabbāti
analyzed: upekkhā vedanā evam vuttanti mahāsatipaṭṭhāna sutte vuttam sā ava vedanā veditabbā ti
translated: Thus it is said. “Feeling should be understood”:

original: lujjanappalujjanaṭṭhena sā vedanā “loko”ti veditabbā.🔽Evaṃ vitthāriteti “sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ sarāgaṃ cittanti pajānāti, vītarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ…pe…
analyzed: lujjana ppalujjana aṭṭhena sā vedanā loko ti veditabbā  evam vitthāritā iti sa rāgam vā cittam sa rāgam cittam iti pajānāti vīta rāgam vā
translated: the world should be understood in the sense of being broken up and scattered.🔽Thus it is said: “He understands a mind affected by lust as a mind affected by lust, and a mind unaffected by lust as a mind unaffected by lust.🔽He understands a mind affected by hate as a mind affected by hate, and a mind unaffected by hate as a mind unaffected by hate. He understands a mind affected by delusion as a mind affected by delusion, and a mind unaffected by delusion as a mind unaffected by delusion. He understands a contracted mind as contracted,

original: sadosaṃ vā cittaṃ, vītadosaṃ vā cittaṃ, samohaṃ vā cittaṃ, vītamohaṃ vā cittaṃ, saṃkhittaṃ
analyzed: sa dosam vā cittam vīta dosam vā cittam sa moham vā cittam vīta moham vā cittam
translated: and a distracted mind as distracted.

original: vā cittaṃ, vikkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ, mahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ, amahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ, sauttaraṃ🔽vā cittaṃ, anuttaraṃ vā cittaṃ, samāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ, asamāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ, vimuttaṃ
analyzed: vā cittam vikkhittam vā cittam mahaggatam vā cittam amahaggatam vā cittam sauttaram  vā cittam anuttaram vā cittam samāhitam vā cittam asamāhitam vā cittam vimuttam
translated: a contracted mind, or a distracted mind, or a exalted mind, or an unexalted mind, or a surpassable mind,🔽or an unsurpassable mind, or a concentrated mind, or an unconcentrated mind, or a liberated mind,🔽

original: vā cittaṃ, avimuttaṃ vā cittanti pajānātī”ti evaṃ satipaṭṭhānasutte vitthāretvā dassite soḷasavidhe citte.
analyzed: vā cittam a vimuttam vā cittam ti pajānāti iti evam sati paṭṭhāna sutte vitthāretvā dassite soḷasavidhe citte
translated: and whether the mind is distracted or not, is great or not, has a higher object or not, is concentrated or not, is liberated or not. ”

original: Tattha sarāganti aṭṭhavidhaṃ lobhasahagataṃ. Vītarāganti lokiyakusalābyākataṃ. Idaṃ
analyzed: tattha sa rāganti aṭṭhavidham lobha sahagatam vīta rāganti lokiya kusala abyākatam idam
translated: Herein, “with hate” is the eight kinds of consciousness accompanied by hate. “Without hate” is the profitable and indeterminate of the sense sphere.

original: pana yasmā sammasanaṃ na dhammasamodhānaṃ, tasmā idha ekapadepi lokuttaraṃ na labbhati.🔽Sesāni cattāri akusalacittāni neva purimapadaṃ, na pacchimapadaṃ bhajanti. Sadosanti
analyzed: pana yasmai sammasanam na dhamma samodhānam tasmai idha eka pade pi lokuttaram na labbhati  sesāni cattāri akusala cittāni na iva purima padam na pacchima padam bhajanti sa dosanti
translated: But since this is a discerning, not a combining, of ideas, the supramundane is not included here in any of the terms.

original: duvidhaṃ domanassasahagataṃ. Vītadosanti lokiyakusalābyākataṃ. Sesāni dasa akusalacittāni
analyzed: duvidham domanassa sahagatam vīta dosanti lokiya kusala abyākatam sesāni dasa akusala cittāni
translated: The remaining four unprofitable kinds of consciousness do not belong to either term. “With hate” is the two kinds accompanied by grief. “Without hate” is the profitable and indeterminate of the sense sphere. The remaining ten kinds of unprofitable consciousness

original: neva purimapadaṃ, na pacchimapadaṃ bhajanti. Samohanti vicikicchāsahagatañceva uddhaccasahagatañcāti
analyzed: na iva purima padam na pacchima padam bhajanti samohanti vicikicchā sahagatam ca iva uddhacca sahagatam ca ati
translated: They do not belong to either the first or the last. They are of two kinds as associated with uncertainty and as associated with agitation.

original: duvidhaṃ. Yasmā pana moho sabbākusalesu uppajjati, tasmā sesānipi idha vattantiyeva.
analyzed: duvidham yasmā pana mohaḥ sabba akusalesu uppajjati tasmā sesāni pi idha vattantiyā eva
translated: But since delusion arises in all unprofitable states, the rest occur here too.

original: Imasmiññeva hi duke dvādasākusalacittāni pariyādinnānīti. Vītamohanti lokiyakusalābyākataṃ.🔽Saṃkhittanti thinamiddhānupatitaṃ. Etañhi saṅkucitacittaṃ nāma ārammaṇe saṅkocavasena
analyzed: imasmin ñeva hi duke dvādasa akusala cittāni pariyādinnāni iti vīta mohanti lokiya kusala abyākatam  thinam iddha anupatitam etat hi saṅkucita cittam nāma ārammaṇe saṅkoca vasena
translated: For in this dyad the twelve unprofitable consciousnesses are included. They are free from delusion.🔽They are contracted when they are accompanied by stiffness and torpor. For this is called “contracted consciousness” because it occurs

original: pavattanato. Vikkhittanti uddhaccasahagataṃ. Etañhi pasaṭacittaṃ nāma ārammaṇe savisesaṃ
analyzed: pavattanataḥ vikkhittanti uddhacca sahagatam etat hi pasaṭa cittam nāma ārammaṇe sa visesam
translated: by contracting upon an object. They are distracted when they are associated with agitation. For this is called “scattered consciousness” because it occurs by scattering over an object

original: vikkhepavasena visaṭabhāvena pavattanato. Mahaggatanti rūpāvacaraṃ arūpāvacarañca.
analyzed: vikkhepa vasena visaṭa bhāvena pavattanataḥ mahaggatanti rūpāvacaram arūpāvacaram ca
translated: with special distraction by means of scattering. They are exalted when they are of the fine-material sphere and immaterial sphere.

original: Amahaggatanti kāmāvacaraṃ. Sauttaranti kāmāvacaraṃ. Anuttaranti rūpāvacaraṃ arūpāvacarañca.
analyzed: amahaggatanti kāmāvacaram sauttaranti kāmāvacaram anuttaranti rūpāvacaram arūpāvacarañca
translated: They are unexalted when they are of the sense sphere. They are with a higher object when they are of the sense sphere. They are without a higher object when they are of the fine-material sphere and immaterial sphere.

original: Tatrāpi sauttaraṃ rūpāvacaraṃ, anuttaraṃ arūpāvacarameva. Samāhitanti yassa appanāsamādhi🔽vā upacārasamādhi vā atthi. Asamāhitanti ubhayasamādhivirahitaṃ. Vimuttanti tadaṅgavikkhambhanavimuttīhi🔽vimuttaṃ. Avimuttanti ubhayavimuttirahitaṃ. Samucchedappaṭippassaddhinissaraṇavimuttīnaṃ
analyzed: tatra api sa auttaram rūpāvacaram anuttaram arūpāvacaram eva samāhitanti yassa appanā samādhi  vā upacāra samādhi vā atthi asamāhitanti ubhaya samādhi virahitam vimuttanti tad aṅga vikkhambhana vimuttīhi  vimuttam avimuttanti ubhaya vimutti rahitam samuccheda paṭippassaddhi nissaraṇa vimuttīnam
translated: Herein, the supramundane is the highest, and the rest are lower. The supramundane is also called “with residue” and the rest “with- out residue.” Herein, the supramundane is with residue, and the rest are without residue. The supramundane is also called “with root-cause” and the rest “without root-cause.” Herein, the supramundane is with root-cause, and the rest are without root-cause. The supramundane is also called “with object” and the rest “without object.” Herein, the supramundane is with object, and the rest are without object. The supramundane is also called “with support” and the rest “without support.” Herein, the supramundane is with support, and the rest are without support. The supramundane is also called “with fetter” and the rest “without fetter.” Herein, the supramundane is with fetter, and the rest are without fetter. The supramundane is also called “with root” and the rest “without root.” Herein, the supramundane is with root, and the rest are without root. The supramundane is also called “with root-cause” and the rest “without root-cause.” Herein, the supramundane is with root-cause, and the rest are without root-cause. The supramundane is also called “with object” and the rest “without object.” Herein, the supramundane is with object, and the rest are without object. The supramundane is also called “with support” and the rest “without support.” Herein, the supramundane is with support, and the rest are without support. The supramundane is also called “with fetter” and the rest “without fetter.” Herein, the supramundane is with fetter, and the rest are without fetter. The supramundane is also called “with root” and the rest “without root.” Herein, the supramundane is with root, and the rest are without root.

original: pana idha okāsova natthi, okāsābhāvo ca sammasanacārassa adhippetattā veditabbo.🔽Upādānassa khandhā upādānakkhandhā, upādānassa paccayabhūtā dhammapuñjā dhammarāsayoti
analyzed: pana idha okāsaḥ uva natthi okāsa abhāvo ca sammasana cārassa adhippeta ttā veditabbo  upādānassa khandhāḥ upādāna khandhāḥ upādānassa paccaya bhūtāḥ dhamma puñjāḥ dhamma rāsayaḥ ti
translated: Herein, the supramundane is the highest, and the rest are lower. The concentrated is that in which there is absorption concentration or access concentration. The unconcentrated is that which is devoid of both kinds of concentration. The liberated is that which is liberated by the liberation consisting in the abandoning of the defilements to be abandoned by that path. The unliberated is that which is devoid of both kinds of liberation. But there is no opportunity for the liberations consisting in the abolition of wrong views, etc., and for the liberations consisting in the tranquilizing of consciousness and its concomitants, because the mode of procedure of the contemplation of dissolution is intended here.

original: attho. Upādānehi ārammaṇakaraṇādivasena upādātabbā vā khandhā upādānakkhandhā. Cha
analyzed: atthaḥ upādānehi ārammaṇa karaṇa ādi vasena upādātabbāḥ vā khandhāḥ upādāna khandhāḥ cha
translated: The aggregates subject to cankers are the aggregates that are a condition for the cankers. The meaning is: the groups of states that are a condition for the cankers. Or alternatively, the aggregates are subject to cankers in the sense that the cankers adhere to them by way of making them their objective support, and so on.

original: ajjhattikabāhirāyatanānīti cakkhu sotaṃ ghānaṃ jivhā kāyo manoti imāni cha ajjhattikāyatanāni
analyzed: ajjhattika bāhira āyatanāni iti cakkhu sotam ghānam jivhā kāyaḥ manaḥ ti imāni cha ajjhattika āyatanāni
translated: The six internal and six external bases are the six internal bases beginning with the eye and the six external bases beginning with visible data.

original: ceva, rūpaṃ saddo gandho raso phoṭṭhabbo dhammāti imāni cha bāhirāyatanāni ca. Ettha
analyzed: ca iva rūpam saddaḥ gandhaḥ rasaḥ phoṭṭhabbaḥ dhammā ti imāni cha bāhira āyatanāni ca ettha
translated: and the six external bases, namely, visible objects, sounds, smells, tastes, tangible objects, and mental objects.

original: pana lokuttaradhammā na gahetabbā sammasanacārassa adhippetattā. Satta sambojjhaṅgāti
analyzed: pana lokuttara dhammā na gahetabbā sammasana cārassa adhippeta ttā satta sambojjhaṅgā ti
translated: But here the supramundane states should not be taken, because the practice of serenity is intended.🔽Seven Factors of Enlightenment:

original: satisambojjhaṅgādayo satta sambojjhaṅgā. Satiādayo hi sambodhissa, sambodhiyā vā
analyzed: sati sambojjhaṅga ādayaḥ satta sambojjhaṅgā sati ādayaḥ hi sambodhissa sambodhiyā vā
translated: The seven factors of enlightenment are the mindfulness enlightenment factor, and so on.🔽For mindfulness, etc., are factors of enlightenment, either because they are factors for the enlightenment of a Buddha or because they are factors for the enlightenment of anyone.

original: aṅgāti sambojjhaṅgā. Tathā hi sambujjhati āraddhavipassakato paṭṭhāya yogāvacaroti🔽sambodhi, yāya vā so satiādikāya sattadhammasāmaggiyā sambujjhati, kilesaniddāto🔽uṭṭhāti, saccāni vā paṭivijjhati, sā dhammasāmaggī sambodhi, tassa sambodhissa, tassā
analyzed: aṅgā ati sambojjhaṅgā tathā hi sambujjhati āraddha vipassakato paṭṭhāya yogāvacaro ti  sambodhi yāya vā saḥ sati ādikāya satta dhamma sāmaggiyā sambujjhati kilesa niddātaḥ  uṭṭhāti saccāni vā paṭivijjhati sā dhamma sāmaggī sambodhi tassa sambodhissa tassā
translated: For the development of insight in one who has reached the plane of the first path is called “enlightenment” in the sense of “shining” .

original: vā sambodhiyā aṅgāti sambojjhaṅgā.
analyzed: vā sambodhiyāḥ aṅgā ati sambojjhaṅgā
translated: Or enlightenment is the combination of the seven enlightenment factors in one who awakens from the sleep of the defilements, or in one who penetrates the truths, and the factors are the enlightenment factors because they are factors for that enlightenment.

original: Cattāri ariyasaccānīti “dukkhaṃ dukkhasamudayo dukkhanirodho dukkhanirodhagāminipaṭipadā”ti
analyzed: cattāri ariya saccāni iti dukkham dukkha samudayaḥ dukkha nirodhaḥ dukkha nirodha gāmini paṭipadā ati
translated: Four Noble Truths: “The noble truth of suffering, the noble truth of the origin of suffering, the noble truth of the cessation of suffering, the noble truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering.”

original: evaṃ vuttāni cattāri ariyasaccāni. Tattha purimāni dve saccāni vaṭṭaṃ pavattihetubhāvato.
analyzed: evam vuttāni cattāri ariya saccāni tattha purimāni dve saccāni vaṭṭam pavatti hetu bhāvato
translated: The four noble truths are stated thus. Herein, the first two truths are the round of rebirths because they are the cause of the round’s occurrence.

original: Pacchimāni vivaṭṭaṃ nivaṭṭatadadhigamūpāyabhāvato. Tesu bhikkhuno vaṭṭe kammaṭṭhānābhiniveso
analyzed: pacchimāni vivaṭṭam nivaṭṭa tad adhigama upāya bhāvato tesu bhikkhuno vaṭṭe kammaṭṭhāna abhiniveso
translated: The last two are the end of the round because they are the means to the ending of the round and to the realization of the end of the round. Herein, a bhikkhu’s devotion to the meditation subject is in the round of rebirths,

original: hoti sarūpato pariggahasambhavato. Vivaṭṭe natthi abhiniveso avisayattā avisayatte
analyzed: hoti sarūpataḥ pariggaha sambhavataḥ vivaṭṭe natthi abhinivesaḥ a visaya ttā a visaya tte
translated: because it is possible for him to discern it in its true nature. There is no devotion to it in the end of the round because that is not its province. And since it is not its province,

original: ca payojanābhāvato. Pañcadhā vuttesūti satipaṭṭhānasutte vuttesu. Suddhaarūpasammasanamevāti
analyzed: ca payojana abhāvataḥ pañcadhā vuttesu iti sati paṭṭhāna sutte vuttesu suddha a rūpa sammasanam eva ati
translated: there is no purpose in devotion to it there. Stated in five ways: stated in the Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta .

original: rūpena amissitattā kevalaṃ arūpasammasanameva. Khandhāyatanasaccakoṭṭhāsānaṃ pañcakkhandhasaṅgahato
analyzed: rūpena a missita ttā kevalam arūpa sammasanam eva khandha āyatana sacca koṭṭhāsānam pañca kkhandha saṅgahato
translated: Contemplation of pure form only: since it is not mixed with materiality, it is only immaterial contemplation. Since the aggregates, bases, and truths are included in the five aggregates,

original: “rūpārūpasammasana”nti vuttaṃ. Pubbabhāgiyānampi satipaṭṭhānānaṃ saṅgahitattā “lokiyalokuttaramissakāneva kathitānī”ti āha.
analyzed: rūpa arūpa sammasananti vuttam pubbabhāgiyānam pi sati paṭṭhānānam saṅgahita ttā lokiya lokuttara missakāna eva kathitāni iti āha
translated: it is said that “it is called contemplation of materiality and the immaterial.” He said “mixed with the mundane and supramundane” because the first two foundations of mindfulness are included in the mundane and the last two in the supramundane.

original: 394. Anibbattānanti ajātānaṃ. Payogaṃ parakkamanti ettha bhusaṃ yogo payogo, payogova
analyzed: a nibbattānam ti a jātānam payogam parakkamanti ettha bhusam yogo payogo payogo uva
translated: Not yet arisen: not yet born.🔽Herein, the word payoga is derived from the root yuj, to join, with the prefix pa .

original: parakkamo, payogasaṅkhātaṃ parakkamanti attho. Cittaṃ ukkhipatīti kosajjapakkhe patituṃ🔽apadānavasena ukkhipati. Padhānavīriyanti sammappadhānalakkhaṇappattavīriyaṃ. Lokiyāti
analyzed: parakkamaḥ payoga saṅkhātam parakkamanti attho cittam ukkhipati iti kosajja pakkhe patitum  apadāna vasena ukkhipati padhāna vīriyam ti sammappadhāna lakkhaṇa ppatta vīriyam lokiya ati
translated: and the meaning of “endeavour” is that it endeavours by way of application. “It raises the mind” : it raises it from falling into the side of indolence.🔽“Energy of striving” : energy that has attained the characteristic of right striving. “Mundane” :

original: lokiyasammappadhānakathā. Sabbapubbabhāgeti sabbamaggānaṃ pubbabhāge. Kassapasaṃyuttapariyāyenāti
analyzed: lokiya sammappadhāna kathā sabba pubbabhāge ti sabba maggānam pubbabhāge kassapa saṃyutta pariyāyena ati
translated: the discussion of the mundane right striving. “The beginning of all” : the beginning of all paths. “In the method of the Kassapa Saṃyutta” :

original: kassapasaṃyutte āgatasuttena “uppannā me pāpakā akusalā dhammā appahīyamānā anatthāya
analyzed: kassapasaṃyutte āgata suttena uppannāḥ me pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ a pahīyamānāḥ anatthāya
translated: because of the statement in the sutta found in the Kassapa Saṃyutta: “Evil unwholesome states have arisen in me, and if I do not abandon them soon,

original: saṃvatteyyu”nti āgatattā. Sā lokiyāti veditabbā.
analyzed: saṃvatteyyum ti āgata ttā sā lokiyā ati veditabbā
translated: that would be to my harm and suffering for a long time” . That should be understood as mundane.

original: Samathavipassanāvāti avadhāraṇena maggaṃ nivattetvā tassa nivattane kāraṇaṃ dassento,
analyzed: samatha vipassanā vā ti avadhāraṇena maggam nivattetvā tassa nivattane kāraṇam dassento
translated: “The energy of serenity and insight” : by the specification, showing the reason for the turning back of the path,

original: “maggo panā”tiādimāha. Sakiṃ uppajjitvāti idaṃ bhūtakathanamattaṃ. Niruddhassa puna
analyzed: maggaḥ pana atiādim āha sakim uppajjitvā ti idam bhūta kathana mattam niruddhassa puna
translated: he says, “But the path” , etc. “Arising once” : this is merely a statement of fact. Because of the non-arising of what has ceased,

original: anuppajjanato “na koci guṇo”ti āsaṅkeyyāti āha – “so hī”tiādi. Anantarameva yathā
analyzed: an uppajjanataḥ na koci guṇaḥ iti āsaṅkeyya iti āha saḥ hi itiādi anantaram eva yathā
translated: one might doubt that “there is no virtue” , so he says, “For that” , etc. Immediately after, as it were,

original: phalaṃ uppajjati, tathā pavattiyevassa paccayadānaṃ. Purimasmimpīti “anuppannā me
analyzed: phalam uppajjati tathā pavattiyā iva assa paccaya dānam purimasmim pi iti anuppannā me
translated: and the fruit arises, so its occurrence is the giving of the condition. In the first case too, that is, in the passage, “If unarisen unprofitable things should arise in me that would lead to my harm” ,

original: kusalā dhammā uppajjamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyu”nti etthapi. Vuttanti porāṇaṭṭhakathāyaṃ.
analyzed: kusalāḥ dhammāḥ uppajjamānāḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyyun ti ettha api vuttam ti porāṇa ṭṭhakathāyam
translated: it is said in the old commentaries that the path is not mentioned.

original: Taṃ pana tathāvuttavacanaṃ na yuttaṃ dutiyasmiṃ viya purimasmiṃ maggassa aggahaṇe
analyzed: tat pana tathā vutta vacanam na yuttam dutiyasmin viya purimasmin maggassa aggahaṇe
translated: But that statement is not correct, since there is no reason for not mentioning the path in the first case as there is in the second.

original: kāraṇābhāvato. Purimasmiṃ aggahite magge anuppajjamāno maggo anatthāya saṃvatteyyāti🔽āpajjeyya, na cetaṃ yuttaṃ āpajjamāne tasmiṃ padhānatthasambhavato. Catukiccasādhanavasenāti
analyzed: kāraṇa abhāvataḥ purimasmin agga hite magge anuppajjamānaḥ maggaḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyya ati  āpajjeyya na ca itam yuttam āpajjamāne tasmin padhāna attha sambhavataḥ catu kicca sādhana vasena ati
translated: For if the path were not mentioned in the first case, it would follow that the unarisen path would lead to harm,🔽but that is not correct, since the meaning of “leading to harm” is possible only if it has arisen.

original: anuppannākusalānuppādanādicatukiccasādhanavasena.
analyzed: anuppanna akusala anuppādana ādi catu kicca sādhana vasena
translated: By the means of accomplishing the fourfold task: by the means of accomplishing the fourfold task consisting in preventing the unarisen unprofitable from arising, and so on.

original: Vuttanayenāti “asamudācāravasena vā ananubhūtārammaṇavasena vā”tiādinā vuttanayena.
analyzed: vutta nayena ati asamudācāra vasena vā ananubhūta ārammaṇa vasena vā ati ādinā vutta nayena
translated: In the way stated: in the way stated thus: “in the sense of non-occurrence or in the sense of non-experience of an object” , and so on.

original: Vijjamānāti dharamānasabhāvā. Khaṇattayapariyāpannattā uppādādisamaṅgino vattamānabhāvena
analyzed: vijjamānā ati uppāda ādi samaṅginaḥ vattamāna bhāvena
translated: Existing: continuing, having the individual essence of presence, being possessed of arising, etc., by virtue of being included in the three instants.

original: uppannaṃ vattamānuppannaṃ. Tañhi uppādato paṭṭhāya yāva bhaṅgā uddhaṃ pannaṃ pattanti🔽nippariyāyato “uppanna”nti vuccati. Anubhavitvā bhavitvā ca vigataṃ bhutvāvigataṃ.
analyzed: uppannam vattamāna uppannam tat hi uppādataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva bhaṅgāḥ uddham pannam pattanti  nippariyāyataḥ uppannanti vuccati anubhavitvā bhavitvā ca vigatam bhutvā a vigatam
translated: and arisen is what is present. For that is called “arisen” in the indirect sense because it has arisen and is present until its dissolution.🔽“What has occurred and disappeared” is what has disappeared after being experienced and being present.

original: Anubhavanabhavanāni hi bhavanasāmaññena bhutvā-saddena vuttāni. Sāmaññameva hi upasaggena
analyzed: anubhavana bhavanāni hi bhavana sāmaññena vuttāni sāmaññam eva hi upasaggena
translated: For the words “experienced” and “present” are said by the word “occurred” in the sense of the general characteristic of occurrence.🔽For a general characteristic is distinguished by a prefix

original: visesīyati. Idha vipākānubhavanavasena tadārammaṇaṃ avipakkavipākassa sabbathā avigatattā🔽bhavitvāvigatamattavasena kammañca “bhutvāvigatuppanna”nti vuttaṃ. Na aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ
analyzed: idha vipāka anubhavana vasena tad ārammaṇam avipakka vipākassa sabbathā avigata ttā  bhavitvā avigata matta vasena kammañca bhutvā avigata uppannanti vuttam na aṭṭhasāliniyam
translated: from a particular characteristic. Herein, kamma is called “what has occurred and disappeared” in the sense of its having disappeared after being present, that is, in the sense of its having disappeared after having given its fruit, because the result that has occurred in the present is not in any way absent, having that kamma as its support.

original: viya rajjanādivasena anubhūtāpagataṃ javanaṃ uppajjitvā niruddhatāvasena bhūtāpagatañca
analyzed: rajjana ādi vasena anubhūta apagatam javanam uppajjitvā niruddha tā vasena bhūta apagatam ca
translated: But it is not called “what has occurred and disappeared” in the way that impulsion is called “what has disappeared after being experienced” in the Aṭṭhasālinī, or in the way that the formed is called “what has disappeared after being” because it has arisen and ceased.

original: saṅkhataṃ bhūtāpagatuppannanti. Tasmā idha okāsakatuppannaṃ vipākameva vadati, na
