analyzed: saṅkhatam bhūta apagata uppannan ti tasmai idha okāsa kata uppannam vipākam eva vadati na
translated: Therefore the present here is only the result, not🔽kamma as well, as in the Aṭṭhasālinī.

original: tattha viya kammampi. Aṭṭhasāliniyañhi bhūtāvigatuppannaṃ okāsakatuppannañca aññathā
analyzed: tattha viya kammam pi aṭṭhasāliniyam hi bhūta avigata uppannam okāsa kata uppannam ca aññathā
translated: For what has occurred and disappeared in the Aṭṭhasālinī and what is present are different.

original: dassitaṃ. Vuttañhi tattha –🔽“Ārammaṇarasaṃ anubhavitvā niruddhaṃ anubhūtāpagatasaṅkhātaṃ kusalākusalaṃ, upādādittayaṃ
analyzed: dassitam vuttam hi tattha  ārammaṇa rasam anubhavitvā niruddham anubhūta apagata saṅkhātam kusala akusalam
translated: This has been shown. For this is said:🔽“The profitable and unprofitable, which have ceased after experiencing the object’s flavour, are called ‘ceased without remainder of what was experienced.’

original: anuppatvā niruddhaṃ bhūtāpagatasaṅkhātaṃ sesasaṅkhatañca bhūtāpagatuppannaṃ nāma.
analyzed: an uppatvā niruddham bhūta apagata saṅkhātam sesa saṅkhatam ca bhūta apagata uppannam nāma
translated: “The rest of the formed, which has ceased after arising without giving a chance to the three kinds of clinging, is called ‘arisen without remainder of what was formed.’

original: ‘Yānissa tāni pubbe katāni kammānī’ti evamādinā nayena vuttaṃ kammaṃ atītampi samānaṃ
analyzed: yāni issa tāni pubbe katāni kammāni iti evamādinā nayena vuttam kammam atītam pi samānam
translated: “The kamma stated in the way beginning ‘Whatever kamma he has done in the past’ is called ‘arisen with a chance for kamma’ because, though past,

original: aññaṃ vipākaṃ paṭibāhitvā attano vipākassokāsaṃ katvā ṭhitattā, tathākatokāsañca🔽vipākaṃ anuppannampi samānaṃ evaṃ kate okāse ekantena uppajjanato okāsakatuppannaṃ nāmā”ti.
analyzed: aññam vipākam paṭibāhitvā attanaḥ vipākassa ukāsam katvā ṭhita ttā tathākata ukāsam ca  vipākam anuppannam pi samānam evam kate okāse ekantena uppajjanataḥ okāsakatuppannam nāma ati
translated: it still stands giving a chance for its own result by preventing the result of some other kamma.🔽“The result, though arisen, is called ‘arisen with a chance for result’ because it is certain to appear when the chance has been given in this way.

original: Idha pana sammohavinodaniyaṃ vuttanayeneva bhutvāvigatuppannaṃ okāsakatuppannañca dassitaṃ. Vuttañhi, sammohavinodaniyaṃ –
analyzed: idha pana sammoha vinodaniyam vutta nayena iva bhutvā avigata uppannam okāsa kata uppannam ca dassitam vuttam hi sammoha vinodaniyam
translated: “Here, however, what has ceased after giving a chance to the formed is called ‘arisen without remainder of what was formed’ and what has ceased after giving a chance to the formed is called ‘arisen with a chance for result’ in the way stated in the Description of Confusion. For this is said in the Description of Confusion:

original: “Kamme pana jahite ārammaṇarasaṃ anubhavitvā niruddho vipāko bhutvāvigataṃ nāma.
analyzed: kamme pana jahite ārammaṇa rasam anubhavitvā niruddhaḥ vipākaḥ bhutvā avigatam nāma
translated: “When kamma has been exhausted, the result that has ceased after experiencing the object’s flavour is called ‘ceased without remainder of what was formed.’

original: Kammaṃ uppajjitvā niruddhaṃ bhutvāvigataṃ nāma. Tadubhayampi bhutvāvigatuppannanti
analyzed: kammam uppajjitvā niruddham bhutvā avigatam nāma tat ubhayam pi bhutvā avigata uppannanti
translated: And when it has arisen and ceased, it is called “experienced and vanished.” Both these are reckoned as “arisen through experience.”

original: saṅkhyaṃ gacchati. Kusalākusalaṃ kammaṃ aññakammassa vipākaṃ paṭibāhitvā attano vipākassa🔽okāsaṃ karoti. Evaṃ kate okāse vipāko uppajjamāno okāsakaraṇato paṭṭhāya uppannoti
analyzed: saṅkhyam gacchati kusala akusalam kammam añña kammassa vipākam paṭibāhitvā attanaḥ vipākassa  okāsam karoti evam kate okāse vipākaḥ uppajjamānaḥ okāsa karaṇataḥ paṭṭhāya uppanno ti
translated: When profitable and unprofitable kamma have prevented the ripening of other kamma, they make room for their own ripening.

original: vuccati. Idaṃ okāsakatuppannaṃ nāmā”ti.
analyzed: vuccati idam okāsa katuppannam nāma ati
translated: When the room has been made in this way, the ripening, as it arises, is called “arisen” from the time when the room is made. This is called “arisen through making room.”

original: Tattha aṭṭhasāliniyā ayamadhippāyo – “satipi sabbesampi cittuppādānaṃ saṃvedayitasabhāvā🔽ārammaṇānubhavane savipallāse pana santāne cittābhisaṅkhāravasena pavattito abyākatehi🔽visiṭṭho kusalākusalānaṃ sātisayo visayānubhavanākāro. Yathā vikappaggāhavasena rāgādīhi
analyzed: tattha aṭṭhasāliniyāḥ ayam adhippāyaḥ sati pi sabbesam pi citta uppādānam saṃvedayita sabhāvā  ārammaṇa anubhavane sa vipallāse pana santāne citta abhisaṅkhāra vasena pavattitaḥ abyākatehi  visiṭṭhaḥ kusala akusalānam sa atisayaḥ visaya anubhavana ākāraḥ yathā vikappa ggāha vasena rāga ādīhi
translated: Here is the meaning of the passage in the Aṭṭhasālinī: “Although all the kinds of consciousness that are states of being felt are alike in being the experience of an object,🔽nevertheless, when the object is experienced with perversion, the mode of the profitable and unprofitable consciousnesses’ experience of their respective objects is distinguished from that of the indeterminate consciousnesses by their occurrence as a mental formation in a continuity that is not perverted.

original: tabbipakkhehi ca akusalaṃ kusalañca nippariyāyato ārammaṇarasaṃ anubhavati, na tathā
analyzed: tad vipakkhehi ca akusalam kusalam ca nippariyāyataḥ ārammaṇa rasam anubhavati na tathā
translated: Just as, by the mode of apprehending a distinction, the unprofitable and the profitable experience the taste of the object in the true sense, not so

original: vipāko kammavegakkhittattā, nāpi kiriyā ahetukānaṃ atidubbalatāya, sahetukānañca🔽khīṇakilesassa chaḷaṅgupekkhāvato uppajjamānānaṃ atisantavuttittā, tasmā rajjanādivasena🔽ārammaṇarasānubhavanaṃ sātisayanti akusalaṃ kusalañca uppajjitvā niruddhatāsāmaññena
analyzed: vipākaḥ kamma vega khitta ttā na api kiriyā ahetukānam ati dubbala tāya sa hetukānam ca  khīṇa kilesassa chaḷaṅgu pekkhāvataḥ uppajjamānānam tasmā rajjana ādi vasena  ārammaṇa rasa anubhavanam akusalam kusalam ca uppajjitvā niruddha tā sāmaññena
translated: It is not result because it is impelled by kamma-force, nor is it functional because the non-causally-originated is too weak and the causally-originated🔽is too calm in one whose defilements are exhausted and who is possessed of the six kinds of equanimity . Therefore it is said to be “with excess” in the experiencing of the taste of the object by means of the act of relishing, etc.,

original: sesasaṅkhatañca bhūtāpagata”nti vuttaṃ. Sammohavinodaniyā pana vipākānubhavanavasena🔽tadārammaṇaṃ avipakkapākassa sabbathā avigatattā bhavitvāvigatamattavasena kammañca
analyzed: sesa saṅkhatam ca bhūta apagatan ti vuttam sammoha vinodaniyā pana vipāka anubhavana vasena  tad ārammaṇam avipakka pākassa sabbathā avigata ttā bhavitvā avigata matta vasena kamman ca
translated: and it is said to be “with remainder” because of the similarity of its arising and ceasing after arising, whether it is unprofitable or profitable. And it is said to be “with the primary elements that are not past” because of the presence of the primary elements that are not past.🔽But in the Sammohavinodani it is said that it is “with kamma that is past” because the object of that kamma, which is not yet ripened, is not absent in any way, and it is said to be “with the primary elements that are past” because of the mere fact of its having been.

original: bhutvāpagatanti vuttaṃ. Teneva tattha okāsakatuppannanti vipākamevāha, na kammampi,
analyzed: bhutvā apagatanti vuttam tena iva tattha okāsa kata uppannanti vipākam eva āha na kammam pi
translated: That is why it is said there only of the result and not of the kamma as well.

original: tasmā idhāpi sammohavinodaniyaṃ vuttanayeneva bhutvāpagatuppannaṃ okāsakatuppannañca🔽vibhattanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: tasmai idha api sammoha vinodaniyam vutta nayena iva bhutvā apagata uppannam okāsa kata uppannam ca 🔽vibhattam ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: So here too the “with the primary elements that are past” and the “with the primary elements that are not past” should be understood as stated in the Sammohavinodani according to the method there.

original: Pañcakkhandhā pana vipassanāya bhūmi nāmāti sammasanassa ṭhānabhāvato vuttaṃ. Tesūti
analyzed: pañca kkhandhā pana vipassanāya bhūmi nāma ati sammasanassa ṭhāna bhāvataḥ vuttam tesu iti
translated: But the five aggregates are called the plane of insight because they are the basis for the act of reviewing.🔽In the past, etc.,

original: atītādibhedesu. Anusayitakilesāti appahīnā maggena pahātabbā adhippetā. Tenāha –
analyzed: atīta ādi bhedesu anusayita kilesā ati appahīnā maggena pahātabbā adhippetā tena āha
translated: The defilements that lie latent: those that have not been abandoned by a path and are to be abandoned by a path are intended. Hence it is said:🔽“They are not to be spoken of as past, etc.”

original: “atītā vā…pe… na vattabbā”ti. Hontu tāva “atītā”ti vā “paccuppannā”ti vā na vattabbā,🔽“anāgatā”ti pana kasmā na vattabbā, nanu kāraṇalābhe uppajjanārahā appahīnaṭṭhena
analyzed: atītā vāpe na vattabbā ati hontu tāva atītā ati vā paccuppannā ati vā na vattabbā  anāgatā ti pana kasmā na vattabbā nanu kāraṇa lābhe uppajjana arahā a pahīna ṭṭhena
translated: Let them be not to be spoken of as past or present;

original: thāmagatā kilesā anusayāti vuccantīti? Saccametaṃ, anāgatabhāvopi nesaṃ na paricchinno
analyzed: thāma gatā kilesāḥ anusayā ti vuccanti iti saccam etam anāgata bhāvaḥ api na īsam na paricchinno
translated: why are they not to be spoken of as future? Are not defilements that have not been abandoned and that are due to arise when the conditions are fulfilled called latent because they are on the way to becoming present?🔽That is so, but their future state is not delimited

original: itarānāgatakkhandhānaṃ viyāti “anāgatā vāti na vattabbā”ti vuttaṃ. Yadi hi nesaṃ🔽paricchinno anāgatabhāvo siyā, tato “paccuppannā, atītā”ti ca vattabbā siyuṃ, paccayasamavāye
analyzed: itara anāgata khandhānam viya āti anāgatā vā ati na vattabbā ati vuttam yadi hi nesam  paricchinnaḥ anāgata bhāvaḥ siyā tatas paccuppannā atītā iti ca vattabbā siyum paccaya samavāye
translated: as is the case with the other future aggregates. That is why it is said: “They are not to be spoken of as future.”

original: pana uppajjanārahataṃ upādāya anāgatavohāro tattha veditabbo.
analyzed: pana uppajjana araha tam upādāya anāgata vohāro tattha veditabbo
translated: For if their future state were delimited, then they would have to be spoken of as present or past. But the term “future” should be understood there as referring to the state of being due to arise, which is dependent on the concurrence of conditions.

original: Idaṃ bhūmiladdhuppannaṃ nāmāti idaṃ yathāvuttaṃ kilesajātaṃ appahīnaṭṭhena bhūmiladdhuppannaṃ
analyzed: idam bhūmiladdhuppannam nāma ati idam yathāvuttam kilesa jātam appahīna ṭṭhena bhūmiladdhuppannam
translated: This is called “arisen by acquisition of plane” : this defilement-group thus described is called “arisen by acquisition of plane” in the sense of not being abandoned.🔽When the cause is acquired, it is called “arisen by acquisition of plane” because it is present and does its function.

original: nāma kāraṇalābhe sati vijjamānakiccakaraṇato. Tāsu tāsu bhūmisūti manussadevādiattabhāvasaṅkhātesu
analyzed: nāma kāraṇa lābhe sati vijjamāna kicca karaṇato tāsu tāsu bhūmisu iti manussa deva ādi attabhāva saṅkhātesu
translated: In the various planes : in the aggregates of existence called “human,” “divine,” and so on.

original: upādānakkhandhesu. Ārammaṇakaraṇavasena hi bhavanti ettha kilesāti bhūmiyo, upādānakkhandhā.🔽Asamugghātagatāti tasmiṃ tasmiṃ santāne anuppattidhammataṃ anāpāditatāya samugghātaṃ
analyzed: upādānakkhandhesu ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena hi bhavanti ettha kilesā ati bhūmiyaḥ upādānakkhandhāḥ  a samugghāta gatā ati tasmim tasmim santāne an uppatti dhamma tam an āpādita tāya samugghātam
translated: For the aggregates of existence are called “planes” because defilements occur in them by making them their object.🔽Not gone to abandonment : not gone to abandonment, not gone to destruction, because the state of not arising in that continuity has not been brought about.

original: samucchedaṃ na gatāti asamugghātagatā. Bhūmiladdhuppannaṃ nāmāti ettha laddhabhūmikaṃ
analyzed: samucchedam na gatā ati a samugghāta gatā bhūmi laddha uppannam nāma ati ettha laddha bhūmikam
translated: This is called “arisen by acquisition of plane” : what has acquired a plane is called “arisen by acquisition of plane”

original: bhūmiladdhanti vuttaṃ aggiāhito viya. Okāsakatuppannasaddepi ca aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ āgatanayena
analyzed: bhūmi laddham ti vuttam aggi āhitaḥ viya okāsa kata uppanna sadde pi ca aṭṭhasāliniyam āgata nayena
translated: like “heated by fire.” And in the case of the sound “arisen by making an interval,”

original: okāso kato etena kusalākusalakammena, okāso kato etassa vipākassāti ca duvidhatthepi
analyzed: okāsaḥ kataḥ etena kusala akusala kammena okāsaḥ kataḥ etassa vipākassa ati ca duvidhatthe pi
translated: in the two senses of “an interval is made by this profitable or unprofitable action” and “an interval is made for this ripening,”

original: evameva katasaddassa paranipāto veditabbo. Idha pana okāsakatuppannasaddena vipākasseva
analyzed: evam eva kata saddassa para nipātaḥ veditabbaḥ idha pana okāsa kata uppanna saddena vipākassa iva
translated: So too, the word “katā” should be understood as a secondary formation. But here the word “katā” is a primary formation, being a word that has arisen by the addition of a suffix.

original: gahitattā “okāso kato etassa vipākassā”ti evaṃ viggaho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: gahita ttā okāsaḥ kataḥ etassa vipākassa ati evam viggahaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: So too, the word “produced” should be understood as a subsequent word. But here, since only the result is meant by the word “produced,” which is used in the sense of “made room for,” the analysis should be understood thus: “Room is made for this result.”

original: Khaṇattayasamaṅgitāya samudācārappattaṃ samudācāruppannaṃ. Tenāha – “sampati vattamānaṃyevā”ti.
analyzed: khaṇa ttaya samaṅgi tāya samudācāra ppattam samudācāra uppannam tena āha sampati
translated: Arisen through occurrence is that which has reached occurrence by being associated with the three instants. Hence it is said: “That which is actually occurring at present.”

original: Ārammaṇaṃ adhiggayha daḷhaṃ gahetvā pavattaṃ ārammaṇādhiggahituppannaṃ. Vikkhambhanappahānavasena
analyzed: ārammaṇam adhiggayha daḷham gahetvā pavattam ārammaṇa adhiggahita uppannam vikkhambhana ppahāna vasena
translated: Arisen through apprehending an object is that which occurs by apprehending an object firmly.🔽Not abandoned by suppression is that which is not abandoned by the suppression abandonment.

original: appahīnā avikkhambhitā. Samucchedappahānavasena appahīnā asamugghātitā. Nimittaggāhavasena🔽ārammaṇassa adhiggahitattā taṃ ārammaṇaṃ anussaritānussaritakkhaṇe kilesuppattihetubhāvena
analyzed: appahīnā a vikkhambhitā samuccheda ppahāna vasena appahīnā a samugghātitā nimitta ggāha vasena  ārammaṇassa adhiggahita ttā tam ārammaṇam anussarita anussarita khaṇe kilesuppatti hetu bhāvena
translated: Not abandoned by eradication is that which is not abandoned by the eradication abandonment.🔽Because the object is apprehended by the apprehension of the sign,

original: upatiṭṭhanato adhiggahitameva nāmaṃ hotīti āha – “ārammaṇassa adhiggahitattā”ti.
analyzed: upatiṭṭhanataḥ adhiggahitam eva nāmam hoti iti āha ārammaṇassa adhiggahita ttā ti
translated: the object is called “apprehended” because it persists as a cause for the arising of defilements in the moments of recollecting it again and again.

original: Ettha ca āhaṭakhīrarukkho viya nimittaggāhavasena adhiggahitaṃ ārammaṇaṃ, anāhaṭakhīrarukkho
analyzed: ettha ca āhaṭa khīra rukkhaḥ viya nimitta ggāha vasena adhiggahitam ārammaṇam anāhaṭa khīra rukkhaḥ
translated: And here the object that has been apprehended by the apprehension of the sign should be regarded as the tapped tree,🔽and the object of the underlying tendency that has not been suppressed should be regarded as the untapped tree,

original: viya avikkhambhitatāya antogatakilesaārammaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Nimittaggāhikā avikkhambhitakilesā
analyzed: viya a vikkhambhita tāya antogata kilesa ārammaṇam daṭṭhabbam nimitta ggāhikā a vikkhambhita kilesā
translated: and the person who has not suppressed the underlying tendency of apprehension of the sign should be regarded as like the tapped tree,

original: vā puggalā vā āhaṭānāhaṭakhīrarukkhasadisā. Purimanayenevāti avikkhambhituppanne
analyzed: vā puggalāḥ vā āhaṭa an āhaṭa khīra rukkha sadisā purima nayena iva ati a vikkhambhita uppanne
translated: and the person who has not suppressed the underlying tendency of apprehension of the sign should be regarded as like the untapped tree. “As before” : in the way already stated under “arisen through non-suppression” .

original: vuttanayeneva. Vitthāretabbanti “imasmiṃ nāma ṭhāne nuppajjissantī”ti na vattabbā.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva vitthāretabbanti imasmin nāma ṭhāne nuppajjissanti iti na vattabbā
translated: “Should be elaborated” : it cannot be said that they will not arise in such and such places.🔽Why? Because they have not been eradicated.

original: Kasmā? Asamugghātitattā. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā sace khīrarukkhaṃ kuṭhāriyā āhaneyyuṃ,🔽imasmiṃ nāma ṭhāne khīraṃ na nikkhameyyāti na vattabbaṃ, evaṃ. Idaṃ asamugghātituppannaṃ
analyzed: kasmai a samugghātita ttā yathā kim yathā sace khīra rukkham kuṭhāriyāḥ āhaneyyuṃ  imasmin nāma ṭhāne khīram na nikkhameyya ati na vattabbam evam idam a samugghāti tu pannam
translated: What is the simile? It is like this. If they were to tap a tree for latex,🔽it cannot be said that the latex will not come out in such and such places.

original: nāmāti evaṃ yojetvā vitthāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: nāma ati evam yojetvā vitthāretabbam
translated: This is how the elaboration should be done by construing “arisen through non-eradication” in the same way.

original: Imesu uppannesūti yathāvuttesu aṭṭhasu uppannesu. Idaṃ na maggavajjhaṃ appahātabbavatthuttā.
analyzed: imesu uppannesu iti yathā vuttesu aṭṭhasu uppannesu idam na magga vajjham appahātabba vatthu ttā
translated: “When these have arisen” : when the eight kinds of consciousness already described have arisen. This is not to be abandoned by the path, because it is not an object to be abandoned.

original: Maggavajjhaṃ maggena paheyyavatthuttā. Rattoti rāgena samannāgato. Esa nayo duṭṭho
analyzed: magga vajjham maggena ratto ti rāgena samannāgataḥ esa nayaḥ duṭṭho
translated: and the path is the means of abandoning what is to be abandoned by the path. “Lustful” means possessed of lust. So too with “hostile” and “deluded.”

original: mūḷhoti etthāpi. Vinibaddhoti mānasaṃyojanena virūpaṃ nibandhito. Parāmaṭṭhoti diṭṭhiparāmāsena
analyzed: mūḷhaḥ iti ettha api vinibaddhaḥ iti māna saṃyojanena virūpam nibandhitaḥ parāmaṭṭho ti diṭṭhi parāmāsena
translated: “Bound” means bound by the fetter of conceit. “Clinging” means

original: dhammasabhāvaṃ atikkamma parato āmaṭṭho. Aniṭṭhaṅgatoti niṭṭhaṃ agato, saṃsayāpannoti
analyzed: dhamma sabhāvam atikkamma paratas āmaṭṭhaḥ a niṭṭhaṅgataḥ ti niṭṭham a gataḥ saṃsaya āpannaḥ ti
translated: clinging to views. “Not penetrated” means not penetrated to the real nature of things. “Not gone beyond doubt” means not gone beyond doubt, not overcome doubt, is the meaning.

original: attho. Thāmagatoti anusayavasena daḷhataṃ upagato. Yuganaddhāti pahātabbappahāyakayuge
analyzed: attho thāma gataḥ ti anusaya vasena daḷha tam upagataḥ yuga naddhā ti pahātabba ppahāyaka yuge
translated: “Gone to a shelter” means gone to a shelter in the form of latent tendencies. “Yoked” means yoked by the yoking of what is to be abandoned and the abandoning.

original: naddhā viya vattanakā ekakālikattā. Saṃkilesikāti saṃkilesadhammasahitā.
analyzed: naddhā viya vattanakā eka kālika ttā saṃkilesikā ati saṃkilesa dhamma sahitā
translated: They are called “yoked” because they occur simultaneously. “Corrupted” means associated with corrupted states.

original: Pāḷiyanti paṭisambhidāpāḷiyaṃ. Tikālikesupi kilesesu vāyāmābhāvadassanatthaṃ ajātaphalataruṇarukkho
analyzed: pāḷiyanti paṭisambhidā pāḷiyam tikālikesu pi kilesesu vāyāma abhāva dassana tham ajāta phala taruṇa rukkho
translated: “In the text” means in the Paṭisambhidā text. In order to show that there is no practice of the defilements in the minor defilements, a tree with unripe fruit is shown in the text.

original: pāḷiyaṃ nidassito, aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana jāto satto asamudāhaṭakileso nāma natthīti
analyzed: pāḷiyam nidassito aṭṭhakathāyam pana jātaḥ sattaḥ asamudāhaṭa kileso nāma natthi iti
translated: But in the commentary there is no such thing as a being who has not aroused defilements.

original: “jātaphalarukkhena dīpetabba”nti vatvā tamatthaṃ vivarituṃ “yathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: jāta phala rukkhena dīpetabban ti vatvā tam attham vivaritum yathā hi itiādi vuttam
translated: Therefore, after saying, “The tree with ripe fruit should be illustrated,” in order to explain that meaning, the following is said.

original: Atha vā maggena pahīnakilesānameva atītādibhedena tidhā navattabbataṃ pākaṭaṃ kātuṃ
analyzed: atha vā maggena pahīna kilesānam eva atīta ādi bhedena tidhā pākaṭam kātum
translated: Or else the simile of the tree with fruit is given in the text in order to make it clear that the defilements abandoned by the path are threefold as past, future and present,

original: ajātaphalarukkho upamāvasena pāḷiyaṃ ābhato, atītādīnaṃ appahīnatādassanatthampi
analyzed: upamā vasena pāḷiyam atīta ādīnam appahīna tā dassana attham pi
translated: and in order to show that those in the past, etc., are not abandoned.

original: “jātaphalarukkhena dīpetabba”nti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha yathā acchinne rukkhe🔽nibbattanārahāni phalāni chinne anuppajjamānāni kadāci sasabhāvāni ahesuṃ, honti,
analyzed: jāta phala rukkhena dīpetabbanti aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam tattha yathā acchinne rukkhe  nibbattana arahāni phalāni chinne anuppajjamānāni kadāci sa sabhāvāni ahesum honti
translated: And it is said in the commentary: “The tree with fruit should be illustrated.”

original: bhavissanti vāti atītādibhāvena na vattabbāni, evaṃ maggena pahīnakilesā ca daṭṭhabbā🔽magge anuppanne uppattirahānaṃ uppanne sabbena sabbaṃ abhāvato. Yathā ca chede asati
analyzed: bhavissanti vā ti atīta ādi bhāvena na vattabbāni evam maggena pahīna kilesā ca daṭṭhabbā  magge anuppanne uppatti rahānam uppanne sabbena sabbam abhāvataḥ yathā ca chede asati
translated: Herein, just as the fruits that are ready to fall from the tree if it is not cut down, but do not arise if it is cut down, are not to be spoken of as past, future and present, because they do not exist in those modes, so the defilements abandoned by the path should be seen.

original: phalāni uppajjissantīti chedanassa sātthakatā, evaṃ maggabhāvanāya ca sātthakatā
analyzed: phalāni uppajjissanti iti chedanassa sa atthaka tā evam magga bhāvanāya ca sa atthaka tā
translated: And just as the tree is useful because the fruits arise if it is not cut down, so the development of the path should be understood to be useful because the defilements arise if the path is not developed.

original: yojetabbā. Nāpi na pajahatīti uppajjanārahānaṃ pajahanato vuttaṃ. Uppajjitvāti lakkhaṇe
analyzed: yojetabbā na api na pajahati iti uppajjana arahānam pajahanataḥ vuttam uppajjitvā iti lakkhaṇe
translated: And “he does not abandon” is said because those that are ready to arise are abandoned. “Having arisen”: the present tense is used in the sense of a characteristic.

original: tvā-saddo. Maggassa uppajjanakiriyāya hi samudayappahānanibbānasachikaraṇakiriyā🔽viya khandhānaṃ parijānanakiriyā lakkhīyati.
analyzed: tvā saddaḥ maggassa uppajjana kiriyāya hi samudaya ppahāna nibbāna sachikaraṇa kiriyā  viya khandhānam parijānana kiriyā lakkhīyati
translated: The word “and” . For the act of abandoning is implied in the act of discerning the aggregates, as the act of realizing the cessation of suffering is implied in the act of realizing the origin of suffering.

original: Tepi pajahatiyevāti ye tehi kilesehi janetabbā upādinnakkhandhā, tepi pajahatiyeva
analyzed: te pi pajahatiyā iva ati ye tehi kilesehi janetabbāḥ upādinna khandhāḥ te pi pajahatiyā iva
translated: He abandons also the aggregates that are generated by those defilements,

original: tannimittassa abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇassa nirodhanato. Tenāha – “vuttampi ceta”ntiādi.
analyzed: tad nimittassa abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇassa nirodhanato tena āha vuttam pi cetan tiādi
translated: because he causes the cessation of the resultant consciousness that is the cause for the aggregates. Thus it is said: “And it is said” .

original: Abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇassa nirodhenāti kammaviññāṇassa anuppattidhammatāpādanena. Etthāti
analyzed: abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇassa nirodhena ati kamma viññāṇassa anuppatti dhamma tā āpādanena ettha āti
translated: By the cessation of the resultant consciousness: by making the kamma-resultant consciousness non-existent. Herein:

original: etasmiṃ sotāpattimaggañāṇe hetubhūte. Eteti nāmarūpasaññitā saṅkhārā. Sabbabhavehi🔽vuṭṭhātiyevātipi vadantīti arahattamaggo sabbabhavehi vuṭṭhātiyevāti vadanti taduppattito
analyzed: etasmim sa utāpatti magga ñāṇe hetu bhūte ete iti nāma rūpa saññitā saṅkhārā sabba bhavehi  vuṭṭhātiyā iva atipi vadanti iti arahatta maggo sabba bhavehi vuṭṭhātiyā iva ati vadanti tad uppattito
translated: in this knowledge of the path of stream-entry, which is the cause. These: the formations called mentality-materiality.

original: uddhaṃ bhavūpapattiyā kilesassapi abhāvato.
analyzed: bhava upapattiyā kilesassa api abhāvato
translated: They say: “He emerges from all becoming” : they say that the path of arahatship emerges from all becoming, because after its arising there is no further rebirth-linking and no defilements.

original: Ekacittakkhaṇikattā maggassāti adhippāyena “kathaṃ anuppannānaṃ…pe… ṭhitiyā bhāvanā
analyzed: eka citta khaṇika ttā maggassa ati adhippāyena katham anuppannānam pe ṭhitiyāḥ bhāvanā
translated: Because the path is of the duration of a single conscious moment: with this intention it is said: “How is it that the development of the path is for the purpose of abandoning the unarisen and for the maintenance of the arisen?

original: hotī”ti pucchati. Maggappavattiyāyeva ubhayakiccasiddhito āha – “maggappavattiyāyevā”ti.🔽Maggo hītiādinā tamatthaṃ vivarati. Anuppanno nāma vuccati, tasmā tassa bhāvanā anuppannānaṃ
analyzed: hoti iti pucchati magga ppavattiyāya iva ubhaya kicca siddhitaḥ āha magga ppavattiyāya iva ati  maggaḥ hi iti ādinā tam attham vivarati anuppannaḥ nāma vuccati tasmā tassa bhāvanā anuppannānam
translated: He asks: “Is it by the occurrence of the path?” Since the two tasks are accomplished by the occurrence of the path alone, he says: “By the occurrence of the path alone.”🔽The path is called “arisen” and “not arisen” in the sense of having and not having reached the path, respectively.

original: uppādāya bhāvanā vuttāti yojetabbā. Vattuṃ vaṭṭatīti yāvatā maggassa pavattiyeva
analyzed: uppādāya bhāvanā vuttā iti yojetabbā vattum vaṭṭati iti yāvatā maggassa pavattiyā iva
translated: Therefore the development of the path should be construed as the development for the arising of what has not arisen, and so on.

original: ṭhiti, tattakāneva nibbattitalokuttarāni.🔽398-401. Kattukamyatāchandaṃ adhipatiṃ karitvā paṭiladdhasamādhi chandasamādhīti
analyzed: ṭhiti tattakāni eva nibbattita lokuttarāni  kattu kamyatā chandam adhipatim karitvā paṭiladdha samādhi chanda samādhi iti
translated: The path occurs only for as long as it occurs.🔽The supramundane states that are produced are only those that are produced for as long as the path occurs.🔽Concentration through desire is concentration obtained by making desire to act predominant.

original: āha – “chandaṃ nissāya pavatto samādhi chandasamādhī”ti padhānasaṅkhārāti catukiccasādhakassa🔽sammappadhānavīriyassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tenāha – “padhānabhūtā saṅkhārā padhānasaṅkhārā”ti.
analyzed: āha chandam nissāya pavattaḥ samādhi chanda samādhi iti padhāna saṅkhārā ati catu kicca sādhakassa  sammappadhāna vīriyassa itam adhivacanam tena āha padhāna bhūtā saṅkhārā padhāna saṅkhārā ati
translated: Therefore he says: “Concentration that occurs by way of desire is concentration through desire.” The formations that are the arousing are a name for energy, which accomplishes the four tasks.🔽Therefore he says: “The formations that are the arousing are the formations that arouse.”

original: Tattha padhānabhūtāti vīriyabhūtā. Saṅkhatasaṅkhārādinivattanatthaṃ padhānaggahaṇanti.
analyzed: tattha padhāna bhūtā ati vīriya bhūtā saṅkhata saṅkhāra ādi nivattana attham padhāna ggahaṇam ti
translated: Herein, “the formations that arouse” are the energy that arouses. The arousing is stated for the purpose of turning away from the formations that are formed, and so on.

original: Atha vā taṃ taṃ visesaṃ saṅkharotīti saṅkhāro, sabbaṃ vīriyaṃ. Tattha catukiccasādhakato🔽sesanivattanatthaṃ padhānaggahaṇanti, padhānabhūtā seṭṭhabhūtāti attho. Catubbidhassa
analyzed: atha vā tam tam visesam saṅkharoti iti saṅkhāro sabbam vīriyam tattha catu kicca sādhakato  sesa nivattana attham padhāna ggahaṇanti padhāna bhūtā seṭṭha bhūtā ati atthaḥ catubbidhassa
translated: Or alternatively, it is “forming” because it forms this or that distinction, and it is all energy. Herein, it is called “pre-eminent” because it accomplishes the fourfold task,🔽and because it is the chief of the remaining formations. The plural “formations” is used because the fourfold energy is intended.

original: pana vīriyassa adhippetattā bahuvacananiddeso kato. Tehi dhammehīti chandasamādhinā
analyzed: pana vīriyassa adhippeta ttā bahuvacana niddeso kataḥ tehi dhammehi iti chanda samādhinā
translated: With those ideas: with the ideas consisting of zeal, concentration,

original: padhānasaṅkhārehi ca. Iddhipādanti ettha ijjhatīti iddhi, samijjhati nipphajjatīti
analyzed: padhāna saṅkhārehi ca ettha ijjhati iti iddhi samijjhati nipphajjati iti
translated: and pre-eminent forming. “Basis for success”: success is what is succeeded in, what is accomplished, what is reached, is the meaning.

original: attho. Ijjhanti vā etāya sattā iddhā vuddhā ukkaṃsagatā hontītipi iddhi. Paṭhamenatthena
analyzed: attho ijjhanti vai etāya sattāḥ iddhāḥ vuddhāḥ ukkaṃsa gatāḥ honti iti pi iddhi paṭhamena atthena
translated: Or alternatively, beings succeed with it, they are successful, they reach the summit, thus it is success. In the first case,

original: iddhi eva pādo iddhipādo, iddhikoṭṭhāsoti attho. Dutiyenatthena iddhiyā pādoti iddhipādo,
analyzed: iddhi eva pādaḥ iddhi pādaḥ iddhi koṭṭhāsaḥ ti atthaḥ dutiyena atthena iddhiyā pādo ti iddhi pādo
translated: success itself is a basis, thus it is a basis for success; the meaning is that it is a footing for success. In the second case, it is a basis for success, thus it is a basis for success;

original: pādoti patiṭṭhā, adhigamūpāyoti attho. Tena hi yasmā uparūparivisesasaṅkhātaṃ iddhiṃ
analyzed: pādaḥ ti patiṭṭhā adhigama upāyaḥ ti attho tena hi yasmai uparu upari visesa saṅkhātam iddhim
translated: a basis is a support, a means of arriving at, is what is meant. Because by it beings reach, arrive at, the success called the higher and higher distinctions,

original: pajjanti pāpuṇanti, tasmā pādoti vuccati. Tenāha – “iddhiyā pādaṃ, iddhibhūtaṃ vā
analyzed: pajjanti pāpuṇanti tasmā pādo ti vuccati tena āha iddhiyā pādam iddhi bhūtam vā
translated: it is called a “basis.” Hence it is said, “It is a basis for success, or it is a footing for success, or it is a support for success” .

original: pādaṃ iddhipāda”nti.🔽Atha vā iddhipādanti nipphattipariyāyena ijjhanaṭṭhena, ijjhanti etāya sattā iddhā
analyzed: pādam  atha vā iddhipādanti nipphatti pariyāyena ijjhana ṭṭhena ijjhanti etāya sattā iddhā
translated: and the foot is the basis for success.

original: vuddhā ukkaṃsagatā hontīti iminā vā pariyāyena iddhīti saṅkhaṃ gatānaṃ upacārajjhānādikusalacittasampayuttānaṃ
analyzed: vuddhāḥ ukkaṃsa gatāḥ honti iti iminā vā pariyāyena iddhi iti saṅkham gatānam upacāra jhāna ādi kusala citta sampayuttānam
translated: Or alternatively, the basis for success is the term for the profitable consciousnesses associated with the jhāna of access, etc., which are called “success” in the sense of succeeding, and also in the sense of beings’ succeeding, succeeding in growth, succeeding in surmounting, by means of that.

original: chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārānaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena pādabhūtaṃ sesacittacetasikarāsinti
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena pāda bhūtam
translated: The meaning is that it is the foot in the sense of a foundation for the rest of the aggregate of consciousness and its concomitants.

original: attho. Teneva iddhipādavibhaṅge “iddhipādoti tathābhūtassa vedanākkhandho…pe… viññāṇakkhandho”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Sā eva ca tathāvuttā iddhi yasmā heṭṭhimā heṭṭhimā uparimāya uparimāya tayo
analyzed: attho tena iva iddhipāda vibhaṅge iddhipādaḥ ti tathābhūtassa viññāṇa kkhandho ti  vuttam sā eva ca tathā vuttā id hi yasmā heṭṭhimā heṭṭhimā uparimāya uparimāya
translated: That is why in the Description of the Bases for Success it is said: “The basis for success is the feeling aggregate … the perception aggregate … the formations aggregate … the consciousness aggregate of one who has thus gone” .🔽And that same success, so called, is the foot for the three things, namely, will, energy, and cognizance, which are respectively lower, lower, and middling, and for the three things, namely, faith, mindfulness, and concentration, which are respectively middling, middling, and higher.

original: chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārā pādabhūtā adhiṭṭhānabhūtā, tasmā vuttaṃ “iddhibhūtaṃ
analyzed: chanda samādhi ppadhāna saṅkhārā pāda bhūtā adhiṭṭhāna bhūtā tasmā vuttam iddhi bhūtam
translated: That is why it is said, “The foot is the basis for success” .

original: vā pāda”nti. Tathā heṭṭhā dhammā iddhipi honti iddhipādāpi, sesā pana sampayuttakā
analyzed: vā tathā heṭṭhā dhammā iddhi pi honti iddhipādā api sesā pana sampayuttakā
translated: For in the first place the things below are success and also a basis for success, while the rest associated with them are only success.

original: cattāro khandhā iddhipādāyeva. Vīriyacittavīmaṃsāsamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasaṅkhātāpi
analyzed: cattāro khandhāḥ iddhipādāya iva vīriya citta vīmaṃsā samādhi ppadhāna saṅkhāra saṅkhātā api
translated: The four aggregates are only bases of success. The three states called energy, confidence, and applied thought are both success and a base of success.

original: tayo tayo dhammā iddhipi honti iddhipādāpi, sesā pana sampayuttakā cattāro khandhā iddhipādāyeva.🔽Apica pubbabhāgo pubbabhāgo iddhipādo nāma, paṭilābho paṭilābho iddhi nāmāti veditabbā.
analyzed: tayaḥ tayaḥ dhammā honti iddhipādā api sesā pana sampayuttakā cattāro khandhāḥ iddhipādāya eva  apica pubbabhāgaḥ pubbabhāgaḥ iddhipādaḥ nāma paṭilābho paṭilābho iddhi nāma ati veditabbā
translated: The rest of the associated states are only a base of success.

original: Ayamattho upacārena vā vipassanāya vā dīpetabbo. Paṭhamajjhānaparikammañhi iddhipādo
analyzed: ayam atthaḥ upacārena vā vipassanāya vā dīpetabbaḥ paṭhama jhāna parikamman hi iddhipādaḥ
translated: Moreover, the preliminary-work part is called a base of success; the acquisition is called success. This is the meaning to be understood. This should be illustrated either by the way of the proximate cause or by insight. For the preliminary-work of the first jhāna is called a base of success;

original: nāma, paṭhamajjhānaṃ iddhi nāma. Dutiyajhāna… tatiyajhāna… catutthajhāna… ākāsānañcāyatana…
analyzed: nāma paṭhama jhāna iddhi nāma dutiya jhāna tatiya jhāna catuttha jhāna ākāsa ānañca āyatana
translated: the first jhāna is called success. The preliminary-work of the second jhāna … of the third jhāna … of the fourth jhāna … of the base consisting of boundless space …

original: viññāṇañcāyatana… ākiñcaññāyatana… nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaparikammaṃ iddhipādo nāma,
analyzed: viññāṇañcāyatana ākiñcaññāyatana nevasaññānāsaññāyatana parikammaṃ iddhipādaḥ nāma
translated: of the base consisting of boundless consciousness … of the base consisting of nothingness … of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is called a base of success;

original: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ iddhi nāma. Sotāpattimaggassa vipassanā iddhipādo nāma, sotāpattimaggo
analyzed: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ iddhi nāma sotāpatti maggassa vipassanā iddhipādo nāma sotāpatti maggo
translated: the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is called success. The insight of the path of stream entry is called a base of success;🔽the path of stream entry is called success.

original: iddhi nāma. Sakadāgāmi-anāgāmi-arahattamaggassa vipassanā iddhipādo nāma, arahattamaggo
analyzed: iddhi nāma sakadāgāmi anāgāmi arahatta maggassa vipassanā iddhipādaḥ nāma arahatta maggo
translated: ‘Success’ is the path of once-return and non-return and Arahantship. ‘The basis for success’ is insight. The path of Arahantship is ‘success.’

original: iddhi nāma. Paṭilābhenapi dīpetuṃ vaṭṭatiyeva. Paṭhamajjhānañhi iddhipādo nāma, dutiyajjhānaṃ
analyzed: iddhi nāma paṭilābhena api dīpetum vaṭṭatiyā iva paṭhama jhānam hi iddhipādaḥ nāma dutiya jhānam
translated: It is also allowable to illustrate it by acquisition. For the first jhāna is ‘the basis for success,’ the second jhāna is ‘success.’

original: iddhi nāma. Dutiyajjhānaṃ iddhipādo nāma, tatiyajjhānaṃ iddhi nāma…pe… anāgāmimaggo
analyzed: iddhi nāma dutiya jhānam iddhipādaḥ nāma tatiya jhānam iddhi nāma pe anāgāmi maggo
translated: The second jhāna is ‘the basis for success,’ the third jhāna is ‘success.’ …

original: iddhipādo nāma, arahattamaggo iddhi nāma.
analyzed: iddhipādaḥ nāma arahatta maggaḥ iddhi nāma
translated: The path of non-return is ‘the basis for success,’ the path of Arahantship is ‘success.’

original: Sesesupīti vīriyasamādhiādīsupi. Tattha hi vīriyaṃ, cittaṃ, vīmaṃsaṃ adhipatiṃ karitvā
analyzed: sesesu pi iti vīriya samādhi ādīsu pi tattha hi vīriyam cittam vīmaṃsam adhipatim karitvā
translated: ‘And in the rest’ is in the energy concentration, etc., too. For there the concentration acquired by making energy, cognizance, inquiry,

original: paṭiladdhasamādhi vīriyasamādhi, cittasamādhi, vīmaṃsāsamādhīti attho veditabbo.
analyzed: paṭiladdha samādhi vīriya samādhi citta samādhi vīmaṃsā samādhi iti atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: dominant is what should be understood as ‘energy concentration,’ ‘cognizance concentration,’ ‘inquiry concentration.’

original: Chandādīsu ekanti chandādīsu catūsu ādito vuttattā ādibhūtaṃ ekaṃ padhānaṃ chandanti
analyzed: chanda ādīsu ekam ti chanda ādīsu catūsu āditaḥ vutta ttā ādi bhūtam ekam padhānam chanda nti
translated: ‘One of the four’ is the one beginning with zeal, since it is mentioned first. The intention is that the first predominance is zeal.

original: adhippāyo. Tenevāha – “tadāssa paṭhamiddhipādo”ti. Evaṃ sesāpīti etena vīriyaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: adhippāyo tena iva āha tadā assa paṭhama iddhipādo ti evam sesā api iti etena vīriyam cittam
translated: Hence it is said, ‘Then that is the first basis for success.’ ‘And in the rest’ is in the rest of the four beginning with energy. ‘Energy’ is the second predominance. ‘Cognizance’ is the third. ‘Inquiry’ is the fourth.

original: vīmaṃsaṃ nissāya vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇantānaṃ vasena dutiyavīriyiddhipādādayo
analyzed: vīmaṃsam nissāya vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pāpuṇantānam vasena dutiya vīriya iddhipāda ādayo
translated: He shows that the second, third, and fourth bases of success should be combined with the remaining three jhānas respectively, in the case of those who develop insight by way of investigation and reach Arahantship.

original: yojetabbāti dasseti. Iminā hi suttantena catunnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ matthakappattaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽dassitaṃ. Eko hi bhikkhu chandaṃ avassayati, kattukamyatākusaladhammacchandena atthanipphattiyaṃ
analyzed: yojetabbā iti dasseti iminā hi suttantena catunnam bhikkhūnam matthaka ppattam kammaṭṭhānam  dassitam ekaḥ hi bhikkhu chandam avassayati kattu kamya tā kusala dhamma chandena attha nipphattiyam
translated: For this sutta shows the meditation subject of four bhikkhus who have reached the summit.

original: sati “ahaṃ lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbattessāmi, natthi mayhaṃ etassa nibbattane bhāro”ti
analyzed: sati aham lokuttara dhammam nibbattessāmi natthi mayham etassa nibbattane bhāro ti
translated: For one bhikkhu exerts zeal, thinking, “I shall produce the supramundane state; there is no difficulty for me in producing it,”

original: chandaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ chandaṃ dhuraṃ chandaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ katvā lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbatteti.🔽Eko vīriyaṃ avassayati, eko cittaṃ, eko paññaṃ avassayati, paññāya atthanipphattiyaṃ
analyzed: chandam jeṭṭhakam chandam dhuram chandam pubbaṅgamam katvā lokuttara dhammam nibbatteti  ekaḥ vīriyam avassayati ekaḥ cittam ekaḥ paññam avassayati paññāya attha nipphattiyam
translated: and he produces the supramundane state, making zeal the forerunner, making zeal the forerunner, making zeal the first, the foremost, the chief, the principal.

original: sati “ahaṃ lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbattessāmi, natthi mayhaṃ etassa nibbattane bhāro”ti
analyzed: sati aham lokuttara dhammam nibbattessāmi natthi mayham etassa nibbattane bhāro ti
translated: Another exerts energy … Another exerts cognizance … Another exerts understanding, thinking, “I shall produce the supramundane state; there is no difficulty for me in producing it,”🔽and he produces the supramundane state, making understanding the forerunner, making understanding the first, the foremost, the chief, the principal.

original: paññaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ paññaṃ dhuraṃ paññaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ katvā lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbatteti.🔽Kathaṃ? Yathā hi catūsu amaccaputtesu ṭhānantaraṃ patthetvā vicarantesu eko upaṭṭhānaṃ🔽avassayati, eko sūrabhāvaṃ, eko jātiṃ, eko mantaṃ. Kathaṃ? Tesu hi paṭhamo upaṭṭhāne🔽appamādakāritāya atthanipphattiyā sati labbhamānaṃ “lacchāmetaṃ ṭhānantara”nti upaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: paññam jeṭṭhakam paññam dhuram paññam pubbaṅgamam katvā lokuttara dhammam nibbatteti  katham yathā hi catūsu amacca puttesu ṭhāna antaram patthetvā vicarantesu ekaḥ upaṭṭhānam  avassayati ekaḥ sūra bhāvam ekaḥ jātim ekaḥ mantam katham tesu hi paṭhamaḥ upaṭṭhāne  appamāda kāritāya attha nipphattiyā sati labbhamānam lacchāma etam ṭhāna antaran ti upaṭṭhānam
translated: He generates the supramundane Dhamma with understanding as the forerunner, with understanding as the head, with understanding as the chief, with understanding as the head, with understanding as the chief.🔽How? Just as when four sons of ministers are going along a road, one of them calls out, “I’ll be the king’s chief counsellor,” one, “I’ll be the king’s chief minister,” one, “I’ll be the king’s chief general,” and one, “I’ll be the king’s chief treasurer.”🔽How? When the first one is diligent in his service, and when the fruit of his service has been produced, he gets the title “chief counsellor” and he is able to say, “I have got this title of ‘chief counsellor’ because of my service.”🔽🔽

original: avassayati. Dutiyo upaṭṭhāne appamattopi “ekacco saṅgāme paccupaṭṭhite saṇṭhātuṃ🔽na sakkoti, avassaṃ pana rañño paccanto kuppissati, tasmiṃ kuppite rathassa purato🔽kammaṃ katvā rājānaṃ ārādhetvā āharāpessāmetaṃ ṭhānantara”nti sūrabhāvaṃ avassayati.🔽Tatiyo “sūrabhāvepi sati ekacco hīnajātiko hoti, jātiṃ sodhetvā ṭhānantaraṃ dento
analyzed: avassayati dutiyaḥ upaṭṭhāne appamattaḥ pi ekaccaḥ saṅgāme paccupaṭṭhite saṇṭhātum 🔽na sakkoti avassam pana rañño paccantaḥ kuppissati tasmin kuppite rathassa puratas 🔽kammam katvā rājānam ārādhetvā sūra bhāvam avassayati 🔽tatiyaḥ sūra bhāve pi sati ekaccaḥ hīna jātikaḥ hoti jātim sodhetvā dento
translated: He produces supramundane Dhamma with understanding as the forerunner, with understanding as the leader, with understanding as the basis on which it stands.

original: mayhaṃ dassatī”ti jātiṃ avassayati. Catuttho “jātimāpi eko amantanīyo hoti, mantena🔽kattabbakicce uppanne āharāpessāmetaṃ ṭhānantara”nti mantaṃ avassayati. analyzed: mayham dassati iti jātim avassayati catutthaḥ jātim āpi ekaḥ a mantanīyaḥ hoti mantena  kattabba kicce uppanne āharāpessāma etam mantam avassayati te sabbe pi  attanaḥ attanaḥ avassaya balena ṭhāna antarāni pāpuṇiṃsu  tattha upaṭṭhāne appamattaḥ hutvā ṭhāna antaram pattaḥ viya chandam avassāya kattu kamya tā kusala dhamma chandena  attha nipphattiyam sati aham lokuttara dhammam nibbattessāmi natthi mayham etassa  nibbattane sāroti chandam jeṭṭhakam chandam dhuram chandam pubbaṅgamam katvā lokuttara dhamma nibbattako
translated: He is not to be asked about his family. analyzed: lokuttara dhammam nibbattesi sūra bhāvena rājānam ārādhetvā ṭhāna antaram pattas viya
translated: He produced the supramundane Dhamma as a king does a precious gem.🔽He should be regarded as the Elder Soṇa, who produced the supramundane Dhamma with energy as the forerunner, with energy as the forerunner, with energy as the chief, with energy as the head.

original: jeṭṭhakaṃ cittaṃ dhuraṃ cittaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ katvā lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbattesi. Mantaṃ🔽avassāya ṭhānantaraṃ patto viya vīmaṃsaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ vīmaṃsaṃ dhuraṃ vīmaṃsaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ
analyzed: jeṭṭhakam cittam dhuram cittam pubbaṅgamam katvā lokuttara dhammam nibbattesi mantam  avassāya ṭhāna antaram pattaḥ viya vīmaṃsam jeṭṭhakam vīmaṃsam dhuram vīmaṃsam pubbaṅgamam
translated: He produced the supramundane Dhamma with consciousness as the forerunner, with consciousness as the chief, with consciousness as the head.🔽He should be regarded as the Elder Mogha, who produced the supramundane Dhamma with investigation as the forerunner, with investigation as the chief, with investigation as the head.

original: katvā lokuttaradhammanibbattako daṭṭhabbo thero mogharājā viya. So hi āyasmā vīmaṃsaṃ
analyzed: katvā lokuttara dhamma nibbattako daṭṭhabbo theraḥ mogharājā viya saḥ hi āyasmai vīmaṃsam
translated: He produced the supramundane Dhamma with investigation as the forerunner, with investigation as the chief, with investigation as the head.

original: jeṭṭhakaṃ vīmaṃsaṃ dhuraṃ vīmaṃsaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ katvā lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbattesi.🔽Tassa hi bhagavā “suññato lokaṃ avekkhassū”ti suññatākathaṃ kathesi. Paññānissitamānaniggahatthañca
analyzed: jeṭṭhakam vīmaṃsam dhuram vīmaṃsam pubbaṅgamam katvā lokuttara dhammam nibbattesi  tassa hi bhagavā suññataḥ lokam avekkhassu iti suññatā katham kathesi paññā nissita māna niggaha ttham ca
translated: He produced the supramundane Dhamma by making the elder, the investigation, and the burden the forerunner.

original: dvikkhattuṃ pucchito pañhaṃ na kathesi. Ettha ca punappunaṃ chanduppādanaṃ tosanaṃ🔽viya hotīti chandassa upaṭṭhānasadisatā vuttā, thāmabhāvato vīriyassa sūrattasadisatā,
analyzed: dvi kkhattum pucchito pañham na kathesi ettha ca punappunam chanda uppādanam tosanam  viya hoti iti chandassa upaṭṭhāna sadisa tā vuttā thāma bhāvataḥ vīriyassa sūratta sadisa tā
translated: For the Blessed One preached the discourse on emptiness to him with the words, “Contemplate the world as void” . And he did not answer the question when asked twice, in order to show that wisdom is the guide.🔽And here the repeated arousing of desire is like the satisfying of desire,🔽so it is said that desire is like a nurse because of its state of being a support. And since energy has the characteristic of firmness, it is like a hero.

original: “chadvārādhipati rājā”ti vacanato pubbaṅgamatā cittassa visiṭṭhajātisadisatā.
analyzed: cha dvāra adhipati rājā ati vacanataḥ pubbaṅgama tā cittassa visiṭṭha jāti sadisa tā
translated: And since the mind is the forerunner of all states, it is like a chief of race.

original: 402-406. Attano saddhādhureti attano saddhākicce saddahanakiriyāya. Indaṭṭhaṃ kāretīti
analyzed: attano saddhā dhurā iti attano saddhā kicce saddahana kiriyāya indaṭṭham kāreti iti

analyzed: anuvattana vasena sampayutta dhammesu inda aṭṭham kāreti tasmai ādhipateyya ṭṭhena saddhā

original: sesesupi. Sammappadhāneti sammappadhānappaṭisaṃyutte suttante. Esa nayo sesesupi.
analyzed: sesesu pi sammappadhāne ti sammappadhāna paṭisaṃyutte suttante esa nayo sesesu pi
translated: and by so

original: Jhānavimokkheti paṭhamajjhānādijjhānāni ceva paṭhamavimokkhādivimokkhe ca. Kāmañcettha
analyzed: jhāna vimokkha iti paṭhama jhāna ādi jhānāni ca iva paṭhama vimokkha ādi vimokkhe ca
translated: The jhāna deliverances: the jhāna are the first jhāna, etc., and the deliverances are the first deliverance, etc. Of course,
