original: Tassāti sammādiṭṭhiyā. Bahukāroti dhammasampaṭivedhe bahūpakāro. Idāni tamatthaṃ upamāhi vibhāvetuṃ, “yathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tassa ti sammādiṭṭhiyā bahu kāro ti dhamma sampaṭivedhe bahu upakāro idāni tam attham upamāhi vibhāvetum yathā hi itiādi vuttam
translated: It has the quality of being a marvel, since it is the condition for the attainment of the fruit of welfare.🔽It has the quality of being a marvel, since it is the condition for the attainment of the fruit of welfare.🔽It has the quality of being a marvel, since it is the condition for the attainment of the fruit of welfare.

original: Vacībhedassa kārako vitakko sāvajjānavajjavacībhedanivattanappavattanākārāya sammāvācāyapi
analyzed: vacībhedassa kārakaḥ vitakko sāvajja anavajja vacībheda nivattana ppavattana ākārāya sammā vācāya pi
translated: It has the quality of being a marvel, since it is the condition for the attainment of the fruit

original: upakārako evāti āha – “svāyaṃ…pe… sammāvācāyapi upakārako”ti. Sammāsaṅkappo hi saccavācāya
analyzed: eva ati āha sammā vācāya pi upakārako ti sammā saṅkappaḥ hi sacca vācāya
translated: It is helpful, he says, in the way stated. For right thought is a special condition for right speech

original: virativācāyapi visesapaccayo micchāsaṅkappatadekaṭṭhakilesappahānato.🔽Saṃvidahitvātiādīsu sammā vidahanaṃ kammantappayojanañca ekantānavajjavacīkāyakammavasena🔽icchitabbanti virativācāvasena saṃvidahanaṃ viratikammantasseva payojanañca nidassitanti
analyzed: visesa paccayaḥ micchā saṅkappa tad eka ṭṭha kilesa ppahānato  saṃvidahitvā iti ādīsu sammā vidahanam kammanta ppayojanam ca  icchitabbanti virati vācā vasena saṃvidahanam virati kammantassa iva payojanam ca nidassitanti
translated: in the sense of abstention, since it is the abandoning of the defilements that have wrong thought for their ground.🔽As regards the words “having determined” and so on, the determining should be understood as the determining by way of the right speech and right action that are entirely free from blame.🔽And the application should be understood as the application of the abstention itself.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evaṃ hissa sammāvācāya sammākammantassāpi bahukāratā jotitā siyā. Vacībhedaniyāmikā
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam evam hi ssa sammā vācāya sammā kammantassa api bahu kāra tā jotitā siyā vacī bheda niyāmikā
translated: For in this way the great helpfulness of right speech and right action can be shown.

original: hi vacīduccaritavirati kāyikakiriyaniyāmikāya kāyaduccaritaviratiyā upakārikā. Tathā🔽hi visaṃvādanādimicchāvācato avirato micchākammantatopi na viramateva. Yathāha –
analyzed: hi vacī duccarita virati kāyika kiriya niyāmikāya upakārikā tathā  hi visaṃvādana ādi micchā vācataḥ avirataḥ micchā kammantataḥ pi na viramatā iva yathā āha
translated: For the abstention from verbal misconduct, which is governed by speech, is helpful to the abstention from bodily misconduct, which is governed by the body.🔽For one who does not abstain from false speech, etc., does not abstain from wrong action either.🔽As it is said: “For one who has passed beyond one thing, … there is no evil doing” .

original: “ekaṃ dhammaṃ atītassa…pe… natthi pāpaṃ akāriya”nti. Tasmā avisaṃvādanādisammāvācāya
analyzed: ekam dhammaṃ atītassape natthi pāpam tasmai a visaṃvādana ādi sammāvācāya
translated: Therefore, right speech, which is non-false speech, etc.,

original: ṭhito sammākammantampi pūretiyevāti vacīduccaritavirati kāyaduccaritaviratiyā upakārikā.
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ vacī duccarita virati kāya duccarita viratiyā upakārikā
translated: And since right action is fulfilled by one who is established in right speech, right speech is helpful to right action.

original: Yasmā ājīvapārisuddhi nāma dussīlyappahānapubbikā, tasmā sammāvācākammantānantaraṃ
analyzed: yasmai ājīvapārisuddhi nāma dussīlya pahāna pubbikā tasmai sammā vācā kammanta anantaram
translated: Since purity of livelihood comes after the abandoning of unvirtuousness,🔽right livelihood is taught after right speech and right action.🔽“But it is of four kinds” is said in order to show this.

original: sammāājīvo desitoti dassetuṃ – “catubbidhaṃ panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ettāvatāti parisuddhasīlājīvikāmattena.
analyzed: sammāājīvaḥ desito ti dassetum catubbidham pana atiādi vuttam ettāvatā ti parisuddha sīla ājīvikā mattena
translated: “Thus far” means by way of pure virtue and livelihood.

original: Idaṃ vīriyanti catusammappadhānavīriyaṃ.
analyzed: idam catu sammappadhāna vīriyam
translated: “This energy” is the energy of the four right efforts.

original: Vīriyārambhopi sammāsatipariggahito eva nibbānāvaho, na kevaloti dassetuṃ – “tato”tiādi
analyzed: vīriya ārambhaḥ api sammāsati pariggahitaḥ eva nibbāna āvahaḥ na kevalaḥ ti dassetum tatas itiādi
translated: Since the arousing of energy is conducive to Nibbāna only when it is embraced by right mindfulness, it is said: “Then, after that, right mindfulness.”

original: vuttaṃ. Sūpaṭṭhitāti bahiddhāvikkhepaṃ pahāya suṭṭhu upaṭṭhitā kātabbā. Samādhissa
analyzed: vuttam su upaṭṭhitā ti bahiddhā vikkhepam pahāya suṭṭhu upaṭṭhitā kātabbā samādhissa
translated: “Well established” means that it should be well established by abandoning external distraction.

original: upakāradhammā nāma yathāvuttavatthuvisadakiriyādayo. Tappaṭipakkhato anupakāradhammā
analyzed: upakāra dhammāḥ nāma yathā vutta vatthu visada kiriyā ādayaḥ tad paṭipakkhataḥ anupakāra dhammāḥ
translated: The helpful states of concentration are the purification of the object, etc., as mentioned above.🔽The unbeneficial states should be understood as the opposite of these.🔽“The results” are the fruits.

original: veditabbā. Gatiyoti nipphattiyo. Samanvesitvāti sammā pariyesitvā.
analyzed: veditabbāḥ gatiyaḥ ti nipphattiyaḥ samanvesitvā ati sammā pariyesitvā
translated: “Having investigated” means having thoroughly sought out.

original: 427. Yathā itthīsu kathā pavattā adhitthīti vuccati, evaṃ attānaṃ adhikicca pavattā
analyzed: yathā itthīsu kathā pavattā adhitthī iti vuccati evam attānam adhikicca pavattā
translated: As talk that occurs among women is called “women’s talk,” so talk that occurs with reference to oneself is called “internal” .

original: ajjhattaṃ. “Evaṃ pavattamānā mayaṃ ‘attā’ti gahaṇaṃ gamissāmā”ti iminā viya adhippāyena🔽attānaṃ adhikicca uddissa pavattā sattasantatipariyāpannā ajjhattaṃ. Tasmiṃ ajjhattarūpe,
analyzed: ajjhattam evam pavattamānāḥ mayam attā ati gahaṇam gamissāma ati iminā viya adhippāyena  attānam adhikicca uddissa pavattā satta santati pariyāpannā ajjhattam tasmim ajjhatta rūpe
translated: With the intention, “We shall become the object of the notion ‘self’ when we occur thus,”🔽it occurs with reference to oneself, that is, in one’s own continuity of aggregates, internally. The meaning is: in the materiality that is the object of one’s own kasiṇa materiality, that is, one’s own head hairs and so on.

original: attano kesādivatthuke kasiṇarūpeti attho. Parikammavasena ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññīti parikammakaraṇavasena
analyzed: kesa ādi vatthuke kasiṇa rūpe iti attho parikamma vasena ajjhattam rūpa saññī iti parikamma karaṇa vasena
translated: Perceiving internally a sign: perceiving a sign internally by means of the preliminary work .

original: ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī, na appanāvasena. Na hi paṭibhāganimittārammaṇā appanā ajjhattavisayā
analyzed: ajjhattam rūpa saññī na appanā vasena na hi paṭibhāga nimitta ārammaṇā appanā ajjhatta visayā
translated: Not by means of absorption, for absorption with the counterpart sign as its object is not possible with an internal object.

original: sambhavati. Taṃ pana ajjhattaṃ parikammavasena laddhaṃ kasiṇanimittaṃ avisuddhameva
analyzed: sambhavati tam pana ajjhattam parikamma vasena laddham kasiṇa nimittam a visuddham eva
translated: But that kasiṇa sign obtained by means of the internal preliminary work is only purified,

original: hoti, na bahiddhā parikammavasena laddhaṃ viya visuddhaṃ. Tenāha – “taṃ panā”tiādi.
analyzed: hoti na bahiddhā parikamma vasena laddham viya visuddham tena āha tam pana atiādi
translated: not as purified as that obtained by means of the external preliminary work. Hence he said, “But that is only purified” and so on.

original: Yassevaṃ parikammaṃ ajjhattaṃ uppannanti yassa puggalassa evaṃ vuttappakārena ajjhattaṃ
analyzed: yassa evam parikammam ajjhattam uppannanti yassa puggalassa evam vutta ppakārena ajjhattam
translated: “When the preliminary work has arisen thus in him”: when the kind of preliminary work described has arisen in him.

original: parikammaṃ jātaṃ. Nimittaṃ pana bahiddhāti paṭibhāganimittaṃ sasantatipariyāpannaṃ
analyzed: parikammam jātam nimittam pana bahiddhā ati paṭibhāga nimittam sa santati pariyāpannam
translated: “But the sign is outside”: the counterpart sign is not included in his own continuity,🔽so it is “outside.”

original: na hotīti bahiddhā. Parittānīti yathāladdhāni suppasarāvamattāni. Tenāha – “avaḍḍhitānī”ti.🔽Parittavasenevāti vaṇṇavasena ābhoge vijjamānepi parittavaseneva idaṃ abhibhāyatanaṃ
analyzed: na hoti iti bahiddhā parittāni iti yathā laddhāni su pasara avamattāni tena āha a vaḍḍhitāni iti  paritta vasena iva ati vaṇṇa vasena ābhoge vijjamāne pi paritta vasena iva idam abhibhāyatanam
translated: “Limited”: the size of a mere myrobalan nut, according to the amount of the preliminary work. Hence it is said, “undiminished.”🔽“Only by means of the limited”: although the extension of the colour is present, this base of mastery is stated only by means of the limited,

original: vuttaṃ parittatā hettha abhibhavanassa kāraṇaṃ. Vaṇṇābhoge satipi asatipi abhibhavatīti🔽abhibhu, parikammaṃ, ñāṇaṃ vā. Abhibhu āyatanaṃ etassāti abhibhāyatanaṃ, jhānaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam paritta tā ha ittha abhibhavanassa kāraṇam vaṇṇa ābhoge sati pi a sati pi abhibhavati iti  abhibhu parikammam ñāṇam vā abhibhu āyatanam etassa ati abhibhāyatanam jhānam
translated: because the cause of the mastery is the limitedness.🔽The mastery is either the preliminary work or the knowledge.🔽The base is the object of mastery. The jhāna is the base of mastery.

original: Abhibhavitabbaṃ vā ārammaṇasaṅkhātaṃ āyatanaṃ etassāti abhibhāyatanaṃ. Atha vā ārammaṇābhibhavanato
analyzed: abhibhavitabbam vā ārammaṇa saṅkhātam āyatanam etassa ati abhibhāyatanam atha vā ārammaṇa abhibhavanataḥ
translated: Or alternatively, the object, which is called the base, is to be mastered.

original: abhibhu ca taṃ āyatanañca yogino sukhavisesānaṃ adhiṭṭhānabhāvato manāyatanadhammāyatanabhāvato
analyzed: abhibhu ca tam āyatanam ca yogino sukha visesānam adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ manāyatana dhammāyatana bhāvataḥ
translated: and the sphere of mastery is so called because it is the basis for the special kinds of happiness of the meditator, and because it is the mental and mental-data bases.

original: cāti sasampayuttajjhānaṃ abhibhāyatanaṃ. Abhibhāyatanabhāvanā nāma tikkhapaññasseva
analyzed: ca ati sa sampayutta jhānam abhibhāyatanam abhibhāyatana bhāvanā nāma tikkha paññassa iva
translated: The meditator’s attainment of jhāna together with its associated states is a “surpassing” because it is the basis for the distinction of the kinds of bliss, and it is a “base” because it is the domain of the mind and mental factors.

original: sambhavati, na itarassāti āha – “ñāṇuttariko puggalo”ti. Abhibhavitvā samāpajjatīti
analyzed: sambhavati na itarassa ati āha ñāṇuttarikaḥ puggalaḥ ti abhibhavitvā samāpajjati iti
translated: The development of the bases of mastery is possible only for one of quick understanding, not for another. That is why he said “a person of superior knowledge.”

original: ettha abhibhavanaṃ samāpajjanañca upacārajjhānādhigamanasamanantarameva appanājhānuppādananti
analyzed: ettha abhibhavanam samāpajjanam ca upacāra jhāna adhigamana samanantaram eva appanā jhāna uppādanam ti
translated: He enters upon it, having mastered it: here the mastering and the entering are the arising of the jhāna in the way already described under the fourth immaterial attainment, immediately next to the access jhāna.

original: āha – “saha nimittuppādenevettha appanaṃ pāpetī”ti. Saha nimittuppādenāti ca appanāparivāsābhāvassa
analyzed: āha saha nimitta uppādena iva ittha appanam pāpeti iti saha nimitta uppādena ati ca appanā parivāsa abhāvassa
translated: That is why he said, “He brings it about that it arises with the mere arising of the object,”🔽and “with the mere arising of the object” is said in order to show that there is no interval of other consciousnesses between the access and the absorption.

original: lakkhaṇavacanametaṃ. Yo khippābhiññoti vuccati, tatopi ñāṇuttarasseva abhibhāyatanabhāvanā.
analyzed: lakkhaṇa vacanam etam yaḥ khippa abhiññā ti vuccati tatas pi ñāṇa uttarassa iva abhibhā āyatana bhāvanā
translated: The development of the bases of mastery is only for one called “of quick understanding” and “of superior knowledge.”🔽Herein, in this object: in this sign.

original: Etthāti etasmiṃ nimitte. Appanaṃ pāpetīti bhāvanāappanaṃ neti.
analyzed: ettha ati etasmin nimitte appanam pāpeti iti bhāvanā appanam na iti
translated: He brings it about that it arises: he brings it about that it is developed.

original: Ettha ca keci “uppanne upacārajjhāne taṃ ārabbha ye heṭṭhimantena dve tayo javanavārā
analyzed: ettha ca keci uppanne upacāra jjhāne tam ārabbha ye heṭṭhimantena dve tayaḥ javana vārā
translated: And here some say this: “When the access jhāna has arisen, then the two or three impulsions that occur next to it are the preliminary work, and the rest is as already stated.”

original: pavattanti, te upacārajjhānapakkhikā eva, tadanantaraṃ bhavaṅgaparivāsena upacārasevanāya
analyzed: pavattanti te upacāra jhāna pakkhikāḥ eva tad anantaram bhavaṅga parivāsena upacāra sevanāya
translated: they are only the access jhāna factors. After that, by the succession of the life-continuum, the access is cultivated.

original: ca vinā appanā hoti, saha nimittuppādeneva appanaṃ pāpetī”ti vadanti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ.
analyzed: ca vinā appanā hoti saha nimitta uppādena iva appanam pāpeti iti vadanti tam tesam matimattam
translated: They are only the access jhāna factors. And after that, without the need for any further development of access, absorption arises with the life-continuum’s change of mode. It is said that absorption is brought about with the arising of the sign. But that is mere opinion.

original: Na hi pārivāsikaparikammena appanāvāro icchito, nāpi mahaggatappamāṇajjhānesu viya🔽upacārajjhāne ekantato paccavekkhaṇā icchitabbā. Tasmā upacārajjhānādhigamato paraṃ
analyzed: na hi pārivāsika parikammena appanāvāraḥ icchitaḥ na api mahaggata ppamāṇa jhānesu viya  upacāra jhāne ekantataḥ paccavekkhaṇā icchitabbā tasmai upacāra jhāna adhigamataḥ param
translated: For the attainment of absorption is not intended here by the “change of mode” of the life-continuum, nor is the reviewing that is intended to be done in the case of the jhāna of the fine-material sphere and immaterial sphere.🔽Therefore, after the access jhāna has been reached,

original: katipayabhavaṅgacittāvasāne appanaṃ pāpuṇanto “saha nimittuppādenevettha appanaṃ
analyzed: katipaya bhavaṅga citta avasāne appanam pāpuṇantaḥ saha nimitta uppādena iva ittha appanam
translated: when one reaches absorption at the end of a number of life-continuum consciousnesses, it is said that absorption is brought about with the arising of the sign.

original: pāpetī”ti vutto. Saha nimittuppādenāti ca adhippāyikamidaṃ vacanaṃ, na nītatthaṃ,🔽tattha adhippāyo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Na antosamāpattiyaṃ tadā tathārūpassa ābhogassa
analyzed: pāpā iti iti vuttaḥ saha nimitta uppādena ati ca adhippāyikam idam vacanam na nīta ttham  tattha adhippāyaḥ vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ na antosamāpattiyam tadā tathārūpassa ābhogassa
translated: And this statement is intended in the sense of the arising of the sign, not in the sense of the actual time of absorption.🔽The intention should be understood in the way already stated.🔽Because there is no such application of attention in the absorption itself,

original: asambhavato. Samāpattito vuṭṭhitassa ābhogo pubbabhāgabhāvanāvasena jhānakkhaṇe pavattaṃ
analyzed: asambhavataḥ samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhitassa ābhogaḥ pubbabhāga bhāvanā vasena jhāna kkhaṇe pavattam
translated: but there is such application of attention in the case of one who has emerged from the jhāna, and that is intended here as the reviewing that should be done at the time of the jhāna by reviewing the jhāna in the way already described.

original: abhibhavanākāraṃ gahetvā pavattoti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Abhidhammaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “imināssa
analyzed: abhibhavana ākāram gahetvā pavatto ti daṭṭhabbam abhidhamma ṭṭhakathā ayam pana iminā assa
translated: It should be regarded as occurring with the mode of surmounting. But in the Abhidhamma Commentary it is said: “This shows his previous aspiration.”

original: pubbābhogo kathito”ti vuttaṃ. Antosamāpattiyaṃ tadā tathā ābhogābhāve kasmā jhānasaññāyapīti
analyzed: pubba ābhogo kathito ti vuttam antosamāpattiyam tadā tathā ābhoga abhāve kasmā jhāna saññāya api iti
translated: Why is it said “even in the attainment” when there is no such aspiration then?

original: vuttanti āha – “abhibhavasaññā hissa antosamāpattiyampi atthī”ti.
analyzed: vuttanti āha abhibhava saññā hissa antosamāpattiyam pi atthi iti
translated: He said: “For there is the perception of surmounting in him even in the attainment.”

original: Vaḍḍhitappamāṇānīti vipulappamāṇānīti attho, na ekaṅguladvaṅgulādivaḍḍhiṃ pāpitāni
analyzed: vaḍḍhita ppamāṇāni iti vipula ppamāṇāni iti atthaḥ na ekaṅgula dvaṅgula ādi vaḍḍhim pāpitāni
translated: “Increased in size”: the meaning is, “increased in bulk.” They are not increased by the addition of a finger’s breadth or a span,

original: tathā vaḍḍhanassevettha asambhavato. Tenāha – “mahantānī”ti. Bhattavaḍḍhitakanti
analyzed: tathā vaḍḍhanassa iva ittha asambhavataḥ tena āha mahantāni iti bhatta vaḍḍhitakam ti
translated: for such increase is impossible here. That is why he said “great.”

original: bhuñjanabhājane vaḍḍhetvā dinnaṃ bhattaṃ, ekāsane purisena bhuñjitabbabhattato upaḍḍhabhattanti attho.
analyzed: bhuñjana bhājane vaḍḍhetvā dinnam bhattam eka āsane purisena bhuñjitabba bhattataḥ upaḍḍhabhattanti atthaḥ
translated: “Food-increased” : food given after increasing it by cooking; the meaning is, half the amount of food that a man can eat at one sitting.

original: Rūpe saññā rūpasaññā, sā assa atthīti rūpasaññī, na rūpasaññī arūpasaññī. Saññāsīsena
analyzed: rūpe saññā rūpa saññā sā assa atthi iti rūpa saññī na rūpa saññī a rūpa saññī saññā sīsena
translated: Perception of forms is “perception of forms.” He has that, thus he is “percipient of forms.” He is “not percipient of forms,” he is “percipient of the formless.”🔽He speaks of the jhāna by the perception in it.🔽The non-arising of perception of forms is its “non-obtainment.”

original: jhānaṃ vadati. Rūpasaññāya anuppādanamevettha alābhitā. Bahiddhāva uppannanti bahiddhāvatthusmiṃyeva
analyzed: jhānam vadati rūpa saññāya anuppādanam eva ittha alābhi tā bahiddhā vā uppannanti bahiddhā vatthusmiṃyeva
translated: “Arisen externally” : arisen only in external physical objects,

original: uppannaṃ. Ettha ca –
analyzed: uppannam ettha ca
translated: And here,

original: “Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni. Ajjhattaṃ🔽rūpasaññī bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni. Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī🔽bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni. Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī bahiddhā
analyzed: ajjhattam rūpa saññī bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni ajjhattam  rūpa saññī bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni ajjhattam arūpa saññī  bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni ajjhattam arūpa saññī bahiddhā
translated: “One percipient of form internally sees forms externally as limited, beautiful and ugly.

original: rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānī”ti –🔽Evamidha cattāri abhibhāyatanāni āgatāni. Abhidhamme pana “ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī bahiddhā
analyzed: rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti  evam idha cattāri abhibha āyatanāni āgatāni abhidhamme pana ajjhattam arūpa saññī bahiddhā
translated: One percipient of form internally sees forms externally as immeasurable, beautiful and ugly. One percipient of the formless internally sees forms externally as limited, beautiful and ugly. One percipient of the formless internally sees forms externally as immeasurable, beautiful and ugly” .

original: rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānī”ti evamāgatāni.
analyzed: rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni appamāṇāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti evamāgatāni
translated: Thus four bases of mastery are given here. But in the Abhidhamma they are given as follows: “One percipient of the formless internally sees forms externally as limited, beautiful and ugly, as immeasurable, beautiful and ugly” .

original: Tattha ca kāraṇaṃ abhidhammaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttameva. Tathā hi vuttaṃ aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ –
analyzed: tattha ca kāraṇam abhidhamma ṭṭhakathāyam vuttam eva tathā hi vuttam aṭṭhasāliniyam
translated: And the reason for this is given in the Abhidhamma Commentary. For this is said in the Paṭṭhāna:

original: “Kasmā pana yathā suttante ‘ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittānī’tiādi
analyzed: kasmā pana yathā suttante ajjhattam rūpa saññī ekaḥ bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni itiādi
translated: “But why are they given in the Suttas thus, ‘One percipient of form internally sees forms externally as limited, beautiful and ugly … ’ ,

original: vuttaṃ, evaṃ avatvā idha catūsupi abhibhāyatanesu ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññitāva vuttāti.
analyzed: vuttam evam avatvā idha catūsu pi abhibhāyatanesu ajjhattam arūpa saññi tā ava vuttā ati
translated: But without saying that, he said here only ‘perceiving internally a form’ in all four bases covered by the fourth jhāna.

original: Ajjhattarūpānaṃ anabhibhavanīyato. Tattha vā hi idha vā bahiddhā rūpāneva abhibhavitabbāni,
analyzed: ajjhatta rūpānam tattha vā hi idha vā bahiddhā
translated: Because the internal forms are not to be overmastered. For it is only forms externally that are to be overmastered here or there.

original: tasmā tāni niyamato vattabbānī”ti.
analyzed: tasmā tāni niyamataḥ vattabbāni iti
translated: So they must be stated as to kind.”

original: Tatrāpi idhapi vuttāni “ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññīti idaṃ pana satthu🔽desanāvilāsamattamevā”ti. Ayaṃ panettha adhippāyo – idha vaṇṇābhogarahitāni sahitāni
analyzed: tatra api idha api vuttāni ajjhattam rūpa saññī ajjhattam arūpa saññī iti idam pana satthu  desanā vilāsa mattam eva ati ayam pana ittha adhippāyaḥ idha vaṇṇa ābhoga rahitāni sahitāni
translated: But here and there they are stated thus: ‘Perceiving forms internally …’ and ‘Perceiving forms externally …’ This is just the teacher’s way of teaching,🔽which is a mere play of his knowledge. But the intention here is this: here all the small forms, whether beautiful or ugly, are overmastered whether they are devoid of colour and shape or possess it.

original: ca sabbāni parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni abhibhuyyāti. Pariyāyakathā hi suttantadesanāti.
analyzed: ca sabbāni parittāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni abhibhuyya ati pariyāya kathā hi suttanta desanā ati
translated: For the teaching in the suttas is by way of synonyms.

original: Abhidhamme pana nippariyāyadesanattā vaṇṇābhogarahitāni visuṃ vuttāni, tathā sahitāni.
analyzed: abhidhamme pana nippariyāya desana ttā vaṇṇa ābhoga rahitāni visum vuttāni tathā sahitāni
translated: But in the Abhidhamma it is by way of the specific characteristic. So the forms devoid of colour and shape are stated separately there, and so are those possessing it.

original: Atthi hi ubhayattha abhibhavanavisesoti. Tathā idha pariyāyadesanattā vimokkhānampi
analyzed: atthi hi ubhayattha abhibhavana visesaḥ ti tathā idha pariyāya desana ttā vimokkhānam pi
translated: For there is a difference in overmastering in both cases. So too, here, because the teaching is by way of synonyms,

original: abhibhavanapariyāyo atthīti “ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī”tiādinā paṭhamadutiyaabhibhāyatanesu🔽paṭhamavimokkho, tatiyacatutthaabhibhāyatanesu dutiyavimokkho, vaṇṇābhibhāyatanesu
