original: tatiyavimokkho ca abhibhavanapattito saṅgahito. Abhidhamme pana nippariyāyadesanattā🔽vimokkhābhibhāyatanāni asaṅkarato desetuṃ vimokkhe vajjetvā abhibhāyatanāni kathitāni.🔽Sabbāni ca vimokkhakiccāni jhānāni vimokkhadesanāyaṃ vuttāni. Tadetaṃ “ajjhattaṃ🔽rūpasaññī”ti āgatassa abhibhāyatanadvayassa abhidhamme abhibhāyatanesu avacanato
analyzed: tatiya vimokkho ca abhibhavana pattitaḥ saṅgahitaḥ abhidhamme pana nippariyāya desanattā  vimokkha abhibhāyatanāni asaṅkarataḥ desetum vimokkhe vajjetvā abhibhāyatanāni kathitāni  sabbāni ca vimokkha kiccāni jhānāni vimokkha desanāyam vuttāni tat etam ajjhattam  rūpa saññī iti āgatassa abhibhāyatana dvayassa abhidhamme abhibhāyatanesu avacanato
translated: The first and second bases of mastery are included in the first and third and fourth liberations respectively, and the colour bases of mastery are included in the third liberation, because of the mastery in each case. But in the Abhidhamma the liberations and bases of mastery are taught without distinction,🔽because the teaching there is by way of the bare essentials.🔽And all the jhānas that have the function of liberations are mentioned in the teaching on the liberations. This is evident from the fact that the two bases of mastery stated as “perceiving forms internally” are not mentioned in the Abhidhamma among the bases of mastery,

original: “rūpī rūpāni passatī”tiādīnañca sabbavimokkhakiccasādhāraṇavacanabhāvato vavatthānaṃ katanti viññāyati.
analyzed: rūpī rūpāni passati iti ādīnam ca sabba vimokkha kicca sādhāraṇa vacana bhāvataḥ vavatthānam katam ti viññāyati
translated: and from the fact that the statement “one who possesses the first jhāna … possesses the first liberation” is a statement common to all the jhānas that have the function of liberations.

original: Ajjhattarūpānaṃ anabhibhavanīyatoti idaṃ abhidhamme katthacipi “ajjhattarūpāni passatī”ti
analyzed: ajjhatta rūpānam an abhibhavanīya to ti idam abhidhamme katthacipi ajjhatta rūpāni passati iti
translated: Because of the impossibility of mastering the internal forms: this is evident from the fact that nowhere in the Abhidhamma is there a statement that one sees internal forms.

original: avatvā sabbattha yaṃ vuttaṃ – “bahiddhā rūpāni passatī”ti, tassa kāraṇavacanaṃ. Tena
analyzed: a vatvā sabbattha yat vuttam bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti tassa kāraṇa vacanam tena
translated: The reason for the statement “he sees external forms” is given in all instances where the words “he sees external forms” are not used.

original: yaṃ aññahetukaṃ suttante “bahiddhā rūpāni passatī”ti vacanaṃ, taṃ tena hetunā vuttaṃ.🔽Yaṃ pana desanāvilāsahetukaṃ ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññitāya eva abhidhamme vacanaṃ, na
analyzed: yam añña hetukam suttante bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti vacanam tam tena hetunā vuttam  yam pana desanā vilāsa hetukam ajjhattam arūpa saññitāya eva abhidhamme vacanam na
translated: This shows that the statement “he sees external forms” in the suttas is made for a specific reason.🔽But the statement in the Abhidhamma that “he does not see forms internally” is made not for that reason but for the purpose of showing the diversity of teaching methods.

original: tassa aññaṃ kāraṇaṃ maggitabbanti dasseti. Ajjhattarūpānaṃ anabhibhavanīyatā ca tesaṃ
analyzed: tassa aññam kāraṇam maggitabbanti dasseti ajjhatta rūpānam an abhibhavanīya tā ca tesam
translated: And the reason why the internal forms are not mentioned is that they are not as evident as the external forms.

original: bahiddhārūpānaṃ viya avibhūtattā. Desanāvilāso ca yathāvuttavavatthānavasena veditabbo🔽veneyyajjhāsayavasena vijjamānapariyāyakathanabhāvato. Desanāvilāso hi nāma veneyyajjhāsayānurūpaṃ🔽vijjamānassa ca pariyāyassa vibhāvanaṃ, na yassa kassaci, tasmā “idha pariyāyadesanattā”tiādinā
analyzed: bahiddhā rūpāṇam viya avibhūta ttā desanā vilāso ca yathā vutta vavatthāna vasena veditabbo  veneyya ajjhāsaya vasena vijjamāna pariyāya kathana bhāvataḥ desanāvilāsaḥ hi nāma veneyya ajjhāsayā anurūpam  vijjamānassa ca pariyāyassa vibhāvanam na yassa kassaci tasmai idha pariyāya desanattā ati ādinā
translated: The diversity of teaching methods should be understood as follows:🔽The diversity of teaching methods is the revealing of a variety of terms for a single thing in accordance with the inclinations of those to be trained.

original: vuttappakāraṃ vavatthānaṃ desanāvilāsanibandhananti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vutta ppakāram vavatthānam desanā vilāsa nibandhanan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: For the diversity of teaching methods is the revealing of a variety of terms for a single thing in accordance with the inclinations of those to be trained, not for anyone else. Therefore the reason for the diversity of teaching methods should be regarded as the distinction stated in the way beginning, “Because here the teaching is by way of terms.”

original: Suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānīti eteneva siddhattā na nīlādiabhibhāyatanāni vattabbānīti ce? Na🔽nīlādīsu katādhikārānaṃ nīlādibhāvasseva abhibhavanakāraṇattā. Na hi tesaṃ parisuddhāparisuddhavaṇṇānaṃ
analyzed: suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti etena iva siddha ttā na nīla ādi abhibhāyatanāni vattabbāni iti ce na  nīla ādīsu kata adhikārānam nīla ādi bhāvassa iva abhibhavana kāraṇa ttā na hi tesam parisuddha aparisuddha vaṇṇānam
translated: If it is asked whether the kasiṇas of blue, etc., should be mentioned since they are established by the words “beautiful and ugly,”

original: parittatā appamāṇatā vā abhibhavanakāraṇaṃ, atha kho nīlādibhāvo evāti. Etesu ca
analyzed: paritta tā appamāṇa tā vā abhibhavana kāraṇam atha kho nīla ādi bhāvaḥ eva ati etesu ca
translated: the answer is no. Because the blue, etc., are the cause of the over- coming only of the state of blue, etc., in one who has already had practice in them. For the limited and measureless state of the beautiful and ugly is not the cause of the overcoming, but rather the state of blue, etc., itself.

original: parittādikasiṇarūpesu yaṃyaṃcaritassa imāni abhibhāyatanāni ijjhanti, taṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: paritta ādi kasiṇa rūpesu yaṃ yaṃ caritassa imāni abhibhāyatanāni ijjhanti tam dassetuṃ
translated: And in order to show which of these kasiṇas of limited, etc., is successful for one of a certain temperament,

original: – “imesu panā”tiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Sabbasaṅgāhikavasenāti nīlavaṇṇanīlanidassananīlanibhāsānaṃ sādhāraṇavasena. Vaṇṇavasenāti🔽sabhāvavaṇṇavasena. Nidassanavasenāti passitabbatāvasena, cakkhuviññāṇavīthiyā gahetabbatāvasena.
analyzed: imesu pana atiādi vuttam  sabba saṅgāhika vasena ati nīla vaṇṇa nīla nidassana nīla nibhāsānam sādhāraṇa vasena vaṇṇa vasena ati  sabhāva vaṇṇa vasena nidassana vasena ati passitabba tā vasena cakkhu viññāṇa vīthiyāḥ gahetabba tā vasena
translated: the following is said: “In these, etc.”🔽By way of the all-inclusive: by way of what is common to the blue colour, the blue appearance, and the blue lustre. By way of colour: by way of the individual essence of colour. By way of appearance: by way of the state of being visible, by way of the state of being apprehensible by the eye-consciousness process.

original: Obhāsavasenāti sappabhāsatāya avabhāsanavasena. Vaṇṇadhātuyā vāti añjanarajatavatthādivaṇṇadhātuyā.
analyzed: obhāsa vasena ati sa pabhāsa tāya avabhāsana vasena vaṇṇa dhātuyā vā ati añjana rajata vattha ādi vaṇṇa dhātuyā
translated: By way of lustre: by way of the state of illumination by means of radiance. In the colour element: in the colour element such as the colour of collyrium or silver.

original: Lokiyāneva rūpāvacarajjhānabhāvato.🔽435. Rūpīti ettha yenāyaṃ sasantatipariyāpannena rūpena samannāgato, taṃ yassa jhānassa
analyzed: rūpāvacara jhāna bhāvato  rūpī iti ettha yena ayam sa santati pariyāpannena rūpena samannāgato tam yassa jhānassa
translated: and it is only the mundane jhāna that is so.🔽As to “possessed of material form”: the material form by means of which he is “possessed of material form” is the special kind of materiality that is the cause of the jhāna.

original: hetubhāvena visiṭṭharūpaṃ hoti. Yena visiṭṭhena rūpīti vucceyya, tadeva sasantatipariyāpannarūpanimittaṃ🔽jhānaṃ. Idha pana paramatthato rūpibhāvasādhakanti āha – “ajjhattaṃ kesādīsū”tiādi.
analyzed: hetu bhāvena visiṭṭha rūpam hoti yena visiṭṭhena rūpī iti tat eva sa santati pariyāpanna rūpa nimittam  jhānam idha pana paramatthataḥ rūpi bhāva sādhakanti āha ajjhattam kesa ādīsu utiādi
translated: The jhāna itself, which is the cause of the special kind of materiality by means of which he is called “possessed of material form,” is the material-form kasiṇa that is the counterpart of that materiality.

original: Rūpajjhānaṃ rūpanti uttarapadalopena vuttaṃ – “rūpūpapattiyā”tiādīsu viya.
analyzed: rūpa jhānam rūpanti uttara pada lopena vuttam rūpa upapattiyā atiādīsu viya
translated: But here the word “material form” is used in the sense of the materiality that is the cause of the jhāna.🔽The third liberation is “one who is resolved only upon the beautiful” .

original: Subhantveva adhimutto hotīti ayaṃ tatiyavimokkho. Idha suparisuddhanīlādivaṇṇakasiṇajjhānavasena🔽vuttoti dassetvā idāni paṭisambhidāpāḷiyaṃ tassa brahmavihārajjhānavasena āgatabhāvaṃ
analyzed: adhimutto hoti iti ayam tatiya vimokkhaḥ idha su parisuddha nīla ādi vaṇṇa kasiṇa jhāna vasena  vuttaḥ ti dassetvā idāni paṭisambhidā pāḷiyam tassa brahmavihāra jhāna vasena āgata bhāvam
translated: Herein, it is stated by means of the jhāna in the various colour kasiṇas such as the blue kasiṇa, etc., which is quite purified.🔽But in the Paṭisambhidā it is stated by means of the jhāna in the divine abidings.

original: dassetuṃ – “paṭisambhidāmagge panā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Idha pana uparipāḷiyaṃyeva brahmavihārānaṃ
analyzed: dassetum paṭisambhidā magge pana ati ādi āraddham idha pana
translated: In the Paṭisambhidā it is stated by means of the jhāna in the divine abidings.

original: āgatattā taṃ nayaṃ paṭikkhipitvā parisuddhanīlādivaṇṇakasiṇavaseneva subhavimokkho anuññāto.
analyzed: āgata ttā tam nayam paṭikkhipitvā parisuddha nīla ādi vaṇṇa kasiṇa vasena iva subha vimokkhaḥ anuññātaḥ
translated: and so the method of the kasiṇa of blue, etc., is rejected and the method of the kasiṇa of the beautiful is allowed.

original: 443. Parikammapathaviyāpīti akatāya vā katāya vā daḷhamaṇḍalādisaṅkhātaparikammapathaviyāpi.
analyzed: parikamma patha viyāpi iti a katāya vā katāya vā daḷha maṇḍala ādi saṅkhāta parikamma patha viyāpi
translated: “In the earth kasiṇa”: in the earth kasiṇa called “the sign of the delimited earth,” whether it is made or not made.

original: Uggahanimittādīnaṃ pathavīkasiṇanti nāmaṃ nissite nissayavohāravasena vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ,
analyzed: uggaha nimitta ādīnam pathavīkasiṇanti nāmam nissite nissaya vohāra vasena vuttan ti daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: The name “earth kasiṇa” should be regarded as said figuratively according to the principle of the dependent origination,

original: yathā “mañcā ukkuṭṭhiṃ karontī”ti.
analyzed: yathā mañcāḥ ukkuṭṭhim karonti iti
translated: just as it is said, “The beds make obeisance to the bedmakers.”🔽“The four kinds of virtue”: the four kinds of virtue consisting of the virtue of the Pātimokkha, etc.

original: Sīlānīti pātimokkhasaṃvarādīni cattāri sīlāni. Sodhetvāti anāpajjanena āpannavuṭṭhāpanena
analyzed: sīlāni iti pātimokkha saṃvara ādīni cattāri sīlāni sodhetvā ati anāpajjanena āpanna vuṭṭhāpanena
translated: “Having purified”: having purified by non-transgression, by restoration of lapsed virtue,

original: kilesehi appaṭipīḷanena ca visodhetvā. Tividhañhi sīlassa visodhanaṃ nāma – anāpajjanaṃ🔽āpannavuṭṭhāpanaṃ kilesehi ca appaṭipīḷananti. Kammaṭṭhānabhāvanaṃ paribundheti uparodheti
analyzed: kilesehi appaṭipīḷanena ca visodhetvā tividham hi sīlassa visodhanam nāma anāpajjanam  āpanna vuṭṭhāpanam kilesehi ca appaṭipīḷanam ti kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanam paribundha iti uparodha iti
translated: and by non-affliction with the defilements. For there are three kinds of purification of virtue, that is to say,🔽non-transgression, restoration of lapsed virtue, and non-affliction with the defilements.

original: pavattituṃ na detīti palibodho rakārassa lakāraṃ katvā, paribandhoti attho. Upacchinditvāti
analyzed: pavattitum na deti iti palibodhaḥ rakārassa lakāram katvā paribandho ti attho upacchinditvā iti
translated: “It is an impediment to the development of meditation”: it is an obstruction, a hindrance, it prevents the arising of meditation. The word “impediment” is derived by dropping the “a” from the fourth syllable and changing the “a” to “i” in the word “palibodho” .🔽“Having cut it off”:

original: samāpannena saṅgāhaṇena vā uparundhitvā, apalibodhaṃ katvāti attho. Kalyāṇamittaṃ upasaṅkamitvāti –
analyzed: samāpannena saṅgāhaṇena vā uparundhitvā apalibodham katvā ati kalyāṇa mittam upasaṅkamitvā iti
translated: Having approached a good friend:🔽One who is dear, respected, and esteemed,

original: “Piyo garu bhāvanīyo, vattā ca vacanakkhamo;
analyzed: piyaḥ garu bhāvanīyaḥ vattā ca vacana kkhamaḥ
translated: Who speaks and is easy to speak to,🔽Who speaks in a way that is deep and meaningful,

original: Gambhīrañca kathaṃ kattā, no caṭṭhāne niyojako”ti. –
analyzed: gambhīram ca katham kattā no caṭṭhāne niyojakaḥ ti
translated: And who does not misrepresent the Teacher.

original: Evamādiguṇasamannāgataṃ ekantahitesiṃ vuddhipakkhe ṭhitaṃ kalyāṇamittaṃ upasaṅkamitvā.
analyzed: evamādi guṇa samannāgatam ekanta hitesim vuddhi pakkhe ṭhitam kalyāṇa mittam upasaṅkamitvā
translated: Having approached a good friend who possesses these special qualities and who is on the side of one’s welfare and happiness.

original: Ananurūpaṃ vihāranti aṭṭhārasannaṃ dosānaṃ aññatarena samannāgataṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ aṭṭhakathāsu –
analyzed: ananurūpam vihāranti aṭṭhāra sannam dosānam aññatarena samannāgatam vuttam ha etam aṭṭhakathāsu
translated: An unsuitable dwelling: one that possesses any one of the eighteen faults. For this is said in the commentaries:

original: “Mahāvāsaṃ navāvāsaṃ, jarāvāsañca panthaniṃ;
analyzed: mahā vāsam nava āvāsam jarā vāsañca panthanim
translated: A large dwelling, a new dwelling, An old dwelling, and a dwelling on the road,

original: Soṇḍiṃ paṇṇañca pupphañca, phalaṃ patthitameva ca.
analyzed: soṇḍim paṇṇam ca puppham ca phalam patthitam eva ca
translated: A dwelling with a female spirit, a dwelling with a male spirit, A dwelling with leaves, a dwelling with flowers, A dwelling with fruits, and a dwelling with a wish.

original: “Nagaraṃ dārunā khettaṃ, visabhāgena paṭṭanaṃ;
analyzed: nagaram dārunā khettam visa bhāgena paṭṭanam
translated: A town, a dwelling with wood, a field, A dwelling with a mixed population, a port,

original: Paccantasīmā sappāyaṃ, yattha mitto na labbhati.
analyzed: sappāyam yattha mitto na labbhati
translated: A dwelling on the border, and a dwelling with no friend,🔽These eighteen kinds of dwellings,

original: “Aṭṭhārasetāni ṭhānāni, iti viññāya paṇḍito;
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa itāni ṭhānāni iti viññāya paṇḍito
translated: Having understood them thus, the wise one🔽Should avoid them from afar,

original: Ārakā parivajjeyya, maggaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ yathā”ti. ;
analyzed: ārakā parivajjeyya maggam sa paṭibhayam yathā ati
translated: As one does a path that is dangerous.

original: Anurūpeti gocaragāmato nātidūranaccāsannatādīhi pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgate. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: anurūpā iti gocara gāmataḥ na atidūra nacca āsanna tā ādīhi pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgate vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: “Suitable” means endowed with the five qualities of a suitable lodging, not too far and not too near, etc. For this is said:

original: “Kathañca, bhikkhave, senāsanaṃ pañcaṅgasamannāgataṃ hoti? Idha, bhikkhave, senāsanaṃ
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave senāsanam pañcaṅga samannāgatam hoti idha bhikkhave senāsanam
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, does a lodging have five factors? Here, bhikkhus, a lodging

original: nātidūraṃ hoti naccāsannaṃ gamanāgamanasampannaṃ divā appākiṇṇaṃ rattiṃ appasaddaṃ🔽appanigghosaṃ appaḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassaṃ. Tasmiṃ kho pana senāsane
analyzed: na ati dūram hoti nacca āsannam gamana āgamana sampannam divā appa ākiṇṇam rattim appasaddam  appa nigghosam appa ḍaṃsama kasa vāta ātapa sarīsapa samphassam tasmim kho pana senāsane
translated: is not too far, not too near, and has a path for going and coming. It is little frequented by day with little sound and few voices by night.🔽It is not exposed to the (four) directions. And when one dwells in that lodging,

original: viharantassa appakasirena uppajjanti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā.
analyzed: viharantassa appakasirena uppajjanti cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārā
translated: robes, alms food, lodging, and medicinal requisites as cure for the sick can easily be obtained.

original: Tasmiṃ kho pana senāsane therā bhikkhū viharanti bahussutā āgatāgamā dhammadharā
analyzed: tasmin kho pana senāsane therāḥ bhikkhū viharanti bahu ssutāḥ āgata āgamāḥ dhamma dharāḥ
translated: And in that lodging elder bhikkhus are dwelling who are learned, versed in the scriptures, observers of the Dhamma, observers of the Vinaya, observers of the Codes,🔽and when one has doubts one can approach them from time to time and ask:

original: vinayadharā mātikādharā. Te kālena kālaṃ upasaṅkamitvā paripucchati paripañhati ‘idaṃ,
analyzed: vinaya dharā mātikā dharā te kālena kālam upasaṅkamitvā paripucchati paripañhati idam
translated: ‘How is this, venerable sir? What is the meaning of this?

original: bhante, kathaṃ imassa ko attho’ti. Tassa te āyasmanto avivaṭañceva vivaranti, anuttānīkatañca
analyzed: bhante katham imassa kaḥ atthaḥ ti tassa te āyasmantaḥ a vivaṭan ca iva vivaranti an uttānīkatan ca
translated: “Venerable sir, what is the meaning of this?” Then those venerable ones explain to him what is not yet explained, reveal what is not yet revealed,🔽

original: uttāniṃ karonti, anekavihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭhāniyesu dhammesu kaṅkhaṃ paṭivinodenti.
analyzed: uttānim karonti aneka vihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭhāniyesu dhammesu kaṅkham paṭivinodenti
translated: “Venerable sir, what is the meaning of this?” Then those venerable ones explain to him what has not been explained, reveal what is obscure, and dispel his perplexity about numerous perplexing points.

original: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, senāsanaṃ pañcaṅgasamannāgataṃ hotī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave senāsanam pañcaṅga samannāgatam hoti iti
translated: “It is in such a way, bhikkhus, that a resting place possesses five factors.”

original: Ettha ca nātidūraṃ naccāsannaṃ gamanāgamanasampannanti ekaṃ aṅgaṃ, divā appākiṇṇaṃ🔽rattiṃ appasaddaṃ appanigghosanti ekaṃ, appaḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassanti
analyzed: ettha ca na ati dūram na ca āsannam gamana āgamana sampannanti ekam aṅgam divā appa ākiṇṇam  rattim appa saddam appa nigghosanti ekam
translated: Herein, not too far and not too near, suitable for walking and sitting, is one factor; during the day it is not crowded and at night it is not noisy, is not frightening, and has few insects;

original: ekaṃ, tasmiṃ kho pana senāsane viharantassa…pe… parikkhārāti ekaṃ, tasmiṃ kho pana
analyzed: ekam tasmim kho pana senāsane viharantassape parikkhārā ati ekam tasmim kho pana
translated: it is one factor; while one is living in that resting place, there is no disturbance of mind from any quarter, is one factor; in that resting place there are elder bhikkhus living, experienced, trained, who have reached the goal, are well-trained in the Teacher’s Dispensation, is one factor; in that resting place the venerable ones teach the Dhamma, that is, the discourses, mixed prose and verse, expositions, verses, inspired utterances, quotations, birth stories, amazing accounts, and questions-and-answers, is one factor.

original: senāsane therā…pe… kaṅkhaṃ paṭivinodentīti ekanti evaṃ pañcaṅgāni veditabbāni.
analyzed: senāsane therāpe kaṅkham paṭivinodenti iti ekam ti evam pañcaṅgāni veditabbāni
translated: Thus it should be understood as having five factors.

original: Khuddakapalibodhaṃ upacchinditvāti dīghakesanakhalomānaṃ chedanena cīvarakammacīvararajanapattapacanamañcapīṭhādisodhanavasena khuddakapalibodhaṃ upacchinditvā.🔽453. Uddhumātakādīsūti ettha ādi-saddena vinīlakavipubbakavicchiddakavikkhāyitakahatavikkhittakalohitakapuḷavakaaṭṭhikānaṃ
analyzed: khuddaka pali bodham upacchinditvā ati dīgha kesa nakha lomānam chedanena cīvara kamma cīvara rajana patta pacana mañca pīṭha ādi sodhana vasena khuddaka pali bodham upacchinditvā  uddhumātaka ādīsu iti ettha ādi saddena vinīlaka vipubbaka vicchiddaka vikkhāyitaka hatavikkhittaka lohitaka puḷavaka aṭṭhikānam
translated: Having cut off the minor impediments by means of the cutting off of long hair of the head and nails, and so on, and by means of the making of robes, the dyeing of robes, the sewing of robes, the cleansing of beds and chairs, and so on.

original: saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Tattha bhastā viya vāyunā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā yathānukkamaṃ🔽samuggatena sūnabhāvena dhumātattā uddhumātaṃ, uddhumātameva uddhumātakaṃ, paṭikūlattā
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo tattha bhastā viya vāyunā uddham jīvita pariyādānā yathānukkamam  samuggatena sūna bhāvena dhumātattā uddhumātam uddhumātam eva uddhumātakam paṭikūla ttā
translated: The bloated, etc., are mentioned here by way of the bloated, the livid, the festering, the cut up, the gnawed, the scattered, the hacked and scattered, the bleeding, the worm infested, and the skeleton.🔽The bloated is so called because it is bloated by the wind that has arisen through the dissolution of the elements in the corpse, and because it is smoky-looking.

original: vā kucchitaṃ uddhumātanti uddhumātakaṃ, tathārūpassa chavasarīrassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: vā kucchitam uddhumātanti uddhumātakam tathārūpassa chava sarīrassa itam adhivacanam
translated: Or alternatively, it is bloated because it is swollen and repulsive.🔽The livid is so called because it is discolored with a bluish hue.

original: Vinīlaṃ vuccati viparibhinnanīlavaṇṇaṃ, vinīlameva vinīlakaṃ, paṭikūlattā vā kucchitaṃ
analyzed: vinīlam vuccati viparibhinna nīla vaṇṇam vinīlam eva vinīlakam paṭikūla ttā vā kucchitam
translated: Or alternatively, it is livid because it is repulsive.

original: vinīlanti vinīlakaṃ, maṃsussadaṭṭhānesu rattavaṇṇassa, pubbasannicayaṭṭhānesu setavaṇṇassa,
analyzed: vinīlanti vinīlakam maṃsussada ṭṭhānesu ratta vaṇṇassa pubba sannicaya ṭṭhānesu seta vaṇṇassa
translated: “Rotting” is blue-tinged, red-tinged in places where the flesh is plump, and white-tinged in places where the fat has collected.

original: yebhuyyena ca nīlavaṇṇassa nilaṭṭhāne nīlasāṭakapārutasseva chavasarīrassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.🔽Paribhinnaṭṭhānesu vissandamānapubbaṃ vipubbaṃ, vipubbameva vipubbakaṃ, paṭikūlattā🔽vā kucchitaṃ vipubbanti vipubbakaṃ, tathārūpassa chavasarīrassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Vicchiddaṃ
analyzed: yebhuyyena ca nīla vaṇṇassa nilaṭṭhāne nīla sāṭaka pārutassa iva chava sarīrassa itam adhivacanam  paribhinna ṭhānesu vissandamāna pubbam vipubbam vipubbam eva vipubbakam paṭikūla ttā  vā kucchitam vipubbanti vipubbakam tathārūpassa chava sarīrassa etam adhivacanam vicchiddam
translated: And it is mostly blue-tinged. This is a term for a corpse that is blue-tinged and wrapped in a blue cloth.🔽“Festering” is pus oozing from places where the skin is broken. Festering is the same as festered. Or alternatively, festering is repulsive because of the oozing.

original: vuccati dvidhā chindanena apadhāritaṃ, vicchiddameva vicchiddakaṃ, paṭikūlattā vā🔽kucchitaṃ vicchiddanti vicchiddakaṃ, vemajjhe chinnassa chavasarīrassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.🔽Ito ca etto ca vividhākārena soṇasiṅgālādīhi khāyitaṃ vikkhāyitaṃ, vikkhāyitameva
analyzed: vuccati dvidhā chindanena apadhāritam vicchiddam eva vicchiddakam paṭikūla ttā vā  kucchitam vicchiddanti vicchiddakam vemajjhe chinnassa chava sarīrassa itam adhivacanam  ito ca etto ca vividha ākārena soṇa siṅgāla ādīhi khāyitam vikkhāyitam vikkhāyitam eva
translated: This is a term for a corpse that is in that condition. “Cut up” is cut in two. Cut up is the same as cut up. Or alternatively, cut up is repulsive because of the cutting.🔽This is a term for a corpse cut in the middle. “Inflamed” is said🔽because of being swollen. Inflamed is the same as inflamed. Or alternatively, inflamed is repulsive because of the swelling.🔽This is a term for a corpse that is in that condition. “Eaten by worms” is eaten by various kinds of worms. Eaten by worms is the same as eaten by worms. Or alternatively, eaten by worms is repulsive because of the worms.

original: vikkhāyitakaṃ, paṭikūlattā vā kucchitaṃ vikkhāyitanti vikkhāyitakaṃ, tathārūpassa
analyzed: vikkhāyitakam paṭikūla ttā vā kucchitam vikkhāyitanti vikkhāyitakam tathārūpassa
translated: This is a term for a corpse that is in that condition. “Scattered” is scattered in various ways by dogs, jackals, and so on. Scattered is the same as scattered. Or alternatively, scattered is repulsive because of the scattering.🔽This is a term for a corpse that is in that condition.

original: chavasarīrassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: adhivacanam
translated: is a designation for a dead body.

original: Vividhā khittaṃ vikkhittaṃ, vikkhittameva vikkhittakaṃ, paṭikūlattā vā kucchitaṃ🔽vikkhittanti vikkhittakaṃ, aññena hatthaṃ, aññena pādaṃ, aññena sīsanti evaṃ tato
analyzed: vividhā khittam vikkhittam vikkhittam eva vikkhittakam paṭikūla ttā vā kucchitam  vikkhittanti vikkhittakam aññena hattham aññena pādam aññena sīsanti evam tatas
translated: Cut up and scattered, scattered, is what is meant. Or it is cut up and scattered because it is repulsive.🔽Scattered is what is meant by cut up and scattered. It is a designation for a dead body that is scattered here and there, with a hand here, a foot there, and a head somewhere else.

original: tato vikkhittassa chavasarīrassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Hatañca taṃ purimanayeneva vikkhittakañcāti
analyzed: tatas vikkhittassa chava sarīrassa itam adhivacanam hatam ca tam purima nayena iva vikkhittakam ca ati
translated: And it is cut up and scattered because it is cut up and because it is scattered.

original: hatavikkhittakaṃ, kākapadākārena aṅgapaccaṅgesu satthena hanitvā vuttanayeneva vikkhittassa🔽chavasarīrassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Lohitaṃ kirati vikkhipati ito cito ca paggharatīti
analyzed: hata vikkhittakam kākapada ākārena aṅga paccaṅgesu satthena hanitvā vutta nayena iva vikkhittassa  chava sarīrassa etam adhivacanam lohitam kirati vikkhipati itas citas ca paggharati iti
translated: Cut up and scattered is a designation for a dead body that is cut up and scattered in the way already described, but with the difference that it is cut up with a knife in the shape of a crow’s foot.🔽It sheds blood, scatters it, it oozes here and there, is what is meant.🔽Blood-smeared is a designation for a dead body smeared with oozing blood.

original: lohitakaṃ, paggharitalohitamakkhitassa chavasarīrassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Puḷavā vuccanti🔽kimayo, puḷave kiratīti puḷavakaṃ, kimiparipuṇṇassa chavasarīrassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: lohitakam adhivacanam puḷavāḥ vuccanti 🔽puḷave kirati iti puḷavakam kimi paripuṇṇassa chava sarīrassa etam adhivacanam
translated: Worms are called maggots. It sheds maggots, scatters them, is what is meant.🔽Maggot-ridden is a designation for a dead body full of maggots.

original: Aṭṭhiyeva aṭṭhikaṃ, paṭikūlattā vā kucchitaṃ aṭṭhīti aṭṭhikaṃ, aṭṭhisaṅkhalikāyapi
analyzed: aṭṭhiyā iva aṭṭhikam paṭikūla ttā vā kucchitam aṭṭhī iti aṭṭhikam aṭṭhi saṅkhalikāya api
translated: Bone is either a bone or a skeleton, or else it is a bone because it is a collection of bones, being a heap of bones.🔽This is a term for a single bone as well as for a skeleton.

original: ekaṭṭhikassapi etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Imesu dasasu asubhesu paṭhamajjhānameva uppajjati,
analyzed: ekaṭṭhikassa api etam adhivacanam imesu dasasu asubhesu paṭhamajjhānam eva uppajjati
translated: The first jhāna only arises in these ten kinds of foulness,

original: na dutiyādīni. Tenāha – idha “paṭhamajjhānasahagatā saññā”ti. Tathā hi aparisaṇṭhitajalāya🔽sīghasotāya nadiyā arittabaleneva nāvā tiṭṭhati, vinā arittena na sakkā ṭhapetuṃ.
analyzed: na dutiya ādīni tena āha paṭhama jhāna sahagatā saññā ati tathā hi a parisaṇṭhita jalāya  sīghasotāya nadiyāḥ aritta balena iva nāvā tiṭṭhati vinā arittena na sakkā ṭhapetum
translated: not the second, etc., and so it is said here, “Perception of the first jhāna” .

original: Evamevaṃ dubbalattā ārammaṇassa vitakkabaleneva cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hutvā tiṭṭhati, vinā
analyzed: evam evam dubbala ttā ārammaṇassa vitakka balena iva cittam ekaggam hutvā tiṭṭhati vinā
translated: For just as a boat in a swift-flowing river is pulled along even against the efforts of the steersman, so too, the mind is pulled along here by the weakness of the object and stands still in unification of mind only through the force of applied thought,🔽and it cannot be made to stand still without applied thought.

original: vitakkena na sakkā ṭhapetuṃ. Tasmā paṭhamajjhānamevettha hoti, na dutiyādīni. Ārammaṇassa
analyzed: vitakkena na sakkā ṭhapetum tasmā paṭhama jhānam eva ittha hoti na dutiya ādīni ārammaṇassa
translated: That is why only the first jhāna is present here, not the second, etc.

original: dubbalatā cettha paṭikūlabhāvena cittaṃ ṭhapetuṃ asamatthatā.
analyzed: dubbala tā ca ittha paṭikūla bhāvena cittam ṭhapetum a samattha tā
translated: And the weakness of the object here is its inability to make the mind stand still by its mere power, owing to its repulsiveness.

original: “Rukkho mato, lohaṃ mata”ntiādīsu yaṃ khandhappabandhaṃ upādāya rukkhādisamaññā,
analyzed: rukkhaḥ mataḥ loham mata nti ādīsu yam khandha ppabandham upādāya rukkha ādi samaññā
translated: In such passages as “The tree is dead, the iron is dead” , the name “tree,” etc., is used figuratively for the trunk, etc.,

original: tasmiṃ anupacchinnepi allatādivigamanaṃ nissāya matavohāro sammutimaraṇaṃ. Saṅkhārānaṃ
analyzed: tasmin anupacchinne pi alla tā ādi vigamanam nissāya mata vohāro sammuti maraṇam
translated: And when that is not interrupted, the expression of death by way of convention, based on the disappearance of warmth in the limbs and so on, is conventional death.🔽Momentary death is the moment-by-moment dissolution of formations.

original: khaṇabhaṅgasaṅkhātaṃ khaṇikamaraṇaṃ. Samucchedamaraṇanti arahato santānassa sabbaso
analyzed: khaṇabhaṅga saṅkhātam khaṇika maraṇam samuccheda maraṇam ti arahataḥ santānassa sabbaso
translated: Annihilation death is the death that is the complete annihilation of the continuum of an Arahant.🔽This is said with reference to the development of insight.

original: ucchedabhūtaṃ maraṇaṃ. Vipassanābhāvanāvasena cetaṃ vuttaṃ. Maraṇānussatibhāvanāyaṃ
analyzed: uccheda bhūtam maraṇam vipassanā bhāvanā vasena ca itam vuttam maraṇa anussati bhāvanāyam
translated: But in the development of the recollection of death,

original: pana tividhampetaṃ nādhippetaṃ asaṃvegavatthuto anupaṭṭhahanato abāhullato ca. Maraṇānussatiyañhi
analyzed: pana tividham petam na adhippetam a saṃvega vatthutaḥ an upaṭṭhahanataḥ a bāhullataḥ ca maraṇa anussatiyam hi
translated: all three kinds of death are not intended, because they do not arouse urgency, because they do not occur, and because they are not prominent.

original: ekena bhavena paricchinnassa jīvitindriyappabandhassa vicchedo maraṇanti adhippeto🔽saṃvegavatthuto upaṭṭhahanato bāhullato ca. Idāni imameva maraṇaṃ sandhāya vikappantaraṃ
analyzed: ekena bhavena paricchinnassa jīvitindriya ppabandhassa vicchedaḥ maraṇanti adhippeto  saṃvega vatthutaḥ upaṭṭhahanataḥ bāhullataḥ ca idāni imam eva maraṇam sandhāya vikappa antaram
translated: For in the development of the recollection of death, what is intended is the cutting off of the continuity of the life faculty, which is delimited by a single becoming, as death.🔽It is intended because it arouses urgency, because it occurs, and because it is prominent.

original: dassento, “heṭṭhā vuttalakkhaṇā vā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: dassentaḥ heṭṭhā vutta lakkhaṇā vā ti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show a different interpretation with reference to this very death, he says, “Or the characteristic of death stated above.”

original: Asitapītādibhedeti asitapītakhāyitasāyitappabhede, asitabbakhāditabbasāyitabbavibhāgeti
analyzed: asita pīta ādi bheda iti asita pīta khāyita sāyita ppabhede asitabba khāditabba sāyitabba vibhāge iti
translated: “With the distinction of eating, drinking, etc.,” with the distinction of eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting. “With the distinction of what should be eaten, etc.,”🔽with the distinction of what should be eaten, chewed, drunk, and tasted.

original: attho kālabhedavacanicchāya abhāvato yathā “duddha”nti. Kabaḷaṃ karīyatīti kabaḷīkāro,
analyzed: attho kāla bheda vacanicchāya abhāvataḥ yathā kabaḷam karīyati iti kabaḷīkāro
translated: because there is no wish to express a difference of time, as in the case of “curds.”🔽It is made into morsels, thus it is morsel-food .

original: āharīyatīti āhāro, kabaḷīkāro ca so āhāro cāti kabaḷīkārāhāro. Vatthuvasena cetaṃ🔽vuttaṃ. Savatthuko eva hi āhāro idha kammaṭṭhānabhāvena adhippeto. Ojālakkhaṇo pana
analyzed: āharīyati iti āhāro kabaḷīkāro ca so āhāro ca ati kabaḷīkāra āhāro  vuttam sa vatthukaḥ eva hi āhāraḥ idha kammaṭṭhāna bhāvena adhippetaḥ ojā lakkhaṇaḥ pana
translated: It is brought, thus it is nutriment . It is both morsel-food and nutriment, thus it is morsel-nutriment .🔽This is said with reference to the object.🔽For only that nutriment which has an object is intended here as a meditation subject. But nutriment characterized as nutritive essence is called nutriment because it brings about the nourishment of the four primary elements. That is not intended here,

original: āhāro ojaṭṭhamakaṃ rūpaṃ āharatīti āhāroti vuccati. So idha nādhippeto paṭikūlākāraggahaṇassa🔽asambhavato. Nava paṭikūlānīti gamanapariyesanaparibhogāsayanidānaaparipakkaparipakkaphalanissandappaṭikūlavasena
analyzed: āhāraḥ oja ṭṭhamakam rūpam āharati iti āhāro ti vuccati saḥ idha na adhippeto paṭikūla ākāra ggahaṇassa  asambhavataḥ nava paṭikūlāni iti gamana pariyesana paribhoga āsaya nidāna a paripakka paripakka phala nissanda ppaṭikūla vasena
translated: because it is impossible to apprehend it as a meditation subject consisting of a sign.🔽There are nine kinds of loathsomeness: loathsomeness in going, in seeking, in using, in lying, in origin, in non-suppression, in suppression, in the fruit, and in the outcome.

original: nava paṭikūlāni. Samakkhanappaṭikūlaṃ pana paribhogādīsu labbhamānattā idha visuṃ
analyzed: nava paṭikūlāni samakkhana paṭikūlam pana paribhoga ādīsu labbhamāna ttā idha visum
translated: But the loathsomeness of smearing is not included here separately because it is included in using, etc.,

original: na gahitaṃ, aññathā tena saddhiṃ “dasa paṭikūlānī”ti vattabbaṃ. Visuddhimagge pana
analyzed: na gahitam aññathā tena saddhim dasa paṭikūlāni iti vattabbam visuddhi magge pana
translated: otherwise it would have to be mentioned as “nine or ten kinds of loathsomeness.” But in the Path of Purification🔽it is said to be “the loathsomeness of the body’s nature” and “the loathsomeness of smearing” .

original: samakkhanaṃ paribhogādīsu labbhamānampi nissandavasena visesato paṭikūlanti visuṃ
analyzed: samakkhanam paribhoga ādīsu labbhamānam pi nissanda vasena visesataḥ paṭikūlanti visum
translated: and the repulsive aspect that is found in the process of decay, etc., is the specific characteristic of the repulsive as a natural attribute.

original: gahetvā dasahākārehi paṭikūlatā vuttā.
analyzed: gahetvā dasahā ākārehi paṭikūla tā vuttā
translated: The repulsiveness that is found in the matter of the bloated, etc., as food, etc., is also a kind of outcome. But the tenfold repulsiveness is stated separately in order to show the special kind of repulsiveness that is an outcome of the preceding.

original: Uppajjanakasaññanti paṭikūlākāraggahaṇavasena uppajjanakasaññaṃ. Saññāsaddo cāyaṃ
analyzed: uppajjanaka saññanti paṭikūla ākāra ggahaṇa vasena uppajjanaka saññam saññā saddaḥ ca ayam
translated: The perception arisen: the perception arisen through apprehending the aspects of the bloated, and so on.🔽The word perception is found in the texts🔽in the sense of the characteristic of perceiving thus: “Perception of forms, perception of sounds” ,

original: “rūpasaññā saddasaññā”tiādīsu sañjānanalakkhaṇe dhamme āgato, “aniccasaññā dukkhasaññā”tiādīsu🔽vipassanāya āgato, “uddhumātakasaññāti vā sopākarūpasaññāti vā ime dhammā ekaṭṭhā,
analyzed: rūpa saññā sadda saññā iti ādīsu sañjānana lakkhaṇe dhamme āgataḥ anicca saññā dukkha saññā iti ādīsu  vipassanāya āgataḥ uddhumātaka saññā ati vā sopāka rūpa saññā ati vā ime dhammā ekaṭṭhā
translated: in the sense of insight thus: “Perception of impermanence, perception of non-self” ,

original: udāhu nānaṭṭhā”tiādīsu samathe āgato. Idha pana samathassa parikamme daṭṭhabbo. Āhārehi🔽paṭikūlākāraggahaṇaṃ, tappabhāvitaṃ vā upacārajjhānaṃ idha “āhāre paṭikūlasaññā”ti adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: udāhu nānaṭṭhā ti ādīsu samathe āgataḥ idha pana samathassa parikamme daṭṭhabbo āhārehi  paṭikūla ākāra ggahaṇam tad pabhāvitam vā upacāra jhānam idha āhāre paṭikūla saññā ati adhippetaṃ
translated: and in the sense of serenity thus: “Perception of a bloated corpse, perception of a worm-infested corpse, these things are classed together, are they classed separately? ” . Here it should be understood in the sense of serenity’s preliminary work.🔽The perception of repulsiveness in nutriment is either the apprehending of the aspects of repulsiveness in the four kinds of nutriment by making them objects of the four kinds of insight or else it is the access jhāna that is developed with that as object.🔽The perception of danger is the perception arisen through apprehending the aspect of danger.

original: Ukkaṇṭhitasaññanti nibbindanākārena uppajjanakasaññaṃ. Aniccasaññanti ettha aniccaṃ
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhita saññanti nibbindana ākārena uppajjanaka saññam anicca saññanti ettha aniccam
translated: As regards the perception of impermanence, etc.,

original: khandhapañcakaṃ uppādavayaññathattabhāvato, hutvā abhāvato vā, tasmiṃ anicce khandhapañcake🔽aniccanti uppajjamānā aniccalakkhaṇapariggāhikā saññā aniccasaññā. Tenāha – “pañcannaṃ
analyzed: khandha pañcakam uppāda vayaññathatta bhāvataḥ hutvā abhāvataḥ vā tasmin anicce khandha pañcake  aniccanti uppajjamānā anicca lakkhaṇa pariggāhikā saññā anicca saññā tena āha
translated: The five aggregates are impermanent in the sense of rise and fall, or in the sense of having been and passing away.

original: upādānakkhandhāna”ntiādi. Tattha udayo nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ, vayo vipariṇāmalakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: tattha udayaḥ nibbatti lakkhaṇam vayaḥ vipariṇāma lakkhaṇam
translated: The perception that arises as the contemplation of impermanence in regard to the five aggregates that are impermanent is the perception of impermanence. Hence it is said: “In regard to the five aggregates as objects of clinging” .🔽Herein, rise is the characteristic of generation; fall is the characteristic of change;

original: aññathattaṃ jarā. Udayabbayaññathattaggahaṇena aniccalakkhaṇaṃ dasseti. Uppādavayaññathattabhāvato
analyzed: aññathattam jarā udaya bbaya aññathatta gahaṇena anicca lakkhaṇam dasseti uppāda vayaññathatta bhāvato
translated: change is aging. By mentioning rise, fall, and change, the characteristic of impermanence is shown.🔽For the five aggregates are called “impermanent” because of the presence of rise, fall, and change.

original: hi khandhapañcakaṃ aniccanti vuccati. Yassa ca sabhāvena khandhapañcakaṃ aniccanti
analyzed: hi khandha pañcakam aniccanti vuccati yassa ca sabhāvena khandha pañcakam aniccanti
translated: And that by means of which the five aggregates are called “impermanent” by their individual essence is the characteristic of impermanence.

original: vuccati, taṃ aniccalakkhaṇaṃ. Tena hi taṃ aniccanti lakkhīyati, aniccalakkhaṇañca🔽udayabbayānaṃ amanasikārā santatiyā paṭicchannattā na upaṭṭhāti, udayabbayaṃ pana
analyzed: vuccati tam anicca lakkhaṇam tena hi tam aniccanti lakkhīyati anicca lakkhaṇam ca  udaya bbayānam a manasikārā santatiyā paṭicchanna ttā na upaṭṭhāti udaya bbayam pana
translated: For it is characterized as impermanent by means of that.

original: pariggahetvā santatiyā vikopitāya aniccalakkhaṇaṃ yāthāvasarasato upaṭṭhāti. Na hi
analyzed: pariggahetvā santatiyāḥ vikopitāya anicca lakkhaṇam yāthāvasarasataḥ upaṭṭhāti na hi
translated: But the characteristic of impermanence does not appear as it actually is because it is concealed by the continuity of the aggregates, when rise and fall are not given attention. But when rise and fall are discerned, the continuity is broken and the characteristic of impermanence appears as it actually is.

original: sammadeva udayabbayaṃ sallakkhentassa pubbāpariyena pavattamānānaṃ dhammānaṃ aññoññabhāvaṃ
analyzed: sammad eva udaya bbayam sallakkhentassa pubbāpariyena pavattamānānam dhammānam aññoñña bhāvam
translated: When he sees the rise and fall of formations in this way, he sees the difference between the earlier and later states of formations that occur in succession.

original: sallakkhaṇena santatiyā ugghāṭitāya dhammā sambandhabhāvena upaṭṭhahanti, atha kho🔽ayosalākā viya asambandhabhāvenāti suṭṭhutaraṃ aniccalakkhaṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti.🔽“Yadaniccaṃ, taṃ dukkha”nti vacanato tadeva khandhapañcakaṃ abhiṇhappaṭipīḷanato
analyzed: sat lakkhaṇena santatiyā ugghāṭitāya dhammā sambandha bhāvena upaṭṭhahanti atha kho  ayosalākā viya asambandha bhāvena ati suṭṭhutaram anicca lakkhaṇam pākaṭam hoti  yat aniccam tam dukkhanti vacanataḥ tat eva khandha pañcakam abhiṇha paṭipīḍanato
translated: And when he sees this difference, the formations appear to him as a continuity. Then the characteristic of impermanence becomes clearer to him than the individual formations themselves, like a bamboo through its joints.🔽And because of the words, “What is impermanent is painful,” the same five aggregates that are impermanent are also painful owing to the pressure of being incessantly renewed.

original: dukkhaṃ, abhiṇhappaṭipīḷanākāro pana dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ. Tenevāha – “anicce khandhapañcake…pe…🔽saññaṃ bhāvetī”ti. Tattha paṭipīḷanaṃ nāma yathāpariggahitaṃ udayavayavasena saṅkhārānaṃ🔽nirantaraṃ paṭipīḷiyamānatā vibādhiyamānatā. Dukkhalakkhaṇañca abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanassa
analyzed: dukkham abhiṇha paṭipīḷana ākāraḥ pana dukkha lakkhaṇam tena iva āha anicce khandha pañca kepe  saññam bhāveti iti tattha paṭipīḷanam nāma yathā pariggahitam udaya vaya vasena  nirantaram paṭipīḷiyamāna tā vibādhiyamāna tā dukkha lakkhaṇam ca abhiṇha sampaṭipīḷanassa
translated: And the mode of pressure is the characteristic of pain. Hence it is said: “When he brings to mind as impermanent, the five aggregates as objects of clinging, he brings to mind as painful what is meant by ‘formations.’ ”🔽Herein, pressure is the incessant renewal of formations that have already occurred and the harassment of them as such.

original: amanasikārā iriyāpathehi paṭicchannattā na upaṭṭhāti, abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanaṃ pana
analyzed: amanasikārā iriyāpathehi paṭicchanna ttā na upaṭṭhāti abhiṇha sampaṭipīḷanam pana
translated: And the characteristic of pain does not appear owing to the non-attention to the mode of pressure, because it is concealed by the postures, etc.,🔽but the mode of pressure itself appears owing to the attention to it.

original: manasi karitvā iriyāpathe labbhamānadukkhappaṭicchādakabhāve ugghāṭite dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: manasi karitvā iriyāpathe labbhamāna dukkha paṭicchādaka bhāve ugghāṭite dukkha lakkhaṇam
translated: When the concealing of the pain that arises in the postures has been uncovered by discerning the constant oppression, then the characteristic of pain becomes evident in its true nature.

original: yāthāvasarasato upaṭṭhāti. Tathā hi iriyāpathehi paṭicchannattā dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ na🔽upaṭṭhāti, te ca iriyāpathā abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanāmanasikārena paṭicchādakā jātā. Ekasmiñhi
analyzed: yāthāvasa rasataḥ upaṭṭhāti tathā hi iriyāpathehi paṭicchanna ttā dukkha lakkhaṇam na  te ca iriyāpathāḥ abhiṇha sampaṭipīḍanā manasikārena paṭicchādakāḥ jātāḥ ekasmin hi
translated: For the characteristic of pain is not evident because it is concealed by the postures. And the postures are concealers of pain because they are the cause of the constant oppression.

original: iriyāpathe uppannassa dukkhassa vinodakaṃ iriyāpathantaraṃ tassa paṭicchādakaṃ viya
analyzed: iriyāpathe uppannassa dukkhassa vinodakam iriyāpatha antaram tassa paṭicchādakam viya
translated: For one posture is like a concealer of pain that has arisen in another posture,🔽just as a thief is concealed by a bush. So too are the others.

original: hoti, evaṃ sesāpi. Iriyāpathānaṃ pana taṃtaṃdukkhapatitākārabhāve yāthāvato ñāte🔽tesaṃ dukkhappaṭicchādakabhāvo ugghāṭito nāma hoti saṅkhārānaṃ nirantaraṃ dukkhābhitunnatāya🔽pākaṭabhāvato. Tasmā abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanaṃ manasi karitvā iriyāpathe labbhamānadukkhappaṭicchādakabhāve
analyzed: hoti evam sesā api iriyāpathānam pana taṃ taṃ dukkha patita ākāra bhāve yāthāvataḥ ñāte  tesam dukkha ppaṭicchādaka bhāvaḥ ugghāṭitaḥ nāma hoti saṅkhārānam nirantaram dukkha abhitunna tāya  pākaṭa bhāvataḥ tasmai abhiṇha sampaṭipīḍanam manasi karitvā iriyāpathe labbhamāna dukkha paṭicchādaka bhāve
translated: But when the postures are known in their true nature as the source of pain,🔽then the concealing of pain is uncovered, as it were, because of the manifest occurrence of the pain owing to the uninterrupted occurrence of formations.

original: ugghāṭite dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ yāthāvasarasato upaṭṭhāti.
analyzed: ugghāṭite dukkha lakkhaṇam yāthāvasa rasataḥ upaṭṭhāti
translated: Therefore, when the concealing of the pain that arises in the postures has been uncovered by discerning the constant oppression, then the characteristic of pain becomes evident in its true nature.

original: “Yaṃ dukkhaṃ, tadanattā”ti vacanato tadeva khandhapañcakaṃ avasavattanato anattā,
analyzed: yat dukkham tat anattā ati vacanataḥ tat eva khandha pañcakam avasavattanataḥ anattā
translated: “What is painful is not-self” .

original: avasavattanākāro pana anattalakkhaṇaṃ. Tenāha – “paṭipīḷanaṭṭhenā”tiādi. Anattalakkhaṇañca
analyzed: avasavattana ākāraḥ pana anatta lakkhaṇam tena āha paṭipīḷana ṭṭhena atiādi anatta lakkhaṇam ca
translated: The mode of non-dominion is the characteristic of not-self. That is why he said, “By the mode of oppressing” , etc.

original: nānādhātuvinibbhogassa amanasikārā ghanena paṭicchannattā na upaṭṭhāti, nānādhātuyo🔽pana vinibbhujjitvā “aññā pathavīdhātu, aññā āpodhātū”tiādinā, “añño phasso, aññā🔽vedanā”tiādinā ca visuṃ visuṃ katvā ghanavinibbhoge kate samūhaghane kiccārammaṇaghane
analyzed: nānā dhātu vinibbhogassa a manasikārā ghanena paṭicchanna ttā na upaṭṭhāti nānā dhātuyo  pana vinibbhujjitvā aññā pathavī dhātu aññā āpodhātu uti ādinā aññaḥ phasso aññā  vedanā ati ādinā ca visum visum katvā ghana vinibbhoge kate samūha ghane kicca ārammaṇa ghane
translated: And the characteristic of not-self does not appear because it is concealed by the compact mass of the five aggregates, which are not discerned by the non-analytic mind.

original: ca bhedite anattalakkhaṇaṃ yāthāvasarasato upaṭṭhāti. Yā hesā aññamaññūpatthambhesu🔽samuditesu rūpārūpadhammesu ekattābhinivesavasena aparimadditasaṅkhārehi mamāyamānā
analyzed: ca bhedite anatta lakkhaṇam yāthāvasarasataḥ upaṭṭhāti yā ha esā aññamaññu upatthambhesu  samuditesu rūpa arūpa dhammesu ekatta abhinivesa vasena a parimaddita saṅkhārehi mamāyamānā
translated: But when the various elements are discerned by discerning them thus, “The earth element, the water element, the fire element, the air element, the space element, the consciousness element,” and by discerning them thus, “A different earth element, a different water element” , etc., and by discerning them thus, “A different contact, a different feeling” , etc., then the characteristic of not-self appears as it actually is when the compact mass of the collection and the compact mass of the object of clinging are broken up.

original: samūhaghanatā, tathā tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ kiccabhedassa satipi paṭiniyatabhāve ekato
analyzed: samūha ghana tā tathā tesam tesam dhammānam kicca bhedassa sati pi paṭiniyata bhāve ekatas
translated: For this compact mass of the collection is a compact mass of what is clung to as “I” and “mine” by determinations that have not yet been pounded down by insight, by misinterpreting as a unity what is a plurality of material and immaterial states that are only a collection and only a becoming.🔽And this compact mass of the object of clinging is a compact mass of what is clung to as “I” and “mine” by determinations that have not yet been pounded down by insight, by misinterpreting as a unity what is a plurality of functions of the various states that are only a collection and only a becoming.

original: gayhamānā kiccaghanatā, tathā sārammaṇadhammānaṃ satipi ārammaṇakaraṇabhede ekato
analyzed: gayhamānā kicca ghana tā tathā sārammaṇa dhammānam ārammaṇa karaṇa bhede ekatas
translated: The compactness of function is discerned when the functions of the various states are apprehended as a unity. The compactness of object is discerned when the objects of the various states are apprehended as a unity.

original: gayhamānā ārammaṇaghanatā. Sā catūsu dhātūsu ñāṇena vinibbhujitvā dissamānāsu hatthena🔽parimaddiyamāno pheṇapiṇḍo viya vilīnaṃ āgacchati, yathāpaccayaṃ pavattamānā suññā
analyzed: gayhamānā ārammaṇa ghana tā sā catūsu dhātūsu ñāṇena vinibbhujitvā dissamānāsu hatthena  parimaddiyamānaḥ pheṇa piṇḍaḥ viya vilīnam āgacchati yathāpaccayam pavattamānā suññā
translated: When this is discerned in the four elements, and the four elements are seen as a unity, then when one touches them with the hand, they become like a lump of foam, and they dissolve.

original: ete dhammamattāti avasavattanākārasaṅkhātaṃ anattalakkhaṇaṃ pākaṭataraṃ hoti.
analyzed: ete dhamma mattā ti avasavattana ākāra saṅkhātam anatta lakkhaṇam pākaṭataram hoti
translated: Then the characteristic of not-self, which is the fact that they are void and cannot be made one’s own, becomes evident.

original: Aparaaccharāsaṅghātavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The explanation of the “Section on the Two-Finger-Breadth Fist” is ended.

original: 19. Kāyagatāsativaggavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kāya gata asati vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: The “Section on Mindfulness Occupied with the Body”

original: 563. Cetasā phuṭoti cittena pharito. Cittena pharaṇañca samuddassa dvidhā sambhavatīti🔽āha – “duvidhaṃ pharaṇa”ntiādi. Purimena atthenāti “sampayogavasena vijjaṃ bhajantī”ti
analyzed: cetasā phuṭaḥ ti cittena pharito cittena pharaṇam ca samuddassa dvidhā sambhavati iti  āha duvidham pharaṇa ntiādi purimena atthena ati sampayoga vasena vijjam bhajanti iti
translated: “Is pervaded by the mind”: is suffused by the mind. And the suffusing of the ocean is twofold, according to the difference in the meaning of the words “suffusing” and “pervading.”🔽The former is the meaning of the words “it is associated with knowledge” .

original: vuttena atthena. Pacchimenāti “vijjābhāge vijjākoṭṭhāse vattantī”ti vuttena.
analyzed: vuttena atthena pacchimena ati vijjā bhāge vijjā koṭṭhāse vattanti iti vuttena
translated: The latter is the meaning of the words “it occurs in the field of knowledge, in the domain of knowledge” .

original: 564. Mahato saṃvegāya saṃvattatītiādīsu ayaṃ pana aparo nayo. Yāthāvato kāyasabhāvappavedanato
analyzed: mahataḥ saṃvegāya saṃvattati iti ādīsu ayam pana aparaḥ nayaḥ yāthāvataḥ kāya sabhāva ppavedanato
translated: It leads to great urgency because it announces the true nature of the body.🔽For the benefit: for the benefit here and now, etc.

original: mahato saṃvegāya saṃvattati. Atthāyāti diṭṭhadhammikādiatthāya. Yogakkhemāyāti catūhi🔽yogehi khemabhāvāya. Satisampajaññāyāti sabbattha satiavippavāsāya sattaṭṭhāniyasampajaññāya
analyzed: mahataḥ saṃvegāya saṃvattati atthāya ati diṭṭhadhammika ādi atthāya yogakkhemāya ati catūhi  yogehi khema bhāvāya sati sampajaññāya ati sabbattha sati a vippavāsāya satta ṭṭhāniya sampajaññāya
translated: For the attainment of security from bondage: for the state of security from the four bonds.🔽For the attainment of mindfulness and full awareness: for the non-abandoning of mindfulness everywhere and for the full awareness of the seven stations of consciousness.

original: ca. Ñāṇadassanappaṭilābhāyāti vipassanāñāṇādhigamāya. Vijjāvimuttiphalasacchikiriyāyāti
analyzed: ca ñāṇa dassana ppaṭilābhāya ati vipassanā ñāṇa adhigamāya vijjā vimutti phala sacchikiriyāya ati
translated: For the attainment of knowledge and vision: for the acquisition of insight knowledge.

original: tisso vijjā cittassa adhimutti nibbānaṃ cattāri sāmaññaphalānīti etesaṃ paccakkhakaraṇāya.🔽584. Paññāpaṭilābhāyātiādīsu soḷasasu padesu paññāpaṭilābhāya paññāvuddhiyā paññāvepullāya
analyzed: tissaḥ vijjā cittassa adhimutti nibbānam cattāri sāmañña phalāni iti etesam paccakkha karaṇāya  paññā paṭilābhāya ati ādīsu soḷasasu padesu paññā paṭilābhāya paññā vuddhiyā paññā vepullāya
translated: For the realization of the fruit of knowledge and freedom: for the realization of the three kinds of clear knowledge and the four fruits of recluseship.

original: paññābāhullāyāti imāni cattāri paññāvasena bhāvavacanāni, sesāni dvādasa puggalavasena
analyzed: paññā bāhullāya ati imāni cattāri paññā vasena bhāva vacanāni sesāni dvādasa puggala vasena
translated: In the case of the sixteen terms beginning with “the attainment of understanding,” the four terms “the attainment of understanding,” “the growth of understanding,” “the increase of understanding,” and “the abundance of understanding” are terms of state in the case of understanding. The remaining twelve terms are

original: bhāvavacanāni. Sappurisasaṃsevoti sappurisānaṃ bhajanaṃ. Saddhammassavananti tesaṃ
analyzed: bhāva vacanāni sappurisa saṃsevā iti sappurisānam bhajanam saddhamma ssavanan ti tesam
translated: “Association with superior persons”: attending on superior persons.

original: sappurisānaṃ santike sīlādippaṭipattidīpakassa saddhammavacanassa savanaṃ. Yoniso
analyzed: sappurisānam santike sīla ādi paṭipatti dīpakassa saddhamma vacanassa savanam yonisas
translated: “Hearing the True Dhamma”: hearing the True Dhamma spoken by those superior persons, which illustrates the practice of virtue, etc.

original: manasikāroti sutānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthūpaparikkhāvasena upāyena manasikāro. Dhammānudhammappaṭipattīti
analyzed: manasikāraḥ ti sutānam dhammānam attha upaparikkhā vasena upāyena manasikāraḥ dhamma anudhamma ppaṭipatti iti
translated: “Appropriate attention”: attention by way of the investigation of the meaning of the teachings heard.

original: lokuttaradhamme anugatassa sīlādippaṭipadādhammassa paṭipajjanaṃ.
analyzed: lokuttara dhamme anugatassa sīla ādi paṭipadā dhammassa paṭipajjanam
translated: “Practice in accordance with the Dhamma”: the practice of the Dhamma, which is the practice of virtue, etc., that follows upon the supramundane Dhamma.

original: Channaṃ abhiññāñāṇānanti iddhividhadibbasotacetopariyapubbenivāsadibbacakkhuāsavakkhayañāṇānaṃ.🔽Tesattatīnaṃ ñāṇānanti paṭisambhidāpāḷiyaṃ “sotāvadhāne paññā sutamaye ñāṇaṃ, sutvāna
analyzed: channam abhiññā ñāṇānam ti iddhividha dibba sota cetas upariya pubbenivāsa dibba cakkhu āsava kkhaya ñāṇānam  tesattatīnam ñāṇānanti paṭisambhidā pāḷiyam sota avadhāne paññā suta maye ñāṇam sutvāna
translated: “The six kinds of direct knowledge”: the direct knowledges of supernormal power, divine ear, knowledge of others’ minds, recollection of past lives, the divine eye, and the destruction of the taints.

original: saṃvare paññā sīlamaye ñāṇa”ntiādinā ñāṇakathāya niddiṭṭhānaṃ sāvakasādhāraṇāsādhāraṇānaṃ
analyzed: saṃvare paññā sīla maye ñāṇa nti ādinā ñāṇa kathāya
translated: “The seventy-three kinds of knowledge”: the seventy-three kinds of knowledge described in the Paṭisambhidāmagga in the section on knowledge beginning with the passage: “Understanding of listening is knowledge of what consists in the heard. Understanding of restraint is knowledge of what consists in the practice of virtue” .

original: ñāṇānaṃ. Imesañhi tesattatiñāṇānaṃ sutamayañāṇādīni sattasaṭṭhiñāṇāni sāvakassa sādhāraṇāni,
analyzed: ñāṇānam imesam hi tesattati ñāṇānam suta maya ñāṇa ādīni satta saṭṭhi ñāṇāni sāvakassa sādhāraṇāni
translated: Of these seventy-three kinds of knowledge, sixty-seven kinds of knowledge beginning with knowledge of what consists in the heard are common to disciples ,

original: “indriyaparopariyatte ñāṇaṃ, sattānaṃ āsayānusaye ñāṇaṃ, yamakapāṭihīre ñāṇaṃ, mahākaruṇāsamāpattiyā
analyzed: indriya para upari yatte ñāṇam āsaya anusaye ñāṇam yamaka pāṭihīre ñāṇam mahā karuṇā samāpattiyā
translated: “Knowledge of the higher and lower faculties of others, knowledge of the underlying tendencies of beings, knowledge of the twin miracle, knowledge of the attainment of great compassion,

original: ñāṇaṃ, sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, anāvaraṇañāṇa”nti imāni cha asādhāraṇañāṇāni sāvakehi.
analyzed: ñāṇam sabbaññuta ññāṇam anāvaraṇa ñāṇan ti imāni cha asādhāraṇa ñāṇāni sāvakehi

translated: “The diversity of the various elements” : “This is the eye element … This is the mind-consciousness element” .

original: soḷasa dhātuyo kāmāvacarā, dve cātubhūmikā”ti evaṃ dhātūsu nānākaraṇaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ🔽pavattati. Tayidaṃ upādinnadhātuvasena vuttaṃ. Paccekabuddhānañhi dvinnañca aggasāvakānaṃ
analyzed: soḷasa dhātuyaḥ kāma avacarāḥ dve cātubhūmikā ati evam dhātūsu nānākaraṇam paṭicca ñāṇam  pavattati tayā idam upādinna dhātu vasena vuttam paccekabuddhānam hi dvinnam ca aggasāvakānam
translated: Herein, knowledge occurs contingent upon the diversity of the elements in this way: “Sixteen elements are of the sense sphere; two are of three planes” .

original: upādinnadhātūsu eva nānākaraṇaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati, tañca kho ekadesatova, na
analyzed: upādinna dhātūsu eva nānākaraṇam paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati tat ca kho eka desataḥ va na
translated: This is said with reference to the elements that are clung to. For the knowledge of the Paccekabuddhas and of the two Chief Disciples occurs contingent upon the diversity of the elements that are clung to, but only in part, not

original: nippadesato. Bahiddhā anupādinnadhātūnaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ tesaṃ avisayova, sabbaññubuddhānaṃyeva
analyzed: nippadesataḥ bahiddhā anupādinna dhātūnam nānākaraṇam tesam avisayaḥ uva sabbaññu buddhānam yeva
translated: in its entirety. The diversity of the external elements that are not clung to is not their province,

original: pana “imāya dhātuyā ussannattā imassa rukkhassa khandho seto hoti, imassa kāḷo, imassa
analyzed: pana imāya dhātuyā ussanna ttā imassa rukkhassa khandho setaḥ hoti imassa kāḷaḥ imassa
translated: but it is the province of the omniscient Buddhas. “Because of the predominance of this element the trunk of this tree is white, because of the predominance of that element it is black, because of the predominance of this one it is red, because of the predominance of that one it is yellow” .

original: maṭṭho, imassa kharo, imassa bahalataco, imassa sukkhataco. Imassa pattaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādivasena
analyzed: maṭṭhaḥ imassa kharaḥ imassa bahala tacaḥ imassa sukkha tacaḥ imassa pattam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādi vasena
translated: ‘This one is smooth, this one is rough, this one has a thick skin, this one has a thin skin.’ And he would think: ‘This leaf is beautiful in colour, shape, and size,

original: evarūpaṃ. Imassa pupphaṃ nīlaṃ, pītaṃ, lohitaṃ, odātaṃ, sugandhaṃ, duggandhaṃ, missakagandhaṃ.🔽Phalaṃ khuddakaṃ, mahantaṃ, dīghaṃ, vaṭṭaṃ, suvaṇṇaṃ, dubbaṇṇaṃ, maṭṭhaṃ, pharusaṃ,
analyzed: evarūpam imassa puppham nīlam pītam lohitam odātam sugandham duggandham missaka gandham  phalam khuddakam mahantam dīgham vaṭṭam suvaṇṇam dubbaṇṇam maṭṭham pharusam
translated: “This one has a rough bark, this one a thick bark, this one a thin bark.” “This one’s leaf is of such a colour, such a shape, such a smell, such a taste, such a potency, such a ripening.”🔽“This one’s flower is blue, yellow, red, white, sweet-smelling, foul-smelling, or of mixed smell.”

original: sugandhaṃ, duggandhaṃ, madhuraṃ, tittakaṃ, ambilaṃ, kaṭukaṃ, kasāvaṃ. Kaṇṭako tikhiṇo,🔽atikhiṇo, ujuko, kuṭilo, tambo, nīlo, lohito, odāto”tiādinā dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati.
analyzed: sugandham duggandham madhuram tittakam ambilam kaṭukam kasāvam kaṇṭakaḥ tikhiṇaḥ  ati khiṇaḥ ujukaḥ kuṭilaḥ tambaḥ nīlaḥ lohitaḥ odātaḥ iti ādinā dhātu nānattam paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati
translated: “This one’s fruit is small, large, long, round, good-looking, ugly, ripe, unripe, sweet-smelling, foul-smelling, sweet, sour, bitter, sharp, or astringent.” “This one’s thorn is sharp, very sharp, straight, crooked, bent, blue, red, or white.”🔽Knowledge occurs in this way contingent upon the variety of elements.

original: Puthu nānāāyatanesūti “idaṃ cakkhāyatanaṃ nāma…pe… idaṃ dhammāyatanaṃ nāma. Tattha dasāyatanā kāmāvacarā, dve cātubhūmakā”ti evaṃ āyatananānattaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati.
analyzed: puthu nānā āyatanesu iti idam cakkhāyatanam nāma pe idam dhammāyatanam nāma tattha dasa āyatanā kāmāvacarā dve cātubhūmakā ati evam āyatana nānattam paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati
translated: In the various fields: knowledge occurs contingent upon the variety of bases in this way: “This is the eye base … this is the mental-data base. Herein, ten bases are of the sense sphere, and two are of three planes.”

original: Puthu nānāpaṭiccasamuppādesūti ajjhattabahiddhābhedato santānabhedato ca nānappabhedesu🔽paṭiccasamuppādaṅgesu. Avijjādiaṅgāni hi paccekaṃ paṭiccasamuppādasaññitāni. Tenāha
analyzed: puthu nānā paṭiccasamuppādesu iti ajjhatta bahiddhā bhedato santāna bhedato ca nānā ppabhedesu  paṭicca samuppāda aṅgesu avijjā ādi aṅgāni hi paccekam paṭicca samuppāda saññitāni tena āha
translated: In the various different dependent originations: in the various different kinds of dependent origination classed as internal and external and classed as of the past, etc.,

original: – saṅkhārapiṭake “dvādasa paccayā dvādasa paṭiccasamuppādā”ti.
analyzed: saṅkhāra piṭake dvādasa paccayāḥ dvādasa paṭiccasamuppādā ti
translated: For each of the factors of dependent origination, beginning with ignorance, is itself called dependent origination. Hence it is said in the Saṅkhyā Pitaka: “Twelve conditions, twelve dependent originations” .

original: Puthu nānāsuññatamanupalabbhesūti nānāsabhāvesu niccasārādivirahitesu suññasabhāvesu,
analyzed: puthu nānā suññatam anupalabbhesu ti nānā sabhāvesu nicca sāra ādi virahitesu suñña sabhāvesu
translated: In the various different kinds of voidness and non-apprehending: in the various different kinds of voidness, which is the state of being devoid of permanence, self, etc.,

original: tato eva itthipurisaattattaniyādivasena anupalabbhamānasabhāvesu. Ma-kāro hettha padasandhikaro.🔽Puthu nānāatthesūti atthapaṭisambhidāvisayesu paccayuppannādinānāatthesu. Dhammesūti🔽dhammapaṭisambhidāvisayesu paccayādinānādhammesu. Niruttīsūti tesaṃyeva atthadhammānaṃ
analyzed: tatas eva itthi purisa atta tta niya ādi vasena anupalabbha māna sabhāvesu makāraḥ ha ittha pada sandhi karaḥ  puthu nānā atthesu ti attha paṭisambhidā visayesu paccayuppanna ādi nānā atthesu dhammesu ti  dhamma paṭisambhidā visayesu paccaya ādi nānā dhammesu niruttīsu ti tesam yeva attha dhammānam
translated: and in the various different kinds of non-apprehending, which is the state of being unapprehendable as a woman, a man, a soul, etc., because of the absence of any such individual essence. The letter m is a connector of words here.🔽In the various different meanings: in the various different kinds of meaning, such as the derived meaning, etc., which are the province of the discernment of meaning. In the various different ideas: in the various different kinds of ideas, such as the condition, etc., which are the province of the discernment of ideas. In the various different ways of expression: in the various different ways of expression, which are called the words that define those same meanings and ideas.

original: niddhāraṇavacanasaṅkhātesu nānāniruttīsu. Puthu nānāpaṭibhānesūti atthapaṭisambhidādivisayesu
analyzed: niddhāraṇa vacana saṅkhātesu nānā niruttīsu puthu nānā paṭibhānesu uti attha paṭisambhidā ādi visayesu
translated: In the various different kinds of eloquence: in the various different kinds of eloquence, which are the province of the discernment of language.

original: imāni ñāṇāni idamatthajotakānīti tathā tathā paṭibhānato upatiṭṭhanato paṭibhānānīti
analyzed: imāni ñāṇāni idam attha jotakāni iti tathā tathā paṭibhānataḥ upatiṭṭhanataḥ paṭibhānāni iti
translated: These are the kinds of knowledge that illuminate that meaning. They are called “illuminations” because they stand by illuminating it in this way and that way.

original: laddhanāmesu nānāñāṇesu.🔽Puthu nānāsīlakkhandhesūtiādīsu sīlassa puthuttaṃ nānattañca vuttameva, itaresaṃ
analyzed: laddha nāmesu nānā ñāṇesu  puthu nānā sīla khandhesu uti ādīsu sīlassa puthuttam nānattam ca vuttam eva itaresam
translated: Among the various kinds of knowledge that have been given names.🔽As regards the various categories of virtue, etc., the distinction and variety of virtue have already been stated. But the others are quite clear since they can be understood in the way already stated.

original: pana vuttanayānusārena suviññeyyattā pākaṭameva. Yaṃ pana abhinnaṃ ekameva nibbānaṃ,
analyzed: pana vutta naya anusārena su viññeyya ttā pākaṭam eva yam pana abhinnam ekam eva nibbānam
translated: But Nibbāna, which is undifferentiated and one only,🔽can be taken as distinguished there by way of the access .

original: tattha upacāravasena puthuttaṃ gahetabbanti āha – “puthu nānājanasādhāraṇe dhamme
analyzed: tattha upacāra vasena puthuttam gahetabban ti āha puthu nānā jana sādhāraṇe dhamme
translated: That is why he said: “Having surmounted the various ideas that are shared by ordinary men” .

original: samatikkammā”ti. Tenassa madanimmadanādipariyāyena puthuttaṃ paridīpitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: samatikkamma ati tena assa mada nimmadana ādi pariyāyena puthuttam paridīpitam hoti
translated: Thus the distinction of Nibbāna is shown by the expression “surmounting” in the sense of “drunkenness-banishing” , etc.

original: Vipule attheti mahante atthe. Mahantapariyāyo hi vipulasaddo. Gambhīresūti sasādīhi
analyzed: vipule atthe ti mahante atthe mahanta pariyāyaḥ hi vipula saddaḥ gambhīresu iti
translated: In the great matter : in the great thing. For the word “great” is a synonym for “vast” .

original: viya mahāsamuddo anupacitañāṇasambhārehi alabbhaneyyappatiṭṭhesu khandhesu ñāṇaṃ
analyzed: viya mahā samuddaḥ anupacita ñāṇa sambhārehi a labbhaneyya patiṭṭhesu khandhesu ñāṇam
translated: In the profound : in the aggregates, which are hard to penetrate for those whose equipment of knowledge is insufficient, like the ocean for divers.

original: pavattatīti visayassa gambhīratāya ñāṇassa gambhīratā vibhāvitā.
analyzed: pavattati iti visayassa gambhīra tāya ñāṇassa gambhīra tā vibhāvitā
translated: The profundity of the knowledge is shown by the profundity of the object.

original: Tikkhavisadabhāvādiguṇehi asādhāraṇattā paresaṃ paññāya na sāmantā, atha kho suvidūravidūreti🔽asamantapaññā ākārassa rassattaṃ katvā. Keci “asamatthapaññā”ti paṭhanti, tesaṃ yathāvuttaguṇehi
analyzed: tikkha visada bhāva ādi guṇehi asādhāraṇa ttā paresam paññāya na sāmantā atha kho su vidūra vidūrā iti  asamanta paññā ākārassa rassa ttam katvā keci asamattha paññā iti paṭhanti tesam yathā vutta guṇehi
translated: It is not shared by others’ understanding, which is therefore not equal to it, but is far, far away from it, in the sense of being remote from it, because of such special qualities as keenness and lucidity.🔽Some read asamatthapaññā . The construction of that is: it has no equal in anyone else because of the special qualities stated.

original: aññehi asādhāraṇattā natthi etissā kāyaci samatthanti asamatthā paññāti yojanā. Atthavavatthānatoti🔽atthappabhedassa yāthāvato sanniṭṭhānato. Na añño koci sakkoti abhisambhavitunti
analyzed: aññehi asādhāraṇa ttā natthi etissā kāyaci samatthanti asamatthā paññā iti yojanā attha vavatthānato ti  attha ppabhedassa yāthāvataḥ sanniṭṭhānataḥ na añño koci sakkoti abhisambhavitunti
translated: As to analysis of meaning: as to the ascertainment of the meaning according to the analysis of its meaning.

original: ñāṇagatiyā sampāpuṇituṃ na añño kocipi sakkoti, tasmā ayaṃ suvidūravidūreti asamantapaññā.
analyzed: ñāṇa gatiyā sampāpuṇitum na aññaḥ koci pi sakkoti tasmai ayam su vidūra vidūra iti a samanta paññā
translated: No one else is able to penetrate it: no one else is able to reach it by the range of his knowledge.🔽Therefore it is far, far away from others, in the sense of being remote from it, and so it is not shared by others.

original: Idāni puggalantaravasena asamantapaññaṃ vibhāvetuṃ, “puthujjanakalyāṇakassā”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: idāni puggala antara vasena asamantapaññam vibhāvetum puthujjana kalyāṇakassa ati ādi āraddham
translated: Now, in order to demonstrate the “not shared” understanding by way of the individual, the text begins with “The good person among worldlings.”

original: “Paññāpabhedakusalo abhinnañāṇo adhigatappaṭisambhido catuvesārajjappatto dasabaladhārī
analyzed: paññā apabheda kusalaḥ abhinna ñāṇaḥ adhigata paṭisambhidaḥ catu vesārajja ppatto dasa bala dhārī
translated: The one who is skilled in the analysis of understanding, whose knowledge is unbroken, who has attained the discriminations, who has reached the four kinds of intrepidity, who bears the ten powers,

original: purisāsabho purisasīho purisanāgo purisājañño purisadhorayho anantañāṇo anantatejo
analyzed: purisa āsabhaḥ purisa sīhaḥ purisa nāgaḥ purisa ajañño purisa dhorayhaḥ ananta ñāṇaḥ ananta tejaḥ
translated: He is a bull, a lion, a chief, a leader, a hero, a man, a sage, a lord, one of infinite knowledge and insight,🔽of infinite power and glory, rich, wealthy, magnanimous, a guide, a trainer, a teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.🔽He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.

original: anantayaso aḍḍho mahaddhano balavā netā vinetā anunetā paññāpetā vinijjhāpetā pekkhatā
analyzed: ananta yasaḥ aḍḍhaḥ mahat dhanaḥ balavā netā vinetā anunetā paññāpetā vinijjhāpetā pekkhatā
translated: He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.🔽He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.

original: pasādetā. So hi bhagavā anuppannassa maggassa uppādetā, asañjātassa maggassa sañjanetā,
analyzed: pasādetā saḥ hi bhagavā anuppannassa maggassa uppādetā asañjātassa maggassa sañjanetā
translated: He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.🔽He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.

original: anakkhātassa maggassa akkhātā, maggaññū maggavidū maggakovido. Maggānugāmī ca pana🔽etarahi sāvakā viharanti pacchā samannāgatā.
analyzed: an akkhātassa maggassa akkhātā maggaññū magga vidū magga kovidaḥ magga anugāmī ca pana  etarahi sāvakāḥ viharanti pacchā samannāgatā
translated: He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.🔽He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.

original: “So hi bhagavā jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passati, cakkhubhūto ñāṇabhūto dhammabhūto brahmabhūto🔽vattā pavattā atthassa ninnetā amatassa dātā dhammassāmī tathāgato, natthi tassa
analyzed: saḥ hi bhagavā jānam jānāti passam passati cakkhu bhūtaḥ ñāṇa bhūtaḥ dhamma bhūtaḥ brahma bhūtaḥ  vattā pavattā atthassa ninnetā amatassa dātā dhamma sāmī tathāgato na atthi tassa
translated: He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.🔽He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.🔽He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.🔽He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.

original: bhagavato aññātaṃ adiṭṭhaṃ aviditaṃ asacchikataṃ aphassitaṃ paññāya. Atītaṃ anāgataṃ
analyzed: bhagavataḥ aññātam a diṭṭham a viditam a sacchikatam a phassitam paññāya atītam anāgatam
translated: He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, a lord.🔽He is the one who has awakened to the world, the unequalled leader of men to be tamed, the teacher of gods

original: paccuppannaṃ upādāya sabbe dhammā sabbākārena buddhassa bhagavato ñāṇamukhe āpāthaṃ
analyzed: paccuppannam upādāya sabbe dhammā sabba ākārena buddhassa bhagavataḥ ñāṇa mukhe āpātham
translated: and all ideas, in all modes, come within the range of the Blessed One’s cognizance.

original: āgacchanti, yaṃ kiñci neyyaṃ nāma atthi taṃ sabbaṃ jānitabbaṃ, attattho vā parattho
analyzed: āgacchanti yam kiñci neyyam nāma atthi tam sabbam jānitabbam atta tthaḥ vā para tthaḥ

original: vā ubhayattho vā diṭṭhadhammiko vā attho samparāyiko vā attho uttāno vā attho gambhīro🔽vā attho gūḷho vā attho paṭicchanno vā attho neyyo vā attho nīto vā attho anavajjo
analyzed: vā ubhayatthaḥ vā diṭṭhadhammikaḥ vā attho samparāyikaḥ vā attho uttānaḥ vā atthaḥ gambhīraḥ  vā atthaḥ gūḷhaḥ vā atthaḥ paṭicchannaḥ vā atthaḥ neyyaḥ vā atthaḥ nītaḥ vā atthaḥ anavajjaḥ
translated: whether it be a stated idea or an unstated idea, whether it be an idea that is hard to fathom or an idea that is easy to fathom,
